column2: LONDON, Ont., Feb. 23 (UP)--Research has shown that nuclear radiation can discolor certain materials, make certain plastics tougher, reduce others to powder, change some liquids into solids and take the stretch out of rubber.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) --The House passed today a bill to raise this year's cotton planting allotment by 3 per cent to alleviate "hardships" under Government -ordered acreage reductions.
ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, Feb. 22--This ship crossed the Antarctic Circle today bound for Buenos Aires after forty-one days of exploration around half Antarctica.
The New Lincoln School, an experimental laboratory in modern education in the grades and high school, has merged with the Boardman School, its nursery -kindergarten counterpart.
The former home office properties of the Mutual Life Insurance Company at 34 Nassau Street and adjoining land have been purchased by the Chase National Bank.
A jammed hearing room at the Department of Licenses resounded for two hours yesterday to emotional pleas for the restoration of "clean, wholesome, old-fashioned" burlesque.

Both the National Association of Wool Manufacturers and the Wool Bureau, Inc., said yesterday that the outlook for the wool textile industry this year was good despite the loss in wool consumption in 1954.
ALBANY, Feb. 23--Republican legislative leaders declared today that they would sponsor a bill for state regulation of union welfare funds.

TACKLING a giant like Scan O'Casey can be classisified as formidable indeed. Even veteran troupes such as the Abbey Theatre of O'Casey's native Ireland have been known on occasion to falter and fail in the face of the playwright's stringent requirements.

THE Whitney Museum will open to the public today retrospective exhibitions of work by Jack Levine and Hyman Bloom. They grew up together in Boston-Levine is just under 40 and Bloom but two years older.

The writer of the following letter is a former president of the National Republican Club and is consultant to the Republican National Committee. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In The Times of Feb. 12, in a dispatch from New Delhi, C. L. Sulzberger
ALBANY, Feb. 23--Two Republican legislators have proposed a law to permit dismissal of an employe who invokes the Fifth Amendment at a hearing involving loyalty.
The principal Government prosecutor in the trial of thirteen secondary Communist leaders yesterday disputed the recent testimony of Harvey Matusow, an admitted liar.
A legislative committee heard yesterday that the Civil Rights Congress had raised $300,000 for defense of the "Trenton Six," but had spent less than $6,000 for legal services.
The state law under which the Long Island Rail Road was dismissed from bankruptcy last August and embarked on a redevelopment program was held constitutional yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23--A roughand tumble city election campaign that promises to outdo anything similar in Chicago's turbulent political past got under way here this morning.
MADRID, Feb. 23--Generalissimo Francisco Franco announced today that he had decided to strengthen the political power of the Falange party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway urged Congress today to keep the Army strong and "suitably deployed" at danger spots throughout the world. His stand differed with President Eisenhower's basic military policy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Eisenhower was informed today that Speaker Sam Rayburn felt slighted because he did not get advance copies of special White House messages.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Prof. Nathaniel Peffer in his letter of Feb. 18 heaps scorn upon Chiang Kai-shek and the chances of the anti-Communist cause in China. He attributes a lack of "sanity" to anyone entertaining "the fantastic notion that some day soon Chiang Kai-shek would cross the waters of Formosa Strait with his few aging soldiers * * * and reinstate himself and his courtiers as the Government of China."
CHICAGO, Feb. 23--Evan Howell, chairman of the Illinois Toll Highway Commission, announced today plans for the sale of about $400,000,000 in bonds to a nation-wide syndicate on March 7.
The much discussed lightweight train moved back into the news yesterday. When it will move on the rails remains uncertain, however.
ALBANY, Feb. 23--The State Board of Equalization and Assessment announced today new equalization rates for 401 of the state's 549 villages.
TOKYO, Feb. 23 -- Japan's Communists have decided to support other Left-wing parties to try to halt a sweeping conservative victory in the national elections Sunday.

Dorothy Marion received recently the $500 Helen Dean Fish Award for 1954 for her "Little Angela and Her Puppy." The presentation is made each year by Lippincott to the author of a first book for juveniles. The award was established by the concern in memory of "one of the most distinguished and bestloved children's book editors in the country."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "Rent Control and Housing," published Feb. 11, aptly calls attention to the heart of the rent-control issue -- namely, that "some way must be found to stimulate housing construction that people can afford."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23-- With Harvey Matusow departed for New York, the Government's turnabout witnesses were relatively muted today. But the impact of their tales lingered on.

This country is now faced with the hard task of trying to plan defenses against the awful menace of hydrogen bombs. Much as we hope and pray that such weapons will never be used, the fact that they exist, and that their numbers in our hands and in possession of the Soviet Union are increasing, forces us to face the grim problem.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)-- A 76-year-old woman, who has served as a Weather Bureau observer longer than any other woman, was honored by the Department of Commerce today for her role in Hurricane Hazel last Oct. 14-15.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Isn't it possible that the terrific rise in juvenile delinquency in New York City can be definitely tied in with the lack of after-school activities? Many city children have no place to go for recreation after school hours.

Directors of the Niles-BementPond Company yesterday voted to oppose any effort by the PennTexas Corporation to acquire control. C. W. Deeds, chairman of Niles, said after the West Hartford, Conn., meeting that not one of the directors would serve on a board on which PennTexas was represented.

MIAMI, Feb. 23--This was a double feature day at the Hialeah race track. Because there were so many entrants, the Hialeah Juvenile Stakes for 2-yearolds was run in two divisions. Each winner hustled down the inside lane after having started from the No. 1 slot in the gates.
The American Broadcasting Company plans to reorganize certain segments of its television program schedule on Saturday and Sunday evenings.

The growing split between East and West poses a more serious problem to mankind than the present conflict over communism, Ahmed S. Bokhari, Under Secretary for Public Information of the United Nations, declared last night.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 23 --Secretary of State Dulles reaffirmed today the "solid intention" of the United States to aid any state covered by the Manila treaty that becomes the victim of aggression.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Eisenhower today sternly denounced as highly irresponsible Democratic proposals for a $20-a-person tax cut.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Feb. 23--Working under difficult conditions, hundreds of ship repairers are rapidly completing the job of installing twin sets of fin-like stabilizers on the Queen Elizabeth here.
Representatives of the New York City Anti-Crime Committee and the District Attorney's office conferred for two hours yesterday on the wiretapping plot.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety -four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 16.
HARTFORD, Feb. 23--The State Senate confirmed today the nomination of Mrs. Margaret Connors Driscoll of Bridgeport to be a judge of the Common Pleas Court.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, widow of the President, has been involved in two embarrassing situations this week. One case, in Armonk, N. Y., resulted from a charge that a speech she was to make would constitute illegal use of a school for political purposes.

LONDON, Feb. 23--The British Army is planning to introduce this year surface-to-surface guided missiles. The idea is to give its field commanders a weapon they can use "irrespective of weather conditions" or of local air supremacy.

PARIS, Feb. 23--Like Pierre Mendes-France, his friend and predecessor, Edgar Faure, the new French Premier, is brilliant and dynamic. These traits may enable him to overcome the shock and disappointment felt by a large part of this country when M. Mendes-France was forced out of office almost three weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--President Eisenhower said today that the United States opposed any ban on tests of hydrogen weapons except as part of a "decent and proper" disarmament plan. To make such a plan effective, he suggested, there must be ways and means of determining that each signatory power is acting in good faith.
BOSTON, Feb. 23--A major dog show honor that had escaped him two previous years fell to the California boxer, Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 23--Britain will not be involved in the defense of China's coastal islands, Sir Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today.
A new musical, "Silk Stockings," co-starring Hildegarde Neff and Don Ameche, opens at the Imperial Theatre tonight at 7:45.

Most of us made our first acquaintance with burlap in kindergarten when its facility for being easily raveled made it a wonderful material with which small hands could work creatively. Burlap presents many more opportunities for grown-up handicrafts than those first simple place mats we carried home proudly to mother.

Roger Payne, who was known as "the world's most educated hobo," died in Bellevue Hospital yesterday. He was about 80 years old. He was struck by an automobile on Feb. 16 at 10:50 P. M. as he was crossing Fourth Avenue at Twenty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The merger of the two great sections of organized labor which their leaders say is impending--despite John L. Lewis and Michael J. Quill--has alarmed disorganized masses of the people by evoking a vision of the largest and most effective pressure group in our history.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 19-- This year, for the first time, the public is getting virtually the full publishable story from officials about the Nevada atomic tests.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 23--The Gothic and colonial era of church architecture in this country is rapidly drawing to a close.

The State Commission on Educational Finances was not appointed until Aug. 9, 1954, and its first report is a pamphlet of only twentyfour pages which merely calls for a mark-time period. Quite correctly the chairman, Henry T. Heald, chancellor of New York University, and John F. Sly, director of staff for the commission, have refused to be hurried into new policy before basic spadework was done.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23--Long liquidation was in full swing again today on the Board of Trade here. While there was a little strength in wheat early, demand faded quickly and stop-loss selling became fairly general.

LONDON, Feb. 23--The stock markets rallied strongly today under the lead of British Government funds for the first time since their retreat began a week ago. With selling greatly reduced, prices responded vigorously to moderate re-expansion of buying. Most buying was said to be short covering or "bargain hunting."
ALBANY, Feb. 23--Governor Harriman withdrew today his request for a 50 per cent increase in motor fuel taxes on April 1.

Plenty of fish to fry--and also to bake or broil--will be available in the Lenten days ahead, according to John Von Glahn of the Fishery Council. Yesterday he listed the varieties expected to be most plentiful from now through Easter.

Because a justice became angry when he was told there was no more room for juvenile delinquents at Youth House, twenty-two Bronx youths were placed in temporary, detention under police guard last night.
Demand for more credit by rapidly growing industries and increased public use of banking services lie behind the growing number of bank mergers.

An Increase last week of 2,674,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was announced yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend they were 176,877,000 barrels, compared with 174,203,000 a week earlier and 175,497,000 a year ago.
CARE will discontinue its package relief service for individuals in eight countries of western Europe after April 8.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--Representative B. Carroll Reece charged today that the funds of great philanthropical and educational foundations had been used to introduce Fabian socialism into the United States. This, he said, was "subversive."
TRENTON, Feb. 23--The New Jersey Legislature was urged today to establish a state center for the hospitalization and rehabilitation of narcotic addicts.

THE principal ingredient of Vance Bourjaily's first novel, "The End of My Life," a story of the second World War, published in 1947, was an earnest and self-conscious, if somewhat clumsy, affirmation of negation.
Mayor Wagner named a sevenman committee yesterday to unriddle a seeming paradox in the city's school system.

The Singer Sewing Machine Company has a new junior-size machine and a new marketing plan. It is introducing a precision -designed miniature sewing machine for children, to be offered beth as a toy and as a primer for the neophyte.

THOSE who attended the recital of Benno Moiseiwitsch last night in Carnegie Hall heard great playing. It was great playing, in the frame and on the scale of grand art, whether or not the listener agreed with everything that Mr. Moiseiwitsch did, as this writer did not.
Lady Mary Greaves, 34-yearold daughter of Britain's Countess of Dysart, was found dead here yesterday morning from an apparent overdose of sleeping pills.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UP)-- Man-made fibers have caused a sharp downtrend in the use of wool for both men and women's clothing, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Market specialists yesterday attributed the decline in prices for United States Government bonds to the fact that the commercial banking system is exhausting its store of "secondary reserve" short-term Treasury obligations.

The twenty-one-story office building at 92 Liberty Street in lower Manhattan has been bought by a syndicate of investors headed by Daniel S. Levy. It is bounded by Liberty, Cedar and Temple Streets and Trinity Place and was sold in a deal negotiated by Aaron Gural of Harris, Newmark Co., brokers.

Led by Speaker Sam Rayburn, the Democrats of the House of Representatives seem ready to act on the belief that it's politically smart to offer to every man, woman and child in tha United States a $20 cut in his federal income tax bill.
The mysterious Eighth Moon of Jupiter, lost since 1941, has been located in its eccentric orbit through calculations of an electronic computer.

The chief of The New York Times United Nations bureau predicted yesterday that Communist China would be seated in the United Nations within a year "if they continue to play their cards as well as they have in the last twelve months."

TAIPEI, Feb. 23--The Nationalist press accused the United States here this week of shackling Nationalist military, naval and air power in attacks against the Chinese mainland. Although the United States Government has no outright authority to give orders to the Nationalist Government, it is understood here that sufficient pressure can be brought to bear whenever it is deemed necessary.

The executive board of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, voted unanimously yesterday to submit to the federation a protest circulated by members of the local against the forthcoming United States tour of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 23--A solution for the problem of overproduction of milk by New York State farmers was given today. It called for inefficient producers to quit their farms, find urban jobs, go to work on the St. Lawrence Seaway project or go on relief.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 23 -- Prince Wan Waithayakon, Foreign Minister of Thailand, proposed today that a combined mobile striking force be established to protect Southeast Asia.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 23 (AP)--The United States Olympic bobsled committee stood firm tonight on its choice of a team that includes Stanley Benham, despite a threat that the whole United States team would be barred from the 1956 games in Italy.

New York University and St. John's of Brooklyn, interborough rivals since 1907, will meet for the thirty-fifth time in Madison Square Garden tonight in the second game of a collegiate basketball double-header.
New vessels of new designs are sliding down the ways to handle the increasing variety of cargoes on the country's 28,996 miles of inland waterways.

The Republican leadership in the State Senate dishonors itself by its continued refusal to act on the designation of Dr. Isador Lubin as Industrial Commissioner. Dr. Lubin is a distinguished economist. On six separate occasions he has been confirmed by the United States Senate for important federal posts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23--Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield tonight described Rotary International as a "dynamic advocate of the free way of life and of the 'good partner' relationship among nations of the world."
Cottage cheese, high in nutrition and low in cost and calories, has a favored place in Lenten meals of the busy homemaker.

That Season Is Here At certain seasons the lady of the house begins to fidget and gets a faraway look in her eye. In late summer, for example, when it is time to think of getting children ready for another bout with the educational system.

The Toronto Maple Leafs muffled the New York Rangers effectively in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Coach Muzz Patrick's skaters, unable to do much against the Leafs' closeknit defense, bowed, 3 to 1.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 23 (AP)-- Hector Constance, a tough young sharpshooter from Trinidad, knocked Kid Gavilan off the comeback trail tonight with a unanimous decision over the former world welterweight champion from Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The Senate voted 62--24 today to give all members of Congress a 50 per cent increase in pay. Just a week ago the House of Representatives approved, 283--118, a 66 2/3 per cent rise.

The American paper industry was urged by one of its leading members yesterday to reverse its traditional protectionist-tariff stand in favor of supporting President Eisenhower's liberal trade program.
Renata Tebaldi, recovered from an indisposition that had kept her inactive for about a week, sang her first Maddalena in Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" last night at the Metropolitan Opera.

THE New York City Ballet presented last night its first premiere of the season at the City Center in the form of George Balanchine's "Roma." To come to the point at once, it was something of a disappointment.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Thursday, Feb. 24 -- Nationalist planes bombed Communist-held islands yesterday north and south of the menaced Nationalist garrison on Nanki Island.
Despite an increase in net sales, earnings of KimberlyClark Corporation and subsidiaries in the quarter ended on
One of sport's rarest events, a match for the world championship in court tennis, will open tomorrow at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
PARIS, Feb. 23--An unusual outpouring of sentiment in favor of Pierre Mendes-France has occurred since he was voted out of the premiership by the National Assembly.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23-- President Eisenhower would not be cut off abruptly today at the end of his news conference.
La Salle and Tom Gola combined to thwart Fordham's basketball hopes last night. Before a capacity gathering at the Fordham gymnasium in the Bronx, the Explorers won convincingly, 64 to 49.
AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 23-- The Amherst quintet avenged an early season loss by downing Wesleyan, 59--47, tonight.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 23--A rift in the Government coalition developed tonight on the eve of the final Bundestag debate on the Paris agreements.

Wall Street's investment mood was much the same yesterday as it had been the day before the holiday. For the second consecutive session railroads dominated the stock list on the up side while industrial issues moved irregularly lower.

St. John's, heavily favored to down New York University, drew away from the Violets in the second half and recorded a 66-50 victory last night. In the first game of the final Madison Square Garden college basketball double-header of the regular season, St. Francis of Brooklyn turned back Iona of New Rochelle, 65--61.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP)--Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today: HOGS Salable hogs, 9,000 head; trading fairly active, steady to 25 cents higher on butchers; mainly steady to strong; sows steady, instances 25 cents lower; most choice 190-240
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 24 (AP)-- An explosion at sea aboard their yacht brought a close brush with death today for Richard J. Reynolds, tobacco heir, his wife Muriel and the yacht's captain, Arthur Kyle.
KEELUNG, Formosa, Friday, Feb. 25--After repeated denials yesterday, the Chinese Nationalists disclosed this morning that the Nanki Island group had been abandoned.

Governor Harriman's withdrawal of his Feb. 1 budget-message request for a 50 per cent increase in motor fuel taxes is an unexpected development. An increase in the gasoline and Diesel fuel taxes bad been scheduled, by general agreement, to take effect Jan. 1, 1956, to underwrite debt service on a $750,000,000 bond issue highway building program, if the voters in November approve such borrowing.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 24--Contemporary, or modern design, made a clean sweep here tonight of the nine awards conferred annually by the Church Architectural Guild of America.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UP) --The Washington Redskins and Calgary Stampeders signed a "no raiding" agreement today that may mark the end of the war between the National and Canadian football leagues.

For a time it seemed that mankind stood in the shadow of a deadly peril which it would never be allowed fully to understand. The peril was first called the A-bomb and now, as we all know, goes under the more ominous name of the H-bomb. Complete secrecy was never possible.

General liquidation dropped rubber prices sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Trade and new speculator buying on a scale-down basis absorbed the offerings. Final quotations were 155 to 195 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower on 2,780 tons.

SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 24 (UP) --Louise Suggs fired a record 67 to lead the first round of the $5,000 Sarasota women's open golf tournament today shortly before ailing Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias announced she was withdrawing from further tournament play.

International Longshoremen's Association officials said last night after a district council meeting that no strike action was planned over the controversial hiring rules that are supposed to go into effect Tuesday.
After sixty-eight years of producing small vessels for defense, pleasure and transportation, the Morris Heights yard of the Consolidated Shipbuilding Corporation is going out of business.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) --The conviction of Jacob Freidus, New York businessman and promoter, on a charge of filing a false financial statement with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in 1950 was set aside today by the United States Court of Appeals.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--Senate and House of Representatives conferees agreed today on a 50 per cent or better increase in pay for all members of Congress and the Federal judiciary.
ALBANY, Feb. 24--The president of the State Tax Commission ordered a review of audit procedures today so that income tax dodgers could be brought to book.

ALBANY, Feb. 24--State authorities, concerned with the threat to the commerce of the Port of New York, held a fourhour conference here today with representatives of the independent International Longshoremen's Association and the Waterfront Commission.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 17-- For almost a year the Government of India has been host to about fifty almost-forgotten men of the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)--A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner ruled today that Eastern Air Lines no longer controlled Colonial Airlines. The decision removes one major stumbling block to a proposed merger of the two companies.

The industrial property at 950960 Franklin Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by the BurtonDixie Corporation to Morris J. Gollenbeck in a transaction negotiated by M. C. O'Brien, Inc. as broker. The property, on a plot 575 by 225 feet at the southwest corner of Montgomery Street, comprises loft buildings two to five stories in height with a total area of 120,000 square feet.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Stock prices fell sharply here today under the shock of a rise of one percentage point in the bank rate. But the announcement of the rise by the Bank of England brought also a strengthening of sterling in the foreign exchange market.
Nuclear energy will prove to be more usuable as a power source for raising the world's standard of living than as a weapon of war, a pioneer atomic scientist declared yesterday.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Feb. 24--Underground explorations for uranium began today at Camp Smith.

The country's newspapers started the year with a 7.3 per cent advance in linage in January over the 1954 volume. Linage reports for fifty-two cities, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures, came to 196,204,008 lines, against 182,932,199 lines for the 1954 month.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--The Administration is getting caught in a cross-fire on its QuemoyMatsu policy.
ALBANY, Feb. 24--A bipartisan proposal to authorize a $250,000,000 bond issue for State University construction has been submitted to the Legislature.
Great Britain yesterday took a long step toward straightening out her tangled currencies.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 24 (AP) --Iraq linked herself with the West tonight for defense against communism by signing a mutual defense pact with Turkey.

Hundreds of telephones are wiretapped legally in this city each year, whatever the number tapped illegally may be. And listening to other people's talk, by new electronic devices as well as wiretaps, seems to be getting scientifically easier.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the public cannot and the manufacturers will not stop the lethal horsepower race now being run by our automobile makers, I suggest that a federal automobile use-tax law be enacted under which the annual tax will be based on the brake horsepower of the car.
This is the first of two illustrated articles on the Paris spring collections, models of which will be available in stores here soon. Tomorrow's article will be on buying a dress in Paris.

LUXEMBOURG, Feb. 24--A recent speech by a French steel executive criticizing the European Coal and Steel Community is regarded here as a prelude to a prolonged contest over the issue of European union. This city is the capital of the community.

IN recognition of the twentyfifth anniversary of the Museum of Modern Art, fifteen paintings by French masters of the nineteenth century have been sent to that institution as a loan exhibition from the Louvre and the Museums of Albi and Lyons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--A recommendation that is reported to have the approval of the United States Commissioner of Education asserts that Federal money for school construction "is not necessary."
The sharp break in the London stock market had reprercussions n Wall Street yesterday. Bids for stocks were lowered and prices fell, but the session was a slowest and narrowest in three weeks.

THE world's largest collection of posters, some 3,000 items dating from 1832, is looking for a permanent home. Part of it is housed in a Dickensian apartment on the top floor at 40 Union Square and part in a Peekskill barn.
The proportion of the aged in the population is rising in Europe as well as in the United States.

MOSCOW, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Ministry of Electric Power Stations, now headed by ex-Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, came under fire in Pravda today. It was accused of inefficient methods and backward ideas.

MAINE'S Narraguagus will never rival Canada's Restigouche as a salmon river, but American anglers who want to do their salmon fishing at "home" will be glad to hear that several northern Maine rivers are continuing to show improvement.
ALBANY, Feb. 24--The Court of Appeals ruled in a five-to-two decision today that a city can turn parking meter funds over to a parking authority to help finance its operations.

THERE are easier ways or A making a living as a violin soloist than taking on the the kind of assignment Yehudi Menuhin attempted with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall last night. Mr. Menuhin could have played either of the two concertos he undertook and earned his evening's fee. The Bartok and Brahms concertos are both massive, challenging affairs, and a violinist who performs one has plenty to do.

LAST night's "Swan Lake" by the New York City Ballet at the City Center was just, about as lovely a performance as anybody has a right to ask for Diana Adams and Jacques D'Amboise are both new to the leading roles, this being only their second appearance in them, and both of them bring fresh qualities of enchantment to an old work.

IF John P. Marquand's novels were not so readable and popular his importance as one of the few major American novelists of his time might be more generally acknowledged. But readability and popularity arouse dark suspicions in some critical quarters, where it is much more fashionable for a writer not to say what he means and so enable a critic to display his brilliance by finding a meaning unnoticed by anyone else.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 24 -- South Africa needs more technical advice, sympathy and investment capital from the United States, Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom said today.

St. Francis and Cardinal Hayes won the semi-finals in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball championship yesterday at Madison Square Garden. The teams will meet for the title there Tuesday.

Eye-appeal of a garment is the most important factor in the sale of men's tailored clothing, according to Jerome I. Udell, chairman of the board of Max Udell Sons Co. For this reason, he said yesterday at the men's fabric clinic of the Textile Distributors Institute at the Plaza Hotel, wash-and-wear clothes have limited sales potential.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 24--The German Press Agency reported tonight that 15,000 to 25,000 persons had demonstrated in Munich against the Paris agreements to arm West Germany.The three-day debate on final ratification of the agreements was begun in the morning in the Bundestag, the lower house of Parliament.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the juvenile delinquency problem was serious, but that the city "certainly has not admitted defeat or is defeated in coping with the problem."
New issues of public utility, insurance and hotel securities totaling more than $53,000,000 will be offered to investors today.
PARIS, Feb. 24--Premier Edgar Faure faced today the problem of getting the Paris agreements voted on by Easter.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The State of Tennessee will take to a Federal Court its fight against the Dixon-Yates private power contract.

Another former Government attorney contradicted yesterday Harvey Matusow's present version of the truth. Matusow, former Communist, has said he testified falsely as a Government witness at the trial at which thirteen secondary Communist leaders were convicted.

Nocturne in the Market The head of the house lately paid a visit to a supermarket. This was partly as an investigator, and partly as supervisor. He long had felt that the spending dollar was something less than elastic, and instead of being composed of one hundred cents was made up of four disappearing quarters.
ALBANY, Feb. 24--More than three dozen speakers urged modernization of the state's marriage and divorce laws today. Their views were expressed at a hearing of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.

In his presentation of our position at the Bangkok conference Secretary Dulles rightly laid some emphasis upon a vital aspect of the problem. He reminded the other seven signatories of the Manila Pact that Southeast Asia was not the only area involved.

A kind of three-dimensional slide rule for bringing blueprints to life was demonstrated yesterday. Dean Faussett, who has won a reputation by painting murals and landscapes without the aid of a gadget, showed how it worked.

The lion and the lamb, the truckers and the railroads, will lie down together in a new and important way on March 3. The Pennsylvania Railroad on that date will start a solid train each way between New York and Chicago, each carrying "piggy back" a hundred trailers of highway common carriers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--In a burst of courtroom pyrotechnics, the Government's long and tangled case against Edward O. Lamb moved toward a conclusion today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Here is a further piece of testimony on the paper work at Washington, especially the billion letters, mentioned in your editorial.

EMPEROR JONES," the Eugene O'Neill play about the Pullman porter turned island dictator, finally had an American television showing on Wednesday evening on the Kraft Theatre (9 P. M. over the National Broadcasting Company network).

CHICAGO, Feb. 24--The leading problem facing American educators is to maintain quality of schooling in the face of expending enrollments, Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, United States Commissioner of Education, declared here today.

The Allstate Insurance Company contended yesterday that it was the nation's largest underwriter of automobile insurance. Its direct written automobile premiums for last year totaled $207,336,000, against $156,221,242 in 1953.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--Mrs. Ruth B. Shipley, head of the State Dpeartment's passport division for the last twenty-eight years, will retire April 30.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24-- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey urged today the replacement of Nationalist China with India as a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council.

As a result of the first decline in wholesale prices since the start of January, eggs are down 2 cents a dozen this week-end, according to the City Department of Markets. Large eggs are generally 67 cents a dozen and medium eggs 59.

A proposed resolution to compel teachers called for questioning about Communist affiliations to name their former party associates was debated vigorously before the Board of Education yesterday. After listening to arguments from a score of speakers, the board postponed action until March 17.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24-- United Artists announced today completion of a deal with Rita Hayworth as star and co-producer with her husband, Dick Haymes, of two pictures to be financed by the distributing company. Mr. Haymes will costar in one of the films, it was said. They will be made by a company to be known as Crystal Bay Productions.
A series of unusual conditions last year depressed earnings of the United Fruit Company to $31,459,780 from $44,556,264 earned the year before.
GENEVA, Feb. 24--Inflation has again become a threat to orderly economic progress in Western Europe.

Three novels with Africa as the background are scheduled for publication in the next two months. On March 22, Macmillan will issue a new novel by Robert W. Krepps entitled "Tell It On the Drums." Set in South Africa in 1883, the story is about the theft of a fortune in diamonds.

Sandy Saddler will defend his world featherweight championship tonight against Teddy (Red Top) Davis. They will meet over the fifteen-round route at Madison Square Garden before an anticipated 7,500 spectators.
Mayor Wagner hopes to visit Israel this summer. If plans now being considered develop, he may extend his trip to include Italy and Ireland.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24--The grain markets steadied today as a lull appeared in the selling pressure of recent sessions.
Moderation characterizes Mainbocher's designs.
SEDALIA, Mo., Feb. 24 (UP)-- The bodies of nine Air Force men, including a Mount Vernon, N. Y., lieutenant, were recovered today from the scattered wreckage of a four-engined tanker plane.
The Washington Toll Bridge Authority sold $10,000,000 of serial and term bonds yesterday for refinancing outstanding obligations of the Washington State Ferry System.
The first section of the Queens Midtown Expressway will open without fanfare at noon today.
The theatre benefit committee of the Jacob A. Riis Settlement House has completed plans for the benefit performance of "Plain and Fancy" on March 9 at the Winter Garden.

GLUCK'S "Orfeo ed Euridice" was revived last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association with striking success. The performance, which had stylistic defects in the musical interpretation, nevertheless affected the audience strongly. In fact, we had not seen a Metropolitan audience respond so warmly to a Gluck masterpiece before.
An unidentified group seeks to win control of W. J. Sloane, 112-year-old furniture and home furnishings chain.

James J. Moran wag indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury on an income tax evasion charge. He was accused of cheating the Government out of $131,307 in additional taxes for a three-year period.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 24--Mason Sears, United States delegate, indicated today that his views and Washington policy on colonialism did not always coincide.
Don Cockell of England agreed to terms yesterday for a title match with Rocky Marciano, the world heavyweight champion. The contest probably will be held in San Francisco's Kezar Stadium on May 19.
LONDON, Feb. 24--The Government took stern measures today to check an inflationary trend and to strengthen the pound sterling.
LONDON, Feb. 24--Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. called on the Soviet Union today to pledge fissionable material to the United Nations as a "concrete step which they can well afford to take."

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 24 --The Manila treaty powers set up today a military staff group and a committee to deal with problems of the alliance. Thus the work of the first meeting of the alliance's council was virtually completed.

The New York Trap Rock Corporation will make donations of $6,250 this year to improve public education in the six Hudson River communities where it operates plants. A spokesman for the corporation said yesterday the company had offered about 10 per cent of its local tax bills to boards of education in Clarkstown, Haverstraw, Tompkins Cove, Wappinger's Falls, Verplanck and Newburgh. Haverstraw, Tompkins Cove and Verplanck have already accepted.

MIAMI, Feb. 24 (AP)--Winning Stride, a candidate for the $25,000 added Black Helen Handicap on March 3, furnished a mild surprise as she defeated eight other crack sprinters in the $5,000 Delray Purse at Hialeah Park today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24-- House Speaker Sam Rayburn of Texas is going to have his own special advance copy of all Presidential messages to Congress.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 24--American investors for the last thirty years have taken more money out of Latin America than they have put into it. The rate of return on investments south of the border also has been rising steadily.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24-- There is a theatre seat for every forty-two persons on the globe, the Commerce Department reported today.
The presentation of the annual Antoinette Perry Awards, recognized on Broadway as the equivalent of Hollywood's Oscars, will take place Sunday night, March 27, at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel.
The eighteenth century mingles pleasantly with later times at the eleventh animal Greenwich House Antiques Show.
New Yorkers were called upon last night by Police Commissioner Francis W. H Adams to have "a greater understanding and forebearance" for their poicemen.
Ed O'Connor scored 23 points to lead Manhattan College's basketball team to a 98-77 triumph over Brooklyn College in Roosevelt Hall, Brooklyn, last night.

An upper Manhattan property passed to new control with the sale of the five-story apartment house on plot 100 by 155 feet at 25 to 31 Post Avenue in the Inwood section by the Sar Realty Company. The building contains forty-eight apartments and was bought by the Henkind-Walsey Company, a syndicate of realty investors, for cash over mortgages amounting to $135,000.
COLON, Panama, Feb. 24-- United States libraries and exchange programs abroad are the "backbone of our propaganda program" and should be increased, Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today.
LONDON, Feb. 24--Britain will spend more in the coming year than in the preceding year to build up her strategic bombing forces and to provide a world net of bases to accommodate them.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Armistice violations by the Communists in North Korea were discussed here today at a meeting of the sixteen United Nations members that took part in the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24-- Party lines in the tax fight were tightened on both sides of the Capitol today. The House of Representatives moved toward a showdown on an income tax cut proposed by the Democrats.
MOSCOW, Feb. 24--Moscow's chief of police, Gen. Georgi V. Sokolovsky, a candidate for election to the Moscow City Council, addressed the voters of the 448th election district this evening.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday were 655,035 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)-- A "National Conference on Juvenile Delinquency" was created today.
A match to establish a new world open champion in court tennis will start at 1:30 o'clock today at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

HAVANA, Feb. 24--Gen. Fulgencio Batista was sworn in as constitutional President today. Cuba's strong man during the Nineteen Thirties and President from 1940 to 1944, who seized control of the Government in March, 1952, in a military coup, was elected Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Successful production of paper from synthetic fibers was disclosed yesterday.

This is the time of year when ski enthusiasts drag out dusty maps and begin thinking about trips deep into New England or to Canada's Laurentians. Snow often is scarce in late February at the closer ski areas. As a consequence, longer junkets provide the only solution.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--The Senate Judiciary Committee heard nine witnesses today at a closed hearing on the nomination of Judge John Marshall Harton to be an associate justice of the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--The largest annual population increase in United States history --2,823,000--was reported today by the Census Bureau. The old mark was 2,718,000 for 1951.
WE can all afford to relax now. Everything about "Silk Stockings," which opened at the Imperial last evening, represents the best goods in the American musical comedy emporium.

AS a pre-requisite for a trip to Florida's spring training camps, it's just as important as packing a suitcase. The tourist first has to saturate himself with the statistical background information to be found in the American League's press brochure, the Red Book, along with the companion volume for the National League, the Green Book.
The "Norby" television show, currently a color film presentation, will become a live production in black and white for an interim period.

HOUSTON, Feb. 24. (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret, a colorful Houston native who normally runs into trouble while playing before his home-town fans, carded a six-under-par 66 today to gain the first-round lead in the $30,000 Houston open golf tournament.
The Transit Authority has studied-and rejected-the use of atomic energy to power the subway system.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--The Transport Workers Union fought a lone and losing battle against labor unity today.

A crucial debate has begun in Bonn which could affect the value of the Paris pacts and the whole future course of Germany. The Bundestag, or lower house of the Bonn Parliament, is now considering final ratification of the complex of treaties, agreements and protocols designed to make a rearmed Germany an integral part of both the Western defense system and of a new and more closely united Europe.
ALBANY, Feb. 24--Frank C. Moore, former Lieutenant Governor, today attributed the inability of some states to finance school construction needs to inadequate and unrealistic tax assessment policies.

State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits called for legislation against prejudice, bigotry and intolerance yesterday. He specified immigration, housing and hate literature as three major areas for action.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 24 --State intervention appeared tonight to have won a new lease on life for three small millinery factories here.

The Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday that, as of Jan. 1, the world's shipyards were building or had on order 1,347 ships of 11,249,398 gross tons. The total compares with 1,423 vessels of 13,052,574 tons listed a year earlier and 1,269 ships of 10,932,313 tons reported last Oct. 1.
MONTREAL, Feb. 24 (UP)-- The Montreal Canadiens and the Toronto Maple Leafs played a 1-1 tie tonight in a National Hockey League game before 14,668 fans at the Forum.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks rose $16,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. The increase, third in a row, was contrary to the usual seasonal decline expected at this time.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with particular interest the editorial appearing in your issue of Feb. 12 entitled "Rubbish and Fires," as well as the letter from Bernice Rogers, Deputy Commissioner of Housing and Building.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--A challenge to free men to help the unfortunate and disprove Communist lies was issued today by President Eisenhower.
Cotton trading was quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices moved 4 points lower to 1 point higher than on Wednesday.
Three alleged Communistfront organizations were charged yesterday with deception in the collection and spending of $3,500,000 in the last dozen years.

The number of older people in our midst and the proportion of the population they represent have grown with such sensational rapidity in the last decade that a social crisis of extreme urgency has now developed, with far too little action being taken to cope with it.
An exciting collection of bridal attire is on view at Saka Fifth Avenue.

NYACK, N. Y., Feb. 24--Six officers of the New York Central Railroad got a rough ride tonight over the system's seventy - year - old West Shore line. Seated on the auditorium platform of Nyack High School, they took their bumps from 600 Rockland County residents, who are aroused over the Central's decision to discontinue passenger service on the West Shore on June 30.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $424,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 24, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Spoke at Masonic breakfast. Met with members of the National Security Council. THE SENATE In recess.
The champions of Delaware River water and proponents of the Hudson River as a future source of the city's supply met face to face yesterday before the Board of Estimate.

HONG KONG, Feb. 24--The People's Daily, the Chinese Communist party organ, denounced today as a "slander" the recent statement by Thai Premier Pibul Songgram portraying Red China's "Thai autonomous area" as a threat to Thailand.

Three and a half months after President Eisenhower announced the nomination of John Marshall Harlan of New York to the Supreme Court the Senate Judiciary Committee has got around to holding hearings on the appointment. The delay is particularly inexcusable both because of the flimsy grounds on which the objections to Judge Harlan rest and because the work of the nation's highest tribunal has been materially held up pending his confirmation.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 24 --Governor Harriman today demanded removal of "outdated, burdensome regulations" on the sale of milk.

The outstanding feature of last night's concert of contemporary music at Carnegie Recital Hall was the first performance here of Three Pieces for Viola and Piano by Francis Buebendorf. Mr. Buebendorf, a product of the Juilliard School, is conductor of the orchestra and opera school at the Kansas City Conservatory of Music.

The outstanding feature of last night's concert of contemporary music at Carnegie Recital Hall was the first performance here of Three Pieces for Viola and Piano by Francis Buebendorf. Mr. Buebendorf, a product of the Juilliard School, is conductor of the orchestra and opera school at the Kansas City Conservatory of Music.

District Attorney Daniel V. Sullivan of the Bronx, members of his staff and Bronx County grand jurors made an annual inspection tour of the Rikers Island penitentiary yesterday. During the tour none of the officials or jurors were informed that an inmate had been stabbed seriously two hours before they arrived.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--The Federal Court of Appeals set aside today a regulation of the Federal Communications Commission limiting the ownership of television stations.

La Salle College of Philadelphia, the titleholder, and Memphis State yesterday accepted bids to play in the forthcoming National Collegiate basketball championship competition. At the same time the University of Connecticut of Storrs and Lafayette College of Eastern, Pa., were named for the National Invitation Tournament.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--One explanation offered for the decision of the Democratic House leaders to legislate at this time a general tax reduction to take effect next year is that the President forecast it in his message on the State of the Union (Jan. 6).
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Work is piling up at the National Labor Relations Board. The machinery is slowing down.
The congregation of the Broadway Congregational Church will commemorate next month the fiftieth anniversary of the opening of its French Gothic edifice at Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.
Extensive public hearings on a permanent code of labor relations for the city and its employes will begin next month, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The United States and the Philippines hope to set an example for the Chinese Communists by the voluntary return next week of seven castaway fishermen from Hainan Island.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 20--In the view of Allied observers here, vulnerability is a major reason why Denmark is "the least enthusiastic member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization."
ALBANY, Feb. 25--The Republican legislative leaders named six lawmakers today to the special committee to investigate wiretapping.
Two members of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra came to the defense of their conductor and their business manager yesterday against charges of proNazi activities and sentiments.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 --Walt Disney has re-edited three of his "Davy Crockett" television shows into a featurelength picture to be put into theatrical distribution in June.
The Radio Corporation of America last year transacted the largest volume of business in its thirty-five-year history while earnings rose 15.7 per cent over 1953.
TRENTON, Feb. 25 -- The Cape May County grand jury charged today that 3,800, or 14 per cent, of the registered voters in the county lacked the qualifications necessary to vote.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 25-- Dulles likes to compare our Asian security arrangements with the palm and fingers of a hand. The United States is militarily muscled each geographical finger: South Korea, Japan, Formosa and the SEATO area.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 25 --The Foreign Ministers of the Manila treaty powers voted unanimously today to send cordial greetings "to the other free countries" that will attend the forthcoming conference of African and Asian nations.
LONDON, Feb. 25--The securities market rebounded today, recovering part of the heavy losses that followed the bank rate rise yesterday.
The danger of a port-wide dock strike was lifted yesterday by an understanding between the Waterfront Commission and the International Longshoremen's Association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The Government today relinquished 8,000 tons of copper to ease a shortage of the metal for civilian products.
Deep beneath the marshy tidelands on which the Czars built their eighteenth and nineteenth century mansions in St. Petersburg, a series of twentieth century underground palaces is nearing completion.

Because a Bird Sang Because a bird sang the walk to the station on a gray February morning seemed less dreary and much shorter than usual. Because a bird sang the station platform damp and the iron, railings dripping cold drops of water seemed a little less bleak.
Stock prices jogged slowly lower for most of the session yesterday, and then recovered most of their losses on the tax bill voting in the House of Representatives.
LET no one complain again, not this season, anyway, that the master playwrights are being permitted to stand on the bookshelves gathering dust. All over the town they are being taken down and aired.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--Robert Tripp Ross, of Jackson Heights, Queens, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be Assistant Secretary of Defense for Legislative and Public Affairs.

Among the many mouthfuls uttered by that old (106-43 B. C.) Roman, Marcus T. Cicero, was this one: "As I approve of a youth that has something of the old man in him so I am no less pleased with an old man that has something of the youth."
CHICAGO, Feb. 25--Prominent educators took sharp issue today with a Presidential subcommittee's report that Federal aid for school construction was not necessary.
OTTAWA, Feb. 25--The Canadian Government has received authority for rigorous control over the export of water power south of the border.
ROME, Feb. 25--The fate of Premier Mario Scelba's Government trembled in the balance tonight. A quarrel between the Liberals and right-wing Socialists about land tenure contracts was the cause.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25-- The president of United Air Lines pointed today to 1955 as the year of decision for American aviation on the question of Jet airliners.

Another chapter in the eternal quest for a peace that would beat swords into plowshares began in London yesterday. Representatives of the United States, Britain, France and Canada met at a conference table with representatives of Soviet Russia to resume the disarmament talks that ended in a stalemate last June.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 25--A sharply accelerated effort to enable the United Jewish Appeal to meet urgent needs throughout the world this year, particularly in Israel, was called for here today.

There is an old Italian saying to the effect that rice is born in water and must die in wine. "Il riso nasce nell'acqua, e deve morire nel vino," is the way it goes. The same thing might be said very properly of fish, which, likewise born in water, is all the better if a glass of wine is savored with it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) --The Senate Labor Committee today approved two of President Eisenhower's top labor post nominees.
The city's oldest and most unusual bridge is showing its age.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 25--It is considered here that the prospect for the return of American fliers imprisoned in Communist China is not hopeless.
Commodity price changes were mixed yesterday on the New York exchanges.
A "floating fire force" will begin operating in the city in April.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 25 (Reuters)--Following are the texts of the final communique issued today by the Southeast Asian treaty conference and of a speech by Secretary of State Dulles at the final session: The Communique The Foreign Ministers of Australia, New Zealand, Pakistan, the Philippines, Thailand, the United Kingdom, and the United States and a representative of France have completed the first meeting of the Council established by the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty.

Mrs. Ruth B. Shipley has certainly not been quite the absolute monarch as head of the State Department's passport division that she sometimes seemed to people who wanted passports and couldn't get them. It is not likely that anyone who a Secretary of State or a President thought should be allowed to leave the country or enter the country was ever prevented from doing so by Mrs. Shipley's mandate.

OTTAWA, Feb. 25--Canadians here and across the country anxiously followed today the intensive efforts to rescue seven persons whose plane was forced down in the barren lands of the Canadian North Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The Consumer Price Index for the United States was unchanged from mid-December to mid-January.
Proposed legislation on comic books is aimed at making them "funny again" and not at destroying an industry or freedom of the press, a State Assemblyman said here yesterday.
Almost 13,000 gift retailers from all over the country yesterday ended five days of brisk ordering to cover Easter, Mothers Day and June bride needs.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru called today for the evacuation of Quemoy and Matsu Islands, held by the Chinese Nationalists.
A large subscription has been reported for the final concert in the series known as the Five Enchanted Musical Evenings to be held on the night of March 4 at Carnegie Hall.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP)--Washington swimmers won two of three first places tonight in tryouts for the United States women's swimming team that will compete in the Pan-American games.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP)--Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today: HOGS Salable hogs, 7,500 head: market uneven, fairly active, strong to mostly 25 cents higher on butchers; close slow; sows around steady: most choice 190-230 pounds butchers,

IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., Feb. 25--Rudy Maki, the 19-year-old daredevil from Ishpeming, Mich., who created a stir by winning the national jumping crown early this month, accounted for an even bigger surprise today as the trials for the United States Olympic ski team began.
A decrease in the quality and quantity of high school science teachers over the country was described yesterday as a principal reason for the shortage of scientists and engineers.

Besides changing her mind, it seems from our Western point of view, an undeniable prerogative of a woman to change her clothes and perhaps her nationality, too. Miss Miroslava Nachodska, a Czech figureskater, was sent to Vienna to compete last week in an international meet.
"A CHOIR OF STARLINGS," a charming work by Leo Smit for four solo voices and chamber orchestra, had its first performance last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with the composer conducting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25-- Judge John Marshall Harlan assured the Senate Judiciary Committee today that he regarded the Constitution as supreme. He said he would not surrender the sovereignty of the United States to any world government.

Everyone connected with the real estate and building industry should oppose any efforts to eliminate or hamper the operations of the Federal Housing Administration in the home loan field, according to George C. Johnson, president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25 (AP)--Bill Yorzyk of the New Haven Swim Club led the qualifiers tonight for the Pan-American 1,500-meter swim at Yale's Payne Whitney Pool.

TROY, N. Y,. Feb. 25 (AP)--Sec Desecco, a sophomore from Schenectady, netted 21 points tonight to set a Rensselaer Polytechnic season basketball scoring record as R. P. I. beat Brooklyn Polytechnic, 68--57.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP) --Joyce Ziske, a newcomer to the pro ranks, and the seasoned Betty Jameson tied for the halfway lead in the $5,000 Sarasota women's open golf tournament today with 141.

The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker: A kit to make a mosaic-top table is available for $8.95 at Bon Bazar, 228 West Fourth Street. The store's officials say it is possible to put the table together in ten minutes and that when it is completely dry it is strong enough to stand on.

[678554] WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The Senate today rejected and the House accepted yesterday's conference agreement on Congressional pay increases. The legislation now goes back to conference. By a vote of 62--7, the Senate demanded elimination of an item allowing each member reimbursement up to $1,250 a year for office expenses beyond the regular appropriated allotment.
Capt. George Wilund set two scoring records as he tallied 38 points to lead Queens to a 103-83 basketball triumph over the Montclair Teachers at Flushing, Queens, last night.
LONDON, Feb. 25--The Government's steps to improve Britain's economic position were generally welcomed today as timely and courageous.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25 (AP)--A compromise plan to end the twenty-one-year bankruptcy of the Missouri Pacific Railroad System was approved by Federal District Judge George H. Moore today as "fair and equitable."

LONDON, Feb. 25--The British Overseas Airways Corporation has Government permission to buy ten of the latest United States airliners. But the company must sell them again when equivalent British aircraft are ready, Parliament was told today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 25 (AP)--Two sophomores, Jim Francis and Ron Judson, scored 21 and 19 points, respectively, tonight to lead Dartmouth to a 77-54 Ivy Basketball League victory over Harvard.
The free world can be saved only by a rediscovery of its spiritual resources. Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl declared here last night.
Fred H. Hill, real estate investor and developer, is continuing his activity on the East Side, where he has contracted to purchase six properties.
Present immigration policies, especially as they affect foreign scholars and scientists, were deplored yesterday at a conference called to promote exchanges of people between this and other nations.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 25 --Public opinion seems to have killed in its early stages something resembling a movement in Colombia like Peronism in Argentina.
TRENTON, Feb. 25 -- New Jersey milk consumers may look forward to a continuation of lower retail prices unless the controls removed last week are restored.
ALBANY, Feb. 25--The abolition of a $2,000,000 tax on the state's bus industry was recommended today by a special transit study committee.

POSSIBLY the rarest commodity in the operatic market is a first-rate Wagnerian tenor. The places you would expect to find him would be Germany and Austria, but the pickings there have been slim for a good many years.

The M. A. Hanna Company and its subsidiaries, producers of coal and iron ore, reported yesterday a net profit of $12,824,758 for last year, equal to $4.03 a common share. This compares with $13,554,287, or $4.27 a share, for 1953.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The Senate voted today to increase the authority of the Federal Housing Administration to insure mortgages by $1,500,000,000.
FORT DIX, N. J., Feb. 25-- An investigation is being conducted into charges of medical laxity here made by a Queens soldier before he died of fulminating meningitis Tuesday.
The volume of new corporate and municipal flotations is increasing.

The return of the lace collar and the continuing popularity of the petticoat may mean a re-education in old-fashioned starching.
PARIS, Feb. 25--Premier Edgar Faure and Foreign Minister Antoine Pinay decided today to give priority to ratification of the Paris agreements.

CANTON, N. Y., Feb. 25--St. Lawrence skiers won the individual and team, honors in the slalom and cross-country events to take a commanding lead in their annual Winter Carnival ski meet at near-by South Colton today.
The problem of where to detain ten of twenty-two youths arrested with zipguns late Wednesday night in the Riverdale section of the Bronx to prevent a gang fight was solved yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Warriors outlasted the New York Knickerbockers through three overtime periods to win, 113--111, before 3,235 fans at Convention Hall tonight.

"Power and Influence," the autobiography of Lord Beveridge, educator, economist and politician, will be published Monday by the Beechhurst Press. Lord Beveridge, sponsor of the report that advanced the cause of social insurance, sheds new light on many episodes of recent history.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Feb. 25-- A. city policeman was posted near the West Island estate of Junius S. Morgan today to prevent the Morgans from fencing off a controversial dead-end road leading to Long Island Sound.
Retail sales of automobiles continue to set records.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 25 --Discussions here between John Foster Dulles and Sir Anthony Eden on the Formosa issue are understood to have failed to bring full agreement.

A new estimate by Columbia University scientists places the time of the creation at 4,800,000,000 years ago, plus or minus 200,000,000 years.

It was a rather strange program with which Harriet Serr occupied herself last night in Carnegie Hall. Only two of the pieces were "pianistic," in the standard sense of the word. These were Chopin's C minor Nocturne and Abram Chasins' "Narrative."

Sandy Saddler breezed through in the defense of his featherweight championship of the world at Madison Square Garden last night. Opposing Teddy (Red Top) Davis, 31-year-old campaigner from Hartford, Conn., Saddler gained the unanimous decision, to the satisfaction of the crowd of 5,272 on hand.

Andy Carey, the 23-year-old third baseman of the Yankees, has agreed to terms. From St. Petersburg, Fla., yesterday George M. Weiss, the general manager of the Bombers, sent word that he and Carey had talked over the telephone.
MIAMI, Feb. 25--If the pricemakers have guessed correctly what the customers will do, there will be an odds-on favorite tomorrow in the $100,000 added Flamingo Stakes for 3-year-olds.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 25--The sixty-three-year-old unfinished New York Cathedral (St. John The Divine) is well on its way toward becoming one of the major architectural challenges of modern times.

The February business review of the Bank of Montreal sees the vastest potential for future Canadian development in the Northwest Territories and the Yukon. Up there, it says, lies 40 per cent of the land fresh water area of Canada. Yet only 25,100 people live there--only one-half of one per cent of the Commonwealth's population.
The writer of the following letter, author and foreign correspondent, was former associate editor of The Saturday Evening Post. His books include "Red Star Over China."

Fifty-six thousand passengers on trains of the New York, New Haven and Hartford and the New York Central railroads were delayed during the morning rush yesterday. Most of those affected were commuters bound for Grand Central Terminal from their homes in Connecticut and in Westchester County.

A small cross-section of what visitors may expect to find at the opening, on March 7, of New York's largest and liveliest antiques fair was shown yesterday at a preview of choice samples at Julius Carlebach, 937 Third Avenue.
Prices on the cotton futures market held within a narrow range of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Old March rose 7 points. Other deliveries were 2 points up to 2 points off.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The Treasury today cleared East German potash shippers of charges that they injured the domestic market by selling below cost. The agency added, however, that it would keep a close eye on future transactions.
A $200,000 suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court against "Plain and Fancy," the musical comedy at the Mark Hellinger Theatre.

THE Conservation Department's report on the special "two-deer" season in portions of the Adirondack wilderness indicates that while the season was hardly an "unqualified success" from a conservation viewpoint, it was interesting and instructive.

Cook County, Ill. An issue of $970,000 of bonds of School District No. 102, Cook County, Ill., was sold yesterday to a syndicate headed by Northern Trust Company at a bid of 100.017 for bonds bearing interest of 2 per cent, 2 1/2 per cent and 2 3/4 per cent, an interest cost of 2.645 per cent.
HOUSTON, Feb. 25 (AP)--Wesley Ellis, a 23-year-old pro making his first winter golf tour, posted his second 68 today to take the 36-hole lead in the $30,000 Houston open.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--A combat uniform with a built-in tourniquet for each arm and leg was patented this week by an Ohioan.

A wide-open fight for team honors shapes up among Yale's defenders, Manhattan, Boston University, Penn State and Villanova in tonight's thirty-fourth annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. indoor track and field championships.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Saturday, Feb. 26--The framework of a Middle East regional defense system is apparent in the Turkish-Iraqi treaty signed in Baghdad Thursday and released for publication this morning.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 25 (AP) --An agreement for the purchase of Frontier Industries, Inc., of Buffalo by the Houdaille-Hershey Corporation of Buffalo and the election of Frontier's president, Ralph F. Peo, as president of Houdaille - Hershey was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Charles E. Wilson favored foreign bidders slightly today in the Defense Department's application of a Presidential order on the "Buy American" Act.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP) --Fifteen horses were named today for the $140,300 Santa Anita Handicap tomorrow, and the eighteenth running of the winter classic once again had the experts predicting a wide open race.
James Dear of England and Albert (Jack) Johnson of New York divided the first four sets of their match for the world open court tennis championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Commissioner Cavanagh's boldness and wisdom in vitalizing the prevention work of the Fire Department have already brought dramatic results, strikingly documented in the report of his first year's activity in office.
ALBANY, Feb. 25--Governor Harriman urged today that communities prepare new higher education facilities for the flood of pupils now in elementary and high schools.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The Democrats' $20-per-person income tax cut squeaked through the House today with a five-vote margin.
DORTMUND, Germany, Feb. 25 (UP)--Canada's Bill Warwick scored six goals today in a firstround match of the world amateur hockey championship to help the Penticton team rout the United States, 12-1.
Food shortages in state stores in Moscow have pushed prices in farmers' markets there up to double or triple the Governmentset levels.
New York has the largest municipal Fire Department in the world, but it is undermanned and much of its equipment is old and in frequent need of repair.
THANKS to an intelligent job of casting and an ingeniously designed physical production, the Equity Community Theatre's revival of "Men in White" does very well by Sidney Kingsley.
Mayor Wagner admitted last night that higher city taxes on general and financial business might soon shift from a "perhaps" to a "must" status in his 1955-56 fiscal program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The index of primary market prices was unchanged over the week ended Tuesday at 110.3 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was held at this level for three weeks now.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Labor's two merging federations agreed today on a statement of international labor policy.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 25 --The eight Manila pact powers ended a three-day meeting here today with a final, decision on Texts of the communique and Dulles speech, Page 2. organization and policy. A. communique setting forth aims and programs was issued.
A witness in Federal Court said yesterday that the Board of Higher Education rejected Harvey Matusow as a consultant in a Communist investigation after he had demanded a fee of $50 a day.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25--Another wave of long liquidation hit Board of Trade grain and soybean futures today. But there was considerable profit taking by shorts, with some commission absorption on the declines in all pits, which tended to steady the market.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The House Education and Labor Committee today moved to prevent Federal closing of schools on military posts. The move was made under a law involving Federal areas.

Rocky Marciano signed yesterday to defend his heavyweight championship of the world against Don Cockell of London. Marciano and his challenger, accompanied by their managers, entered into a formal agreement at the offices of the International Boxing Club.
PATUXENT NAVAL AIR STATION, Md., Feb. 25 (AP)-- The world's fastest waterbased air transport, the Convair R3Y-1 Tradewind, flew nonstop across the United States yesterday in six hours.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 25, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Had breakfast with Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower; Nelson A. Rockefeller, Arthur S. Flemming, Defense Mobilizer, and Rowland R. Hughes, Budget Director.

When Vice President Nixon reached Nicaragua on Feb. 19 on his goodwill tour of Central America President Anastasio Somoza surprised him by exhibiting an array of lethal weapons said to have been used in an attempt to assassinate Senor Somoza last April.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 25-- Informed observers said tonight the signing of the Turkish-Iraqi treaty had sounded the deathknell for the Arab League. They believe the lines now are drawn between Iraq and Egypt in a struggle to win the allegiance of the smaller Arab states.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The British Labor party, long hagridden by feuds, will come out of its corner fighting and as nearly united as it is possible for it to be next week for the first great political debate of what is expected to be an election year.

A shortage of food in Petrograd in the early days of March, 1917, brought into the streets crowds that rioted and fought with the police. Troops sent in to quell the disorders joined the rioters.

Department store sales in the United States in the week ended Feb. 19 were 5 per cent greater than in the like week last year, according to the Federal Reserve Board. In the previous week they were up 1 per cent, in the four weeks ended Feb. 19 they increased 2 per cent and in the year to that date they were 6 per cent higher than in the corresponding 1954 period.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26 -- The Yale University swimming team coasted to its 125th consecutive dual meet victory by topping Dartmouth, 60 to 24 today. The Elis won six of ten first places as they extended their ten-year skein.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Gen. John E. Hull, commander in chief of United States and United Nations forces in the Far East, is retiring on April 30.

Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom thinks that South Africa needs from the United States more technical advice, more sympathy and more investment capital. So Leonard Ingalls reports to this newspaper from Capetown, Mr. Strijdom also believes that we could help by making "a proper attempt to understand our problems, especially our racial problems."

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. -- To this old town's display of historic buildings, which annually attracts thousands of visitors, has been added another ancient Spanish dwelling. THE browsers who hovered constantly about the well-stocked "bookstore" at last week's National Photo Show at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory gave ample proof that interest in photographic literature is growing at a surprisingly accelerated pace. Sponsored by the American Photographic Book Publishing Company, Inc., the idea provided such an attractive lure for hundreds that during certain periods visitors had to wait their turn to get at the book racks.
HELPFUL to early planners is Norway's announcement of its full program of spring and summer events. More than the usual number of motor coach trips and fjord excursions are listed.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Cut down buddleia and abelia to within a few inches of the ground, if not done last fall. Prune hydrangeas and any other shrubs that do not bloom in spring. It is too early to prune hybrid tea roses but the sooner grapevines are done the better. Brambles can be trimmed whenever it is convenient to do so.

Members of the Alumnae Association of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, the Bronx, will hold their annual card party and fashion show next Saturday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria. A new international language known as Interlingua will be taught for the first time in a college classroom when the 1955 spring semester begins at the New York University Division of General Education. An auxiliary tongue with regular, simplified grammar and root words from many national languages, Interlingua is designed to overcome language barriers faced by scientists and persons in foreign trade and travel.
