Cornell's fencing team posted a 14-13 victory over Columbia at the Lions' gymnasium yesterday.

DALLAS, Feb. 26 -- Work on multi - million - dollar projected Texas toll roads this week reflected the continued healthy outlook of Southwestern business and high construction activity. Ground was broken for a $140,000,000 Dallas-San Antonio Super Highway, and bonds were sold for the $137,000,000 Dallas-Houston Toll Road.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, America's Davis Cup stars, will meet tomorrow in the singles final of the annual Pittsburgh Golf Club invitation indoor tennis tournament.

THE Symphony of the Air, Arturo Toscanini's former N. B. C. Symphony, gave a dramatic concert at Carnegie Hall not long ago without a conductor. It was such a huge success that you would think that the men would wish to carry on without a conductor. Not at all. It would be an intolerable strain on the individual players, and, in the end, it would not produce the best results.

ROYAL portraiture has always presented the artist with a difficult problem and never more so than in England today. For although there is no longer an official "Sergeant Painter to the King" (there is still a Poet Laureate, a Master of the Queen's Music and a Keeper of the Queen's Pictures), each new sovereign chooses as soon as possible after Coronation an artist to paint the "State Portrait."

" NO other species of birds, to the best of our knowledge, ever approached the passenger pigeon in numbers," A. W. Schorger writes. And yet, almost within one generation (1870-1900), this bird -- whose fabulous numbers, estimated from two to five billion, had taxed the credulity of spectators -- was exterminated.

BONN, Sunday, Feb. 27 -- Despite Chancellor Adenauer's triumph, his Social Democratic opponents were certain they had walked off with a tremendous propaganda victory that had undermined the moral authority of the West German Government and the ruling four-power coalition.

Once again an attempt is being made to dispel the threat of the mushroom cloud that destroyed Hiroshima and now hangs menacingly over the entire world. But the principal atomic powers -- the United States, Britain, France, Canada and the Soviet Union -- reopened their secret negotiations in London on Friday under less than favorable auspices.
Wall Street leaders, their fingers tightly crossed, take off for Washington this week.
Sole reliance upon "positive thinking" to solve "all problems of life" was discouraged yesterday by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum.

DORIS BELL BALL is a British physician who writes novels, mostly mysteries, under the pseudonym of "Josephine Bell" -- a name with pleasing echoes of Dr. Joseph Bell, the prototype of Sherlock Holmes.

New York State is to be allotted 123 representatives to the White House Conference on Education this year under the tentative plan prepared by President Eisenhower's Conference Committee. More than 2,000 persons are to take part in the conference, Nov. 28 through I Dec. 1.

TWO HUNDRED years ago you couldn't hire a decorator. At least not in the way you do it today. At that time if you decided to fix up your house you were probably pretty much your own decorator and depended on the cooperation of artisans working in various trades connected with furniture design.

Lawyers' associations recently have liberalized their stands concerning coverage of their members by Federal Social Security. But they are not abandoning their efforts to have Congress grant tax exemption on funds provided by professional persons for their own retirement plans, just as contributions to private pension plans for employes by non-professional business concerns are exempted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced today the award of its gold medal for "exceptional and extremely valuable accomplishments in the field of aviation safety" to Dr. Barry G. King of its headquarters here.

ONE becomes so inured to fine words being followed by no deeds that it comes as a delightful shock to note how rapidly the International Exchange Program has turned plans into action. In the few months since I. E. P. decided to expand its activities, it has performed what amounts almost to a miracle.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 26 -- A former waterfront union official was arrested here today as a material witness in an investigation of an $8,000 hold-up of a dice game last Sunday.

NOT long ago an eminent British, editor offered to bet 100 to 10 that should Donald Maclean appear at his club one day for lunch, the Government could do nothing serious to Maclean and that, on the contrary, the missing diplomat would be able to do something pretty serious in the way of libel actions to those who have called him a traitor.
The business outlook continues favorable, according to the latest survey of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
There was a 15 per cent drop last year in the number of venereal disease cases reported to the City Health Department. A total of 33,293 cases were listed, as against 38,958 in 1953.

TWENTY years ago S. G. Soal was an outspoken critic of card experiments in ESP (extrasensory perception). He now views them with approval. This London mathematician even undertook a research of his own to expose the fallacy he suspected in the ESP work -- only to find that he had accumulated good evidence on ESP even while expecting negative results.
Edward H. Rowley has been elected a director of the Zonite Products Corporation. He is president of Rowley United Theatres of Dallas, Texas.
Two hundred Sanitation Department workers will report tomorrow for three weeks of intensive training in enforcement of the anti-litter laws.
The retirement of the dean of women students at Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, was announced yesterday by the seminary president, Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen.

" THERE are places in Great Britain that are way out beyond the villages, and beyond the macadamed roads, and beyond the telegraph wires. * * * They are way out beyond time too." These are the opening lines of Phyllis Hastings' new novel and they are prophetic; an ancient voice echoes in every page.

ALL the ingredients of a successful first novel are here: the American veteran of the German campaigns (dissatisfied with the stifling domesticity he found at home) volunteering to work for the Civilian Personnel Office in Germany; the dimlit North German town, its population shell shocked, its black markets prosperous, its underworld literally living in cellars below rubble and buried corpses.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Senator Walter G. McGahan, Republican of Queens, introduced in the Legislature this week a bill that would increase the commissions charged by employment agencies.

THERE are no rules for choosing the art with which you want to live. Taste in paintings is as personal as taste in people. And one should feel as free to indulge in it. There is no trick to buying art. It is as easy to find and simple to purchase as any other object you have in your home.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Pennsylvania's attorney in Delaware River water litigation said today that New York "must yield" in any question concerning prior right to the Delaware's water.

TO the home gardener no fruit is more delicious than that produced in his own back yard. For this he is willing to sacrifice innumerable hours waving a spray gun over his trees to keep insects and disease away.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 26 -- Steel mills consumed 6,619,820 tons of Lake Superior iron ore in January as the industry continued its comeback. The figure was the largest in twelve months, according to the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association. Furnaces consumed 6,995,621 tons in January, 1954.

JOHN MARQUAND is that rare kind of writer, a really good novelist of manners. He knows what only the best novelists of this kind do, how to make the reader see the customs and habits of large areas of a society through the realized life of the people who generate them and give them vitality.

EVEN though it is only a partial success, Charles Gorham's fifth work of fiction marks a distinguished advance in his literary career. What he aims to do in this vivid and always readable biographical novel is to render in print the tormented life of the French artist, Paul Gauguin.
GENEVA, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Colds and sore throats are under all-out attack at Sampson Air Force Base near here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Since Dwight D. Eisenhower became President of the United States, the population of this country has increased by 5,496,000. The total on January 1 of this year was 163,930,000 -- 38,351,237 more than when Herbert Hoover left the White House in 1933.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund winds up its forty-third annual appeal today with record-breaking contributions totaling $408,603.16.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 26 -- Mayor Ernest A. Ashdown has announced that he is quitting politics and will not be a candidate for re-election when the village voters go to the polls next month.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 26 -- The Turkish - Iraqi treaty is merely the first step toward effective cooperation between the countries, it was pointed out here today. The provisions are extremely loose and fall short of the language used in the Turkish - Iraqi communique on Jan. 12, announcing the decision to conclude the treaty.

MEXICO is becoming increasingly attractive as a base of operations for American film producers. At present, eleven pictures, wholly or partially financed by Hollywood studios and independent operators, are scheduled to be made South of the Border this year.

THE title of this novel, a phrase from Eliot's "Prufrock," emphasizes the way in which members of the staff at Daddy Tom's summer camp in the Tennessee mountains fall shyly or slyly in love with their colleagues.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 -- Two programs -- one Federal, the other state -- for diverting surplus waters of two northern California rivers hundreds of miles to the southward were before Californians this week.

The office building of the future will have outside walls that transfer heat from the sunny side, where it's hot, to the shady side, where it's cool. This kind of "external air conditioning" will be made possible' by lining the walls with flat coils of copper tubing to carry water from one side to the other under the direction of thermostats.
Engineering concerns are rushing plans for improving methods and materials for building highway and airport pavements.

For the sixteen big league clubs spring training will get under way officially on Tuesday. Some, like the Yankees, Dodgers and Senators, have been conducting rookie camps, getting an early look at the younger hopefuls.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- A Columbia University team that refused to be awed by Pennsylvania's Ivy Basketball League leaders upset the Red and Blue, 90 -- 82, in an overtime game before 4,600 at the Palestra tonight.

CURRENTLY there is ever growing interest in creating a garden inside the home. Besides the well-known kinds of house plants, like the many members of the large family of philodendron, the decorative and unusual plant is becoming more common.
HOUSTON, Feb. 26 -- Jerry Barber grabbed the fifty-four-hole lead in the $30,000 Houston open today by closing with a spectacular 125-yard hole-out shot for a record nine-under-par 63.
Motorists will be riding rainbows when plans now under way to produce colored tires are completed. The colors will match or outdo those of the automobiles themselves.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 24 -- The Buenos Aires press made politico-religious scandal this afternoon of the case of the Mother Superior of the French Convent of the Assumption who refused to keep children of divorced parents in her school. A divorce law was adopted here as part of the anti-church campaign in December.

" WHEN you look at goods in a supermarket, you are shopping in the market-places of the world," says Mrs. Bendick, for there you find coffee from South America, sardines from Maine and Norway, tea from India.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 26 -- Michigan Democrats quietly proposed their Governor as a 1956 Presidential possibility today. The Governor, G. Mennen Williams, did not protest.

GEORGE ("SLIM") LEWIS, who describes himself as an "elephant tramp" for the purpose of entitling his autobiography, is what circuses call a bull hand, or elephant handler. All elephants, of whatever sex, are known as bulls in captive-animal circles, as Lewis soon gets around to informing his readers.
The relentless urge for lobscouse assailed Albert G. Bruck off the coast of Florida, as he stood watch aboard a power barge bound for Galveston.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 21 -- United States Public Law 48 of the Eighty-second Session of Congress, unknown to all except a comparative handful of Americans, is getting some pleased and detailed consideration in universities all over India.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Navy's swimming team rallied today and scored a one-foot victory in the 400-yard free-style relay to beat Army, 44 to 40. The swim meet was the feature event of a four-sport program between the service academies.
Nearly half a million Americans picked up passports, packed their bags and left for foreign parts last year. A fifth of them were from this city.

RICHMOND, Feb. 26 -- Fifth Reserve District shoppers are not quite as active as they were in January. While sales to date are 6 per cent above the same period last year, this figure is disappointing when it is recalled that the early 1954 trade was dull in comparison with that of the previous year.

PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 26 -- Communist China "must never be allowed to shoot its way into the United Nations," Senator John Sparkman told 200 "Boy and Girl Legislators" on the Princeton University campus today.

IN a book that is one part superb and two parts stimulating yet dissatisfying, Frederik Pohl has collected three hitherto unpublished short novels of science-fantasy. West's "Little Men," a tale of a world governed by outsize children, shows occasional flashes of masterful irony and one weirdly wonderful scene of adolescents devising their own proper worship for their own peculiar gods.

SELDOM does a book fill a vital need so admirably as this one. The last general work examining the subject of Congressional investigations appeared some thirty years ago. Since then the investigating power of Congress, having been put to new and spectacular uses, has come to occupy a vastly more important place in the American political system than ever before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The United States Indian Commissioner, Glen Emmons, opposed today legislation introduced by Senator George W. Malone, (Republican of Nevada), to end Government supervision over Indians.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has asked for law to prevent exploitation of women brought here from the South, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands by employment agencies.

" A dirty business" -- those were Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes' words for wiretapping. Last week in New York a shadowy affair involving the business of wiretapping had various bodies concerned with law enforcement astir.

THE happiest of all book titles, it has long seemed to me -- and I do not mean that in any optimistic sense -- is W. H. Hudson's "Far Away and Long Ago." In memorability, in sound, and in apt descriptiveness, it achieves perfection.

LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- It was another "Black Saturday" for British soccer teams today. Snow and ice prevented starts in twenty-six of the scheduled sixty-two league games -- twenty in England and six in Scotland.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Sam Tufano's Wise Margin made a strong stretch run today to win the $19,000 Letellier Memorial at the Fair Grounds and establish himself as a top contender for the rich New Orleans Handicap next week.

SENATOR FRANK CARLSON of Kansas, originator of a number of ideas which the Post Office Department has adopted in developing its programs for special stamps, has introduced in Congress several bills to the effect that Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield be "authorized and directed" to issue postal items of a commemorative character.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- The business pick-up in Chicago during December was confirmed by the report of the Bureau of Economics and Business Research division of the University of Illinois. While some of the indexes showed only a seasonal increase, the major indicators showed improvement over December, 1953.

HARTFORD, Feb. 26 -- Connecticut Democrats were told tonight that the Republican party nationally was attempting to "deify" President Eisenhower "while it thinks up attempts to ram through more giveaways or stealaways upon the American people."

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 27 -- Evidence of brutal and subtle tortures inflicted by Chinese Communists and North Koreans on British prisoners of war in Korea is disclosed in a document published today by the Ministry of Defense.
Six of the eleven top leaders of the Communist party of the United States will complete next Tuesday the five-year prison terms they have been serving for criminal conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The political crockery which House Democrats and Republicans hurled at each other this week over the first revenue bill of the Eighty-fourth Congress marked the first serious partisan disturbance of the session. There will be others in preparation for the Presidential contest of 1956. The mutually antagonistic co-tenants of the government structure were bound to quarrel, since each seeks sole occupancy.

IF the Chinatown Fair, Inc., on Mott Street ("The Amusement Center of Chinatown. Win Beautiful Chinese and American Merchandise. Play Pokerino. Skee Ball. Shooting Gallery -- Real Bullets.") is any criterion, then the Chinese are the most scrutable people in New York, particularly on a Sunday when they jam the place and set their children to riding in the latest non-riding jet airplanes.

WHAT Mendes - France and his glass of milk were to cartoonists the world over, the playwright Henry de Montherlant and his "Port-Royal" have been to Paris columnists. His daring in writing a play that runs without an intermission for two hours and twenty minutes has provided commentators with the juiciest morsel to come their way in a long time.

Ed Conlin turned in a superb job last night as Fordham's basketball team beat New York University, 67 to 56, in the thirty-sixth meeting between the Bronx rivals. The game was played at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., Feb. 26 -- The task of picking six skiers to represent the United States as jumpers in next January's Winter Olympic Games at Cortina, Italy, received an unscheduled interruption today. The cause was gusty headwinds, which made conditions hazardous.

Now when we talk about decreasing revenues at a time when the Government * * * is still spending somewhat more than it takes in, we are reaching some kind of heights in fiscal irresponsibility. * * * -- PRESIDENT EISENHOWER.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Val Peterson told Congress today that a lot of thinking on defense against massive bomb attack was obsolete and "much of it possibly dangerous."

MADEMOISELLE FRANCOISE SAGAN is living a very pleasant adventure, though a dangerous one. She is so young (18) -- yet she is already a celebrity in Europe as a result of this, her first book. Her words are quoted, her comings and goings make news.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- An eminent British physicist said today that the Soviet Union and the United States each had, or soon would have, enough hydrogen bombs to destroy the main centers of population and industry of the other.

This is to thank you for your article on traveling exhibitions The whole field needs more understanding and promotion; especially in the realm of interchange with other countries. The final paragraph went to the heart of the matter, in its suggestion that some critical body is needed to deal with selection, costs and the routing of shows to the most desirable points.

MELBOURNE, Feb. 18 -- The United States' attitude is in large measure the key to Australia's future policy regarding military forces for Southeast Asia. The visit of the Australian Prime Minister, Robert Gordon Menzies, to President Eisenhower on March 13 is awaited here with interest.

Last August Governor Dewey appointed a commission of fifteen citizens, headed by Chancellor Henry T. Heald of New York University, to make a study of the state's educational problems. The emphasis was to be placed on the financing of the schools, and the part that the state should play in this support.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 26 -- Navy found the target in the second half to beat Army's basketball team, 67 to 45, today. With a rousing rally that pleased a gathering of 3,000, including top Navy officials, the midshipmen concluded the season victoriously at Dahlgren Hall after overcoming a session of poor markmanship.

A FEW Sundays ago, your critic performed a genuine public service when, with the aid of a letter that had been printed in the Harvard Alumni Bulletin, he helped explode the myth that G. B. Shaw wrote "St. Joan," "Man and Superman," etc.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- A four-car pile-up and gasoline-fed flames sent three racing drivers and three spectators to a hospital today and cut short the 125-mile Nascar race for modified stock cars.

SIR EDWARD L. SPEARS is the distinguished soldier, M. P. and man of letters who in the 1940 spring, when Hitler struck westward, was dispatched to Paris to serve as the Prime Minister's eye and ear at the war councils of the French Government.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Second Lieut. Bob Clotworthy, 23, Mountainside, N. J., today used a near-perfect back one-and-one-half to somersault his way into a berth on the United States diving team that will compete in the Pan-American games.

THIS assemblage of science-fantasy strikes me as being nothing more than an anthology made up from other anthologies. A good 90 per cent of its selections -- most of them abridgments of, or excerpts from, longer pieces -- are readily available in other anthologies or in medium-priced collections of an author's works.

Mr. Yarmon refers to left-handedness as sinistrodextrality. He would never pass high school Latin on that one. For "sinistro" means left and "dextro" means right and the word obviously is so much doubletalk. What he meant to say is sinistro-manuality.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Feb. 26 -- The last of 200 carrier pigeons that flew combat missions in Korea were back at this Army post today.

JULES CAMBON of France, who died in 1935 at 90 and who was probably the ablest diplomat of his time, once said: "The day secrecy is abolished, negotiation of any kind will become impossible." The prediction has proved startlingly accurate, although it is unlikely that even the prescient M. Cambon envisaged the oratorical free-for-all of the past decade -- the propaganda sessions that have so largely replaced professional diplomacy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Representative Clement J. Zablocki, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today the House Foreign Affairs Committee would call on Secretary of State John Foster Dulles for a "definite statement of our policy regarding Matsu and Quemoy Islands."
The vast and far-ranging fleet of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service performed thirty-two assistance-at-sea missions last year.

The two banks in Baldwin, L. I., are set to close their doors at 2 P. M. next Friday. Four hours later they'll open for evening business as branches of Nassau County's rapidly growing Meadow Brook National Bank.
The Industrial Workers of the World -- the best known of the radical labor organizations in this country -- celebrated yesterday its fiftieth anniversary.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 26 -- A. B. (Happy) Chandler, former Baseball Commissioner, is running for Governor of Kentucky this year.

Huntington defeated the New York trio in the final round match of the George Sherman Memorial tournament at the Squadron A Armory last night, 12-to-11. A capacity crowd of 1,000 witnessed the encounter in which Huntington led almost all the way.
WITH a toehold in higher ground, merchants and manufacturers are convinced that only a combination of adverse factors can shake them loose.
The second of three permanent day camp sites that will provide facilities for 5,000 New York children will be opened in June at Orangeburg, N. Y., by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.
BOSTON, Feb. 26 -- Politicians have sharpened their legislative scalpels for new surgery on the City Charter.
TOKYO, Sunday, Feb. 27 -- Japan will choose a new House of Representatives today in the nation's sixth and quietest post-war election.
WE'VE heard educators say -- more than once and sometimes wistfully -- that it takes fifty years for a new development in their field to grow strong enough for general public acceptance.

THE attention of the world has been focused on the removal, now begun, of 58,000 Africans from the western areas of Johannesburg to new housing made available farther west at Meadowlands. What are the facts of this situation?

Too tired to move, let alone drive, the New York Knickerbockers dropped a 79-72 decision to the Milwaukee Hawks yesterday at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. The third straight setback dropped the Knicks into third place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 26 -- How California shall spend its many millions of dollars of accumulated royalties from offshore oil is a lively question as the Legislature prepares to go back into session next week.

STATION WOR-TV, which televises baseball games at Ebbets Field, is naturally a Brooklyn rooter. Last week it became known that WOR-TV has now made a Dodgers rooter out of its sister affiliate, WOR radio.

TRENTON, Feb. 26 -- The 1955 primary election campaign in New Jersey will get under way within two weeks. An entire sixty-member Assembly is to be elected this year, and eleven of the twenty-one seats in the State Senate are at stake.

EDOUARD PEISSON is a French sailor who turned novelist and has won acclaim in his native land for his stories of the sea. "The Liner" is his introduction to an American audience, a welcome presentation indeed.

Because of the constructive policy of The New York Times in conveying news to the United States and abroad I am sure you will be interested in comments regarding the current trip of Vice President Nixon and his wife through Central America.

HAWAII, before the coming of the white man, is the setting for this story of young Lua, son of a princess, who is destined to be chief of his people. The story deals mainly with his day-to-day life among his family and with his education for leadership under the guidance of the village priest.

The Canadiens of Montreal will meet the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The contest will mark the final local appearance of the season for the Flying Frenchmen, and it will begin at 7 o'clock.

The Henry Street Settlement will be the beneficiary of a luncheon and tour to be held on April 19 at the headquarters of the settlement at 265 Henry Street. Mrs. Edmund F. Johnstone is chairman of the benefit committee. Serving with her as vice chairman is Mrs. Bruce A. Gimhel.

THE scene of Mildred Walker's bracing new novel is Montana, specifically a small town named Brandon Rapids and a cattle ranch in the neighboring King Butte country, where the wind blowing over the empty prairies can roll tumbleweed as big as a bushel basket and the cold can strike forty below.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Christians in the United States were urged today to increase help to the national churches in undeveloped areas in Asia and Africa.

The chairman of next season's campaign for the Friends of the Philharmonic-Symphony will be Chester G. Burden, former vice president of the Commercial Cable Company. He will succeed David M. Keiser, who was chairman of the first four campaigns.

A. H. Raskin's "John L. Lewis -- 'A Glorious Anachronism'" (Feb. 13) was brilliant. What Raskin did in this informative, dramatic and graphic account of the rise and recession of The Great John and the development of our modern labor movement as a whole points up the poverty of the American screen and stage and novel in contrast to the rich maturity of American journalism.

Twenty-two professional architects, engineers and advisers on religious building design here have accepted invitations to join a board of consultants at the Columbia University School of Architecture.
OTTAWA, Feb. 19 -- A hefty young Canadian industry -- air freight into the Arctic -- is warming up for its biggest job.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- Gunnar Myrdal, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission in Europe, today defended the organization's handling of an unpublished report on the price of oil in Western Europe.
French eighteenth century furniture of unusual quality and other objects from the collection formed by the late Mrs. Seton Porter of New York, will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday.

BACK in my teaching days, I had a colleague who taught a very elevating course in the Humanities, a course which purposed to give the students some general understanding of the arts. He often told a story about one of his students who played the piano.

FROM the day she was launched in the autumn of 1938, H. M. S. Kelly was a tiddley job, which is Royal Navy lingo for a smart ship. She was commissioned on Aug. 23, 1939, so that her entire peacetime service was exactly ten days long.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- A tall, lanky school man from Texas ribbed his colleagues without mercy today -- and they took it.

OCALA, Fla. -- For a long time the springs of Florida -- with the possible exception of Silver Springs and St. Augustine's small Fountain of Youth -- were largely overshadowed as a tourist attraction by the state's miles of sandy beaches.

The Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on the nomination of Judge John Marshall Harlan to be a justice of the United States Supreme Court reached the height of nonsense on Friday -- and dangerous nonsense at that. The prize witness seemed to be George Racey Jordan, a former Air Force major, whose latest activity was to try -- vainly -- to get ten million signatures on a petition opposing Senate censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Manhattan, missing few bets, regained the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. team title last night. George Eastment's green-sashed Jaspers bagged one first place, one second and six thirds in the varsity track and field carnival at Madison Square Garden to tally 27 points.

THE baby sea otter's parents chose a kelp bed off Black Reef in the Aleutian Islands as a home safe from their worst enemies -- men, sharks and killer whales. From a rock ledge on the reef, Peter, the Aleut boy, watched and made plans to capture the otters.

Mr. Faulkner shows commendable modesty in rating himself only second among the five best American novelists of his time. In omitting from the list the name of James T. Farrell, however, he may have ignored the one United States writer of this era who will be most highly regarded by future generations.

JAZZ musicians are apt to achieve their initial acclaim to the accompaniment of heated controversy. Is the new star really playing jazz or is he simply debasing a noble art? This argument was stirred up by the arrival of Benny Goodman's orchestra, by the appearance of Dizzy Gillespie, of Charlie Parker and, more recently, of Dave Brubeck, among others.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The statesmen are relying on massive retaliation with atomic weapons to protect the country. But the Marine Corps is taking no chances. It is improving its cold steel technique.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- The United Nations Children's Fund will aid 3,500,000 more mothers and children in 1955 than during the past year, it was predicted here today.

STORIES of religious conversion are so numerous, and in some cases so stereotyped, that there exists a tendency to patronize them as a species of literary piety undeserving of critical attention or general circulation.

COLOGNE, Germany, Feb. 26 -- America's hockey all-stars, who had appeared startled in their first test against Canada, regained their composure today and scored an 8-1 triumph over Finland in the world amateur hockey championship.

The 1955 fund-raising campaign of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross will be started next Tuesday. A parade of Red Cross floats and workers will move up Broadway from the Battery to City Hall.

Recommendations for meeting the needs of the gifted children among the nearly 3,000,000 boys and girls enrolled in New York State's public, private and parochial schools are contained in a study entitled "Bright Kids -- We Need Them," prepared by the Board of Regents Council on the Readjustment of High School Education.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Feb. 26 -- The Pennsylvania State University's $300,000 nuclear research reactor is to be in full operation before the end of its current centennial year.
The Health Department is establishing a poison-control center. It will provide physicians and hospitals with information, diagnostic facilities and aid in treatment.
IN almost every garden, whether it be estate or backyard size, there are certain plants that give especial pleasure to the grower. And therein lies one of the real joys of gardening.

THE reader is given fair warning: by the time he is halfway through this book he will feel so well acquainted with helicopters he will want to dash to the nearest heliport or wherever else the whirly birds are operated and try to fly one of them.

THE waterless washer and the refrigerator composed of drawers predicted for ten years from now may not yet be a reality, but certainly other developments in major equipment for the kitchen took several strides forward during the past year. The improvements are notable both for design and function.
NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 26 (UP) -- The American Legion Auxiliary carried out a "very successful" two-hour drive today to rid the city of objectionable comic books.

BONN, Germany, Sunday, Feb. 27 -- (AP) Seven of the fourteen North American Treaty Organition nations have completed parliamentary ratification of the Paris treaties. But among the Big Three powers only Britain has ratified.

MINNIE C---, a 14-year-old girl, lost her arm when she was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train in July, 1941. That was six months before Pearl Harbor. Last fall -- more than thirteen years after the accident -- her claim for damages was paid, after two jury trials and three appeals.

BOISE, Idaho, Feb. 26 (UP) -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, assailed the Eisenhower Administration today as "the wrong Administration in office for the wrong purposes, doing the wrong things, and for the wrong people."

WITH spring just around the corner, the main parade of flower shows is about to begin. For weeks, all the professional gardeners, hobbyists, garden club members, commercial growers and tradesmen have been making plans for the displays they will set up this year.

THE airline industry, which has looked on the temporary Idlewild terminal as only a slight improvement on a Central American bus station, is generally happy about the blueprint for modern new facilities.

" A PHOTOGRAPHER'S Gallery," a new place for exhibiting pictures regularly, will open next Sunday with a public reception from 1 to 5 P. M. at 49 West Eighty-fourth Street with an exhibition of photographs by Roy De Carava, 1953 Guggenheim Fellow.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- The February business review of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia notes that the Government bought about 14 per cent of the nation's output of goods and services last year. It shows that most of the money goes for national security, and most of it comes from taxes on income -- personal and corporate.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland said today he did not believe there was "any real threat" against Judge John Marshall Harlan's promotion to the Supreme Court
The Welbilt Stove Company would be merged with the Detroit-Michigan Stove Company and the latter's name then changed to the Welbilt Corporation under a proposal just announced.
HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 26 -- A downtown development and business men's group here has begun studying the feasibility of installation of an air-conditioned monorail rapid transit system.

EVEN in the winter, when most garden operations are at a standstill, chemical control of weeds can proceed. In fact, there are distinct advantages in spraying certain unwanted plants during late winter and early spring.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Millions of citizens in eleven of sixteen Soviet Union republics will elect deputies tomorrow to republic parliaments, or Supreme Soviets.

One of the livelier shows at the New York World's Fair of 1939-40 ran continuously at the telephone company exhibit, where visitors from all over the country could call the folks back home toll free. The only strings to the deal were the wires leading to 200 earphones to which other fairgoers glued themselves for blissful, sanctioned eavesdropping.

IN the entertaining introduction to "Report From Malaya," Vernon Bartlett states that it is not a book for the experts, but rather that it is designed merely to help "dispel some of the illusions" about Malaya and the conflict there.
AN avid appetite for blue cheese has developed in this country. It has become a gastronomical vogue in much the same way chiffon pies, waffles and club sandwiches were in fashion a few years back.
Nineteen Maritime Administration employes have received honor awards for public service, Louis S. Rothschild, who heads Government maritime activities, announced last week.
SAN REMO, Italy, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles fought to a five-set victory over Fausto Gardini of Italy today to enter the final of San Remo's international tennis tournament.
Governor Harriman said yesterday that the "lives and health of many persons are seriously endangered" by "loopholes" in the rent control law.
Congress and the Administration were urged last week to continue the annual $660,000 Federal grant to the four state maritime academies in New York, Massachusetts, Maine and California.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 19 -- Sheikh Hassan el-Hodeiby, now serving a life sentence in an Egyptian prison, is still regarded as the Supreme Guide of the Moslem Brotherhood. Members in a dozen countries, reaching from Syria and the Sudan to Indonesia, so regard him.

ASIDE from cathedrals and whipped cream cakes, Old Austria has also contributed a variety of horsemanship to the modern world. The Spanish Riding School (its foreign name proves that it is dynastically Habsburg and therefore typically Austrian) cultivates a slow ballet danced on hooves, a stately centaurian Swan Lake of elegant and effortless precision.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 26 -- The abandonment of the Nanki Island group by the Chinese Nationalists this week put the spotlight of world attention directly on the offshore islands of Matsu and Quemoy.

AS hostess-manager on the Protocol Staff of the State Department, Mrs. Victoria Geaney has the only job of its kind in the Government: she runs Blair House, which puts up the heads of nations. What with one world crisis and another, more heads, both hereditary and constitutional, were put up last year than ever before and the end is not in sight.

While going to the aid of a motorist in an accident, a father of seven children was struck by an automobile and fatally injured yesterday. The accident happened on the Belt Parkway at 127th Street, South Ozone Park, Queens.
Harold Edward Nicolai bears lightly the distinction of having been best man at thirty-eight weddings, of having three unrelated children named for him, and of being godfather to five others.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The strategic positions of the Republican and Democratic parties some twenty months ahead of the great test of 1956 are now being slightly but importantly altered.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Federation of American Scientists said today the United States should remove the secret label from more information on atomic energy.

Airline travel is safer than ever, according to insurance men. A passenger can buy more than twice as much machine-made insurance at more reasonable rates before take-off than he could ten years ago, a survey of the expanding auxiliary industry shows.

LONDON'S Festival Ballet paid us a brief visit last week at the Brooklyn Academy, and though three performances are scarcely enough to make us genuinely acquainted with any company, especially when it has been questionably adorned with guest artists, it is nevertheless possible to record some definite impressions.

Stock prices displayed a softer tone last week in trading that was restricted to four sessions by the Washington Birthday holiday. Weakness in the London market and a rise in the British bank rate from 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent spurred liquidation here.
AMONG the more celebrated transients now visiting Manhattan are Claudette Colbert and Ray Bolger. Both will be making live television appearances from New York this week.
MILPITAS, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Ford was warming up today for a showdown battle with Chevrolet in the West.

CURIOUS men have always gone slumming or explored the rarefied altitudes of society to know how, the other half lives. With a complex character like Ludwig Bemelmans and as quaint and irrepressible a subject as the late Elsie Lady Mendl, such a simplification becomes ineffective.

Stock prices displayed a softer tone last week in trading that was restricted to four sessions by the Washington Birthday holiday. Weakness in the London market and a rise in the British bank rate from 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent spurred liquidation here.
AMONG the more celebrated transients now visiting Manhattan are Claudette Colbert and Ray Bolger. Both will be making live television appearances from New York this week.
MILPITAS, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Ford was warming up today for a showdown battle with Chevrolet in the West.

CURIOUS men have always gone slumming or explored the rarefied altitudes of society to know how, the other half lives. With a complex character like Ludwig Bemelmans and as quaint and irrepressible a subject as the late Elsie Lady Mendl, such a simplification becomes ineffective.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 26 -- A campaign for $3,300,000 in capital funds has been started by the trustees of Colgate University.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Girls from the Walter Reed Swimming Club of Washington broke two American records in the trials for the Pan-American games team that ended tonight. They will lead a squad of eighteen selected to compete in the international contests.

Re Morton Yarmon's article "On the Other Hand" (Feb. 13) about the extent to which left-handed persons are receiving the attention of banks (check books) and the makers of desks tools, violins, saxophones, sports goods and a variety of other manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- This country's roads are badly in need of major overhaul and expansion.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits is starting a new attack on "the steadily mounting emergency of juvenile delinquency."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Bill Yorzyk of the New Haven S. C., posted the fastest times in three of six events in the two-day Eastern Division of the Pan-American swimming trials which ended tonight.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Feb. 26 (AP) -- G. R. White's Trim Destiny easily defeated six other 3-year-olds in the $5,000 Hot Springs Handicap before a crowd of 12,054 at Oaklawn Park today.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Lawrenceville School scored a record point total today in winning the prep school division title of the fifty-fifth annual Eastern interscholastic swimming championships.

AS a recent development in tourism, it is now a fact that people in New York are going to school to learn how to go on vacation. Several "travel courses" have lately been launched, among them one at the New School for Social Research and one at Hunter College.
CAIRO, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The Supreme Military Tribunal decided today to exclude the public from its trial of seven Jews -- six men and a woman -- accused of Communist activities.
Applying modern production methods to old-style jewelry is proving a boon to manufacturers.
IF A nation-wide poll of conservation and sports groups could be made to identify the arch-enemy of conservation of this generation, the vote unquestionably would be unanimous --- dams.
ROME, Feb. 26 -- Premier Mario Scelba's chances of avoiding a Cabinet crisis are thought to have increased somewhat in the last twenty-four hours.

Sleeping arrangements of today must often share space with other family activities. Because of this the look of the sofa bed has changed. It not only takes on the shape of a sofa, and the scale of one, but also borrows many of the sofa's more decorative details.
BOSTON, Feb. 26 -- Harvard's hockey team gained its fourteenth victory tonight by routing Yale, 9 -- 1, at the Arena.
A bill to simplify customs evaluation of dutiable imports is expected to be the next major item of President Eisenhower's trade program to go before Congress.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 26 -- The National Assembly unanimously approved today the Turkish-Iraqi pact signed Thursday night in Baghdad. [The Iraqi Parliament also ratified the treaty Saturday.]

The obvious strong support in both Iraq and Turkey -- as well as in Pakistan -- for the newly ratified security alignment is a good omen. It means that there is a realistic appraisal of the danger and a realistic determination to meet it. Turkey and Pakistan took the lead in forming new associations to help that security.
ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Prof. Guy E. Grantham, who long has dramatized freshman physics at Cornell University, will retire July 1, the university announced today.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 -- The opinions of New York art experts are being used as ammunition in a civic battle over a striking new bit of public statuary.

AMERICA has always been the despair of the ideologues. It has been our fate as a nation not to have ideologies but to be one. European observers have long been impressed and bewildered by the failure of the United States to experience the deeply rooted and ardent class conflicts of the Old World and the variety of social ideologies that they produced.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 26 -- Gen. Lauris Norstad, Deputy Supreme Allied Commander for Air, was encamped today in the snow five miles south of Versailles with 250 officers and men of his staff.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- An unusual type of oil obtained from sperm whales can be used to protect water holes and reservoirs in arid zones against evaporation, British scientists state.
Many persons of prominence are supporting the April 12 benefit performance of "Three For Tonight" for Greer, a Children's Community.
OTTAWA, Feb. 26 -- The adventure of seven persons lost since Tuesday in the frozen wilds of the Canadian North ended happily today.

CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 26 -- Attorney General Grover C. Richman Jr. declared here last night that the most immediate and essential proposal before the state was acquisition of the Round Valley reservoir site in North Jersey.
Oil is Brazil's biggest problem, in the opinion of economists and industrialists who have watched the nation emerge almost overnight from the donkey to the airplane age.

WHEN 9-year-old Jenny dished out the daily hominy and syrup for Aunt Linda's twins and herself, she had little awareness of being orphaned and poor. Accepting the lack of material things as casually and uncritically as she accepted the Florida sunshine all around her, Jenny moved in a fanciful world of her own.
DETROIT, Feb. 26 -- The United Auto Workers, C. I. O., has an international strike fund of $7,254,987, according to an audit report made public here.

ELMER DAVIS dedicates this small volume to "the first victim of the hydrogen bomb, J. Robert Oppenheimer." This suggests that Dr. Oppenheimer's distaste for a weapon that might destroy millions of lives does not seem to Mr. Davis a crime.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Hillside House, Santa Barbara's organization for the care and rehabilitation of cerebral palsied patients, is moving ten miles across town to its new $500,000 home.
HAVANA, Feb. 22 -- The statue of Ferdinand VII of Spain, one of Cuba's most unpopular historical figures, finally has been removed from the Plaza de Armas in front of the Havana City Hall.

ED SULLIVAN had better forego any further "tributes" on his "Toast of the Town" presentation. over C. B. S. The sixty-minute program he dedicated last Sunday to the late Gertrude Lawrence was a shameful and wretched affair.

MONT TREMBLANT, Que., Feb. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Ralph Miller, a United States Army racer, put together two runs of 1 minute 50.9 seconds each today to take the Canadian downhill skiing championship.

IN his review of the Brogan book, Mr. Commager says that "we (the United States) are the oldest republic, the oldest federal system, with the oldest written Constitution and the oldest democralc colonial' system in the world."
GENEVA, Feb. 26 -- British Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler gave his country's economy, as he would put it, a sharp tug on the reins this week.

In April, 1954, the Chicago Operations Office of the Atomic Energy Commission announced that Dr. Samuel Untermeyer of the Argonne National Laboratory had developed a revolutionary portable X-ray unit that needed no electric current. The source of the X-rays (actually gamma rays) was radioactive thulium 170, thulium being an element found in rare earths.

MANY friendly historians have written about F. D. R. and many unfriendly ones, but almost all of them have one trait in common, that they know where they stand. Edgar Eugene Robinson. Professor of American History at Stanford, however, is like Zekle of Lowell's "The Courtin'":
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- British diamond circles were not admitting to any worry about the synthetic diamonds produced by the General Electric Company.

MANILA -- Corregidor, last stand of the Allied forces in Southeast Asia at the beginning of the War of the Pacific, is to be opened formally to world tourists next month in a fresh bid for the Philippines' share of vacation travel in Asia.
Any yachtsman, even a beginner, can spin a yarn in retrospect. But on Thursday night there will be a switch. Power cruiser skippers will try to conjure some salty tales before they happen!
BERLIN, Feb. 20 -- West Berlin is one place where they dote on Americans.
Dr. Paul V. Lemkau has been appointed director of mental health service for the New York City Mental Health Board. The position carries an annual salary of $20,000.
RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 26 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles conferred today with Burmese Premier U Nu. Mr. Dulles said later he had come here neither to woo neutral Burma nor to be wooed.

Dr. Edward Teller, now of the University of California, has done his best to expunge the impression that, after all other physicists had tossed it aside as an impossibility, he alone saw the way to the achievement of the hydrogen bomb. He makes a fresh attempt at giving proper credit in an article which he publishes in the current issue of Science.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 26 -- More than forty men, women and children were dead or missing tonight amid flood waters in western New South Wales. Nearly 40,000 persons were homeless in thirty towns.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Betty Jameson of San Antonio took the lead in the $5,000 Sarasota open golf tournament today. She shot a 71, three under women's par, for a fifty-four-hole score of 212.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd said today that an impending Congressional pay increase might make it more difficult to defeat a $20-a-person cut in next year's income taxes.
SINGAPORE, Feb. 26 -- Sir Anthony Eden denied here today that he objected in Bangkok yesterday to citing communism as the enemy of the Manila pact nations.

IN Honolulu, on the way home after five weeks on location in Hong Kong for "Soldier Of Fortune," Clark Gable was quoted in a news dispatch as being ready to retire. On the set here Mr. Gable was very definite in his denial. "Retiring I think that reporter got off the beam somewhere!"
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 26 -- Betty Jameson of San Antonio took the lead in the $5,000 Sarasota open golf tournament today. She shot a 71, three under women's par, for a fifty-four-hole score of 212.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd said today that an impending Congressional pay increase might make it more difficult to defeat a $20-a-person cut in next year's income taxes.

The blockfront on the east side of the Grand Concourse, between 204th and 205th Streets in the Bronx, has been purchased by 3130 Grand Concourse, Inc., Isadore Rosen, president, for improvement with an apartment house for 126 families and garage for 100 cars.
The so-called "right-to-work" laws were described yesterday by four out of six student panelists, as anti-labor measures used to lure out-of-state industry.

Visitors to Greenhouse There are a few niggardly little signs of spring as the calendar pages turn slowly from right to left. The days are longer, and the sun seems bent on proving the truth of the old saying that it grows warmer in February.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 27--A Negro national leader reported today that there were "scores of southern communities that would desegregate public schools at once if they were not hamstrung by state officials."

Ponchielli's "La Gioconda" will return to the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday evening, March 9. It has not been heard since the 1952-53 season. In this revival, the leading roles will be sung by Zinka Milanov, Nell Rankin, Kurt Baum and Leonard Warren.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 27 --Pat O'Neal, the Long Island Sound junior sailing champion, captured his first regatta of the waning frostbite season by leading the fleet with Little Bit at Larchmont Yacht Club today.
HOUSTON, Feb. 27 (AP)--Mike Souchak of Durham, N. C., fired a seven-under-par 65 today to win $6,000 in top money in the $30,000 Houston Open, richest tournament on the winter tour.

LUXEMBOURG, Feb. 27--In a speech last week Pierre Ricard, head of the French Steel Federation, said that Jean Monnet, chairman of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, should pay more attention to coal and steel and less attention to politics.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Feb. 27 (AP)--The New York Knickerbockers defeated Fort Wayne, Western Division leaders in the National Basketball Association, for the seventh straight time in their nine-game series today, 95--83.

British sterling staged a sharp rally in late week following the hardening of the English bank rate to 4 1/2 per cent, from 3 1/2, which had ruled but for a fortnight. The new rate is the highest since March 10, 1932.

IT is not often that a ballet has two premieres, but that is exactly what has happened to George Balanchine's "Western Symphony,' which was on last night's program of the New York City Ballet at the City Center.
Loss of Formosa to the Chinese Communists would make the West Coast an outer defense of the United States, Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan asserted yesterday.

THE Concert Society of New York completed its second season yesterday afternoon when it presented its sixteenth concert of 1954-55 at Town Hall. The highlight of the program was Hindemith's "Herodiade," which was recited by Vera Zorina, accompanied by members of the Saidenberg Little Symphony.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP)--Glenn Roberts of Daytona Beach won the 1955 Grand National Race for late model stock cars today with a record average speed of 93.158 miles an hour.

The Hendrick Hudson, one of the largest rooming houses on the upper West Side, has been purchased by the Eastpearl Realty Corporation. It is an eight-story building containing 536 rooms and occupying a plot 206 by 135 feet at 380 Riverside Drive, at 110th Street, and was sold by the Baum Residence Corporation, Lean F. Cantor, president.
Fountain House Foundation, Inc., a rehabilitation and recreation center for former mental patients, will be the beneficiary of the evening performance on April 19 of "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof."
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 27-- The Jewish Labor Committee reported today that anti-Semitism in employment was more widespread than it had realized.
An intensive campaign will be started in April by the Fire Department against motorists who fail to give the right-of-way to fire apparatus.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Labor party spokesmen charged today that the measures taken by the Government last week to strengthen Britain's economy showed the Conservatives' policy of lifting all controls had not worked.

The traffic between New York and Florida this winter has been the heaviest recorded by the commercial airlines. It surpasses last year's busy season by close to 30 per cent and is expected to remain heavy for at least six weeks.
LEADVILLE, Colo., Feb. 27-- Exercise Hail Storm, the Army's special mountain warfare training program, ended today, at Camp Hale near here.

Investment demands are likely to rise to record heights in 1955, and upward pressure upon longterm interest rates is likely to persist, according to a study prepared for the Bankers Trust Company by Roy L. Reierson, the bank's economist.

HONG KONG, Feb. 27--Two American students imprisoned by the Communist Chinese for three and one-half years as spies arrived here today, free and full of praise for their former jailers. They said in the presence of United States Consulate representatives that they had been "spies" for the United States and that the Communists had been "justified" in imprisoning them.
The tramp-ship charter market steamed through confused waters last week. Observers were not able to tell whether the tide was running in or out or was just slack.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Senate will hold the Congressional spotlight this week. After a series of close votes in the House in the last two weeks, the approaching legislative battles are expected to center on the other side of the Capitol.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 27--The Dutch dollar trading account last year showed a deficit of about $100 million, against a surplus of $65 million in 1953.

SINGAPORE, Feb. 27--The Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty Organization--to use its full name-- is no tightly knit organism like NATO. Everybody from Eden on down calls it SEATO for the sake if convenience. But SEATO is not in original or separate entity.

The men's clothing industry operated at 86 per cent of capacity in January. This was the same rate as in the 1954 month but compared with 81 per cent In January, 1953. Production of regular-weight men's suits increase'd 15 per cent compared with the 1954 month, but the output of summer-weight suits was off 24 per cent, according to the Clothing1 Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

Americans never have had the enthusiasm for polenta they have for that other Italian staple, spaghetti. Yet in northern Italy, polenta--corn meal cooked like pudding or porridge--is eaten at least once a day. In the Dolomites it is practically the staff of life.
Samuel Lubell has made a generally successful effort to go back to beginnings and think through our American foreign trade policy. He thinks we need a new one.

PARIS, Feb. 27--Passage by the Bonn Bundestag of a motion relating to the Saar today is expected to make more difficult the ratification of the Paris agreements by the French Parliament. Premier Edgar Faure has set this ratification as first priority on the program of the new French Government.

Last year the New York Telephone Company completed one of its largest programs of expansion and improvement in service facilities with an expenditure of $185,000,000, Keith S. McHugh, president, informed shareholders in the annual report issued today.
ALBANY, Feb. 27--Republican leaders are considering seriously three major changes in the State Rent Control Law.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)-- President Eisenhower said today he was encouraged because many national organizations were trying to contribute to the strength and effectiveness of the United Nations.
American interests ordered more ships abroad in eight postwar years than they built at home, according to a survey made public today by the magazine Marine Engineering.
MADRID, Feb. 27--Generalissimo Francisco Franco declared today that the monarchy was the only governing institution suitable for Spain.
DUST and looming shadow hold Wanamaker's in dark thrall now. Footfalls echo there as in a mountain tomb and the whole aspect, somehow, is of haunted emptiness.
There is "no moral basis" for making public intoxication a violation of law, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh asserted yesterday in a report on the judicial approach to the problem of alcoholism.

OTTAWA, Feb. 24--When a youngster throws a temper tantrum, openly defies his parents, starts lying or stealing, wellmeaning observers in this psychiatryminded age are likely to advise: Get professional help.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 27 --Frank Hurt, 18-year-old skier from Middlebury College, won the men's division of the fourth annual MacKenzie combined downhill and slalom race on Whiteface mountain today. Hurt had a time of 1 minute 4.5 seconds for the two events.
Major changes in the direction of Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)-- A call for a firm American policy based on the independent sovereignty of the United States in a peaceful world community of free nations was made today. The appeal was issued by the Committee of Endorsers of a Program to Govern Our Foreign Relations.

IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich., Feb. 27--The United States will be represented by the youngest Olympic ski jumping team ever to wear its colors when the international winter games are held at Cortina, Italy, next January.
The methods now used in preparing and administering the city's huge expense budgets were defended yesterday by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP)--The New York Yankees announced today that Pitcher Ewell Blackwell had asked for reinstatement and that the request had been granted.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 27 (AP)--Bill Disney of Pasadena, Calif., and Jay Hasbrouck of Newburgh, N. Y., today shared the senior men's title of the national indoor speed skating tournament.

An item of news from Central America that was more significant than it looked was the word from Tegucigalpa, capital of Honduras, that a basic labor code had been signed by Julio Lozano Diaz, the Chief of State. It went into effect Feb. 17.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 27-- The Foreign Ministers of Turkey, Greece and Yugoslavia will meet here tomorrow to take the political temperature of their tripartite alliance.

BAYONNE, N. J., Feb. 27-- Although still far from becoming a ghost city, Bayonne today is on the ropes economically. Some industries have moved out. Others are cutting down their operations in a period of post-war retrenchment.

The announced intention of Republican legislative leaders at Albany to sponsor a bill to regulate labor union welfare funds is both expected and welcome; expected because of the recommendations made last year by the Insurance Department under the Dewey-appointed Superintendent Bohlinger, welcome because the recommendations are sound.

SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) --Betty Jameson of San Antonio mixed spectacular chipping and steady putting to shoot a 73 today for a total of 285 in winning the 72-hole Sarasota women's open golf tournament by two strokes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Our ever-present need for used clothing has become acute and the Gouverneur Hospital Social Service Committee hopes some of your readers who have always been most helpful will again send contributions.

The First Bank Stock Corporation, holding company for seventy-five banks in Minnesota, Montana and North and South Dakota, is offering 361,922 new shares of capital stock to its shareholders for subscription at $31.50 a share. One share may be bought for each eight held.
Four noteworthy developments marked the history of the New York Stock Exchange in 1954, Keith Funston, its president, declared in the annual report issued for release today.
The man who has done more waterfront arguing than any other shipping official in the Port of New York has resigned his post.

MIAMI, Feb. 27--Eddie Arcaro stepped out of the shower room at Hialeah's jockey quarters late yesterday afternoon. He was wearing nothing but a towel and a wide grin. The claim of foul, which Ted Atkinson had lodged against Arcaro and Nashua after the thrilling Flamingo Stakes, had been disallowed.

Ski teams at schools in Massachusetts and Connecticut have gone through one of the most tantalizing winters in history. There has been A scarcity of snow on their campuses. As a result, the would-be skiers have spent most of the season skating and engaging in cross-country runs.

Two current news stories that really emanate from Red China are extraordinarily contradictory. The British Government has published an official document (not Parliamentary and therefore not privileged) that gives the details of the abuse of British prisoners by the Chinese Communists.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Favored Canada and Russia continued their domination of the world ice hockey championship tonight as each turned in its third victory, but the United States remained in contention with its second triumph in three games.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Feb. 27--The efforts of the rectors and academic senates of most West German universities to check or suppress the rebirth of dueling fraternities has been almost entirely frustrated.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 --Robert Ryan will appear with Clark Gable in "The Tall Men," which Twentieth Century-Fox will start filming March 7. Jane Russell also will co-star.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved within a narrow trading range last week with mixed net changes at the close. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange finished from 70 cents a bale Wgher to 45 cents lower than the previous week.
A new collection of children's spring clothes at Macy's should satisfy the most fashion-conscious youngster in New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- President Eisenhower is finding that the middle of the road is a dangerous place in heavy traffic.
A new civic group, the Committee for Modern Courts, made its appearance yesterday with the aim of improving administration of justice in this state.
SINGAPORE, Feb, 27--New Zealand may soon send ground troops and air units to help fight Communist guerrillas in Malaya.

With baseball's spring training camps opening tomorrow, "Omnibus" has scheduled for next Sunday an American opera based on a famous legendary player. He is known only as Casey, a name that will live on and on among some admirers of epic poetry but never in Baseball's Hall of Fame.
Junior-sized customers, Franklin Simon predicts, will like the long-torso, full-skirted look for spring. The store offers this style in a number of fashions sized 7-15.
A half century of progress toward a new spirit of brotherhood in the United States was summed up here yesterday by Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

ROME, Monday, Feb. 28--A Government crisis was averted early today. AH factions in the National Council of the Liberal party buried their animosities to permit Liberal Ministers to remain in Premier Mario Scelba's coalition Cabinet.

When the Bethlehem Steel Corporation completes an expansion program next year the company's capacity to produce "light" steel finished items will be more than quadruple what it was twenty-five years ago.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- The grain and soybean futures markets were swamped by successive waves of liquidating sales the past week. Prices crumbled as the selling pressure increased.

Renata Tebaldi, soprano: Mario del Monaco, tenor, and Ettore Bastianini, baritone, made a joint appearance in concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening. The event had been postponed one week because of an indisposition on Miss Tebaldi's part.

ALBANY, Feb. 27--Mayor Wagner asked the Legislature today to reject two proposals that he said would weaken the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York. Most of the subscribers to the plan, a private nonprofit organization, are city employes.

The Montreal Canadiens, striking for three goals in 31 seconds, humbled the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, 7 to 1. The Broadway Blues were trailing only by 2--1 when the blow struck in the third period.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27--New steel business rose last week. In nany cases it exceeded the capacity of the mills.
TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 28 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama's conservative Government appeared certain today to remain in power on the basis of returns from yesterday's election.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, Feb. 26--In its daily probing of the atmosphere this U. S. Navy Antarctic expedition has recorded a temperature 120.3 degrees below zero Fahrenheit. It was not found over the polar icecap but near the Equator.

Wes Santee, Mal Whitfield, Harrison Dillard, Horace Ashenfelter, Bob Richards and track and field's other headliners will rendezvous at Madison Square Garden for the last time this winter in the New York chapter Knights of Columbus games on Saturday.
PARIS, Feb. 27--The prospect of substantial reserves of oil in France has sparked a wide and coordinated search over much of this country and sent oil stocks on the Bourse to a record high.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27--Red flags n profusion were flying all over Moscow today. The Soviet capital was, so to speak, celebrating Election Day along with all other cities, towns and villages in eleven of the sixteen Soviet Union republics.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 27-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon arrived from St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, today and was greeted by a nineteen-gun salute.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Hoover Commission's twentynine recommendations on Federal medical services were based on a report by a task force that worked under two chairmen.

A DEBUT recital was played at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon by a young pianist of unusual promise, Heinz Hammerman. A native of Vienna. Mr. Hammerman came to this country in 1947 and was naturalized in 1952.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)-- A "prompt and thorough" investigation by the Interstate Commerce Commission of reported plans to consolidate the Boston and Maine Railroad and the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad under a single management has been asked by the two Massachusetts Senators. They are Leverett Saltonstall, Republican, and John F. Kennedy, Democrat.

The Travelers Aid Society of New York is celebrating this winter the fiftieth anniversary of its incorporation. For half a century the society's representatives have stood at the city's railroad stations, bus terminals, piers and, more recently, the International Airport at Idlewild, ready to help very young and very old travelers, as well as the sick and the confused, to reach as happily as possible their eventual destinations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Following are excerpts from the report of the (Hoover) Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government on Federal Medical Services: Chapter I Federal Health Services The Federal Government has undertaken a large measure of responsibility to protect the health of the whole 160,000,000 people in the nation.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 27--The United Jewish Appeal started its 1955 campaign here today with $17,650,000 in individual donations.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 27-- In preparation for possible large bombing raids by the Chinese Communists, the City Government here has set up a special committee to store food.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government is a twelvemember body headed by former President Hoover. It was created by Congress in 1953. It is the second commission on Government organization headed by Mr. Hoover.
PARIS, Feb. 27--Franco-German trade negotiations that began before the formation of the new Government in France will now be pushed. The aim is rapid agreement on a new pact to cover three years.

LONDON, Feb. 27--To say that the City was shocked by the decision to raise the bank rate 1 per cent to 4 1/2 per cent, and by other accompanying changes in official financial policy, describes its reactions but mildly. Temporarily, at all events, it was dismayed.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 27--The United Nations drew a picture today of a world economy steadily expanding since World War II.
Shunning pretension, tonight's opening at the President bears the label of "Shoestring Revue." It will start demonstrating its wares at 8 P. M.

RICHARD STRAUSS' composite chamber comedyopera, "Ariadne on Naxos," or, rather, a singular version thereof, was presented for the first time on television by the N. B. C. Opera Theatre yesterday afternoon.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27--A vast system of community colleges, to be built within commuting distance of every high school graduate who wants a college education, was proposed here today.
One of every twelve pupils m the city's elementary schools does not receive a full day's schooling.

The report of the Presidential Advisory Committee on Energy Supplies and Resources Policy deserves wide attention and careful scrutiny. A sound national policy with regard to fuel supplies is of great importance, yet the formulation of such a policy raises intricate and controversial problems affecting not only our domestic economy but also our foreign policy.
LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Prime Minister Churchill is being challenged to offer a law that would gag broadcasting.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Aug. 7, 1953, the Refugee Relief Act became effective. Ostensibly it was to be a great humanitarian gesture to permit 214,000 refugees, escapees, expellees, and orphans to enter the United States as non-quota immigrants.
Net income of the Armstrong Cork Company last year increased to $11,913,676 from the 1953 net of $9,24,978, and was the second highest on record, according to the annual report.
A proposal under which private capital would build city schools as part of new business skyscrapers and apartment houses is being studied by Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate.
OTTAWA, Feb. 27--The Canadian dollar is showing a remarkable affinity for parity with United States currency.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The United States has begun a counteroffensive against Soviet "cultural propaganda."

ELOISE POLK, a young pianist from St. Louis, made her debut yesterday afternoon in Town Hall with a rather unusual program. She devoted the first half to Mozart, playing the D minor Fantasy, Sonata in D (K. 576) and "Under dummer Pobel meint" Variations.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 27-- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States was prepared to defend Laos with air and sea power against any Communist invasion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) --Two top Congressional Red hunters said today that they were convinced that Harvey Matusow had told the truth when he first appeared before Congress and the courts as a Government informer.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra opened its United States tour here today with music of the German masters and a packed house in Constitution Hall.
The church was described yesterday as the world's best organized opportunity for investment.

NEW YORK audiences got a foretaste of Tuesday's Berlin Philharmonic program when Remus Tzincoca, last night in Carnegie Hall, led members of the New York PhilharmonicSymphony through Beethoven's Fifth Symphony and Wagner's Prelude and "Liebestod" from "Tristan und Isolde."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)-- The Senate Banking Committee reported today that most persons responding to its questionnaire about the stock market felt "there was no danger in present market levels."

Although a few doubts and misgivings, and not a little domestic politics, were reflected in the votes by which the West German Bundestag ratified the Paris agreements yesterday, the news, on the whole, was good. It was better, indeed, than some had expected.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Hoover Commission diagnosed the present state of Federal health services today as a chaotic condition suffering from waste and duplication.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having enjoyed a front on-thespot seat as the befuddled in 1946 sought to discount and disparage our real friends in China and turn that vast area over to the Chinese Communists. I read and listen, with considerable interest, as Senator Wayne Morse and others advocate turning Formosa over to the United Nations for disposal.
The Rev. Frederick Burgess announced yesterday his intention to retire next Jan. 1 as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy, 26 West Eightyfourth Street.

THE boom in jazz is producing some hep disk jockeys. With competition from television playing hob with the old schedules of radio, the sound broadcasters are giving increased time on the air to a new breed of record spinners.

Lord Dunsany, the Irish author, arrived in New York last Thursday on one of his frequent visits to this country. After delivering a talk at the Library of Congress in Washington today, he plans a leisurely lecturing tour. He expects to return home on June 8.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--In what is beginning to seem the distant past of twentieth century American politics, the oldest young man in the Republican party came out of Minnesota to bid for prominence in national affairs.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 27 --The 1954 report of the Swiss National Bank demonstrates the soundness of the Swiss economy, characterized by profitable trading and the maintenance of full employment.

The Swiss Football Club of the German-American League defeated the Hakoah eleven of the American League, 3--2, at the Brooklyn Soccer Field yesterday. The setback eliminated Hakoah from the National Challenge Cup series.
When Wesley C. Mitchell in 1927 brought out his study, "Business Cycles: The Problem and the Setting," it became almost overnight the standard reference work on the subject.
PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Feb. 27--A young man recently discharged from the Army as the sole support of his mother wounded her critically this morning and shot and killed himself.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 27-- Ratification of the Paris agreements on arming and the Saar was completed tonight in the Bundestag.

When the leader of Tammany Hall comes forward with a reform that can only weaken the power of machine politicians New Yorkers may be pardoned for feeling the way some old Trojans felt when the Greeks came bearing gifts.

Barring a small minority of dissent, the approval of the Paris pacts by the decisive lower houses of both the German and French Parliaments has been hailed with gratification throughout the Western World as another long step toward greater European unity and stronger Western defense.
