MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 1 (AP)--Dr. Pontecorvo said he had decided to make his statement, which had the effect of telling the world where he was, because "the atomic threat hanging over the world forces me as a scientist having relations with atomic problems to make the present statement."

Usually infallible, the fifth edition of Webster's Collegiate Dictionary is wrong on poached eggs. It says that "to poach" is "to cook in boiling water . . . as a poached egg." But culinary experts agree that the proper way to poach eggs is to cook them in liquid just below the boiling point.

TRENTON, Feb. 28--The Republican -dominated New Jersey Legislature is expected to relinquish, at least for the next eight months, its weekly televised report to the electorate, it was learned here today.

The advent of the Committee for Modern Courts, dedicated to the proposition that the courts of New York are in urgent need of thoroughgoing reconstruction, is welcome news indeed. Litigants, bedeviled, often for years, by the intricacies and delays of justice, well know the need for reform.

Six veterans' organizations announced yesterday the combining of their fund-raising activities in New York County. Spokesmen said that if the project were successful, it might do away with the street sales of poppies.

Two things stand out immediately from the election returns in Japan. Premier Hatoyama and his Democrats will be back in power. With the support of the equally conservative Liberals he will have a good working majority. On the other hand, the two Socialist groups-- with an assist from the Communists --have made enough gains to block constitutional amendments, since these require a two-thirds vote.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 28-- With neither a holdout nor an injured player to disturb the general outlook, the Giants began assembling today for the launching of the 1955 training campaign.
PARIS, Feb. 25--The wares displayed at the twenty-fourth Salon des Arts Managers here would leave the American, housewife envious only when it comes to antique furnishings and foods.
Two "brainwashed" Americans, just released from Communist prison camps, typify one aspect of an unresolved problem.
PARIS, Feb. 28 (AP)--Charles Humez, France's European middleweight champion, tonight stopped Pierre Langlois, his longtime rival in 2:31 of the fifth round.
Albert (Jack) Johnson defeated James Dear of England, 3 sets to 1, in the second block of their match for the world open court tennis championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28-- President Eisenhower acclaimed the opening of the Inter-American Investment Conference here yesterday as evidence of the ripening of the relationship between the United States and Latin America from that of "good neighbor" to that of "good partner."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter charged today that Edward J. Corsi, new State Department consultant on refugee problems, had been associated with two organizations he termed Red.
The New York Knickerbockers will meet the Syracuse Nationals, Eastern Division pace-setters, in the second game of the National Basketball Association double-header tonight at Madison Square Garden.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--The Legislature's investigation of illegal wiretapping got under way today.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams declared yesterday that salaries of policemen here were so "shamefully" low as to "invite corruption."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 --"On the Waterfront" scored another triumph tonight when its author, Budd Schulberg, was cited by screen division members of the Writers Guild of America for having turned out the "best written American drama" produced in 1954.

THE GOVERNOR Vetoed a bill providing for transfer of cases from City Court of New York to lower court. Signed three bills including one permitting deer hunting with long bow in Westchester County again this year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Saleble hogs 13,000 bead: market slow, butchers and sows unevenly 25c to 50c lower than last Friday's average: bulk of sales of butchers 190 to 230 pounds, $15.75

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Federal Judge Henry A. Schweinhaut today ordered the State Department to grant William Clark of Princeton, N. J., who was dismissed in 1953 as Chief Justice of United States courts in Germany, a hearing on his attempt to obtain a passport.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- A union leader accused Congressional investigators of "union busting" and using "paid liars" today.

THE music world has its mergers, too. Some time ago two groups dedicated to the cause of contemporary music merged, and came up with a name worth trying for size on a check or headline: The League of Composers-- International Society for contemporary Music, United States Section, Inc.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28--College officials took it on the chin again this morning.
Spokesmen for the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange said yesterday that it had consented to the order "to avoid the trouble and expense of further proceedings."

Railroad freight rates did not kill the cock robin of the coal trade, according to Edgar V. Hill, chairman of the Traffic Executives Association of the Eastern Railroads. And an exhibit purporting to name the five factors that were the guilty ones was issued yesterday by Mr. Hill to support his assertion.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We are grateful to you for the editorial of The New York Times of Feb. 12 "Rubbish and Fires." It takes its place beside several other recent editorials in which you have, I believe, quite effectively shown the way to practical fire prevention.

The 1955 Red Cross fund-raising campaign for the New York chapter starts today with a parade from the Battery to City Hall. Floats and bloodmobiles will dramatize for us the work the Red Cross does and its need for money with which to do it.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 28--St. Francis of Brooklyn defeated St. Peter's, 63-55, in a semi-final game of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics District 31 basketball tournament at the Dickinson High School gymnasium tonight.
The steel industry turned out 2,191,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last week--more than in any week since early in June, 1953, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Hoboken's first big new pier in twenty-five years will be opened to world commerce today under the house flag of American Export Lines.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28--Mental health specialists are reducing antagonisms among school children. However, the specialists are finding it harder to get along among themselves.

Day Not There Today is, of course, the day which isn't there. The calendar page may call it March 1, but that is no more than a bookkeeper's error. Glance forward to 1956 and the same day will be Feb. 29, glance back to '52.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 28 (AP) --The State Times, a new afternoon daily newspaper, rolled from the press at 11:30 A. M. today.
CAIRO, Tuesday, March 1-- An Egyptian spokesman said that Israeli forces killed thirtyseven Egyptians and wounded twenty-nine others in an attack in the Gaza area last night.

A site of 16,000 square feet at 209-223 East Fifty-third Street has been assembled for an apartment house by the Sprain Construction, Inc., of Which Robert Beckley is vice president. The latest acquisition is the five-story building at No. 233 which was purchased from Philip Hoffman through Leo J. Tevlin, broker.
Operations of the American Enka Corporation last year

Jack Frieman has purchased the five-story apartment house accommodating forty-six families at 311 Seventy-ninth Street in North Bergen, N. J., from the Broadrock Realty Company. The C. B. Snyder Organizations were the brokers and the attorneys were Seymour Jacobs for the buyer and Ben Osherov for the seller.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Thirteen convicted Communist leaders failed today to win a Supreme Court hearing on the ground that Harvey Matusow had given false testimony a their trial.
ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, Feb. 27--Recording devices aboard this ship have completed a survey of cosmic rays from the Arctic to the Antarctic.

LONDON, Feb. 28--Sir Winston Churchill received an unusual picture of himself in action today. The Parliamentary Press Gallery presented to the Prime Minister a watercolor by Edward Ardizzone. The picture shows Sir Winston in a characteristic pose at a dispatch box in the House of Commons with Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden, Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler and Defense Minister Harold Macmillan seated on the front bench.
ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- William Wilson of New York was reappointed to the State Power Authority today by Governor Harriman.
A veteran secret police official, Col. Gen. A. P. Zavenyagin, appears to have taken charge of Soviet nuclear weapons production as a result of the Moscow Cabinet shuffle.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange had agreed to halt practices that the agency charged had helped to raise coffee prices.
The scrap over exports of scrap metal spread yesterday to a third type of secondary metal--scrap aluminum.
Active cotton futures declined 13 to 19 points a pound (65 to 95 cents a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Slate Department cold-shouldered today a Burmese suggestion that the United States send an unofficial mission to Communist China to discuss imprisoned United States fliers.

Three new security issues totaling $30,250,000 will be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates. The bulk of the new offerings will consist of securities of the May Department Stores Company and Calumet Hecla, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Senate Finance Committee put off today for twenty-four hours a vote on a $20 income tax cut passed last week by the House.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The United States and Canada exchanged letters today intended to rule out any duplication of effort in the construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

In 1927, Andre Siegfried, French economist and historian, published his book "America Comes of Age." He has written a new volume reassessing the American scene in the light of our emergence as a leading world power.
DETROIT, Feb. 28--The General Motors Corporation said today that it had made "outstanding progress" in its efforts to stabilize employment.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 --Hal Roach Jr., television and theatrical film producer, became sole owner today of the eighteenacre Hal Roach Studios in Culver City.
TOKYO, Feb. 28--Premier Ichiro Hatoyama received assurances of support today from the chief rival party in the new Parliament to be formed as a result of the election Sunday.
BELIEVE it or not, there is a lot of talent in the "Shoestring Revue," which opened at the President last evening.

GARY GRAFFMAN, gifted young American pianist who already has appeared here with two orchestras this season, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. He played nothing but substantial works, and in all of them he combined expressiveness with technical mastery.
BOSTON, Feb. 28--A legislative committee went through the motions today of hearing arguments on a bill that was doomed.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (Reuters) --Great Britain was threatened with another disastrous dock strike today when negotiations broke down in an overtime dispute, main issue in a damaging twenty-nine-day stoppage last fall.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 1 --Prof. Bruno Pontecorvo, a top British atomic scientist who disappeared in 1950, has been in the Soviet Union for several years, the newspapers Pravda and Izvestia disclosed today.
Three more years of peaceful labor relations in the city's biggest industry appeared assured last night.
Two Montreal stock dealers were permanently barred yesterday from securities business in the State of New York.
A $13,210,721 contract for building and installing sixteen generators for the St. Lawrence power project was signed here yesterday by the State Power Authority and the General Electric Company.
A Brooklyn couple were sentenced yesterday to six-month prison terms as owners of a television repair service that carried on fraudulent practices.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 28 (AP) --Iowa subdued Minnesota, 7270, tonight to clinch at least a tie for the Big Ten basketball title. A crowd of 20,176, the largest gathering to watch a game in a college arena, saw the Hawkeyes rally to win.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 28-- Vice Chancellor Franz Bluecher, one of the four Free Democratic ministers in the West German Cabinet, offered his resignation today.
THE PRESIDENT Backed the Red Cross fund campaign. Conferred with Admiral Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs. Conferred with his economic advisers.

THE Sportsmen's Council of the Marine District of New York has not, as many believe, abandoned the fight to prevent the pollution of coastal waters. It has been assembling its forces and gathering data to support Congressional action.

Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier" has been selected to open the new season of the New York City Opera at the City Center on Thursday, March 17. It will be conducted by Joseph Rosenstock, the company's general director.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Long liquidation and local selling were the dominant factors in the grain market today. Corn sold at new lows, and new low marks were registered also for May, July and September soybeans.

THE Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors, which last month showed work by its painter members, yesterday opened the second section of the annual exhibition, devoted to work by sculptors, at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. Work by fifteen artists makes up the highly diverse display.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--Governor Harriman has thrown his support behind the Jockey Club's plan for a new super-track in New York City area.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Senate and House of Representatives conferees agreed unanimously today on a 50 per cent increase in Congressional pay without extra benefits.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- James David Preston, who has seen hundreds of Senators "retired" by the public, retired himself today.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y. Feb. 28--This "Queen City of Long Island Sound" is being cut in two by an $18,000,000 incision.
Bob Baker, Pittsburgh heavyweight, extended his winning streak to eight by gaining a unanimous decision over Rex Layne of Lewiston, Utah, at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--A 17-year-old physicist-mathematicianchemist, Frederick P. Greenleaf of Allentown, Pa., received tonight the $2,800 Westinghouse Grand Science Scholarship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Total silence prevails in the neighborhood of Senator George of Georgia over the Supreme Court decision in the so-called Capps case. The silence strongly implies the Senator was not impressed by the argument that this decision should prompt him to renew at this session pressure for his substitute for the Bricker amendment that failed of passage last time by only one vote.
Control of the welfare fund once ruled by Thomas F. Lewis, slain labor boss of the Yonkers Raceway, was returned yesterday to the local union that he headed.
Most coffee options fell the 2cent-a-pound daily limit during trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
The consent order announced by the Federal Trade Commission yesterday may change the price structure of coffee--to the benefit of roasters and consumers alike.
KREFELD, Germany, Feb. 28 (AP)--The United States hockey team scored four goals in the third period tonight to defeat Switzerland, 7-3, in the world ice hockey championship.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has called for the record of last week's legislative committee hearings on charity frauds. After examining it he will decide whether to prosecute officers of organizations who allegedly diverted to Communist purposes money collected ostensibly for worthy causes.
WHITE PLAINS. N. Y., Feb. 28--State funds for modernization of the Westchester parkway route from the Bronx to Connecticut were asked unanimously this afternoon by the County Board of Supervisors.
Large corporations will go on decentralizing management despite increasing use of "electronic brains," Don G. Mitchell declared yesterday.
SINGAPORE, Feb. 28--Sir Anthony Eden flew in a helicopter from Kuala Lumpur today to a jungle fort deep in the rugged interior of the near-by State of Negri Sembilan.
At the end of the first month of the school term last fall Public School 188 in Queens had the unenviable distinction of being the most overcrowded school in the city.
Stocks rolled forward yesterday in a relatively quiet session.
Dudley B. Bonsal, an attorney here since 1932, will head a special study of the Federal loyaltysecurity program for the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

The formation of what was described as an advertising agency specializing in a fashion approach to men's apparel was announced yesterday by E. A. Korchnoy, whose concern, E. A. Korchnoy, Ltd., will begin operations today at 10 East Fortyninth Street.
The volume of new bonds publicly offered here in February declined sharply from the month before but stock flotations increased. Both classes of offerings were larger than in February, 1954.
LONDON, Feb. 28--J. R. Campbell, editor of The London Daily Worker, asserted tonight that the newspaper had fabricated from a Moscow radio broadcast what looked like a London "scoop."
Criminal and civil action against a milk drivers' local was threatened yesterday by a group of welfare leaders.
Charles Chaplin has severed his last connection with the American film Industry by selling to United Artists his 25 per cent interest in that company.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Feb. 27--The prospective integration of West German forces into European defense poses a geographical question to which the planners at the Supreme Headquarters here have not yet found the answer.
MIAMI, Feb. 28--Someone in the Hialeah press box had tossed a casual remark over his shoulder.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 1 --Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin, who became chief of the Soviet Government three weeks ago today, has reorganized the upper level of his Cabinet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 --A union was penalized today for failing to show that it had given its financial reports to the members.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28--On the eve of the official start of spring training, Casey Stengel today predicted a one, two finish for his 1955 Yankees. In everyday parlance this means Stengel looks for his former world champions to finish no lower than second in the American League race this year.
LONDON, Feb. 28--The stock market started the week buoyantly today under the influence of British Government securities.

To the surprise of the New York Stock Exchange, which has just conducted another survey of public opinion about the market, 49 per cent of upper-income investors who own stocks believe that Federal taxes have no effect on their investment decisions.
HARTFORD, Feb. 28--Republican control of twelve major state departments ended at midnight tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- Mrs. Alice K. Leopold, assistant for women's affairs to the Secretary of Labor, today announced a two-day conference to reappraise women's place in employment.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The Supreme Court refused today to hear a case that challenged the constitutionality of an international treaty.
Moscow's concern about nuclear physics goes back to before the outbreak of World War II.
The Columbia Broadcasting System's public affairs department, which normally thinks in terms of adults rather than children, is planning a project especially for the younger folk.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (Reuters) --Elegant furniture of the opulent Regency period competed for attention at Britain's biggest home show here today with the latest in multi-colored plastics, household fabrics and electronic kitchen magic.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28--The Thor Corporation, once one of the country's leading makers of washing machines, announced today it would close and sell its main manufacturing plant in Cicero, Ill.

PARIS, Feb. 28--The reservations expressed by the West German Bundestag yesterday concerning the Saar do not alter the accord reached between Bonn and Paris last October, Foreign Ministry officials said today.
ALBANY, Feb. 28--Governor Harriman vetoed a bill today on the ground that it defeated its purpose.
Ibsen's "The Master Builder," in a new adaptation by Max Faber, opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Phoenix Theatre, Second Avenue and Twelfth Street.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 28--Ingrid Bergman is so incensed at what she terms the caddish treatment she has received from the Swedish press, that she has resolved to never again set foot in Sweden after the present run of "Joan of Arc at the Stake" ends in midMarch.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Commissioner Ford Frick fined the Milwaukee Baseball Club $500 and fourteen of the club's players smaller amounts today for violation of the March 1 spring training deadline.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28-- The Government made public today the largest budget in India's history.
The New York State Supreme Court yesterday held, in effect, that authorized broadcasts of a baseball game do not constitute news in the public domain.

MIAMI, Feb. 28 (AP)--For the third time this winter, the Belair Stud's Ambient was beaten as an odds-on choice. He finished third to Mandil and Mr. Al L. in the Gold Coast Purse at Hialeah Park today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt warned today that there was danger of the United Nations technical assistance program ending in May.

PARIS, Feb. 28--It is agreed here, as well as in Bonn, that the coalition of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has been weakened by the struggle over ratification of the Paris and Saar agreements. This is an adverse factor for the union of Europe.
GENEVA, Feb. 28 -- The United States is virtually assured of the one thing it had to have to open the way for United States adherence to the revised General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The State Department has advised protesters against the American appearance of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra that all legal requirements for admission to this country had been met.
An "Inspiration Gala" will be held tomorrow night at the Brooklyn Museum. It will honor a woman who believed museum pieces should lead an active life and even influence the future.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Defense Department requested today a draft of 8,000 men in April for the Army. This is the lowest call since the beginning of the Korean war in 1950.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 --The first press conference held today by Walter (Smokey) Alston, the Dodgers' manager, was marked by the absence of all other Brooklyn club officials. Last spring, when Alston was starting his freshman year, no conference was staged without practically all other Brooklyn officials being present.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28 (UP)--The Soviet Union warned Britain again tonight that British-supported armament of West Germany would nullify the BritishSoviet friendship treaty of 1942.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 28-- Secretary of State Dulles paid a lively seven-hour visit today to the Kingdom of Cambodia. There, where ornate palaces and Buddhist temples contrast with the simple houses and simple lives of the peaceful farm folk, he conferred with the King.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a seaman could make a ship "unseaworthy."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm prices increased four-tenths of 1 per cent during the month ended Feb. 15.

Fifteen hundred persons attended a rally of the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross in the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn yesterday. The 1955 fund-raising campaign of the New York Chapter begins today with a parade from the Battery to City Hall.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Anti-American feeling in Europe has eased noticeably during the past few months. During the past four years this writer has traveled over the Continent, constantly meeting persons of many walks of life and of most nations in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Supreme Court ruled today in a 6-to-2 decision that the Securities and Exchange Commission had jurisdiction over fees paid in public utility reorganization proceedings.

RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 28--Premier U Nu announced today that Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier, was willing to receive an unofficial United States mission to discuss the case of imprisoned American airmen. The mission would also discuss other tensions between Washington and Peiping.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Harvey Matusow, bristling with anger, leveled accusations against some leading recanted Communists today.
WHEN Elmer Davis' "But We Were Born Free" developed into a surprise best-seller last spring a great many people were enormously gratified.

The overcrowded school and the under-used school are two problems that march side by side in New York City, reflecting in part the failure to anticipate quickly enough where new plant will be needed and in part the depopulation of certain older areas.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in February was the smallest since last October, as a result of the fewer number of business days. Sales, however, were the largest for any February since 1936.

ALBANY, Feb. 28--Republican lawmakers decided today to prune $17,600,000 from Governor Harriman's $1,345,000,000 budget. At the same time they announced there would be no further increases in state taxes this year. This meant that a $17,200,000 corporate franchise tax increase requested by the Governor would be rejected.
HONG KONG, Feb. 28--Two Americans who came out of a Chinese Communist jail praising the Communists held to their ideological views today after twenty-four hours of freedom in British Hong Kong.

IBSEN'S "The Master Builder" has restored the Phoenix Theatre to art. As acted in Second Avenue last evening, "The Master Builder" turns out to be the best of this season's Phoenix productions and one of the best of the Phoenix's career.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1-- The Giants officially launched their 1955 training season today. Leo Durocher declared this "camera day" and the result was a field day ail around.
NEW ORLEANS, March 1-- The Inter-American Investment Conference took note today of the fact that North American investors are taking more capital out of Latin America than they are putting back.

Plans for the purchase of the First National Bank of New York by the National City Bank of New York were announced yesterday. The boards of directors of both institutions were reported to have approved the merger proposal.

"CAMERA THREE" is a local program that genuinely fulfills the role of an experimental workshop in television. Its current project-- an insight into the strange and mysterious world of Edgar Allan Poe--is among its best efforts--an exciting and reassuring illustration of what can be done in TV with little money and lots of imagination.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- Universal has scheduled a modernized treatment of the Luigi Pirandello play, "As Before, Better Than Before," for production this month.
New York City's ten big department stores did a shade better last month than in the like month last year. A survey by The New York Times found that sales were up 1 per cent.

Never let it be said that Howard Greer followed Paris. There isn't a straight line in his entire collection. This California designer is a great advocate of flattering the female figure and, as seen yesterday at Jay Thorpe, is still master of the curving silhouette.

A time lag of several years in declassifying atomic information was charged against the Federal Government yesterday. It was described as "seriously delaying the full development of atomic energy for civilian uses."
WASHINGTON, March 1-- Congress gave final approval today to a bill raising its own pay by 50 per cent.
This is mostly about a fellow who has fired 250,000 rounds of pistol ammunition without ever hitting anything but himself -- once.
Legs of lamb now available at 53 to 75 cents a pound are of the heavier weights that present a problem to most shoppers. For the average family, a nine-pound lamb leg is just too much meat.

Samuel Davis, Manhattan Democrat, introduced legislation in the City Council yesterday to ban the use of hand trucks on sidewalks for commercial purposes. The proposed law was referred to the Committee on General Welfare.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with the greatest attention the editorial entitled "Inflation in Chile," appearing in your Feb. 26 edition. The editorial contains a dramatic exposition of the economic and political difficulties through which Chile is passing at this time.

SINGAPORE, March 1--Britain evidently considers that the strategic frontier of Southeast Asia lies in the extreme south of Thailand. There, across the narrow Kra Isthmus just above Malaya's border, Commonwealth troops would make their stand if Peiping invades the Manila pact area.

The one-story taxpayer at 33-01 Thirtieth Avenue in Astoria, Queens, has been sold by Helen Sarnoff Sanders to the Eastford Management Company, an investing syndicate represented by Korotkin Oppenheim, attorneys.
WASHINGTON, March 1--The Government revised and shortened its lists of essential activities and critical occupations today. They reflect changes in the economic and military situation since 1950.

AS is usually the case during the busy winter season, the variety of exhibitions makes generalizations well nigh impossible. That they are all, in one way or another, contemporary is often the sole link discernible.
Two leading trade associations in the maritime field have announced appointments to toplevel posts.

ALBANY, March 1 (AP)--The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions: Bearpen Mountain--8-40 inches old snow; skiing fair. Cooperstown--3-12 inches wet; fair. Kiamesha Lake (Concord)--10-15 inches machine-made; poor.

Public offering of four new security issues aggregating $83,925,000 will be made today by underwriting syndicates. The sale of $60,000,000 of convertible debentures of the Union Oil Company of California will account for the major portion of today's offerings.
ALBANY, March 1--The Board of Regents charged today that the state scholarship program "fails utterly to meet the requirements of our young people for higher education."
WASHINGTON, March 1--The Secretary of Labor and the president of the American Federation of Labor ate roast turkey today in a try for better relations.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- A split in the cotton industry over disposal of surplus cotton was spread across the record of a Senate subcommittee today.
Guests sitting down to the $50a-plate Escoffier memorial dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel March 14 may be sure the menu has the approval of an exacting group of chefs and gourmets.

Six leaders of the United States Communist party were released from Federal penitentiaries yesterday. They had each served forty months of five-year sentences for having conspired to advocate the violent overthrow of the government.

We should like to believe that our New York Legislature had the political courage, the good sense and the open-mindedness to bring three major issues out on the floor for debate and a vote at this session. There is reported to be considerable doubt that any will get out of committee in either branch or both.

The Inter-American Investment Conference now being held in New Orleans has importance far beyond the business deals it stimulates. It will help assuage the feelings of Latin Americans from the Rio Grande to Patagonia who think their self-appointed good neighbor is neglecting them for nations both more favored and more remote.

Jackie Robinson was a little annoyed about his weight. "I went to Miami to lose three pounds and instead I gained six," said Jack. "Played a lot of golf and ate too well, I guess." Robby weighed 215 on arrival here.

Sal was a young truck driver --a carefree lad of Italian parentage. Just before he started for Korea his first son was born. While he was away, the baby became desperately ill and needed seven transfusions of blood, which were supplied by the Red Cross.

Canadian retailers have decided to take a close look at buying and selling habits in the United States. Delegates to the annual conference of the Canadian Retail Federation, held in Ottawa yesterday, agreed they might well learn a profitable trick or two from their brethren in this country.

Crook-back Richard III, so dubbed by Shakespeare, may yet have his place straightened out in English history. At least that is the proposition to which an organization called Friends of Richard III, Inc., formally dedicated itself yesterday at its first membership meeting in the Sulgrave Hotel.
A new baby-sitting program for teen-age girls and children 3 to 5 years old was started yesterday. Judging by the interest and pleasure of the participants, it was a success.

Theatrical, civic and business personages gathered yesterday morning in a room of the twenty -two story structure, erected on the site of the famed Empire Theatre, where a plaque was dedicated to the former playhouse.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Camp Kilmer, N. J., has become a casualty of Army economy.

The Syracuse Nationals moved a step closer to the Eastern Division title in the National Basketball Association campaign by halting the New York Knickerbockers, 105 to 102, in the curtain -raiser of last night's doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- Bruno Pontecorvo, British atomic scientist who has been working in the Soviet Union, has $15,000 in his name at the United States Treasury.

Two more books with African backgrounds will be published this season. On March 18 Appleton -Century-Crofts will issue "Leopards in the Night," a work of non-fiction by Guy Muldoon. The author was an agricultural officer at an outpost in Nyasaland.
Table settings, displayed yesterday at the Pierre Hotel by the Irish Linen Guild, suggested some ideas that might easily be reproduced by homemakers with their own collections of table accessories.
Stocks pushed forward in early trading yesterday but many of the gains were lost by the close. The New York Times rail average, during the advance, reached its highest point since Oct. 10 1930.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1-- By the time the Yankees had concluded the first two hours of spring training today at Miller Huggins Field the thermometer was pushing 80. The athletes were perspiring freely but none complained.

LONDON, March 1--The Westbury, the first hotel to be owned and operated by an American concern in this ancient capital, was opened today. At a ceremony the hotel received the official blessing of Winthrop W. Aldrich, United States Ambassador, and of Peter Thorneycroft, President of the Board of Trade.
Deserving students will benefit from the April 12 performance of Christopher Fry's play, "The Dark is Light Enough."
NEWARK, March 1--Coordinated planning for future transportation needs in New Jersey was urged today by Perry M. Shoemaker, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.

GEORGE BALANCHINE'S "Pas de Trois (II)" had its premiere last night in the program of the New York City Ballet at the City Center, with Patricia Wilde, Melissa Hayden and Andre Eglevsky as its dancers.

NEW DELHI, India, March 1 --The United States will set up a special fund for economic development in Asia and will look to the countries of the area for the lead on how mutual aid plans should tie organized.
A 25-year-old Brooklyn furniture repairman, father of two children, was booked on a homicide charge at 1:44 A. M. today in the brutal murder of Ann Yarrow on Feb. 6.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 2--The five-nation conference on disarmament, which had been threatened by an apparent "leakage" of news to the Communist newspaper here, survived its second session yesterday and will continue for at least one more meeting.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 1-- Israeli Army headquarters here said today that an Israeli unit was attacked at 9 o'clock last night near the Egyptian armistice lines opposite Gaza and pursued the attackers into Egyptian territory.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- Limitations on exports of highquality scrap were proposed today by industry spokesmen. The limitations would go into force March 31, when current licensing regulations expire.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- Harvey Matusow said today that his former wife had told him that she once had contributed $70,000 to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
PARIS, March 1--The advisory Council of the Republic decided today to set March 22 for its debate on the Paris agreements.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- President Eisenhower today became an honorary member of a fire engine company founded in 1774 by George Washington. Today it is purely honorary and social. With the membership in the Friendship Veterans Fire Engine Company of Alexandria, Va., went a battered helmet that was worn by the chiefs of the engine company in the time of Washington.

GAZA, Egypt, March 1-- Palestinian students besieged the headquarters of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization here for one hour today. The demonstration broke out as the casualty list of attacks last night on Egyptian army units reached thirty-eight dead and thirty-three wounded.

Directors of the Robert Gair Company, Inc., manufacturer of folding cartons, shipping containers and paperboard, have approved the acquisition of the Southern Advance Bag and Paper Company, Inc., and the Great Southern Box Company, Inc.

INDIAN SPRINGS, Nev., March 1--While the rest of the world worries about escaping atomic radiation, there is a little band of men at Indian Springs Air Force Base here whose work is just the opposite.
PITTSBURGH, March 1--Only one major group of workers is still away from its jobs in the fifteen - month - old department store strike here.
DETROIT, March 1 -- The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation announced plans for new plants today.

MIAMI, March 1 (AP)--A major threat for Gulfstream Park's $100,000 added Florida Derby on March 26 loomed when Simmy sped six furlongs in a scorching 1:10 today to win the $6,000 Silver Springs at Hialeah Park before 16,969 fans.
ABOARD THE U. S. S. ATKA, Feb. 28--This ship mailed 600 letters yesterday by throwing them overboard.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) --Two Democratic Senators today endorsed John Marshal Harlan as a Supreme Court Justice and said his connection with the Council of Atlantic Union would have no adverse effect on his judicial role.
The dean of Yale Divinity School was scathingly critical last night of most religious radio and television broadcasts.
Yale University defeated the University of Virginia, 13--12, in a sudden-death overtime period in the opening game of the Intercollegiate Indoor Polo championship at the Squadron A Armory last night.
Substantially more is known here about the Soviet Union's progress in nuclear weapons and atomic energy than is generally realized.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)--The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock market follows: HOGS Salable boss 7,000 head; fairly active; bulk butchers unevenly 25c or more higher top however only steady with Monday;

Secretary Dulles has completed a visit to four countries on the Asian front line against Communist aggression. His purpose was to deliver to these countries personally a message from the Bangkok conference of the Southeast Asian collective defense organization.
PARIS, March 1--Advocates of a federal European union do not consider the Western European Union plan, just ratified by the West German Bundestag, as a step toward this union.
Mayor Wagner expressed himself yesterday as "shocked" at the "city-be-damned" attitude of the Republican legislative majorities.
The 1955 fund-raising campaign of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross began yesterday with parade from the Battery City Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Eisenhower called George W. Perkins of New York back into Government service today. He was named the United States permanent representative on the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

BUENOS AIRES, March 1 (AP)--President Juan D. Peron took control today of three Argentine provinces, superseding elected Peronista officials. The officials had come under criticism previously for failing to cooperate with other officials of the Peron Administration.
The Grand Central area as a whole was thrown open yesterday for redevelopment.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)--Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, declared here tonight that international trade was "the most effective antidote for war." If we lose the cold war, he said, "it will be because we failed to recognize the absolute necessity for applying to our foreign trade the same principles of long-term installment credit which have been the basis of our own domestic economy."
Portland, Ore., sold $8,000,000 of exposition-recreation bonds in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.0051 per cent.

The City College Department of Hygiene issued a statement yesterday acusing Dr. Buell G. Gallagher of having caused "a steady decline in the intercollegiate athletic program at the college." The charge was promptly denied by the college president.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) --A House Un-American Activities subcommittee voted unanimously today to cite John T. Gojack, union official, for contempt of Congress. He had refused to answer questions about communism.

The soft goods lines, particularly the shoe and leather industries, are beginning to assume a more normal role in the economy, according to Irving R. Glass, executive vice president of the Tanners Council of America. Speaking yesterday at the opening of the forty-sixth semiannual Leather Show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, he said that volume was improving and better quality was being stressed.

LONDON, March 1--Sir Winston Churchill said today that Britain and the United States must increase their superiority in nuclear weapons and so convince the Soviet Union that a surprise attack on the West could not prevent immediate retaliation.

LONDON, March 1--The stock markets were quieter and less active here today--the last day of a turbulent trading account. Recovery in prices as a whole made slower headway despite signs that improvement in Government funds had begun to exert a more powerful upward pull on fixed interest stocks generally.

CHICAGO, March 1--Long liquidation appeared to have run its course in the wheat market, prices moving up sharply today as shorts covered. Commission absorption also was in evidence on the theory that recent selling may have been overdone, while the steady undertone in the domestic cash markets tended to check selling.
TRENTON, March 1 --The farm price of fluid milk in New Jersey was reduced 1.8 cents a quart today by Floyd R. Hoffman, director of the State Office of Milk Industry.

St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn regained the New York Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball title with a 40-39 victory over Cardinal Hayes of the Bronx in the final play-off game at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
MANILA, March 1--Secretary of State Dulles assured Vietnam's Premier, Ngo Dinh Diem, in Saigon today that all the Allied Governments would support him in his country's fight against communism.

'Tecs and Trollope A quite learned gentleman, in truth an egghead, an intellectual, came up with a curious remark the other day. Nothing would he gained by mentioning his name, but he is a university professor, and thus is charged with directing the minds of the young into proper channels.
LONDON, March 1--Prime Minister Churchill stoutly maintained today his opposition to letting radio or television compete with Parliament as a forum for discussion of the nation's affairs.
ALBANY, March 1--Governor Harriman today nominated Charles Poletti of New York as a trustee of the State Power Authority. The nomination was immediately confirmed by the Senate.

MANILA, Wednesday, March 2--A four-day meeting of United States chiefs of mission in the Far East opened this morning with Secretary of State Dulles addressing a closed meeting of the group. It was the first time that a United States Secretary of State has ever personally attended such a regional meeting.
HILO, Hawaii, March 1 (UP)-- A "very strong earthquake," believed to be centered near the Kilauea volcanic crater, was recorded today and may be building up pressure for another eruption.

There are not many aspects in which the United Nations is really united and really a personality. It is not quite a unified personality even in the Trusteeship Council, which has been quietly discussing problems of the trust territories for some time back, and yesterday held its 587th meeting.

The Government yesterday canceled its civil claim for $2,258,350 in back income taxes against Frank Erickson, 58year-old bookmaker. Thomas E. Scanlon, Director of Internal Revenue for Brooklyn and Long Island, filed the release in Brooklyn Federal Court.

THE Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra played for the first time in New York last night, and at least within Carnegie Hall there was not only friendliness but an eager welcome. So as far as the distinguished audience seemed to be concerned, the orchestra and its conductor, Herbert von Karajan, were triumphant.

The mink is bringing fancy prices at the fur auctions these days. He and other fur mammals have increased in importance in the market place as a result of the resurgence in the fur-manufacturing industry.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Consolidated Edison Company is to be congratulated on staking out a future claim to atomic energy benefits. However, the newspaper publicity attending the announcement of Con Edison's plans to build a privately financed $40 million reactor in Peekskill is unfortunate since it may force the company into a premature and expensive adventure.

MIAMI, March 1--The most sensational young jockey on the turf today, unquestionably would be Willie Hartack-- except for one factor. That factor is another sensational young jockey, Willie Shoemaker. It makes for a rather ironic situation.
The National Broadcasting Company's radio network will revise virtually its entire weekend program schedule, beginning in the early summer, and initiate a new type of network service.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1--Egypt protested to the Security Council tonight that an "act of aggression" was committed by Israel in yesterday's border clash in the Gaza area.
Net profit of the International Harvester Company for the quarter ended Jan. 31 increased to $6,950,000 from $4,660,000 in the
ALBANY, March 1--Dr. Isador Lubin was confirmed by the Senata today as State Industrial Commissioner after dramapacked political maneuvers.

Plans for consolidating operations of the Roscoe Manufacturing Company, maker of girls' underwear, under one roof were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the twelve-story loft building at 4246 West Thirty-eighth Street.
Congested highways have focused too much attention of public officials on automobiles and not enough on transit, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.
ALBANY, March 1--The Harriman administration has begun an investigation of the Stateowned spa at Saratoga Springs.

The Waterfront Commission yesterday invited Governor Harriman and Gov. Robert B. Heyner of New Jersey to send personal observers to a labor conference today involving the controversial new port hiring rules.
There will be plenty of advertising for toys for the rest of the year. The Toy Guidance Council, Inc., industry trade group, is setting in motion a promotion plan on behalf of manufacturers.
FRANKFURT, Germany, March 1--A case on whether German industries that employed slave labor must compensate them came up for appeal today.

THE country's foremost quill man comes to town from New Haven about once a week to revive interest in old-fashioned quill pens. He is Lewis Glaser, a former cavalry officer. He is a graduate of the Illinois College of Agriculture.
ALBANY, March 1--A bill to make permanent a temporary law barring loyalty risks from state jobs involving security was introduced in the Legislature today.
WASHINGTON, March 1--A House committee studied today proposals of "basic and minimum" ethical practices designed to reform Congressional investigations.
The Health Department is preparing to give 250,000 school children here the Salk vaccine against poliomyelitis if it is proved effective.
Bonds called for redemption in February before maturity declined to $82,357,000 from $283,775,000 in January.

The trend toward earlier marriages, hailed as wholesome by most family life specialists, is complicating society's problems in at least one way, Kenneth D. Johnson, Dean of the New York School of Social Work, said yesterday.

THE possibility of a seasonal commercial fishing industry for bluefin tuna has worried sports fishermen for several years. The "exploratory" activities conducted by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has done nothing to allay these fears.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 1 --Roy Campanella gave his once-crippled left hand its first real test today and the evidence is that he passed.
CHICAGO, March 1--This has been a gloomy week for college and university officials. Today, for the third time in four days they-found themselves the target of sharp attacks.

First nighters will assemble at 8 o'clock this evening to inspect the new arrival at the Music Box, "Bus Stop." It represents William Inge's third drama, all of which found shelter on Fortyfifth Street.
Potato prices rose sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the April position gaining the 1/4cent-a-pound limit for a while.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 24 to 34 points ($1.20 to $1.70 a bale) yesterday, in one of the widest price movements in several months.

In its report exposing again the fantastic waste and chaos within the medical services of the Federal Government the Hoover Commission has laid the basis for a reform that could be of immense importance, provided the Administration and the Congress together have the political courage to carry it out.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 27--South Africa's Nationalist Government is seen as tending toward a tightly knit system in which everything that is not prohibited is made compulsory.

There is "no place to hide" domestic smoke and industrial fumes in the atmosphere, experts agreed here yesterday. They described new techniques to remove dirt and irritan's from the gases that flow out of chimney stacks.
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 1 (AP)--Wiffi Smith carded a record 68 today to win the medal in the women's South Atlantic amateur golf tournament.

The number of fathers who desert their children is "growing by leaps and bounds" and becoming a serious national problem, Federal Social Security Commissioner Charles I. Schottland said yesterday. The situation is receiving too little attention, he added, and a national conference on the subject is being considered.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- The State Department declined to say today whether it would allow a delegation of Soviet farmers and scientists to visit Iowa at the suggestion of The Des Moines Register.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- The United States has served a fresh demand on Peiping for the release of forty-one American civilians held in "unwarranted detention."
ALBANY, March 1--Major Republican revisions of Governor Harriman's $1,345,000,000 executive budget were approved today by the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 1--A representative of seventy-five Republican women leaders told President Eisenhower today that they were getting the women of the country organized to work for him in 1956.
WASHINGTON, March 1--A potato diversion program to help farmers dispose of part of their 1954 crop now in storage was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

Tall and slender women will applaud Pauline Trigere's "dandy jacket." This garment, tunic in effect, figured prominently in a showing of Miss Trigere's spring clothes presented at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday by Lord Taylor.
Un-lionlike March made its entry yesterday with none of the thunder of the imperial beast but rather like a bedraggled cat.
ALBANY, March 1--Mayor Wagner reluctantly asked the Legislature today for permission to tear down the Third Avenue Elevated.
WASHINGTON, March 1--The Senate Finance Committee voted 9 to 6 today against the Houseapproved $20-a-person income tax cut.
Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad yesterday replaced five directors who had tendered their resignations in the last two and a half months.
The Republican-controlled Legislature, was accused yesterday of attempting to emasculate the office of the State Commissioner of Investigation.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 -- Uruguay today renewed her form of government, a council on the Swiss style, for a first full elected term of four years.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) --Edward J. Corsi, State Department aide, criticized by Representative Francis E. Walter for alleged left-wing connections, asserted today that "I don't know what he's talking about."
CHICAGO, March 1--Most white Southerners are uneasy about desegregation but will accept it as a fact of life, says a sociologist.

The Federal Maritime Board approved yesterday the charter of the liner Laguardia to the recently formed Hawaiian Steamship Company, Ltd. The term is for six years, subject to an annual review of the agreement. The 17,900-gross-ton vessel will run in passenger-cargo service between San Francisco and Honolulu.

Charles Parker Davis, 6 years old, of 70 Valentine Street, Highland Park, N. J., received yesterday the silver medal of the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York for rescuing an 8-year-old chum from drowning.
NEWARK, March 2 (AP) -- Worried New Jerseyans, unaware that sirens blasting the night air were part of a practice air raid alert, flooded police and newspaper switchboards with calls tonight.

The conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra denied yesterday that he ever had been sympathetic to the principles of National Socialism. He also denied being unsympathetic to the democratic way of life in the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 2-- Hastening the modernization of the Federal interstate highway system will cut city traffic congestion, Charles D. Curtiss, United States Commissioner of Public Roads, forecast today.

CALI, Colombia, March 2-- The Colombian Government has involved itself in a fight with the press on two fronts. It is forcing all radio stations to give free time to a Government news program and it is about to publish a Government-subsidized newspaper in competition with others.
At Public School 151 in Woodside, Queens, this equation is causing a considerable stir: Three Goldsteins + three Kontoses= two sets of triplets.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- How long the Western world can sustain its superiority in atomic weapons is problematical, President Eisenhower observed today.

LONDON, March 2--The stock markets moved hesitantly and cautiously today. Fresh early gains at the start of a new trading account were not fully held and prices closed irregularly, despite the recovery in sterling and several more good company statements.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) --The White House today released most of President Eisenhower's news conference for direct quotation and public viewing.
Parents and teachers might well talk less to young persons about "taking responsibility" and do more to provide youth with opportunities for community service, Mrs. Millicent McIntosh said yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2--Three-fourths of the Yankees' infield is set. It will be a big upset if anyone displaces Andy Carey from third, Gil McDougald from second and Bill Skowron from first, Manager Casey Stengel said between workouts at Miller Huggins Field today.
LONDON, March 2 -- Twelve American girls were presented to Queen Elizabeth II today. They were among 500 debutantes who made their curtsies at an afternoon presentation at Buckingham Palace.

The awful arithmetic of the hydrogen bomb has been demonstrated to the British people in a masterly speech by Prime Minister Churchill. His address was a solemn warning to the Soviets against risking a nuclear war. He made it grimly plain that if the Soviets, either through miscalculation or dictatorial insanity, should launch a nuclear attack on the Western World, the Western World would embark on massive retaliation in kind.
LONDON, March 2 -- Prime Minister Churchill disclosed tonight that in 1953 President Eisenhower refused to join him in seeking a conference with Georgi M. Malenkov, then Premier of the Soviet Union.
THREE of the newly opened one-man shows reveal anew the variety of work being done within modern idioms of expression.

The southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Twenty-third Street, one of the largest plots in the Chelsea section, has been sold by Swiss interests to I. Jerome Riker in a deal negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2--Plans for celebrating in San Francisco the tenth anniversary of the signing of the United Nations Charter are being curtailed because of cost.

Control of one of the world's largest piers changed hands yesterday. The John W. McGrath Corporation leased Pier 6, at Forty-second Street, Brooklyn, from the Bush Terminal Company. The change becomes effective April 1.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- Congress soon will receive a program for economic aid to Asia, President Eisenhower told his news conference today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The closing levels were 3 points lower to 9 points higher than on Tuesday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2--The United Nations Security Council will meet Friday on Egypt's new complaint against Israel.
A private British air carrier, Airwork, Ltd., started yesterday a new scheduled all-cargo service across the Atlantic.
What might turn out to be the first known deposit of natural gas produced in commercial quantities in the Catskill Mountains has been discovered near Shandaken, N. Y.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 2--Norodom Sihanouk, 34-year-old King of Cambodia, abdicated today in favor of his father. A royal proclamation broadcast by the Cambodian radio said he was handing over the monarchy to Prince Norodom Suramarit, 58, because the application of his proposed constitutional reforms in this Indochinese state had been "obstructed."
Home cooks who would not think of trying their hand at yeast-raised bread often turn out successfully a so-called "quick loaf."

TELFORD TAYLOR has guts. Also facts. These do not often make best sellers, but they are hard to beat in a book. In this first authoritative study of Congressional investigations,* the author walks down the long line of history, pointing out friend and foe of American constitutional law. Because one Senator is censured or one professional antiCommunist finger man confesses he is a liar does not mean the demagogues are through, only submerged.

CHICAGO, March 2 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department at Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs- 10,000 head: market slow and uneven: butchers steady to mostly 25c lower: sows steady to 25c off: most sales choice 190 to 230 pounds $15.75 to $16.25: a

Franchot Tone and Theodore Mann have decided to do Robert Thom's play, "The Minotaur," in London this spring rather than on Broadway. Associated with them in the venture will be Donald Alberry, who recently sponsored there "I Am a Camera" and "The Living Room."

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture cautioned Congress today against a two-price plan designed to sell more United States rice abroad. The plan might do this country great harm in the politically sensitive producing areas of the Far East, it said.

William J. Keating resigned yesterday as counsel for the New York City Anti-Crime Committee. He said his decision was based on his awareness of a 'deep-seated resentment" against him by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and the prosecutor's chief aides.

In the face of a continuing labor dispute, the new Grace Line pier at West Fifteenth Street will be opened for business on Monday morning for the first time. It has been unused since it was turned over to the company last December under lease from the city.

Several new sofas that convert to beds indicate that designers are wideawake to the needs of the average homemaker. For, in recent months, tremendous improvements have been made both in mechanics and appearance.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Jefferson Caffrey received a "well done" today from President Eisenhower on his retirement after forty-four years as a career diplomat.

Plans for a special radio program in honor of Arturo Toscanini have been canceled by the National Broadcasting Company. The major cause of the cancellation seemed to be traceable to the conductor himself, who was said to disapprove of personal publicity.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) --A new plan to increase the Federal gasoline tax 1 cent or more a gallon to help pay for highways was discussed at a Congressional hearing today.

TORONTO, March 2 (UP)-- Maurice (Rocket) Richard, seeking the one hockey honor that has eluded him -- the National League scoring championship-- set up three goals tonight to move past Jean Beliveau as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3--2.
NEW ORLEANS, March 2-- The promise of atomic power for Latin America was discussed today at the third session of the Inter-American Investment Conference here.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House has authorized direct quotation of the President in some sections. In others, as required by conference rules, the President's remarks are in direct discourse.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- President Eisenhower said today only good could come from Russians' getting together with Americans to explore how corn grows tall and hogs grow fat.

KREFELD, Germany, March 2 (UP)--Russia's defending champions struck with stunning speed in the first period tonight, then held the upper hand the rest of the way to defeat the United States, 3--0, in the world amateur ice hockey competition.
OTTAWA, March 2 (Canadian Press) -- A Royal Commission has been set up to inquire into Canada's coastal shipping trade, George Marler, Minister of Transport, announced today.

Mayor Wagner is "shocked" at what he regards as a "New York City be damned" attitude of the Republican legislative leaders in Albany as to Governor Harriman's budget. The Governor himself protests against this "injustice."
HAVING written a wonderful play two years ago, William Inge has now written a better. He calls it "Bus Stop." It was beautifully acted at the Music Box last evening.

Commodity futures prices were generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, coffee, potatoes, cottonseed oil, rubber, burlap, hides, wool, zinc and copper were stronger; sugar moved mixed, and silk and soybean oil ended lower.
ROME, March 2--Pope Pius XII celebrated today his 79th birthday and the sixteenth anniversary of his elevation to the pontificate.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 2 (AP) --George Taniguchi rode Karim to victory today in the $22,400 Christopher J. Fitzgerald Handicap at Santa Anita.

Assets of the General Motors Corporation have pushed above the five-billion-dollar mark. The world's largest manufacturing enterprise began 1954 with assets of $4,405,475,042. It ended the year with assets of $5,130,093,595.

A new electronic system enabling for the first time the automatic tabulating of card invoices imprinted at point of sale with data from customer credit cards, was announced yesterday by the Farrington Manufacturing Company, Boston.
There is a story, probably apocryphal, about a young Italian visiting Paris who ate spaghetti every day for a week because it was the only item he understood on restaurant menus.
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 2 (UP)--Gloria Armstrong, 25year-old Oakland, Calif., player, shot a hole-in-one today to highlight the opening round of the South Atlantic women's amateur golf tournament.
IRVING, Tex., March 2 (UP)-- A superintendent of eight public schools who was dismissed without explanation said today that state Democratic politics was at the bottom of the trouble.

That crocus of the fashion world, a pale gray flannel suit, led off a showing of Harry Frechtel spring coats and suitis yesterday. The collection was presented at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Lord Taylor.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) --Senator Joseph R. McCarthy accused top Army Signal Corps officers today of negligence and incompetence. The Wisconsin Republican said the Rosenberg spy ring "could possibly be continuing to this very day."

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- When the reporters asked President Eisenhower today whether he was going to run again in 1956, he made two comments: (1) he liked the weather in San Francisco better than in Chicago; and (2) civilization would be in a bad way if it ever adopted the "indispensable man" theory.
HONG KONG, March 2--All seven Hainanese fishermen who were rescued as castaways by a United States Air Force plane last May 16 returned today to Red China.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) --Senator J. William Fulbright cautioned stockmarket traders tonight not to make hasty decisions because of an investigation of the market, starting tomorrow.

Stock prices rose yesterday to new peaks for the upward movement. Gains of 2 or more points were scattered throughout the list, but strength was centered in the rail, motor, steel, chemical and aluminum groups.

The refusal of the Senate Finance Committee to accept the $20-a-person tax handout pushed through last week by the Democrats of the House is a victory for responsible fiscal policy; but it is a victory that is still a long way from being clinched.
JONES BEACH, L. I., March 2--The pupil visited the master today. Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey called on Robert Moses to learn about parks.

YESTERDAY (March 2, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Signed Congressional - judiciary pay rise bill. Held news conference. THE SENATE Eulogized the late Senator Maybank of South Carolina and recessed at 4:02 P. M. until noon Friday.

ALBANY, March 2--Governor Harriman voiced "grave concern" today over two Republican proposals to revise state rent controls. But he stopped short of a threat to use his veto power if the changes were incorporated in pending legislation despite his objections.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- The United States has "protested vigorously" against the expulsion of the Rev. Georges Bissonnette from the Soviet Union.
Incorporation papers for the new statewide Committee for Modern Courts were signed yesterday by Presiding Justice David W. Peck at his Appellate Division chambers.
Sulphur, the real culprit in most of the smoke that plagues city dwellers, can be removed by timely treatment and thus improve air blankets over municipalities.
BELLEAIR, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- Commissioner Ford Frick fined the Kansas City Athletics $250 and six team members a total of $275 today for beating the March 1 spring training starting date.

An increase last week of 4,433,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks brought them to a new peak of 181,310,000 barrels, according to the weekly figure of the American Petroleum Institute. The previous peak of 180,384,000 barrels was reached on March 26, 1954.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 2--One of Branch Rickey's beardless wonders was on the mound at Terry Park the other day. He was pitching batting practice. The Mahatma, a white pith helmet atop his noggin, was seated in a chair behind the cage. His sharp eyes missed nothing. The youthful pitcher, a 20-year-old named Gonzales Naranjo, served one up with his strong right arm.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 2--The Central African Federation has decided to undertake a hydroelectric-power development that would be larger than Boulder Dam. The cost would be $240,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2--Whatever action the Senate may take on the tax bill, the conflict of wills between the President and the Democratic majority in Congress has already begun. If the Senate stands by its Finance Committee, which is the expectation, the bill extending certain tax rates will go back to the House without the $20 per head income tax cut for next year which was sponsored by Speaker Rayburn.
ALBANY, March 2--Republican leaders agreed today to speed the enactment of a law assuring to New York City its full 5 per cent from the amusement tax.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I would like to take exception to a portion of the letter from Sidney Rheinstein, posted at Genoa, in which he expresses amazement at the cleanliness he observed in Italy and the apparent prosperity of the Italian people.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 23: Decreases of $307,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $346,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, and $591,000,000, in demand deposits credited to domestic banks, and an increase of $146,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.
ALBANY, March 2--Measures aimed at protecting the interests of children in divorce cases and preventing fraud in obtaining annulments were passed by the Assembly today.
Blyth Co., Inc. and associates yesterday won the award of $50,000,000 of Pacific Gas and Electric Company's bonds. The successful bid was 100.938 for bonds bearing 3 3/8 per cent interest.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday unless otherwise specified.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There are sound reasons why the Port of New York Authority cares to have nothing to do with metropolitan rapid transit or with the pressing problem of New Jersey rail commuters.
JERUSALEM, March 2--Premier Moshe Sharett warned today that if Egypt proclaimed that she was maintaining a state of war against Israel she must face the consequences, including armed clashes.
MOSCOW, March 2--The Rev. Georges Bissonnette, an American Roman Catholic priest in Moscow, was ordered today to leave the Soviet Union. The reason for his expulsion was not immediately stated.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The break-up of the Arab League following conclusion of the TurkishIraqi pact was predicted in Washington today.
PARIS, March 2--News of the Cambodian King's decision to abdicate in favor of his father was reported here in brief dispatches from Pnompenh.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- President Eisenhower signed the Congressional-judicial pay increase bill today.
Albert (Jack) Johnson won the first half of his match with James Dear of England for the world open court tennis championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) --The American Legion complained today that the Administration's new military reserve program did not go far enough. It urged Congress to put universal military training into effect.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 2-- Turkey, Greece and Yugoslavia announced tonight they would continue to build up their military strength to resist aggression from any quarter.
Residents of the city soon will find it easier to attend to their banking chores. A growing number of giant commercial banks will open their branch doors from 6 to 8 P. M.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Instead of looking at things so much from the standpoint of whether our prestige is going to be hurt by this or that action, why do we not look at things more from the standpoint of right and wrong?

Performances of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on the afternoon and night of April 1 at Madison Square Garden have been taken over to raise funds for the Summer Day Camp in East Harlem of the James Weldon Johnson Community Center, Inc., 173 East 112th Street.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- If your copy of Pravda or Izvestia does not come, blame the Post Office Department.
LONDON, March 2 -- The Treasury announced today that the gold and dollar reserves of the sterling area dropped $82,000,000 last month. The total on Feb. 28 was $2,681,000,000.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) --The Air Force disclosed today that its new B-52 hydrogen bombers would be ready for combat soon.

Like a great many Americans, Senator J. William Fulbright watched with mild fascination the almost vertical advance of security prices in November and December, 1954, and found it disturbing. It was too reminiscent of 1928-29, he felt, for comfort.

Ralph Ellison, author of "The Invisible Man," has been selected by the American Academy of Arts and Letters to receive the Prix de Rome Fellowship. The term of the award starts in October. It includes the privilege of living at the American Academy in Rome for one year.
Evangelist Billy Graham may become the Fulton J. Sheen of Protestantism.
SPORTSMEN who find their activity in wood, field, stream and salt water spent almost $85,000,000 for hunting and fishing licenses during the fiscal year that ended last June.
IN THE GAZA ZONE, March 2--Mobs of Palestinian refugees braved army and police gunfire in the city of Gaza today to protest against recent Israeli attacks.
MOSCOW, March 2--Two Soviet Ministers whose departments have long been criticized were discharged today by Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin.
Russeks rushed forty designs it had bought at the recent Paris fashion showings to the manufacturers here so as to have adaptations ready by March 14.
It is more dangerous for firemen to rush to fires through this city's traffic than to fight the flames, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said last night.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financing subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, arrived in Wall Street yesterday afternoon to borrow $250,000,000. By evening it had all but about $20,000,000 in hand.
The suburban shopping center is coming to town. It will take over the former Ohrbach's store on Fourteenth Street.

A 14-year-old boy who was believed to have fought a gun duel with a patrolman in the Bronx ten days ago was arrested last night. The police said he had a double-barreled zipgun capable of firing .22-caliber bullets.
William Patrick Farrell, the Brooklyn wood finisher who has been charged with the murder of Ann Yarrow, was committed yesterday to Bellevue Hospital for mental observation.
ALBANY, March 2--Industry spokesmen today urged a change in workmen compensation laws concerning occupational deafness.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) --The State Department is reported ready to notify about ten independent American oil companies that they can join five major oil concerns in marketing part of Iran's vast oil output.
LOS ANGELES, March 2-- "Manufacturers of appliances and other consumer items can't take sides in the economic battle between conventional dealers and the so-called discount houses."

LOS ANGELES, March 2 (AP) --The Sewell Avery forces fighting to retain control of Montgomery Ward Co. announced a door-to-door campaign for stockholder support today to offset the efforts of a young financier to take over the company.
In its fifty-fourth collection of custom-order clothes created under the direction of Miss Ethel Frankau, Bergdorf Goodman has scored another hit.

MIAMI, March 2 (AP)--Julio Mederos, 195 1/2 pounds, of Havana, knocked out Roland LaStarza, 189, of New York tonight in the fifth round. The bout was the feature of four scheduled ten-rounders in Miami Stadium.

Charles L. Smith, a writer, bought the four-story dwelling on plot 22 by 100 feet at 124 East Thirty-first Street from D. Ellis Lit and plans to occupy part of the house for a studio and apartment and convert the remainder to apartments and commercial space.

NEW DELHI, India, March 2 --The Indian Communist party has taken a drubbing at the polls in the state of Andhra. It has been left politically crippled and publicly rejected in a state that has been a Communist stronghold.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Harvey Matusow declared today that he probably had lied about every person he ever testified against in Congressional hearings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 --The Screens Extras Guild has voted by a margin of 25 to 1 an amendment to the bylaws empowering the board of directors to expel any member who refuses to testify before a "properly constituted Government body" concerning present or former membership in "Communist or Fascist organization."
The writer of the following letter was formerly Bulgarian press attache in Washington.
PAHOA, Hawaii, March 2 (AP)--A new volcano split a half mile crack in a cane field on Hawaii's tormented eastern tip today.
ALBANY, March 2--Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck accused Mayor Wagner today of playing "pure, unadulterated politics" with the issue of state aid for New York City.
The hydrogen bomb has made war obsolete as a means of settling differences between nations, William L. Laurence, science reporter of The New York Times, said yesterday.

Dissenting Report Is Filed A gentleman who was recently laid low --briefly--by an unidentified but definitely unfriendly virus has filed a report with this department concerning one aspect of his enforced inactivity.

HONOLULU, March 2 (AP) -- Claude Jagger, public relations man who formerly was an assistant general manager of The Associated Press, died last night of what the police said was a self-infliced gunshot wound.
MIAMI, March 2 (AP)--The Hasty House Farms' Stan, under the top weight of 128 pounds, finished with a rush today to win the Hialeah Turf Handicap and earn $44,800 at Hialeah Park.
Holyoke, Mass., awarded $4,000,000 of 2.2 per cent water bonds to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates yesterday on a bid of 100.131. The bonds mature from 1956 to 1985.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby assured Congress today that the Administration health program would not be "an entering wedge" for socialized medicine.

SINGAPORE, March 2--British diplomats and administrators completed today a conference on Asian problems. They reportedly concluded that an indefinite continuation of the "cold war" in Asia could be expected. They felt that a "hot war" was unlikely but nevertheless a constant possibility.

Two new figures in the murder of Joseph Aronowitz on Feb. 15 were held in Brooklyn last night as material witnesses. Bail was set at $50,000 each. They had been questioned all day after their arrest by State Troopers Tuesday night near Catskill, N. Y.
CHICAGO, March 2--A tangle of neuroses is creeping through Washington under the heat of the Federal security program, mental health specialists were told today.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- Administration leaders assured the Senate Finance Committee today that President Eisenhower would take pains to protect American business if the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act was Extended for another three years: Their testimony was an attempt to head off opposition forces, which almost succeeded in amending the bill drastically when it was before the House of Representatives three weeks ago.
