CHICAGO, March 2--Near-by wheat futures were relatively strong today, especially in the current month, which gained on the deferred months. But late selling caused sharp recessions from early tops.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 2 -- Legislators of Pennsylvania and New Jersey conferred here today without reaching definite conclusions on bi-state action on use of Delaware River water.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- President Eisenhower renewed today his opposition to an incometax cut. But Senate Democrats quietly marshaled for a major fight to the end.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The President of the United States thinks labor unions can't "boss" any great number of Americans. The president of the American Federation of Labor agrees with him.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) --The United States Information Agency reported to Congress today that Communists had been stepping up their "hate the United States" propaganda despite much talk of peaceful coexistence.
Columbia remained a contender for the Ivy League basketball title by defeating Princeton, 65 to 58, at the Lions' University Hall gymnasium last night.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 2 --Don Newcombe pitched his first batting practice under a blazing sun today. He emerged streaming with persipration but happy about his arm.
HARTFORD, March 2--The counsel for the Connecticut Congress of Industrial Organizations was rejected today for appointment to the Common Pleas Court.
WASHINGTON, March 2--A merry President Eisenhower scoffed today at suggestions he was "an indispensable man" to a Republican victory in 1956.
The flat straight lines of modern architecture, sometimes dictated by cost, can be warmed and accented with proper use of stained glass, ceramics or murals.

It's an axiom in the stock market that anything that has more buyers than sellers will go up. A prime example of that axiom is the current case of Chicago and North Western Railway. This week the road notified its stockholders that it had a $800,000 loss in January.
If Senator J. William Fulbright thinks that his "friendly study" of the stock market, is going to be a kid-glove affair, he is reckoning without Wall Street.

Old dwellings occupying the block front on the south side of Booth Street, between Sixtyseventh Road and Sixty-seventh Drive, in Forest Hills, Queens, will be razed soon to make way for a large apartment house.
Long Island University announced yesterday the withdrawal of support from the College of Podiatry. The podiatry school is the only one in this state.

MANILA, March 2--Secretary of State Dulles today told United States Ambassadors in the Far East that the time had come to end the retreat in Asia. The meeting between Mr. Dulles and American chiefs of mission in fifteen countries in this part of the world was regarded here as highly important in shaping United States Far Eastern policy.

United Air Lines has increased its advertising budget substantially and is putting more of its money into newspaper and magazine space. E. A. Raven, director of advertising, said that a major share of the fund would go into 150 daily newspapers in the eighty cities served by the line.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- President Eisenhower spoke out today against any claim by the Chinese Nationalists for United States help in invading the Communist mainland.
CHICAGO, March 2 -- Once again college and university officials came in for severe criticism today.
Roy M. Cohn denied emphatically yesterday that he had ever suggested to Harvey Matusow that he testify falsely at the trial of thirteen secondary Communist leaders.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The solution of the knotty problems of rent control is not advanced by such extreme statements as those contained in the letter, published in your edition of Feb. 24, from W. E. Russell, chairman of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, a landlord's propaganda organization.
Thirteen George Polk Memorial Awards for "distinguished achievements in journalism" were announced yesterday at Long Island University.
The Boston Bruins clinched a berth in the National Hockey League play-offs by defeating the New York Rangers, 2 to 1, at Madison Square Garden last night.
The city took a major step yesterday toward the construction of a new Police Academy.

Either St. Louis University's basketball team or that of Tulsa University will play in a firstround game of the 1955 National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden. These squads are tied for the lead in the Missouri Valley Conference.
LONDON, March 2 (AP)--The British Overseas Airways Corporation will send the first of fleets of turbo-prop Viscounts and four-engine De Havillands for operation on West Indian routes next month.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2-- Leo Durocher's enthusiasm rose with the temperature today. While the Giants went through their second day of training, the champions' manager let it be known he already was convinced his No. 1 reclamation project of the campaign, the rehabilitation of Big Jim Hearn, would meet with unqualified success.
In the massive, turreted armory at Park Avenue and Sixtyseventh Street, members of Company K, 107th Infantry, turned out last night for a backslapping 100th anniversary reunion.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 2--Vice President Richard M. Nixon, who has shunned political matters during his Caribbean area tour, was the object of two political declarations today.

CHICAGO, March 3--All grain and soybean futures declined sharply in the early trade today. Wheat later registered a substantial recovery, led by the March and May futures, and rye also made a good comeback. There were partial recoveries in corn and oats.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- Israel has informed the State Department and the British Foreign Office of her dismay regarding the new Iraqi-Turkish pact.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) --The Eisenhower Administration told the Supreme Court today it might imperil the security of the country to give Government employes charged with disloyalty a chance to confront their accusers.

Advertisers should concentrate on the targets of their advertising and on what they want to accomplish, instead of the method used, Harold S. Barnes, director of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, said yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, March 3-- Machinery contrived for the Inter-American Investment Conference will be kept intact for the future.
Hillside, one of the oldest estates in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, has been purchased by a group of home owners in Riverdale who are dividing it into home sites.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3--All eyes were on Bob Turley today at Miller Huggins Field.

When the Security Council meets today to deal with Egypt's complaint of armed Israeli aggression and Israel's counter-complaint it will be confronted with the present crisis not as a set of isolated incidents but against the whole long background of animosity between the two countries since the very formation of Israel in 1948.

IN THE GAZA STRIP, March 3--Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, chief of staff of the United Nations truce supervision organization today visited the scenes of two night attacks by Israeli forces Monday at Gaza.

The second annual National Collegiate skiing championships will start in Vermont today. The downhill phase of the competition is to be held at Mad River Glen in Waitsfield. Then the scene will shift to near-by Northfield, where the title events will be concluded tomorrow and Sunday.
Cotton futures continued to decline yesterday.

The United States and the Nationalist Republic of China are now formal allies, following exchange in Taipei of ratification documents bringing into force their mutual defense treaty signed last December. This alliance takes its place, and closes the last gap, in the multifaceted Pacific defense system represented by the American alliances with Japan, Korea and the Philippines, by the ANZUS pact and by the Southeast Asian collective defense treaty.
LONDON, March 3--The fall in gold and dollar reserves last month further reduced stock market business today, but prices gradually improved after a cautious start and generally closed firm.
Louis Horst has been chosen as the winner of the Fourth Annual Capezio Dance Award, the major honor of the year in the field of dance.

LONDON, March 3--Sir Winston Churchill suggested today that a hydrogen bomb attack on Britain by the Soviet Union would provoke immediate retaliation, by the United States without prior consultation here.

"The Wayward Saint," in which Liam Redmond gained immediate promotion to stardom, closes Sunday night at the Cort. Because Paul Vincent Carroll's comedy-fantasy will have registered its twenty-first performance at its departure, the producers (Courtney Burr, John Byram and Elliott Nugent) will have a firm grip on the film and other rights.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, March 3--Vice President Richard Nixon arrived here today on the final stage of a goodwill tour of the Caribbean area.
NO individual who plays even a minor part in the framing of waterfowl regulations would stand a chance of winning a popularity contest.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- The Administration seeks to return property seized during World War II to individual owners in West. Germany, subject to a limitation of $10,000 a person. It will ask Congress to authorize this.

PARIS, March 2--The United States loan of $100,000,000 to the European Coal and Steel Community is expected to produce new investments of $350,000,000 to $400,000,000 in the basic industries of the six member countries.

THE first "Tristan und Isolde" of the season last night in the Metropolitan Opera House had its special excellences and rather surprising shortcomings, and these emanated principally from the same sources of the interpretation.
The Prime Minister of Britain performed a much-needed service for the United States in his speech to the House of Commons Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP)--Henry Ford 2d said today that the United States would be playing into Russia's hands if it failed to cooperate with the United Nations technical assistance program to underdeveloped nations.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has reviewed his chairmanship of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations in 1954 and found it good.

MIAMI, March 3 (AP)--W. L. Huntley's Rosemary B., a 13-to-1 chance, was in a running mood today and sped to a length and a half victory in the $33,800 Black Helen Handicap, the closing feature of Hialeah Park's racing season.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent above sales in the similar period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ERIC HOFFER, the San Francisco longshoreman who wrote one of the most provocative books of modern times, "The True Believer," did not say all he had to say in that cynical comment on the mass movements of history. He holds a great many other coldly objective and harshly materialistic opinions about the human race.
A speedy trial will be sought for a Lower East Side physician who was indicted Wednesday on charges that he made more than $12,000 in three years by illegally prescribing narcotics for addicts.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP)--Butcher hogs sold weak to mostly 25 cents lower today with the top price--$16.25--at a new low since 1950. Sows were steady to 25 cents down.

Loans to business by leading New York City banks increased by $72,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. This was the fourth consecutive weekly increase and is contrary to the usual seasonal decline at this time.

CHICAGO, March 3--Dr. Lester Dragstedt, head of the Department of Surgery at the University of Chicago, tonight described Dr. Allen's announcement as "very important." It was the climax of twelve years of research, he said.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 3 (AP)--Walter Romans of Baltimore, a working professional on his vacation, had a record sevenunder-par 29 on the back nine for a 65 and a one-stroke lead in the $12,500 Baton Rouge open golf tournament today.
The Chase National Bank and associates completed the offering yesterday of $15,500,000 of 3.10 per cent serial bonds of the Hempstead and North Hempstead, L. I. Central High School District No. 2.
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 3 (AP)--Pat Lesser, the defending champion, and Wiffi Smith, the medal winner, survived the quarter-finals of the women's South Atlantic amateur golf tournament today.
LONDON, Feb. 28--A mandible fragment of a 100,000-year-old man has been extracted from a desert region in South Africa, The man must have had an immense jaw.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 3-- As Leo Durocher drove his Giants through a sizzling drill today, one thing became clearly evident.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 (AP)--The Yankeees today elected Jerry Coleman as the team's player representative to replace Allie Reynolds, who recently retired from baseball.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 --The Technicolor Corporation is working toward the development of an "all-purpose system" for the photographing and projection of motion pictures.
Indian Head Mills, Inc., which recently acquired the assets of Naumkeag Steam Cotton Company, has sold the letter's plant in Salem, Mass., to Webb Knapp, Inc., real estate developers and builders.
MOSCOW, March 3 -- The Soviet Government is not expected to change its decision to expel the Rev. Georges Bissonnette, an American priest, from the Soviet Union.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 3 --Sandy Amoros, who has yet to convince Manager Walt Alston that he can be a full-time Dodger outfielder, was fined $100 today.

Home cooks buying the Sunday roast this week-end will find themselves confronted by an embarrassment of riches. Supermarkets, seeking to stimulate an unusually slack consumer demand for meat, are featuring "specials" right across the board--that is, in pork, veal, lamb, beef and turkey.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Democratic proposal to cut personal income taxes by $20 has been met with a cry of "politics" from the Republicans. This, coming from the party of the "new look," "the recaptured initiative," "the number games," and "the unleashing of Chiang Kai-shek" is high praise indeed.

MOLNAR'S comedy "The Guardsman" was revived on Wednesday evening over the Columbia Broadcasting System network with Claudette Colbert and Franchot Tone in the leading roles. Electronically, the production was in color but theatrically it was only monochrome.
ALBANY, March 3--The Court of Appeals ruled against New York City in two sales-tax test cases today.
Helen Clifford, a designer for William Fox, has accomplished the nice trick of handling high fashions so simply that a woman might wear them season after season.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- Two sponsors argued today for the bipartisan plan for Federal aid to school construction that grew out of a special hearing on crowded schools last year.
CHICAGO, March 3--Opposition to permanent Universal Military Training was reaffirmed today by the General Board of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

A colorful presentation of "the great outdoors" will be confined within four walls during the ten-day run of the new Sports and Vacation Show which opens tonight at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Mar. 3--The Senate Judiciary Committee agreed today to vote next Wednesday on the nomination of Judge John Marshall Harlan of New York for the Supreme Court.

Billy Graham, East Side welterweight, will be back in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. Graham, recognized as the most skillful boxer in the 147-pound division, will endeavor to give a lesson to Chico Vejar of Stamford, Conn.

L. Judson Morhouse, state Republican chairman, proposed yesterday that a budget investigatory staff be provided for the Republican minority of the City Council. Two of the twenty-five Councilmen are Republicans-- Stanley Isaacs of Manhattan and Robert E. Barnes of Queens.

PARIS, March 3--One of the committees of the advisory Council of the Republic adopted today an amendment to the Paris agreements providing for West Germany's armament within the framework of the Western European Union.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 3-- Secretary of State Dulles warned the Chinese Communists today to drop all plans to invade Formosa and the Pescadores.
Criticism of the Administration's stand on possible defense of the Formosan Strait Islands of Quemoy and Matsu was made in a statement issued last night by Christian Action.
MOSCOW, March 2--Emphasis is being placed on the development of Soviet heavy industry to strengthen not only this country but also China and other Communist states.
A strike of maintenance and shop employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad was threatened yesterday by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union. C. I. O.

The New York City AntiCrime Committee announced last night that it was accepting the "resignations" of its executive director and staff counsel. They are the men whose revelations two weeks ago touched off current wiretapping investigations.

A twinkling inkling of what the future may hold for the motorist was presented in Manhattan yesterday. It was an iridescent blue automobile, long and wide and low, with the look of a rocket about to blast off.

YESTERDAY (March 3, 1955) TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council discussed conditions and visiting mission's report on conditions in British-administered Tanganyika. Standing Committee on Administrative Unions -- Studied report on administrative union affecting British Cameroons.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday were 635,453 cars, the Association, of American Railroads announced today. This was 19,582 cars or 3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 40,422 cars or 6.8 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 33,199 cars or 5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
A plan to combat juvenile delinquency through a $3,000,000 annual city subsidy to community centers and settlement houses was put forward yesterday by Abe Stark, President of the City Council.
A critical survey of piers in the Port of New York has evoked wide interest among steamship companies and waterfront labor groups.
A new formula for salary schedules for teachers has been proposed in a move to bring about a compromise in the controversy over single-salary lists.
The audio portion of certain television programs will be heard on radio as a part of the National Broadcasting Company radio network's new "week-end plan."
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The stock market needs more than an investigation. A thorough study of the psychological effects of security trading is overdue.
Ohrbach's has really boxed itself in this season. The new spring collection of suits and coats from the Grey Room enclose feminine curves in right angles.
WASHINGTON, March 3--A blueprint for making plane-toground radio contact as simple as using a dial telephone has just been submitted to airline planners.

"Day of Reckoning," a novel by Ralph de Toledano, will be published March 24 by Holt. It is the story of a man determined to avenge the death of a friend at the hands of Communists. The novel is based on actual events, such as the Tresca murder.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The United States is ready to scrap the Korean armisticepolicing commission as useless.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3-- After almost two hours of play E. Mauran Beals of Boston defeated Morys Bruce, the British title holder, in the United States amateur court tennis championship today. The score was 6--4, 2--6, 6--5, 1--6, 7--5.
Harry Sacher, counsel for thirteen convicted Communist leaders, accused Roy M. Cohn of not testifying truthfully yesterday.
ST. AGATHA, Me., March 3-- The financial plight of this northern Maine border town is a symptom of a potato depression in Aroostook County.
A tentative settlement was reached yesterday in a contract dispute between unionized composingroom employes and the publishers of nine daily newspapers in the metropolitan area.

IT has been sixteen years since Walter Gieseking last appeared as piano soloist with the New York PhilharmonicSymphony. He was back last night with the orchestra at Carnegie Hall, doing the solo honors in two works, and he was entitled to assume that once again he was being accepted fully on all sides in New York at least as a musician.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 3-- Highway experts called on pressure groups today to bear in mind that new roads must be made for safety and not just for profitable proximity to commercial enterprises.
Lew White, for twenty-five years an organist in theatres and on radio and television, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after an illness of several months. His age was 52.
LOS ANGELES, March 3--A new medical discovery was disclosed today at the meeting of the Society of Graduate Surgeons of Los Angeles County Hospital in the Ambassador Hotel.
YESTERDAY (March 3, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Had breakfast with Senator William F. Knowland of California, Republican leader of the Senate. Met with the National Security Council.
LOS ANGELES, March 3 (UP) --Harlow H. Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, said today the automobile industry might produce more cars this year than ever before.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $76,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Billy Graham, the evangelist, addressed a religious rally in Madison Square Garden last night. More than 22,000 persons attended. An additional 5,000 who could not get in the hall gathered in Forty-ninth Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Feb. 25 you published a letter from Harold C. Urey, Nobel Prize winner and Professor of Nuclear Studies at the University of Chicago. In his letter Professor Urey objects to the criticism leveled at him by Herbert Bayard Swope in a letter previously published in this column.

KFAR BATYA, Israel, Feb. 25 --Twelve young Falasha Jews, who might be taken as living proof of the legend that today's Ethiopians descend from Solomon and the Queen of Sheba, are studying at this children's village.
Manhattan's basketball team vanquished Fordham, 60 to 55, last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.
There is a chance that the sun may shine again on Hamilton Grange.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 3-- Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of State Dulles today at the exchange of instruments of ratification of the mutual defense treaty between the United States and Nationalist China: Taiwan [Formosa] is the area where today the Chinese Communists most actively press their aggressive designs.
BY what standards are we to look at the Originals Only production of "A Streetcar Named Desire"? It opened in the Sheridan Square cellarage last evening.

WASHINGTON, March 3-- Robert R. Young's Alleghany Corporation, the holding company he used to gain control of the New York Central System, won its fight today to avoid the rigid supervision of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Manhattan will be greener around the middle this spring, thanks to the efforts of three ex-suburbanites and a native who shares their passion for trees.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Congress started to examine today one of the most interesting paradoxes in American Government. This is that the United States spends more money and energy on Government information and propaganda than any nation in the Western world, yet is more widely misunderstood overseas than, any other leading nation.
CAIRO, March 3--Egypt's Premier warned today that she would not depend on the United Nations for defense of her frontiers. Egypt will meet force with force, he said.
The New York subway system is going to get a $2,252,500 cleaning.
ALBANY, March 3--Averell Harriman appears to be thriving on the cares of state office.
New York may become the official birthplace of the unified labor movement.

For many years Americans have been accustomed, and with good cause, to reproach the Soviet Union for its Iron Curtain and for the great barriers it imposes upon free exchange of persons and ideas with non-Communist lands. Yet today we find ourselves in a position where we have provided Soviet propagandists with material for throwing the same reproach back upon us.
New York University's basketball team gave Coach Howard Cann the 400th triumph of his thirty-two-year coaching career by defeating City College, 56--54, in the Fordham Gymnasium last night.
KINGSTON - ON THAMES, England, March 3--A plaque from Kingston, N. Y., commemorating the first "round-trip across the Atlantic by a small powered vessel was unveiled here today.

A manufacturer of novelty jewelry has purchased the twelve-story loft building on plot 50 by 100 feet at 148-50 West Twenty-fourth Street from the Southside Dress Company in a deal negotiated by Williams Co.
A historic event took place last night in the New York City Bar Association Building: a group of judges reported to a representative group of lay citizens on the operation of the courts.

As the flood of annual reports reaches its spring crest, the spotlight is naturally on sales and earnings. But a careful scanning of the fine print reveals some equally significant figures--those for capital expenditures.

Coffee prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange after two days of strength. The spot March option held steady but the other months were off more than 1 cent a pound and the September position was down the 2-cents-apound limit.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 3--The Pittsburgh Pirates finished forty-four games behind the pennant-winning Giants in the National League last year. In the American League the Boston Red Sox finished fortytwo games behind the champion Indians. But the Bosox wound up in fourth place, while the Buccaneers landed in the cellar, a dismal eighth.

MEXICO CITY, March 3 (AP) --Tony Holguin of Midlothian, Ill., set a rugged pace for the opening round today of the $5,000 Mexican national open tournament. He turned in a 66 on the par-72 course of the Chapultepec Golf Club.

TOKYO, March 3 -- Japan wants her share of the sea-going traffic to Communist ports. Among the proposals put forward by the Transportation Ministry for the benefit of the Japanese shipping industry is the relaxation of various United States regulations concerning maritime commerce with Communist nations.
Seven judges of the highest court in the city appealed last night for a court reform program to be effected with the aid of "informed public opinion."
Funds to finance the expansion program of the New Jersey Turnpike will be obtained from the sale of $34,000,000 of second Series B bonds on March 17.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senatorial fears that the stock market advance may have gone too far received a reassuring answer today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- Israel countered Egypt's complaint of aggression by asking the Security Council today to take up charges that Cairo had violated the armistice agreements. Israel listed six accusations to support her complaint of "continuous violations" by Egypt endangering international peace.

WASHINGTON, March 3--Senate leaders said today after a preliminary nose count that the Senate would reject a $20-a-person income tax cut by from six to twenty votes. The House has approved such a measure.

Stocks were strong in the early trading yesterday. But in the afternoon, although a good part of the advance was retained, the market acted as if it knew that Senator J. William Fulbright had his eye on it.
On a sales increase of 88.3 per cent, the net income of Northrop Aircraft, Inc., for the six

HILO, Hawaii, March 3 (UP)-- A menacing river of molten lava from Kilauea volcano stopped just short of the deserted village of Kapoho today. Hopes were raised that the homes of 335 residents might be spared.
PATRICK of Ballytobin and his son, The MacGillicuddy, are the pride of the Fighting Irish, formerly the old Sixtyninth New York Infantry, now the 165th.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Administration's reciprocal trade extension bill is apparently heading into a Senate fight. And the fight is expected to be as stiff as that which almost brought drastic modifications when the measure was before the House of Representatives.

When children make friends with youngsters of other races or backgrounds, parents who have lived more or less "segregated" lives may find they have to make some emotional adjustments to the situation.

Certain Spring Meetings Those who give advice to young persons about to be married fail to tell them one thing they should know. This is that when two persons marry and have children, and those children start going to school, there come into view spring ParentTeacher Association meetings.
ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, March 2--Can a ship off Palmer Peninsula in the Antartic "hear" a flash of lightning over Washington? With luck, this ship may bring home an answer.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- United States' security and superiority in the atomic field can best be preserved by reliance on the American system of free enterprise, Congress was told today.
GENEVA, March 2 -- West Germany has accepted a fiveyear time limit for the dismantling of its system of import controls on farm products.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Relative to the proposal to decontrol so-called "luxury" apartments, there is an indisputable shortage of high-grade apartment space.

NEW DELHI, India, March 3--Sir Anthony Eden asked today that a step toward negotiated settlement be taken by renunciation of force in the Far East. The British Foreign Secretary has come to New Delhi for talks on the Formosa Strait situation with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

BOSTON, March 3 (UP)--Jean Beliveau fired home two goals tonight to spark the leagueleading Montreal Canadiens to a 4-1 victory over the Boston Bruins. A crowd of 11,634 saw the game in the Boston Garden.

An outstanding American orthopedic surgeon has been named to lead a pioneering medical mission to Indonesia. The scope of the project embraces 17,000,000 disabled persons in the world's sixth largest country.
WASHINGTON, March 3-- This year got off to an auspicious start from the standpoint of personal income and manufacturing activity.
ROME, March 3--The police raided the Roman headquarters of the Church of Christ, a United States Protestant denomination, twice today.

The Communists in the southeast Indian state of Andhra have met disaster in the first elections held since that territory was separated eighteen months ago from the State of Madras. The count is not quite complete, but it looks as though the Moscow-supported group would have only a handful of seats in the 196-member Assembly.
Alexander Summer, real estate lealer, told yesterday of an adverse report that was made last April on the $25,000,000 Washington Square Southeast redevelopment project.

WASHINGTON, March 3--Senator Byrd of Virginia has revived the old effort to give authority to the President to disapprove particular items in revenue bills instead of, as now, being obliged to veto or approve them in toto. He has proposed an entirely new formula which may find favor for the general objective which hitherto it has lacked.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 3 (UP)--Canada's Penticton V's and Russia's defending champions tonight skated toward a Sunday showdown for the world amateur ice hockey championship. They are tied for first place with 6-0 records.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 --Louis E. Wolfson today requested an opportunity to testify before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee in Washington in connection with his fight to control Montgomery Ward Co.
A total of 1,949 deep-sea ships sailed in and out of New York harbor last month.
The writer of the following letter was the former editor of the Shanghai China Press.
ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, March 3--A group of Americans is planning to try to endure the hardships of a sixmonth winter night at the South Pole.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4--Casey Stengel had just finished outlining his rotation of starting pitchers today for the 1955 season.
The scheduled Broadway spring production of "Saint Joan" by the Canadian Players, Ltd., has been postponed indefinitely, but the Shaw drama still may be done here this season by a London management.

NEW DELHI, March 4 (UP)-- Chester Bowles said today "Our quarrel is not with the common man who walks the streets of Moscow or Peking [Peiping], nor with the approach of his government to domestic affairs, which is in no sense our business."
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 4 --South Vietnam's three private armies, totaling about 25,000 men, announced today they had united to try to form a new anti-Communist Government.
Houston, Tex., sold $15,000,000 of Independent School District bonds in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.59 per cent.
ALBANY, March 4 (UP)--Skiarea operators today reported the following conditions to the State Department of Commerce: Alpine Meadows--4-5 inches powder snow, 1-6 granular; skiing good.
OSLO, Norway, March 4--Two recent management changes are viewed here as indicating a general shake-up among the executives of the Scandinavian Airlines.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4 (AP)--Cornell's big three of John Sheehy, Chuck Rolles and Dick Meade spear-headed a 41-point second-half tonight as the Big Red defeated Harvard, 72--58, in an Ivy Basketball League game.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The members of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee found themselves yesterday wandering in the half-world of the statisticians and mathematicians.
LONDON, March 4--A British business man told his fellow Britons today that competition from other nations, particularly Japan, was endangering this country's sales in the United States.
Mothers usually are dismayed when they first see that their child is no longer the dependent baby he once was.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, March 4--Vice President Richard M. Nixon urged the countries of Central America and the Carribbean today to form a strong regional coalition. The purpose would be to insure their political stability and economic prosperity.
WASHINGTON, March 4--Val Peterson, Civil Defense Administrator, and the American Federation of Labor endorsed today President Eisenhower's proposed new military reserve training program.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh's report on the problem of the alcoholic is a humane and enlightened document that shows how far apart are the ideal and the actual on the handling of the Skid Row derelict. "There is no drearier example of the futility of using penal sanctions to solve a medical or social problem," says Judge Murtagh.

James J. Moran pleaded not guilty here yesterday to a charge of evading Federal income taxes. The former first deputy fire commissioner was accused in Brooklyn Federal Court of cheating the Government out of $131,307 in three years.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 4 (UP)--Jerry Barber and Marty Furgol shot steady, sub-par golf today to move into a tie for first place at 134 at the halfway mark of the $12,500 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The index of average primary market prices declined 0.2 over the week ended on Tuesday, to 110.1 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices for farm products and processed foods and a slight decrease in the index for industrial commodities accounted for the decline.

BOSTON, March 4 (AP)--New York's Carl Braun got off the bench to score 4 important points near the finish tonight and help the Knicks gain a 95-92 National Basketball Association victory over Rochester at the Boston Garden.
In active trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, cotton futures prices fell 14 to 20 points (70 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, March 4--A Federal grand jury reindicted seven Connecticut Communists today on charges of conspiring to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 4-- Chinese Communist gunboats and motorized junks assaulted Kaoteng Island in the Matsu group today, the Nationalist Defense Ministry announced.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- The White House has decided not to make public the guest lists of President Eisenhower's "stag" dinners and other private parties.

A former Government attorney admitted yesterday that he had had some doubt about a story that Harvey Matusow, self-proclaimed liar, told him in pre-trial examination. However, Matusow related the story at the trial of thirteen secondary Communists.

LONDON, March 4--The United States has invited Sir William Penney, Britain's leading nuclear weapons expert, to visit America to discuss a greater exchange of nuclear information. The invitation is understood to reflect the belief here that advanced British processes for making hydrogen bombs are more efficient and less expensive than those laboriously pioneered by American scientists.

Three winners of Viking Fund medals for 1954 were announced last night. The awards are made annually for outstanding scientific achievement to an archaeologist, an anthropologist and a physical anthropologist.
LONDON, March 4--Conservative leaders warned Britons tonight against voting for a divided Labor party in an early general election.

Chico Vejar made it close in his ten-round fight with Billy Graham of the East Side at Madison Square Garden last night. The Stamford, Conn., scrapper gained the decision by a majority vote of the officials after a tussle that was thoroughly enjoyed by the crowd of 4,804.

A Look at March The first week of March is traditionally a time when weather prognosticators try to make up their minds whether to predict early or late arrival for the soft winds and balmy days of spring.

We share Governor Harriman's gratification that the port is to be spared another crippling strike. But we find little else in the pier situation to be cheerful about. The circumstances under which the threatened strike was averted are bound to encourage the idea that enforcement of waterfront rules can be blocked by a show of force.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4-- Finalists a year ago, Alastair B. Martin, of Glen Head, L. I., and Northrup Knox of Buffalo, will meet again tomorrow for the amateur court tennis championship of the United States. Martin will be seeking his seventh crown and his sixth in succession.

In a world torn by strife and in a hemisphere where democracy has lost many battles it is worth while to turn our eyes once more to little Uruguay, which has just passed another milestone of freedom. Five days of gay but dignified ceremonies attending the transfer of power to the new National Council of Government ended yesterday.

The writer of the following letter is an anthropologist specializing in the Middle Eastern field. To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the closing portion of the last of her five excellent articles on the problems of the aged Edith Evana Asbury makes a brief but telling reference to the Asian family pattern which protects the older men and women by retaining them as organized members of the family.
MOSCOW, March 4--After nearly five years of oblivion, Prof. Bruno Pontecorvo atomic scientist who disappeared from Britain in 1950, showed himself in Moscow this afternoon.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 4 (AP)--Illinois' Ralph Fessenden lowered the Big Ten 300-yard record twice with a pair of sparkling performances tonight while favored Michigan led in qualifiers by placing fifteen in preliminaries of the conference indoor title track meet.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 4-- Speedy completion of the Federal interstate highway system, as provided in President Eisenhower's 101,000,000,000 road program, was urged today by Eastern highway officials.
The Federal Maritime Board has approved the application of the South Atlantic Steamship Line to become the seventeenth subsidized American steamship company.
ALBANY, March 4--The correspondent of The Daily Worker has been barred from off-therecord press conferences with Governor Harriman.

The Rev. Dr. Adam Clayton Powell Jr. said yesterday that he would call upon the 15,000 members of his congregation tomorrow to boycott Harlem savings banks that practice "Jim Crow-ism" and "economic lynching."
WASHINGTON, March 4-- The State Department came to the defense today of Edward Corsi, special assistant to the Secretary of State for refugee and migration problems.
WASHINGTON, March 4--The Treasury Department demoted and later permitted a security officer to resign because of a family problem.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) --President Eisenhower today nominated former Representative John S. Wood, Democrat of Georgia, to a three-year term on the Subversive Activities Control Board.
Another barrage in the battle of technical versus liberal arts education was fired yesterday in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- Extension for two years of the Renegotiation Act was recommended to Congress by President Eisenhower today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 4-- China's imperial techniques in Southeast Asia are mindful of those Russia employs in Europe. The organizational methods of communism are made to suit Peiping's purposes along the Mekong River valley just as they are tailored to Moscow's needs along the Danube.

PRESENT-DAY religious art again is the subject of an exhibition of paintings, sculpture and objets d'art at the Parish Hall of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, 12 West Eleventh Street. The committee of arrangement has been at some pains to collect work not only by local American artists but also by several abroad.
THE PRESIDENT Met with his Cabinet. Sent Congress message asking extension of renegotiation law.
A former waterfront union official was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of failing to file tax returns on income of more than $34,000 in 1951 and 1952.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 4 (UP)--America's team of collegians and Europeanbased soldiers put on its best performance in the world amateur ice hockey championship tonight. The United States sextet skated to a 6-2 victory over Poland.

LONDON, March 4--Security prices continued to improve today though business dwindled further. Selective buying of industrial shares found the market short of offerings. Price gains therefore often were out of proportion to the turnover.

Singapore will hold elections in April to choose a majority of a new popularly constituted Legislative Assembly. This is a notable advance in self-government in the Crown Colony. Meanwhile, the language question has become an issue. The Chinese Chamber of Commerce--an influential body in the great commercial city--has determined to petition the Queen to authorize Chinese as an official language in Singapore when the new Assembly meets.

Though there are optimists enough among engineers who declare that in a few years it will be possible to generate electricity as cheaply with uranium as with ordinary fuel, the Transit Authority has decided to proceed with present rehabilitation of subway power plants, old as they are, at a cost of $178,000,000, rather than to rely on atomic power, which is not yet out of the developmental stage.

SPORTS and Vacation Show highlights: Not an Indian whooped, not a wolf howled, when the doors of the Kingsbridge Armory opened at six o'clock last night to admit the waiting crowd of outdoor enthusiasts to the new Sports and Vacation Show.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: The proposal of the Port of New York Authortiy and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to construct the world's longest suspension bridge over the Narrows should be abandoned in favor of a tunnel.
Thirty thousand dollars' worth of clothing, furs and jewelry, along with $189 that was to have been contributed to the Red Cross, was stolen yesterday from the apartment of three Brooklyn sisters.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 160 West Seventy-seventh Street has been sold by the Patra Realty Corporation to an investor in a deal negotiated by Alice Cohn, broker. Title was insured by the Inter -County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed irregularly higher yesterday. Rubber, hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and sugar were firmer; potatoes, wool and copper were mixed, and cocoa and coffee ended lower. Volume was light in most markets, generally limited to evening of holdings for the weekend.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- Neil H. McElroy, chairman of the Committee for the White House Conference on Education, announced today seven subcommittees.

GENEVA, March 4--The danger of an irreparable breakdown in cooperation among the free nations to maintain order in international trade is acute. In the opinion of leaders of the Geneva trade conference, the critical period is likely to last four to six months.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- Irving Florman, former United States Ambassador to Bolivia, received a patent this week for a radiation detector and alarm to be installed in an automobile.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Feb. 26 --Undeveloped hydroelectric potential totaling more than 20,000,000 horsepower lies in four major river systems of northern British Columbia and the Yukon, it was reported by an engineer here.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 4-- There is a deal of fond hope in the Giant camp that Jim Hearn and the once-retired Larry Jansen will regain their cunning this spring. Also that several youngsters, notably Al Worthington, Paul Giel and Joe Margoneri, will come through to give the corps a fresh lift.
OSLO, Norway, March 4-- Norway's Labor Government, like the Socialist Governments of other Scandinavian countries, is hard up for money.
Robert Gordon Menzies, Prime Minister of Australia, will be honored here tonight at a dinner of the Pilgrims of the United States.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 4 (AP)--David Singer's Hangover made it three straight victories today in the $12,400 Armed Handicap, opening feature of Gulfstream Park's forty-three-day meeting.
An enthusiastic crowd turned out for the opening of the new ten-day Sports and Vacation Show at Kingsbridge Armory last night.

PARIS, March 4--In their first contact members of the Cabinet and the National Assembly clashed today. The issue was the program left in deadlock by the fall of the Government of Premier Pierre MendesFrance.
WASHINGTON, March 4--Pay rises for the armed forces and postal service were approved today by House committees.
A Queens grand jury accused some private hospitals yesterday of an "utter disregard" for the welfare of surgical patients.

American Federation of Labor tugboat and harbor craft workers will make another attempt Monday afternoon to solidify organizational gains made among the city's ferryboat men and to force contract negotiations between their union and the Department of Marine and Aviation.
ALBANY, March 4--Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, said today "many people around the country" favored Governor Harriman for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1956.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- Walter Winchell's stock market tips dominated the Senate Banking and Currency Committee's hearing today.
BONN, Germany, March 4-- Israel, one of the world's youngest nations, is about to introduce her first new ocean-going passenger vessel.

Wes Santee, Mal Whitfield, Charley Jenkins, Horace Ashenfelter, Harrison Dillard and Bob Richards top a star-studded entry for tonight's thirty-sixth annual games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus.

An investor has purchased the six-story building containing forty-six apartments and six stores at 1791 Walton Avenue in the Bronx from Maje Realty Company through Wishnow Horowitz, brokers. The sale was subject to a first mortgage of $103,000.

There are only two books published today. One is "Leaves From a Doctor's Diary," by Edith E. Johnson, M. D. It is a volume of reminiscences covering twenty-seven years of practice in Palto Alto, Calif. The publisher is Pacific Books, Palo Alto.

Mrs. Sylvia Jaffin Singer, an assistant district attorney of New York County, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor Wagner as a justice of the Domestic Relations Court. The Mayor also announced the appointment of Anthony Drexel Duke as a member of the New York City Youth Board.
Religious services today and tomorrow will give special emphasis to the Girl Scouts in the United States.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Farm and labor witnesses testified before the Senate Finance Committee today on the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

"In this country, if someone dislikes you or accuses you, he must come up in front. He cannot assassinate you or your character from behind without suffering the penalties an outraged citizenry will inflict.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) --The National Mediation Board said tonight the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., had agreed to cancel a strike threatened for midnight Sunday against the Pennsylvania Railroad.
WASHINGTON, March 4--A political split has developed in the United Steelworkers, C. I. O. It challenges the leadership of the union president, David J. McDonald.
ROME, March 4--The United States Embassy intervened today in the feud between Texan missionaries of the Church of Christ and Italian officialdom.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 4--The Security Council urged Israel and Egypt today to desist from violence or provocation that could inflame the Middle East.
CHICAGO, March 4 -- The grain market opened firmly, this morning, with March wheat again in the lead, but free selling caused prices to sag.
In the 1953-54 season 20,000,000 persons rolled balls on 85,000 alleys in 12,250 bowling establishments in the United States.
Merger of two metallurgical research concerns, the Horizons Titanium Corporation and Horizons Zirconium Corporation, will be considered by stockholders on March 22.
WASHINGTON, March 4--To err is human; to collect, sublime. So goes the philosophy of the Internal Revenue Service.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Cash dividend payments by corporations amounted to $721,000,000 in January, $32,000,000 more than in January, 1954, the Department of Commerce reported today.
MOSCOW, March 4--Anna Louise Strong, American writer who was arrested and deported from the Soviet Union in 1949, was formally absolved today of charges that she had spied on the Soviet Union.
ALBANY, March 4--John F. O'Connell of Larchmont has resigned as chairman of the State Liquor Authority.

NEW ORLEANS, March 4 (AP) --The Southwestern Journalism Congress today saluted The New York Times for "providing the most complete reporting of significant events by a newspaper in the United States during the last twenty-five years."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 4 (AP)--Ohio State, the defending champion, and Michigan's Wolverines were locked in a duel tonight as the forty-fifth Western Conference swimming championships reached the halfway mark.
General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein asserted yesterday that crime could be reduced by setting up clinics where narcotics would be supplied to addicts.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 4 --Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, announced today plans to develop a 3,000-acre industrial district in a Rhode Island potatogrowing section. He said it would be the first and perhaps the largest in a series of industrial parks he hopes to build along the railroad between New York and Boston.
MOSCOW, March 1 -- New York may be a wonderful town to the song writers, but not to the compilers of the Great Soviet Encyclopedia.

While attention has been focused on Formosa new developments have been taking place on another Asian front. They include; (1) a steady build-up of Communist forces in North Korea in violation of the armistice agreement; (2) the inability of the "Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission" to prevent, or even to inspect and report, these violations because of the obstructionist tactics of its Communist members.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., March 4--We are educating our children to live in "a world that no longer exists," Lawrence K. Frank said here today. Instead, we should be trying to raise children who "can bear the burder of freedom," if we are to maintain a free society, he added.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 4 --Govs. George M. Leader of Pennsylvania and Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey agreed today on a cooperative effort to develop and conserve the water resources of the Delaware River.
DETROIT, March 4 (AP)--Chevrolet and Ford both claimed today to have finished in top place in the number of passenger cars delivered at retail last year.

CHICAGO, March 4 (AP)--Department of Agricultural reports on livestock trading here today: HOGS Salable hogs 7,500 head; trading uneven; butchers slow early, but later moderately active; general trade steady to weak; mainly steady on butchers 230 pounds and heavier;
MINEOLA, L. I., March 4-- Seven members of Local 138, Operating Engineers Union, A. F. L., were acquitted of assault by a jury in First District Court here today.

"The Barber of Seville" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera last evening, with Lily Pons making her first appearance of the season in the role of Rosina. Eugene Conley sang Almaviva for the first time this season and Sandra Warfield took her first Metropolitan role of Berta.

THE weatherman has been unseasonably considerate these winter days of some hardy 3-to-5-year-olds, members of a year-round outdoor play group in Queens. As long as the thermometer registers 22 degrees or above and storms are not in progress, a group of seventy youngsters hurries eagerly three mornings a week to the play center, a feature of the Fresh Meadows apartment development.

New corporate and preferred stocks for which definite offering dates have been set for next week total $318,524,000, according to the Investment Dealers Digest. This compares with $607, 720,000 a week earlier.
PARIS, March 4--The French Foreign Ministry took issue with German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer tonight on the question of London's and Washington's attitude toward the Saar.

WAITSFIELD, Vt., March 4-- Dartmouth's skiers gained the jump over eleven rivals as the national collegiate championships began with the downhill event on Mad River Glen's Catamount Trail and Grand Canyon today.
Thomas J. Curran, the New York County Republican leader, yesterday denounced revisions in the rent control law that the Republican majority in the Legislature has agreed on.

The stock market rose yesterday for the fifth session in a row. As on Thursday, the industrials were stronger than the rails and or a while it appeared that The New York Times' index of twenty-five such issues might pierce the 1929 high.

An unofficial crime investigator who revealed a police raid on a wiretapping center before the District Attorney had been informed was ordered yesterday to reveal the sources of his information to a grand jury.

Mrs. Robert F. Wagner made the rounds of Red Cross services in the city yesterday, and found them fascinating. The Mayor's wife was having a close-up of the agency's activities as part of her duties as chairman of women's special events in the annual campaign, which runs through March.

GREEN HAVEN, N. Y., March 4--A daughter, their fourth child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Jerome F. Gould of Green Haven on Feb. 18 at the United Hospital in Port Chester. Mrs. Gould is the former Miss Gretel Bleich. The child will be named Lisa Anne.

THE program given by Artur Rubinstein for his piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall was a formidable one, and no question about it. It was performed formidably, not invariably, perhaps, with plenary inspiration, but masterfully, as of course, and phenomenally in its greatest moments.

WASHINGTON, March 4--A fundamental difference of opinion in the Department of Justice on the constitutionality of the Government's loyalty procedures was disclosed today. It arose over the belief of some officials that the constitutional right of due process of law had been denied to Dr. John Punnett Peters in the actions that led to his dismissal from a part-time Government job.
The First Army rolled out the red carpet yesterday for an 11year-old boy. The boy is six years under the minimum age for recruits. But he has expressed an unusually strong desire to join up.
Howie Schloemer of City College broke his own meet record for the 220-yard free-style event last night in the qualifying trials for the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference swimming championships.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 4--It is a trifle early and a bit warm to be tossing fuel on the flames of the Dodgers-Giants feud. But Leo Durocher made a toss all the way from Phoenix, Arizona.
WASHINGTON, March 4-- Japan's internal political situation has stalled disposal of $85,000,000 worth of surplus American farm products, informed sources said today.

The flow of foreign capital into Canada eased in 1954 for the first time since the war. While, the total was far from a trickle, the decline was reflected in a reduction in Canada's foreign -trade deficit to $427,000,000 in the year. This compared with a 1953 trade deficit of $439,000,000.
A 42-year-old Brooklyn window washer was dragged thirty-two blocks underneath an automobile Thursday night. He died in Norwegian Hospital thirteen hours later.

A dramatic demonstration of a new form of brain surgery, in which a chemical replaces the knife, was witnessed by physicians meeting here yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, March 4 --Chester Bowles urged Indians tonight to take a look at "what's right" about United States foreign policy instead of concentrating on what's wrong.
Good things came in a small package yesterday, when Knize, the designer, took the wrappings off a collection of spring suits in his New York salon, on Fiftysixth Street.

Teaching and research in the fields of international and foreign law are under rapid expansion at the Columbia University School of Law.

LEUKEMIA CONTEST-- The De Villiers Foundation, a nonprofit organization created Jan. 31, 1949, encourages research into the causes, treatment and cure of leukemia and allied diseases. Its founder, Rudolph Roesler de Villiers, died unexpectedly a few months ago, but the work will go on.
WHEN Christopher Fry's "The Dark Is Light Enough" opened eleven days ago, New York's most cultivated audience assembled at the ANTA Theatre.
BONN, Germany, March 5 -- United States officials here seem confident that the Social Democratic party and the West German Trade Union Federation will cooperate in carrying out the Paris agreements.
A new play by the British playwright, J. B. Priestley, will have its first performance Wednesday at the formal opening of the new Hall of Fame Playhouse at New York University.

THE American Red Cross this month opens its annual drive for support of its humanitarian work. It seeks $85,000,000 for its many services--aid to veterans and their families; help for the sick and wounded; civilian disaster relief; a blood program for civilians and national defense; first aid training, and much more.

JERUSALEM, March 5--The Israeli Government is likened by one experienced foreign observer to a pair of brothers in an unfriendly neighborhood. One tries to win friends, the other relies on his fists. For six months the diplomat has had a chance, but now the fighter is asserting himself.

Home owners are urged by George C. Johnson, head of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, to review their property insurance at least once a year, and immediately after any enlargement or improvement is made.

From now on we shall be counting firsts, and cherishing them--the first robin, the first bluebird, the first crocus, the first hepatica, and all down the list. That somewhat alleviates the whims of March weather, for we know that snow and cold can't settle down among us very long at a time now.

The New York Athletic Club's power cruiser race to Block Island has passed its first halfcentury. Ex-commodore Carl E. Schuster, Dr. Alien B. Durmont and other Winged Foot members have new plans for this summer's fifty-first predicted-log event.

FOR years Civil War books have touched on the ill-fated courtship of the KentuckyTexas General John Bell Hood and the glittering "Buck" Campbell of the great riceplanting clan. In the Southern caste system of the Eighteen Sixties, the romance was one that intrigued a great many people.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5--Assistance to five countries will be recommended for the first time by the United Nations Children's Fund here Monday.

The big oil companies are acting on their own to restrict oil imports as recommended by the President's Cabinet Committee.

FAR and away the most popular of annual flowers today is the petunia. This may be traced to the many excellent and different varieties introduced in the last ten years or it may be simply because of their performance in general.
The North Atlantic passenger steamship trade is well on the way toward the busiest year in its history.

Vigilance, determination and education in the operation of the new Planning Act of New Jersey were stressed in an address before the Home Builders Association of Northern New Jersey. George H. Beckmann, broker, made the statement at a recent panel discussion meeting of the association.
DETROIT, March 5 (UP)--The Detroit Red Wings twice turned New York penalties into a pair of goals tonight to rout the Rangers, 6--2, in a National Hockey League contest before 13,717 fans.
An industry built on sand is prospering and becoming more solid each day.

THE outward purpose of this brief, entertaining first novel concerns the struggle of a Maine priest to succeed in his mission as Bishop of Seattle, Wash--apparently, Seattle was not yet an archdiocese. His predecessor had been a jolly, generous man who was inclined to over-indulge his priests and flock.

ALTHOUGH Tom Ewell isn't striving to be known as "Two-Feet-on-the-Ground Ewell," he has every right to the accolade. Mr. Ewell, it became known the other day, on his own stipulation, will take to the road in "The Seven Year Itch," the local company switching with the national on March 28.
HARTFORD, March 5--The Joint Education Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly is opposed to having the state set up and operate an educational television network.

An uncomplicated book, "The Small Rain" spins a beach mood of Swedish sand and surf, of sun-washed dunes and cool pine forests. The enchantment of the place permeates the book and gives the reader an urgent desire to go there.
BOSTON, March 5--Greater Boston taxpayers were billed this week for the rides they failed to take last year on the rapid transit system.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) --The White House Correspondents Association held its thirtieth annual dinner tonight with President Eisenhower as honored guest and the subject of a mild ribbing.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- In the shadow of Lakeland's 3,000-foot Helvellyn peak, Donald Campbell, 35-year-old son of the former speed king, Sir Malcolm Campbell, is waiting patiently. When Charles Chaplin sold his last remaining American film interest last week, there was an immediate reaction in Wall Street. Mr. Chaplin surrendered his 25 per cent holding in United Artists Corporation. Financial circles immediately concluded that the company was planning to go public. Rumors to that effect had been circulating for months; now they had something to work on.
ALBANY, March 5--The Republican legislative leaders accused Governor Harriman today of taking a "king - can - do - nowrong" attitude toward his 195556 budget.

A FLORAL extravaganza of unusual interest is scheduled for April 23 to May 3 at Ghent, Belgium. This is the "Ghent Floralies"--the name taken from a Roman springtime festival honoring Flora, the goddess of flowers-- which is held at five-year intervals and is unique of its kind, having been inaugurated in 1809 as a small flower show.

LINCOLN, Mass., March 5 (AP) --Joseph L. Snider Professor of Business Economics at the Harvard Business School and the author of many books or the subject, died yesterday after a long illness. His age was 60.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5--A United Nations commission made up of eighteen women leaders will examine the 1955 record made by women in winning political rights, economic benefits and educational advantages.

Foreign Minister and Vice Chairman of the People's Republic --a hugely important political figure, without doubt, but with no special overtones of glamour. COPENHAGEN, March 5-- Gunnar Nielsen returned home from the United States complaining of the lack of American hospitality and vowing never again to take part in an indoor track meet. He holds the world indoor record of 4:03.6 for the mile.

You may not be familiar with a curious mineral named diatomite, but you can hardly have failed to benefit from it in one way or another. And now researchers believe they are about to open a whole new phase in the mineral's career of service to man.

PARIS. COMPLETING two gifts made in 1949 and 1951, Monsieur Paul Gachet and his sister have recently presented the Museum of the Louvre with an important collection of works by Cezanne, Van Gogh, Guillaumin and Pissarro.

WASHINGTON, March 5--An American Zionist leader said tonight the State Department was excluding Israel from Middle East defense pacts. The methods used, he said, imply "a de facto withdrawal of recognition from Israel and denial of its existence.

LONDON, March 3--The first scientific observations made on a living coelacanth, or "fish with legs" have been published in the British science magazine Nature. The account came from Prof. James Millot of Paris, a zoologist who is organizing the capture of three of the coelacanths --relics of a long-ago era --in the waters around Madagascar.

WHEN Coleridge wrote that "Friendship is a sheltering tree," he must have been viewing the source of his inspiration from the comfort and intimacy of a tree bench. Such a seat not only encourages rest or sociability, but also proves a practical and ornamental asset to the lawn or garden spot.
FORT DIX, N. J., March 5-- Preventative treatment against the meningococcus organism was ordered for all soldiers here today by medical officials.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Mar. 2--Otto Koester's reappearance in connection with the slave labor test case of Norbert Wollheim now before the appeal court was not greeted with much enthusiasm by representatives of West German industry.

A JOINT effort in molding youth has been agreed upon by Johns Hopkins University and the American Broadcasting Company. Beginning Saturday, March 26, from 7 to 7:30 P. M., they will present a television program deigned to interest young people in science and engineering careers.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5--Of the seven Yankee squads Casey Stengel has had in spring training the current Bombers are the best-conditioned, he said today. "I've never had it so good," the manager declared between workouts on sun-drenched Miller Huggins Field.

WASHINGTON, March 5--Spring arrived in Washington this week, just before the Premier of Italy and just after Mr. Harvey Matusow, the inventor of the stringless yo-yo.

MOSCOW, March 5--For the first time in his eight years in Moscow the Swedish Ambassador, Rolf Sohlman, was formally received by a Soviet Premier today. He had a fifteen-minute meeting with Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin in the Kremlin.

The 1955 Summer Workshops in Family Finance is offering 450 scholarships at eleven universities under the sponsorship of the National Committee for Education in Family Finance, 488 Madison Avenue, New York City. Any educator who can demonstrate a need and use for family finance education is eligible for a scholarship.
Cornell University won the National Intercollegiate indoor polo championship last night at Squadron A. Armory. The team from Ithaca defeated Yale, 19 to 5, before a crowd of 1,000.

LOS ANGELES, Calif. SUNNY days and bright blue skies--typical California weather--ushered in "Plant a Tree Week," which began last Tuesday and terminates tomorrow, Arbor Day, with seventy tree-planting events.

Columbia beat Brown last night, 75--68, to gain a tie with Penn for first place in the Ivy Basketball League. Penn lost to Princeton. The Lions' game, played in the Columbia gymnasium, was the last league contest for the hosts this season.

Ned Buntline and those who followed him in the dime-novel, thriller-diller may be blamed or thanked, but the West, for fictional purposes, begins far beyond the Mississippi and ends on the eastern slopes of the Sierra Nevada.

THE "Income Stream" in the United States is now getting the assiduous attention and study earlier reserved for the stately rivers of the land. "The Changing American Market' is monumental in breadth of approach and the care with which the rapidly growing income stream of the American people is examined--an income stream that happily gives promise of a full and growing flow for a high standard of living.

IN the office of Al Altman, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Eastern talent executive, is a bulging file labeled "The Blackboard Jungle." It is packed with hundreds of photographs and resumes of boys in the 15-20 age bracket.

ST. PETERSBURG--Traffic over the Sunshine Skyway, since its opening last Labor Day, has to date exceeded the most optimistic hopes of the bridge's advocates. JACKSONVILLE, Fla.--Airlines and railroads have set early dates for the beginning of special spring and summer Florida vacation inducements, including the increasingly popular package plans and a lowered railroad coach fare.

Harvard's undefeated swimming team gained its tenth victory with a 70-14 rout of Columbia at the Lion pool yesterday.

The practice of "retained percentage" is freezing millions of dollars of building credit, according to the Producers Council. A recent conference of building industry executives urged that these credits be freed for active use.

THE theme for National Wildlife Week, to be observed this year March 20-26, is "Save America's Wetlands." The extraordinary value--and increasing rarity--of marshes, swamps and similar areas may not be apparent at first sight to most people, who have been accustomed to looking on wetlands as mere waste places, breeding grounds for mosquitoes and of no possible use.

The junior Senator from Arkansas, who heads up Congress' first stock market study in a generation, will yield nothing in polish, shrewdness, wit or intelligence to the men of Wall Street.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 5 -- Reduction of tariffs and quotas on Latin-American trade with the United States was urged today by Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
HANOVER, N. H., March 5-- Dartmouth insured itself of no less than a fourth-place standing in the Ivy Basketball League by trimming Cornell, 74--62, tonight.

RENO, Nov., March 5--Regents of the University of Nevada voted today after a fivehour hearing to seek an impartial investigation of the university's administration.

The National Association of Travel Organizations is promoting a reform which should appeal both to those who travel on holidays and to those who stay at home. It is so simple and makes such eminent good sense the wonder is it hasn't been adopted long ago.

HOLLYWOOD. SCREEN writers are by all odds the least publicized of Hollywood citizens. They turned the spotlight on themselves last week, however, by staging a big, friendly shindig --their own awards ceremony.
DETROIT, March 5--The auto industry's "little three"--American Motors, Studebaker-Packard and Kaiser Motors--are improving their production standing.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon returned today from his fourweek tour of ten nations in the Caribbean area. He declared these countries were entering a new era of political and economic stability.
AS we have come to expect during recent years the twentieth century paintings, largely French, shown at the Janis Gallery, form brilliant and exclusive gatherings. The present group is no exception.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 5 --A driver "education-enforcement program" has given the Pennsylvania Turnpike the best safety record in its fourteenyear history.
PARIS, March 2--The anniversary of the establishment of the French Line was commemorated today at the seaport of Granville in Normandie, as the centennial year of the shipping company hove into view.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) --The White House today assured 30,000,000 natural gas consumers that their pocketbooks would be protected if independent gas producers were exempted from Federal price controls.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "Tosca" Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc. Leading roles will be filled by Renata Tebaldi as Tosca, Giuseppe Campora and Walter Cassel.

Modernization of the internal structure of Tammany Hall along the lines being proposed by Carmine G. DeSapio, its leader, represents another major step in a studied and deliberate campaign to eliminate the stigma so long associated with the name of Tammany.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 5 (UP)--Pat Lesser of Seattle defeated Mary Ann Downey of Baltimore. 3 and 2, today to win her second straight title in the South Atlantic women's amateur golf tournament.

More than 500 persons went in the rain late last night to the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in response to a television appeal for blood for a child.

THE omelet party solves that perennial domestic problem -- how to entertain economically and yet with dash. A current fashion in New York, the omelet party may be staged in many settings--a kitchenette, an entrance hall, a dining room, a formal living room --wherever guests can view the preparation.

For a while last week it looked as if March, 1955, would replace September, 1929, as the historical month for Wall Street. New York's indoor track season ended last night as it started --with records, thrills and upsets. The thirty-sixth annual games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, staged before a crowd of 10,000 at Madison. Square Garden, produced some of each.

The Yankee manager folded his arms across his manly bosom and stared stonily across Miller Huggins Field, just like a sphinx. But soon his vocal chords began to simmer and seethe in the fashion of a volcano that has been suppressed too long.

Dear Mr. President: You requested the Internal Security Division of the Department of Justice to review the employe security program and to recommend any needed improvements based upon a study of the actual operating practices thereunder.
"I HOPE Columbus was right," said a sailor on the Atka as he gazed at the surrounding ice pack, "because if he wasn't we are on the edge of the world right now."

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, March 5--The Yugoslav Government has decided to create a central planning directorate for the country's electric power development program. This constitutes a reversion to a form of central control that the Government had tried to abandon in the past few years.

Robert Gordon Menzies warned last night that Communist and near-Communist propagandists were trying to divide and conquer the free world by exaggerating differences between the British Commonwealth and the United States.
WASHINGTON, March 5--The Eisenhower Administration wrote its prescription today for curing the ills of its Federal employe security program.
LONDON, March 5--George Brown, Laborite member of Parliament, warned his party today against its own destruction. He said it must end its internal feuding to avoid that.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. Newspapers are emphasizing more and more the need of improving the quality of teachers, to the end of lessening the volume of adolescent crime through the influence of better teaching. There is another need which merits equal emphasis.

CHOKE OF THE WEEK: A few mild days are not a signal to remove winter coverings and unhill the rose bushes. Loosen coverings around perennials and seedlings so air can circulate and prevent decay. Maintain deep mulches all year under rhododendrons, camellias and other acid-loving shrubs. Prop up coldframe sash during a warm midday.
THOUGH he is now 78, Pablo Casal has agreed to take part in another festival this summer in Prades, the town in southern France where he has lived since his self-imposed exile from Spain.

TO THE EDITOR: FOUND Kenneth Rexroth's review of Kathleen Norris' "Miss Harriet Townshend" most tediously dispirited. * * * His reaction to Miss Norris' world of "simple virtues and clearcut issues" is really rather pitiful.

TO THE EDITOR: FOUND Kenneth Rexroth's review of Kathleen Norris' "Miss Harriet Townshend" most tediously dispirited. * * * His reaction to Miss Norris' world of "simple virtues and clearcut issues" is really rather pitiful.

BASED on a collection of contemporary narratives edited in the eighteenth century by Bernardo Gomes de Brito under the title of "Historia Tragicomaritima," this study of disasters at sea between 1552 and 1649 clarifies one phase of the decline and fall of the Portuguese Empire.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 5 -- Earl Franklin Seaman, architect and planner of housing developments in this area, died unexpectedly yesterday afternoon in Irvington. His age was 62.

CONNECTICUT--Communities Students at the New Haven State Teachers College are participating in an unusual college-community program that has helped social agencies, children and the students themselves. The program, called Community Laboratory Experiences, gives sophomores, who the next year will go into the college's professional education program, some contact with children before they begin formal classes.

CHICAGO--Engineering and construction problems are the least among obstacles in the path of plans to speed traffic through northern Illinois and relieve pressure on obsolete local highways. If writs were pavement, motorists might speed through the Prairie State unstayed.

Balance of Power The central theme of the diplomatic history of Europe as recently reviewed in "The Struggle for Mastery in Europe 1848-1918," by A. J. P. Taylor, fellow of Magdalen College, Oxford University, is the Balance of Power (with the capital letters).

THE sixth Composers Forum at Columbia University on Saturday night introduced to United States audiences the music of Julian Orbon. The 28-year-old Spanish-born composer is already well known in Cuba, where he makes his home.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 6--Demand was keen in most sections of the stock market last week, under lead of Royal Dutch, Philips, Unilever and A. K. U., but interest subsided somewhat toward the week-end.
A new traffic and revenue record was set last year by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
Preliminary plans have just been completed for restoring Richmondtown as that peaceful, rustic former county seat of Staten Island appeared from 100 to 250 years ago.
Organized labor's no-raid pact was faced with one of its most complex tests yesterday.

THE Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, Fabian Sevitzky, conductor, which last performed in this city in January of 1950 and is now celebrating its twenty-fifth season, appeared last night in Carnegie Hall.
The Transit Authority officially affirmed yesterday that its deficit for the last half of 1954 came to $4,685,353.
PITTSBURGH, March 6 (AP)-- The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette tonight quoted Senator John W. Bricker as saying he had the support of President Eisenhower for a proposed constitutional amendment on treaties.
The 105th anniversary today of the birthday of Thomas G. Masaryk, the first President of Czechoslovakia, was celebrated yesterday in Gzechoslovakian tradition with native songs, music and gymnastics.
