CAIRO, March 6--Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia announced tonight agreement on measures to "strengthen the Arab structure politically, militarily and economically." They issued a joint communique in Cairo, Damascus and Riyadh, the respective capitals.

Dark shades in flannels will be popular in boys' and students' tailored suits next fall, according to a survey by the Boys Apparel Buyers Association and the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

The Ford Foundation appropriation of $50,000,000 for college and university faculty salary increases recalled yesterday other philanthropic projects that had benefited teachers in institutions of higher learning.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- The return of a rich store of captured German archives will soon become the subject of negotiation with West Germany.

Staging a fourth-quarter rally, the New York Knickerbockers gained a firmer hold on second place in the Eastern division of the National Basketball Association by beating the Rochester Royals, 101 to 96, yesterday afternoon.

QUITO, Ecuador, March 6-- Ecuador's President and a former President, although they are political foes, both insisted today that they believed the Ecuadorans had learned to manage their country by election rather than by revolution.

There was some unusual gear on the players' bench the other day as Vermont Academy's basketball team went through a routine parctice. In addition to the expected clock, first-aid kit, tape, bandages and reserve basketballs, were several hammers.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $64,331,594,349. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
ALBANY, March 6--The Republican -controlled Legislature is scheduled to pass its own revised version of Governor Harriman's Executive Budget this week.
The Rev. Dr. Chester A. Pennington announced yesterday that he would leave the Methodist Church, of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
The minister of the Broadway Congregational Church stepped back figuratively yesterday morning and took a confident look at the 50-year-old French Gothic edifice.
Rebuilding of the organ at the Riverside Church will be completed in a fortnight. It will then be the largest in the city. the city.

A concert performance is a searching test of an opera. GianCarlo Menotti's "The Old Maid and the Thief" survived it handsomely late yesterday afternoon when it was played at Carnegie Hall by the Symphony of the Air, with four singers and Sigmund Spaeth serving as the narrator.
ALBANY, March 6--Attorney General Jacob K. Javits wants the laws against the fraudulent sale of securities tightened.
ATLANTA, March 6--A group of race relations experts urged today that "responsible southern voices repudiate fraudulent leadership on the school segregation issue."
WASHINGTON, March 6-- Congress has taken new interest in a code of fair practices to hold investigations in leash.
The writer of the following letter was for many years a member of Parliament in the Union of South Africa and has held the post of Minister of Labor.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 6--The American Jewish Tercenterary Committee presented a plaque to the United States military Academy today in commemoration of Jewish participation in the nation's military service.
KREFELD, Germany, March 6 (UP)--Canada's Penticton V's won the world amateur hockey crown from Russia today with a 5-0 victory that stunned the Soviet skaters.
PARIS, March 5--In the dispute over the Saar territory, politics on both sides of the Rhine threatens to impair months of careful work by diplomats.

Louis Fontinato scored the first goal of his National Hockey League career last night at Madison Square Garden. However, his accomplishment was not enough to bring victory to the New York Rangers. The Broadway Blues waged a stout fight against the Detroit Red Wings but the visitors gained the decision, 2 to 1.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 6-- Willie Mays walloped his first home run of the spring training campaign today. The blow, a robust 400-foot clout that soared high over the barrier in left center, was the chief item of news at the camp of the world champion New York Giants.
The world ship-charter market definitely leveled off last week and dipped slightly in some sectors.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) --The Air Force is ready to examine 6,358 nominees for the first class of 300 air cadets.
ALBANY, March 6--Governor Harriman today appointed seven new members to the Temporary State Commission on Educational Finances. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., former Representative, was among them.

The story of UNICEF--the United Nations Children's Fund--is the story of the U. N.'s best-known, best-loved social agency, helping to health, millions of hungry and underprivileged youngsters of eightyeight countries and territories. Yet despite the great, long-term humanitarian work being achieved, always on miniscule budgets, UNICEF must perennially "present" its story to the more fortunate nations for continued support; when this lags, as is happening now, UNICEF's programs throughout the world are imperiled.

An investor has purchased the fourteen-story apartment house for fourteen families on plot 50 by 100 feet at 1067 Fifth Avenue, between Eighty-seven and Eighty-eight Streets, from William F. Chatlos. There are 133 rooms in the property, which was sold in a deal negotiated by Herbert Papock of Collins-Tuttle Co., brokers.

THE school building stood on the top of a high hill. It was a big brick structure housing both the high school and the junior high. From her desk in the study hall on the third floor Sarah Lou Gross could look out and see seven dwellings, a winding road and several fields that climbed the slope of another hill covered with woods.
WASHINGTON, March 6--The Administration has made a new and solemn appraisal of the military and political situation in Asia as a result of Secretary of State Dulles' visit to that region.

CHICAGO, March 5--The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced today it would ask the United States Court of Appeals on Monday to dismiss the fifteen-year-old "Detroit case," involving wholesale sales of gasoline to jobbers in the Detroit area.
JERUSALEM, March 6--Israel was condemned today for the battle with Egyptian forces last Monday night in the Gaza Strip.
PHILADELPHIA, March 6-- The Philadelphia Electric Company reported today that it produced and delivered more electricity, gas and steam in 1954

The deep and growing disquiet felt by many Americans about the operations of the Federal Government's employe security program has finally impelled the Eisenhower Administration to order some badly needed improvements. The latest changes represent a forward step which can be welcomed against the background of all too many public examples in which the security program has worked manifest injustices against loyal and competent federal workers.
LONDON, March 6--Last week the stock markets here remained unsettled but staged quite a remarkable recovery from the slump caused by the unexpected rise of 1 per cent in the bank rate.
ALBANY, March 6--Governor Harriman and Attorney General Jacob K. Javits will be the chief speakers at a conference on commercial frauds to be held at the Capitol March 15.

ABOARD U. S. S. ATKA, at Sea, March 6--The men of the United States Navy icebreaker Atka, who for two months have seen no other human beings than their shipmates, prepared today to enter the largest city south of the Equator.

BOSTON, March 6 (UP)--The Boston Bruins moved to within 2 points of third place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 3-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs before a crowd of 10,000 at Boston Garden.

The observance of Girl Scout Week begins today and will emphasize three ideas: "Believe, Belong, Build." Girl Scout Week programs will be planned to show that Scouting helps girl to live up to those high objectives, as Scouts demonstrate their abilities and achievements to parents, friends and supporters.

WASHINGTON, March 6--A conference of American and Asiatic business men to explore investment opportunities for American private capital in the Far East was suggested last week by Joseph M. Dodge, head of President Eisenhower's Council on Foreign Economic Policy.
THE telephone wire tap, which started, near as anyone can check, right here in New York City just sixty years ago as a police function, seems to have got pretty much out of hand.
CHICAGO, March 6--Illinois Bell Telephone Company announced today an increase in net profit for 1954, but it said the rate of return on its investment in plant and equipment was still too low.
The wiretap scandal is heading toward showdowns today in a grand jury room and in the New York City Anti-Crime Committee.
Opposite movements in British, sterling and the Canadian dollar proved the absorbing topic of interest to dealers in the foreign exchange market last week.

Technological improvements in the manufacture of dolls that started last year would mean increased prosperity for this segment of the toy industry and better value for consumers. That is the opinion of David Rosenstein, president of the National Association of Doll Manufacturers and of the Ideal Toy Corporation.
Dramatizations of three short stories by James Thurber, a man who is regarded with admiration and affection by countless men, women and dogs, will open tonight at the Theatre de Lys.
OSLO, Norway, March 6--The Labor Government of Einar Gerhardsen, which came to power Jan. 22, has found that economic laws also apply to Socialists.

An audience of 2,000 crowded the promenade ballroom of the Manhattan Center yesterday afternoon to hear the Polonia Opera Company present two oneact operas by Stanislaw Moniuszko, Poland's most noted nineteenth -century opera composer.

In today's news columns are reported the preliminary plans of the New York City Park Department for restoring Richmondtown on Staten Island. The department and the Staten Island Historical Society announced in August, 1953, a grant of funds from the New York Foundation to finance preparation of plans for preserving, restoring or rebuilding the principal buildings of the old county seat.
Thousands of radio listeners will turn out early tomorrow to honor a man who has been rousing some of them from slumber for the last thirty years.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- The President and Mrs. Eisenhower listened to a sermon on "Faith For Our Times" today by Billy Graham, the evangelist. He was guest preacher at the Eisenhowers" home church. The preacher addressed two congregations of about 1,100 each at the National Presbyterian Church at 9 A. M. and 11 A. M. Crowds of church members and visitors were standing in

PITTSBURGH, March 6-- Steel customers were pressing last week to get on the order books. Incoming business was up from that of a month ago. The swell in volume was occurring before the general seasonal advance usually appears--the middle of March.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- Secretary of State Dulles returned to Washington today from two weeks of observation of "the forward positions of freedom" in Asia.
VIENNA, March 6--Chancellor Julius Raab declared today that his Government would not be coerced by threats into granting Jewish claims against Austria.

WASHINGTON, March 6-- Fears that relaxation of EastWest trade restrictions would result in massive Communist buying in the West have been put at rest by preliminary trade figures for 1954, Administration sources said today.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- March winds caused scores to soar in the third round of the $5,000 Jacksonville women's open golf tournament today --with a four-way tie for the lead the result.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 6--John B. Royce of Brookline, Mass., had the best-of-breed winner tonight in the seventy-fifth specialty show of the Pekingese Club of America. The victor was Ch. Fabulous of Dah-Lyn, a 3 1/2year-old pale apricot homebred.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The inclusion of officers of the Department of Sanitation (foremen, assistant foremen and district superintendents) in the city's career and salary plan is a notable event that seems to have gone almost unheeded by any public attention.
The First Army surgeon announced, last night that the three cases of meningitis reported at Fort Dix, N. J., do not constitute an epidemic.
Religious support for the principles of Scouting was given yesterday to members of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York.
Six college students in the New York Times Youth Forum explored yesterday some of the reasons for the national shortage of scientific manpower.
Cargo Ships El-Yam, Ltd., of Israel has ordered from a German shipyard four of the largest all-purpose freighters in the world.
MADRID, March 6--It has become apparent during the last few weeks that Generalissimo Francisco Franco's plan to restore the power of the monarchy in Spain has stirred considerable political ferment.

SPORTS and vacation show highlights: A search that covered almost every tackle booth at the Kingsbridge Armory yesterday eventually was successful. We located a display that included, among other line-storing and line-dispensing gadgets, a piece of mechanism that undoubtedly will be unknown to our grandchildren--a baitcasting reel.

PENTICTON, B. C., March 6 (Canadian Press)--A crowd of 6,000, more than half the population, shattered the quiet of this Okanagan Valley town today at the news that the hometown Penticton V's had won the world hockey championship.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The tenth anniversary of the dramatic capture of the Remagen Bridge occurs on March 7.

Record sales and earnings were attained last year by the Oswego Falls Corporation, manufacturer of paperboard food containers and milk bottle closures and dairy packaging machinery and equipment. The report to be released today shows 1954 consolidated net earnings of $1,703,666, or $2.39 a share on 647,598 common shares.
ALBANY, March 6--The State Rent Administrator declared tonight that rent controls would bog down if landlords were permitted to pass along increases in taxes and other operating costs.
LONDON, March 6 (AP)--British exporters were urged yesterday to tackle quickly an expanding South American market or risk being frozen out for the next twenty years.

William J. Schmitt and Alexander Pfeiffer, trustees of Series F Mortgages, sold the Metro Theatre at 2255-59 Webster Avenue, corner of Ford Street, in the Bronx, to A. Cuneo for cash. Assessed at $140,000, the property is 100 by 125 feet and was sold in a deal negotiated by G. Satriale Son, brokers.
WASHINGTON, March 6--Apparently Tuesday is to be the big day in this week's "friendly study" of the stock markets by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.
TOKYO, March 6--Fear of an adverse reaction in the United States is causing many Japanese to reconsider their plans for increasing trade with Communist China.
Fog and rain disrupted airline travel yesterday and made driving a matter of necessity rather than pleasure.
G. Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, was the first witness at the Senate Banking Committee's "friendly study" of securities speculation on Thursday.

GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ballet "Ivesiana" had its first presentation of the season last night by the New York City Ballet at the City Center, and to make it an even more impressive occasion, he had added a new section to the work.
PARIS, March 6--Premier Edgar Faure returned tonight from a studious week-end in the south of France to confront a series of major problems.

THE notion that an advertising agency must be a corporate dolt in television theatrical matters is not standing up too well in one quarter. The J. Walter Thompson Company, one of the largest agencies, is quietly walking off with some major honors for distinguished TV drama.

Secretary of State Dulles returned yesterday with a word of cheer after another one of those appointed rounds from which neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night can stay his swift completion. This time he had been in such places as Burma, Indochina, the Philippines and Formosa.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- John Foster Dulles' meeting with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek on Formosa last week was not as chummy as the official pronouncements indicated.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6--He was exaggerating, of course, but Casey Stengel said today if he had his way the Yankees would play 200 exhibition games. The pilot would welcome a longer pre-season schedule than the thirty contests that are listed.

The National Cash Register Company last year increased its net income 14.8 per cent and attained record commercial sales, Stanley C. Allyn, president, reported in the annual statement issued for publication today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 6--United Artists will finance and distribute the production of "Storm Fear," to be made by Theodora Productions, the independent company organized by Cornel Wilde and his wife, Jean Wallace.

LONDON, March 6--The seriousness of the split in the Labor party was pointed up today. Several party spokesmen devoted much of their political talks to their own problems rather than to the failings of the Conservatives.
At the age of two or so a toddler learns that he can say "no." Parents are in for a lively time until youthful intoxication with this new power wears off, usually around the age of 3.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) --Authorization of quick tax write-offs for $91,320,649 of defense -connected business construction or expansion was announced today by the Office of Defense Mobilization. Certificates were issued from Feb. 10 to 23.
A kerosene - heater explosion killed one person in a Brooklyn tenement yesterday.
Faculty members of the nation's private colleges and universities are to get a collective salary increase of at least $50,000,000.

American labor unions have given three impressive demonstrations of enlightenment and maturity recently that call for public recognition. Of the three, the pledges of two outstanding labor leaders to fight racial and religious bias have the widest implications.

CHICAGO, March 6--Long liquidation in wheat futures appeared to have run its course last week, but other grains had periods 'of weakness as holdings were unloaded on a thin market. Corn and oats showed little inclination to rally, and rye had a wide open break at one time although making a good recovery from the low spots.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The Senate Small Business Committee announced today that it would conduct nineteen investigations or "studies" at this session of Congress. They will cover such topics as brewery mergers and New Jersey gasoline price wars.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 6--Sir George Bolton, director of the Bank of England and head of its foreign exchange control department, visited Switzerland last week. He discussed with banking experts the problems of foreign exchange markets -- above all, problems concerning transferable sterling.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- The Senate may decide this week whether to join the House in handing the President a Democratic plan to lop $20 per person off the income tax.
More American maritime workers reported injuries last year than in 1953, but fewer showed up for sick call, the Marine Index Bureau reported yesterday.

W. G. Crisp of Vancouver, B. C., has won the Dodd, MeadBoys Life prize for his manuscript "White Gold in the Cassiar," a story of a young boy's vacation in the Cassiar Mountains of the Alaskan Peninsula. Presented annually for the best story for boys 12 to 16 years old, the award consists of $2,000 and additional royalties.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 6--Don Hoak probably is the most determined candidate for a regular job on the Brooklyn Dodgers' roster.
The West Coast's largest coat and suit manufacturer is planning to make San Francisco the "Paris of the West."
About Reading "at Whim" Columbia's Lionel Trilling -- scholar, professor and writer of essays--in an interview the other day got off a particularly felicitous phrase.

A good reducing diet, according to Dr. Margaret Ohison of Michigan State College, has these important characteristics: It contains edible foods. It offers foods that train the appetite. It is built on foods that do not make the dieter conspicuous in a social situation.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 6--The Milwaukee Braves were singing when they reported for their first official practice last Tuesday. The rich baritone voice of Bobby Thomson was leading them.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. again asked Congress today to make it easier for the Government to prove alleged perjury.

Cotton prices in the domestic market were under persistent selling pressure last week. Active futures contracts traded on the New York Cotton Exchange finished from $3 to $4.05 a bale lower than the previous week.
Baseball is supposed to be our national sport. It has been shabbily treated by our creative figures.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., March 6-- Paced by Billy Olson in the jump and Henning Arstal in the slalom, the University of Denver successfully defended its National Collegiate Ski title today. Trailing the Pioneers as the three-day meet ended was Dartmouth, followed by Middlebury.
The luxury liner Queen of Bermuda finally sailed from New York yesterday for Bermuda after dismissing 300 strikers as "deserters."
SYRACUSE, March 6--The New York State Council of Churches urges Governor Harriman today to take the lead in organizing a "state-wide, toplevel, all-embracing attack" on juvenile delinquency.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 6--Princeton will meet Brown in the first game of an Ivy Basketball League double-header tomorrow night at Dillon Gymnasium. The outcome will make the second test, pairing Columbia and Penn, either a title contest or the first of two playoff games to decide the league champion.
The city's millinery workers came up yesterday with a new idea for safeguarding the industry's employers against the impact of business reverses.

Investments for equipment can hardly be diminished. On the contrary, all political leaders have recently urged increased credits to agriculture and increased investments overseas. Furthermore, a reduction in defense expenditures is judged impossible, in the first place because of the international situation, and further because the autonomous rearmament of Germany makes many experts fear that an arms race may develop between France and Germany.

PHNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 6--In any treatise on monarchic institutions a special chapter should be devoted to Norodom Sihanouk Varman, the impetuous King of Cambodia. For it is Norodom Sihanouk who first developed the sitdown strike as a royal technique.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 6 (AP)--Jimmy Clark of Laguna Beach, Calif.; Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., and Bo Wininger of Oklahoma City tied at 278 in the $12,500 Baton Rouge open golf tournament today. An eighteenhole play-off will be held tomorrow.
A United Nations study of how much the atomic and hydrogen bomb tests may be poisoning the world's atmosphere was urged yesterday by the Federation of American Scientists.

THE faithful turned out in force to hear Jennie Tourel sing a typically interesting program of songs Saturday evening in Town Hall. Miss Tourel has one of the most devoted groups of followers imaginable, and her work was greeted with uniform enthusiasm -- as much enthusiasm for those moments when she was not singing very well as for those moments when all of her resources were focused.
More advertising agencies are doing better. Last year there were sixty in this country and Canada whose billings exceeded $10,000,000 each. The figure, a record, compares with fifty-seven in 1953.
Sophie's new custom-order collection at Saks Fifth Avenue is a delightful medley of springfresh colors, floating chiffons and pleats.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Mar. 6--Unlike managers, who have only one guess, there are men in baseball who have two guesses. They're the chief scouts of bigleague clubs--and they had better be right both times.
Shipping, which cannot pass its bridges until it comes to them, faces the same danger in New York's Arthur Kill as befell a supertanker in the Suez Canal last December.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Again we congratulate The New York Times for its constructive interest in the affairs of New York City's public schools. The two articles by Leonard Buder give an excellent picture of the tremendous problems facing the city and its schools and also the fact that despite the great effort made we are lagging far behind in providing necessary and adequate facilities.
WASHINGTON, March 6-- John D. Jernegan, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, asserted today that Israel could not be included in any defense pact with the Arab states until tensions were resolved.
Andrew Frierson, baritone, was heard in a song recital at Town Hall last evening. The event was a benefit for the remodeling fund of Grace Congregational Church.
"The Truth About Wiretapping," a television play inspired by local current events, will be presented on Thursday, April 7, from 8:30 to 9 P. M., over the National Broadcasting Company network.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --Foreign interests were declared today to be trying to "scuttle" the law requiring that at least half of United States Government-financed cargoes be carried in American ships.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The apparent submission of industry and in particular the nation's automobile producers to the proposed guaranteed annual-wage scheme is appalling. As thus far conceived, the injurious effects on the auto industry and on the economy generally of such a plan would seem to warrant militant opposition on the part of the producers, one that would marshal the forces of public opinion against its realization.

If March's intentions are ever honorable, they are never clear. And yesterday they showed themselves in all their ambiguity. The morning was clear and snappy, as a good March morning should be. Something of Sunday's desultory drizzles was frozen white on the brown pavement and in the black gutter.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 7--Charges of a "deal" to permit the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company to build an "explosive" natural gas pipeline across Westchester were denied this afternoon by Republican county officials.

JERUSALEM, March 7--Three incidents that had contributed to the Israeli-Arab tension before the Gaza attack of last Monday came before the EgyptianIsraeli Mixed Armistice Commission today. Egypt was held responsible in two of the cases and Israel in one.

A plot about 90 by 100 feet containing four houses at 209 to 215 East Fifty-first Street has been assembled as the site for a, twelve-story and penthouse apartment building. The property was acquired by an investing client of Imre Von Schreiber in a transaction negotiated by Louis C. Dupuy Jr. as broker.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --Albert E. Kahn, New York book publisher today "proudly" invoked the Fifth Amendment and refused to tell Senators whether he was a Communist.
ALBANY, March 7--Republican legislative leaders decided at a policy conference today to defer action on rent control until the budget had been adopted.
BANGKOK, Thailand, March 7--Premier U Nu of Burma arrived today for a week-long state visit that is expected to further the growing amity between his country and Thailand.
The Rev. Georges Bissonnette, Roman Catholic priest forced to leave Moscow last week, said yesterday that "God is not dead in the Soviet Union."

MOUNT CHARLESTON, Nev., March 7 (UP)--The Atomic Energy Commission set off its biggest nuclear explosion of the year today. Extra precautions were taken to prevent a fall-out of radioactive dust on populated areas.
New York City is ready to take over the rent control field here if the state sees fit to abandon it, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --A compromise bill to increase the 1955 national cotton acreage allotment was suggested today by Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, as a Senate Agriculture Subcommittee wound up hearings on the matter.

Benjamin Franklin, James Madison, Evander Childs and Samuel J. Tilden scored firstround triumphs in the city Public School Athletic League basketball tournament play-offs yesterday at Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 11,000 looked on.
BUENOS AIRES, March 7-- Hopes were running high here today that Argentina would get her first large loan from the United States in five years. It would be for a steel plant.

Ronnie Delaney, Akron middleweight, gained the decision over Al (Sugar) Wilson of Englewood, N. J., in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The verdict in favor of the westerner was unanimous.
As a host to convention delegates and tourists, New York outdid itself last year.
Snowflakes mingled with sunbeams over the New York area yesterday.
LONDON, March 7--Britain announced tonight that Gen. Sir Gerald Templer would investigate the status of Britain's colonial military forces around the world.

BONN, Germany, March 7-- The West German Government's spokesman disclosed semiofficially today that no attempt would be made to negotiate with France over the disputed interpretation of the Saar agreement before final ratification of the Paris agreements by the French.
Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies of Australia received the city's honors yesterday and appealed for British-American unity.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Before the H-bomb reduces our cultural and industrial centers to contaminated, pulverized rubble a protest against the indefinite continuation of a policy of cold war through increasing armed power must be made.
WASHINGTON, March 7--The Army and the Air Force are sharply divided on the indoctrination of war prisoners against Communist brainwashing techniques.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7-- Leo Durocher took time out from routine today to appraise his bench. This is the popular term managers have come to use for reserve material.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- President Eisenhower heard a union appeal today for a minimum wage higher than the 90 cents he has recommended. He gave no commitment except to agree to consider the arguments.
BUENOS AIRES, March 7-- The United States Navy icebreaker Atka arrived here today, concluding her Antarctic mission exactly two months after leaving Wellington, N. Z.
The over-the-counter market in securities is much larger than all the stock exchanges put together. But it is far less publicized and less understood.
Daylight saving time may save the city treasury money for street lighting, as Mayor Wagner has observed, but Broadway showmen seem to prefer moonlight saving time.
WASHINGTON, March 7--A small band of heroes was inducted today into the Society of the Remagen Bridge under the sponsorship of President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, March 7--The Senate Banking and Currency Committee spent much of its time today on the over-the-counter market. This is where securities not listed on the exchanges are traded.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 7 (AP)--Duntreath Farm's Pegeen, a filly that had been tested against the best of her division, won the Lady Broadcast Purse at Gulfstream Park today before a sweltering crowd of 19,691.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The frightening resolution before the Board of Education of the City of New York, in my judgment, seeks invasion of human dignity. If adopted it would be a vicious attack upon the self-respect and conscience of our teachers, which each teacher is deemed to possess and which is so necessary for them to carry on in the classroom in the guidance of our children.
TRENTON, March 7--The New Jersey Legislature voted today to appropriate $200,000 for an "impartial" study of proposals to increase the state's supply of drinking water.

The 1955 Television Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association began a twoday meeting yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel. The group will review "certain portions" of its proposed program for the telecasting of college football games next season.
A Brooklyn youth was sentenced yesterday to a year in the penitentiary for sounding a malicious false alarm of fire. It was the stiffest jail term ever imposed for the offense in this city.
ALBANY, March 7--Assembly Speaker Oswald D. Heck said tonight that the appointment of more justices to the State Supreme Court hinged on the approval of Mayor Wagner.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7--Predictions of a breakup in the Arab League were denied today in a statement by Kamil Abdul Rahim, spokesman for the league at the United Nations.

BOSTON, March 7 (AP)--Jim Pollard sank a 20-foot push shot with thirty seconds left tonight to give the Minneapolis Lakers a 97-96 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knickerbockers.

LONDON, March 7 -- Industrial issues tended to ease slightly today in the face of light selling pressure. By contrast, British Government securities remained firm, several gaining about one-eighth of 1 per cent.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 7 --Columbia drew first blood tonight in the play-off for the Ivy League basketball title. Storming from 13 points behind in the first half, the Lions defeatet Pennsylvania, 73-71, on the neutral floor of Princeton's Dillon Gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --A decision to switch the nation's airways eventually to a new and still secret radio-navigation system is being challenged.
Three masked robbers took $24,459.23 yesterday morning from the Forest Hills, Queens, branch of the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

The Federal Trade Commission is taking the "hard approach to hard-core cases" of mergers. Its chairman, Edward F. Howrey, yesterday attributed the tough attitude to the commission's deep concern about the frequent commercial and industrial marriages.

The Fulbright Committee's request over the week-end for Pentagon data on defense contracts had repercussions in Wall Street yesterday. Aircraft issues suffered setbacks ranging to 5 points, and pulled other sections of the list down with them.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., March 7--New air raid warning signals for the United States and Canada were announced today by the Federal Civil Defense Administration.

A threatened strike today of workers on the Staten Island municipal ferry wag averted last night. Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, said there would be no interruption of service. He made this announcement after having conferred three and a half hours with leaders of Local 333, United Marine Division, A. F. L.

"The First-Nighter," a British comedy by Philip King concerning itself with the involvements, off-stage nad on, of a summer theatre troupe, has been acquired for fall production by Sandor A. Ince and Joel Schenker.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- The striking power of the guided missile--and a naval ability to deliver it--was emphasized to Congress today.

CHICAGO, March 7--The grain and soybean futures price structure crumbled again today under a wave of long liquidation, with the market still drawing its main support from occasional short covering. The markets were still victims of technical conditions, with the trade apparently more deeply overbought than was supposed a few days ago.
The sponsor who started "I Love Lucy" on television will sever its connection with the program.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7--There was a note of wonderment in Dixie Walker's voice when he spoke. "Never in my life," said the one-time Peepul's Cherce in Brooklyn, "did I ever see so many fine young ballplayers as we have here." Dixie is a new coach on Eddie Stanley's St. Louis Cardinal staff.
Nine weeks of "harmony" on the New York waterfront ended off key yesterday morning.

HOLLYWOOD Calif., March 7 --Robert Mitchum today became the newest member of Hollywood's growing star-producer colony. He has incorporated as DRM Productions and will make five pictures for United Artists.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 7 --With seven days of perfect training weather behind them, the Dodgers today announced a starting line-up for their first exhibition game against the Milwaukee Braves at Miami on Thursday night.
BATON ROUGE, La., March 7 (UP)--Bo Wininger shot a sixunder-par 66 today to win the $12,500 Baton Rouge open golf tournament in an 18-hole playoff with Jimmy Clark and Billy Maxwell.
Gimbels found out yesterday that shoppers snap up bargains on Herald Square as quickly as they do on Fourteenth Street or in the city of Washington.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 7 (UP)--Mrs. Jackie Pung, the transplanted Hawaiian playing out of Cincinnati, performed steadily today to win the Jacksonville women's open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) --The Department of Commerce today announced tighter regulations for the export of iron and steel scrap.
ALBANY, March 7--A bill to assure to New York City the full 5 per cent amusement tax was delayed in the Senate tonight-- by a Democrat.
The city has revamped its payroll system by throwing out a lot of the cumbersome paper work that long made steady drains on city costs and annoyed employes.
Thirty persons were overcoma by carbon monoxide fumes yesterday while working in a sportswear manufacturing plant in lower Manhattan. Sixteen were hospitalized, none in serious condition.

THE problem is how to make James Thurber's Mr. and Mrs. Monroe sketches fit the theatre. In a stage version by Paul Ellwood and St. John Terrell, three of them ("Three by Thurber") were acted on an experimental basis at the Theatre de Lys last evening.

When the Senate begins debate this week on the Democratic proposal to cut income taxes by $20 a person next year's Presidential campaign will loom in the background perhaps even more importantly than this year's state of the budget.

The new Hatoyama Government in Japan now faces the task of matching its election promises with performance. The promises envisaged a more "independent" national policy, based on increased military strength through speedier rearmament, and increased economic strength through "normalized" relations and expanded trade with the Communist world.
ALBANY, March 7--Governor Harriman urged women Democrats today to revolt against domination of the party by men.

Trying to match or mix fabric patterns and colors is sometimes difficult for the new homemaker who finds that decoration is just as much a part of her job as cooking. A new group of drapery and slip cover materials by Riverdale Fabrics now at B. Altman may help solve the coordination problem.

The seven major newspapers in this city are holding and enlarging their linage gains over 1954. A compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures indicated that the newspapers had 11,548,650 lines of advertising in February, compared with 10,897,328 in the 1954 month.

The General Motors Corporation's offer of 4,380,683 shares of common stock to shareholders terminated at 6 o'clock last night. According to all indications, the $325,000,000 financing was as fully subscribed as could be expected through the medium of an offering to shareholders on a subscription rights basis.

WASHINGTON, March 7--Unless the Government retreats in the case involving the Army's use in 1945 of the Austrian property of Maria Jeritza Seery, the opera singer, the Supreme Court will be presented with another constitutional issue involving Executive agreements.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 (AP)--George Gobel was named tonight the outstanding new personality in television at the seventh annual awards ceremony of the Television Academy.

The origin, of chili con carne-- literally, chili peppers with meat --remains a mystery. But there is no doubt of the growing popularity of this bitingly hot concoction of beef and sometimes beans, seasoned with ground dried chilies.

The White Motor Company cleared $4,888,644 in 1954, equal to $5.37 a share on 827,017 outstanding common shares, it was announced yesterday. For 1953, net income was $5,015,367, equal to $6.20 each on 782,497 common shares.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- About 250,000 new patients will enter hospitals in the United States this year because of mental illness.
WASHINGTON, March 7--A new judicial concept that limits the immunity of sovereign nations from legal action was announced today by the Supreme Court.
PARIS, March 7--A plea that the United States and Britain be asked to intervene in the dispute over the Saar territory between the French and West German Governments was made here today.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- Secretary of State Dulles conferred with President Eisenhower this morning on the need for a firmer stand by the United States and the free world in the Far East.
PHILADELPHIA, March 7-- The Democratic organization today selected Richardson Dilworth as its candidate for Mayor. The primary election will be May 17.

Elmer W. Endter, a member of Louis E. Wolfson's slate of nominees for the board of Montgomery Ward Co., resigned yesterday as an official of the Standard Oil Company of California. The board of Standard of California accepted his resignation.
BONN, Germany, March 7-- The movement of Germans westward that began ten years ago has continued inside West Germany.
Finished cotton goods are making a much better showing in the women's dress lines than activity at the gray goods level would indicate.
The University of San Francisco yesterday was voted college basketball's top 1954-55 team by the United Press board of coaches.

THE trouble with Howard Swiggett's new novel, "The Strongbox,"* is that it isn't a bit convincing. Its ingenious plot moves rapidly and is sufficiently original so that one reads on. But it is impossible to believe in its various wooden and theatrical characters and impossible to care a hoot what becomes of them.
SPORTS and Vacation Show highlights: If the show visitors were asked to vote on the most interesting display the chances are the antique decoy exhibit would win by an overwhelming majority.

A $2,500,000 first mortgage bond issue has been arranged by Brooks, Harvey Co. with an insurance company for the Rockaway Point Development Corporation, owner of the Rockaway Point summer resort in Rockaway, Queens.
The National Antiques Show, which sets up shop annually in Madison Square Garden, opened its eleventh display there yesterday for a week's run.

A Pause Between Enthusiasms The sap is starting to run and the gardener should be rejoicing. It's almost spring -- and green tips are pushing cautiously into view from the bulbs buried with such care last fall.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Building tradesmen started a big push today for new labor legislation.

Financing of the first part of the proposed Northern Illinois Toll Highway, a 193-mile project estimated to cost about $400,000,000, was discussed here yesterday afternoon at a meeting for representatives of about 500 underwriting and investing institutions.
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would increase its police force to a record total of 852 at a yearly cost of $1,400,000.
TOKYO, Tuesday, March 8 (AP) --Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor was appointed today United States Far East Commander in Chief and head of the United Nations Far East Command, effective April 1.
GENEVA, March 7--The task of revising the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) was completed today. The documents in the revised accord will be opened for signature tomorrow.
HONG KONG, March 7--The Peiping People's Daily said editorially today that Communist China would "welcome all genuine international efforts" to relax tension in the Formosa area.

SUFFERN, N. Y., March 7-- The Republican party will have top position on the village election ballots in New York State on March 15, according to a directive received to day by Village Clerk George Cox from the office of the Attorney General.

Two insurance men and a salesman were selected yesterday as the first three jurors in the General Session trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke, oleomargarine fortune heir, on charges of compulsory prostitution.

Cocoa futures fell the cent-apound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The spot month, which has no limit, fell 140 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The volume was 125 lots and there were forty-six offerings not taken at the close.

LOS ANGELES, March 7-- Sale of the 80,025 shares of common stock in Capitol Records, Inc., still held by the estate of George G. (Buddy) de Sylva for $1,400,437 was approved today by a Superior Court judge.
PARIS, March 7--The Pasha of Marrakesh, Thami El Glaoui, declared today that he was opposed to moves to replace the present Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa.

Muriel King has come up with a hatful of tricks in her spring collection for Stein Blaine. The star of yesterday's show was a basic dress with half a dozen presto changes plucked by manikins out of a magician's silk topper.

THE Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, will open its fifty-eighth annual Gold Medal Exhibition today. Partly installed in the league galleries on the second floor, the display overflows into the large and small dining rooms on the first floor.

La Salle's Explorers, headed by Tom Gola, start their bid for their second straight National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball title tonight when they meet West Virginia in the finale of a triple-header at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, March 7--The Supreme Court handed down a decision today in a case involving the renegotiability of the famous "Red Sea" charters.

The fifteen-story and penthouse office building at 711 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-fifth Street, has been acquired by the Columbia Pictures Corporation for its own use and occupancy. The building and leasehold ownership were acquired from Webb Knapp, Inc., and associates who retain the fee.

CHICAGO, March 7 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,500 head: general trade uneven, moderately active: butchers and sows steady to 25 cents lower, mainly steady to weak: most choice 190 to 230 pound

BOSTON, March 7 (AP)--The State Boxing Commission today handed Sugar Ray Robinson what amounts to a lifetime ban in Massachusetts for his lastminute run-out from last Saturday night's scheduled bout with Georgie Small of Brooklyn.

News that conversations have begun with West Germany on the return of captured German archives now in United States and British possession raises some questions vitally affecting our security. The German archives are in many respects one of the greatest intelligence treasure troves ever received by this country--treasure that is still in many cases of current interest rather than of interest only to historians.
The Furness Bermuda Line offered the olive branch yesterday to the 300 seamen, who walked off the luxury liner Queen of Bermuda last Saturday, stranding 560 Bermudabound vacationers.

A parking lot is the only construction a city contract requires New York University to make in the pending Washington Square Southeast redevelopment project, it was charged yesterday. The issue arose in a taxpayer's injunction suit in Supreme Court.
LONDON, March 7--Sir Anthony Eden indicated today that under present conditions an international conference on the Formosa situation was out of the question.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 7--President Tito projected Yugoslavia into the nuclear age on the domestic front today.
WASHINGTON, March 7-- The first perjury indictment against any of the Government's false witnesses on communism was returned today against Mrs. Marie Natvig.
ROME, March 7--The question of land tenure contracts arose again today to plague Premier Mario Scelba as he made preparations for his official trip to Washington.
YESTERDAY (March 7, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Met with eleven veterans of the Remagen Bridge capture ten years ago. Received National 4-H Club award winners.
A Bucharest radio broadcast has revealed that Rumania has found important uranium resources, and expects to build a major atomic-power industry.
ALBANY, March 7--The Harriman Administration's investigation of the State Liquor Authority ran into objections today.

In one of the sharpest breaks this season cotton futures prices fell 90 cents to $2.25 a bale yesterday. Trading was heavy all day. The market opened 4 to 21 points (fifths of a cent a bale) lower and abruptly broke to losses of 71 to 111 points on active months.
A union-inspired boycott of milk deliveries to two low-rent housing projects was called off yesterday.

Vernon Duke, the composer, has written his autobiography. Little, Brown will publish it March 24 under the title "Passport to Paris." Vladimir Dukelsky, the author's name in Russian, tells of his escape from the Bolsheviks, of his writing ballets for Diaghilev in Paris and of his success in this country with "April in Paris" and the score of "Cabin in the Sky."

The $50,000,000 promised private colleges and universities by the Ford Foundation to help raise their teachers' salaries is a truly magnificent contribution, promising beneficent results put of all proportion to the initially huge size of the grant itself.
Regulations governing the operation of proprietary hospitals will be tightened considerably.
The cool temperature and snow flurries set the mood for buying Christmas items at two toy shows here yesterday, but somewhat reduced the anticipated opening-day attendance.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 7--Bunting is becoming a lost art in baseball. Perhaps it is so because Ralph Kiner once remarked "Players who bunt don't ride around in Cadillacs."
PIERRE, S. D., March 7 (UP) --The South Dakota Legislature was accused today of persecuting the Hutterite sect, which lives in "share the wealth" colonies.

The New York Music Critics Circle yesterday voted a salute to the ninety-six musicians of the former N. B. C. Symphony who, instead of drifting apart when the National Broadcasting Company ceased financing them, have continued their orchestra under the name of the Symphony of the Air.
Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell declared last night that the level of labor skills has deteriorated so dangerously that our survival as a nation could be imperiled.

WASHINGTON, March 7--The Interstate Commerce Commission announced an inquiry today into charges that New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad interests were trying to gain control of the Boston and Maine Railroad.
CINCINNATI, March 7 (AP) The Ohio River crept tonight toward its highest level in seven years.
GENEVA, March 7--There are 385,000 Chinese refugees from Communist China and about 282,000 dependents living in Hong Kong.

ALBANY, March 7--The chairman of the Legislature's investigation of wiretapping said today he had decided to use William J. Keating, former counsel to the New York City Anti-Crime Committee, as an unpaid consultant.
New York's war on litterbugs yesterday became the affair of twenty-eight city departments.
SURELY there must be a trace of fairy dust from coast to coast this morning. Last night's television presentation of Mary Martin as "Peter Pan" was a joy.

FORT SILL, Okla., March 7 (AP)--A nine-colonel court-martial board acquitted Maj. Ambrose H. Nugent today on all Specifications and charges accusing him of collaborating with the enemy while a prisoner in the Korean war.
The New York Anti-Crime Committee will stand behind its former counsel, William J. Keating, in his defiance of the grand jury investigating wiretapping.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 7 (AP)--The Matsu Islands off the Chinese mainland, 100 miles northwest of Formosa, will be defended and are steadily being reinforced, junior Nationalist officers said today.

LONDON, March 8--Sir Anthony Eden today urged a settlement of the Formosa crisis involving concessions by both sides and leading to discussion of China's representation in the United Nations. The political future of Formosa would also be discussed under the Foreign Secretary's plan.
The Civil Rights Congress accused a joint legislative committee yesterday of having distorted at public hearings the financial accounts the congress had given to the committee voluntarily.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The once-beaten bipartisan farm bloc bounced up today with a bill to restore high, rigid farm price supports.

Single-breed dog shows in which the breed is divided by color, coat variety or size henceforth must carry through to a best-of-breed decision, the delegates of the American Kennel Club decided yesterday.

Multnomah County, Ore., borrowed $12,000,000 on serial bonds yesterday to finance bridge construction. The securities were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by First National Bank of Chicago at an interest cost of 2.0224 per cent.

The fifteen-story building containing fifteen stores and 106 apartments at 25 East Eightysixth Street has been sold by the estate of Alfred Falter to a client of Gershman Gellinoff, attorneys. The sale was negotiated by J. L. Nunberg, vice president of Byrne, Bowman Forshay, as broker.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) --The Government has decided to allow thirteen Russian student editors to visit the United States, Administration sources said tonight.
Every department in the store participated in Henri Bendel's spring presentation yesterday.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 8-- When the Giants and Indians squared away last autumn it was their first meeting in world series competition. However, the clubs were by no means strangers to each other.
Bankers expressed fears here yesterday that home building was going too fast.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 8 (AP)--Forces opposed to the United States-backed regime of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem have rebelled. The uprising started with two pitched battles.

LONDON, March 8--The stock market remained unsettled today, either because today was the pay day for the last trading account or because of doubts about the current period. Volume of trading dwindled further and prices drifted downward under light selling.

WASHINGTON, March 8-- Senators studying the behavior of the securities market heard today that, although stocks might not now be too high, the public was developing an all-too-familiar type of speculative hysteria.

WASHINGTON, March 8-- The policy of the Federal Communications Commission to give preference to nonnewspaper applicants over newspaper applicants in licensing broadcast stations was assailed in the Federal Court of Appeals today.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 9 (Reuters)--The Hungarian Communist party has accused Premier Imre Nagy of "duping the working class by demagogic promises" and causing the "unsatisfactory work of heavy industry in 1954."

"American Literature in Parody: A Collection of Parody, Satire and Literary Burlesque of American Writers Past and Present" is planned for publication next month by Twayne. Among the contributors to the volume are E. B. White, Mark Twain, James Thurber, Frank Sullivan and Cornelia Otis Skinner.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 8 --Joe Black may have mastered the "new pitch" that Charley Dressen tried, with disastrous results to teach him in the spring of 1953.
MEXICO CITY, March 8 (AP)-- Twenty-six persons, including four from the United States, were killed today in the flaming crash of a commercial airliner near Mexico's west coast.

The excesses of some notorious Congressional investigating committees have for years made it incumbent on both houses of Congress to adopt general rules of procedure that would curb the worst of the abuses.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- The White House staff, more powerful under the Eisenhower system of delegated responsibility than ever before, is gradually undergoing a fundamental change.

Commodity futures rose irregularly yesterday in generally dull trading here. The domestic sugar contract, however, registered the most trades of the year. Coffee, potatoes, cottonseed oil, hides, zinc, tin and copper rose; rubber eased, and cocoa, sugar, soybean oil, wool and burlap ended mixed.

Two women were among five jurors selected yesterday for the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke. One of the women had served on a jury that sent two murderers to the electric chair and the other is the mother of a divinity student.

CHICAGO, March 8 (AP)--Butcher hogs were 10 to 25 cents lower today at a top of $15.75 a hundred pounds. This was the lowest top since December, 1949, and as low as any since June, 1946. The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock markets follows: HOGS Salable hogs 13,000 head: general trade

The City Council approved yesterday a local law banning the sale, manufacture or possession of toy or imitation pistols or revolvers that duplicate the actual weapons. Twenty members voted in favor of the law amending the Administrative Code.
The New York City Police Department has not used wiretapping to the extent many apparently believe, the Police Commissioner said yesterday. He defended the practice.

Setting a Good Example Parents like to think --rightly or wrongly --that it is desirable to have children of school age regard their elders as having been good scholars; if not brilliant then certainly several notches above average.

SPORTS and vacation show highlights: The rifle and scattergun enthusiasts who gather at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx seem to be concentrating on one display. Ed Agramonte, the Yonkers dealer and gunsmith, has assembled an assortment of firearms that should delight any gun crank.

THE Alumni Association of the Manhattan School of Music generally presents its concerts in the school's auditorium at 238 East 105th Street. Last night, for the first time, it offered its program in a hall more accessible to the general public, the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

It will cost the city at least $3,000,000 a year--"if the city can pay it"--to take over rent control, State Rent Administrator Charles Abrams said last night. The change, he warned, would "substitute local pressures for what is now a sensible administration."
DETROIT, March 8 (AP)--The Chrysler Corporation paid K. T. Keller $300,900 last year as board chairman and a member of the finance committee. L. L. Colbert, president, received $250,900.

The Skelly Oil Company reported yesterday a net income for 1954 of $29,455.250, or $5.12 each on the 5,746,117 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $31,276,785, or $5.44 a share in 1953. Gross income was $211,081,894 against $215,316,524.
La Salle impressively launched its defense of the National Collegiate basketball championship by routing West Virginia, 95-- 61, at Madison Square Garden last night.
THE New Yorker, or the dweller in any other large city, for that matter, develops a natural sound-filtering system that protects him against sound-induced madness.
BUENOS AIRES, March 7-- Antarctica is literally at the end of the earth, but it cannot be ignored in looking to the future.
Mayor Wagner and thousands of other citizens got up early yesterday to pay tribute to a veteran radio broadcaster.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)--Wholesalers did $8,750,000,000 worth of business in January, about $700,000,000 more than in January, 1954, the Department of Commerce said today. Meanwhile, the report said, wholesalers' stocks of goods, seasonally adjusted, increased slightly from December to January with the entire increase in nondurable goods.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Legislation for a three-year national survey of the alarming mental health problem was set rolling in Congress today.
Toy producers were advised yesterday to keep their products out of cut-price outlets lest they lose the year-round business done by department stores.
LONDON, March 8--A stone quarry 100 miles west of London has been converted into a depository where vital records can be safeguarded from the effects of atomic and hydrogen bombings.
BANGKOK, Thailand, March 8--Premier U Nu of Burma said today his country would not change its decision to stay out of the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Alliance.
The charges made against the Hungarian Premier appear to darken still further the prospects of former Soviet Premier Georgi M. Malenkov.
YESTERDAY (March 8, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Cancelled some of his appointments because of a cold. Lunched with Bernard M. Baruch. Named Dillon Anderson as his special assistant to replace Robert Cutler.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 8 (UP) --By riding three winners today, Willie Shoemaker set a Santa Anita Park record with a total of seventy-six at the meeting. He has two days of racing here remaining in which to better the new mark.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8-- The Court of Common Pleas today absolved Local 1,291, International Longshoremen's Association, of conducting a secondary boycott in a labor dispute involving the freighter Panamolga.

A gala Golden Jubilee Ball to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the Travelers Aid Society of New York will be held on May 3 in the ballroom of the Ambassador. The event will be sponsored by the Celanese Corporation of America.

KANSAS CITY, March 8 (AP) --Quincy (Ill.) College's Hawks upset St. Francis of Brooklyn, 84--82, in the first round of the seventeenth national Intercollegiate (N. A. I. A.) basketball tournament today.

HOUSTON, March 8 (AP)--Wes Santee ran away from Fred Dwyer and Bob McMillen in the last 200 yards while easily winning the mile race in a PanAmerican team warm-up meet against the Southwest All-Stars. His time was 4:08.5.

Fernand Point, who died last Saturday in France, was thought by many to have been the greatest chef in the world. New Yorkers who had dined at his restaurant, La Pyramide in Vienne, just south of Lyon, recalled yesterday the man whose kitchen was known to gourmets from Shanghai to Seattle.

Veterans' organizations helping to combat juvenile delinquency were praised yesterday by Mayor Wagner. He spoke at a luncheon at which the newly formed New York County Joint Veterans Fund announced its budget.

CHICAGO, March 8--E. W. Endter said today he believed that both Montgomery Ward Co. and its competitors had tried to use "pressure" to prevent his leaving the California Oil Company to join the Louis E. Wolfson group battling for control of Ward's.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Secretary of State Dulles warned Communist China tonight that the United States was no "paper tiger."

Reports yesterday indicated that only 2 per cent of General Motors' new common stock offered as rights to stockholders had not been subscribed for by investors. A formal tally is expected today on the $325,000,000 offering which closed on Monday.

Five apartment houses in the Bronx have been sold in a single deal by C. C. I. Realty Corporation to 1886 Morris Corporation through Robert E. Hill, Inc., broker. They contain a total of 119 apartments.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 8 --The Connecticut General Assembly was asked today to create the Greenwich Gas System, Inc., a new corporation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of March 3 entitled "The $20 Handout" misses a most important point. It is undoubtedly true that politics was responsible for the timing of the proposal to reduce income taxes by a tax credit of $20 per individual.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8--Frank Leja, the 19year-old bonus boy, will start at first base for one of the teams tomorrow, when the Yankees play their first intra-squad game of the spring training season. It will be only a six-or seveninning "contest," but for the Holyoke (Mass.) lad it will be a chance for which he has been waiting.

WHEN Peter Churchill first went to Vichy France as a secret agent of the S. O. E. (Special Operations Executive) of the French division of the War Department he wore two money belts containing 2,000,000 francs. That was in January, 1942, and Mr. Churchill was 32 years old, a star graduate of a strenuous course in sabotage and underground conspiracy, a young man with a "resilient nature" and a "normal zest for action."
LONDON, March 8 -- The Labor party's Parliamentary leaders moved today to obtain the expulsion of Aneurin Bevan from the party.
KATMANDU, Nepal, March 8 --At 11 A. M. today the tourist age came to Nepal.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, said today he thought he would appoint a civilian committee to tackle the problem of brain-washed Americans.

More than half of the crewmen who walked off the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda last Saturday have reapplied for their jobs. This wag conceded yesterday by Fred Jones, one of three waiters whose discharge in a dispute over wage demands led to a strike of 250 to 300 crewmen.

MEXICO CITY, March 8 (AP)-- Jorge Pasquel, millionaire Mexican sportsman who led a raid on United States baseball talent in 1946, died in a plane crash in San Luis Potosi last night. Five others in the plane also were killed.
WASHINGTON, March 8--A Senate group today unanimously approved Dr. John von Neumann for membership on the Atomic Energy Commission.

Nine hundred twenty-three persons became citizens of the United States yesterday in the first ceremony of its kind in Brooklyn College's Walt Whitman Hall. Judge Walter Druchhausen welcomed the new citizens and urged them to take an active interest in their government.

The United States and Germany have reached a preliminary understanding on an American plan calling for a partial return of German property in this country seized during the war. According to this plan, which must still be approved by Congress, the United States proposes to return such property to individual owners in West Germany up to a maximum of $10,000 per person, and to restore all German copyrights, trade marks and cultural property.

Many of the principles that go into compiling a successful spring wardrobe can equally well be applied to Refurbishing a home, according to C. Eugene Stephenson, president of the American Institute of Decorators.

Plans have been advanced at recent meetings for the tenth annual entertainment known as the Bal des Berceaux, which will be held on the night of March 25 in the St. Regis Roof under the auspices of the Committee of French-American Wives.
The Senate Banking Committee's "study" of the stock market touched yesterday on one of its most controversial aspects-- margin trading.
Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies of Australia gave domesticity priority over diplomacy yesterday.

BONN, Germany, March 8-- The Bundestag debate on the Saar agreement will be reopened here Friday of next week. The Social Democratic Opposition has filed a motion asking that final ratification of the Saar agreement be halted until new French-German conversations have clarified its meaning.

PARIS, March 8 -- Premier Edgar Faure tonight won his first skirmish with the French National Assembly. The Assembly voted 364 to 242 to reject a motion to shelve the Government's proposals for increases in the pay of Government employes.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 8-- With the exhibition campaign only three days away, Manager Leo Durocher took inventory of his Giant pitching resources today. These, too, he seemed to find in excellent shape.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 8 (AP)--The New York Knickerbockers gained a 99-96 victory over the Rochester Royals tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
The 1954-55 Friends of the Philharmonic campaign to raise funds for the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra set a record, both in amount of contributions and number of contributors.

MATSU ISLAND, China, March 6--Today I stood upon a perilous outpost of the free world. It is on these tiny islands, the nearest only five miles from Red China, that democracy and communism come into direct contact.

CINCINNATI, March 8 (AP) --The crest of a "major" Ohio River flood rolled closer to the heavily populated Cincinnati area today but the Army Engineers reiterated that "there has been nothing like a catastrophe."
New York Archdiocese regional directors for the 1955 appeal of the Bishops Welfare and Emergency Relief Fund met yesterday to begin their campaign.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- Sewell Avery's management of Montgomery Ward Co. is facing a second front fight.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) --A left-wing labor union put up money to get Harvey Matusow, turnabout witness, to write a book, it was testified today.
Sigmund Janas Sr., former president of Colonial Airlines, pleaded guilty yesterday to falsifying its records. He appeared in United States District Court before Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman.

Domestic smelter shipments of slab zinc rose sharply last month, spurred by lively demand from the automobile, electrical appliance and galvanized products industries. And although production continued to rise, smelter stocks dwindled to the lowest level since May, 1953.
WASHINGTON, March 8--A basic code of fair treatment of those accused in House of Representatives investigations was approved by its Committee on Rules today.

A new study of 750 victims of rheumatic fever--"childhood's greatest enemy"--suggests that the hormones ACTH and cortisone are no more effective than aspirin in treating sudden attacks of the disease.
A quiz program offering $64,000 in cash to a studio contestant who can answer seventeen questions is being prepared for television presentation.

The fine results produced during 1954 by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau are reason for gratification and gratitude by all who share in the benefits. Since there can hardly be anybody who doesn't share in them, directly or indirectly, the jubilation can be general.

The following is the text of the address by Governor Harriman at the dinner of the nationalities division of the Democratic National Committee, Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, last night: I am happy tonight to join with the nationalities division of the Democratic National Committee and to salute the splendid work you have done for our party--including your work in the New York State campaign last fall.
LONDON, March 8 (AP)--Dai Dower, a 21-year-old Welsh coal miner, gained a decisive fifteenround victory over Nazzareno Giannelli of Italy tonight to win the European flyweight crown.

The coordinated effort Mayor Wagner has launched to exorcise the litter and dirt of New York calls for enthusiastic support by all concerned --and that means everyone in town. The public, outraged by the filthy conditions that exist, will be satisfied with nothing less than success in this effort.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 8-- French policy in Indochina seems to be changing. For a long time its obvious duality of purpose embarrassed General Ely, France's High Commissioner. From the start General Ely has supported the American thesis that South Vietnam cannot be saved from communism unless it receives full independence.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams urged last night that his successors be appointed for specified terms to guarantee that the Police Department would be free of political influence.
Longshoremen returned to work at the Grace Line's North River terminal yesterday afternoon in response to the urgings of their union leaders.

Looking over the panel of witnesses that the Senate Banking and Currency Committee announced it was calling in the stock market inquiry, some persons, one suspects, noting there the name of a Harvard economics professor, might possibly have wondered why, with so many experts on the stock market available, a man of his academic background should have been included.
The nation's post-war submarine construction program has produced many experimental vessels and prototypes of different kinds, but not enough of any one type.

LONDON, March 8--Sir Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that he was hoping to announce soon a 'new association" with Iraq. It would replace the present treaty with that country and bring Britain into the Turkish-Iraqi alliance.

YESTERDAY (March 8, 1955) TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council began general debate on conditions in Britishadministered Tanganyika for 1953. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Committee on Enforcement of International Arbitral Awards--Continued study of preliminary draft convention.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- The long-promised Congressional investigation of the Administration's security program began this morning. It recessed this afternoon in wordy confusion.

It was early rising yesterday morning for 300 young art students, bound on a special mission from Philadelphia to New York. Seven large buses deposited still yawning boys and girls at the Museum of Modern Art, at about 10 o'clock, to begin an unusual adventure.

PARIS, March 8--It was understood tonight that Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, would not ask Washington and London to clarify their attitudes toward the future of the Saar. This step was urged yesterday by a Gaullist deputy.

New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $44,000.000 will be offered to investors today. Among the offerings are debentures and convertible preference stock of industrial companies, new common stock of an Eastern public utility company and new capital stock of an automobile insurance concern.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 8-- Chinese Nationalist leaders insisted tonight that Matsu and Quemoy would be defended.

Wall Street broke ranks yesterday and stocks retreated in a disorderly fashion. Many prices fell 2 to 6 points and on four occasions the tape fell behind the floor transactions -- three times in the first hour and seven in the final thirty minutes of the session.
TRENTON, March 8--Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, angrily berated the Republicandominated State Senate today for its failure to approve acquisition by New Jersey of Round Valley.

TAMPA, Fla., March 8--Some men make a hobby of collecting stamps. Others collect money, either ancient coins or crisp new dollar bills. But Frantic Frankie Lane, the fast-moving general manager of the Chicago White Sox, has made a hobby of collecting third basemen. At last count he'd assembled thirty-four of them since taking over the front office at Comiskey Park.

The testimonial technique, in which well - known persons in various fields use and endorse a product, has been proved highly successful in making sales. An extension of this device, based on the experiences of animals, is being put into magazine space by the Carrier Corporation for its air - conditioning equipment.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8--A historic Hollywood association was resumed today when Samuel Goldwyn committed his film production of "Guys and Dolls" to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for distribution.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America had at the end of 1954 mortgage and real estate investments totaling $5,086,000,000, it reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 8 -- Grain futures rallied today, reflecting somewhat more confident buying in all pits. There was also considerable short profit-taking, following Monday's declines.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., March 8--Plans for the construction of a $300,000 race track for sports cars two miles north of this village were revealed last night. The announcement was made by the Bridgehampton Road Races Corporation.
ALBANY, March 8 -- All of the major Republican revisions of Governor Harriman's budget were written into law today over Democratic opposition.

PUCCINI'S "Tosca" was the opera last night at the Metropolitan, with Renata Tebaldi taking the part for the first time on this stage. The performance was given for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies.
ALBANY, March 8--The rivalry between Governor Harriman and Jacob K. Javits, Attorney General, over juvenile delinquency grew fiercer today.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America had at the end of 1954 mortgage and real estate investments totaling $5,086,000,000, it reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 8 -- Grain futures rallied today, reflecting somewhat more confident buying in all pits. There was also considerable short profit-taking, following Monday's declines.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., March 8--Plans for the construction of a $300,000 race track for sports cars two miles north of this village were revealed last night. The announcement was made by the Bridgehampton Road Races Corporation.
ALBANY, March 8 -- All of the major Republican revisions of Governor Harriman's budget were written into law today over Democratic opposition.

PUCCINI'S "Tosca" was the opera last night at the Metropolitan, with Renata Tebaldi taking the part for the first time on this stage. The performance was given for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies.
ALBANY, March 8--The rivalry between Governor Harriman and Jacob K. Javits, Attorney General, over juvenile delinquency grew fiercer today.

BOWIE, Md., March 8 (AP)-- The Bowie race course will open its thirty-three-day spring meeting tomorrow with the most lavish stakes program in its fortyone-year history and with every stable filled or allotted.
Another "crude, home-made bomb" exploded in a rental locker in the Long Island Rail Road section of Pennsylvania Station at 5:17 P. M. yesterday.
ALBANY, March 8--Republican lawmakers were just about back where they started today on the thorny problem of rent control.

A dozen librarians from abroad toured the New York Public Library yesterday. Outside, better publicized attractions of the metropolis went unnoticed as the visitors eagerly learned how the city serves its reading public and admired the extensive reference collection.
Roadblocks in financing the proposed 40,000-mile Federal interstate highway system were forecast yesterday by a special committee of the United States Conference of Mayors.

Drawing upon the nostalgic attributes of burlesque, "Strip for Action" will be groomed for the musical stage. Naturally, that snappy title will be retained. Based on the Howard Lindsay-Russel Crouse comedy, first examined here during the 1942-43 season, the shenanigans will be introduced by Howard Hoyt, in association with William G. Costin Jr.

CARROLL GLENN, violinist, played a Town Hall recital last evening, demonstrating that she has gained immeasurably in stature since her last appearance here in 1947. Her playing had breadth and maturity. Miss Carroll has gone a long way toward justifying the promise of her earlier performances here.
MOSCOW, March 8--Moscow has called Teheran's attention to the 1927 treaty between the Soviet Union and Iran. According to the Soviet interpretation, this forbids Iran to join any "military bloc."
Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain mixed a solid punch with a coaxing pat yesterday in his fight against city "litterbugs."

An aircraft company, for the first time in the peacetime history of the industry, has sold more than a billion dollars' worth of its products in a single year. The annual report of the Boeing Airplane Company, made public yesterday, gave its volume for 1954 as $1,033,176,265.
How much higher is the high rounded look? Exactly two inches, according to the design specifications of a leading corset manufacturer.

This nation's colleges and universities must train at least 1,000,000 young American technicians and teachers for service in under - developed countries, State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits declared last night.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- Top Senate Democrats promised President Eisenhower today a quick showdown on the tax fight.

Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' broadcast last night, as recorded by the New York Times: I return from two weeks in Southeast Asia and the West Pacific. I visited the forward positions against which the waves of communism are beating and where the issues of war and peace, of freedom and captivity, hang in precarious balance.
