WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Chemical industry spokesmen urged today that the bill extending the Rciprocal Trade Agreements Act be amended to give the Tariff Commission more authority over the President's rate-reducing powers.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 1 point up to 18 points down (5 cents a bale up to 90 cents down) yesterday.
The country's biggest union will become a federation within a federation if some of its leaders have their way.
ALBANY, March 8--Governor Harriman today nominated Ira J. Palestin of the Bronx, a leading member of the Liberal party, as a member of the State Tax Commission.
The appointment of Warren Moscow, Assistant to Mayor Wagner, as executive director of the New York City Housing Authority was announced yesterday by Philip J. Cruise, authority chairman.

JERICHO, Jordan, Feb. 26-- Twenty-three successive walls of Jericho tumbled down long before Joshua's priests "blew with the trumpets" about 3,300 years ago. A team of British and American archaeologists has discovered the walls.
WASHINGTON, March 8-- President Eisenhower named Dillon Anderson today to be his Special Assistant for National Security Affairs.
NORFOLK, Va., March 8-- Improper loading coupled with adverse sea conditions was given today as the basic cause of the capsizing and sinking of the freighter Mormackite off Cape Henry last October.

Mayor Wagner says that "the City of New York is prepared to take over the rent control field if the state sees fit to abandon it." We hope that necessity will not arise, and the Mayor says he does too. It would, in our opinion, prolong if not perpetuate rent control.
A ten-week waterfront training program for port watchmen is being planned by seven portwatching companies employing 1,000 men.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Repeal of statutes that permit manufacturers to fix retail prices with immunity from the antitrust laws will be advocated in a report at the end of this month.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 9 (AP)--Setting a track record, Hilton Dabson's and C. J. Caithness' Nance's Lad injected himself into the Florida Derby picture today. He scored a lengthand-a-half victory, beating nine 3-year-old opponents in the second running of the Hutcheson Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

GREENOCK, Scotland, March 9 (Reuters)--Crystal Cube, first ship of her type in the world to carry raw sugar cane in bulk-- instead of in bags--was launched here today. The sponsor was Mrs. Ian Lyle, wife of the chairman of Tate Lyle, sugar refiners.

WASHINGTON, March 9-- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 2: Decreases of $151,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $474,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted and $131,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and an increase of $500,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks.
Secretary of State Dulles has warned the Chinese Communists that the tiger has claws.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 9-- The proposal by the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Anthony Eden, for a Formosa settlement brought varied reactions here.
A Defeat for New York News that New York City may lose the headquarters of the nation's engineering societies is an echo of a happening seventy-five years ago today.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., March 9--The official coast-to-coast speed record of just over four hours was smashed by the Air Force today, not once but three times.
The city's school building and modernization program achieved its greatest gains last year.

Four modern concertos, three of them heard for the first time in this city, were presented last night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The soloists were the Ajemian sisters --Maro, pianist, and Anahid, violinist.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conductor, with the Harvard Glee Club and Radcliffe Choral Society, giving their 100th performance together, united forces last night in Carnegie Hall for Mr. Munch's interpretation of Berlioz' "Damnation of Faust."
LONDON, March 9--Reports that Princess Margaret intends to marry Group Captain Peter Townsend, British Air Attache in Brussels, are circulating here.

State Controller Arthur H. Levitt announced yesterday plans for the sale of $50,715,000 of New York State housing bonds on March 22. The obligations will be dated April 1, 1955, and will come due serially on April 1 from 1957 to 2005.
BONN, Germany, March 9-- The crisis in Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's coalition over the Free Democratic party's opposition to the Saar agreement appeared today to have been settled.
The stock market spent much of yesterday demonstrating the well-known fact that securities prices can go down as well as up.

A capacity crowd filled the Astor Theatre last night for the world premiere of the Warner Brothers film "East of Eden." The entire proceeds were donated to the non-profit drama workshop, the Actors Studio.
WASHINGTON, March 9--Defense Department officials supplied fresh ammunition today for the Democratic campaign against the Administration's so-called "numbers game" on security risk dismissals.
When Capt. Jan P. Boshoff makes his next trip to this country it will be as a back-seat driver at best.
An economist said yesterday that "the pattern of business activity this year seems likely to be a good first half with some hesitation in the second half."
The city's top school authorities pleaded yesterday for the $3,500,000 item in Governor Harriman's budget for special aid to Spanish-speaking children in the public schools here.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 9-- It was virtually home run or no count today as the Giants' junior varsity turned the tables on the regulars in a seven-and-a-halfinning intrasquad game.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 9 (UP)--Barbara Romack of Sacramento, Calif., and Mrs. Marjorie Lindsay McMillen of Decatur, Ill., shot sub-par golf today as all the favorites survived the first round of match play in the Florida East Coast women's amateur championship.

SAYREVILLE, N. J., March 9 --A robot toll collector made its official debut today at the Raritan toll plaza of the Garden State Parkway here. It flashes a green light for honest, tollpaying customers, but turns on red lights and an alarm bell and sets off a camera to catch shortchange artists or deadbeats.
With the economy on the upgrade, business men across the country are rapidly stepping up their bank borrowings.
Mrs. Marjorie Post Close Hutton Davies was granted a divorce yesterday from Joseph E. Davies, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

The action of the Senate Judiciary Committee yesterday in endorsing John Marshall Harlan for the Supreme Court came four months to the day after President Eisenhower had nominated him. If there had been any material reasons for questioning the President's selection, the delay would of course have been understandable.

WASHINGTON, March 9--Inevitably protests have followed the recent public realization that general use of the United States mails is denied to Pravda, Izvestia and other foreign organs of international communism. The ban by the Post Office Department is not new, and the Attorney General's opinion which confirms the department's power to make this exclusion dates back to 1940.
PARIS, March 9--The hope of a four-power conference on Germany next May is still held by the present Government. Such a conference was proposed by former Premier Pierre MendesFrance.

The Heald Commission on Educational Finances, recently enlarged with the appointment of a half dozen new members by Governor Harriman, meets again in New York City tomorrow. The importance of its assignment has been freshly emphasized by the budget controversy now going on in Albany.
WASHINGTON, March 9--The managing partner of the world's largest brokerage house said today that he did not know where the stock market was going to go and doubted that anyone else did.
ALBANY, March 9--The Legislature completed passage today of twelve budget bills submitted by Governor Harriman.
Name your favorite spring fashion and, if it is one of the leading trends, Bloomingdale's Green Room is almost sure to have it.
Mayor Wagner's aides are completing the draft of a bill to eliminate state representation on the New York City Transit Authority.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 --Three novels by the late Thomas Wolfe have been acquired for filming by GregoryGoldman Productions.
Six thousand teen-age boys attended a mass in honor of St. Dominic Savio at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

Newspaper campaigns will break this month for the shaving and writing instrument divisions of Eversharp, Inc., and will continue at a saturation level through August. The announcement was made jointly yesterday by Cunningham Walsh, which handles the account, and the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

SPORTS and vacation show highlights: Among the items on display on the Kingsbridge Armory acreage are several that should be of real interest to the angler or hunter who wants to "rough it" in reasonable comfort.

Soviet Russia has been weakened by the continuing internal struggle for control and by an agricultural crisis, Harrison E. Salisbury, former Moscow correspondent for The New York Times, said yesterday.
Some questions that may have been puzzling many about a police raid on an alleged wiretapping center in East Fifty-fifth Street Feb. 11 were purportedly answered yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Factory employment picked up in February, the Government said today. The total job situation, however, was not significantly different from January's.

ADMIRERS of Campigli will find in recent paintings by this Italian contemporary at the Cadby Birch Gallery, 21 East Sixty-third Street, that the archaically mannered ladies who have featured so prominently in his past work are still in fine shape.

Paul M. Butler, Democratic national chairman, pictured the Eisenhower Administration last night as one of shadows rather than substance. In many respects, he said, the Administration is following a course to the right of the late Senator Robert A. Taft.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Paul G. Hoffman, former Foreign Aid Administrator, told the Senate Finance Committee today that the reciprocal trade bill should be passed unchanged.

The country will not face a housing slump as long as the economy is prosperous, "as it apparently will remain," a construction economist told bankers here yesterday. A banking leader, however, took a more cautious view.

WASHINGTON, March 9-- The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that a trade group and more than a score of its members had conspired to restrain competition in the sale of advertising specialties. These included calendars, cigarette lighters, notebooks and key cases distributed by concerns to create goodwill among customers.
LONDON, March 9 -- British engineers have successfully tested a new lightweight aircraft ejection seat that can parachute a pilot to safety from a speeding aircraft, even at ground level.

The Marine Midland Corporation announced yesterday the election of Charles H. Diefendorf as chairman of the board of directors and the appointment of Baldwin Maull as president. Bayard F. Pope, who had been chairman since 1934, has been named chairman of the executive committee.

LONDON, March 9--Sir Winston Churchill will spend a short holiday in Sicily during the Easter recess of Parliament. Because the future of Sir Winston is the future of British politics in what both parties now consider an election year, his holiday, announced today, has reawakened speculation about the Prime Minister's plans and the course of Conservative party policy.
The Communist party's bitter attack yesterday on Premier Imre Nagy suggests he is to be made the scapegoat for Hungary's recent economic failures.

LONDON, March 9-The break in Wall Street on Tuesday depressed prices further here today. Losses by Government stocks ranged up to 2 shillings 6 pence ($1.35) and in industrial shares to 2 shillings (28 cents). Sentiment also was affected by reports that Australia might curtail imports.
Into every homemaker's routine there comes a time, once or twice a week, when she is forced to a standstill. This is the period known as standing-in-line-at-thesupermarket.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 8--A conference of anti-Communist countries to discuss the defense of South Africa has been proposed by the South African Government.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Qualified officials discounted today a United Press report from Tokyo that suggested general war in Asia might be only a few weeks away.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP)--Butcher hogs sold steady to 25 cents higher while sows held steady today as the market staged a mild recovery from its five-year low of yesterday.

Eight individual champions and a team champion were crowned in the nineteenth annual Eastern Golden Gloves Amateur boxing program sponsored by the News Welfare Association at Madison Square Garden before 8,799 fans last night.
Two union officials were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy to extort $64,000 from members of a dairymen's organization under threat of labor trouble.
A plan under which Americans of Scottish descent would give financial assistance to their Highland kin was outlined yesterday by Lord Malcolm DouglasHamilton.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 (UP)--Jimmy Murray, the promoter, announced today that the Rocky Marciano - Don Cockell world heavyweight title fight would be held at Kezar Stadium May 16. He predicted a milliondollar gate for the bout.
WASHINGTON, March 9-- The Democratic leadership of the Senate heavily counter-attacked the Eisenhower Administration today in the tax fight.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP)--The Department of Justice promised today to keep an eye on the synthetic rubber industry for anti-trust violations.
WASHINGTON, March 9--A Senate committee planned today to start investigating television networks late this month.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 (AP)--Raul (Raton) Macias of Mexico tonight scored a technical knockout over Chamrern Songkitrat of Thailand at 2:38 of the eleventh round to win the National Boxing Association's version of the world bantamweight championship.
TOKYO, March 9 (AP)--The Peiping radio warned today that any interference with the Finnish tanker Aruba or her cargo of fuel oil on the high seas "is not to be tolerated."
YESTERDAY (March 9, 1955) TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council continued general debate on British-administered Tanganyika. Standing Committee on Petions --Considered draft report concerning Tanganyika.

YESTERDAY (March 9, 1955) THE GOVERNOR Returned from New York City. Held Cabinet meeting with members of his staff and department heads. Met with thirty-two lawyers from fourteen foreign countries taking advanced studies at the New York University Law Center.
WASHINGTON, March 9--A "community approach" to curing the 750,000 patients now in this country's mental hospitals was urged today.
Next Monday workmen will begin removing doors, chandeliers and other fixtures from the vacant offices of the Pulitzer Building at 63 Park Row. This will begin the demolition of the old structure.
ROME, March 9--The Church of Christ refused today to compromise in its "war of the sign" with the Italian police.
The Temporary State Commission on the Courts was urged yesterday to support a more sweeping reorganization of the city's youth courts than it had yet been willing to recommend.
WASHINGTON, March 8--The Export-Import Bank of Washington today approved a credit of $1,023,000 for the Nordberg Manufacturing Company of Milwaukee.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9--It happens every Spring. The rookies "stole the show" today at Miller Huggins Field in the Yankees' only intrasquad game of the training season.
CHICAGO, March 9--Louis E. Wolfson, fighting for control of Montgomery Ward Co., defended his business record today on the mail order company's home grounds.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Ten unions announced today that they would strike three Southern railroads Monday.

Five books of fiction and nonfiction about Africa have been listed in this space in the last two weeks. Now two more have been announced for publication this month. One is John Wiles' "The Moon to Play With." It is a novel about a good-humored South African Negro youth engulfed by white civilization.
Lack of money is forcing many private welfare agencies to curtail their services, particularly in child care, Raymond W. Houston, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, said yesterday.
TOKYO, March 9--Harold E. Stassen warned the Japanese today that too much reliance on trade with the Communists would be risky.
ROME, March 9 -- During a debate on the Paris agreement today, gray-haired Communist and neo-Fascist Senators argued with their fists.

"THE POSTMAN"* is a short novel, a minor work, written by Roger Martin du Gard in 1933, at a time of his life when he had first surmounted a terrible physical crisis. He then resolved a severe artistic conflict (the details of which, with a reticence characteristic of him and altogether unusual in a novelist, he has never discussed).
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 9--Princeton routed Columbia, 86--69, tonight to win the Ivy Basketball League title and a berth in the National Collegiate championship tournament.

With obvious concern over the explosive situation in the Far East, but with continued hope for the preservation of peace, Secretaries Dulles and Eden have now reported on their recent consultations in Asia and the policies their Governments propose to pursue to avert a crisis.

TOKYO, March 9--While the Chinese Communists are conceded to be in a position to take Quemoy and Matsu islands "any time," the Reds are in no position to undertake a dangerous assault on Formosa, according to the best available information here.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- President Eisenhower joined twenty Republican women at breakfast today.

An increase last week of 1,033,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend supplies were 182,343,000 barrels, a new record, compared with 181,310,000 a week earlier and 177,563,000 a year earlier.

PONCHIELLI'S "La Gioconda" is full of good tunes. It was Wagner who said there was enough material in it for several operas. There is certainly enough to give everyone-- principals, chorus, ballet and orchestra--something interestto do.

After an ownership of a few months, the six-story business building on lot 25 by 100 feet at 9 East Forty-seventh Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, has been resold by Leo Kossove, operator, to an investor.
Radio and television stations here have taken measures to curb misrepresentation in advertising.

BUENOS AIRES, March 9-- Eleven Antarctic penguins, wrapped in Argentina's summer sun and red tape, languished today on the decks of the icebreaker Atka in Buenos Aires harbor. However, hopes grew during the day that they could be put aboard a freight plane next Monday and flown to zoos in the United States.

CHICAGO, March 9--Sharp gains were registered in grain and soybean futures, but the early high spots attracted considerable selling and the market reacted from the extreme advances. Outside trade was not disposed to follow the upturns, but there was commission support on setbacks.
Martin's of Brooklyn is out to fool the eye this spring. Belts, pockets and tabs appear in unexpected places on their new coats, which are now ready for the racks.
ALBANY, March 9 -- A new Republican rent-control bill was in preparation today. Its tentative provisions represent a substantial retreat from earlier proposals.

The six-story building containing fifty-eight apartments at 15 Crown Street in Brooklyn has been purchased by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York in behalf of an investing syndicate. The sellers were Louis Kroman and Tillie Meerbaum.
ALBANY, March 9 -- The trouble with the state employes' retirement system is that few employes benefit by it.
BUENOS AIRES, March 9-- The French Convent of the Assumption, one of Buenos Aires' largest and most exclusive religious schools, has been closed by the Ministry of Education.

When the Government of Hungary announced a month ago that Premier Imre Nagy was "ill" and would be inactive for at least some months many observers speculated that his "illness" was at least as much political as it was physical. These speculations have now been fully borne out with publication of the Hungarian Communist party Central Committee's attack on Nagy's "rightist deviationism" and "anti-Marxist ideas."
Electric skillets, pressure cookers, packaged ready-to-brown biscuits, muffin and pastry mixes --these are the props that today's cook will put to work in simplifying old-fashioned apple recipes.
The inscription "E. G. Booz's Old Cabin Whiskey" on an amber glass bottle is today a collector's item.

The New York Knickerbockers face the Boston Celtics tonight in the first of three games in four days between these teams. Second place is at stake in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division.
LONDON, March 9--The House of Commons rejected tonight a Labor party motion censuring the Government on "the serious situation" in the cotton industry. The vote was 288 to 256.

The Waterfront Commission is prepared to approve all existing longshore "area" hiring customs and practices that are not in direct contravention of the law. However, the bi-state agency wants all such practices "put on paper" for study and comparison with the intent of the Waterfront Compact.
The annual luncheon in behalf of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will be given on Tuesday at the Town Hall Club.

WASHINGTON, March 9--The House Armed Services Committee today approved construction of three more atomicpowered submarines, a fifth supercarrier and conversion of more ships for guided missile operation.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) --The Pacific Northwest Pipeline Corporation today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve sale of stock to finance its construction of the first natural gas pipeline into Oregon and Washington.
Mayor Wagner does not think much of the proposal that the Police Commissioner be appointed for a fixed term and be removable only for malfeasance or misfeasance.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently The New York Times deplored the decline of Slavic studies in the educational institutions of this country. One reason cited for the decline was the fear of students that their study of Russian or related languages might subject them to future investigations.
The number of civilian employes at the New York Port of Embarkation will be cut by about 500 within a few weeks as a result of less work and improved operational methods.
The International Longshoremen's Association took a long step last night toward re-entering the American Federation of Labor.
MOSCOW, March 9 --This spring workmen will begin dismantling the steel frame of what was to have been a forty-sixstory Government office building.
A police raid last night broke up a dice game called "bunko" played by 400 Queens women to raise money for the New York Heart Association.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 9-- The family automobile, a necessity for Nassau County's 1,000,000 shopping and commuting residents, poses an ever-increasing parking headache for motorists and municipal official alike.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Times should be commended for its continuing interest in court reform, as is evident by the editorial entitled "Judges' Report to Laymen" and by many news and special articles on the subject.

WASHINGTON, March 9--The Judiciary Committee voted today to report favorably to the Senate the nomination of Judge John Marshall Harlan for the Supreme Court. Five Democrats and five Republicans voted for the appointment, two Democrats and two Republicans against it.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 9 (UP)--Abe Hirschberg's Berseem got Johnny Longden as a rider today and raced to a length and a half victory in the $28,250 Santa Barbara Handicap at Santa Anita Park.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 9 (UP)--One of the leaders of a rebellion against the Government of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem surrendered today with 600 of his troops.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

ALBANY, March 9--Long Island commercial fishermen clashed with sportsmen today over a proposed law specifying that striped bass be caught only by hook and line. Nets would be outlawed. Spokesmen for the commercial fishermen warned that the bill's adoption would result in the loss of 500,000 pounds of striped bass from the market and make the price prohibitive.
WASHINGTON, March 9-- The United States views as "a matter of grave concern" shipment of kerosene bound for Communist China aboard the Finnish tanker Aruba.
The wildcat strike of British seamen from the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda collapsed yesterday.

The federal employes' security program as conducted by both the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations has produced some severe jolts to traditional American concepts of fair play. But few official governmental statements on the subject have been more shocking in their implications than the one published in this newspaper yesterday coming from Assistant Attorney General William F. Tompkins.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 9 --Walt Alston would "like to see fewer home runs and more base hits" by his 1955 Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) --Edward T. McCormick, president of the American Stock Exchange, warned the Securities and Exchange Commission today against making corporations submit semi-annual financial reports.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 17 to 27 points (85 cents to $1.35 a bale) yesterday.
The New York commodity futures markets firmed yesterday. Dealers attributed the price rises to increased tension in the Far East.

Color sets the stage for modern living in B. Altman's newly redecorated Young Homemakers rooms. It gives a contemporary touch to settings using traditional or colonial furniture and becomes the blender for mixture of styles.
The Sanitation Department fired a warning shot yesterday while its big guns were being wheeled into position to blast litter out of the city's streets.
Fire engines from now on will take the right of way in city traffic returning from as well as going to fires.

The newly organized House, in its efforts to create an issue that might embarrass the Administration, is more likely, if it continues along present lines, to embarrass the Senate and ultimately the Democratic party. First it sought to curry favor with the voters by catching a free ride on an Administrationsponsored tax increase measure for its $20 tax-reduction handout.
A Broadway production in early May of "The Righteous Are Bold," the Irish drama by Frank Carney, was announced yesterday by Basil Langton.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) --Immigration Commissioner Joseph M. Swing said today that the "wetback invasion" across the Mexican border had been stemmed for the first time since before World War II.

One out of every ten homes in southern New Jersey will have year-round electric air conditioning by 1965, B. L. England, president of Atlantic City Electric Company, predicted yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon of the New York Society of Security Analysts in Schwartz' Restaurant, 54 Broad Street.
The absence of such degenerative diseases as arteriosclerosis and diabetes among Yemenite Jews in Israel was reported here yesterday.
ALBANY, March 9--Governor Harriman announced today the creation of a twenty-two-member business advisory council in the State Commerce Department.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 9--Two deep-sea fishing trawlers will set sail this week from Hong Kong under the United Nations flag.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 9--The Baseball Encyclopedia lists eighty men named Smith who have played in the major leagues. It's probable that none was more obscure than Mayo Smith, the new manager of the Phillies. The baseball world was stunned when the news clicked over the tickers last October that the Phils had reached into the Yankee chain to sign a total stranger to a managerial contract.

Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said last night that liberty and law were inseparable. They can be preserved for a free people, he added, only by "balanced judgment reconciling the needs of each."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 (AP)--The National Boxing Association, despite a rebuff by the California Athletic Commission, renewed its efforts today to obtain recognition for Raul (Little Mouse) Macias as world bantamweight boxing champion.
Frankie Ryff, unbeaten lightweight from the Bronx, will engage Danny Jo Perez, West Side fighter, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.
TOKYO, Friday, March 11-- Harold E. Stassen said today that Japan could play a key role in the economic development of Asia.
ALBANY, March 10--Governor Harriman disclosed today that his freeze of new public works construction quietly had melted away.

SPORTS and Vacation Show highlights: Many new tackle items are being displayed and tested at the booths and pools at Kingsbridge Armory, many of them fabricated of plastic, fiber, glass and assorted materials.

A big week-end for Alpine competitive skiers starts on Cannon Mountain in Franconia, N. H., today. Scheduled are the national men's championships and Olympic tryouts which are to be carried over through Sunday. The giant, slalom will open the proceedings.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. discovered yesterday that he had issued orders in direct contravention of the amended Traffic Code.
A major reorganization at Children's Village, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., has produced big dividends after a year's trial, the establishment for delinquent boys reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 10-- The Eisenhower Administration and the Democratic Congress were involved today in a tax struggle amid perhaps the most bitterly partisan atmosphere of the President's tenure.

GENEVA, March 10--The first coherent picture of trade among countries of the Communist bloc that is available to the West was presented today. It was drawn by the secretariat of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe in its annual survey.

WASHINGTON, March 10-- Inventories held by the nation's businesses at the end of January were estimated at $76,800,000,000 by the Department of Commerce today. The figure is $3,300,000,000 lower than that at the beginning of last year.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The United States has balked at a formal agreement with Spain that would put marriages by service men based in that country under Roman Catholic canon law.
The Board of Estimate appropriated $85,350,000 yesterday for a start this year on construction of the projected $140,000,000 dam and reservoir at Cannonsville, N. Y. The vote was unanimous.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- (AP)--Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks opened the Administration's counter-attack today to Democratic sniping at President Eisenhower's $101,000,000,000 Federal-state highway plan.

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia, Ludek Pachman, Czechoslovakia; Laszlo Szabo, Hungary, and Hector Rossetto, Argentina, were the winners in the opening round of the eighteenth international chess masters tournament at the Hotel Provincial in Mar del Plata, Argentina, according to a report received from Buenos Aires yesterday.

Fashion fitted the weather yesterday, when Hattie Carnegie showed her spring and summer custom collection at her Fortyninth Street salon. The mood was mild and nostalgic, with a gentler silhouette than is usually seen in Carnegie clothes.

WASHINGTON, March 10--The purposes of the tax bill produced by the Democratic Policy Committee of the Senate emerge with a clarity that does not always invest baldly partisan maneuvers. Principally these purposes are:

YESTERDAY (March 10, 1955) TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council discussed conditions in Tanganyika and RuandaUrundi. Standing Committee on Administrative Unions-Considered administrative union affecting Tanganyika.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) --The Senate sent to the Attorney General today a report condemning a "mail cover" put on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and some of his associates in 1952.

A rather unusual program was directed by Guido Cantelli last night in Carnegie Hall. He led the Philharmonic-Symphony through two movements-- "Spring" and "Summer"--of Vivaldi's "The Seasons." This rarely heard work was followed with the first Philharmonic performance of Walter Piston's sevenminute Toccata.

Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey expressed doubt last night that "our free system could have survived or the peace of the world could have lasted long" without the nomination of Dwight D. Eisenhower for President in 1952.
Bill Van Breda Kolff of Lafayette was named coach of the year for 1955 by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association yesterday.

Fewer ships and planes from foreign points arrived in the Port of New York and at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, last month than in January. However, they carried much more lucrative cargoes for Uncle Sam.
The Transit Authority cleared the tracks yesterday for four major subway projects that ultimately will cost $64,800,000.
WASHINGTON, March. 10-- Angry Congressional Republicans assailed Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, in concert today. They accused him of having involved the President's wife in politics.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10--It was another magnificent day, the tenth such since spring training opened. The sun blazed fiercely out of a deep blue sky, a sky that was only faintly flecked by wispy clouds. There was hardly enough breeze to stir a frond on the palm trees-encircling Al Lang Field.

Sealed bids for two gardentype apartment colonies in New Britain, Conn., which were put up for sale by the Public Housing Administration, were opened yesterday at the P. H. A.'s New York field office at 346 Broadway. The housing was erected by the Government during World War II for defense workers' families.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that a bill to eliminate state representation on the Transit Authority was drafted without his knowledge or consent.
The Salvation Army reversed two city customs yesterday.
WHEN New Yorkers went to bed sixty-seven years ago tonight drumming rain, sleet and hail beat at their windows. The city folk thought this was spring come a-weeping.

A "medium - priced" movie theatre ticket for students in the 12-to-18 age group was suggested yesterday as a means of attracting more young people to movies. The idea was put forth at a gathering of more than seventy film executives at the Sheraton Astor Hotel.

CHICAGO, March 10--While the grain markets were irregular today, the general undertone was strong. Wheat futures especially vere given good support on small recessions, with Both old and new crop deliveries moving up sharply.
WASHINGTON, March 10-- The Government agreed today to let eleven editors of Soviet student and youth publications visit the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I note that your item in The New York Times of Feb. 25 relating to my notification to the President and his designation of a successor upon the expiration of my term June 22, states that I, "originally appointed as a Republican, changed [my] political affiliation in the late Nineteen Forties to that of 'independents'."

BOSTON, March 10 (UP)-- George (Red) Sullivan, a former Boston wing, returned to haunt his old team-mates tonight as he led the Chicago Black Hawks to a 3-2 National Hockey League victory over the Bruins before a crowd of 6,573 at the Boston Garden.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 7--On her recent Antarctic cruise the U. S. S. Atka skirted 7,000 miles for suitable coastline looking for suitable harbors. She pointedly by-passed the sector claimed by Britain, Chile and Argentina.
State Rent Administrator Charles Abrams moved yesterday to take the profits out of illegal rooming houses here.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 10 (AP)--The crest of the Ohio River flood, which already has caused $13,000,000 in damage and left thousands homeless, moved downstream from Cincinnati today.
The activities of Stuff and Guff, the bronze figures that appear to strike the hours on the clock at the north end of Herald Square, will be suspended for two weeks.
Shoppers will find a good variety of perishable foods at reasonable cost this week-end. The prices on most items are the same as a week ago.

Danny Lewicki yesterday received an award that he never dreamed of getting a few seasons back. Danny of the crewcut was named the most valuable player on the Rangers' team yesterday by the vote of the local hockey writers.

Spring and the Farm The winter must be over now, and if proof be needed stand for a time at a country road leading off from one of the main highways. Just a month or so ago all cars sped by on obviously pressing business.
WASHINGTON, March 10-- President Eisenhower today nominated James Weldon Jones, Democrat of Farmersville, Tex., to serve on the Tariff Commission until June 16, 1957.

Having experienced previous success in overcoming crises affecting the longevity of GianCarlo Menotti's product. Chandler Cowles is hoping luck will favor him once more. Instead of closing Mr. Menotti's opera.

Operations of the MerrittChapman Scott Corporation and subsidiaries for 1954 produced a net income of $3,211,524, according to the report issued yesterday by Louis E. Wolfson, president and chairman. This compares with $3,494,688 a year earlier.
ALBANY, March 10 -- The state's highest court ruled today that it was perfectly legal to make a private bet on such things as the outcome of a world series baseball game or a prizefight.
PARIS, March 10--Premier Edgar Faure repulsed an attack today inspired by the tax revolt among discontented small shopkeepers.

JEROME HINES got his first chance at Don Giovanni at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and he did the role with his blood. This is no figure of speech. In the opening scene of Mozart's opera, the young American bass-baritone dueled so vigorously with the Commendatore (Luben Vichey) that the latter's sword broke.
Sure signs of spring were observed in Times Square yesterday afternoon.
HONG KONG, March 10--Red China's 1955 agricultural production plan calls for increases of 10,000,000 tons of grain and 225,000 tons of cotton.

WASHINGTON, March 10-- President Eisenhower affirmed today the intention of the United States to continue its efforts in the defense and development of Western Europe if the Paris agreements were ratified.
Housing in New York City is in such a serious condition that the public is now "shockproof" to stories about it, Ira S. Robbins charged yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 10 -- The sharp retort by President Tito of Yugoslavia to Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov on Soviet-Yugoslav relations was published here today.

The New York Knickerbockers gained a firmer grip on second place in the National Basketball Association Eastern Division race last night, defeating Boston, 114 to 95, at Madison Square Garden before 9,245 fans.

The novelty of the program presented late yesterday afternoon by the Composers Group of New York at the Mason Hamlin Salon, 3 East Forty-third Street, was the appearance of Robert Fairfax Birch as soloist in a group of his own songs.
The integrity of the New York State Forest Preserve, under increasing attack from many quarters, is at the moment seriously threatened by proponents of the controversial Panther Mountain Dam.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 10--A Southern regional workshop conference on program planning for educational television got under way here today.
LONDON, March 10 -- With the stock market still prey to uncertainty, prices drifted lower here today.
Present state laws permitting the use of wiretapping in criminal detection were strongly defended yesterday before the Joint Legislative Committee that is studying the matter.

In an effort to speed final ratification of the Paris pacts President Eisenhower has again pledged the United States, within the framework of the North Atlantic alliance, to participate in the effective defense of Europe. To that end, in a message addressed to the Prime Ministers of the seven countries constituting the Western European Union, the President reaffirms that when the pacts are ratified it will ba American policy:

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) --A Senate subcommittee said today that juvenile delinquency was mounting at a "disgraceful" rate. It called for drastic Federal and local action to avert a "bigger and tougher crop" of delinquents in years to come.
Prices of cotton futures rose 14 to 21 points (70 cents to $1.05 a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Ever wonder how a fashion gets its start? A British business woman who recently visited here has an interesting explanation for why tweeds have been so much in favor.
ROME, March 10--The Italian Senate finished today two weeks of debate on the Paris agreements to arm West Germany and admit it into the Atlantic alliance.
CHICAGO, March 10 (UP) --An official of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that Airline safety was getting close to "the ultimate objective of a zero fatality rate."

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP)--Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today: HOGS Salable hogs, 9,000 head: trading moderately active, but market closing slow and some hogs unsold; butchers unevenly steady to 25 cents higher: sows mainly 25 cents
JERUSALEM, March 10--The Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission found today that a group of Israelis had murdered five Jordanian Bedouins March 4 in the hills west of the Dead Sea.
A new police procedure to speed the transmission of stolencar alarms to the men on patrol was announced yesterday.
Konrad Adenauer is ill of the grippe no official statement was issued tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10--Frank Sinatra became today the third personality United Artists has agreed to finance in independent film production. The others signed this week were Robert Mitchum and Joan Crawford.

On Feb. 21 the Democratic majority of the House Ways and Means Committee, in a maneuver calculated to identify that party with tax relief for the Little Fellow, tacked onto the Administration bill for extending the corporate income taxes and certain excise taxes a provision which would have given every income taxpayer a rebate of $20 and increased the allowance of each dependent by the same amount.

Commodity futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light in most markets. Potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, silk and copper were mixed; coffee, cocoa, sugar and burlap were lower, and rubber, hides, wool and zinc ended higher.
PARIS, March 10--Foreign Minister Antoine Pinay began today his fight for ratification of the Paris agreements.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. issued a flat denial today that it had exerted pressure on any individual or corporation in connection with the controversy between industrialist Louis E. Wolfson and Montgomery Ward Co.
LONDON, March 10 --The British Overseas Airways Corporation decided today to buy ten Douglas airliners in order to remain in the thick of the competitive fight for North Atlantic passenger traffic.
NEW DELHI, India, March 10 --India has banned the export of monkeys without special permission. The move takes effect immediately.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Times is to be congratulated for its forthright editorial of March 3 supporting the Governor's request for $3.5 million in state aid for the education of non-English-speaking pupils in New York City. And in this connection it is indeed unfortunate that the New York State Commission on Educational Finances, in its interim report, has failed to take a similar position.

In an hour yesterday--between 10 and 11 A. M.--the stock market suddenly aboutfaced after three days of retreating and made up all of Wednesday's losses. In late afternoon dealings, however, almost one-half the earlier gains were erased.
ALBANY, March 10--The Department of Education today proposed a plan to relieve the state's shortage of nearly 9,500 nurses.
ALBANY, March 10--The state is acting to provide relief for New York City's problem of housing juvenile delinquents.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A careful study of your excellent editorial "The Gaza Incident," published on March 4, clearly establishes the significant similarities in it to those in the far greater crisis in the Formosa Strait. "Not at peace and yet not in a state of active war" has a familiar and ominous ring, but how long can we avoid the latter state?

New York City borrowed $25,000,000 yesterday on an issue of tax anticipation notes due on May 4 at an interest rate of 1 1/4 per cent. City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, who made the announcement, said the notes are subject to redemption on or after April 25.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 10 (AP) --Louise Suggs shaved a stroke off par today with a 71 in a glittering opening bid in defense of her women's Titleholders golf championship.
Fears for the future of cotton are groundless in view of the scientific interest that has been attracted to it, according to Hugh Comer, chairman of Avondale Mills.
The biggest press conference in the country opened yesterday at Columbia University, with 4,500 reporters firing important questions of the day. They wanted to know:
PITTSBURGH, March 10-- The Westinghouse Educational Foundation today announced a $5,000,000 financial aid program to colleges and universities.
Business forecasters were advised last night to drop their "economic lullaby" and look into "economic realities."
WASHINGTON, March 10-- Department store sales in the United States last week were 15 per cent above those in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

TELEVISION'S remarkably fine season in drama continues. In "Crime on the Streets" on the Elgin Hour Tuesday evening over the American Broadcasting Company's network, Reginald Rose wrote a social drama of enormous power and human insight. John Cassavetes contributed an immensely compelling performance. Chalk up another major hit.

Two adjoining buildings con taining thirty-eight apartments and two stores at 2294 Washington Avenue and 489 East 183d Street, the Bronx, have been purchased by Lender Realty, Inc., headed by David H. Passberg, operator and investor.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- During the week ended yesterday member bank reserves decreased $34,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
LONDON, March 10--The struggle for control of the Parliamentary Labor party neared an irremediable breach today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 10-- With the preliminary phase of the spring training campaign closing today with a brisk batting and fielding workout, the Giants appeared set to move into a more serious sphere of action.
Loans by the twenty leading New York City banks to brokers and dealers on securities climbed $77,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a new high.
Borough President Hulan Jack has come up with a new variant of the city's perennial plan to extend Fifth Avenue through the middle of Washington Square Park.

A suggestion that food manuprocessors by consumer advertising can increase restaurant trade and so sell more to such eating places was advanced yesterday by Ransom Callicott, president of the National Restaurant Association.

Ten Puerto Rican Nationalist party members were convicted early yesterday of seditious conspiracy. An eleventh defendant was acquitted. The Federal Court jury, which had deliberated sixteen hours, brought in its verdict at 3:20 A. M.
Cabinet regime, the former ruler maintained, adding that the system he favored would provide the country with a more stable government.
Beginning June 1, the Wednesday night boxing bouts that are televised under the sponsorship of the Pabst Brewing Company will be seen on a different network.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 10 --Turkey has sent a note to Syria protesting against participation by Damascus with Egypt and Saudi Arabia in an alliance that was said to be directed against the Turkish-Iraqi agreement.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 10 (UP)--Johnny Longden rode Louis B. Mayer's Alidon to a fivelength victory today in the $33,850 Camino Real Handicap at Santa Anita. This was his eleventh stakes victory of the meeting that closed today.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Maritime Administration asked for bids today for construction of the Government's first "roll-on roll-off" ship.
Fifteen hundred thirty-six police rookies, including four women, must be at home by midnight or face summary dismissal.
Conflicting claims continue to emanate from automobile makers. The picture is not yet clear. The manufacturers have one eye on dealers' inventories and another on the used car market.
YESTERDAY (March 10, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Renewed assurances the United States would continue indefinitely its efforts in defense of Western Europe if Paris agreements are ratified.
JANNE JANESCO, dramatic soprano from Pendleton, Ind., sang her second recital in Town Hall last evening.
MIAMI, March 10--A two-rur homer by Don Zimmer, a triple by Charley Neal and a single by Sandy Amoros in the eighth inning gave the Dodgers a 3-2 victory over the Braves tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 658,975 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 23,522 cars or 3.7 per cent more than for the preceding week, 68,399 cars or 11.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 25,889 cars or 3.8 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Walter Winchell announced last night that he would end his association with the American Broadcasting Company "as fast as possible" because of disagreements over finances and his protection against libel suits.
WASHINGTON, March 10-- The Atomic Energy Commission revealed today that the nation's highest security clearance had been denied to 494 of 503,810 persons investigated for it since 1947.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Export-Import Bank of Washington approved today a $60,000,000 line of credit to help finance the sale of equipment from this country for a $250,000,000 steel mill in Argentina.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 10 (UP) --Jaroslav Drobny, the Wimbledon champion, and Austria's Fred Huber reached the men's doubles final today in the Egyptian lawn, tennis championships by defeating Sidney Schwartz of Brooklyn and Gottfried von Cramm of Germany, 6-4, 4-6, 6--3, 6--3.

A five - story apartment house at 1697 First Avenue, southwest corner of Eightyeighth Street, has been sold by Agnes Ries to the 1697 First Avenue Realty Corporation, which insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. Arthur Otto Seller the co-broker in the deal.
A male skunk named Petunia, formerly used in promotional displays in a Sixth Avenue pet shop, climbed the social ladder yesterday and became one of the live exhibits at the Museum of Natural History.

PARIS, March 10--Esso-Standard, S. A. F., will set up a new organization in France in May for exploiting existing claims and for research in new areas of this country. Esso-Standard, S. A. F., is 81 per cent controlled by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Gulf Oil Corporation.
MOSCOW, Friday, March 11 --The Soviet Union has formally asked the United States whether it is willing to exchange visits of agricultural delegations between the two countries.

Next to the coior and excitement of attending the couture collections in Europe, seeing Bergdorf Goodman's presentation of imported designs at the store yesterday was a good second. Here was captured not only all the important fashion news, but also much of the magic that gives French showings a dramatic quality peculiarly their own.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 10 (AP)--Michigan defeated Harvard, 7--3, in the opening game of the National Collegiate hockey tournament tonight.
Sudden enactment of the guaranteed annual wage as an economic law was suggested yesterday as the only feasible approach to the problem.
CAIRO, March 10--The new United States Ambassador to Egypt spent an hour and a half today with Egypt's Premier canvassing the Middle East situation.

The Government has decided that the Republic will not collapse if eleven Russian editors of student and youth publications spend thirty days visiting American colleges and universities. Consequently, as Attorney General Brownell announced yesterday, the provisions of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Law will be waived on the theory that the projected visit of these young persons will do us more good than harm.
WASHINGTON, March 10-- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters gave every indication today that it was getting ready to take in the International Longshoremen's Association.
WASHINGTON, March 10-- A woman anthropologist told a Labor Department conference on womanpower today that women still only partly "participate in the main stream of American society."

WASHINGTON, March 10-- Two prominent witnesses before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee joined today in attacking the Administration's liberal mortgage - lending policy and lack of control over consumer credit.
WASHINGTON, March 10-- A $745,845,015 annual pay rise for 2,000,000 members of the military and related services was approved by the House of Representatives today. The vote was 399--1.

GASTON LE TORCH, a professional soldier "fond of wine, gambling and the company of women," wasn't very busy after his compulsory retirement. A veteran of Madagascar and Tonkin, Dahomey and the Western Front, he had survived forty single combats, twenty bayonet charges and thirtysix duels.

A block of 464,700 shares of the Corning Glass Works, representing about one-eighth of the holdings of the family of Amory Houghton, chairman, and of related trusts, is to be offered to the public at the end of this month.

A study of one of the great stock market crashes, that of 1929, is presented by John Kenneth Galbraith in his forthcoming book "The Great Crash." The author, who is Professor of Economics at Harvard University, gave his views on the present stock market before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, March 10-- Every opposition party has a rough time about half-way between Presidential elections, and the Democrats are now in that unhappy position.
The United Defense Fund has decided to disband after five years' operation.
Net income of E. I du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and consolidated subsidiaries increased 46.2 per cent in 1954 despite a 3.5 per cent decline in sales.
WASHINGTON, March 10-- The Commerce Department here will go through the motions of an atom bomb evacuation exercise here tomorrow.

Our City Hall reporter's story in this newspaper yesterday telling of a bill to change the composition of the Transit Authority and give the Mayor sole appointive power seems to have caused a teapot tempest. Mayor Wagner professes ignorance of the bill, but the purposes of the measure seem entirely consistent with remarks about the authority that Mr. Wagner has been making since early January.
Daylight-saving time for October won the unanimous, enthusiastic approval yesterday of the City Affairs Committee of the City Council.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 Directors of the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce have decided to seek more shipbuilding for the West Coast despite refusal of the House Armed Services Committee to support a guarantee to that end.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 11 --Turkey and Iraq have agreed to admit Britain to their alliance. They have decided Britain should not have to wait to join the pact until other Middle Eastern states had acceded.

Pat Moriarty declared yesterday it must have been the leprechauns. The police of the West Fifty-fourth Street station said that was a most unlikely story, even for a County Kerry man. Then, said Pat, let them produce a better one to explain the magic fire hydrant.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The State Court of Appeals today upheld the dismissal of John P. Crane as a New York City fireman for refusal to waive immunity before a grand jury.
A hearing on an order for William J. Keating to show cause why he should not be cited for contempt was adjourned yesterday until Tuesday.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 11 (AP)--Betsy Snite, a 16-year-old high school girl from Norwich, Vt., beat some of the best women skiers of the nation today. She was making her first bid for a 1956 Olympic team berth.

The cause of a united Europe took another step forward yesterday when the Italian Senate completed Italy's parliamentary approval of the Paris pacts by a decisive majority. Except for a handful of independents, only the Communists and crypto-Communist leftists, representing the interests of the Soviets, voted in opposition in what was merely a perfunctory gesture, since their boasted nation-wide campaign against the pacts had boomeranged.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- Members of the Fulbright Committee heard today about a strange, two-headed monster that could menace the capitalistic system.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- Soviet farmers are going to get a chance to study the American skills they wish to adopt to grow high-quality corn, hogs and other farm products.

AN all-Bach sonata recital was presented at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Eugenie Dengel, violinist, and John Goldmark, pianist. The inspiration for the program was a literary one, a book by Fritz Rothschild called "The Lost Tradition in Music," which was, or purported to be, an explanation of how Bach's music was performed in the composer's own time.
Terms were set yesterday for the Gian-Carlo Menotti opera, "The Saint of Bleecker Street, to continue its Broadway engagement on a four-perfonnance a-week basis.
Willard F. McDonald landed in New York yesterday after four months of trolling for temperatures in the seven seas.
Hundreds of hometown newspaper editors may expect a visitation of job applicants 7 to 17 years old this summer, if a bit of advice given yesterday is heeded.
PHILADELPHIA, March 11-- La Salle and Canisius reached the Eastern regional finals of the National Collegiate basketball championship tonight.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 11-- The Giants and Indians launched their eighteen-game spring exhibition series today before a gathering of 6,263. And if this Is to be, as it is being enthusiastically billed, "a replay of the 1954 world series," the opener certainly followed the script.

The eighteenth National Invitation basketball tournament will begin today at Madison Square Garden with two games in the afternoon and two at night. The other rounds will be next Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday nights.
HONG KONG, March 11--A dual process of military recruitment and demobilization has been going on in Red China.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26--Soviet millinery manufacturers can design nice hats, but win they ever get around to making them? That's what the ladies want to know.
SEATTLE, March 11 (AP)--A high State Department official said in effect tonight the United States stood ready to help all friendly Asian, countries that helped themselves.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- In a direct approach to Vienna the Soviet Union has proposed again an international conference to conclude an Austrian state treaty before ratification of the Paris agreements to arm West Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- The index of average primary prices declined 0.1 during the week ended on Tuesday to 110.0 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
JERUSALEM, March 11--The chief of the United Nations Truce Supervision Staff ruled today against altering the factual findings in the condemnation of Israel for the Gaza incident.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., March 11 --Governor Harriman has been asked to postpone final action on the Wantagh-Oyster Bay Expressway.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) --Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, proposed today a Congressional study of what he called a "major disagreement" between civil and military air officials over the nation's basic air navigation system.

LONDON, March 11--British archaeologists are searching for the 2,700-year-old library dedicated to Nebo, the Babylonian god of writing. It was Nebo who had charge of the "Tablets of Fate," on which the destiny of man was thought to have been decided.
Several brands of vacuumpacked coffee dropped to less than $1 a pound yesterday, the first time the price has been that low in many months.

The immediate occasion for the new promotions may well have been the need to provide high-ranking officers for the unified command of Soviet and Eastern Europe, which, Moscow has announced, is being set up. Nonetheless, the political undertones in the new appointments are suggested by several of the names of the men promoted.
CHICAGO, March 11--Wheat and corn were sharply higher at the opening today, reacted on profit taking, and climbed again on commission buying.

A tract of about three acres in Saddle Rock, L. I., has been purchased by Homestead Property, Inc., of which Frank McNamara is president, for improvement with ten houses in split-level and ranch designs. The property is on the west side of Hawthorne Lane and runs through to the east side of Little Neck Bay, south of Greenleaf Hill.

YESTERDAY (March 11, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Nominated former Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan to be Ambassador to the Philippines. Met with his Cabinet. Had luncheon with a group of twenty-one freshmen members of the House.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 11--A jury convicted Albert Fuller, former chief deputy sheriff, today of murdering the man who had vowed to wipe out Phenix City's crime empire. The jury fixed punishment at life in prison.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- Val Peterson, Civil Defense Administrator, advised all citizens today to build some sort of underground shelter "right now."

Two years ago Sybil Connolly's designs were introduced for the first time in America at a Fashion Group showing in New York. Since then the success of this young Irish designer has been marked not only in this country but also in Canada and Australia.

NEW DELHI, March 11-- India has signed an agreement with the Standard Vacuum Oil Company, owned jointly by the Standard Oil Company (N. J.) and the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, for joint prospecting for oil in the West Bengal Basin, K. D. Malaviya., Minister for Natural Resources told the lower house of Parliament today.

CHICAGO, March 11--A bank executive said here today that banks are no longer "unsympathetic institutions where customers come on bended knee for loans." Instead, he said, they are sales - conscious establishments with competition acting as an energizing, stimulating force to bring about "constructive change."
Preachers in many synagogues and churches today and tomorrow will pay tribute to the American Red Cross, which this month is carrying on its annual fund campaign.
A new cancer hospital and research center for so-called "hopeless" cases was established here yesterday.
The Democratic leadership of the House was denounced last night by a Negro leader for "pussyfooting on segregation."

Frankie Ryff had an easier time than he had expected with Danny Jo Perez of the West Side in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The undefeated boxer from the Bronx carried off the unanimous decision by a wide margin, and there was no one in the crowd of 4,597 who could disagree with the verdict.

To many of us, no doubt, the Trust Territory of Somaliland, extending some 1,100 miles along the Indian Ocean, may have a political significance. That is, Italy, though not a member of the United Nations, received this area to administrate in return for coming belatedly to the Allied side during the Second World War, and also in return for territories of which the same war deprived her.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11--Casey Stengel, studiously observing his Yankees in spring training saw enough good to make up for the bad as the Bombers dropped a 3-1 decision to the St. Louis Cardinals today.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- From the State Department view, a security risk is not barred from a Government job if the Government needs him desperately enough.

For many years Soviet propagandists have sneered at free enterprise countries for their "anarchy and chaos." They have drawn invidious comparisons between economies such as ours and their own centrally planned economy, arguing that only with such planning can economic activity be "rational."
Representatives of the Baltimore area and the New York area of the Methodist Church have taken the first step toward the transfer of seventeen Negro congregations from the former area to the latter.
EVANSTON, Ill., March 11 (UP)--Marquette defeated the three-time National Collegiate basketball champion, Kentucky, 79-71, and advanced to the quarter-finals of the 1955 tournament tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The first sale of United Statesmade ghee was announced today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Thomas M. Horner, Chaplain of the Horace Mann School, protesting our State Department's refusal to renew the visa of Metropolitan Boris, who was sent from Soviet Russia, needs an explanation.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 11--The Quemoy islands received today their heaviest artillery attack in several weeks. Fifty-two shells rained down on Nationalist positions from 2 P. M. to 2:25 P. M.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 11 (UP)--The New York Knickerbockers clinched second place in the eastern division of the National Basketball Association tonight by defeating the Boston Celtics for the second straight night, 97-95.
CHICAGO, March 11 (AP)-- Sewell Avery, chairman of Ward, told stockholders today their "security of investment" in the company would be destroyed if Louis E. Wolfson gained control.

PARIS, March 11 -- Former Premier Paul Reynaud submitted a bill today that would make it easier to amend the Constitution and would provide for an obligatory connection between repeated Cabinet crises and the dissolution of the National Assembly.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) --Spokesmen for two major oil companies objected today that amending the Administration's foreign trade bill to curb petroleum imports would interfere with "freedom of trade and competition."

The following products might make housekeeping more of a pleasure than a chore: Bright red, blue-green and French gray, in addition to conventional black, are used by Casco Products Corporation for new steam or dry combination irons.
The nation's steel industry turned out 8,503,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., March 11--Tonight at Miami Stadium neither the baseball nor the crowd was up to last night's standard. The Braves won from the Dodgers tonight, 4-3, by the margin of an unearned run. The 7,477 fans were outnumbered more than 3,000 by last night's attendance.

Two books dealing with the American presidency are scheduled for publication later this year by New York University Press. One will be "The Presidency Today," by Edward S. Corwin, Professor Emeritus of Jurisprudence at Princeton University.

ROME, March 11--The Senate completed tonight Parliament's ratification of the Paris agreements. These accords provide for the creation of the Western European Union and the admission of a sovereign, armed West Germany into the Atlantic alliance.

More fish swim in the sea (and stream and lake) than the average cook may recognize. In tier enthusiasm for the quick-fix fish stick and the frozen filet, she neglects certain species that are low in cost, have fine flavor and offer variations in the family menu. Lent is the obvious time to investigate what John Von Glahn of the Fishery Council calls the "little-loved fish."

FORT MONROE, Va., March 11--If proposed Army manpower cutbacks are made, the United States will have great difficulty holding until full mobilization can take effect in the event of war, one of the Army's top generals said today.

M. Shapiro Son Construction Company, Inc., obtained first mortgages totaling $3,670,000 on the 362family Pierce Manor garden apartment colony it is building at Parker Road and Irvington Avenue in Elizabeth, N. J.
Forty-six persons were arrested last night and early today on Manhattan's West Side as the police resumed their bigscale week-end offensive against undesirable persons.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- The White House and John Foster Dulles denied today that President Eisenhower and his Secretary of State disagreed about the defense of Quemoy and Matsu Islands.
Settlement of two libel suits against Walter Winchell by The New York Post and its editor, James A. Wechsler, was disclosed yesterday.

FRANCONIA, N.H., March 11 --Rain, hail and thunder marked the opening of the three-day trials for Alpine berths on the 1956 American Olympic ski squad today. It was a trying session as sixty-eight aspirants weaved through a giant slalom course on Cannon Mountain.
The temperature reached 65.5 degrees at 5:50 P.M. yesterday, making it the warmest March 11 in the eighty-four-year history of the Weather Bureau here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In their full-page advertisement in The Times of Feb. 28 the Committee of Endorsers urge us, in their "Program to Govern Our Foreign Relations," to base our policies on the Golden Rule and the teachings of Christ.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 --A preliminary injunction today forbade the San Francisco Board of Education to enforce a ruling banning participation by public school teachers in local political campaigns.
Columbia's team retained the epee title as the fifty-eighth Intercollegiate Fencing Association tournament began yesterday. Twelve colleges are competing.

WE had last night the pleasure of listening to Antonin Dvorak and his native woodnotes wild--or merely naive and lovely--in the form of his opera, "Rusalka," presented by the American Choral Foundation in Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- The word was passed about the Senate today that President Eisenhower was determined to veto any Democratic income taxcutting legislation.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- Former Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be Ambassador to the Philippines.
BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, March 11 (AP)--Top-seeded Doris Hart and Mrs. Dorothy Knode today advanced to the women's singles final in the Ciudad Barranquilla tennis championships.
The new-capital market promises to continue moderately active for the immediate future.
THE present selection of paintings and water-colors at the exhibition of Collectors' Finds at the Maynard Walker Gallery, 117 East Fifty-seventh Street, includes some tempting pictures.
LONDON, March 11--Consumer resistance in Britain has had the same effect on the cost of tea as similar resistance in the United States has had on the cost of coffee prices are down.
ALBANY, March 11 (AP)--The State Department of Commerce yesterday received the following reports from operators of ski areas:
The stock market declined sharply yesterday, but steadied in late trading. The late steadiness, however, did no more than turn a rout into a fairly orderly retreat.

Welfare Department employes gave 340 pints of blood yesterday to the regional Red Cross blood program. The donation honored the late Joseph P. Piccirillo, First Deputy Commissioner, who was instrumental in establishing the department's blood bank.
WASHINGTON, March 11--A harness for parakeets and canaries was patented this week by Evelyn Cooke of Memphis, Tenn.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) Gen. Lucius D. Clay, retired, said today it would be "just about impossible" to evacuate United States cities in an atomic attack without a multi-billion-dollar new system of interstate superhighways.

Many of the difficulties in which the textile industry finds itself today have arisen because it is "aged and inbred," Georges F. Doriot, Professor of Industrial Management at the Harvard Business School, declared yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 11 (AP) --Patty Berg fired a record 68 today--four under men's par-- and took the lead at the halfway mark in her quest for a sixth women's titleholders golf crown.

Attendance continued heavy yesterday at the American Toy Fair at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels and in private showrooms throughout the city. The ten-day show opened last Monday. The registration is about 11,750.

When the Export-Import Bank establishes a $60 million credit to help set up a steel mill in Argentina it is difficult to avoid reading in a transaction of such magnitude an implicit gesture of friendliness to the Peron Government

Rabbi Louis I. Newman was honored last night at a special service commemorating his twenty - fifth anniversary as spiritual leader of Congregation Rodeph Sholom. The service was held in the synagogue at 7 West Eighty-third Street.

Five days a week Johnny Addie is a keeper of brokers' accounts for William P. Hoffman Co. at 111 Broadway. There is nothing unusual about that. There are 10,000 others in jobs just like his in the overstuffed money belt on the lower end of Manhattan.

Bishop Horace W.B. Donegan proposed yesterday the establishment of a series of hostels for youthful offenders. Such a step would help overcome the present shortage of lodgings for such youths and keep them from returning to delinquency, he said.
Prescriptions to combat heart disease showed the largest gain, 23 per cent, last year in a national survey of all types of prescription products.
MANHATTAN, Kan., March 11 (UP)--Bradley beat Southern Methodist, 81 to 79, as the national collegiate regional basketball play-offs began tonight.
Walter Winchell's radio and television news program eventually may move to the National Broadcasting Company network.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- An average increase of 20 per cent in New Jersey commutation fares was recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today.
A prominent Brazilian legislator expressed confidence here yesterday that his country would work its way out of its financial difficulties.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 11 (UP)--The anti-Communist Government of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem, under military and political attack at home, was sharply criticized today for its "failures" by a special French parliamentary subcommittee.
The Senate committee studying the stock market learned yesterday of one of the nation's oldest and most successful pension and profit-sharing plans.
Boscobel, an early architectural treasure in the Hudson River Valley, is ready for the scrap heap. A wrecker has bought the twenty-room Regency mansion for $35.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- The United States opposes a foreign ministers' conference with Britain and France at this time on the problems outstanding in Indochina.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 11--A political battle more significant than Dienbienphu is now being fought in Vietnam. The United States, with all its prestige, is actively engaged. It is no secret that we are openly intervening at almost every level on behalf of the existing Government in the south.

The laboratory set aside for him at St. Mary's Hospital, London, where he spent most of his professional life, will no longer receive Sir Alexander Fleming. He died yesterday from a heart attack, and in that attack the world lost a scientist who possessed the alertness and the curiosity that always characterize great research.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11--Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today scheduled "The Barretts of Wimpole Street" for remaking late this year. Sidney Franklin, who made the 1933 production for the studio, will direct.

LONDON, March 11--Investors remained depressed today despite a further rise in the sterling exchange rate and maintenance of the Treasury bill rate. A further retreat was led by Government securities and prices drifted lower to a weak close on persistent though not heavy selling.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- A labor utilization specialist predicted today that the American woman of the future would be working at a job except when her children were of nursery age.

The financial community was warned last night by the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ralph H. Demmler, to do some objective thinking about its responsibilities. Mr. Demmler urged members of the New York Security Dealers Association at its annual dinner at the Biltmore, to take steps, if they are needed, to assure the proper functioning of the capital markets.

SPORTS and vacation show highlights: Several thousand visitors at the Kingsbridge Armory contributed to the exhaustion of the attendants at the Ocean City tackle display, one of the largest tackle exhibits at the
Tornadoes and thunderstorms ripped across the flood-swept Ohio Valley to the coast yesterday in the worst windstorm of the year.

Two representatives of "organized gangsterism" were sentenced yesterday to fifteen years each for evading $850,000 in Federal income taxes and concealment of assets. This is believed to be the stiffest sentence imposed in a tax evasion case here.

ITALY has lost many battles--but won every occupation. It has vanquished all its conquerors. From the time the first bearded enlisted man crossed the Alps with Hannibal's Second Elephant Battalion to the G. I. muleskinner from the Thirty-fourth Division working his way up the sides of the Apennines in the Nineteen Forties, to the new bearded peacetime hordes barreling down a dozen Via Romas in hired Fiats, all roads have led to Italy.

A Supreme Court jury yesterday awarded Frank Koehler, 59year-old marine surveyor, $300,000 for the loss of a leg. At an earlier trial. Mr. Koehler was awarded $230,000, but this decision was reversed by the Appellate Division last December and a new trial was ordered.
TOKYO, March 11 (AP)--The Peiping radio accused Secretary of State Dulles today of "preparing to attack China from three fronts."
The first giant forging press to be completed under the United States Air Force heavy press program has started production at North Grafton, Mass.

The five-story apartment house at 471 Madison Avenue in Elizabeth, N. J., has been sold by the New Jersey Realty Company to the Fleetwood Realty Company, represented by Murray E. Kempler, attorney. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
WASHINGTON, March 11-- Senator Richard L. Neuberger urged American Jewry tonight to help in the development of the Negev. This is Israel's southern desert that borders on Egypt and the Red Sea.
LONDON, March 11--Aneurin Bevan, asserted tonight that although he differed with Clement R. Attlee on policy he was not challenging the former Prime Minister as leader of the Labor party.
The economic development of Central and South America has been hampered, it was asserted yesterday, by sensationalism and a lack of responsibility on the part of most American newspapers.
PHILADELPHIA, March 11-- The race for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination at the May 17 primary was thrown into confusion by actions taken today and tonight.

LA JOLLA, Calif., March 11 (AP)--Mrs. Beverly Baker Fleitz and Louise Brough played up to their role as favorites today in the tennis tournament that was to have marked the comeback of Maureen Connolly.
