KATMANDU, Nepal, March 11--A prince who once was a palace prisoner has become the central figure in an ancient kingdom's struggle to find a place for itself in the twentieth century.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your report of the Feb. 26 hearing on the appointment of Judge Harlan to the United States Supreme Court began:
Two Governors and a Mayor were on hand yesterday to welcome Governor Harriman to his new offices in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

Boys High of Brooklyn captured the team title for the ninth straight time in the fiftyfirst annual public schools athletic league indoor track and field championships. The meet was held at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

Mothers of young children share with nursery school teachers a common "occupational hazard"--a tendency to become so involved in duties and routines that they lose their perspective on the purpose of their labor.

MEXICO CITY, March 11 (AP) --The Pan-American Congress awarded the 1959 Pan-American Games to Cleveland today, ending a three-day wrangle over the site and clearing the way for tomorrow's opening of this year's games.
The automotive industry is facing a turbulent year because of union demands for a guaranteed annual wage, an industry spokesman declared yesterday.

Juror No. 9--Miss Kay Brunell-- was dropped yesterday from the jury in the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke. The action was taken by consent of opposing counsel and General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente.

TWO of the week's graphic art exhibitions deserve special attention. One is of prints (supplemented by recent paintings) by Misch Kohn, one of the outstandingfigures in the thriving group of modern Chicago artists, at the Weyhe Gallery, 794 Lexington Avenue.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 11--The British administrators of Togoland were warmly praised today by V. K. Krishna Menon of India in the United Nations Trusteeship Council.
The link between the Garden State Parkway and the New York State Thruway under consideration in New Jersey will cost more than $23,000,000, Gov. Robert B. Meyner said yesterday.

Cocoa futures prices tumbled the 1-cent-a-pound limit in most contracts yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The spot month, which has no limit, was off 111 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The December position was 99 points lower.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday dropped 19 to 30 points (95 cents to $1.50 a bale).

Saturday Forecast: Mud This is Saturday, and regardless of what those people in the Weather Bureau may say, today's cynical prophecy is for mud. This is not a crack at the people down there, who are public servants and so above reproach, but if they prophesy anything but mud they will be wrong.

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia yesterday gained his second victory in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata. Playing the back pieces, he defeated B. De Greiff of Colombia, according to a report from Buenos Aires.

HAVING spoofed with Shaw in "Misalliance" and probed with Kingsley in "Men in White," the Equity Community Theatre Players now are singing and dancing in "High Button Shoes," the musical comedy that Jule Styne, Sammy Cahn and Stephen Longstreet provided for Broadway in 1947.
National Airlines is seeking an injunction to halt construction of permanent facilities at New York International Airport.
WASHINGTON, March 11--A complete replay of the case of Dr. Irving Peress, by now perhaps one of the country's most famous dentists, will open on Capitol Hill Tuesday.
MADRID, March 11--Roman Catholic Bishop Angel Herrera of Malaga has called for a new press law implementing constitutional guarantees of freedom of opinion.

Three governors conferred here yesterday with Mayor Wagner on plans to evacuate the city in case of hydrogen-bomb attack and to provide shelter for the population of the metropolitan area against radioactive fall-out.
A Czech Immigrant whose memories range from the AustroPrussian war of 1866 to the television program he watched last week will turn 102 years old today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) --Scattered Democratic opposition to proposed contracts for the sale of the Government's synthetic rubber industry to private concerns spread from the House to the Senate today.

Yanni Evangelides' custommade gowns seem designed for the moonlight-and-magnolia set His new collection, shown yesterday at Bonwit Teller, consists largely of dreamy evening dresses in floral painted organzas with form-fitting bodices and full, floor-length skirts.
The Junior Auxiliary of the New York Infirmary will give a "Country Dance" on March 25 at the Jager House, 1253 Lexington Avenue, for the benefit of the Infirmary's nursery.

Claudio Arrau gave a typical program last night in Carnegie Hall. To most pianists, the Liszt Sonata is enough to build a concert around. Mr. Arrau not only took on the Liszt, but placed next to it Schumann's C major Fantasia, one of the really tough customers of the repertory.
MOSCOW, March 11--Ten Soviet Army and Air Force generals were raised today to the rank of marshal.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 11 (UP)--The University of Pittsburgh took a 7-point lead tonight in the thirty-second annual Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championship by gaining a hairline victory in the 400-yard free-style relay.

WHAT are monologues, spoken across the footlights, but personal essays! What are essays, spoken by way of the booksellers, but monologues! Same thing, even down in one case to the same agreeable author.

An unusual range of material is appearing this week in the auction galleries. In one of the sales for collectors and homemakers the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, will offer autographed checks and franked envelopes of the Presidents from George Washington to Harry Truman, as well as Presidential campaign badges.

BEGINNING with a banal situation, William Inge has written a fresh and illuminating drama. "Bus Stop" is the work of an expert craftsman. But it is also the work of a writer who has a wistful awareness of the loneliness of human beings.
Tuberculosis remains a major cause of dependency, despite "great strides" in the prevention, detection and treatment of the disease.

MIAMI -- At one time, years ago, Washington's Birthday marked the beginning of the end of Florida's winter season. The railroads carried the heaviest northbound traffic of the winter on or about that date. By March 1 a large part of the winter visitors had departed.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- One hundred and ten of the 250 masterpieces in the sesquicentennial exhibition of the Philadelphia Academy of the Fine Arts will be shipped abroad this month for showing in five European countries.
Senator Alexander Wiley urged President Eisenhower last night to strike in force at Communist China if it becomes evident that the Communists are preparing to invade Formosa.
PALO ALTO, Calif., March 12 -- "Stardust" particles from outer space are being "trapped" by a Stanford University radar "spider" weaving its invisible web across the skies.

THE great tragic artists of the world are four, and three of them are Greek. It is in tragedy that the pre-eminence of the Greeks can be seen most clearly. Except for Shakespeare, the great three. Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides, stand alone.

WHEN Alice Tisdale Hobart, author of "Oil for the Lamps of China," first began to write, her intention was to present "in a series of novels the interesting and dramatic interplay of Eastern and Western minds brought together in the Orient." Her new novel is a measure of the success with which she has carried out that original intention.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 12 (AP) -- Penn State's Karl Schwenzfeier took the all-around trophy today in the eastern intercollegiate gymnastic meet at the Naval Academy.

THIS, Mr. Grierson's fourth novel, is about the effect of wartime separation on the lives of young married people. David Mitchelson, a lawer whose wartime job is to advise British soldiers in Iraq on the matter of divorce, in faced, at the climax of the novel, with his own wife's defection.
THE Post Office Department is still at work on the problem of producing multicolored stamps. In a recent public address, Albert J. Robertson, Assistant Postmaster General, declared:

I cannot refrain from writing and congratulating Gilbert Millstein for his wonderful article, "Words Anent Music by Cole Porter" (Feb. 20), about the fabulous Cole Porter. Mr. Millstein's admirable style was even more enhanced by the subject matter chosen.

The committee on labor and social security legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York opposes repeal of the Condon-Wadlin Law. This law prohibits strikes by public employes in this state and penalizes such strikers with dismissal. Governor Harriman has asked for repeal.

Drawing, demonstrated in figures, landscapes and still lifes by James Ernst will be the subject of the second lecture in a free art series on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The artist, a faculty member of City College, Extension Division, is assistant supervisor of the library's Art Education Project.
A veritable gold mine has been discovered by many of the country's leading food processors since the war.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 12 -- Three Princeton University departmental chairmen have been appointed to endowed chairs formerly occupied by other distinguished teacher-scholars, it was announced today by Dr. J. Douglas Brown, dean of the faculty.
HONG KONG, March 12 -- The Dalai Lama has been named head of a preparatory committee for establishing an expanded "Tibet autonomous region" within Red China's national framework.
NEW DELHI, India, March 12 -- An attempt on Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's life was made today at Nagpur in central India.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- That fragile commodity known as morale took a turn upward this week in the military services, when the House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved pay increases.

FROM the seeds of sermons written more than a quarter of a century ago Lloyd C. Douglas (1877-1951) cultivated a harvest of best selling novels. Those early seeds now gathered together in a volume entitled "The Living Faith" result in his most exciting book.
THE discussion in the following paragraphs was suggested by the title of a new bridge book by Richard Miller of York, Pa. Note that the title, and not the book itself, was the inspiration.

LISBON -- A new law came into being last year which will greatly improve everything for the tourist who chooses to visit Portugal. It was framed so that he will find better accommodation and service and at the same time it will indirectly protect his pocketbook. This is because prices here, which are already low compared to other European countries, will remain low.

For the Democrats, the political situation is this: They have no illusions about the President's popularity, and no real expectation he will not run again. Their problem is simply how to find issues that may rub some of the gilt off him.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- A seven-year-old argument between rival school of astronomers here has resulted in a public declaration on what, to most laymen, is the most incomprehensible subject of all -- the size and form of the universe.
BATON ROUGE, La., March 12 (UP) -- James J. Corbett was named athletic director at Louisiana State University today to complete the school's change over to a "new look" in athletics.

Mayor Wagner has asked the Federal Home and Housing Agency to approve a "workable program" covering at least $261,800,000 in housing and slum clearance projects for which Federal assistance is sought.
Capturing six of the ten events, Dartmouth University's swimmers defeated Columbia, 48 -- 36, in an Ivy League test in the Lions' University Hall pool.

Further details on the United States' allocation of nuclear material for research reactors of other countries are announced by the Atomic Energy Commission. At the same time, the commission urges American industry to assist other nations in the design and construction of research reactors and components.

THE statisticians in the field say that about 70 per cent of all the paint applied to houses nowadays is put on by the house-holder. Some 60 per cent of the floor tile is home-laid, and about the same proportion of wallpaper is home-hung. About 50 per cent of the attic insulation and finishing is installed by the ambitious amateur.
The annual drive to raise $5,000,000 for the relief of destitute persons overseas begins today in Roman Catholic parishes throughout the country.

THE New York City Ballet closes its season with two performances today. Among the numerous other events that are scattered over the city during the week is John Butler's Dance Theatre in Brooklyn Wednesday, with some new works and some guest artists. The complete schedule is as follows:

A MORE infectiously delightful book than this translation from the French "Le Vent dans les Voiles" would be hard to find. As light as a zephyr, as glittering as chrysolite, the silk-bedizened, rum-soaked fable skips about the centuries, landing back at its starting point scarcely out of breath.

THE setting of May Sarton's novel is Harvard, Cambridge and Boston and its characters are university intellectuals surrounding a brilliant professor, Edward Cavan, who, withdrawing further and further from them in political and spiritual dissent, ends by throwing himself under a train.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 12 (AP) -- T. P. Morgan's Ezio, winner of last Saturday's inaugural handicap at seven furlongs, today had no trouble going another furlong at Loncoln Downs. The T. P. Morgan racer won the $10,000 Providence Handicap by twelve lengths.

COPENHAGEN -- The sesquicentennial of the birth of that famed Danish story teller, Hans Christian Andersen, to be observed under royal auspices in his birthplace, Odense, April 2, is a fitting overture to Denmark's tourist season.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has postponed until March 28 or 29 the start of hearings on ratification of the agreements arming West Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A historic church, just brought back to life, was shown to the public today for the first time as a newly restored architectural gem today.

ON March 23 the Home Fashions League will name a group of "Trail Blazers" for the year. The league, composed of professional women in the home field, annually selects for commendation those products that are "a genuine departure in the design and styling of contemporary home furnishings, and a significant contribution toward the advancement of the industry as a whole."
The renewed police round-up of "undesirables" on the West Side netted 151 persons between noon and midnight yesterday. The crackdown had been resumed Friday with the advent of spring-like weather.

LIKE most boys in the throes of creation, Henri would get so absorbed in his whittling that he seldom knew what was going on about him. Even when, one day, the wind shook the cart in which he was sitting, Henri continued to whittle -- until the cart started rolling downhill on a wild, runaway journey.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 12 -- Just when it appeared that the Yankees might have righted themselves, Tom Gorman, the bespectacled righthander from Valley Stream, L. I., blew up in the eighth inning today and the Boston Red Sox counted two runs to beat the Bombers, 3 -- 2.

MINIATURE African violets are among the latest additions to an ever-lengthening list in the fad for diminutives. They also add a new fillip to the collecting of this popular house plant. The average miniature African violet forms a tea-cup size plant four or five inches in diameter, whereas a full-scale variety under careful cultivation may grow fifteen to twenty-five inches across.

MONUMENTAL is the word for Walter Franklin George, the organ-voiced patriarch of the Senate and the third most powerful man in the United States in foreign policy. For "Mister George" -- this is what his wife "Miss Lucy" calls him in the way of the old-fashioned Southern gentlewoman in speaking to others of her husband -- is for the Eisenhower Administration in these tense days both a rock and an adornment.

ARTIST, sportsman, breeder and judge of dogs, Edwin Megargee has produced the most comprehensive reference book on this subject for young people that I have seen. He has included, he says, an illustration (a sepia line drawing) of the best example of every recognized breed in America, and I am perfectly willing to take his word for it.

WOODMERE, L. I., March 12 -- Retarded children will benefit from the "April in Paris" dinner dance to be held April 16 at the Seawane-Harbor Club in Hewlett Harbor. Funds realized will contribute to the maintenance of a class for local retarded children, which is supported in Hempstead by the Five Towns Chapter of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- A heavy fog that cut visibility to 40 feet hid the progress of the twenty-six yachts entered in the 284-mile St. Petersburg-Havana race tonight.
The 22,501-ton liner Queen of Bermuda was back in service yesterday after a week of trouble that followed a walkout of about 300 seamen.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Eight years ago today, after a series of urgent meetings with his Secretary of State, George C. Marshall; his Secretary of Defense, James C. Forrestal, and his Army Chief of Staff, General Dwight D. Eisenhower, President Harry S. Truman rode to Capitol Hill at noon to address a joint session of the Congress.

THE growing of strawberries in the lower Gulf area has long been restricted to Missionary, a variety which has an extended bearing season and heavy production of good quality fruit. Missionary is also readily propagated from its prolific runners, and plants are fairly resistant to the leaf spot disease. Recently Missionary has been Ibeset by virus diseases which i have reduced its cropping.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 12 -- Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence, 22, rocketed down mile-long Cranmore Mountain to win the women's national downhill championship today in her comeback fight for more Olympic honors. Her combined time for two runs was 2:13.5.
American music, painting, sculpture and writing will be evaluated by artists and critics at a Creative Arts Conference at Columbia University March 25-26.
The Soviet Government has lifted a corner of the curtain of secrecy for the first time on some of the experimental work in fundamental atomic physics going on in its laboratories.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- Steady progress on two new suspension bridges over the Delaware River has accentuated the need for speedy completion of engineering studies of the proposed Delaware Expressway.
WESTON, Conn., March 12--1 iss Pe"nelope Katherine White was married here this afternoon to Robert Gunther Harras in theI 'orfield Congregational Church! by the Rev. Karl Ostberg.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- Migration from the countryside to the city will be checked in the Soviet Union as a consequence of the intensive effort to raise agricultural production, in the opinion of a prominent economist.

TOKYO -- In anticipation of a possible record tourist year, the Japanese Government is lending money to hotel owners for enlarging their facilities. The booking of several international conferences into Tokyo suddenly awakened the authorities to the shortage of accommodations.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- William J. Smith of The Associated Press became tonight the first photographer to win two years in a row the grand prize award of the White House News Photographers Association.

THIS region is no exception. As elsewhere in the United States, the strawberry is a favorite fruit. In Oregon where the commercial strawberry crop, grown mainly for freezing was 30,600 tons in 1954 and the 1955 forecast is 32,400 tons, the backyard gardener still likes to grow his own.

BOWIE, Md., March 12 (AP) -- An unexpected disqualification occurred in the $10,000 added Burch Memorial Handicap today. Mrs. Samuel M. Pistorio's brazen Brat received first money after finishing second to the Elkcam Stable's Ifabody.

IN my short and merry life in the theatre, I have discovered that there are two sharply contrasting opinions about the place of the drama critic. While in some quarters it is felt that the critic is just a necessary evil, most serious-minded, decent, talented theatre people agree that the critic is an unnecessary evil.

WHEN the sad news reached us that poet, dramatist and diplomat Paul Claudel was dead we got after our French operator and had her ship over to us some of the leading editorials and what-nots on the maitre.

THIS novel of a Midwestern liberal Governor who wants to be President and who comes face to face with the moral and other problems of practical politics is obviously timely. But, of course, the scholarly William Cleveland, who leaves a college teaching post for politics, is not a thin disguise for Adlai Stevenson.

Civil Defense Administrator Val Peterson laid it on the line on Friday in his testimony before the Senate Armed Services subcommittee. He advised all citizens to build some sort of underground shelter "right now" into which they might retire if and when an enemy began dropping hydrogen bombs on the country.
ATLANTA, March 12 -- Problems relating to educational television and academic freedom were discussed today at a Southern regional workshop conference on television program planning.

MESA, Ariz., March 12 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs beat a New York Giant unit, 5 -- 0, today as they collected all their runs off southpaw ace Johnny Antonelli in the first three innings. Three Chicago pitchers, Bob Rush, Paul Minner and Sam Jones held the Giants to five hits.

WAS Henry Steele Commager clowning when he wrote in his review of "Politics in America" by D. W. Brogan. "It was said of a famous English historian, 'Tout comprendre, Tout pardonner,' and we might substitute the name of Brogan for the great Tout"?
TRENTON, March 12 -- The Republican-dominated New Jersey Legislature will reconvene Monday.

UNDERWATER swimming is undoubtedly the most practical of all athletic endeavors. Finned, masked, and belunged, the diver has his choice of bringing up ancient sunken cannon, striking subaqueous oil, ushering at underwater movies, or just passively drifting and listening to croakers croak and blue-striped grunts grunt.

ROME -- Before the modern Columbus sets out from Europe to discover the New World he is told to be sure to have his yellow inoculation certificate with him, not to put his shoes outside the door of an American hotel room expecting them to be shined overnight and not to engage -- never! never! -- in such forms of outdoor flirting as may be routine in Paris and Rome, Vienna and Madrid.

Continued heavy store orders for Easter ready-to-wear goods resulted in a lack of desirable dresses for immediate delivery last week, according to resident-buying offices. A few manufacturers of moderate - priced dresses, already working only on summer numbers, were forced to reinstate their spring best sellers.

The Federation of American Scientists suggested last week to Henry Cabot Lodge, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, that the United Nations appoint a commission to explore the dangers that lie in continued nuclear explosions. The suggestion is important because it comes not from Government officials but from technically trained men many of whom have worked on the production of both A and H-bombs.

THE literary myth goes that in the Thirties in England a group of undergraduates -- called the Oxford group and consisting of W. H. Auden, Cecil Day Lewis and myself, and then later joined by Louis MacNeice -- started a so-called movement in verse.
BRUSSELS -- If a car with a United States number plate breaks down on the road in Belgium, the scouts of the Belgian motorists' aid association, "Touring Secours," will lend a hand free of charge.

AMONG the many reliable strawberry varieties for home use in this region, my first recommendation is the old Howard 17 (Premier), especially now that virus-free plants of it are becoming readily available.

APPLYING Graham Greene's own definition of certain of his novels, his most recent picture story might best be described as an "entertainment". This is pure melodrama, starring a brave and resourceful steamroller of an early Rube Goldberg pattern and a gang of smugglers.
MENLO PARK, N. J., March 12 -- New Jersey has made encouraging progress in the treatment of sex offenders, it was re ported today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported that factory employment in Pennsylvania dropped 12,000 to 1,009,000 during January. This year's January, decline, the bank noted, was not as large as last year's.

THIS season's new production of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" will be the opera the Metropolitan will give most frequently on its spring tour. It will be played in eight of the sixteen-cities to be visited.

DURING the past few years commercial strawberry production in the Southwest has gained more than any other comparable fruit. This is also true for home culture. This rapidly increasing popularity is due largely to the new strains
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A plan to use Federal taxing power to compel manufacturers to build defense plants outside areas vulnerable to nuclear bombing is under consideration.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12 -- Communist China's admission now to the United Nations would harm the organization, Ernest A. Gross told a New York Times youth forum here today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 12 -- The Indonesian Government is faced with renewed outbreaks of violence in its northernmost province of Achin (Atjeh), in Sumatra. As the furor over the still unconfirmed reports of mass murders by Government troops continued, a report from Achin today indicated widespread flare-ups all over the province.
FAIRVIEW, N. J., March 12 -- An explosion in a construction shack here today killed one boy, fatally burned his brother and left two other lads in critical condition with burns.

WINNIPEG, March 12 (Canadian Press) -- The United States Thomas Cup team took a 3-1 lead in games over Canada last night in the North American zone badminton tie and needs only two more victories to advance into further international play.

I HAVE just read Mr. Josef Alexander's letter in The New York Times last Sunday. Although he doesn't name the Louisville Orchestra as the recipient of a grant of "nearly half a million dollars," it is apparent we are the ones he meant and we are grateful to him for calling us "a fine American orchestra."

ROME, March 12 -- Pope Pius XII attended a thanksgiving mass in the Sistine Chapel this morning to celebrate the sixteenth anniversary of his coronation. The full pomp and circumstance of Vatican ceremonies, suspended during the 79-year-old Pontiff's illness, were in evidence today for the first time in more than three months.
The mere existence of the United Nations, despite its imperfections and failures, offers hope for peace, Sir Leslie Knox Munro told 4,000 young journalists here yesterday.

THIS is opening day for the eighty-fourth New England Spring Flower Show and until Saturday "Gardens the World Over" are in bloom at the Mechanics Building, Boston, Mass. Sponsored by the Massachusetts Horticultural Society, the show will be open daily from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

After intervention by the American Civil Liberties Union, written regulations under President Eisenhower's security risk program are being provided for Americans serving under Government contract as technical aid experts overseas.

THE onset of spring, with its dampness and its changes of temperature, is likely to bring out the worst in wooden doors -- warping, sagging, sticking and squeaking. With seven to fifteen doors in the average home there is bound to be at least one that gives trouble, and there are usually more.

The New Jersey polo team defeated Squadron A in the A1 Parsells 9-goal Memorial Tournament match at the Squadron A Armory last night. The visitors were aided by a handicap of one goal but they did not need it as they rode to a 15-to-10 triumph.

THE "dark and bloody ground" -- that was what the Indians called Kentucky. Still, this did not stop Abraham Lincoln's grandfather -- who was also named Abraham Lincoln. In 1780 he sold his prosperous Virginia farm and followed Boone's blazed trail through the Cumberland Gap into Kentucky's meadowlands.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The current legislative session is being enlivened by rivalries within the two major political parties as well as by the clashes between them. For the most part the intraparty struggles are being waged below the surface while the interparty battles are out in the open.

TRADITIONALLY we have been the guardians of China's integrity and independence. Our refusal to allow Japan to dominate China led us into the last World War. Our effort in combat was sustained by the thought that the defeat of Japan meant the end of trouble in the Pacific.
DETROIT, March 12 (UP) -- Federal officials disclosed today a $53,000 shortage in the funds of the $4,000,000 Ford Rouge Employes Credit Union.

Once American buyers have put their money on the board in Paris, backing the choicest French fashions, the game is far from over. The next move is to rush the originals to the United States, have them copied and present them to the public at prices they can pay.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- All lawyers abominate liars who testify for the other side and they are always pained to discover that a witness has lied for their side.

Tax barriers have long been a major obstacle to private United States investment abroad. With the recent renewed emphasis on increasing such investment in Latin America, a revamping of tax systems involved is being actively studied.

When the Southern Pacific Railroad announced last month that it would build a $30,000,000 oil pipeline along its main route, Wall Street was surprised. The surprise should have been tempered by the recollection that Southern Pacific, since its organization as a Kentucky corporation seventy-one years ago this week, has ever had an eye for off-track business ventures.

An American-made 35mm camera with original features and designed for average use at a medium price was introduced hero last week by Graflex, Inc. The new miniature is the Graphic 35, a rangefinder camera with a novel push-button focusing system and priced at $89.50 with eveready leather case and flash unit.

At the recent conference of the Association for Higher Education, Senator J. William Fulbright, himself once a university president, pointed a finger at his former colleagues for overspecialization and gross neglect in the teaching of the humanities.
LONDON, March 12 -- Emanuel Shinwell, former Minister of Defense, and George Brown, former Minister of Works, today spurred the Labor party campaign to expel Aneurin Bevan.

Mrs. Harold Brandaleone has been named chairman of the committees working on the annual spring membership luncheon to be given by the Women's Division of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind. The luncheon, which will be given April 4 in the Waldorf-Astoria, is the climax of the division's drive for new members.

LONDON, March 9 -- Amendments made by Lloyd's Register of Shipping to its rules for construction of ships are expected to cause broad modifications of about 300 ships of the British and foreign merchant fleets. The changes were made because of structural failure in vessels of similar design, most of them wartime welded ships.
NEW DELHI, India, March 12 (AP) -- A joint communique issued here tonight said agreement had here been reached on a "number of outstanding disputes" between India and Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright said today that the $7,000,000,000 decline in securities this week "seems to confirm there is an undue amount of speculation" in the stock market.

AMONG the things that defy prophecy are the reactions of artists and the ways of art juries. The twenty-fourth Corcoran Biennial of Contemporary American painting, opening today in Washington, is a case in point.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 12 -- King Norodom Suramarit said in a speech yesterday it was up to the people to decide on the constitutional reform plan of his predecessor.
OFFICIALS of customs, immigration, health and other Federal services who inspect passengers debarking at New York piers have been doing a little soul-searching of their own these past months.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 12 -- A growing feeling that the Turkish-Iraqi pact is not incompatible with the defense grouping of Syria, Saudi Arabia and Egypt surrounds talks now under way here.

Dr. Syuzo Naka, who is professor of medicine in Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan, holds that specialists in nutrition have not paid sufficient attention to the relation of mother's milk to the development of the human brain.

ECONOMIC theories got a good going over last week, not only by witnesses before the Senate inquiry into the stock market, but by bankers who are beginning to show concern over the rate of home building.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- C. V. Whitney's front-running Fly Wheel impressively qualified for next Saturday's $50.000 added Gulfstream Park Handicap as the gray horse won the $15,000 added Appleton Handicap with ease before 19,332 at Gulfstream today.
The fourth annual Easter Sunday luncheon and fashion show for the Sister Kenny Polio Fund will be held in the grand ballroom of the Pierre on April 10.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 12 -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem sent tanks, an artillery barrage and forty battalions of infantry today against rebel forces. The insurgents hold a large area sixty miles south of Saigon.
OSLO -- "Doing" Scandinavia naturally includes Norway since it incorporates everything Nordic, and among the Scandinavian countries has very old traditions in catering to the tourist trade.

MILWAUKEE, March 12 -- Abe Woodson of the University of Illinois equaled the world indoor record in the 50-yard high hurdles with a 6.1 second victory tonight in the fifth annual Milwaukee Journal track games.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Rice, a crop that helped win a hot war, appeared likely today to become a major weapon in the "cold war."

" EVERYONE has to have a little house of his own," begins Beatrice Schenck de Regniers in this unusual and charming little book, in which she explores the need for privacy that even the most gregarious child feels at times. The house can be under a dining-room table, a cave behind the bushes or a tent of blankets.

RICHMOND, March 12 -- Bank debits in the Fifth Reserve District in February reached $5,670,000,000, which was 13 per cent higher than in that month last year. Widespread business activity was indicated in all states except West Virginia. Last week also saw another upturn in department store trade.

" THE BIG KNIFE," Clifford Odets' dramatic analysis of a Hollywood star, his coverie and his milieu, which New Yorkers saw in 1949 with the late John Garfield as the harried actor, seems headed for the movies.

Plans have been completed for a supper dance to be held on April 26 in the Officers Club at the New York Naval Shipyard for the benefit of the Brooklyn-Long Island Division of the New York State chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.

HAYDN: Quartets in C and B flat, Op. 76, Nos. 3 and 4; Vienna Konzerthaus Quartet (Westminster). Competent, musical, never very imaginative performances. As a recording, an impressive example of string tone.

IT'S too bad -- or, then again, maybe it's just as well -- that the opinions children and teen-agers hold about their parents seldom come to adult attention. Isolated growls parents hear aplenty but a well-documented, unvarnished bill of complaint is rare.

It is most encouraging to notice the continued growth of programs established by American corporations to aid colleges and universities. Those designed to provide scholarship assistance are especially praiseworthy.
The National Cargo Bureau, only two and half years old, has received the reputation of being a chief mate's principal "kibitzer," and a welcome one at that.
The United Negro College Fund will open its campaign for $1,750,000 on March 21. The thirty-one presidents of the member colleges will convene here next week-end.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Senator William F. Knowland predicted today that the Senate would defeat a Democratic plan to cut personal income taxes. The Senate then will adopt an Administration-supported bill to retain present corporation and excise taxes the Republican leader said. The levies are scheduled to decrease on April 1.

A COMPOSER who made front-page news some months ago spent several days in town during the past fortnight without stirring a ripple of excitement. The fault was not New York's, which hardly knew that he war here.

DETROIT, March 12 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings kept alive their faint hopes for a seventh straight National Hockey League championship tonight with a 3-2 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks before 13,224 fans at Olympia.

THE eighteenth annual Maryland House and Garden Pilgrimage is scheduled from April 29 to May 12. Under the sponsorship of the Federated Garden Clubs of Maryland and the Society for the Preservation of Maryland Antiquities, about 200 of Maryland's finest homes and gardens will be opened to the public.

SINCE the beginning of this year, everybody in Sweden, including resident foreigners, is guaranteed medical care against illness under a new compulsory health insurance law. It is one of the most comprehensive social medical systems ever introduced anywhere.

A BRITISH actress who, on two of her rare visits to Hollywood, carried off the "Oscar" for the best performance of the year, sets herself a standard up to which (in the Churchillian parody of officialese) it is difficult to live.

CHOIR OF ST. FRANCIS OF ASSISI: Compositions by Domenico Stella, Allessandro Boroni, Albino Varrotti and Bernardino Rizzi; Gian Francesco Capponi, conductor (Victor). Although issued as a Victor "colectors" item "of great historical and musical interest," this new recording of works by modern Franciscan composers was made in Italy in 1952.
MIAMI, Fla., March 12 -- Manager Walt Alston unveiled Russ Meyer as his starting pitcher tonight and the Monk was a victim of the shutout pitching of Billy Pierce for three innings at Miami Stadium.

COLOMBO, Ceylon -- The tourist trade here is at a record peak, having now become this island's fourth largest industry. Hundreds of tourists come ashore daily in this port, several important world cruises are to deposit thousands more for visits in the coming months, while international airlines bring in their regular quotas.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 12 -- Denmark's Social Democratic Government introduced today a harsh program designed to make the Danes spend less on themselves and pay more taxes in an effort to stave off economic collapse.

IN 1947, Barbara Spencer, a New Zealand nurse, went with her physician husband to northwest China, at the edge of the Gobi Desert to set up and operate a hospital for a cooperative established by another New Zealander, Rewi Alley.
The National Association of Social Workers will come into being in October with a membership of 20,000 professional social workers from seven organizations.
LONDON, March 12 (AP) -Third Division York City fought its way into the semi-finals of the Football Association Cup competition today -- and so equaled an English soccer record.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 12 -- Turkey's leaders and United States officials here are increasingly convinced of the need for a new formulation of Washington's Turkish policy.
NICHOLAS M. SCHENCK, president of Loew's, Inc. (parent company of Metro - Goldwyn-Mayer), is a man who makes very few statements for publication. Even when he speaks publicly he is circumspect.
Governor Harriman said yesterday he hoped reports that Vyacheslav Molotov was losing his influence in the Soviet Union were true.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Senate Banking Committee's "friendly" inquiry into the stock market has turned out to be something new in the way of Congressional investigations.

The East Side House Settlement, which serves the welfare and social needs of children and families in the Upper East Side, will be aided by a luncheon and fashion show on March 29 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.

LONDON -- Provided luxury and sophistication are not required there is a lot to be said for a holiday "down on the farm." It is perhaps commonplace to remark that in no other country so small as Britain is such a rich variety of lovely bucolic scenery to be found.

PREMIER is one of the oldest and best strawberry varieties in this part of the country. It was first introduced in Massachusetts in 1909. Its rise to popularity was spectacular and it has held its place. For example, in Michigan approximately one-half the commercial acreage is planted to Premier and it is a favorite in the home garden too.

ULLSWATER, England, March 12 (AP) -- Donald Malcolm Campbell of Great Britain narrowly averted an accident today while speeding over Lake Ullswater at 150 miles per hour in his turbo-jet hydroplane Bluebird.

Stock prices followed a roller coaster pattern last week. Sharp losses gave to some rallies, but a third selling drive on Friday. put prices at new lows since early February. It was the first week in quite a while when few persons referred to the 1929 stock boom.

GOOD strawberries can be grown in Colorado and of surrounding states in spite of some differences in soil and climate from many of the older settled areas of the country. The chief difficulties are more or less alkaline soil, lack of rainfall, dry air, hot sun in winter and erratic spring weather.

Contract negotiations between the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York and the Deck Scow Captains Union will be resumed on Wednesday afternoon, William E. Cleary, executive vice president of the employers' organization, said yesterday. The union's demands, which were submitted in the form of a rewritten version of the existing agreement, were rejected by the Harbor Carriers last week.
BONN. Germany, March 12 -- The principal West German labor organizations have sent warnings to labor leaders that the Communists are organizing a large-scale infiltration campaign from East Berlin.
BOSTON, March 12 -- A controversy over the chairmanship of the Democratic State Committee has rung up the curtain on the 1956 campaign in Massachusetts.

Members of the Metropolitan Section of the Woman's Auxiliary to the American Society of lV[echanical Engineers have arranged their annual card party for Thursday afternoon in the ballroom of the Pierre.

ROME -- The latest Roman tourist attraction is a visit to the Colosseum by subway. One of the ten stations of the new underground line is situated a stone's throw from the 1,900-year-old symbol of Roman grandeur.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- An uproar developed on Capitol Hill today over the Finnish tanker Aruba, bound for Communist China with kerosene suitable for jet plane fuel.

The Red Cross is unusual among American organizations. It is based on the Gene va treaties to protect the sick and wounded of armies. Its charter comes from Congress, which obligates the Red Cross to serve our Armed Forces and to carry on programs of disaster relief and prevention. It is a quasi - governmental agency whose chairman and eight members of its governing body are appointed by the President.
Cornell's team captured the three-weapon title for the first time yesterday as the fifty-eighth annual Intercollegiate Fencing Association championship came to an end.

The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany said yesterday that $10,000,000 had been allocated for this year in behalf of victims of Nazi persecution throughout the free world. The money will also be used for global relief, rehabilitation, cultural restoration and educational programs.

Nardi Reeder Campion writes proudly and well of the U. S. Military Academy and of its new Superintendent, Lieut. Gen. Blackshear M. Bryan, in the article "West Point's 'Supe': 'No Potted Palm'" (Feb. 27).

The New York Heart Association's program will lead eventually to ways of prevention and better methods of treatment for 500,000 persons now suffering heart and circulatory diseases, according to Arthur F. Douglas, vice president and campaign chairman.

Another positive step toward a firm peace in Central America has been taken with the establishment by Costa Rica and Nicaragua of a five-man commission to strive for settlement of any new issues that may arise between the neighboring republics.
Boys in Correggio, Italy, are playing baseball with bats and balls sent to them by Westbury, L. I.
UNITED STATES tourists are throwing away millions of dollars a year by failing to take advantage of the fact that the currency of many foreign countries is cheaper here than it is there.

DETROIT, March 12 (AP) -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, said today his party did not intend in any way to make the health of Mrs. Eisenhower a campaign issue in 1956 if President Eisenhower sought re-election.
OXFORD, England, March 12 (UP) -- Clement Zimmer, a 23-year-old graduate student from New York, was found dead in a courtyard near a women's college here today.
The Bush Terminal in Brooklyn is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary. Brain child of the late Irving T. Bush, it was incorporated in 1905.
LONDON, March 12 -- The British Government is planning to improve its anti-Communist intelligence and police services throughout its colonies and territories.
A luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the New York Heart Association will be held on April 10 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE subtitle of this extraordinary fine book of poems might be "Hansel and Gretel in America." For one who looks at literature as a history, it is a work of very great importance. For one who reads poetry as just poetry, and is willing to be backed into a corner by it, this volume is quite as important.
THEY are trying all sorts of things to get motorists past the pay stations of bridges, tunnels and turnpikes with less delay and irritation. Almost everything, that is, short of eliminating tolls.

Two armed men bound and gaged two employes of the Longchamps Restaurant, Broadway and Forty-first Street, and escaped yesterday with $500. They overlooked $6,000 in cash in an open safe in their haste to make their getaway, according to the police.

IN all ages men have been interested in natural history -- the bodily structure and habits of animals, birds, fish and insects. This interest has sprung from two sources -- a desire for information and the fascination of observing the Creator's handiwork In the Middle Ages this second approach was both more direct and more absorbing than it is today.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 12 (UP) -- Maryland University rallied tonight to retain the Eastern Intercollegiate boxing championship.

DETROIT, March 12 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther demanded today that Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, apologize for saying "some scaremongers" were trying "to frighten automobile workers with the bogeyman of automation."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 12 -- The first law in South Africa aimed specifically at preventing Communists from teaching has been proposed in Cape Province.
MEXICO CITY, March 12 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines of Mexico formally opened the second Pan-American Games today before a capacity crowd in the huge eliptical stadium of University City.
ROME. March 12 -- The great Italian land reform program, designed to make land available to at least some of Italy's landless peasants, is now about one-third completed.
Schools and colleges have been the "convenient scapegoat" for people frustrated and confused by the events of the last decade, according to Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College.
A two-price system for agricultural products -- one for the domestic market and another for sales abroad -- may be injected into the nation's farm program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 (AP) -- Carl (Bobo) Olson, the world middleweight champion, pounded Willie Vaughn of Los Angeles, the California titleholder, all over the ring tonight and gained a unanimous ten-round decision in a non-title bout.
OTTAWA, March 12 -- Canada is taking an anxious second look at her civil defense preparations and what she sees is none too reassuring.

MANY gardeners try to get along without a coldframe. However, after my gardening family's experience both with and without this accessory, I maintain that no one can take full advantage of the potential of even a small garden -- flower or vegetable -without some kind of permanent frame.

THE name of Bela Schick has become a household word through his discovery of the method of determining susceptibility to diphtheria. But even those persons who know of the Schick test may not realize that Dr. Schick is an outstanding pediatrician and a scientist who has added greatly to our knowledge of allergy and scarlet fever.

CAIRO, March 12 -- The fundamental conflicts in interests and ambitions within the Arab world have been stripped bare by two months of envenomed dispute over opposed Egyptian and Iraqi views of a suitable defense policy for the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Democratic politicians at the moment are a lot of assorted characters searching for a precise issue with which to contest the Presidential campaign of 1956. Republican politicians veer between hope and belief that they have theirs already --Dwight D. Eisenhower. The possibility that this belief may be sound furnishes the Democrats with the core of their problem.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 12 (UP) -- Mrs. Grace DeMoss Smith of Miami chopped two strokes off men's par to defeat Barbara Romack, 4 and 3, and win the Florida East Coast women's championship today for the second straight year.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 12 -- Twenty incorporated villages in Westchester County will go to the polls Tuesday to elect local officials. Thirteen will have contests.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Dr. Harris J. Levine, president of the Jewish National Fund of America, criticized the State Department tonight for arming the Arab states "while leaving Israel unarmed and unaided."

FULLY half the fun in home alone workshop projects is talking shop. Amateurs spy on professionals for tips; they exercise their own ingenuity in solving problems; they invent gadgets and tell their friends. Here are a few gathered from do-it-yourselfers, professionals and manufacturers:

RALPH McGILL concedes in his review of "Now Is the Time" that Lillian Smith is "right" when she "insists" that it would be relatively easy for the United States to achieve integration in education quickly, if only people would "will so to do."

An increase in foreign-aid cargoes during the last three months of 1954 opened 4,500 more berths to shorebound American seamen in the nation's privately owned cargo fleet, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

The forthcoming United Nations-sponsored International Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy, which will convene in Geneva on Aug. 8 of this year, could well mark the beginning of a new era of international cooperation.
NORFOLK, Va., March 12 (AP) -- A Federal court order was issued today temporarily restraining Virginia from leasing one of its state parks to a private operator.

A single narrow furrow plowed in sunbaked ground separates the State of Israel and the Gaza strip, a rectangle of 125 square miles under Egyptian administration. In this area are camps for the Arabs made homeless as a result of the war with Israel in 1948.

The Judson Health Center at 34 Spring Street will benefit from an "Easter Bonnet" fashion show and luncheon to be held on April 10 in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza. Since 1921, the center has worked to improve the health and living conditions in one of New York's most crowded areas.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 12 -Ch. Taylor's Dark Knight, the dog bought for the pet price of $100 by Dr. Gilbert H. Taylor of Glen Cove, L. I., added to his laurels tonight.
The names of five of a group of eight longshoremen involved in a kickback investigation of the Waterfront Commission have been ordered removed from the dockworker register of the bi-state agency.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The President's lawyers are girding to repulse a new challenge to his powers.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., March 12 (AP) -- The clowning Harlem Globetrotters toyed with the Washington Generals and amused a nation-wide television audience and a gymnasium full of sailors today in cavorting to a 64-53 basketball triumph.
Fifty-four regattas of varied size and magnitude will be held in New York State this season. Several of them will cover two days of racing.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 12 (UP) -- Jaroslav Drobny and Fred Huber won the men's doubles title today at the Egyptian lawn tennis championships and Angela Mortimer, one of Britain's most promising young players, captured the women's singles crown without losing a game.
FORT DIX, N. J., March 12 -- This military encampment is scheduled to be the First Army's transfer and overesas replacement center.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 12 (UP) -- The University of Pittsburgh won its fourth straight team title in the Eastern Collegiate swimming championships tonight. The Panthers scored 69 points.

FRANCONIA, N. H., March 12 -- Competing over a course that was extremely fast, Chiharu (Chick) Igaya and Billy Beck, 1952 Olympian, tied for national downhill skiing honors today. The leaders, products of Dartmouth's coaching system, had a margin of more than 2 seconds.

JAMES DEAN is the young man who snags the acting limelight in "East of Eden," which arrived at the Astor last week. Its opening has started a lively controversy over his histrionic kinship with Marlon Brando -- and his professional competence.

ON April 16 of this year a vast English mansion in South Harting, Sussex, is to be turned over to the National Trust and will become an historical showplace. One of its points of interest for future visitors will no doubt be the fact that the fabulous beauty, Lady Hamilton. Nelson's great love, began her climb to fame within its walls.

LET those who arrogantly despise their parents' and grandparents' tastes beware. Let those who ruthlessly sweep out their attics pay heed. Not only is the fickleness of taste inevitable, but so is the phenomenon of conscientious revivals.

EDINBURGH -- More Americans than ever before are spending more of their vacation time in Scotland, and not only for sentimental reasons. In 1954 more than 300,000 overseas visitors -- over half of them from the United States and Canada -- came, saw and were conquered by the legendary beauty of the Scottish Highlands.
AT last, New York State has begun to cash in on one of its most abundant natural resources -- the vanity of automobile owners.

IN relatively recent times investigators have learned an enormous amount about man as a biological species and a builder of societies. Inevitably, our notions about human nature have changed. We still do not know enough to prevent crime, mental diseases or armament races.
The Ford Foundation's grant of $50,000,000 to raise college teachers' salaries again has focused attention on the financial plight of our colleges and universities.

THERE was no question of the news in television last week: it was Mary Martin's radiant "Peter Pan." The electronic excursion into Neverland was perhaps television's happiest hour. In spirit and laughter a whole country joined hands with the little boy who wouldn't grow up.

Billy Graham sailed yesterday on the French liner Liberte. He will open a four- month preaching tour of Europe in Scotland next Monday. Appearances have been scheduled for him at major cities on the continent. He will return here about Aug. 1.
ANDOVER, Me., March 12 (AP) -- Tauno Pulkkinen of the Finnish, Ski Club, New York, won his third consecutive United States Eastern amateur cross-country championship today.

AMONG the mysteries of the stock market, aside from those now being studied in a friendly way by Senator J. William Fulbright, is its language, which is, in some respects, as esoteric as a three-for-one spilt in the shares of a uranium-prospecting company.

DRINKING in its fabulous success in having transferred "Peter Pan" from the Broadway stage to a television studio, the National Broadcasting Company has a similar project in mind. It is negotiating to put on "The Saint of Bleecker Street," the Gian-Carlo Menotti opera, after it closes at the Broadway Theatre.

North Western Pulp and Power Company has announced that it will begin construction by late spring on its projected $33,000,000 mill to make bleached sulphate pulp in Hinton, Alberta, Canada. North Western is jointly owned by St. Regis Paper Company and North Canadian Oils, Ltd.
General Motors Corporation's offering of 4,380,683 shares of common stock was brought to a successful conclusion last week.

NAGPUR, India, March 12 (AP) -- Babu Rao, the rickshaw puller who attacked Prime Minister Nehru today, came from the Maharashtra region of Western India. A Maharashtra man was hanged for the 1948 assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Raymond J. Kelly, chairman of the Railroad Retirement Board, says he sees no need for a special investigation into reports that ten known Communists are working for the board.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The United States' China policy is in a dilemma. For it is a cardinal principle of this Administration and of President Eisenhower personally to avoid war. Yet the Administration, with the President in the lead, feels that it must risk war over the defense of Quemoy and Matsu, two groups of small Nationalist-held islands just off the Communist-held mainland of China.

THE full-length broadcast of Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera made by the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra and soloists on Jan. 17 and 24 of last year, under the direction of Arturo Toscanini, has just been issued by R. C. A. Victor (three disks).

" Seeing the World," a short play written by Mary F. Lindsley, an English instructor at Hunter College, will be presented at the college in the Bronx at 12:10 and 1:10 P. M. this Wednesday and at the 695 Park Avenue building on Friday at 12:15 P. M.

IT'S common knowledge that Theodore Dreiser's "An American Tragedy" and its many adaptations (most recent of them the film "A Place in the Sun") stem from the 1906 drowning of Grace Brown by Chester Gillette, in a lake in the Adirondacks, but surprisingly we've never had a full-length account of the factual case be- fore Charles Samuels' DEATH WAS THE BRIDEGROOM (Gold Medal, 25 cents).

GENEVA, March 10 -- The French economy is stagnant and lacking in regional balance, according to a study by the Secretariat of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. This special study was contained in this year's annual European survey issued today.
Dr. John L. Miller, Superintendent of Schools in Great Neck, L. I., received last night the annual award for Distinguished Service in Education presented by Long Island University.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- More than four months after he was chosen by President Eisenhower to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court Judge John Marshall Harlan of New York seems to be nearing the place on the bench.

LIQUID rubber, first developed for such large-scale uses as roofs, floors and masonry surfaces needing waterproofing, is now available in small quantities and a great variety of colors. It comes in four-ounce jars and among its suggested applications are: touching up convertible tops on automobiles; skid-proofing rugs; coating such metal tools as pliers and wire cutters; sealing metal casement windows where rain might drive in; filling up rubber gaskets (car windshields and windows).

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 12 -According to military leaders here, the Chinese Communists are putting more and more emphasis on the war of nerves while building up jet airfields within flying distance of Formosa and the Pescadores Islands.

The guided missile -- the almost human robot of the skies -- was again in the news last week as Washington and London discussed their defense budgets and scientists proposed a detailed cost study of an earth satellite. These and a host of other facts indicated that the missile age, which started when the Germans bombarded London with rockets and pilotless aircraft, is now approaching maturity.
Decorating the Florida sand at the moment are pretty girl in swimsuits. Later on they will grace beaches and resorts throughout the country.
PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- La Salle, defending champion, reached the semi-finals of the National Collegiate basketball championship tonight.

LONDON, March 12 -- Britain was swept this week by reports that Princess Margaret will marry Group Captain Peter Townsend, British air attache in Brussels, after her fifth birthday on Aug. 21. At this age members of the royal family can marry without consent of the sovereign.

IN the fluid, casual atmosphere of Indonesia, accumulating solid, clear-edged facts resembles reaching for eels. But one can at least dispose of some of the lurid misconceptions about these islands which are current abroad.
A liquid has been found that behaves electrically like a solid semi-conductor.

VIENNA -- Austria offers herself to the American tourist this year primarily as an Alpine country -- a three-dimensional land where change of scenery and climate which would require a day's travel on the straight may be achieved by an hour's ascent to higher levels.
" Placing faith in modern technology and science alone" was condemned yesterday by Rabbi Zev Zahavy as "idolatry dangerous to civilization."
HAMBURG, March 12 -- Max Schmeling, former heavyweight boxing champion, has worked his way up to a new title -- champion mink-breeder.

The Home for the Aged maintained by An Association for the Relief of Respectable, Aged, Indigent Females in the City of New York will be aided by the proceeds from a performance of the Eastern show and the presentation of "The Glass Slipper," a new motion picture starring Leslie Caron, on the night of March 31 at Radio City Music Hall.
" FOR his unique contribution to the modern dance as composer, accompanist, teacher, critic and general force for progress," Louis Horst is the recipient of the fourth annual Capezio Dance Award.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The "great blow to the farm economy is yet ahead" unless Congress repeals the Administration's flexible price support program, the House Agriculture Committee has just reported.

In your recent portrait of the labor leader George Meany -- "New Task for Blunt Meany" (Feb. 20), by A. H. Raskin -- the author wrote: "The other 'invisible ruler' of the council in the Green regime was the late William L. Hutcheson of the Carpenters. In August, 1953, undeterred by Tobin's comeuppance (italics mine) Hutcheson decided to give Meany a taste of his power. * * *"

SON of a moderately well-to-do upholsterer in the Austrian town of Linz, August Kubizek had to wage the often-fought battle of the artistically talented boy in nineteenth-century households: he pined to be a musician while his father, of course, insisted he continue the upholstery business.
All Madison Square Garden college team scoring records tumbled last night as St. Louis topped Connecticut, 110 -- 103, in the opening round of the eighteenth annual National Invitation Tournament.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 12 -- Continued drift of labor to the metropolitan centers was shown in a survey released last week by the State Employment Service. The report showed employment had increased in forty-nine counties since 1950, and had declined in thirty-eight others.

BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, March 12 (AP) -- Top-seeded Tony Trabert of Cincinnati won the Barranquilla tennis championship today by defeating second-seeded Tom Brown of San Francisco, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A House committee declared today that the admission of Hawaii and Alaska to the union would be good for the nation as well as for the territories.
A gift of $4,035 was made yesterday to the Juliette Low World Friendship Fund by children in 2,000 Girl Scouts troops in New York City.

NEW DELHI -- The temple, the tiger and the Taj Mahal will find themselves linked by air this spring for the benefit of the tourist in India. If there is one thing that India has plenty of, it is distance.

THERE is no house plant of which it is easier to obtain more than the bryophyllums, which produce duplicates of themselves lavishly in their leaf notches. These bryophyllums hail mostly from Madagascar and are called variously Chinese, Hawaiian or Bermuda air plant.

WE often hear comments about "dismal" productions, but has anyone dared to criticize the "quality" of the audiences? I think, in particular, of the audience that watched a recent performance of "The Master Builder'' at the Phoenix.
TORONTO, March 12 (UP) -- The New York Rangers rallied for two quick third-period goals to beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game before 12,800 fans tonight.
GUATEMALA, March 8 -- It appears certain the meeting of the Organization of Central American States, scheduled for this month here, will be held after all.
CAPETOWN, South Africa -- Travelers to the Union of South Africa will enjoy the benefits of eight years of concentration by the national government on attracting tourists to this part of the world.
The Police Department, in a special memorandum yesterday, instructed all policemen to cooperate with the Department of Sanitation and other city agencies in the anti-litter drive.

IT is often asked where and how a conductor begins to learn his trade. Some, and there are experienced conductors among them, ask whether conducting can be taught at all. There is no question that genius operates as triumphantly in this field as in others.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Republican and Democratic national headquarters may not have much in common these days, but they share a single watchword: silence means consent.

EARLY one morning, with the sun slanting at an acute angle and striking light reflections off iron roofs and smooth stones, Jacob van Schoor walks across the silent South African veld and comes upon Setole lying in a bloody, beaten up heap.
SO 'UTHAMPTON, L. , March 12--Plans re being formed for a tour of historical homes and gardens in Southampton, to be held on June 25 under the auspices of the Southampton Cclbnial Society.
MANY an $85-a-week office worker with a three-week vacation is passing up native playgrounds this year and going abroad.

SERIOUS music is a dead art. The vein which for three hundred years offered a seemingly inexhaustible yield of beautiful music has run out. What we know as modern music is the noise made by deluded speculators picking through the slagpile.
LOS ANGELES, March 12 -- California and Arizona are approaching settlement of a century-old dispute about their boundary.

IF you stored the outdoor furniture away last season without refinishing, spring is the time to survey the damage done by weather, and to renew the finish for another year. The need will be even greater if you left the furniture out during the winter.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 12 (AP) -- Michigan tonight defeated Colorado College, 5 -- 3, to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championship for the fifth time in the eight years the tourney has been played.

CHORE OF THE WEEK: March is a windy month when broken, dead or weakened limbs may be blown from trees. Anticipate such damage by pruning and then burn branches on a quiet day. Burn other waste wood and similar debris as well as unused firewood to destroy borers wintering within.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 1 -- The flame under the Israeli melting pot has been turned down and evened. The Government is moving away from the "pressure cooker" method of Westernizing immigrants from oriental countries.
HARTFORD, March 12 -- Republican legislative leaders in Connecticut have begun work on their own state budget for the two-year period beginning July 1.

BELGRADE -- Tourists will be able to penetrate this summer into the heart of Yugoslavia, the only Communist-led country outside the Iron Curtain, because of new road, rail and air facilities, which are expected to induce them to do so.
For once Michael J. Quill has approached a contract deadline without issuing a single strike threat.
TOMORROW the Kings-bridge Armory will be just another drill floor.
The New York State savings banks are seeking legislative permission to invest in common stock of commercial banks.

JERUSALEM -- The Bible Land is becoming real tourist country. Israel will give its visitors better service this year than last, and 1954 was not too bad for those who came here. Now the adjustment period is really over.

KARACHI, Pakistan -- To most Americans who have not come east of Suez, mention of a holiday on the Indian subcontinent evokes hazy concepts of the exotic and the mystical. There also is a ruggedly romantic area virtually unknown to the Western traveler.
NEW HAVEN, March 12 -- Yale University is making plans to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the birth of one of its most illustrious graduates, Nathan Hale.
Willard Bargar has been appointed director of purchases for the Eastern Brass and Copper Company.
PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- The five-week controversy over the design of the first new building adjacent to the Independence National Historical Park project has ended.
MOSCOW, March 12 -- Moscow's official press came to the defense of Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov today against criticism aimed at him last Monday by President Tito of Yugoslavia.

ALTHOUGH I am not an "organic gardener," as the term is generally understood, I will say that I am all in favor of at least one organic gardening phase -- earthworms. Over the years all my experiments prove that a double- barrelled program gives the best results in the home garden.

The triple tie for first place in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, Argentina, was broken, yesterday.

KARL SHAPIRO's review of W. H. Auden's "The Shield of Achilles" says "The shield of Achilles in Homer has emblazoned upon it the triumphs of the future." According to Horace, dormitat Homerus; in this case dormitat Shapiro.

THIS city, known throughout Germany for its coal mines, steel mills and its theatre, will conduct an unusual experiment in the history of the German stage beginning Tuesday. Unquestionably, it will be the first time a single theatre in this country has ventured to produce six American plays in one week.

THE Scottish poet and critic Edwin Muir is probably best known over here for his translations of Kafka. Just now his poetry is being promoted in England by younger poets who see Muir's very quiet, dream-haunted verse as an antidote to T. S. Eliot.

Teachers College, Columbia University, will direct a $514,000 project to assist the Mexican Government to make a study of the technical and industrial manpower needs of Mexico. The project is to be financed by the United States Foreign Operations Administration as a technical-assistance service to Mexico.

WHAT we have here is certainly a puzzle and perhaps a challenge. William Gaddis (among other things, to be sure) is playing a game with such readers as he may be fortunate enough to have, a game for which he has devised the rules.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 12 -- The change to nuclear operations authorized by the North Atlantic Council as the basis for allied military planning is being achieved quickly in the air arm but is lagging in the ground commands.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 12 -- Ankara University is considering the inauguration of an extension system, including night adult classes and correspondence courses, modeled on the example of United States universities.

IS Soviet expansionism simply a continuation of traditional Russian imperialism, pressed forward under the cover of new slogans and with the use of unorthodox methods? Is Russia, presently and traditionally, hostile, irreconcilably hostile, to the values and the survival of the democratic and liberty-loving West? Or is the Soviet system merely an unruly Siamese twin of the Western way of life?

THE world of the traveler is a strange and yet a heartening globe. It occupies the same continents and islands, the same seas and atmospheres as the world of the diplomats and politicians who scurry around setting up blocs and barricades, drawing lines beyond which people must not go.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 12 (AP) -Patty Berg, shooting for her sixth women's titleholders golf crown, posted a 74 today to retain her 1-stroke lead over Mary Lena Faulk after 54 holes of the tournament.

Yesterday morning's Young People's Concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony in Carnegie Hall was brightened by the presence of Dubravka Tomsic. It was this young lady from Yugoslavia who gave a Town Hall piano recital just about a year ago, playing in a manner that some of her elders could have envied.
RUDY VALLEE is willing to admit that the years have slipped by since he first began making sensible girls giddy with musical items like "I'm Just a Vagabond Lover."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 12 -- Gov. James E. Folsom knocked the breath from unsuspecting insurance companies this week.
Atomic energy researchers in Detroit, backed by twenty-five collaborating power systems, have concluded that a large breeder reactor for industrial use is now feasible.
BUENOS AIRES, March 12 -- The world's eleven most famous penguins are likewise going to be the most pampered, according to plans announced today.

THE Wittelsbach dynasty for centuries helped to determine the policies of Europe. Three times it wore the German Emperor's crown, but, more often than not, its wearers had sought family prestige rather than German centralization.

Ron Holmberg, a 17-year-old high school student, gained a straight-set victory yesterday in the singles final of the invitation tennis tournament at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn. Holmberg scored over Phil Hanna of Jackson Heights, Queens, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3 -- 1, today for their third straight exhibition victory. The triumph was marked by tight pitching, including an effective three-inning stint by Frank Smith.
The top Communist leaders recently released from prison have posed questions that might upset normal probation regulations.

THE $25,000 Popular Photography contest for 1955 is announced in the April issue of the magazine. The issue also contains an article by Bruce Downes, the editor, on how to win prize contests, supplemented by advice from ten experienced judges.

Fordham's Tom Courtney unfurled the fastest half-mile clocking ever recorded on a flat board track last night when he won the invitation run in meet record time of 1:52.6 at the annual New York Pioneer Club's games.

It's not long before the maple sap begins to flow that the red osiers come to life and all the willows quicken. Those gardeners who have grapes to prune know how early the sap moves and how full and even profligate is its flow. It is almost as though the trees and shrubs and vines were ready to burst with the pressure.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 12 -- Vocational guidance tests are a hoax, according to Dean Nancy Duke Lewis of Pembroke College, Brown University.

IN the most surprising places -in symphonic or theatrical "green rooms" where performers wait between numbers, in hospital corridors, in club cars, in college faculty rooms and in clubs -an eaves-dropper can hear much talk about quarter-inch chucks, alkyd paints, dado saws, plastic veneers, alkali-resistant floor coverings and a lot of other special jargon.

The Engineering Research Institute of the University of Michigan has delivered to the Defense Department the major components of two sleek, needle-nosed rockets which will make it possible to explore the atmosphere to altitudes of 400,000 feet at what physicists regard as a bargain price.

The report that President Eisenhower will veto the tax bill if it contains any form of the proposed $20-a-head reduction is a welcome sign that the Administration is determined to fight this battle through to the finish.
Aluminum producers are seeking a sharp reduction in their shipments to the Government stockpile to relieve what threatens to become an industry-wide shortage of primary metal.

DUBLIN -- The most cheering news for prospective tourists to Ireland during 1955 is the immense improvement in rail travel and the further extension of the luxury bus package tours, which proved to be the most popular attraction for Americans last year.

ONE of the most irritating of current conventions was the subject of an excellent article by Jacques Barzun in last Sunday's issue. I have not been able to discover when the term "creative writing" in the sense of its present usage began, but I should welcome its end.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 12 -- The Indians today broke the spell the Giants had woven around them for almost a year. And they did it in spectacular fashion, upending the world champions, 4 -- 3, before a crowd of 5,167 Cleveland sympathizers.
LOS ANGELES, March 12 -- The Army and Navy are mounting another large-scale foray against the mythical enemy they have been combating for nearly a decade.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 12 -- Protestant forces were preparing today for a fight against a proposal in the Legislature which they say would pave the way for legalized race track betting in the state.

Carrying boxes of Shamrock, Limerick hams, and Irish whisky as gifts for the Mayors of New York, Boston and Philadelphia, a group of Irish men and women arrived today at International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. They said they were looking forward to taking part in the St. Patrick's Day parade on Fifth Avenue.
CLEVELAND, March 12 -- Steel production continues to boom in the Cleveland-Lorain district, advancing to a four-week high of 97 per cent against the previous week's revised figure of 95 per cent.

STRAWBERRIES have become increasingly popular in many parts of this region. They are one of the most profitable commercial crops for farmers and for some time have been sufficiently esteemed to warrant a yearly festival. The event is held at Buckhannon, W. Va., the center of the strawberry land.
NOT since "Death of a Salesman" made even strong men weep six years ago has a Broadway play yielded so many soggy handkerchiefs as "Anastasia," currently holding sway at the Lyceum.

The Lots for Little Thrift Shop, which for twenty-five years has aided seven charitable organizations, will gain by a silver anniversary luncheon to be held in the ballroom of the Ambassador on April 19.
