OGDEN, Utah -- A mammoth engineering job slated to begin this year midway across the Great Salt Lake is expected to improve transcontinental rail travel, change the saline content of a portion of Utah's inland sea and might even have a considerable bearing on future highway planning in this part of the Far West.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Five airlines and their ground crews have settled a wage dispute of several months' standing.
The State Department has postponed indefinitely the June 30 deadline for all foreign seamen shipping into American ports to obtain individual visas.

THE current debate over economic aid to Asia is surely one of the most curiously muffled political controversies of recent years. People realize that some general scheme is under consideration. They read accounts of differences of opinion over it within the Administration.
GENEVA -- By far the biggest thing happening in Switzerland this summer is the Festival of the Winegrowers at Vevey.
FORT DIX, N. J., March 12 -- United States Senator Clifford P. Case of New Jersey, inspected medical and housing facilities here today but said his visit was "not critical or unfriendly."

MUSICAL composition during the first half of our century was vigorously alive partly because of the amount of controversy it was able to arouse. GERMANY'S greatest artist, Albrecht Duerer, who was maturing at the time Columbus discovered America, is having what amounts to his first one-man show in this country, opening Thursday at the Morgan Library. British Parliaments are elected for five-year terms, but a Government can dissolve Parliament and call for new elections at any time. Picking the best time is both a key prerogative and persistent worry of the party in power.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Labor costs in the Chicago area are due for a rise this year. Estimates of the extent of the gain made by members of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago ranged up to 20 per cent. However, the bulk of the estimates were between 2 and 5 per cent.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., March 12 (AP) -- Pitt won the Eastern Intercollegiate wrestling title for the second time in two attempts.

Two persons were injured in crashes involving five autos at Ninety-sixth Street and Central Park West yesterday. The mishaps occured after a driver with no license or registration tried to escape a patrolman's questions.

Powell Davies, pastor of Washington All Souls Church, praises the erudition and affirms the acceptability of a thesis that would deny the existence of the very beings in whose honor his church has been named.

DENVER, March 12 (AP) -- Fall-out of radioactive dust in Colorado from the Nevada nuclear tests has reached a point where it cannot be ignored by those concerned with public health and safety, two scientists at the University of Colorado medical center said today.

Last fall, well after the season for vacations or country music, my wife and I were spending a week-end in an almost deserted hotel in the Berkshire music belt, at which the violinist and Mrs. Kreisler were staying.

SEBRING, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- at 10 A. M. (New York time) tomorrow, the flash of the starter's green flag will send eighty sports cars away from the starting line in Florida's well-known international Grand Prix of Endurance.

FROM Burlington, Vt., there has just come the disillusioned wail of one John W. Aldridge, 32 years old, who is resigning as a teacher of literary criticism and creative writing from the University of Vermont.

STOCKHOLM -- Judging by the ever-growing number of visitors from the outside, Sweden remains one of the favorite tourist countries. This is so in spite of the fact that very little has been done to alleviate the hotel shortage, chronic since the end of World War II.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 12 -Contests in six municipalities will be featured at the election of officials next Tuesday in fifty-two Nassau County villages.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Business men are turning to the private airplane at a record pace.

THIS is not quite a novel -it's a group of eight short-story chapters clustering around a stanch old Huguenot family in Capetown, South Africa. The flavor of the country is here in rich detail; even the jungle wilds are included, during a caravan trip to Natal where a witch doctor, complete with a coronet of brightly polished brass bullet cases, works his magic.
MANILA, March 11 -- The commitment of the United States to hold the line against Communist China has calmed the Filipinos.

The magnitude of the problem faced by Washington in dealing with farm surpluses is revealed in the latest figures on Government-owned farm products. At the end of 1954 the Government held title to some $4,230,000,000 worth of farm surplus food and fiber and was incurring a daily bill of $700,000 to store them.
AMERICAN housewives spend two billion dollars a year on white bread. Some feel they are being short-changed. From this consumer and from that come such typical comments as these:

NEWARK, March 12 (AP) -- A former Belleville public works official, a construction concern and its president have been acquitted of charges of conspiracy to obtain money by false pretense from the town of Belleville.

Unusually able and mature students will be encouraged to move into advanced work more rapidly under a program of advanced standing adopted by Radcliffe College. The plan, to start in September, aims at more effective continuity between secondary school and college and seeks to help young women avoid duplicating in college the work they have already done in secondary school.

GENEVA, March 12 -- Last week, for the second time, representatives of the leading trading nations of the Western world produced an agreed code of rules by which to guide their conduct of foreign trade policies.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 12 (AP) -- Susan Blodgett of the Skating Club of Boston, who was fourth last year, today took top honors in the juvenile ladies' division of the eastern figure skating championships.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands -- With a still-rising volume of visitors in prospect, the three Benelux neighbors -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, and in particular the Netherlands -- are freshening and bracing themselves once again for the rush of American and European tourists to their borders.
MADISON, Wis., March 10 -- The long knives of the Wisconsin Republican party are being whetted for the political scalp of Senator Alexander Wiley.
Both seeded teams were knocked out of the New York Athletic Club's sixth annual pro-amateur squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 12 (AP) -- Iowa's Big Ten basketball champions put down a desperate second-half Marquette rally tonight to win the National Collegiate regional final, 86 -- 81. The Hawkeyes will meet La Salle at Kansas City next week.

In this department's review of the year, published on Dec. 26, 1954, it was stated that Dr. Henrik Dam, who won the Nobel Prize for discovering vitamin K, and Dr. Halfdan Hebo produced ulcers in the stomachs of chickens and got what Dr. Hebo calls "'Exul,' a substance that will cure human ulcers in from ten to thirty days."

Drew Middleton's article, "Open Covenants Unopenly Arrived At" (Feb. 27) fits the actual manner in which the Federal Constitution was proposed and ratified. The Philadelphia Convention met in executive sessions; its members were pledged to secrecy; its official record showed only the "ayes and noes" on resolutions.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, asked President Eisenhower today "what, if anything," he was doing to obtain the freedom of United States service men held prisoner by the Chinese Communists.
The housing problem as it affects Negroes was scrutinized yesterday by leaders of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, meeting at 20 West Fortieth Street.

An unused housing for a conveyor belt spanning the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive (East River Drive) twenty feet above the roadway at Seventy-fifth Street collapsed at 2:25 A. M. yesterday, hurling 150 tons of concrete onto the drive.
The Merida, the first of four new ships being built for the Venezuelan Line, will arrive here Tuesday on her maiden voyage to this port.

LANSING, Mich., March 12 -A research center for gifted children has been established in a country setting between here and Eaton Rapids. The project will be known as the Youth Unlimited Foundation Research Center.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 12 -- The Yale swimming team had to win the final event in record time to defeat Harvard, 44-40, at the athletic building pool today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores in the week ended yesterday were about 7 per cent greater than in the corresponding period last Fear. Balmy weather brought the first pre-Easter shoppers looking for apparel. The gain represents performance of ten stores against eleven in the like 1954 week.
EL PASO, Tex., March 12 -- Federal Judge R. E. Thomason held Harvey Matusow, turncoat professional witness, in contempt of court today for what be called a deliberate attempt to obstruct justice.

LONDON, March 12 -- British politics moved swiftly this week out of the surface placidity of the last two years into a period of turbulence and change. This transition is bound to alter drastically the combinations of personalities and policy that have dominated the Conservative and Labor parties since World War II.

THE shipping industry on both sides of the Atlantic is using restraint in forecasting traffic volume for 1955, but spokesmen cannot conceal the fact that this is expected to be the biggest post-war year.

ISTANBUL, Turkey -- The big news this year for travelers bound for Turkey is the opening on June 10 of the Istanbul Hilton Hotel. The latest addition to the international Hilton chain is a 500-bed ultramodern structure overlooking the Bosphorus.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Governor Harriman today added fourteen names to the state committee that will participate in the White House Conference on Education next fall.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Benjamin C. Willis, superintendent of schools, estimated this week that it might take as much as $150,000,000 to replace old, and largely obsolete, school buildings built here before 1900.
CAIRO -- Egypt is enjoying what authorities believe is the greatest tourist boom since Herodotus, a well-known Greek travel writer, visited the Pyramids in the fifth century before Christ.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 11 -- One of the prospective big battles of California's 1955 legislative session entered its preliminary phase this week.

FOR seventy-five years the camellia has been known and grown in the Pacific Northwest. In early days, when the chief source of camellia plants was the Orient, garden-minded Northwesterners would hurry down to the Portland, Ore., docks whenever an Oriental steamer came in, and bargain with the sailors for the small plants they had brought along.
The twenty-second annual observance of Port of New York Day on Tuesday will be an all-day affair in giving this harbor its yearly tribute.

ATHENS -- That smug smile by which European reception clerks notify tired travelers that the hotel is "full up" is to be seen more frequently in Athens these days than ever before. Word seems to have passed about that here life is cheaper than irr other European capitals, which happens to be true.
NAPEAGUE, L. I., March 12 -- Contractors lost the moon, the flood tide and therefore the chance to move the Napeague Coast Guard station off the bottom of the shallow harbor here today.

WITH her usual warmth and simplicity, the author here portrays a series of episodes in the life of a small Charleston girl. Diana yearns to help Grandmother sell the fascinating treasure that crowd her antique shop, but her well-intentioned efforts too often result in mishaps -- a near-accident to a valuable grandfather's clock, a costly mix-up in the sale of a figurine, catastrophe to an irresistible china dog.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 12 -- The Atomic Energy Commission set off an atomic bomb above a cloud of smoke today to test the theory that man-made "smog" can protect cities from the furnace heat of the nuclear fireball.
NEWARK, March 12 -- Essex County's first attempt to assess municipalities more equitably for county costs was completed this week and met with varied reactions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12 -- The world at long last is engaged in a serious endeavor to develop atomic power for peaceful uses on a scale comparable to its devastating potentialities in war.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12 -- Roman Patrol, apparently a top contender for the Kentucky Derby, ran like a prairie fire in the stretch today to win the $49,000 Louisiana Derby, the closing feature of the Fair Grounds racing season.

In the maneuvering between New York's Democratic Gov. Averell Harriman and the Republican-controlled Legislature, the fundamental political positions of the two parties have stood out clearly. They are:

The Harvard University debating team won top honors yesterday in the eighth annual Invitational Debate Tournament at Brooklyn College. The topic was: "Resolved that the United States should extend diplomatic recognition to the Government of Communist China."
Racial discrimination is "relatively" low in Westchester County, the Social Research Laboratory of City College's Sociology and Anthropology Department said in a report last week.
PARIS, March 12 -- Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, will thank President Eisenhower for his promise that United States troops will remain in Europe as long as it is threatened.

Twenty-seven managing and news editors from seventeen states, the District of Columbia and Canada will begin tomorrow a two-week seminar on newspaper problems. It will be held at the American Press Institute at Columbia University.

THE establishment of Paul Klee, the artist who dreamed with his eyes open, as one of the formidable figures of twentieth-century art, is the tribute that an over-public age pays to privacy. Driven from the everyday world, privacy has sought refuge in the fastnesses of art whence Klee's secret whimsy exerts the spell of a wonder-working image.

HERE'S a neatly packaged escape kit ready to be dropped to the reader. If taken together this triptych of adventure stories from three different continents forms a do-it-yourself lesson in the field of escape.
BONN -- West Germany this year will be prepared to accept almost any number of foreign tourists. The days of hotel shortages, transport limitations and rationing of any sort are completely over.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Central Intelligence Agency is house-hunting, and thereby hangs a tale.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Two high officials today joined an apparently concerted Administration drive for President Eisenhower's plan to reorganize the military reserves.
DENVER, Colo., March 12 -High winds this week dealt another blow to rapidly deteriorating wheat crops and range lands of the dust bowl.

PARIS -- France's offerings to foreign visitors this year are simply a heavy program of festive activities -- and her own charming self. The charm is being further increased by a widening effort to make sure that tourists will not be able to get the impression that they are being "taken" by excessive charges.
DARIEN, Conn., March 12 -- Soft words were used today by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff to quiet the wrath of Fairfield County residents on matters concerning the New England Thruway.
LE HAVRE, France -- After eleven years of energetic reconstruction, Normandy is again attracting thousands of tourists to its beaches, its green hedge-rowed hinterland and lively market towns.
MOSCOW, March 12 -- A Soviet magazine that has been missing from the newsstands for two months reappeared today with an apology for having published a "right deviationist" article on economics.

In two critical tests for United States foreign policy -- Formosa and Germany -- Washington's problem has been the search for policies that would effectively meet the Communist threat and still be acceptable to the allies. The search has been difficult. The Formosa situation is explosive and could set the whole Far East aflame. The German situation involves enmities that have lacerated European civilization for two centuries.

ATLANTA, March 12 -- Demands for Easter apparel and other spring goods exceeded expectations in most department stores of the Southeast last week. Sales of home furnishings and appliances also continued well above levels of last year.

HOBOKEN, N. J., March 12 -- After 118 years and eight months ferry services between this city and downtown Manhattan on the Christopher Street line will be discontinued by the Lackawanna Railroad at 6 o'clock on Tuesday evening.
DETROIT, March 12 -- Mr. Butler assailed the economic policies of the Eisenhower Administration in a speech tonight at a Wayne County Democratic "victory dinner."
Manhattan properties representing all the realty holdings of the Nerwal Realty Corporation have been purchased by Sydney M. Barton in a "package" transaction involving more than $3,000,000.

James Felt Co., Inc., brokers, placed a first mortgage of $500,000 at 4 3/4 per cent for fifteen years on the one-story office and factory building at 125 Beechwood Ave., New Rochelle, N. Y., leased to Gries Reproducers Corp., and they placed a first mortgage of $110,000 at 4 1/4 per cent for ten years on the two-story bank and office building at 928 McLean Ave., Yonkers, with William Sherry as co-broker.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- Following are the text of the recommendations of the (Hoover) Commission on Reorganization of the Executive Branch of the Government on lending, guaranteeing and insurance activities of the Federal Government, and excerpts from dissenting statements:

Trans World Airlines has taken delivery of the first of a new fleet of twenty turbocompound -powered Lockheed Super Constellations that are to be flown in daily service between New York and Los Angeles.
Members of New York Typographical Union No. 6, A. F. L., approved yesterday a two-year contract negotiated March 3, with ten metropolitan daily newspapers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your March 7 editorial "Loyalty and Justice" makes a trenchant and significant contribution to the re-examination and reform of the federal employe's security program.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that the commission's budget had leveled off at about $2,000,000,000 annually, with about half for manufacture of nuclear weapons.
NAPEAGUE, L. I., March 13 --An unoccupied Coast Guard station took a little sea voyage this afternoon after four months of planning.

As required by the Federal Housing Act of 1954 Mayor Wagner, in a detailed presentation forwarded to Washington and made public here yesterday, has documented New New York City's need of further assistance on slum clearance, its proof of having a "workable" program, and its competence to advance such a program.

Moran Towing Corporation will begin operations this week on a new waterfront facility worked out with the city's Department of Marine and Aviation to move the city's vast bulk of excavating materials with a minimum of traffic congestion.

The season's first performance of Wagner's "Parsifal" will be given Wednesday evening, March 23, at the Metropolitan Opera. In the cast will be Bernd Aldenhoff, Josef Metternich, Margaret Harshaw, Deszo Ernster and Nicola Moscona. Fritz Stiedry will conduct.

Duquesne's top-seeded quintet plays Louisville's basketball team and Cincinnati, the fourthfavored entrant, meets Niagara in quarter-final round games tonight in the eighteenth annual National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden.
CHICAGO, March 13--Grain and soybean futures showed a decided reversal of form last week. Long liquidation early in the week was followed by substantial price recoveries all along the line.

Various problems of real estate appraising will be discussed at the annual regional conference of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers in Atlantic City, N. J., on April 1 and 2. The meetings will be held at the Claridge Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) --The House Armed Services Committee denied today that the Navy's new super aircraft carriers would be "sitting ducks" for hydrogen bombs or radioactive fall-out.

TOKYO, Monday, March 14--Despite United States urging, Japan plans no marked increase in spending for her defense the coming year. Premier Ichiro Hatoyama said today there might be a "slight" increase in the armed forces budget, but "by and large" it would be the same as last year's.
ALBANY, March 13--A $12,000,000 pension dispute has arisen between Mayor Wagner and the New York City Transit Authority.
Postal employes sent to President Elsenhower last night a giant postcard asking his support of their proposed pay increase.

THE Symphony of the Air gave the fourth and final concert of the series that it has devoted to American music yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Only composers who were winners of Pulitzer Prizes have figured on these programs.

MIAMI, March 13--The Dodgers stuck to their pattern of losing every other day at Miami Stadium when the White Sox beat them today, 6-5, before 9,510 fans. The Brooks got twelve hits, but half the blows went to waste.

NEWARK, March. 13--A 51year-old passenger, shouting "I've got a gun," terrorized last night thirty other passengers and the crew of an Eastern Air Lines plane five minutes before it landed at Newark Airport.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 13 (AP)--Premier Ngo Dinh Diem is menaced in the north by armed political rebels and in the south by determined religious sect armies and private interests.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 (AP)--The sixty-seven-foot cutter Mogu, scratch boat in the St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race, spurted into the lead tonight after 120 miles in the 284mile race.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The United States military high command has issued an iron-clad order in the event of any enemy attack on this country.
BOSTON, March 13 (AP)--The Boston Celtics ended their regular National Basketball Association schedule today with a 112101 victory over the New York Knickerbockers at the Boston Garden.
Cotton futures prices moved last week over the widest trading range so far, this year, and closed with net losses of 19 to 28 points, or 95 cents to $1.40 a bale.

WITH great simplicity and professional excellence, the Broadway Chapel Players yesterday presented a dramatic poem called "In April Once." Written by the late William Alexander Percy, a Southern poet and teacher, it is a moving story of man's search for faith in the Middle Ages.

There was a greater degree of stability in British sterling and the Canadian dollar last week, as these units rebounded from the nervous and spotty trading of the preceding week. A fair volume of business was involved.
VIENNA, March 13--Matyas Rakosi has told Hungarians that the Communist party has defeated its enemies and preserved its unity.

A gigantic "Operation Checkerboard" will move local offices of the Coast Guard, Federal Bureau of Investigation, Internal Revenue Service and other Government agencies to new locations within this city.

The latest Government statistics on this country's labor market would seem to provide at least moderate ground for good cheer. As compared with February, 1954, there were almost 300,000 fewer persons unemployed. Factory employment last month was 117,000 more than the preceding month.
WASHINGTON, March 13--A lop-sided civil war is raging among a group of railroad unions.
Five to ten million dollars may be saved yearly on the cost of constructing highway and railroad bridges across navigable waterways, according to Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday the award of 221 citations to members of the department. Six awards, honorable mentions, were for extraordinary bravery at hazard of life in line of duty. Three policemen were cited for exceptional merit, forty-two were commended, 103 were named for meritorious police duty and sixty-seven for excellent police duty.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The American consumer appeared to be about as well off financially early this year as he was a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Senator J. William Fulbright raised a point during his inquiry last week that, in the circumstances, was by no means unnatural. Said he:

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 13--The annual report of the Commercial Bank in Zurich, issued this month, declared that conditions would soon lead to the investment of new Swiss capital in Germany on a large scale.
MEXICO CITY, March 13 (AP) --Argentina, won two gold medals against one for the United States in track and field as competition started in the second Pan-American Games today.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Harold E. Stassen returned today from a three-week tour of seven nations forming what he called "the arc of Free Asia."

George A. Sloan disclosed yesterday that he had written a letter of resignation as chairman of the board of ths Metropolitan Opera Association.He gave the pressure of other commitments as the reason for his action.
PARIS, March 13--New efforts are being made to develop trade with Great Britain and Australia, to decrease the French deficit with the sterling zone.
Just before the start of a spring fashion show last week at Best's a store representative announced the company's determination to make ladies look both feminine and up-to-the-minute.
PARIS, March 13--French official circles are minimizing reports from South Vietnam that clashes between the Government and native religious sects are leading to civil war.
The agreement between Israel and the American Financial and Development Corporation for Israel, which underwrites the sale of Israel bonds here, will be terminated soon.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- A sharp curtailment of Federal lending services in favor of private interests was recommended today by the Hoover Commission.
The Federal Trade Commission acted yesterday in Washington to stop what it called false and misleading advertising by two companies.

It was thirty-eight years ago this week that the last Romanov Czar of Russia abdicated. If past practice is followed there will be no observance of this anniversary in the Soviet press. History records that the democratic beginnings of March, 1917, were strangled barely eight months later.

KINGS POINT, L. I., March 13 --Hannibal Choate Ford, holder of patents on inventions that led to the design of modern gunfire computers and bombsights, died at his home here last night. His age was 77. He had suffered a stroke recently.
Record high world-wide sales of $424,349,000 were achieved by the Colgate-Palmolive Company last year, according to the an-
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 13--Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. returned today from the disarmament talks in London, expressing guarded optimism about their outcome.
ALBANY, March 13--Attorney General Jacob K. Javits appointed today a seventeen-member committee to help him enforce the ethics code.
WASHINGTON, March 13--A proposed code of minimum standards for "fair play" by investigating committees faces what could develop as a strong movement to broaden its scope.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Senator Alben W. Barkley and Abba Eban, Israeli Ambassador, joined tonight in an appeal for peace between the Arab states and Israel.

Out in the hinterlands where, in season, there are lawns to be mowed and leaves to be raked, the vanguard of spring has arrived with a lurch and a bump. It is the season known to noncity folk as Mud Week. This is the time when the frost comes out of the ground, mutilating roads and melting driveways.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 13 (AP) --Patty Berg won Her sixth women's titleholders golf crown today. She shot a 73 for a total of 291. This was two strokes under the 72-hole record for this tournament.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: So much derision has been heaped upon President Eisenhower's "unleashing of Chiang Kai-shek" and so little has been said in its defense that one wonders whether this early act by Mr. Eisenhower as President was really such an amateurish gesture of futility.

The Dean of New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) declared yesterday morning that psychoanalysis and depth psychology "are increasingly successful in taking people apart, but these sciences alone cannot put a man together again."
The Douglas Aircraft Company reported over the week-end that seventeen airlines had ordered 109 four-engine commercial airliners from it in the first two months of the year.
LIMA, Peru, March 13--Senator Alejandro Roel, sought by the police for two months for alleged conspiracy against the Government, is reported to have claimed asylum in the Uruguayan Embassy here.

The last few weeks have been disappointing ones for the wrestling, swimming and track teams at Phillips Exeter Academy. Last season, the Exonians won important post-season tournaments in all these sports. This campaign the best they could do was to finish second in all three.
WEST POINT, N. Y., March 13--Forty-five boys from broken homes found understanding and friendship today in the cadets at West Point.
The Traffic Department is about to start on a vast offstreet parking program. The objective is to provide 41,500 car spaces at a cost of $94,400,000 in the next six years.
To commemorate the life and achievements of Elmer A. Sperry an award was announced yesterday by David W. R. Morgan, president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

Negotiations are in progress for "Father Knows Best," which goes off the Columbia Broadcasting System television network March 27, to be featured on the National Broadcasting Company hookup next autumn.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 13--Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, said today that American public opinion could be counted upon to support Israel in her determination to be a free nation in the Middle East.

Wheels have been set in motion to expedite the arrival of "The Young and the Beautiful." Once labeled "Josephine," the play is based on five short stories by F. Scott Fitzgerald that were printed in The Saturday Evening Post.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- The State of Tennessee will take to court tomorrow its fight to kill the Dixon-Yates private power contract.

Walter Winchell has authorized a statement in which he "regrets and withdraws" anything he wrote or said that might have been construed as a charge that The New York Post or its publisher or its editor was Communist or sympathetic to communism.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amounted to $63,918,479,303. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13--The Yankees, who bowed to the Boston Red Sox, 4-2, today, now are 4-for-0 in the Grapefruit League and Mickey Mantle, their big hope for 1955, is 12-for-0 at bat.

While the Finnish tanker Aruba was plodding across the Indian Ocean yesterday with 13,000 tons of Rumanian kerosene supposedly designed for the jet planes of Communist China, Foreign Operations Administrator Harold E. Stassen was getting out of an airplane in Washington. Let us look at the Aruba first.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The United States Government is holding up publication of the Big Three Yalta conversations primarily because they contain statements that would be embarrassing to Allied policy in Germany.

Oxtails, currently priced at about 19 cents a pound, are rich in flavor and, although bony, have a good proportion of meat. They require long slow cooking in moist heat to make them tender. In many foreign countries, they are used for soup stock or braised.
AN uncommonly interesting song recital was given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by Gayle Pierce, who assembled an admirable program and sang it with artistry.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- The Hoover Commission's recommendations on Federal lending activities was based in part on a report prepared by a study group headed by Paul Grady of New York, a partner in the accounting house of Price Waterhouse Co.
In her violin recital last night at Town Hall, Camilla Wicks further consolidated her position as one of America's outstanding young instrumentalists of concert stature.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 13-- It may have taken the Indians a time before getting around to beating the Giants. But, having taken a fancy to it, the matter now looks as though it might become habit-forming.

All season long, the Rangers were unable to do anything effectively at home against the Chicago Black Hawks. Last night, when it was too late to do any good, the Broadway Blues "solved" the Hawks, subduing them, 5 to 2.
Cargo shippers took the initiative last week as charter market rates sagged a bit for the second consecutive week.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies of Australia arrived today for talks on Allied defense strategy for Formosa and the rest of the Far East.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- As the Fulbright Committee's "friendly study" of the stock market grinds on, the chances of a great body of new regulatory legislation grow smaller.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 13--Finance Minister Johan van de Kieft last week submitted proposals to Parliament for tax cuts totaling 500,000,000 guilders, or nearly 10 per cent of the total tax revenue.
MEXICO CITY, March 13 (AP) --The program for tomorrow's competition in the second PanAmerican Games, the names of United States competitors in parentheses (New York time):

OTTAWA, March 13 (Canadian Press)--The Federal Cabinet failed yesterday to reach a decision on Government backing for the proposed east-west 2,200-mile natural gas pipeline after two sessions of discussion.

SAULT STE, MARIE, Mich., March 13--A century ago, in temperatures sometimes thirty degrees below zero, 1,600 men labored here with shovels, wheelbarrows and crude rock drills to complete the St. Mary's Falls Canal.

The contribution of United States investment capital to Latin-American economies is being scrutinized anew. Investors here are taking more funds--including earnings--out of Latin America than they are putting back.

The largest outlet in the Wallachs chain of men's clothing stores will open today at 555 Fifth Avenue, corner of Fortysixth Street. The outlet, probably the largest men's wear establishment on Fifth Avenue, has 21,400 feet of space on two floors, according to John D. Gray, president of Wallach's, Inc.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 13 --A Chinese Nationalist Navy spokesman said today the Nationalists would need no assistance in taking the Finnish tanker Aruba if she attempted to run the Nationalist blockade in Formosa Strait.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Secretary of the Treasury attacked today as a "political quickie gimmick" an individual income tax cut sponsored by the Senate Democratic leadership.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 13--The fifteenth event of the Saw Mill River Kennel Club today had no best-in-show judging, but it had a touch of royalty.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 31--A twenty-four-hour ban on wholesale trade in key commodities was imposed by the Danish Parliament tonight.
MOSCOW, March 13 (UP)--The Soviet Government newspaper charged today that the United States sought control of atomic raw materials under the guise of President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace plan.

Among the innumerable fine accomplishments of the League of Women Voters is creation of the Carrie Chapman Catt Memorial Fund, a research and educational group working to promote among the women of America, Europe and Asia the principles and practices of democratic government.

The transportation of overseas cargo by air is steadily increasing. The many American-flag and foreign -flag airlines that carry both passengers and cargo between New York and foreign airports welcomed a newcomer at Idlewild last week. It was the British-flag all-cargo carrier, Airwork Atlantic.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 13 -- How to unleash and direct atomic air forces to meet attack has become a dominant preoccupation at Supreme Allied Headquarters here.
Those Soviet farmers planling to visit Iowa for instruction in corn growing probably would earn more if they went to the Dakotas, where climatic conditions are more nearly like those of Russia.

The American Revolution is the subject of two books by well-known authors, which Doubleday will publish a little more than two weeks apart. Scheduled for March 30 is Bruce Lancaster's one-volume history entitled "From Lexington to Liberty," an account of men and battles.

CLIFFORD CURZON gave his only New York concert of the season Saturday evening in the Hunter College Auditorium. The eminent British pianist was heard in Mendelssohn's "Variations serieuses." Schubert's posthumous B flat Sonata, three Ravel pieces and Schumann's "Faschingsschwank."

IN the summer of 1953, when Peter Mayne revisited his friends among the wild hill peoples of the North West Frontier Province and the tribal regions of Pakistan, thermometers in Peshawar registered 115 degrees in the shade. In the few weeks that Mr. Mayne spent in Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, some 1,000 persons died of heat stroke.
Without actually admitting that teen-agers do not understand themselves, a group of high school pupils yesterday expressed uncertainty about decisions they had to make.
Hope for the end of Russian domination of Hungary was the theme of Hungarian Freedom Day, celebrated here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government is a twelvemember body headed by former President Hoover. It was created by Congress in 1953. It is the second commission on Government organization headed by Mr. Hoover.
NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence regained two national ski titles today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 13-- There can be no pretense of political respectability in South Vietnam until the moral dead weight of Bao Dai, so-called Emperor and Chief of Staff, is shed. Bao Dai is an evil, venal man. He has collaborated successively with the Japanese, the Communists and the French Colonial Administration.

Trans-Atlantic Saxophones After-theater crowds had begun to fill London's Savoy Ballroom thirty years ago tonight when, at 11:15, an announcer on the bandstand began the first trans-Atlantic broadcast by saying, "Hello, America."
Representative Paul A. Fino, Republican of the Bronx, urged support yesterday for the Democratic proposal to legalize without delay bingo playing through religious, charitable and fraternal groups.
PITTSBURGH, March 13-- Those steel consumers who several weeks ago were taking lightly the talk about a tighter market are now finding it necessary to order somewhat further ahead.
A $2,000,000 portion of the famed collection of books and manuscripts formed by the late Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach has been sold to the bibliophile's one-time clerk.
"OMNIBUS," which seems to be reaching farther into the outfield for material as its current season progresses, came up with one of its most bewildering catches yesterday.

Blue-uniformed women from the American Red Cross attended the morning service yesterday at Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth street. Thirty-six nurses formed a procession headed by a color guard.

BOSTON, March 13 (UP)--The Boston Bruins defeated the Montreal Canadians, 4-2, tonight before 12,000 at Boston Garden. The game was marked by a fight in the third period and the banishment of Maurice (Rocket) Richard.
BONN, Germany, March 13-- West Germany may have to subsidize its coal-mining industry to maintain the stability of its rapidly expanding economy.
TULKARM, Jordan, Feb. 26-- The Arab infiltrator weaves like a dark thread through the pattern of violence along the ArabIsraeli frontiers.

In a pastoral letter read yesterday at masses in every church of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, Cardinal Spellman asked for "more generous support than ever before" of the annual Bishops Welfare and Emergency Relief Fund appeal.

LONDON, March 13--The stock markets last week presented a striking contrast to those of the preceding week. Then they were rebounding with remarkable vigor from the shock administered by the rise in the bank rate.
Platform tennis, big brother of paddle tennis, has grown up. As a national competitive sport it has just passed its twenty-first birthday.

SEBRING, Fla., March 13 (UP) --The twelve-hour Florida Grand Prix of endurance sports car race wound up in an uproar tonight. Officials declared a British Jaguar the winner and the Texas owner of a Ferrari promptly lodged a protest.
ROME, March 13--The situation, of Premier Mario Scelba has again become shaky, only ten days before his scheduled departure for the United States.
FRANCONIA, N. H., March 13--The national Alpine skiing championships and Olympic trials had a green and white motif today.
A miniature electronic "brain" that solves flight problems for pilots traveling at supersonic speeds has been developed for the Air Force by the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13--Budd Schulberg's novel of the prize-fight business, "The Harder They Fall," has been bought by Columbia from R. K. O. Radio Pictures, which held the screen rights for several years.

A GREAT man's word portrait of New York City after an all-blanketing snowstorm has turned up in a letter written 109 years ago by Capt. Robert E. Lee when he was stationed at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn.

Doodles, squiggles, whorls and blobs--in varicolored paint, pencil, crayon or clay--may not strike every parent as the ideal wall covering for the nursery. However, at least one father who gave his son the privilege of doing his own decorating has been entirely satisfied with the results.

Governor Harriman expressed confidence yesterday that he could force the Legislature to reinstate $4,000,000 in school aid for New York City. He avoided using the word "veto," but he declared he would "throw back" to the Legislature any "piecemeal" educational bills until a "rounded program" including his requests for the city was passed.
WASHINGTON, March 13-- United States policy on Quemoy and Matsu is being left vague on purpose, but the trend in the Government is toward more dramatic aid in defense of Formosa and the Pescadores.

PARIS, March 13--Former Premier Paul Reynaud's bill to give French Cabinets more stability has drawn considerable support in the National Assembly. But some Deputies believe it can be accepted before the 1956 elections only if M. Reynaud's other bill for revising voting procedure on constitutional amendments is passed soon.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 13--J. W. Porter blasted the ball some 400 feet over the left-field fence during batting practice, Manager Bucky Harris beamed.

Gross capital expenditures last year by the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway were $41,528,393. Of this $25,700,000 went for equipment, according to the road's sixtieth annual report, released for publication today. In 1953 gross capital expenditures amounted to $87,400,521.
WASHINGTON, March 13--A Senate-House staff task force reported today that much-controverted immigration laws were working out better than critics contended.

With a great day for the Irish coming late this week, when New York feasts in honor of St. Patrick, it seemed timely to talk to John M. Conway about Irish food and drink. Mr. Conway arrived last week from Chicago to take up his duties as the new Consul General of Ireland.

THE outlook is much brighter for the deer herds in the central Adirondack area. The crusted snow and higher temperatures have made it possible for the deer to move into areas where more food is available.
Some early arrivals in town for Easter are well-dressed toy animals and decorated eggs at Penthouse Gallery, 15 West Fifty-fifth Street.
LOS ANGELES, March 14 -- Rail shipments from America's industrial heartland to California are increasing faster than the flo wof California fruit, vegetables and lumber to Eastern markets.

A self-supporting, nongovernmental project for aiding members of the Christian minority in the Holy Land was described yesterday by Sim Amir. Mr. Amir, who represents the Holy Land Christian Crafts Society, said it now had the services of sixty lay workers and forty nuns and priests in Nazareth.
ALBANY, March 14 -- Republican lawmakers agreed in separate Senate and Assembly conferences tonight on most major provisions of a new rent control program.
Three thousand fur-hungry women stormed Macy's yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, March 14 -- For the first time in more than 100 years, a prince of the royal family of Nepal ascended the throne as a free man today.

A fund campaign in March! When the income tax is due! What's Red Cross thinking of? This plaint has been heard ever since the beginning of World War II, when the Red Cross fund campaign was moved into the early spring.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Business concerns have told the Government they plan to spend $27,000,000,000 on new plant and equipment in 1955, reversing the sag that began with the 1953 recession.
MOSCOW, March 14 -- An armed intruder, apparently a Soviet citizen, shot and wounded a Soviet policeman on guard at the British Embassy last night and forced his way into the building.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Air Transport Association said today that the scheduled airlines had voted to repeal on June 15 their agreement for a reservations reconfirmation rule. The Civil Aeronautics Board must approve the decision before it can take effect.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Senator John C. Stennis said today that he would vote against confirmation of John Marshall Harlan to the Supreme Court because of the judge's lack of judicial experience.

Like the lion whose teeth have been pulled, March 15 has suddenly lost its bite for us. No longer is this the day when circumstances force us into the family countinghouse, when we search for money that isn't there.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- John Foster Dulles told Congress today that abandoning the reciprocal trade program would bring grave consequences to the free world's fight on international communism.

ALBANY, March 14 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the Mayor of Northport, Suffolk County, and two members of the Village Board of Trustees were ineligible to seek re-election in tomorrow's balloting.
Harris J. Klein urged the Board of Estimate yesterday to veto four engineering contracts approved last week by the Transit Authority.

"SIDE SHOW" is the word the Phoenix Theatre uses to describe its Monday evening programs. But a bolder word would better suit John Webster's "The White Devil," which was acted last evening. As a side-show it is one of the biggest shows of the year.

OPERA is fair game for spoofing, but the trouble with most satires and parodies is that they are not so funny as specimens of the real thing. It takes an expert to make inspired fun, and there has been no greater expert than a little magician called Mozart.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 14 -- Authorities investigating a spy ring have ordered four members of Communist diplomatic staffs to leave Sweden.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Frank G. Millard, former Attorney General of Michigan, was named today to succeed John G. Adams as general counsel of the Army. He will assume the position May 1.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Senate today approved without objection President Eisenhower's nomination of Dr. John von Neumann of New Jersey to a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The State of Tennessee and a host of public power bodies and associations in the Tennessee Valley asked for a court order today to block the Dixon Yates private power contract.

Readers who scan our newspaper headlines or have read Bruno Pontecorvo's statement might, at times, feel doubt enter their minds and believe that we only pursue destructive aspects of atomic energy. Let me hasten to correct this impression by mentioning the following fact, which has not been emphasized enough.

KANSAS CITY, March 14 (AP) -- A "compromise" 1955 college football television plan of the National Collegiate Athletic Association today cleared its biggest hurdle when the Big Ten extended its approval.

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia and Laszlo Szabo of Hungary held the lead in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, according to reports from Buenos Aires yesterday. Each has won four games in a row.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the resignation of Daniel Kornblum from his $14,000-a-year post as Deputy Labor Commissioner. Mr. Kornblum, who was director of the old City Labor Relations Division in the Impellitteri Administration, has been engaged for more than a year in drafting a labor relations code for municipal employes.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 14 -- Leo Durocher, irked no end by three straight defeats heaped upon his Giants on two successive afternoons and in three different towns, called on his jayvees today to do something about it.
The bears appeared to be in full command in Wall Street yesterday.

Louis E. Wolfson, who was characterized in Montgomery Ward Co.'s annual report last week as "the most serious problem" facing that company, would like to face the big mail-order company's chairman, Sewell Avery, under oath.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Senate's tax fight approached its climactic phase tonight with the issue still in doubt.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The proposal to introduce modern administration to the state's court system appeared to be in jeopardy today.

NEWARK, March 14 -- A violent outburst that prevented detectives from taking him into court put off the arraignment today of a man who terrorized fellow-passengers on an airplane last night. The prisoner was removed to the Martland Medical Center here for observation.
Culture has come to one of the dreariest jobs in the home -- wiping dishes. New kitchen towels take their designs from ancient civilizations, Rome, Greece and Egypt.
Twenty-three thousand postcards will be sent to New Yorkers this week in an appeal for used articles to replenish the shelves of the Opportunity Shop, at 46 West Forty-seventh Street.

TARANTO, Italy, March 14 (UP) -- Authorities today listed twenty-four seamen missing and feared lost in a double disaster in which a Greek trawler sank off Southern Italy and a British lifeboat capsized while attempting a rescue.
BONN, Germany, March 14 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Opposition is about to attack the principle of direct representation of electoral constituencies in Parliament.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The World Bank today lent $10,000,000 to a corporation founded to assist the growth of private industry in India.

"Three Cases of Murder," a British-made trilogy of melodramas, which arrives at the Plaza, is today's lone film newcomer. The stories are "In the Picture," "You Killed Elizabeth" and "Lord Mountdrago." They feature Elizabeth Sellars, John Gregson, Emrys Jones, Alan Badel, Leueen MacGrath and Orson Welles.
OXFORD, England, March 14 (UP) -- Police officials said today a freak fall apparently had caused the death of Clement Zimmer, 23-year-old United States graduate student early Saturday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 14 (AP) -- An estimated 25,000 non-operating employes of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad and two subsidiaries went on strike today. Fifteen passenger trains were canceled by nightfall.
CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- Representatives of a Chicago grain company told a Congressional committee today that terminal grain storage facilities at Chicago should be enlarged and regulated.

The expected arrival this morning of Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns, Chief of Staff of the United Nations Truce Supervisory Organization in the Near East, is another reminder that the U. N. is by no means a futility in times of international tension.
A plea that the independent International Longshoremen's Association have a "reasonable opportunity" to prove that it can keep peace on the docks was made last night by James B. Young.
Leprechaun or human, whoever carried that vanishing hydrant off and on the Avenue of the Americas can give thanks that Thursday is St. Patrick's Day.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 14 -- The Pakistani Government was prepared tonight to return the administration of East Pakistan to the United Front party.

"Crusade in Asia: Philippine Victory," to be published April 15 by John Day, will be Gen. Carlos Romulo's first non-fiction book in eight years. In it he tells how the sweep of events that had taken his homeland to the brink of Communist revolution was turned back.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- The absence of women in high United Nations posts was deplored here today at the opening of the 1955 session of the Commission on the Status of Women.
Fire apparatus returning from alarms will regain the right-of-way in traffic under a face-saving formula worked out yesterday by the Fire and Traffic Commissioners.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 14 -- An attempt to assassinate one of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem's most important officials failed today.
LONDON, March 14 -- Spot commercials on British television will cost advertisers as much as $2,800 a minute.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 15 (AP) -- The newspaper Asahi said today the Bank of Tokyo and a Philippine business men's group have "virtually reached agreement" on a plan to set up and invest jointly in a Manila bank.
BOSTON, March 14 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra is so efficient that a guest conductor making his United States debut this week feels "shy" during rehearsals, Igor Markevitch said today.

An intimate revue, "Once Over Lightly," featuring Zero Mostel, Sono Osato and Jack Gilford, will open at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock. The musical is being presented by Nola Chilton, John Howell, Lee Nemetz and Yale Wexler under the corporate name of Cuadro Productions.
HOUSTON, Tex., March 14 (AP) -- The defending champion, Polly Riley of Fort Worth, shot a 73 today to win medal honors for the second straight year in the women's Texas Golf Association tournament.

Cocoa prices tumbled the 1-cent a pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The spot month, which has no limit, was off 135 points (hundredth of a cent a pound). Volume was 191 lots and there were forty-two unsatisfied offerings at the close.

LOS ANGELES, March 14 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the Republican party should develop the strength to elect a President. rather than gain office through the popularity of a candidate.
CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The nation's steel-making facilities were operated at 92.9 per cent of theoretical capacity last week and produced 2,241,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings. It was the largest weekly output since the first week of June, 1953, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported.

BUENOS AIRES, March 14, -- The Atka's eleven penguins left by plane today for their haven in Washington's National Zoo. They had been picked off the Antarctic ice shelf Feb. 15 by crewmen of the United States Navy icebreaker.

MEXICO CITY, March 14 (AP) -- Two United States soldiers leaped more than 26 feet in the broad jump and their teammates won three other track and field championships today as the United States dominated competition in the Pan-American Games.

ALBANY, March 14 -- The Senate approved tonight a bill that will guarantee New York City a full 5 per cent return -- or more -- from its amusement tax. The vote was unanimous, and there was no debate.
OTTAWA, March 14 (Canadian Press) -- If builders still used wood as much as they did thirty years ago, Canada's lumber industry couldn't fill their needs, a forestry expert says.

World stocks of refined copper dropped to 188,916 tons last month, the lowest level in nearly two years. The decline was laid to flourishing demand and a strike in the mines of Southern Rhodesia. At the end of January producers' stocks were 205,278 tons.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- Chronic, severe malnutrition is taking an "appalling" toll in five Central American countries, the executive board of the United Nations Children's Fund was informed today.

This is D-Day in New York. The all-out, coordinated campaign of the city's departments against dirt begins in earnest with the frontal attack of the 200 new Sanitation patrolmen now serving summonses to those who violate the cleanliness laws. Following a special order by Commissioner Adams, the police will also cooperate in the drive and summon offenders to court.

Ten candidates for the Niles-Bement-Pond Company directorate were proposed yesterday by the L. D. Silberstein interests for election at the annual meeting on April 6. Mr. Silberstein, who has been battling to oust the present Niles management, told stockholders in a letter that he was soliciting their proxies to vote for the following and himself as directors:
Western Union Telegraph Company set a new high in gross operating revenues and the highest net income for twenty-five years in 1954.
A 5-year-old Chinese orphan, reportedly smuggled out of Communist China this month, arrived here yesterday for adoption by her aunt, who herself escaped three years ago.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 14 (UP) -- The free-market dollar rate continued to soar today and reached the all-time high of 89 cruzeiros to the dollar. This was 7 cruzeiros above the closing quotation last week.
BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., March 14 -- Mianus Gorge has cast aside winter to unfold its primeval splendor.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Strong support for the Senate Banking Committee's friendly study of the stock market came from the Federal Reserve Board chairman today.

LONDON, March 14 -- A Foreign Office spokesman said tonight that a report had been received from Ambassador Sir William Hayter on the incident, but that it added little to the press accounts. The identity and motive of the attacker remain unknown, he said.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 14 -- Connecticut's proposed monopolizing of Mianus River water in times of emergency was opposed today by Jacob K. Javits, New York State Attorney General. Westchester County officials were notified by Mr. Javits that he was asking Governor Harriman to intercede with Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut.

On this annual observance of Port of New York Day, when city, state and shipping interests will celebrate the importance of our great harbor to the general welfare, blessings and problems naturally intermingle. Nothing has occurred, of course, to rob us of the natural advantages that make this harbor unique.
The famed Wanamaker pipe organ, which reputedly cost $200,000 when it was installed in the New York store in 1921, was sold at auction yesterday for $1,200.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 14 -- "I'm all ready for the big bum," announced Johnny Orlando, the keeper of the keys in the Red Sox clubhouse. The words sounded harsh but they bore an underlying note of deep affection. No one in baseball worships Ted Williams more than Johnny Orlando.

SEBRING, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Briggs Cunningham's British Jaguar has been declared provisional winner of the twelve-hour Florida International Grand Prix of Endurance. But it will be at least two weeks before the official results are known.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Four Colorado men who got sentences of fifteen to sixty years for jury tampering won new trials today.

The clothing industry is making a big splash at the retail level. Wallachs is putting some heavy linage into newspapers to call attention to its new show-place, which opened yesterday at Fifth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street.

BONN, Germany, March 14 (AP) The British High Commission announced today the Royal Navy had taken over three 110-ton armed ships from a West German shipyard. The British said the Luerssen shipyard in Bremen had started building the craft in defiance of Allied orders.
Sammy Walker of Springfield, Mass., gained a split decision over Milo Savage, Salt Lake City middleweight, in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Bears had the advantage in today's grain and soybean futures market. Initial quotations were weak in all pits, and declines were extended later in the absence of any active demand.

The voluntary agreement by twenty-four radio and television stations in the metropolitan area to curb misrepresentation in advertising is a sensible step that deserves commendation. Some of the stations that have subscribed to the new code have never tolerated the "bait" advertising against which the agreement is directed.
The State Department of Taxation and Finance said yesterday that nearly 5,000,000 persons would have to file New York income tax returns for 1954. Returns and payments are due by April 15.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Val Peterson, Federal Civil Defense Administrator, said tonight that New York City poses "the toughest problem in the world" for Civil Defense.

Because meat takes the biggest slice out of the food budget, cost comparisons of various cuts, to see which is cheapest and which molt expensive, are always interesting. If the home is alert to such comparisons they may help to stretch dollars, too.
Brooklyn Tech and Benjamin Franklin High moved into the semi-final round of the Public Schools Athletic League championship basketball tournament yesterday at Madison Square Garden.
HAVANA, March 14 (AP) -- Ciclon, a 51-foot cutter owned by Luis Vidana of Havana, tonight won the 284-mile St. Petersburg to Havana yacht race for Class A craft.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- A campaign to raise $1,000,000 for the establishment of a motion picture hall of fame, will be officially opened tomorrow.
CAIRO, March 14 -- An Egyptian spokesman repeated today the Arab argument that peace in the Middle East could come only if Israel consented to implement basic United Nations resolutions on Palestine.

Gimbels presented a tripleheader yesterday in its showing of French, Italian and English imports. They included not only top couturier creations with meticulously made American copies, but also European boutique designs in ready-to-wear assortments and a group of one-of-a-kind couturier originals.

A Queens sewing machine company and three of its officers were arraigned yesterday on charges of fraudulent advertising on television. The accusation in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, was based on a criminal information.
Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross invited the Citizens Budget Commission yesterday to join her in a drive for $250,000 in private funds for "experimental programs" for prisoners.
BALTIMORE, March 14 -- John David Provoo, facing a second trial on wartime treason charges, was set free today.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The legislative committee investigating wiretapping decided today that the subject was too big and too important to handle in a five-week study.
Cincinnati, 17 points behind early in the second half, capped a tremendous rally by defeating Niagara, 85 -- 83, in two overtime periods at Madison Square Garden last night.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 14 -- The Yankees today outscored the Milwaukee Braves, 12 -- 11, for their initial triumph in the Grapefruit League.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 14 (UP) -- The Eisenhower Foundation requested the Kansas Legislature today to create a Presidential library commission to receive President Eisenhower's papers. The records would include those from the time he took command of Allied forces in Europe in World War II until he leaves the White House.
A professor of psychiatry said yesterday that art teachers and parents should not try to be professional psychiatrists. He was Dr. A. H. Maslow of Brandeis University, Waltham, Mass.

One of the great New York City and State financial and political mysteries is the operation of the so-called state-aid formula for education. The newspapers frequently refer to it as being arrived at by "a complex formula." Thus a matter which affects every taxpayer in the most direct way possible is treated as if it were something for the experts and the experts alone.
PARIS, March 14 -- The Cabinet met informally tonight to discuss policy in the two French protectorates of Tunisia and Morocco.

Cutting of a ribbon made of necktie fabric yesterday opened the new Wallachs store, the largest men's wear retail shop on Fifth Avenue. The store at 555 Fifth Avenue has a frontage of 125 feet on the avenue and eighty feet on Forty-sixth Street.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 14 -- A shortage of white manpower is threatening white supremacy in South Africa, Minister of Labor Jan de Klerk declared last night.
The Census Bureau recently came up with some startling figures.

PARIS, March 14 -- There is a growing awareness in Europe that the Atlantic alliance includes atomic powers and non-atomic powers -- those able to deter or defend through possession of the new weapons and those that must rely upon others for such deterrence or defense.

GENEVA, March 14 -- A new kind of farm problem is developing in Western Europe. Several countries have "surpluses" of food products too high priced for export, and other countries are on the same road.

MADRID, March 14 -- For political reasons, an interview with Juan Carlos of Bourbon that was to have been published in Arriba, official organ of the Falange party, is now expected to appear elsewhere.

LONDON, March 14 -- Negotiations between Britain and the Soviet Union for an informal two-power meeting broke down last summer over Moscow's insistence that a four-power conference be held simultaneously.
NEWARK, March 14 -- A hundred West Shore commuters donned pig-face masks today to dramatize their fight against abandonment of passenger service between Weehawken and Albany.

LONDON, March 14 -- A rally in British Government issues helped to steady the industrial stocks here today and turn some early losses among the leaders into gains of a few pence. However, the industrials closed irregular, with many more falls than rises.
MEXICO CITY, March 14 (AP) -- Program of events tomorrow in the second Pan-American games, with names of United States entrants in parentheses (New York time).

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A domestic political conflict with important international implications developed today over the question of publication of the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin conversations at the 1945 Yalta conference.
Sales of the nation's chain and mail order stores in February were 4.9 per cent greater than in the like 1954 month, according to a survey by The New York Times.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Defense problems of the free world in Southeast Asia were explored today by President Eisenhower and Robert Gordon Menzies, Prime Minister of Australia.
AMONG art exhibitions opening yesterday was a carefully chosen miniature retrospective showing of water-colors by David Fredenthal at the Milch Galleries, 55 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Companies contracting to purchase Government-owned rubber plants gave individual assurances to the House Armed Services Committee today that small rubber operators would get their fair share of the output.
TRENTON, March 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, presented to the Republican-controlled Legislature today the final installment of a record $286,784,289 budget.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Plans to build six glass and aluminum apartment house skyscrapers at two lakefront locations on Chicago's North Side at a cost of $25,000,000 were announced today. The six buildings would be one of the biggest private apartment building developments in Chicago's history.
Silicones, the remarkable chemical cousins of sand that repel water from raincoats, water-borne stains from everyday wear and catchup from the sides of catchup bottles, keep sifting into the news.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs, as reflected in ninety-one-day bill sales, have increased slightly.

ALBANY, March 14 (AP) -- Governor Harriman signed a bill today to let motorists plead guilty of traffic violations without appearing in court. All communities except New York City and Nassau County will be required to install the "mail-order" system, effective Sept. 1.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation increased its net earnings last year by 45 per cent to $22,445,996, highest in its twenty-three-year history. Sales, second largest on record, were 11 per cent below the peak volume of 1953, but 10 per cent above 1943, the top year of World War II, Robert E. Gross, president, reported.

The Government of Israel reiterated last night its willingness to "sit down tomorrow" at a conference table with all the Arab nations to negotiate a permanent peace treaty ending hostilities in the Middle East.

TAMPA, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Recent attendance, trade area population and baseball park size will be major factors in picking new members if the American League ever expands beyond its present eight clubs.

HARTFORD, March 14 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff disclosed today that he had ordered a top-to-bottom reorganization in the "completely demoralized" division handling the purchase of land for the New England Thruway in Connecticut.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 14 -- The Danes have agreed to tighten their belts for the next two years to meet the financial crisis that has arisen from overspending on social welfare and on consumer goods.
A General Sessions jury of ten men and two women, plus two men alternates, was completed yesterday for the retrial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke on compulsory prostitution charges.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 14 -- Chinese Nationalist fighter planes attacked a Communist convoy near Quemoy Island today. They reported sinking three 150-ton gunboats and seven armed junks carrying troops.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday for 1954 a record net income of $65,295,186, excluding a net gain of $1,865.851 on the sale of a British subsidiary company, Birlec, Ltd. After preferred dividend requirements, net earnings were equivalent to $4.34 each on the 14,584 shares of common stock outstanding. Net sales were $352,273,825.
The victim of a subway assault whose shots routed four young thugs was held yesterday on a charge of possessing a revolver without a permit.
TRENTON, March 14 -- New Jersey's Labor and Industry Commissioner said here today that the state faced an "insidious hazard" from the fall-out of radioactive material from atom bomb tests in Nevada.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- Mayor Joseph S. Clark Jr. decided today not to run for re- election. His action assured District Attorney Richardson Dilworth of the Democratic nomination for Mayor at the primary election May 17.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Repeal of the mandatory silver purchase laws was asked today by seven Senators.

NEW HAVEN, March 14 -- The Yale Library has opened an exhibition of political campaign literature in conjunction with Yale University's Conference on Responsible Leadership in a Democracy. The material covers the period from the election of George Washington to the Eisenhower- Stevenson campaign of 1952.

MANILA, March 14 -- After fifteen months in office, the Administration of President Ramon Magsaysay is judged by observers here as neither a success nor a failure. However, the months ahead are regarded as critical
A gunman's invasion of the British Embassy in Moscow on Sunday recalled to diplomatic observers in this country two previous incidents in the Soviet capital.

The Ann Nassau Realty Corporation has contracted to purchase the six-story commercial building at 22 East Forty-second Street which has been occupied for the past thirty-five years by Alex Taylor Co., sporting goods concern. The tenant has leased the ground floor and basement at 7 East Thirty-eighth Street and will move from Forty-second Street by April 1.
Rudy Garcia, Los Angeles featherweight, scored an impressive knockout victory over Nate Brooks of Cleveland at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

LIVERPOOL, England, March 14 (Reuters) -- The British Government is encouraging United States "flag discrimination" although it has protested against it in the past, the annual report of the Liverpool Steamship Owners Association charged today.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- M. Stanley Livingston, an atomic scientist, said today Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had used the Government's security program "to obtain publicity at the expense of individuals later judged to be completely loyal."

The proposed drastic revision in the domestic lending services of the Federal Government is probably the most controversial of the recommendations yet produced by the second Hoover Commission. It would involve alterations in public policy as well as changes in governmental technique and structure.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Important new medical knowledge about how to treat nuclear explosion survivors is being kept from American doctors by needless official secrecy, a Senate subcommittee was told today.

RICHMOND, Va., March 14 (AP) -- The United States Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals today put segregation of the races in public parks and playgrounds in the same class with segregation in public schools.
ROME, March 14 -- Romans indulged today in the big city diversion of muttering about subway service.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Supreme Court reiterated today a doctrine laid down in earlier decisions that "the Federal Government may tax what it also forbids.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 14 -- Governor General Ghulam Mohammed plans to visit Syria, Lebanon and Jordan next month to hasten Middle East defense alliances. Pakistan has a mutual security agreement with Turkey, and Turkey signed a similar pact last month with Iraq.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Agreement was announced today in a long-standing labor dispute between five major airlines and the A. F. L machinists union covering more than 14,000 mechanics and other ground service employes.

The basic agreement between the United States and Britain on fundamental concepts has been illustrated again by Prime Minister Churchill's latest statements in the House of Commons. In thorough concord with President Eisenhower, the Prime Minister declared yesterday that the only safe policy is peace through strength, based on unity.

Events tonight: Renata Tebaldi, soprano, Mario del Monaco, tenor, and Ettore Bastianini, baritone, Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, Efrem Zimbalist, violinist. Carnegie Hall, 8:30; American Chamber Orchestra, Town Hall. 8:30.

The city plans to increase police salaries by $200 in 1955-56 and $100 more in 1956-57. Budget Director Abraham D. Beame, in giving details of the plan yesterday, said the rise would make New York's police force the highest paid in the United States.
ATLANTA, March 14 (UP) -- A nine-state walk-out by 50,000 workers put long distance telephone service on an emergency basis in the South today.

NEW HAVEN, March 14 -- Oliver C. Henkel Jr. of Mansfield, Ohio, 17-year-old freshman at Yale, will represent American youth on a mission that leaves New York Wednesday to present 15,000 gifts to Greek children for the Share Your Birthday Foundation.

The Florida State Improvement Commission announced yesterday that it would receive bids March 31 on an issue of $6,000,000 of Manatee County bridge revenue bonds. Dated Aug. 1, 1953, the obligations will come due on Aug. 1 from 1957 to 1983.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 14 (AP) -- Bobby Avila, second baseman and the Cleveland Indians' last holdout, left by plane today for his home in Mexico after refusing the Indians' latest salary offer.
MIAMI BEACH, March 14 -- (UP) -- Leopold Stokowski, the conductor, was cut off the air last night when he objected to a radio script that placed his age at 73 and described his mother as Irish.
TRENTON, March 14 -- New Jersey Republican leaders are dissatisfied over the way Federal patronage is being dispensed.

A new one-story building at 37-15 Fifty-seventh Street in Woodside, Queens, has been leased by the Heyer Corporation of Chicago, manufacturer of office duplicating equipment. The property is owned by Frank Kaiser. The lease was negotiated by the Greiner-Maltz Company as broker.

Port Newark checkers continued yesterday to resist conciliatory gestures by longshore union leaders and the eleven-month dispute with the Waterman Steamship Corporation went on with no settlement in view. Three locals of the International Longshoremen's Association accuse the company of discrimination in hiring clerks and checkers.
Television networks are planning to cover another nuclear explosion test in the Nevada desert next month.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Harold E. Stassen said today that President Eisenhower's foreign aid recommendations would include a "significant increase" for free Asia.
Mayor Wagner opened officially yesterday what he termed the "biggest litterbug drive in the city's history."

Competition for the Stanley Cup, symbolic of the world professional ice hockey championship, will begin a week from tonight with games at Montreal and Detroit. The schedule for the cup play was drawn up yesterday in this city by the board of governors of the National Hockey League, with President Clarence Campbell directing the session.
New green cabbage from Florida and Texas now is offered for about 7 cents a pound, a reasonable price at this season.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Democrats and Republicans met half-way today in diagnosing the economic health of the country. They agreed that the "economy has been improving...
The most popular indoor sport at this time of the year is wrestling with an income-tax blank.

SANTA ANA, Calif., March 14 -- Charges of conspiracy to ask and receive bribes, contained in an Orange County grand jury indictment, today were dismissed against Sam L. Collins, former Assembly Speaker.

CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- The threat of revolt by the Big Ten over regional football television -- an issue within the N. C. A. A. for more than a year -- was completely dissipated today when the Conference voted to accept the N. C. A. A.'s 1955 TV program.
DETROIT, March 14 -- The first talks in the crucial 1955 contract negotiations in the auto industry were held here today.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith yesterday criticized a Senate-House staff report on the working of immigration laws as "statistical hokum."

MIAMI, Fla., March 14 -- Carl Erskine did his first pitching tonight and emerged quite satisfied. Although he walked two runs over the plate, the Dodgers beat the Baltimore Orioles, 6 -- 3, before only 4,263 fans at Miami Stadium.

Consolidated gross revenues of the Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest producer of aluminum, increased last year to $713,004,925 from $711,073,898 in 1953. Consolidated net income, however, declined to $46,471,470 from the record $48,848,094 earned the year before.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 607 pints of blood on Friday. Included were 104 pints given at Long Island University, 385 Flatbush Avenue Extension, Brooklyn. On Saturday 104 pints were given at the Baron de Kalb Council, Knights of Columbus, 3000 Emmons Avenue, Brooklyn.
Charlie Parker, one of the founders of progressive jazz, or be-bop, died here last Saturday night.
ROME, March 14 -- Premier Mario Scelba triumphed today over opposition within his own Christian Democratic party and assured his continuation in office.
