WASHINGTON, March 14 - Partisans and nonpartisans rarely agree on a set of facts and therefore on even their superficial meanings, and this is especially true in the political community. But recently the Congressional Quarterly, which is non-partisan, and the Democratic Digest, which is the organ of the Democratic National Committee, achieved harmony among their adding machines on the comparative voting statistics of 1952-54.
ALBANY, March 14 -- Governor Harriman and Attorney General Jacob K. Javits reached a truce today in their dispute over how the state should attack the juvenile delinquency problem.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Eight Republicans appealed to the House today to give the Administration's flexible farm price support system "a chance to work."

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that members of Jehovah's Witnesses, a religious sect, might be willing to fight a "theocratic war," but not an earthly one, and still be sincere conscientious objectors.

The windstorms and floods last week in the Pittsburgh area have earned the title "Catastrophe Serial Number 57" from the National Board of Fire Underwriters. Lewis A. Vincent, general manager, estimated yesterday that they would give rise to some 12,000 claims against stock fire insurance companies in western Pennsylvania alone.
Meeting the problem of juvenile delinquency requires "broad social engineering," Richard Clendenen warned here last night.
ALBANY, March 14 -- A compromise in the dispute between Governor Harriman, a Democrat, and the Republican-controlled Legislature over state educational grants was in process of negotiation tonight.
A pilgrimage of poets and players will make its way to Gramercy Square South tonight. And gathered around Percy MacKaye, they will read his own poems to him in tribute to his eightieth birthday.
FORTUNATELY, Zero Mostel is a low comedian, not interested in the mind. He is noisy, ugly, bulky, messy and funny.
ALBANY, March 15 (AP)--The State Commerce Department today received the following reports from operators of ski areas: North Creek--2-24 inches base; skiing fair. Old Forge--5-12 inches frozen
ALBANY, March 15--The Senate Finance Committee approved today a bill to bar racial discrimination in any publicly assisted rental housing.

An extension of daylight saving time for New York City until the last Sunday in October was voted unanimously yesterday by the City Council. Normally the daylight saving period, which will begin this year on Sunday, April 24, would terminate on the last Sunday in September, the 25th, this year. Under the new statute 1955 daylight saving time would end Sunday, Oct. 30.

The Democratic proposal to cut individual income taxes now in defiance of sound fiscal principles was defeated in the Senate yesterday and the Administration's measure extending corporate and excise tax rates was passed, but the battle is not over.

TAMPA, Fla., March 15 (AP) --President Warren Giles of the National Baseball League today said the league would "liberalize" the rule restricting catchers to the catcher's box until the ball has left the pitcher's hand. A bulletin to that effect went to league officials, managers and umpires.

Re-evaluation of depreciation allowances under present tax laws is essential if the steel industry's high rate of expenditures for facilities is to continue, according to the United States Steel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)--Following are two key rollcall votes by which the Senate today killed proposals for a cut of at least $20 on individual income taxes: On Johnson Proposal Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the Democratic leader, offered a substitute for the Administration tax bill, which was confined to excise and corporation levies.

LOUISVILLE, March 15 (AP)-- The Louisville and Nashville Railroad, battling to restore its strike-crippled passenger and freight service, today won a court order requiring train crews to cross picket lines set up by 25,000 nonoperating workers.
A Manhattan Republican woman district leader was described yesterday as a "vicious racketeer" who preyed on stateemployed charwomen.
The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company reported yesterday for 1954 a record net income of $7,164,373, or 58.96 a share. This compares

MANILA, March 15--When 47-year-old Ramon Magsaysay became President in January, 1954, his hair was jet black. Today he is starting to gray at the temples. A Filipino's hair usually does not start to gray until much later in life.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 15-- Leo Durocher tried to make it again today with his jayvees. This time it did not work so well.
CHICAGO, March 15 (APl)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A three-year survey of school health services in this city will begin April 1, the Health and Welfare Council of New York City announced yesterday.
A PERFORMANCE of rare skill was contributed by Eileen Heckart in the leading role on the Goodyear Television Playhouse over the National Broadcasting Company network on Sunday night.

Adolescence is so widely discussed and forms such a focus of concern for parents that many of the significant changes in a child during his "middle years" tend to be overlooked, Miss Anne Bassinger of the Brearley School feels.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- The Government's loyalty-security program went under intensified fire in Congress today.
SEOUL, Korea, March 15-- Prospects for friendly relations between the Republic of Korea and Japan look doubtful in this South Korean capital.
Patrick J. Moriarty got back his fabulous fire hydrant yesterday, and no action was taken against him.
Spring fashion, U. S. A., was neatly outlined yesterday at De Pinna. American-designer clothes, less expensive styles for "young moderns" and sportswear all were presented in one showing.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 15 --Heavy voting marked today's elections in eleven incorporated Suffolk County villages balloting for local officials. The following results were reported: AMITYVILLE The Union party, out of office for two years, made a clean sweep by defeating that People's party.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- The sequel to last year's ArmyMcCarthy hearings opened on Capitol Hill today with a prologue suggesting an imminent fight between the Army and Senator John L. McClellan.

Use of Ellis island for a permanent international trade center was proposed yesterday by a New York importer and exporter. He declared such a venture would bring the Federal Government revenues of "upward of $1,000,000 annually."
Pausing to toss off two fingers of milk, former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey showed a group of sales executives yesterday how the dairy surplus could be ended.

WASHINGTON, March 15-- Department of Commerce officials said today that newsprint supply and demand were now in "good balance." This situation should continue at least through 1956, they told a House Interstate and Foreign Commerce subcommittee.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -- Three pitchers whose combined ages total 103 years, hurled the Yankees to a 9-2 victory over the Phillies today. The oldest of the three, Lefty Ed Lopat, looked the best. At 36, the canny southpaw was clearly more impressive than Ewell Blackwell, 32, and Tommy Byrne, 35.
Village voters in ninety-four communities in Westchester, Rockland, Nassau and Suffolk Counties elected local officials yesterday in annual spring balloting.
Sanitation Department patrolmen, talking softly but carrying big pads, handed out 1,071 summonses yesterday on the open ing day of the tougher anti-litter drive.

WASHINGTON, March 15-- The Air Force said today its newest missile, the Falcon, was a miraculous weapon. It has the mission of knocking down "enemy bombers, carrying the hydrogen bomb, long before they reach their targets."
Contempt-of-court proceedings against William J. Keating in the wiretapping investigation were postponed again yesterday for six days to give his attorneys more time to prepare their defense.
DETROIT, March 15--A major contribution to traffic accident prevention in city streets was offered today by advances in truck construction.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) --Two Democratic Senators deplored today a "growing tendency" within the Administration to "clamp an unnecessary lid of secrecy" on information that should be made available to the public.
Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation anonunced yesterday completion of negotiations with six banks for a $60,000,000 credit to finance a major portion of its 1955 construction.
LONDON, March 15--The Council of Christians and Jews made a gesture of invitation today toward Roman Catholic churchmen to resume the membership in the Council they resigned last autumn.

The only thread linking the diverse international fashions shown yesterday by the Celanese Corporation of America was the fiber they contained-- Celanese acetate. The designs, by couturiers from France, Italy, Great Britain and Ireland, were presented in the Celanese concern's offices, 180 Madison Avenue.

A Chelsea builder, William Willett, began pushing his plan for daylight saving in Britain around 1907, but it took the First World War with its fuel shortage to convince lawmakers in England and most other European countries that using the sun rather than electricity or gas was a sound economy in spring, summer and autumn months.
It used to be said of the Model T Ford, "You can get it in any color, so long's it's black." And tire makers have long confined themselves to two colors--black and white.

Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 10 to 16 points (50 to 80 cents a bale) yesterday, except for the near-by March contract, which expired at noon 26 points above the previous day's close.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- The Atomic Energy Commission danied tonight that it was withholding important information on the treatment of victims of nuclear explosions.

Dayton's high-geared basketball team poured on the speed in the closing minutes last night to rout St. Louis, 97-81, in the quarter-final round of the eighteenth annual National Invitation Tournament. In the opening contest of a double-header that attracted 9,850 spectators to Madison Square Garden, St. Francis of Loretto, Pa., turned back Holy Cross, the 1954 tournament winner, 68-64.

The first place to guard against tyranny is "at the administrative level," Simon E. Sobeloff, United States Solicitor General, said here last night. He warned that no system could provide effective court review for all official conduct.
BONN, Germany, March 15-- The Social Democratic party seemed to have won sufficient outside support today to jeopardize the Saar agreement in the Federal Constitutional Court.
It might well be said that as goes paperboard, so goes the national economy.

BOSTON, March 15 (AP)--The Boston Celtics, paced by Bob Cousy and Frank Ramsey, beat the New York Knickerbockers, 122-101, tonight. The game was the first of their best-ofthree National Basketball Association play-off series in the Eastern Division.

MIAMI, March 15--The walls of the press room in Brooklyn's main baseball factory at Vero Beach are papered with photographs of all the Dodger heroes. There are some huge, life-sized action shots and also the usual 8x10 newspaper-size pictures of every man on the squad. It makes for a most attractive display.
ALBANY, March 15--Governor Harriman attempted today to incite an upstate revolt against the Republican residential rent plan.

PARIS, March 15--Premier Edgar Faure made a strong plea today for ratification of the Paris agreements to arm West Germany within the Atlantic alliance. He did so in an address to the Foreign Affairs Committee of the advisory Council of the Republic, the second chamber, which is to vote on the agreements this month.
The stock market rallied sharply yesterday. Prices retraced more than three-quarters of the ground lost on Monday and closed at about the best levels of the session.

WASHINGTON, March 15-- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States and Australia saw very much eye to eye on the various problems confronting them in the Western Pacific. But a question at Mr. Dulles' news conference brought out that United States and Australian strategic concepts were in fact opposed.

An apartment house is planned at the northwest corner of Kings Highway and East Fortieth Street in Brooklyn where a plot of about 18,000 square feet has been purchased by Joseph Levine of Freeport, L. I. The seller was Mrs. Ruth Norris, as executrix of the Hegeman estate.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 15 --The Legislative Yuan (Parliament) was told today that President Chiang Kai-shek had rejected the idea of a cease-fire for the Formosa Strait. The rejection was made in talks with Secretary of State Dulles March 3.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Edgar Snow's letter of Feb. 26 is the latest of a series in your paper urging the United States to knuckle under to Red China by forcing our allies, the Nationalists, to evacuate Quemoy and Matsu without a fight.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- The Senate rejected today all Democratic efforts to cut the individual income tax.
Workmen had a spectacular view early yesterday of the lower New York skyline as they started tests on Manhattan Bridge. These are in preparation for major repairs of the forty-fiveyear-old span.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- Secretary of State Dulles indicated today that the invasion of the Gaza strip would delay new United States guarantees of Israel's integrity.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 15--The United Nations' Palestine truce chief said today that he did not expect full-scale fighting to break out between Israel and her Arab neighbors.

ATLANTA, March 15 (UP)-- The Southern Bell Telephone Company charged today its cables had been "sabotaged" forty-six times in three states as a strike of 50,000 telephone workers went through its second day.
Last-minute intervention yesterday afternoon gave the Christopher Street ferry a fifteen -day lease on life.

HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., March 15--In spite of intermittent rain throughout the polling hours, the voting was heavy in the six Rockland County villages where there were contests today. In five villages where there was no opposition, the regular tickets were elected.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- President Eisenhower took on a social duty for his ailing wife today and toured the Washington flower show.
WASHINGTON, March 15--Independent petroleum producers urged Congress today to tighten import quotas on foreign oil.
SINGAPORE, March 15--The arrival here today of a United States aircraft carrier with four destroyers was linked to the expected call of the Aruba.

Coatless in Chaos This is March now, and with such a dubious month there has come the usual routine worry. A thoughtful appraisal would perhaps not rank it with so insolvable a problem as living within the budget, but it is difficult enough in its small way.

A group of amateurs from across the Hudson have made current history in the highly professional publicity game. Every major New York daily newspaper but one ran one or more pictures (a number on the front page) of West Shore commuters wearing pig masks on their trips to work Monday morning.
New York Harbor enjoyed its annual moment in the spotlight yesterday in the twenty-second observance of Port of New York Day. The queen of the world's ports was a well-flattered star by nightfall.
THE season's steady diet of contemporary one-man shows is varied this week by a number of group exhibitions. These include paintings of the past and present by artists both here and abroad.
The same family of-micro-organisms that makes various antibiotics, vitamins and hormones has been put to work to make a chemical building block with a wide list of uses.

The writer of the following letter served as special ambassador in connection with the Panmunjom negotiations. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your extremely able Washington correspondent, Arthur Krock, seems bent on some impish delight in a recent comment on Supreme Court action.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15--The John van Druten comedy, "Bell, Book and Candle," will be done by Phoenix Corporation as its first independent production to be financed by Columbia Pictures.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 15-- Village elections were held today in fifty-two Nassau County communities. There were contests in the following villages: EAST HILLS The incumbent East Hills party won easily over the Home party, which had assailed "one-party government."
ANOTHER two weeks should find the 1955 angling season well under way, at least in coastal waters. Trout fishermen will have to wait until the second Saturday in April.
LONDON, March 15--A year of industrial peace was forecast for Britain today as wage agreements were reached in two key industries.
THE PRESIDENT Went to a flower show; met with Republican Congressional leaders; discussed program for retarded children with Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland and Pearl S. Buck.

ALBANY, March 15--A conference on ways to combat "gyps" in advertising, sales and repair service touched off a new clash today between the Harriman administration and Attorney General Jacob K. Javits.
ALBANY, March 15--Lawyers who make a practice of appearing frequently before the State Liquor Authority are not necessarily more successful for their clients than others.
The Texas Company, major producer and refiner of oil, achieved last year the highest sales and earnings in its history, the annual report informs shareholders.

A Negro lawyer won yesterday the New York Newspaper Guild's annual Page One award for national public affairs. The award went to Thurgood Marshall, special counsel to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, for leading the right against racial segregation in the public schools.

Some big corporations making a varied line of products assign the advertising for each item to a different agency or break the account up into segments according to the media to be used. Others give all their advertising to a single agency.

Since Louis Calhern left Broadway for Hollywood after his admirable portrayal of King Lear during the 1950-51 season, he has been thinking of returning. Word came yesterday that he had obtained leave from Metro-Goldwyn -Mayer to double as star and director of "The Wooden Dish."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 15--Yugoslavia accepted today a Soviet proposal to resume the trend toward improved relations.

CHICAGO, March 15--Choppy price fluctuations marked trading in the grain markets today. At times wheat and soybeans were decidedly weak, but both registered a good recovery from the low spots. Long liquidation was not much in evidence, but the buying demand was slack at times, while local operators were inclined to sell.

MANILA, March 15--The Philippine Republic is the only Asian member of the Manila treaty organization that can be called a democracy in our sense of the word. That is to say it is governed by the people and for the people. Such is not the case in Thailand, whose capital is the nodal point of the alliance but whose political system is undisguised autocracy.
Pat Ward, the state's principal witness in the retrial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke on vice charges, proved yesterday to be a source of confusion to both the prosecution and the defense.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 9--Australia is expected to show a substantial deficit in overseas trade in the financial year ending June 30. This may necessitate reimposition of some of the import controls applied early in 1952 to get trade into balance.

CHICAGO, March 15--Net income of Wilson Co. in the quarter ended Jan. 29, the first quarter in the company's fiscal year, was higher than a year ago, James D. Cooney, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting today.

Sweet sap is running in the maple trees from southern New Hampshire across to Geauga County in Ohio. It is too early for comprehensive crop reports, but indications are that the syrup to which the sap is boiled down will be excellent in quality this year.

Cocoa futures did an aboutface yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange and closed up the 1-cent-a-pound limit in all positions. The spot (March) option, which has no limit, rose 130 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).
Two dogs with an obvious passion for Richard Strauss' music were selected yesterday for operatic debuts at the City Center tomorrow.
A sharp decline in trans-Atlantic shipping business in 1954 made the year the worst income period in the last twenty years, American Export Lines, Inc., reported yesterday.

THE Oratorio Society of New York, which began presenting the complete B minor Mass of Bach in the spring of 1927, last night gave its twenty-eighth performance of the work. For the first time the society used the Hunter College Auditorium.
BOWIE, Md., March 15 (AP)-- Nick Shuk and Willie Hartack shared the riding honors today with three winners each.

In helping underdeveloped countries to raise their living standards direct government aid has received by far the greatest attention. It began with President Truman's dramatic espousal of "Point Four." Since then the emphasis in Washington has swung toward the encouragement of private capital investment abroad.
New York women no longer will need a passport or a wallet stuffed with travelers' checks to bring home a dress with a European label. It can be bought right here in Herald Square.

LONDON, March 15--The stock market here was heartened today by another sharp rally in Government issues. Losses again outnumbered gains among industrial shares but the close was steady after prices had thrown off the inhibiting effect of yesterday's weakness in Wall Street.

LONDON, March 15 (Reuters) --Britain pared $8,680,000 today from her nuclear budget for the coming year. But the cut from last year's figure was described as of "no importance" by a spokesman for the Atomic Energy Authority.
WASHINGTON, March 15 --President Eisenhower has assured Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, of full backing in any Congressional fight over restoration of high, rigid farm price supports.
Ambitious plans for putting television to work for religion were announced yesterday by the Southern Baptist Convention.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 15 (UP)--Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said tonight that the Communist threat had not diminished and war could break out "almost any place, any time."

YESTERDAY (March 15, 1955) TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council continued questioning of special representative of administering authority on economic conditions in Ruanda -Urundi under Belgian administration.

AT noon tomorrow 115,000 men, women and children will trudge Fifth Avenue in the annual St. Patrick's Day parade. Their points of assembly, their order of march, even their music and their conduct, are pretty much under the control of one man.
HAVANA, March 15 (AP)--The blue-hulled Hoot Mon won the championship of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference today. The Class C yacht swept the three races that made up the competition.

THE Museum of Modern Art is temporarily cramped for exhibition space by reason of its show of examples of good design in main floor galleries and the big photographic show "The Family of Man" on the second floor.

Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower will serve as honorary chairman of the April in Paris Ball, which will be held April 15 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Charitable projects here and in France will benefit from the ball.

An agreement has been reached for the television debut of "The $64,000 Question." The quiz program will award $64,000 in cash --the largest jackpot ever offered by radio or TV--to a studio contestant who can answer seventeen questions.

Reform of a court system, or even lack of system, which is itself a product of gradual growth and improvisation to meet new needs, is bound to be slow, and perhaps wisely so. But finally a time comes when meditation, debate, hearings, consultations and all the other preliminaries customary in democracy must give way to action.
With a pair of Irish wolfhounds leading the way, Irish men and women by the thousands will strut up Fifth Avenue tomorrow in honor of St. Patrick's birthday.

Budget Director Abraham D. Beame proposed yesterday pay increases of $200 in 1955-56 and $100 in 1956-57 for firemen, the same as for policemen. The offer stirred up protest from the Uniformed Firemen's Association.

Three robbers escaped with more than $30,000 worth of diamonds and jewelry and $1,220 in cash after holding up a midtown jewelers' office last evening. The hold-up occurred at 6:30 P. M. in an eleventh-floor office at 10 West Forty-seventh Street in an area known as the jewelry district.

MIAMI, March 15--The Dodgers suffered indignities at the hands of a former Dodger, a Yankee and a Giant tonight. A five-run ninth inning for the Orioles was sparked by the hitting of Billy Cox, Gene Woodling and Hoot Evers, and Baltimore won, 8-6.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) --The House unanimously approved today a bill to speed punishment for balky witnesses appearing before Congressional committees.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 --A plan to enable United States ocean shipping to cut into the foreign - flag bulk tramp business and thereby give more jobs to American crews was presented today.
MONTREAL, March 15--A population authority said today the United States would run out of its natural resources rapidly unless it checked its population rise.

The latest of the Pacific alliances --that between the United States and the Chinese Nationalist Government --appears to be undergoing an evolution which has led to differences of opinion and of tactics. However, such differences have developed in our alliance with South Korea, and for that matter, in the whole North Atlantic alliance, without impairing their effectiveness.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- Confidence in this country's economy is such a fragile thing that it can be lost in a day, the Secretary of the Treasury warned today.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 15-- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, said today that a Soviet attack now against the West would be defeated. He based his judgment on relative airpower.

It has become common practice for the Shipbuilders Council of America to report each month that no new construction contracts have been received by the nation's private shipyards. In the report for February, however, two other negatives were added.
PARIS, March 15--The Governments of France and Tunisia resumed negotiations today on conventions establishing internal autonomy for the French protectorate.

MEXICO CITY, March 15 (AP) --Arnold Sowell of Pittsburgh whipped his team-mate, the great Mal Whitfield, in the 800meter run today to add to the United States' list of track and field championships in the PanAmerican Games.
Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia gained his fifth consecutive victory in the international chess masters' tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday, according to a report from Buenos Aires.
LONDON, March 15--The Parliamentary Labor party meets tomorrow morning to vote on a withdrawal of the party status in Parliament from Aneurin Bevan.

WE did not hear Eugene Ormandy's orchestral transcription of Bach's Organ Prelude and Fugue in C minor that opened the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall but we did hear him give one of the strongest and noblest readings of the Sibelius fifth Symphony within individual memory.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today that industrial production hit a seventeenmonth high early this month.

REGINA, Sask., March 15 (Canadian Press)--Tenley Albright and Hayes Alan Jenkins added a touch of daring to the compulsory school figures today to pace the North American figure skating championships.
A moderate increase in commercial exports this year was predicted yesterday at the Export Managers Club's thirtyfifth annual convention. The meeting at the Statler Hotel will end today.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- Senator William F. Knowland said today that it was "hign time" Congress got the facts on the 1945 Yalta conference.
ALBANY, March 15--Fiftyone state officers and employes have made a public record of their major private investments.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., March 15--A Uranium "land rush" burst from this southern California oil center at noon today.

James Madison High School of Brooklyn and Jamaica High of Queens scored easy triumphs as the semi-final bracket of the city Public Schools Athletic League championship basketball tournament was filled yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 15-- Secretary of State Dulles expounded today a doctrine of less-than-massive retaliation by the United States anywhere in the world if it became engaged in major military action.

ACF-Brill Motors Shareholders of ACF-Brill Motors Company at a special meeting yesterday in Philadelphia approved an amended plan of reorganization relating to the spinoff of Hall-Scott Motors Copany After the vote the meeting was recessed until March 18.

T. E. Lawrence, whose account of life in the R. A. F., "The Mint," will be published tomorrow more than thirty years after its composition, is the subject of a new and elaborate biography scheduled for publication this summer by Holt.

Four new security issues totaling $31,518,750 will be offered to the public today. They are bonds and preferred stock of one public utility, preferred stock of another utility and debentures of a loan company.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 15--Forty-nine would-be Air Force generals spent eight hours at Mitchel Air Force Base today worrying about such matters as the composer of the Surprise symphony and the joys of operating a power shovel.
First Boston Corporation and associates submitted the best bid yesterday for $6,600,000 State of "New Jersey highway bonds due April 1, 1957 to 1990.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) --The Department of Justice today obtained a consent antitrust judgment against three leading makers of grade-crossing protective devices.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The Democratic House of Representatives sliced $77,000,000 today from the Administration's first money bill for the next fiscal year.

Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, has purchased the twelvestory loft building at 840 Broadway from the 840 Holding Corporation. The property, on a plot 50 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of Thirteenth Street, is assessed at $200,000.

MONTREAL, March 15 (UP) --Maurice Richard entered a hospital today. The hockey star had been complaining of head and stomach pains. An official investigation of his fight in Boston Sunday night will go on as scheduled.

The American Chamber Orchestra was heard in its final concert of the season at Town Hall last evening. Robert Scholz conducted, and Kenneth Smith, bass; Stuart Sankey, contrabassplayer, and Herbert Feldman, violist, were soloists.

BOCHUM, West Germany, March 15 (Reuters)--Mrs. James B. Conant, wife of the United States High Commissioner in Germany, today opened a week of American theatre for Bochum citizens with a lecture on the history and tradition of the stage in the United States.
Enlargement of South Beach on the southeast shore of Staten Island was started yesterday.

Among overweight men between 40 and 65 years old there is a greater danger of heart attacks in regaining weight after reducing than in simply remaining overweight, according to a city nutrition expert.
Sudden, strong winds, occasionally reaching gale force, caused the deaths of four men here late yesterday.
The Administration has moved a step closer toward committing the United States to an atomic strategy.
PARIS, March 16--Premier Edgar Faure said today that France must become a nuclear power.
DETROIT, March 16--Michigan's slow pace in preparing for the St. Lawrence Seaway received some critical attention here last week.
WASHINGTON, March 16-- Prime Minister Churchill's light - hearted approach to some pressing world problems took a rhyming turn on one occasion.
TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council questioned special representative of administering authority on social conditions in Ruanda-Urundi under Belgian admisintration.

The stock market advanced again yesterday. Prices as measured by The New York Times' composite average of fifty representative listed issues rose 1.49 points to close at 270.61, the best level of the week. The advance put the list within one-quarter of a point of whire it had closed last Friday.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP)--The Senate Agriculture Committee approved a bill today authorizing an additional cut up to 15 per cent in 1955 burley tobacco planting allotments.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent letter Sara Strauss Hess suggests that funds derived from the $350,000,000 bond issue approved by the voters of New York State in November, 1954, be allocated primarily "to the training of psychiatrists and their adjunctive therapists," and only in part to new buildings.
ST. PAUL, March 16 --A member of the Roman Catholic hierarchy said here today that religion had been "almost eliminated" from daily life.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16--John Kucks, who may still develop into the Yankees' pitching find of the spring, was the losing hurler as the Bombers bowed, 3--1, to the Chicago White Sox today.

DETROIT, March 16 (AP)--The president of Montgomery Ward Co. scoffed today at Louis E. Wolfson's claim that he will win control of the company at the annual stockholders meeting in Chicago on April 22.
Bernard Newman is an exponent of simple elegance, and women who search for this type of clothes will find his new collection of ready-to-wear originals at Bergdorf Goodman.

MEXICO CITY, March 16 (AP) --Rod Richard, Barbara Jones and Bob Backus won championships for the United States in the Pan-American Games today. However, their efforts were overshadowed by a world record hop, skip and jump by Adehemar Ferreria Da Silva of Brazil.

Green for Today Green is the color of the shamrock and green is the color for today. Is it mere coincidence that this is also the season when nature invariably delights everyone in the northern latitudes

SEOUL, Korea, March 16 -- South Korean defense officials have asked United States military authorities to stock South Korea with atomic cannon. The request was made to Gen. John E. Hull, United States and United Nations Commander in the Far Eas who agreed to relay the plea to Washington.
Southward the course of industrial empire continues to take its way. And not all of it is at the cost of New England's mill towns.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 16 (AP)--Mrs. Mae Murray Jones of Montpelier, Vt., and Mary Patton Janssen of Charlottesville, Va., each carded a 75 to tie for the medal honors today in the fifty-third North and South Amateur golf tournament.
A juror who had been visited Tuesday night by a newspaperman was dropped yesterday from the Minot F. Jelke vice case.

The City Planning Commission yesterday raised the question why the city should have to buy new fire pumpers while sixty-five virtually new ones bought for civil defense purposes stand relatively idle.
The United States will be the first country to put at sea a big freighter powered by a gas turbine.
ALBANY, March 16--A new feature of the Republican rent control bill was disclosed today. It immediately drew sharp criticism from Charles Abrams, State Rent Administrator, and Democratic legislators.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) --A group of freshmen Democratic Congressmen called today for a new approach to United States foreign policy in an effort to relieve world tensions and abolish war.
The Yalta conference was an effort to solve problems looming with the imminent defeat of Germany in World War II and the attempt to enlist Soviet forces in the Allied war against Japan.
The Commerce and Industry Association called yesterday for legislative action to end corruption, abuse and maladministration of union welfare funds.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 16--Governor Luis Munoz Marin has recommended to the Legislature a law barring rum, whisky and other hard liquor advertisements from radio and television.
New issues of corporate securities valued at more than $36,000,000 will be offered to investors today.
VIENNA, March 16--The Austrian Government has proposed to Moscow that a state treaty for Austria be negotiated apart from any other matter--which means apart from the German problem.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday rose 6 to 18 points 30 cents to 90 cents a bale).
WASHINGTON, March 16-- President Eisenhower asserted today that the Republican party could win the Presidency with any worthy candidate if it enacted fine programs for the benefit of all America.

Two leaders in the electronics field are talking merger. Harry S. Vickers, president of the Sperry Corporation, and James H. Rand, president of Remington Rand, Inc., announced yesterday that negotiations were being held toward consolidation of the two companies on a "fair and equitable" basis.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 16--Johnny Podres was sitting in the Dodgers' dressing room on that fateful day in October of 1953, minding his business and at peace with the world. He had passed his twenty-first birthday the week before and his team was in the world series against the Yankees. Life was wonderful.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 16-- Ted Williams was reported today to be ready to return to the Boston Red Sox. The heavy-hitting outfielder had announced at the close of last seas nthat he was quitting the game.
The United Biscuit Company of America announced yesterday that its net income last year amounted to $1,851,255, or $1.45 a common share, compared with $4,213,16, or $3.96 a share, in 1953.

WASHINGTON, March 16-- Speedy action to rebuild Southwestern Washington through a redevelopment plan was urged today by President Eisenhower. He called for the effort in a letter to George A. Garrett, president of the Federal City Council of Washington.
SEVILLE, Spain, March 16-- The Vatican issued today a statement interpreted as public censure of Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Seville.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) --Former Governor Dewey said today he confidently hoped President Eisenhower would run again next year.

The Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will benefit from the fourth annual luncheon and fashion show, to be held by the Spence-Chapin Corner Shop Committee next Wednesday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 16 (AP)--Nance's lad won the $20,750-added Fountain of Youth Handicap at Gulfstream Park today. Those fans who backed him down to 3-to-2 favoritism had several anxious minutes before his victory was confirmed by the stewards.

MIAMI, March 16 (UP)-- Bobby Dykes of Miami, defeated Kid Gavilan tonight. He gained a unanimous ten-round decision before 5,000 in Miami Stadium. It was the second straight defeat for the former welterweight champion in his comeback attempt.
PARIS, March 16--Premier Edgar Faure reaffirmed today the principle of internal autonomy for Tunisia. His predecessor, Pierre Mendes-France, promised such autonomy last July 31.

Shall a school teacher who has in all good faith broken off from the Communist party be required to report to school authorities the names of any other teachers who have also been members of the Communist or similar subversive groups? That in essence is the sticky question on which the New York City Board of Education is scheduled to make a decision at its meeting today.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) --Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House has authorized direct quotation of the President in some sections. In others, as required by conference rules, the President's remarks are in indirect discourse.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16--Poetry is not a frequent source of inspiration for movie plots, but Columbia's Jerry Wald thinks studios have been missing a good bet in passing up the writings of Robinson Jeffers.
LONDON, March 16--The Archbishop of York, the second figure of the Church of England, told a hushed House of Lords tonight that Britain's decision to manufacture the hydrogen bomb was right.
PHILADELPHIA, March 16 (AP)--James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, told stockholders today that "we are more optimistic going into 1955 than at any time in the past eight years."

Two men, close to the firing line in the food business--the retail store--came up with some interesting observations pertinent to advertising yesterday. They are Charles Ricciardelli, maanger of Food Fair's store in the Port Authority Bus Terminal, and William Herde, manager of the Grand Union store at Eighty-sixth Street and First Avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) --A former Army officer testified today that the loyalty case of former Maj. Irving Peress slipped by him in a flood of paperwork.

Bernardo Wexler of Argentina defeated Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia in the sixth round of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday, according to a report from Buenos Aires. It was Ivkov's first loss in the competition.

Most commodity futures prices on the New Yark exchanges rose yesterday, in sympathy with the stock market. Rubber, hide, burlap, wool, silk, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc and tin advanced; coffee and potatoes eased and cocoa, sugar and copper ended mixed.

New York Air Brake Unfilled orders of the New York Air Brake Company were $14,600,000 on Feb. 28, against $12,700,000 on Dec. 31, 1954, Bernard Peyton, chairman, told the annual meeting in Flemington, N. J., yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 16--Corn futures were strong and higer today, with fairly general buying at times. Bulls showed more confidence due to the small receipts and light country offerings and intimations that growers will put a large part of their remaining surplus under Government loan unless prices advance much above this level.
Water gushing from a burst main flooded a Queens street, tore up a large section of sidewalk and disrupted service on an IND subway line yesterday.

A "truck-air-truck'' door-to- door service was announced here yesterday. Delos W. Rentzel, formerly Administrator of Civil Aeronautics and now chairman of Slick Airways, Inc., large certificated air freight carrier, told of the new operation.

Scribner has announced that a volume is in preparation that will complete the late Dr. Douglas Southall Freeman's biography of George Washington. Dr. Freeman's sixth volume on Washington was published posthumously last year.

CHICAGO, March 16--Latin America's prospects for population growth and economic development make it a profit yielding area for United States investors who observe certain unofficial ground rules. J. Peter Grace Jr. of New York, president of W. R. Grace Co., said today.

Nonfat dry milk--dry skim milk, some cooks call it--was revamped last fall to make it instantly soluble in hot or cold water. Always an excellent product (low in cost, high in food value), it became even more useful.

The New York Knickerbockers beat the Boston Celtics, 102 to 95, at Madison Square Garden last night. The New Yorkers' victory evened the National Basketball Association Eastern Division play-off series at one game apiece.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 16--A leading Arab spokesman urged the United Nations today to police the troubled Arab-Israeli frontiers with day-and-night patrols and powerful searchlights.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 16-- Leo Durocher played it with the varsity today and the result was gratifying. For the Giants went back to performing in the manner of world champions as they brought down Stan Hack's Cubs, 5 to 3, to take a 2-1 lead in the spring series.
Linens and laces still make ladies portrait-pretty, judging from the new Samuel Winston collection. It was shown yesterday by Rosette Pennington, 20 East Fifty-sixth Street.
ALBANY, March 16--Governor Harriman is seriously considering an attempt to sidetrack and perhaps to abandon the state's compulsory automobile inspection program.
LONDON, March 16--According to informed sources the United States Government will be invited--and will agree--to join the Turkish-Iraqi defense treaty within a few months.
BERLIN, March 16 -- The United States has been the chief helper and best customer of the Askania Corporation, several of whose executives are on trial here for illegal trade with Communist China.
ALBANY, March 16--Two proposals to revise the New York City Transit Authority Law were abandoned quietly by Mayor Wagner's Administration today.
(Bohlen Collection) BOHLEN MINUTES TOP SECRET The President said he understood the foreign ministers had another report to make, and he woud ask Mr. Stettinius, who presided today, to give it.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 16 --The Dodgers and the Orioles showed 2,084 Holman Stadium fans a lot of scoring today. The Brooks made eighteen hits without a home run and the Orioles eleven hits with one home run. It was an 18-8 Brooklyn triumph.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) --The Children's Bureau has started a survey to find out how many black-market babies are being adopted each year.

A symphony orchestra and a jazz band can be thrown together on the same stage and induced to make exciting music. It can, that is, if you can get Duke Ellington to provide the band and to write the music.
ALBANY, March 16 (UP)--Governor Harriman said today the Administration was trying to find an accurate yardstick to maesure unemployment in New York State.
The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday it had notified subscribers that May 2 is the deadline for reserving their present seat locations for next season.
WASHINGTON, March 16-- Alger Hiss was nearly left off the Yalta delegation.

The eight-story and penthouse building used for storing records at 25 to 31 South William Street through to 37-43 Stone Street has been sold by the estate of Samuel McCrudden to Stanley W. Kempner and Morton Wormser for investment.

Mayor Wagner began the seclusion of his annual ten-day budget "retreat" yesterday. He starts with a current budget of about $1,640,000,000. Departmental requests of the more than one hundred agencies of city government run to $1,868,061,980, or nearly a quarter of a billion dollars more than they are getting now.
PAPHOS, Cyprus, March 16 (Reuters) -- Demonstrators smashed courthouse windows and stoned policemen today as a British court opened a trial of thirteen men for civil-war conspiracy.

A lovely table setting can do more to revive lagging appetites than all of grandma's old- fashioned spring tonics. Now on display at Stern Brothers are examples of table effects that can be achieved with little expense.

The Yalta conference was one of two meetings at which the basic framework of the United Nations was laid. The other was the Dumbarton Oaks conference of 1944. It took its name from the estate in Washington where the conference met.

The situation at Albany is unsatisfactory and disappointing. The Legislature has been in session for ten weeks. It hopes to adjourn in about two weeks. It has been preoccupied, obsessed, by political wrangling over budget, rent control and Harriman appointees.
Luscious red strawberries, here from Florida at this in-between season when there are few fresh fruits, offer many possibilities for simple week-end desserts.
ATLANTA, March 16 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation was called into the three- day-old walkout of Southern Bell Telephone Company workers today.

The International Paper Company and its subsidiaries last year achieved the highest sales and earnings in its fifty-seven- year history. John H. Hinman, board chairman, attributed the improved earnings to the expiration of the excess profits tax and other tax savings.

Moliere's comedy, "The Miser," starring Maurice Schwartz, will open tonight at 8 o'clock at the Downtown National Theatre, Second Avenue and Houston Street. Louise Jergan is responsible for the English version of the French work.
WASHINGTON, March 16 --Western leaders suggested some of the "world's finest resorts in a vain effort to lure Marshal Stalin from the Soviet Union for the 1945 "Big Three" meeting.
"Fair trade," the principle that permits manufacturers legally to fix minimum store prices on their products in most states, is under fire.

WASHINGTON, March 16-- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 9:
Hanson W. Baldwin said yesterday that "resolute, firm, fair and stable United States policies throughout the world are essential to the preservation of peace."
MOSCOW, March 16--Soviet authorities identified today the man who shot his way into the British Embassy on Sunday. They stated that he was deranged.
The strike-shut Brooklyn Eagle announced yesterday that it never would publish again.
Studies indicating that a substandard diet in expectant mothers may produce children below par in intelligence were reported here yesterday.
The United States must increase imports to protect her own prosperity, an export trade group was told yesterday.
ALBANY, March 16 (UP)--The State Commerce Department today received the following reports from operators of ski areas: North Creek--2-24 inches base; skiing fair.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Among the allegations of what happened at the Yalta conference in 1945 that have received wide public acceptance are two in particular on which, the official records cast no light. One was that the Navy representatives at this Roosevelt- Churchill-Stalin meeting opposed the concept that Russian intervention was essential to assure the defeat of Japan.
PITTSBURGH, March 16-- The A. F. L. Teamsters Union got the green light today to roll delivery trucks at the five downtown department stores after nearly sixteen months.

Aluminum, Ltd., announced plans yesterday for a $190,000,000 expansion of its huge Kitimat, B. C., smelter. The project will raise the Canadian plant's capacity to 331,500 tons a year --more than twice the capacity already installed or under construction.
WASHINGTON, March 16-- President Eisenhower declared today that he expected more nonsensitive Government jobs to be found for Federal workers deemed "security risks" in sensitive positions.
The city continued to scrub its public face yesterday, but 938 litter summonses gave evidence that it was not clean enough.

Earnings of the Shell Oil Company last year were the highest in its history, with sales at a record for the fifth consecutive year. Assets passed the billion dollar mark for the first time. H. S. M. Burns, president, noted in the thirty-third annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The present rib-crushing conditions in uptown Lexington Avenue trains in the morning endanger the lives of shorter passengers. The cars of the Third Avenue El are also full to capacity during the morning rush below 149th Street.
ALBANY, March 16--An Administration bill requiring state registration of employe welfare funds was introduced in the Assembly today.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) --Congress received conflicting advice today on how long and under what terms to continue the program for recruiting Mexican farm laborers.

For the historic record, and as a service to the nation, The New York Times prints today the complete official account of the Yalta conference held during the closing days of the last World War, as compiled by the Department of State.

A Government offer of immunity in a wartime espionage investigation was labeled yesterday as a move to trap the witness into a perjury indictment. This charge of "entrapment" was raised in the first test of the constitutionality of the law granting witnesses immunity from prosecution in cases involving national security.
ALBANY, March 16--The Republican bill to legalize bingo by amending the State Constitution was reported out of the Senate Finance Committee today.

More people became blind in the United State's last year than in any previous year of our history. This was reported here yestreday at the opening of a three-day meeting of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 16--The advertising profession was advised today to attract talent by selling itself much as it does soap.

An increase last week of 1,081,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks to 183,424,000 barrels, another record, at the week-end was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. The inventory figure compares with 182,343,000 barrels, the previous peak, a week earlier and 177,783,000 a year earlier.
BOSTON, March 16--Boston's last coast-wise general cargo service will be discontinued April 5. Officials of the Pan Atlantic Steamship Corporation said that a $500,000 loss in 1954 prompted the move.

We note with the deepest regret the decision of our good neighbor The Brooklyn Eagle to cease publication. Until the strike that suspended operations on Jan. 29 this newspaper had never missed publication of an edition for 114 years. It had been a forceful, interesting, public-spirited, inquiring newspaper, with first loyalty to the community it served, but attentive also to the world beyond its borders.

LONDON, March 16--The recovery in stock market prices spread today from Government securities to industrial shares. However, rises of one shilling (14 cents) or two shillings by many industrials were ascribed partly to sentimental as well as technical reasons.
The 1955 line of Youngstown Kitchens, introduced this week by Bruno-New York, Inc., will be available at Gimbels on April 1.
MONTREAL, March 16--The twentieth North American Wildlife Conference ended today with general agreement that more public education was needed in the conservation of the Continent's natural resources.
WASHINGTON, March 16-- Appraisals of the inquiry into the stock market and its effect on prices and confidence in the economy came from three sources today.
MOSCOW, March 16--An allegation that the armed forces of the United States, Britain and France are at least twice as large as those of the Soviet Union was published here today.

BOSTON, March 16 (UP)-- Earl (Dutch) Reibel's goal at 14:58 of the third period helped the Detroit Red Wings score a 5-4 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight. The game at Boston Garden was watched by 7,917 fans.

Fifteen-hundred Lower East Side school children, selected by their teachers because of leadership qualities and community interest, have participated in The Bowery Savings Bank's "Junior Adviser" program since its inception six years ago.
Springfield, Mo. Springfield, Mo., has designated March 29 for the sale of $11,127,000 of public utility bonds dated April 1, 1955, and maturing on April 1 from 1958 to 1982.
Alger Hiss confirmed last night that he had unsuccessfully opposed Soviet proposals at the Yalta Conference to admit three Soviet Republics as independent members of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 16-- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies of Australia said today the differences between Australia and the United States on strategy in Southeast Asia were "but specks on the surface of the deep stream of unity in our relation."

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) --Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, today scheduled public hearings on wiretapping for next Wednesday. He said any requested witness "who doesn't want to come will be subpoenaed."

The ten-year fight of Arnold Bernstein, pre-Hitler German shipping magnate, against the Holland-America Line for the value of his Red Star Line shipping properties ended yesterday. Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock approved a settlement.

B. Gertz, Inc., department store of Jamaica and Flushing, signed a $10,000,000 long-term lease yesterday in the new $40,000,000 suburban shopping center near Hicksville, L. I. Gertz is the first to sign in the development, which is scheduled to open in September, 1956.

NEWARK, March 16--Hearings on the New York Central's plan to abandon passenger service on its West Shore Division were recessed today until April 19. Meanwhile the Public Utility Commission will study a motion on behalf of commuter groups to dismiss the application.

WASHINGTON, March 16-- The Finnish Embassy announced today that the owners of the Finnish tanker Aruba, which was carrying kerosene to Communist China, had ordered the ship to proceed to the nearest non- Communist port.
LONDON, March 16--Aneurin Bevan was expelled from the Parliamentary Labor party today by a majority of only twenty-nine votes.

SAG HARBR, L. I., March 16 --In one of the most spirited contests in the history of this eastern Long Island village, a last-minute opposition slate over whelmed the incumbent Mayor and two trustees in yesterday's election.
WASHINGTON, March 16-- After the Big Three got through disposing of the world at Yalta, everybody went to a party and had a grand time.
The tax on general and financial business to meet the city's need for additional revenue must be increased in the fiscal year 1955-56, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP)--The House Armed Services Committee gave overwhelming approval today to the Government's plan to sell its synthetic rubber factories to big rubber, oil and chemical companies.
THE dream of every mezzosoprano is to sing the title role in "Carmen," and Blanche Thebom did so for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera last night.

The lawyer making a coffee table in his basement workshop and the 5-year-old playing fireman with the garden hose are getting at least one common satisfaction, a mental health group was told last night.
WASHINGTON, March 16--The Senate Democratic leadership publicly warned President Eisenhower today of coming trouble for his tariff-cutting plan in the aftermath of his victory in the tax fight.
EL PASO, Tex., March 16 --Harvey Matusow was sentenced today to three years in Federal prison for contempt of court here.
ART of the past--European and Oriental-is represented in two of this week's important exhibitions.

MONTREAL, March 16 (UP)-- Maurice (The Rocket) Richard was banned today from all remaining National Hockey League games this season. He was also barred from the postseason play-offs for the Stanley Cup.
ST. LOUIS, March 16 (UP)-- Ron Murphy and Bill Mosienko scored tonight as the New York Rangers and the Chicago Black Hawks played a 1-1 tie in a National League Hockey game.
KATMANDU, Nepal, March 11--Almost every hour of the day impossible things are taking place in this country where men once threw themselves in the dirt when their rulers passed.

WASHINGTON, March 16--President Eisenhower disclosed today that atomic weapons would be used with "bullet" precision against military targets in the event of war. In any combat, "where these things are used on strictly military targets and for strictly military purposes, I see no reason why they shouldn't be used just exactly as you would use a bullet or anything else," he asserted.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Times editorial on "Legislative Anachronism" is most timely because of current Congressional efforts to upset President Eisenhower's flexible farm program. Some Congressmen would resurrect the old inflexible 90 per cent of parity support for the six basics-- wheat, corn, cotton, tobacco, peanuts and rice.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The forthcoming return of the United States icebreaker Atka to our shores is an opportune time to congratulate The New York Times and, in particular, your very able correspondent, Walter Sullivan, on his excellent dispatches.

(Bohlen Collection) BOHLEN NOTE SECRET At the last plenary session,, the communique was discussed and most of the conversation dealt with the details of language, the results of which are apparent in the final communique agreed upon.
The National Invitation basketball tourney will resume tonight at Madison Square Garden. The first of the two semi-final games will start at 7:45 o'clock.

A committee of prominent persons has been formed to work for the success of the annual Russian Easter Ball, which will be held on April 20 in the ballroom of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Tolstoy Foundation, Inc.

Louis E. Wolfson clashed head-on with an official of the A. F. L. Boilermakers Union here yesterday. The occasion was the annual meeting of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, at which Mr. Wolfson presided as board chairman.

WASHINGTON, March 16-- The State Department's account of the Malta and Yalta conferences includes this list of abreviations, symbols and code names: ACC--Allied Control Commission. A-D--Assistant Secretary of State, James C. Dunn.

The old West 100th Street police station went out of use yesterday, but the Twenty- fourth Precinct carried on in a new house. The men in blue moved with simple efficiency and no regrets to a building on Central Park West, just north of Ninety-ninth Street.
WASHINGTON, March 16-- The post-war partition of Poland, symbolic of all East Europe's subjugation by the Soviet Union, is described in gripping terms in the Yalta papers made public tonight.

YESTERDAY (March 16, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Held news conference. Nominated Allen Witfield of Des Moines to be member of the Atomic Energy Commission; Ellis O. Briggs of Topsfield, Me., to be Ambassador to Peru, and William S. B. Lacy of Leesburg, Va., to be Ambassador to Korea.
Work is already under way on the Dixon-Yates power plant at West Memphis, Ark., Mr. Dixon disclosed yesterday.
PARIS, March 16--Favorable votes in three Senatorial committees today gave promise of rapid ratification of the Paris agreements for arming West Germany.
A thousand rapt youngsters enjoyed a program of Viennese music by the New York Philharmonic -Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP)--Today's report of the llvestosk markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 9,000 head: general trade active: all weights butchers mainly 25c higher, but the late market slow with a few sales around steady; sows 25c or more up: most
WASHINGTON, March 16-- For the first time United States troops will test armor as protection in an atomic explosion. The test will occur in April, at Camp Desert Rock, Nev.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 16 (UP)--The Louisville Nashville Railroad, hit by a strike that is causing widespread unemployment, announced today it was suspending all operations.
PHILADELPHIA, March 16 (UP)--A suit to prevent the barring of Negroes from Government -insured houses and apartments was dismissed in Federal District Court here today.

OUR beach-running correspondent from the dunes of Dare on the North Carolina outer banks seems more interested in mirages these days than in the surf casting possibilities. This is rather strange in view of the imminence of spring and the arrival of the channel bass.
NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., March 16--Mayor Jasper Messina was declared defeated for re-election here today, but Carl M. Christ, the Election Board chairman, pronounced the vote null and void.

WASHINGTON, March 16-- Following are the foreword and introduction to the State Department's book of documents dealing with the World War II conferences at Yalta and Maltal in 1945. This portion of the book explains the purpose and method of assembling the documents.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 --Officers of three maritime unions today assailed Harry Lundeberg, West Coast sailors' leader.

ST. PAUL, March 16 (AP)--A fast finish gave the Minneapolis Lakers an 82-78 victory over the Rochester Royals tonight. It was the first game of the Western Division three-game play-off in the National Basketball Association.
MANILA, March 16--In the Philippines the Communist menace is being defeated by a lively attempt to bring democracy to the people rather than through military suppression alone.
WASHINGTON, March 16-- The Senate confirmed late today the nomination of Judge John Marshall Harlan of New York to the Supreme Court. The vote was 71 to 11.

TODAY one of the most famous unpublished books of modern times is finally published. Its original sale price was $500,000 (that is no typographical error) for a single copy. Now, in a limited edition of 1,000 copies, it costs $20. With a touch of whimsey-- or aren't they kidding?--Doubleday calls this the "inexpensive edition."
WASHINGTON, March 16-- The fabulous story of how President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin tried to reorganize the world in a week at Yalta was finally made public today.
ALBANY, March 16--The Republican leader of the Senate suggested today that the Heald Commission receive funds to set up special classes for non-English- speaking children.
WASHINGTON, March 16-- Personalities mentioned in the documents dealing with the Malta and Yalta conferences were listed by the State Department as follows:

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 16 --A farmhouse in the Negev, seven miles from the Egyptian frontier was wrecked by bombs last night. The house was unoccupied, but a settler in charge of the village guards who engaged the marauders was wounded.

CALI, Colombia, March 2--A Colombian citizen has begun court action to set aside as unconstitutional the treaty signed between the United States and Colombia in 1914. settling their differences over North American support of Panama's independence.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UP) --Five New York witnesses pleaded the Fifth Amendment today when asked by a House un-American activities subcommittee if they had any connections with the Communist party or the Labor Youth League.
TOP SECRET (Yalta, 9 February 1945.) Report to the President and Prime Minister of the agreed summary of conclusions reached by the Combined Chiefs of Staff at the "Argonaut" conference:
WASHINGTON, March 16-- Premier Stalin told President Roosevelt at the Yalta conference that he himself was a Zionist in principle but that Soviet Jews had posed a difficult problem for him.

WASHINGTON, March 16-- President Eisenhower told his news conference today that he knew of "no reason" why the City of Memphis should not build its own power plant and that he would favor its construction.
WASHINGTON, March 16-- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy attacked the President's brother, Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, and the President himself in the Senate today.
ROME, March 16--The Sacred Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith published today an excommunication decree issued more than three years ago against a Chinese priest.
LONDON, March 16--There are two men who hold the undivided attention of the House of Commons whenever they speak. One is Sir Winston Churchill. The other is Aneurin Bevan.

The apartment and store property at 641-647 Elizabeth Avenue in Newark, N. J., has been sold by the New Jersey Realty Company to the Rubin Corporation. The three-story structure, on plot 100 by 100 feet, contains four stores and twenty - two apartments. J. L Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
The metropolitan college basketball coaches yesterday went on record as favoring the adoption of the pro rules for college play next year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17--Egypt asked today for severe penalties to punish Israel for "brutal aggression" against Egyptian forces in the Gaza area.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 17 --The Association of National Advertisers called today for "prompt and vigorous" enforcement of statutes against "bait" advertising.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 (AP)--John Barnum and Doug Higgins carded sevenunder-par 65's today to set the first-round pace in the $12,500 St. Petersburg open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- The Export-Import Bank of Washington today authorized a total of $21,325,000 in credit needed to help finance the sale of American capital goods abroad. The credit lines ranged from $75,000 to $10,000,000 and were granted to five manufacturers with orders from abroad for American productive machinery and related services.
Major American oil companies replied yesterday to charges by the Economic Commission for Europe that they had combined to keep oil prices high in Western Europe.
KATMANDU, Nepal, March 17 --Fourteen white-shrouded Brahman priests took the body of a god-king from an airplane today and carried it three miles to the cremation ground.

MANHASSET, L. I., March 17 --Long Island University will open a coeducational college of arts and sciences in Brookville in September. Registration for the first freshman class will start tomorrow in the administration building on the Brookville campus.
Differing views on the functions of Federal minimum wage laws were given yesterday by Rocco C. Siciliano, Assistant Secretary of Labor, and Isador Lubin, State Industrial Commissioner.

A blockfront gasoline station property in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by Loomis J. Grossman, real estate investor. The property, 200 by 75 feet, is on the south side of Queens Boulevard, between Thirty -third Street and Thirty-second Place.

THE flamboyant spirit of Mac Hyman's best-selling novel "No Time for Sergeants" was captured effectively in the television adaptation presented on Tuesday night. The story of the Air Force experiences of Will Stockdale, the amiable Georgia plowboy, was dramatized on the United States Steel Hour over the American Broadcasting Company network.
The Hospitalized Veterans Service and its newly organized branch, Music in Hospitals, Ltd., of Great Britain, will benefit from a preview of a new British film, "Chance Meeting."

Helicopter pilots have started carrying their own heliports with them. During the hurricane season last year it was found, that the only facilities the Coast Guard's helicopters lacked to operate with complete self-sufficiency were portable landing platforms.

WASHINGTON, March 16-- Friendship International Airport, twenty-nine miles from Washington and nine miles from Baltimore, was designated today as a supplemental airport to serve the the nation's Capital.

The Thrift Shop of the Play Schools Association will benefit from a tour on April 19 of local homes that contain varied art collections. The association is devoted to the planning and supervision of the play activities of many school-age children in the city.

WASHINGTON, March 17--The impending departure from Government of Presidential Assistant Robert Cutler makes pertinent a review of the functions, activities and growth of the National Security Council. In this high advisory group (the President alone makes the decisions) are ground out the policies which could mean the survival or death of the Republic.

OTTAWA, March 17 -- Trans Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd., announced today that its negotiations with the Government for financial aid in the $350,000,000 project to bring natural gas from Alberta to the East had broken off without agreement.

Shortly before marchers began to assemble in West Forty-eighth Street for the St. Patrick's Day parade yesterday, swift-working thieves knocked out a jewelry manufacturer and escaped with $50,000 worth of gems.
PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP) --The National Football League and the Canadian leagues, recently reported close to peace in their player - raid dispute, were back at each other's throats today.

Commonwealth Edison Company and its subsidiaries achieved gains in 1954 in electric operating revenues and net income. This was achieved in spite of a decline in kilowatt hour sales and loss of operating revenues from its former gas properties, according to the annual report released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- Senate investigators of the Peress case, exploring a jungle of Army red tape, today heard that a series of blunders and an act of Congress had caused the dentist's Army promotion.

MOSCOW, March 17 -- Prime Minister Churchill's reasons for withdrawing his proposal for a meeting last summer with the Soviet Premier were denounced as "groundless" by the Soviet Foreign Ministry tonight.

EVERY fresh evidence of "fall-out" -- the spread of radioactivity after an A-bomb or H-bomb test -- starts the telephones ringing in Atomic Center, Inc., on the seventh floor at 489 Fifth Avenue. Mail picks up there and visitors come in greater numbers.

ANNE MORROW LINDBERGH, who was born a poet, aspires in moments of selfcommunion to be a saint. It was during a series of such moments that she wrote her little book of meditations called "Gift Prom the Sea." The sainthood toward which Mrs. Lindbergh aspires is not a condition of holiness. She is more modest in her ambitions.
Motorists' tolls accounted for nearly 65 per cent of the record gross revenue of the Port of New York Authority last year.
YESTERDAY (March 17, 1955) SECURITY COUNCIL Council heard report by Palestine truce chief. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council continued consideration of conditions in RuandaUrundi.

Futures prices on the New York exchanges registered irregular changes yesterday in generally dull trading. Coffee, sugar, potatoes and tin were mixed; rubber, hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and zinc eased, and cocoa, copper, wool and burlap advanced.

MEXICO CITY, March 17 (AP) --The United States track and field forces collected three more championships in the Pan-American Games today. But the Yank baseball team suffered a surprise reversal and Wes Santee, the Kansas mile king, gave a disappointing performance in the 1,500-meter run trials.
TRENTON, March 17--The year - long investigation into the governmental activities of the late Harold G. Hoffman, former Republican Governor, produced new disclosures today.
The New Jersey Turnpike Authority borrowed yesterday $34,000,000 on a bond issue to finance widening of the turnpike from four to six lanes for about sixty miles.

The logic of compulsory automobile inspection to insure mechanical safety is so self-evident that Governor Harriman's suddenly expressed doubts are incomprehensible to us. The law requires semi-annual inspection in state-licensed but privately operated stations, and every car must bear on the windshield by Sept. 1, 1955, a sticker showing wheels, brakes, steering, lights, etc., in roadworthy condition.

Housewives stocking kitchen shelves and refrigerators for week-end meals will find pork loins selling at the lowest levels for this season since 1950, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- Senatorial opposition to passage of an unamended reciprocal trade bill mounted today as the Senate Republican whip joined critics demanding major changes.

JERSEY CITY, March 17-- The president of the Jersey City Board of Education, the superintendent of schools and a high school principal were indicted tonight. They are accused of keeping on the payroll two school employes who performed no work.

ARMONK, N. Y., March 17-- Visitors to two model houses in the Windmill Farms development here may go home with some decorating tricks to try out themselves. The houses, decorated by Celia Endore and D. Phillip Spencer, will be open to the public this week-end.
Production of newsprint in the United States and Canada maintained a record-breaking pace in February.
Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers throughout the country, as gathered by The New York Times on the publication of the Yalta documents: East NEW YORK Was the Deal Necessary?

The first English translation of the letters of Alexander Sergeevich Pushkin, the Russian poet, will be published by the Indiana University Press. The first volume of the two-volume work will appear next year. The manuscript, including an introduction and commentary, is the work of J. T. Shaw of the Slavic Studies Department of Indiana University.

A 3-week-old boy was kidnapped yesterday by a young woman who induced the infant's mother to take him to St. Luke's Hospital, 440 West 114th Street. At the out-patient department of the hospital the abductor walked out with the baby.

CLEVELAND, March 17 (AP)--The president of Montgomery Ward Co. declared today that the present management would win the impending proxy battle. Having done so, he said, the same methods of operation that have always been used will be employed.

WASHINGTON, March 17--President Eisenhower indicated today that "the state of the world next spring" would have a bearing on his decision whether to seek re-election. He was asked to run again by a group of twenty Congressmen and former Congressmen who joined Feb. 22, 1952, in a letter urging him to seek the nomination originally.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 17-- Most everything came to a standstill here today. For this was the day of the annual parade that ushers into Phoenix the great rodeo of the southwest.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Despite the apparent lack of direction in the program of the U. S. I. A. abroad, as told by James Reston, there is still one field in which the agency is performing well.

WASHINGTON, March 17--A determined one-man drive for a special appropriation to aid mentally-retarded children was disclosed today. It was revealed in House of Representatives appropriations hearings made public today.
LONDON, March 17 -- The Cunard Steam Ship Company has placed an order for another 22,000-ton liner for the run from Britain to Montreal with John Brown Co., the Clydebank shipbuilders.

MIAMI, Fla., March 17 (AP)-- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, told party followers tonight that he was "going on the assumption that Dwight D. Eisenhower will be the Republican candidate for President in 1956."
WASHINGTON, March 17-- Two outspoken witnesses set the Senate Banking and Currency Committee back on its heels today during its study of the stock market.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, was urged today to move Government-owned cotton into foreign markets at competitive world prices. In a letter to the Secretary, 129 members of the House of Representatives asserted that the reduced acreage brought about by Federal control was "about to ruin the economies in many of the cotton states."
During the Senate Banking Committee hearings on the stock market, one of the most controversial subjects in financial circles --the capital gains tax--has come up for repeated discussion.
ALBANY, March 17--A special state commission recommended today that the Washington Street produce market in Manhattan be replaced by modern facilities for the wholesale marketing of food.
OTTAWA, March 17--Secretary of State Dulles arrived today and discussed common problems with Canadian Government officials.
SEVILLE, Spain, March 17 (AP) -- Pedro Cardinal Segura y Saenz, isolated in his own archbishopric, was reported today to have told intimates "not even the Civil Guards will get me out of my diocese."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 17--Yugoslavia is reintroducing the principle of work norms, a familiar appurtenance to working conditions in other Communist -led countries that had been more or less abandoned here in recent years.
Teachers questioned by the Board of Education about former affiliation with the Communist party must divulge names of party associates if so directed by the Superintendent of Schools.

Alger Hiss, whose role at the Yalta conference long has been a subject for hostile speculation, spent his time there exclusively on planning for the United Nations. He presented views opposing those of the Soviet Union on major issues.
