ST. PAUL, March 17--The National Catholic Conference on Family Life called on the American people today to accept "wholeheartedly and lovingly" the thousands of mentally retarded children in their midst.
REGINA, Sask., March 17 (AP) --The United States swept all but the pairs competition in the North American figure-skating championships which ended here last night.
Properties in Greenwich Village figured prominently in Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday.
ALBANY, March 17--The Senate approved and sent to the Assembly today a bill giving the Public Service Commission the power to regulate charges of movers in New York City.
MOLIERE has collaborated with Maurice Schwartz on "The Miser," which opened last evening at the Downtown National Theatre, Second Avenue and Houston Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 17--George Breen, a Cortland State Teachers College swimmer, won the Eastern Intercollegiate 1,500-meter free-style championship tonight. He clipped the intercollegiate record with a clocking of 19 minutes 0.4 second.
Although acting is a heritage of George M. Cohan Jr., he prefers to head his music publishing firm. Nevertheless, he is hearkening to the call of the legitimate stage, but not on a permanent basis.
David Wayne has asked to be released from his starring role on the "Norby" television show.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 17 --Salt Lake City's Jewish community has invited 8,000 music lovers of all faiths and from all parts of the state to a concert Saturday by the Utah Symphony Orchestra featuring works of contemporary American-Jewish composers.

THE New York City Opera Company opened its twelfth spring season last night at the City Center. The first of the thirty-four performances to be given was Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier," a work first brought into the company's repertory in the fall of 1949.
NEW DELHI, India, March 17 --An Indian concern has received a license to import a large number of tractors from the Soviet Union, the Ministry of Food and Agriculture reported today.
The stock market showed no definite trend yesterday until just before 3 P. M. Then investors appeared to have suddenly made up their minds that stocks were still a buy.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17--Elston Howard, the first Negro to have "made" the Yankees' roster, now appears to have "made" the team. His eighthinning double scored two runs as the Bombers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals today, 7-4.
Newspaper history was made yesterday as The New York Times printed and circulated the full official record of the Yalta Conference together with its normal budget of news and advertising.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- Harold E. Stassen made public today the dimensions of the Administration program to fight communism in Asia by means of economic aid.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 17--The Dodgers still can't win two in a row. They blew a 4-2 lead in the seventh inning today and lost to the Orioles in the tenth, 5-4.
President Ramon Magsaysay of the Philippines said last night that economic development rather than military might would determine the fate of free Asia.

Nobody has yet quite figured out the importance of Ford Motor Company, Ltd., in relation to its big American parent. But figures reported from London yesterday in a Reuters dispatch indicated that British Ford is a lusty child.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- The American Federation of Labor has stepped into the dispute stirred up by Harry Lundeberg, West Coast sailors' leader, and his plan for supplying entire crews for vessels.

GUIDO CANTELLI, conducting the concert of the Philharmonic -Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall, began with a Rossini overture that was not the overture to "Semiramide" or "La Gazza Ladra" or other chestnuts of the Rossinian repertory.

JERUSALEM, March 17--The killings of two Arab farmers by Israeli patrols were reported by the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization today. In each case Israel was absolved from blame because the farmers were inside Israeli territory.

A 33-point scoring spree by Steve Matell of Madison High. Brooklyn, was the highlight of the Public Schools Athletic League's basketball semi-finals at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Matell and his mates tripped Franklin, 56-40, after Jamaica had set back Brooklyn Tech, 60-48.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 666,548 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 7,573 cars or 1.1 per cent more than for the preceding week, 56,611 cars or 9.3 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 33,635 cars or 4.8 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

PARIS, March 17--Premier Edgar Faure won a victory in the advisory Council of the Republic today. The debate in the Council on the Paris agreements for arming West Germany were set for next Wednesday.
LONDON, March 17--The advance in stock market here slackened today. Price gains, on selective investment demand, were smaller than yesterday.
SAN LEANDRO, Calif., March 17--Sale of a home in this bayarea city to a Japanese-American dentist and war veteran has been canceled because of a death threat to the home owner.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) --The United States Food and Drug Administration has warned that fraudulent uranium "cures" were sweeping the country.

MONTE CARLO, March 17-- Thirty-six international contract bridge experts, representing ten European nations and the United States, played the first session of the second annual Monte Carlo Individual World Championships this afternoon.

MANILA, March 17 -- More than any other country in this part of the world, the Philippines is identified with the United States in the minds of the people of Asia. Therefore the young Philippine republic has become in a sense a showcase for the United States.
Safety organizations and the garage industry here united yesterday to protest Governor Harriman's reported plan to sidetrack compulsory automobile inspection.
Hearings on a plan to increase the price paid to farmers for milk were ended here yesterday.

Ohrbach's has scored another great success in its collection of import designs and exact American -made duplicates. These included a number of important models not seen in any of the other recent collections.

The real danger to the President's three-year program for a gradual and moderate liberalization of tariffs lies not in the possibility of outright defeat of the measure, but rather in the addition of ruinous restrictions, limitations and qualifications. Through such devices the high-tariff lobby could accomplish its real objectives without actually killing the bill as such.
DALLAS, March 17--The American Zionist movement was scored here tonight for what were termed its efforts to influence United States Government policy in favor of Israel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Daley is indeed correct when he says in his article in The Times of March 9: "If an athlete receives an athletic scholarship or its equivalent at a college it is impossible to consider this as anything but a capitalization on his skills.

Aneurin Bevan, the stormy, impetuous, somehow likable leader of the left wing of the British Laborites, has lost a battle--or perhaps a skirmish--with Clement R. Attlee, leader of the Parliamentary Labor party. He has been subjected to a punishment technically known as "withdrawing the whip," which means that his section of the Parliamentary Labor party will no longer be recognized by the regular Attlee Laborites.

MOSCOW, March 17 (Reuters) --Following is the text of the Soviet Government's statement on the letters exchanged between Sir Winston Churchill and Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov, followed by the letters, as issued by the Soviet Foreign Ministry:
Top-seeded Duquesne and second -seeded Dayton will meet in tomorrow night's final of college basketball's eighteenth annual National Invitation Tournament.
Loans to business by twenty leading New York City banks climbed $171,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, owing chiefly to borrowings to meet March 15 tax payments.
Repeated tearful breakdowns by Pat Ward as she was subjected to a relentless crossexamination brought an early halt to yesterday's session of the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Diplomats of the major powers expressed dismay today over the "violation of confidence" in publication of the Yalta documents by the United States.

The leasing of two and one -half floors by the National Industrial Conference Board in the new twenty - two - story office building at 460 Park Avenue was announced by Alan V. Tishman vice president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, owner - builder.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with interest your editorial of March 12 entitled "The Nomads of Somaliland."

The Cities Service Company and its subsidiaries had consolidated earnings of $60,397,240 last year, it reported yesterday. Of this sum, $43,724,163 represented net earnings and $16,673,077 profits from the sale of the last two Cities Service domestic utility interests.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 17--In the last week of the 1954 season the Dodgers promoted Karl Spooner to the varsity from Fort Worth of the Texas League. He shut out the champion Giants, striking out fifteen. Then he shut out the Pirates, striking out twelve. It was as spectacular a double-barreled debut as any rookie ever made.

After many weeks of unnecessary delay the Senate has confirmed the nomination of Judge John Marshall Harlan of New York to the Supreme Court. Nine Democrats from the deep South voted against confirmation. They were joined by two Republicans, Langer of North Dakota and Welker of Idaho.
ALBANY, March 17--A public hearing was ordered today on proposals to promote modernization of horse-race tracks. It will be held here on March 25.
WASHINGTON, March 17--An appeal for relief from overwork in her own office was made by Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby in House appropriations hearings made public today.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 10,000 head: market moderately active butchers unevenly steady to 25 cents lower: sows steady: bulk of choice 190 to 330 pound butchers. $16.25 to $16.50, including
WASHINGTON, March 17-- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $839,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
Frank D. Schroth, publisher of The Brooklyn Eagle, said yesterday that his decision to suspend publication was "irrevocable."
The Port of New York Authority awarded $4,097,753 in construction contracts yesterday. The improvements were for five of the seventeen facilities operated by the agency.

WASHINGTON, March 17-- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 11 per cent above sales in the same period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Noted for its leather goods, Mark Cross, 707 Fifth Avenue, ventures into a new field today with a gift department specializing in wood, ceramics and precious metals.

LONDON, March 17--The Government announced today that the budget would be presented to the House of Commons on April 19. This is widely interpreted as meaning that a general parliamentary election will be held in the autumn and not in the spring.

Joey Lopes, lightweight boxer from Sacramento, will oppose Carmelo Costa of Brooklyn at Madison Square Garden tonight. The bout, scheduled for ten rounds, will mark the first main event for each fighter in the Garden.
LONDON, March 17--The Soviet Union has notified British manufacturers and exporters it intends to cancel millions of dollars worth of orders placed here last year.

BONN, Germany, March 17-- The West German Government refused comment today on publication of Yalta documents by Washington. It did not wish to commit himself on the eve of the final ratification of Paris and Saar accords, scheduled tomorrow in the Bundesrat, the upper house of Parliament.
Digby Morton is beginning to feel like Janus, the ancient god with two faces. The designer leads a double life in fashion, one on either side of the Atlantic.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- The pay rise for the armed services was urged at a Senate hearing today as a means of saving money as well as strengthening the national security.
CHICAGO, March 17 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today warned the Chinese Communists in the bluntest of terms that they would be met with atomic weapons if they embarked on any new aggression.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 17 (AP) -- The co-medalists, Mary Patton Janssen and Mrs. Mae Murray Jones, survived their first-round match play tests today in the fifty-third North and South Amateur Golf tournament.

GENEVA, March 17--The pattern of oil prices in Europe is wrong, the secretariat of the United Nations' Economic Commission for Europe says in a report published here today. The report is critical of the way the major world oil companies conduct their business.
The Navy transport Gen. R. E. Callan is hard aground on Red Hook Flats in the Upper Bay about one mile from the Brooklyn shore, it was made known officially yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 17 --Turkey has invited France to join in the Turkish-Iraqi defense agreement.
LONDON, March 17--The Comet jet airliner will emerge in a new, higher-powered model as a result of the disastrous crashes that have grounded the aircraft for a year.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- The sponsor of the Communist Control Law urged today that the Justice Department act against Red tainted unions that were shopping around for snug harbors.
The Board of Education may be near a solution of the present teachers' salary controversy and the long-standing dispute over the "single-salary" schedule.
It was a question yesterday of being green with the Irish or blue with the cold. For many hundreds of thousands, it was a bit of each.
The question as to how many people listen to car radios and during what hours has reportedly been answered.

Publication of the Yalta conference record, printed yesterday in this newspaper in full, is reverberating around the world. It is producing repercussions which on first impact manifest themselves in dismay in some quarters and controversy in others. But in the long run it should have a wholesome and constructive effect on free world policies.
WASHINGTON, March 17-- How the Russians began building the Iron Curtain before the end of World War II was reported in the Yalta papers by Averell Harriman.
PARIS, March 17--Publication of the Yalta documents caused great puzzlement and some indignation in France today.
CHICAGO, March 17--Price movements were irregular on the grain market here today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17--This was ladies' day in Hollywood. They dominated the casting news about three pictures that are set for early filming.

MONTREAL, March 17--Thousands of spectators took over the Forum tonight in a frenzied demonstration against Clarence Campbell, president of the National Hockey League. They were furious over the suspension of their idol, Maurice (the Rocket) Richard.
TOKYO, March 17--Japan read with deepest Interest today of the United States and British dealings with the Soviet Union at Yalta in 1945.

LONDON, March 17--Sir Winston Churchill said today the United States version of the Yalta conference contained "serious mistakes." He told the House of Commons that Britain would consider publishing a version of her own after the entire Washington document had been read in London.
SUGGESTIONS of moods of nature and of the artist's reaction toward them are clearly to be felt in the colorful abstract paintings by Perle Fine at the Tanager Gallery, 90 East Tenth Street.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 17 (UP)--The country's leading basketball coaches were urged by Howard Hobson of Yale today to consider adopting the rules used by the professionals.

THOSE who insist upon getting their landlocked salmon fishing at the earliest possible date will have to settle for Sebago Lake in Maine. The local guides and other prophets insist the ice will go out on part of that lake in time for an April 1 opening.
ALBANY, March 17--The State Rent Administrator and Democratic legislators attempted today to build a new political backfire against the revised Republican rent control plan.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) --The Maritime Administration said today it was re-examining the question whether the St. Lawrence Seaway should be declared an essential trade route on which American ships could be subsidized against foreign competition.
Anyone prone to doubt that the baseball season is less than a month off should visit the main lobby of the New York Public Library today.
BOSTON, March 17--Daily dosages of a new synthetic hormone, in amounts small enough to fit on the head of a common pin, have been used successfully to treat Addison's disease.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- (AP)--Four organizations urged Congress today to overhaul the loyalty-security program. They said it had brought on such things as "a dragnet system * * * a chamber of horrors * * * political demagoguery."
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 17--The State Pardon Board delayed action today on a plea for clemency by a condemned Negro after Gov. Leroy Collins said that he was investigating the case.

THE Metropolitan Opera presented "Otello" last night with two new artists in principal roles. Lucine Amara sang her first Metropolitan Desdemona, and Set Svanholm, a last-minute replacement for the ailing Mario Del Monaco, made his first Metropolitan appearance as Otello.
New schedules eliminating variations in the rates charged for electricity by the Long Island Lighting Company were approved yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The tragedy of Yalta, as indicated in the official documents on the conference there, was the failure of the United States and Britain to coordinate their policies in the face of the Soviet menace.
Mrs. Elizabeth Fisher Brewster, widow of the Rev. William N. Brewster, Methodist missionary to China, died yesterday in Cincinnati. Her age was 93.
ALBANY, March 17--Governor Harriman disclosed today that he would entertain Adlai E. Stevenson at the Executive Mansion over the week-end.
Surprise support for a proposal to extend Fifth Avenue through the middle of Washington Square Park has been announced by the Washington Square Association.
Recent advances in medical science indicate that the blinding eye disease retrolental fibroplasia, which strikes children prematurely, may be eliminated entirely.

Snowman Was Here In the wastes of the Himalayas there is, or there is not, a being called the abominable snowman. Things which might, or might not, be tracks have been found, and now that Everest has been capped exploration can settle to the more important business of finding their source.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 (AP)--The Federal Court of Appeals today affirmed the 1952 conviction of fourteen California Communist leaders charged with conspiring to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the United States Government.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dipped 5 to 14 points (25 to 70 cents a bale) yesterday.

PASSAIC, N. J., March 18--A report that excessive profits were involved in lease-purchase agreements between real estate concerns and the New Jersey Division of Employment Security was attacked today. Nicholas Martini, counsel to one of the concerns, called it "unfair, incomplete and obviously political."
To continue to control or to decontrol commercial and business rents in this city was the multi-million-dollar question debated yesterday before the Temporary State Commission on Rents.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 18--With Bob Wiesler, Lou Sleater and Jim Konstanty doing the hurling, the Yankees beat the Kansas City Athletics, 6--0, at Connie Mack Field today. The shutout was the first registered by the Bombers in the Grapefruit League.

The only book published today is "The Development of American Literary Criticism," by Harry H. Clark, Richard H. Fogle, Robert P. Falk, John H. Raleigh, C. Hugh Holman, edited by Floyd Stovall (University of North Carolina, $4). It is a collection of essays.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) --The House of Representatives today voted funds to pay recently raised Congressional salaries and to start work on a new office building for House members.

Rubbish From Where? What is the source of all the rubbish which lies about the place at the end of winter? Sticks, stones and old tin cans cover the ground outside, while paperback novels, torn magazines and broken toys are everywhere within the house.

Witold Malcuzynski gave an all-Chopin recital last night in Carnegie Hall. He played for a good-sized audience and turned in steady performances that were gratifyingly free from some of the eccentricities that previously have been noted in his work.

CHICAGO, March 18 (AP)--Butchers type hogs sold unevenly steady to 25 cents higher in an active market today. Sows sold steady to strong. The $17 hog was back, although that price was paid for only a part deck. It represented a gain of 65 cents in the top price for the week. Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

WOODWARD, Okla., March 17--Panhandle areas of Oklahoma and Texas, which spawned the great dust bowl of the Nineteen Thirties, have come through the first serious winds of the 1955 season without extensive permanent damage.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development granted a loan of $54,500,000 to Australia today.
LONDON, March 18 -- The stock market demonstrated its new-found steadiness with another rise today, though closing prices were slightly below the best.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Annual fuel bills of consumers of natural gas will rise $200,000,000 to $400,000,000 eventually if present rigid Government controls on prices of the fuel are relaxed, President Eisenhower was told today.

Hearing's on studies of the Temporary Commission on the Courts reveal the outmoded processes by which justice is being administered in this state. Not the least of these findings is that "young people, children and families are not adequately dealt with in our courts, due in part *** to lack of auxiliary services."

TOKYO, March 18 (AP)--United States and Soviet delegates exchanged angry words today in a United Nations agency over trade with Red China. An Indian delegate had proposed that all Asian nations trade with the Chinese Communists.
Twelve tugs yesterday pushed the Navy transport Gen. R. E. Callan off Red Hook Flats, in the Upper Bay, where she had run aground Wednesday morning.

"RIGOLETTO" was the second performance of the New York City Opera Company's spring season last night in the City Center. Emerson Buckley, previously known as a conductor with the Fortune Gallo Opera Company, made his City Opera debut in Verdi's music-drama.
Winter, which has been pretty stingy with snow this season, turned in a shovel-worthy performance yesterday, three days before the arrival of spring.

There are many interesting aspects in Mr. Stassen's report on projected aid to Asia. Several stand out. It is not to be an "emergency" program. It is to be based on the idea of raising the gross national product in several countries over a period of years. It will not replace or displace private assistance, a conspicuous example of which is the mobilization of American help to aid recent refugees to Formosa.
Formation of a new corporation to assist independent TV stations, both U. H. F. and V. H. F., to obtain a more profitable operation was announced yesterday.

BONN, Germany, March 18--West German ratification of the Paris and Saar agreements was completed today in the Bundesrat, or upper house of Parliament. The agreements, which provide for arming West Germany and making it sovereign and set up a quasiinternational status for the Saar, were approved by the Bundestag, or lower house of parliament, Feb. 27.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- The question agitating and confusing Washington about the Yalta documents is why the State Department made them public.

MONTE CARLO, March 18-- Samuel Goudsmit of the Netherlands led a field of thirty-six invited European and United States contract bridge experts this afternoon in the second annual Monte Carlo Individual Championship.
Governor Harriman has been asked to approve a bill that would increase pilotage fees in the Port of New York by 75 cents for each foot of a ship's draft.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for an emergency $12,000,000 appropriation to develop plans for evacuation, shelters and other ways to meet a hydrogen-bomb attack.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 18-- Nationalist Premier O. K. Yui promised the Government would shield no guilty party involved in $1,000,000 timber scandal. A company manager has been accused of collusion with five Government agencies to defraud both the Chinese and United States Governments.
Fifty-eight teachers will be directed to answer under oath questions on whether they or their colleagues have Communist affiliations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 (UP)--The United States today disclaimed responsibility for a United Nations study that said the price of oil in Europe was based on oil prices in this country.

Through the efforts of our three great religious faiths hundreds of millions of pounds of food, clothing, medicines and other supplies will go this year to victims of War, flood, famine and disaster in all parts of the free world. Protestants, Catholics and Jews currently are engaged in their annual appeals for funds with which to support the worldwide projects of their overseas relief organizations.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Roosevelt ignored or was unaware of a United States Navy request for a base in the Kurile Islands when he decided that the Soviet Union should get that island group to persuade Russia to fight Japan.
PARIS, March 18--New obstacles loomed today in the way of the Government's plan for rapid ratification of the agreements to make West Germany an armed ally of the West.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: To argue, as does Judge Jacob Panken, that to require ex-Communists to divulge the activities and identity of former cellmates in the Communist conspiracy is un-American and anti-American, is to maintain that the ordinary rules of law and morality do not apply to Communists or former Communists.
The Brooklyn Eagle was informally put up for sale yesterday.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 18 --The Giants and the Indians brought their traveling world series circus here today. Before a gathering of 10,752 fans the pair proceeded to spray the terrain with twenty-nine hits.

THE writing career of Millen Brand to date is spanned by four novels, the first of which, "The Outward Room" was published in April, 1937, and the fourth, "Some Love, Some Hunger,"* was issued this week. It is almost eight years since "Albert Sears" came out. Before that, in April, 1939, there was "The Heroes."
KANSAS CITY, March 18 (AP) --La Salle, in control most of the way, defeated Iowa, 76--73, in the semi-final round of the National Collgiate basketball tournament tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent discussion created by the arrival of the Berlin Symphony Orchestra emphasizes an interesting feature of the Immigration and Nationality Act which is sometimes overlooked.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- President Eisenhower will present prize photography awards to members of the White House News Photographers Association tomorrow night, then receive one himself.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- The executive board of the International Longshoremen's Association elected Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia a vice president today.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- The Voice of America, in its broadcasts overseas, is straddling on the question whether the Yalta decisions were wise or unwise.

There will be around-the-clock basketball activity at Madison Square Garden today. The schedule calls for two schoolboy games in the morning, a professional game in the afternoon and a pair of college games at night.
"Why, they'd pay a buck a head just to watch him go fishin'."
TOKYO, March 18--Japan's newly elected House of Representatives picked Ichiro Hatoyama tonight to succeed himself as Premier.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Women's City Club of New York has for many years been concerned with the problem of overlapping jurisdiction, delays and lack of any centralized administration in the courts of New York as highlighted by the excellent editorial in The New York Times of March 16.
OTTAWA, March 18--A formula for avoiding a shooting war in the Far East was advanced today by Secretary of State Dulles.
Decorating a new home is a thrilling challenge even to the busiest of career women, Lily Pons declared in a recent interview here.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 18 (UP)--The captain of the Finnish tanker Aruba rejected today demands of his crew that the ship enter a neutral port in Ceylon.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) --The State Department has prepared galley proofs of the first of another explosive series of documents designed to repudiate the Truman Administration's famous White Paper on China, it was disclosed today.
Intimate secrets in the life of Pat Ward were raked over by George Washington Herz yesterday as he sought to discredit her testimony in the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke.
DETROIT, March 18 -- New records in automobile production were in the making this week.
OTTAWA, March 18--Secretary of State Dulles today defended the State Department's release of the Yalta documents for publication.
THE southern fishing circuit seems to be reaching a peak now that spring is just around the corner. The angling hot spots range from Peru to the Bahamas.

MEXICO CITY, March 18 (AP) --Louis Jones of New York won the Pan - American 400 - meters championship run today. In doing so he clipped four-tenths of a second from the world record. His time was 45.4 seconds. As he finished the race he collapsed.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 18 --The Dodgers were involved in a deal with the Baltimore Orioles today. They sent the experienced Erv Palica to the American League team and what they got in return brought an interesting development.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Following are State Department documents taken from "The Conference at Malta and Yalta, 1945."

The suburban commuter who thinks his chief worries concern catching his train may be ignoring another potential problem--the effect of suburban living on family life. A conference of educators and students was told yesterday that family life in Suburbia might present "cause for concern."
WASHINGTON, March 18-- An Administration official took issue today with the President and his Attorney General and called for a thorough overhaul of the Government's employe security program.

A group of college presidents gave Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, a few potentially difficult moments yesterday during a question-and-answer period of international affairs.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 18--Thirty-two Vietnamese have been arrested in northeastern Thailand for allegedly having crossed the Laotian frontier illegally and having attempted to subvert Vietnamese refugees in Thailand.
DACCA, Pakistan, March 18 -- The Central Government decided today to relinquish direct control of East Pakistan to the popular Opposition leader whom it branded a traitor ten months ago.

FRANKFURT, Germany, March 18 (AP)--The United States High Commissioner's court dismissed today security violation charges against Michael R. Rothkrug of Westport, Conn., former intelligence official in Berlin.

MONTREAL, March 18 (AP) Riot-torn Montreal cooled off today. Merchants counted damage running into thousands of dollars. The destruction followed a riot by fans at the hockey game between the Montreal Canadiens and the Detroit Red Wings last night
A thief gave a penthouse occupant a bloody nose and a black eye yesterday and then brought the victim an ulcer pill and a glass of water.
MONTPELIER, Vt., March 18 -- The state of New York received an official request from neighboring Vermont today to tighten restrictions on teen-age drinking.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 --A $21,000,000 addition to the teaching and application of health education was dedicated today on the San Francisco campus of the University of California.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) --Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey announced today the Treasury will borrow $3,000,000,000 next week against its June tax collections.
CHICAGO, March 18--A vigorous selling drive in soybeans helped unsettle the grain futures market today. The whole list was weak except for March wheat, which was relatively steady.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) --The United States Chamber of Commerce elected A. Boyd Campbell of Jackson, Miss., today as its president.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18--The United Nations organization is reported to be pressing Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist Premier, for action on the eleven United States airmen still held captive by Peiping.

Trading on commodity futures on the New York exchanges yesterday was dull and featureless. Only the vegetable oils and potatoes had sizable volume. The activity was limited largely to evening of holdings for the week-end.
Women short in stature, or on cash, or both, will like S. Klein's spring collection of coats and suits.
SEOUL, Korea, March 18-- President Syngman Rhee scornfully rejected today recent Communist overtures for a conference on unification of Korea.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 18 -- A wide - ranging program embracing all aspects of the American economy to emphasize distribution as the heart of prosperity and national well-being was put before the Association of National Advertisers today.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 18--No matter how we prefer to describe United States policy toward Communist China, it is now plainly limited to "containment" rather than "liberation." Only within this context can one view the question of the coastal islands still remaining in Chiang Kai-shek's hands.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Republican partisanship has virtually wrecked the inquiry into the stock market, Senator J. William Fulbright said today.

YESTERDAY (March 18, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Met with Cabinet. Left White House for overnight stay at Gettysburg farm. THE SENATE Confirmed by voice vote nomination of Joseph Campbell to be Controller General.
The completed organ at Riverside Church will be dedicated at 11 A. M. tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- "Lysistrata," a comedy that is more than twenty-four centuries old, got out of a post office safe today.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- The downtrend in net earnings of small manufacturing corporations since 1950 appears to have halted, the Small Business Administration told Congress today.

POTENTIAL travelers in Spain, with memories of "Carmen" and Hemingway to warm their blood, will be stirred by the attractive exhibition. "Los Toros"--paintings, drawing and memorabilia of the bull-fight--at the Karnig Gallery, 19 1/2 East Sixtysecond Street.

VALPARAISO, Chile, March 18 (AP)--Rescue was reported near today for the remaining 100 passengers on a Chilean vacation cruise vessel that went on the rocks in the Strait of Magellan off South America Tuesday with 200 aboard.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- Joseph Campbell of New York was confirmed by the Senate today as Controller General of the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18--United Artists is one major film company that has no objection to its producer-associates purchasing successful television properties as the basis for motion picture productions. Executives of the distributing corporation, who are holding discussions here with Western division branch managers on sales campaigns for forthcoming releases, reportedly will suggest to Henry Fonda that his first production for the company be based on the Emmett Kelly autobiography, "The Clown."

William J. Keating yesterday pleaded the same privilege of anonymity for his sources of information on wiretapping as that legally accorded client and lawyer or penitent and priest. His plea was in answer to a citation for contempt for his refusal to identify his sources.

MEXICO CITY, March 18 (AP) -- Tomorow's schedule in the Pan-American Games follows, with the names of the United States entrants in parentheses (New York Time) : TRACK AND FIELD 10:30 A. M.--Decathlon: 110-meter hurdles, discus, pole vault (Ernest Shelton, Robert Richards, Rafer Johnson).
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 18--Smashing two records en route, John Glover of Dartmouth won the Eastern Intercollegiate 50-yard free-style swim crown today.
LONDON, March 18 -- The British Government has rejected a United States suggestion that tho secret minutes of the 1945 Potsdam conference be published, authoritative sources said tonight.
The General Dynamics Corporation last year had consolidated net earnings of $20,795,472, according to the annual report issued for publication today.

In discussing our defense plans in Southeast Asia the Australian Prime Minister, Robert Gordon Menzies, has given us a felicitous and significant phrase. There are differences of opinion as to strategy and tactics, he said, but he went on to declare that these were "but specks on the surface of the deep stream of unity in our relation."
WASHINGTON, March 18-- Harsh partisan debate over the Yalta conference broke out in the Senate today.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., March 18 (AP)--The Rochester Royals squared their national basketball association Western Division play-off series with the Minneapolis Lakers tonight by winning a nip-and-tuck affair, 94--92.

DETROIT, March 18--Improved prospects for the StudebakerPackard Corporation were forecast today in the company's report for 1954. Although the corporation had a net loss of $26,178,315 in the year, James J. Nance, president, said substantial progress had been made toward consolidating the two organizations.
WASHINGTON, March 18-- Senator Harry F. Byrd delivered today what many legislators considered a jolting blow to the Eisenhower Administration's highway-building plan.
PARIS, Saturday, March 19-- Premier Edgar Faure avoided today an overthrow of his Cabinet threatened by the action of rate French taxpayers.
ST. PAUL, March 18--The National Catholic Conference on Family Life warned today against the "growing disintegration" of the home and a "constantly mounting secularist mentality.

WASHINGTON, March 18--An ice cube that cools drinks fast was patented this week by Caryl M. Ashley for the Carrier Corporation, Syracuse, N. Y. "The problem confronting both homemakers and bartenders has been to be able to cool a glass of beverage quickly," Mr. Ashley told the Patent Office in his application.
The stock market did little more than mark time yesterday.
Hope that a campaign against construction of the Narrows Bridge would be successful for at least a year was voiced yesterday by officials of the Save Bay Ridge Committee.
Geoffrey W. T. Atkins, holder of the British, American and Canadian titles, reached the semifinals of the amateur racquets championship of the United States yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 18 --Efforts are continuing here to arrange a political settlement of the differences between Premier Ngo Dinh Diem and opposition politico-religious groups.
HACKENSACK, N. J., March 18--On recommendation of Attorney General Grover C. Richman, Superior Court Judge J. Wallace Leyden here today dismissed forty-one indictments against thirty-one persons.
"Hey, lady. I've got fresh green peppers for 10 cents a pound! How about it ?"
GLEN COVE, L. I., March 18 --Two children, hunting for a coin tonight with a lighted match in a darkened apartment, set off a flash fire that killed three men. Four persons were injured.
ST. PAUL, March 18--The National Catholic Conference on Family Life warned today against the "growing disintegration" of the home and a "constantly mounting secularist mentality.

"The problem confronting both homemakers and bartenders has been to be able to cool a glass of beverage quickly," Mr. Ashley told the Patent Office in his application.

NEWARK, March 18--Federal Judge William F. Smith signed a show-cause order today under which the Interstate Commerce Commission will be asked to prolong the life of the Christopher Street ferry until its fate is decided by a special court.

The fifty-seven-family apartment house at 2240-42 Tiebout Avenue in the Bronx has been purchased by Sarana Estates, Inc., headed by Anna Goldstein, from the One Four Nine Holding Corporation, headed by Jack Rubin.
Cotton futures lost 7 to 24 points (35 cents to $1.20 a bale) in trading here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 18--Charles P. Taft described opponents of the reciprocal trade program as "professional pessimists" today. In so doing he touched off the bitterest wrangle in a month of Senate Finance Committee hearings on H. R. 1.
DALLAS, March 18--The American Council for Judaism reported here today that it had made marked progress toward the establishment of a philanthropic organization.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) --The Senate today voted $1,020,679 for investigations in the coming year, but only after running into an economy buzzsaw in the form of Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana.
CHICAGO, March 18--Members of the National Council of Presbyterian Men were urged today to read the daily newspapers as diligently as their Bibles.
MUNSEY PARK, L. I., March 18--Nassau County's pants burglar believes in striking while his victims are hot--under the collar. He did just that early yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) --Farmers plan to continue large acreages of crops this year --especially feed grains--despite Government attempts to curtail harvests.
Harold Riegelman, vice president of the National Committee on Alcoholism, will direct a $262,000 campaign to establish the city's first alcoholic information center.

Dr. Kalman Apfel and Morton Rubinow, both of the Bronx, won the men's pair championship last night from a field of eightytwo pairs of bridge experts. This was the opening event of the ten-day Eastern States Bridge Championships.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) --Officials of Americans for Democratic Action today attacked the Administration's foreign policy as placing too much emphasis on "military might."
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 (UP)--Jay Hebert of Woodmere, L. I. gained a threestroke lead at the halfway mark in $12,500 St. Petersburg open golf tournament today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 18 (AP)--Union spokesmen and officials of the struck Louisville and Nashville Railroad sat down with President Eisenhower's chief mediator today in an effort to end the walkout on the line's fourteen-state system.
Carmelo Costa of Brooklyn outpointed Joey Lopes of Sacramento, Calif., in the ten-round main bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

A shipper's organization has confirmed that there is an upward trend in orders for railroad cars. This had been indicated Thursday by the American Railway Car Institute's report that 2,422 cars were ordered in February, or 414 more than in 1954.

STOWE, Vt., March 18--Two skiers, each popularly known as Andy, shared the slalom honors as the second annual American International ski races began on Mount Mansfield today. They were Andreas Molterer of Austria and Mrs. Andrea Mead Lawrence of Parshall, Colo.

The public market for new capital is continuing moderately active. The calendar of corporate bond and preferred stock issues for which marketing dates have been set total $425,300,000, according to the Investment Dealers Digest.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- Maj. Irving Peress' chief at Camp Kilmer, N. J., testified today he had kept close watch on the controversial Army dentist but never had found anything subversive in his activities.
A $300,000 libel and damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court against officers of the American Guild of Variety. Artists and the Associated Actors and Artistes of America.

Between Feb. 15 and March 15 on the New York Stock Exchange aggregate short interest --the borrowed stocks sold in expectation of replacing them at a lower figure--declined to the lowest level since March 15, 1954.

The principal architects of labor unity are getting more unity than they like. After twenty years of wondering how to get together, the high command of organized labor finds itself embarrassed by some unwelcome hitch-hikers on the unity bandwagon.
WASHINGTON, March 18--A subcommittee of the House of Representatives agreed tentatively today to tone down the Administration's military reserve program.

An investing client of Samuel Davidson has purchased the apartment house at 902 Fortyfourth Street, corner of Ninth Avenue, in Brooklyn, from the G. S. W. Realty Corporation. The buyer, who insured title with the Kings County Capital Corporation, paid cash over mortgages amounting to $157,000.

WASHINGTON, March 18-- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended March 15, 1955 to 110 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Slight reductions in average prices of farm products and processed food accounted for the decrease.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 18 Approval of a direct power exchange set up between the Bonneville Power Administration and the Idaho Power Company was hailed here today.
RICKETY chairs are one of the minor curses of contemporary civilization. The culprit in this case is central heating. Constant warm, dry air shrinks wood joints and loosens the most tenacious glue.

THE New York City Ballet closed its recent season with a favorable balance both artistically and financially, and everybody should be feeling pretty pleased about it. Its four-week intake totaled $175,000, and its activity for the year 1954-55 left it with four new ballets by George Balanchine, all paid for, and a small bit of cash in the bank.

NEW DELHI, India, March 19 --Indian Communist leaders are holding a series of secret meetings that will determine future strategy of the Communist party in the country.
OAKVILLE, Ont., March 19 (AP)--Mrs. Authur Timleck, mother of eighteen children, died today at the age of 57.
LOS ANGELES, March 19-- The world champion Giant showed a gathering of 17,893 today how they win with Willie Mays.

BANGKOK, Thailand--Despite the cold war tensions enveloping Southeast Asia, this charming, shambling metropolis of gilded Buddhist temples and burgeoning new streets and buildings remains as attractive and as accessible as ever to the traveler.

TEACHERS GUILD--Award The John Dewey Award for outstanding contribution to education, sponsored by the New York Teachers Guild, has been given to Profs. John L. Childs and George S. Counts of Teachers College, Columbia University. They were cited for their "inspirational teaching at Columbia University which brought courage, responsibility and understanding of education's role in a free society to the teachers in your classes."

BONN, Germany, March 17-- The German Supreme Court ruled recently that the Government was not obligated to be truthful in information given to the press. This has been protested in the official organ of the German Press Association.
GUATEMALA, March 15-- The Government is thinking of wiping out the remnants of the agrarian reform of former President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman.

COLOGNE, Germany, March 19 (Reuters)--Herr Kleiber came here several days ago with his United States - born wife Ruth. She said tonight she and her husband must begin "another phase in our vagabond life from one hotel to another."
WHILE it had been said that gardening and the royal and ancient game of golf are not compatible, at least one form of the latter, the putting green, is frequently installed on home grounds.
Opponents of a bill that would put certain types of inland waterway bulk cargo under Government regulation have mobilized to defeat the measure.
WASHINGTON, March 19--A fifteen-year-old dispute in the Crazy Mountains of Montana accented a national forest problem of growing magnitude this week.

VIENNA, March 19--Austria will ask the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for aid in developing her hydroelectric resources. Her appeal for the greater part of the $100,000,000 required will be supported by West Germany, France and Italy, which would share in the power produced.
State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits stressed last night the immediate need of an emergency program for juvenile delinquency.

LONDON, March 19 (Reuters) --Results of today's British soccer and rugby games: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division Aston Villa 3. West Bromwich Albion O, Blackpool 2. Leicester City 0. Bolton Wanderers 0. Cardiff City 0 (draw).

A ONE-MAN exhibition of sixty dye transfer color prints of bird and nature subjects by Eliot F. Porter will go on display tomorrow evening at Limelight Photo Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, where it will hang through April 17.

MIAMI, Fla., March 19 (AP)-- Irra Pettina, Metropolitan Opera soprano and Broadway musical star, flew here from New York today to be with her husband, who was badly burned in a fire.

WASHINGTON--For the first time in my life, I have been traveling extensively through the eastern portion of the United States. Most of this travel has been by train, some by automobile. It has taken me into most of the states between the Great Lakes and Manhattan Island.

Long Island builders are displaying models today to mark the formal opening of new housing colonies. Most of the developers are favoring the split-level design although some are offering houses in ranch and Cape Cod styles.

THE bulbs which flower in summer are a motley group and three of the most exotic are achimenes, gloxinias and tuberousrooted begonias. These three merit attention for their novelty and their beauty of flower form and brilliant color plus decorative foliage.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 19 (Reuters)--The crew of the Finish tanker Aruba today decided to sail the ship to the Indian Ocean between Malaya and Ceylon and then await further orders. The tanker is bound for Communist China with a cargo of jet plane fuel.

TORONTO, March 19 (UP)-- The Toronto Maple Leafs clinched third place in the National Hockey League tonight. They blanked the Chicago Black Hawks, 5--0, before 12,826 fans.

NANCY HALLINAN'S "Rough Winds of May" brings us far more than the usual stormy weather of adolescence. Celia Kerr whose pangs of growing up stretch to 425 intense pages, is an English Junior Miss in a nightmare.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 19--A long-range program to meet Florida's expanding college enrollment has been submitted to state government officials.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- The fate of statehood for Hawaii and Alaska in the present session of Congress apparently turns on the wishes of President Eisenhower.

The atom and hydrogen bombs have virtually outdated the philosophy that "it's right to do what is expedient," Charles Henry Mahoney of the United States delegation to the United Nations said last night.
PARIS, March 19--Monsieur Pierre Poujade was angry today. This is important news because he is one of the most influential men in France at the moment.

NEW YORK'S Manhattan, Boston's Beacon Hill and the downtown sections of Philadelphia, Chicago, Detroit and Cleveland all have city gardens with the same basic problems--lack of sunlight, poor soil and polluted air.
The Commerce and Industry Association has recommended revision of the Condon-Wadlin Act outlawing strikes by public employes in the state.

A mile and a half of exhibits, representing the major portion of the world's recent progress in radio and electronics, will be opened tomorrow morning at Kingsbridge Armory and Kingsbridge Palace, the Bronx.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 19-- Nassau County will seek legislative approval next week of a bill to modernize the county's planning for future growth and development.

A WORRISOME modern phenomenon is the fast-growing intelligence of modern machines. Both big and little computers are getting horribly clever. They design the wings of airplanes, play execllent checkers and hatch hydrogen bombs.
New York affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations mobilized yesterday to win Congressional approval of a Federal minimum wage of $1.25 an hour.
TRENTON, March 19--A highlevel struggle is being waged for control of the Republican party in New Jersey. It has extended to Washington, and evidences of the all-out contest are increasing daily.

A regional shopping center is planned for a twenty-four-acre site at Vails Gate in the town of New Windsor, N. Y. The development, to be known as the Gateway, will be on Route 32, about three miles south of Newburgh.

HOWEVER accustomed we try to be to the ComptonBurnett techniques, each new novel is a fresh shock treatment --individual, complete and stunning. In every corner of the eternal English country house which is Miss Compton-Burnett's painted backdrop, lurks some deadly truth.

SINCE their inauguration in 1953 the Allabout Books have won an enthusiastic audience among fact-hungry young people. They appeal to the reader who has passed the science primer stage yet who wants an easy access into the world of science.

MOSCOW, March 19--Prime Minister Churchill, who so often has been represented in the United States as being overeager for a meeting with the Russians, is being represented here, as the man who never wanted such a meeting at all.

THE American Broadcasting Company has staked another television claim in Hollywood's movie industry. Out of Hollywood came A. B. C.'s biggest new show this season, "Disneyland," and from there will come another major production next autumn to be produced by Warner Brothers Pictures.

HAVING brought the sights, smells and creeping dangers of the jungle to thousands of armchair tiger hunters through "The Man-Easters of Kumaon." Jim Corbett will greatly enlarge his audience with "The Temple Tiger" and what might be termed more of the same.
BOSTON, March 19--Ninetyyears ago this month a group of Bostonians undertook to rehabilitate children left homeless and destitute by the Civil War.

THE! Time Machine stopped and I stepped out through a rolling mist and stood listening. Silence. That total suspension of sound, that silence felt by people who travel up the sky in a balloon. The world gone, the- clamor of the world gone with it. Only a soft breathing in the ropes of the balloon as you follow along where the-wind wants to go.
PINEHURST, N. C., March 19 (AP)--Barbara Romack, Wiffi Smith, Pat Lesser and Mary Ann Downey won their quarter-final round matches today in the North and South amateur golf tournament.

OUTDOOR relaxation has different meanings in different sections of the country. To some people it is simply sitting on a screened porch, to others it may mean lounging on a paved terrace. But the amount of use any such area will get depends mainly on its location.

A Fifty-seventh Street druggist, a night watchman in Pearl River, N. Y., and a Czech refugee physician have won a new friend for the United States behind the Iron Curtain--and perhaps have saved a life.

Small bush fruits might be tucked onto a small property where the larger tree kinds won't fit. The smaller plants do require careful pruning, fertilizing and good cultural practices through the year to assure a rich and bountiful harvest.

HAVING successfully overcome the desire for more than one performance of certain recorded works-- at least temporarily--I envisioned easy sledding ahead in building my LP record library. However, since my visits to record shops are becoming a little more frequent, and gifts from LP-minded relatives are increasing the number of albums on hand, I find that selection of new additions, as well as the proper library arrangement, are giving me considerable mental and physical exercise.

Once Over LINES from some backyards-- Deflation Division: From Vernon Duke's forthcoming "Passport to Paris": A French critic, beholding Mr. Duke come out on the concert stage in Oxford bags, criticized. "His music was barely visible behind his sumptuous trousers."
Dr. Josephine Bicknell Neal, distinguished for her research work on poliomyelitis, meningitis and encephalitis, died yesterday in New York Infirmary. Her age was 74.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 --Governors of the State Bar of California rejected today a proposed law to disbar lawyers taking refuge in the Fifth Amendment.

Persons prominent in society and business will be in the cast of "Utopia, Ltd.," a Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, which will be given from April 13 through April 16 in the Hunter College Playhouse. The performances will be given by the amateur Savoyards of the Blue Hill Troupe as a benefit for the Legal Aid Society.

FOR the first time since the long-playing revolution of 1948-49 the engineering phase of the record business has just about caught up with itself. During the coming year, say recording engineers, nothing spectacular is likely in their field.
General Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, said last night that the present risk of war could not be diminished by sacrificing American principles to complacency.

SOME ambitious do-it-yourself projects are shelved because necessary power equipment is too expensive ito own; needed repairs around the house are often postponed because they will take too long with hand tools.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., March 19--Potato dealers and growers in eastern Long Island are perturbed over the possibility that the National Labor Relations Board may rule their laborers "food processors."
BERKELEY, Calif., March 19 -- Some 200 conservationists from all parts of the United States ended a two-day session today, hopeful they would find ways to preserve the wilderness areas.

THE advent of spring has many signs. It may be the first robin, a pussy willow in bloom here and there or a yellow cloud of forsythia on a far-off hill. Sometimes it might be a colorful throw rug of crocus or snowdrops cast upon a lawn or tucked under a shade tree.
The Jamaica High basketball team captured its first city Public Schools Athletic League championship at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
OF course it is a pity that so much of all creative work is so closely related to the personality of the one who does it.

New commercial space is in good demand in Manhattan. The latest record in rental activity has been established at the Amoco Building at 555 Fifth Avenue. About a week ago, renting of store and office space was completed in the new skyscraper at 99 Park Avenue.

The assets of the life insurance companies in the United States make up the greatest single pool of capital savings in the world. As a source of investment money, this pool is largely a closed affair, however, easily tapped by borrowers from the United States and Canada, but virtually inaccessible to the rest of the world.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) --The Federal Communications Commission proposed today that Congress authorize it to conduct a sweeping study of the entire broadcasting and telecasting industry.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 --City officials have cast Representative Clair Engle, California Democrat, in the role of an arch villain plotting to grab a part of San Francisco's water supply.

FIVE of the world's leading travel organizations have enthusiastically welcomed the recent United States proposal that the United Nations seek ways of promoting tourism. At Washington's suggestion, delegates from eighteen countries will take up the matter at meetings opening here March 29.

ELSEWHERE in these columns is a report on the Do-It-Yourself Show that opens hero tomorrow, and that report stresses the trend toward making it easier for householders to tackle the projects that are dear to their hearts.

A NUMBER of spring and summer courses to be held in New York and other sections of the country were announced last week. Subjects covered include color portraiture and movies as well as instruction for beginners.

A doctors' center is planned for Smithtown, L. I., by a group of physicians who will occupy office space in the building. The site is at the corner of Lawrence and Percy Avenues, about a block south of Main Street.

IN the past half-dozen years, conservatism, so long the despised poor relation in American political thought, has seemed at last to have come into its own. Where once the demigods of liberalism held sway, now one hears excited talk of Burke, Calhoun, Disraeli and Viereck.
GARDEN CITY, Kan., March 19--Nearly 6,000,000 acres in southwestern Kansas have been baked powder dry in recent weeks and windstorms have begun to blow away the soil.
DANBURY, Conn., March 19 --Here's a man who says he can tap any telephone that has not been equipped with his own patented cable insuring immunity.

A LIGHT little number for all its deep-quilted padding, "A Room in Paris" is not without a certain two-dimensional charm. At the start, one is genuinely concerned with the soul-searching, and the reluctant maturing, of art-student Stanley Kagen, comfortably squirreled away on the Left Bank with his "winter girl."
"THE First Symphony of Brahms is mathematical music evolved with difficulty from an unimaginative brain." (The Boston Gazette, Jan. 24, 1878.)

In the garden as in the house the right accessories serve to enhance basic individuality and charm. Appropriate to their setting and used in moderation, ofcourse, such accessories become as much a part of the garden as its flowers and trees, birds and bees.

THE whole of "A Train of Powder" is about trials. Or, to put it more precisely, each of the pieces in Rebecca West's newest book finds its occasion in a moment when moral society calls immoral man to account for some grievous infringement of its laws.

BERLIN, March 19--On the ground that the Communists, like the Nazis, inject propaganda into art, Erich Kleiber has resigned as musical director of the Berlin State Opera. He and his family have fled to West Germany.

The theme of National Wildlife Week, which begins today, is "Save America's Wetlands." Many people may wonder what wetlands-- marshes, swamps, sloughs, bayous, etc.--have to do with any form of wildlife other than mosquitos. They may wonder what better use could be made of wetlands than to drain them.

The big spring buying season for agricultural chemicals is getting under way across the land. And so many products are being offered to the farmer to help him grow crops, fatten animals and kill bugs that choosing the right chemicals to fill his needs is becoming one of his problems.

Eighteenth century Philadelphia furniture will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at a sale that also will include American and English cabinetwork, clocks, silver, paintings, Chinese export porcelain and porcelain once in use in the White House.

Yale was leading Harvard by five matches to four yester at the end of the first day of play in the second annual intercollegiate invitation court tennis tournament. Princeton, with only one victory, was out of the running for the James H. Van Alen Trophy in the round robin competition.

THE book digest idea has reached the photography field in a new British publication which, however, is only a compilation rather than the group of book condensations the title leads one to expect. For Philip Johnson's "Photo Digest No. 1" (London: Fountain Press; Philadelphia: Rayelle. $1.95), which suggests the start of a series, is merely a collection of selected chapters from eight current English books.

TO THE EDITOR: THE review by J. A. M. Meerloo of Joseph Wortis' "Fragments of an Analysis of Freud" contains the statement: "What Freud did not even know was that -- against every analytic rule--each session was written down immediately afterward."

THE R. T. Bozak Company offers a new speaker enclosure designed for use with the Bozak B-207A Coaxial Speaker. This speaker is composed of a Bozak B-199A Woofer with a coaxially mounted Bozak B-200X Dual Tweeter.

A FORTHCOMING R. C. A. Victor release, "Poet's Gold," will feature Carl Sandburg reading his own poems and singing folksongs from all parts of the country. Also heard will be the voices of Helen Hayes, Raymond Massey and Thomas Mitchell, reading the "Rubaiyat," "The Rime of the Ancient Mariner," "The Children's Hour," and other works.

TOKYO, March 19--Premier Ichiro Hatoyama said today he would send a special envoy soon to the United States to explain Japanese policy and to calm fears over his determination to promote better relations with Communist countries.

Only victory brought smiles yesterday to competitors in the fifth annual figure and speedskating contest at the Wollman Memorial Ice Skating Rink in Central Park. And happiest of all was Barbara Roberts, who won medals in two categories.
Pleasure - boating's spotlight will be focused on Long Island this week, particularly on the fifteen units of the United State Power Squadrons comprising the Third District.

THERE is hope, brethren. So long as there is at least one firm common ground, there is hope that West and East will meet. Could there be any more solid basis for understanding than the discovery that the troubles with tenors are the same the world over ?

THE exhibition of prints and drawings by Albrecht Duerer at the Morgan Library contains such a wealth of treasures that it would be welcome at any time, but is especially so now. This has been a particularly dry season for old master exhibitions and the present show, illuminating intelligently the artist's personality, is an exemplary occasion for recalling to the present the greatness of the past.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York is "strenuously opposed" to the Neely Amendment to H. R. 1, which is a reciprocal trade bill, William F. Giesen, general manager and counsel of the organization, said yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 19--Cornell's track team beat Yale, 60 1/2 to 48 1/2 at Coxe Cage today. Yale had been unbeaten in dual and triangular meet competition, but had bowed to the Big Red in the Heptagonal Games.

THE eleven penguins that were brought up from the Antarctic by the Atka and flown from Buenos Aires to Washington's National Zoological Park last week are typical of the only greeters in an otherwise inhospitable land.

BROWSING through audio shops today can quickly induce the illusion that it is always two weeks before Christmas. The abundance on the shelves comes in large part from a "rounding out" of equipment lines on the part of old and new concerns.

PASSING of the vernal equinox early tomorrow morning means the beginning of a season when millions of people prepare to spend their leisure time in the great outdoors. Scientifically, this annual movement of the equinox--occurring at 4:36 A. M., E. S. T.--is purely an astronomical transition by the sun and earth denoting the first day of spring.

TURF grass makes an ideal playing surface for many games. And, what is more, a variety of outdoor sports can be played on even comparatively small home lawns since the areas can be superimposed one upon the other as season and inclination dictate.

"LOOKING at things that belong in history books" and lodging in a modest trailer was not Lucinda Weiler's idea of vacation travel--especially since the discovery of coal on their Ohio farm meant money to spare for luxuries.

A search is now under way for twenty-five students in the nation's engineering schools who show the highest talent and promise in science and engineering. This "cream of the crop" is wanted for an experiment to be conducted this summer at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.
The New York State Thruway is facing major construction problems on the last miles going southwest from Buffalo to the state line terminus and northwest to Niagara Falls.
A New Haven polo team won the Al Parsells Memorial tournament at the Squadron A. Armory last night.

WHEN Victor reduced its prices last January, forcing a general reduction by nearly all other record companies, certain results were anticipated. Among those anticipated results were a stabilization of prices, a reduction in discount-house operations and a tremendous increase in record sales.

In an annual revival of classical traditions, the Barnard College gymnasium will ring with shouts of Nike (Greek for "victory") as freshmen and sophomores compete in the 53rd Greek Games next Saturday.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- Congress again next week begins grappling with the controversial problem of Federal regulation of natural gas prices.

Outstanding secondary school students may obtain college credits under a new plan adopted by Yale University. It will allow exceptional students to obtain degrees in less than the standard four years of college work.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 19--Westchester's first big county-wide music festival in seventeen years will be held April 19.

Fourteen world authorities on such varied subjects as atomic and hydrogen bombs, guided missiles, electronics, mathematics, aerodynamics and astrophysics have been engaged as consultants by the Convair Division of General Dynamics Corporation.

TRENTON--Gov. Robert B. Meyner proposed last week the rehabilitation and improvement of 84,000 acres of state parks and forests that have been long neglected. At the same time he asked that New Jersey, for the first time in its history, provide the public with a state-owned and developed beach on its fine Atlantic coast.

BELGRADE, March 19-- Yugoslavia this week accepted the Soviet bid to let bygones be bygones. After the spat in which Marshal Tito called Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov a liar the trend toward friendlier relations was endorsed on both sides.

THE opening of the Mesabi iron range, that richest of three great wounds in the side of northeast Minnesota, is the background for Sarah Lockwood's interesting and often exciting novel. Her chief actor is one Steve Bradway, a lumberjack turned tycoon, who allegedly, does the discovering and developing in these pages.

WHEN I joined the Metropolitan Opera in 1935, my first impression of the dress rehearsal of "Aida" (a stunning musical performance with the divine Rethberg) was rather disappointing from the scenic angle.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- President Eisenhower today created a new post of Special Assistant on disarmament problems. He gave the position Cabinet rank and designated Harold E. Stassen to fill it.

ALMOST before the ink had a chance to dry on this column's report last Sunday, Nicholas M. Schenck president of Loew's Inc., announced a decision in regard to the company's studio, MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, that let loose a floodtide of speculation in Hollywood.
WHY do people collect records? Seems like a silly question. They don't buy them to fill bookshelves. Books are thicker, have prettier bindings and make a more variegated show.

ESTABLISHED grasses resume growth with the first favorable days of late winter, and by the first day of spring many species, especially Kentucky and Merion bluegrass, may be a vivid green. In the depleted soils of the New York area, nature alone cannot supply all the impetus to start lawns off to a successful season.
ONLY my admiration for Mr. Crowther's high standard of criticism permits me to indulge in an opinion contrary to his review of "East of Eden."
EVEN in these days of 2,4-D and other chemical weedkillers, most gardeners will agree that hand weeding is here to stay. Furthermore, most will concede that it has compensations.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 16 --Turkey is seeking a $300,000,000 long-term United States loan as a sequel to consultations now being conducted by Turkish and United States economic officials here.

This is the economic background against which the Senate's stock market inquiry was conducted last week: Since the 1953-54 recession ended last summer, the economy as a whole has picked up about half its decline.
Communists, disguised as everything from street sweepers to priests, are infiltrating every Asiatic country, Mrs. Oswald B. Lord reports after a three-month survey.

LAST week's reflections on the abuse of the term "creative writing," followed by a chance rereading of some pages of James Branch Cabell's "Beyond Life." have suggested that it might not be unprofitable to give a little thought to our use of the words "realism" and "romance."

ROME is a large and sprawling city, in which even a Roman occasionally can lose himself--or try to. At least, that's what director Michelangelo Antonioni a nervous, retiring worker thought the other day as he surveyed his location setting--a private villa belonging to a well-to-do young nobleman, hidden on the far reaches of a quiet, villa-studded dead-end street in the elite, almost suburban section of Rome known as Parioli.

LONDON, March 19 -- The frantic struggles within the Labor party this week obscured to a great degree an important restatement of one of the fundamental points of British foreign policy. This is that, although they differ on the timing of a meeting, both the Conservative Government and the Labor Opposition are convinced that the Western powers led by Britain should confer with the Soviet Union this year.

Roses probably are one plant grown in every city, town and hamlet in the country. Some of the popular varieties are originated by American hybridists, others are bred abroad. However all of the bushes no matter what the variety, set out in spring or fall by gardeners, are grown in this country.

INFORMATION intended to clarify the Panama Postal Administration's position regarding the issuing of stamps bearing portraits of all Popes "recognized" by the Roman Catholic Church was made available here last week by C. Arrocha Grell, Panama's Minister of Justice.

The writer of the following letter is president of the Japan Tariff Association. Recently, as Ambassador at Large, he led reparations talks with the Philippines. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Free trade" has long been an international watchword.
PARIS, Sunday, March 20-- An agreement on future economic relations between France and the Saar was officially announced early today.
SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., March 19 (AP)--Erin's Cottage, an Irish import owned and trained by Mr. and Mrs. M. G. Walsh, captured the Sandhills cup in the rain today.

The Boston Celtics yesterday eliminated the New York Knickerbockers in the Eastern Division play-offs leading to the National Basketball Association championship. Red Auerbach's Celtics rebounded from an N. B. A. record 45-point second quarter by the Knicks to gain a 116-to-109 triumph at Madison Square Garden.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19--Battling stiff winds and tricky greens, Jay Hebert retained his three-stroke lead in the third round of the $12,500 St. Petersburg open golf tournament today.

EDWARD R. MURROW and Fred W. Friendly made no mistake in turning over their "See It Now" program to Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine last week. The Columbia Broadcasting System show was in expert hands.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 19-- (AP)--The Minneapolis Lakers overpowered the Rochester Royals, 119--110, in the deciding game of the Western Division semi-final play-off tonight. A crowd of 4,219 attended.
Geoffrey Atkins will defend his amateur racquets championship of the United States today against Clarence C. Pell Jr. of New York in the final at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
American business and industry will welcome spring this week with much the same feeling that a youngster has for Christmas Eve.

The gradual but steady decline in potato prices that started late in November came to a halt early this month. After prices had fallen about $1 a hundred pounds on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the Maine Potato Marketing Administration Committee recommended raising the minmium size for shipments against commitments on the board.

IN Ireland in the morning of Christianity men were still alive who had voyaged to Tir Na N'Og, and Cuchulain and Maeve and Finn were but yesterday's memories. It was a time, as Patricia Lynch makes clear in her "Knights of God," when laughter and good talk and love of music and scholarship went hand in hand with devotion to God.

Members of the Women's Association, of St. Mark's-in-theBouwerie Protestant Episcopal Church have taken over the pre-opening performance of the new revue, "Phoenix '55," on the night of April 10 at the Phoenix Theatre.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) --Americans for Democratic Action today criticized both the Republican Administration and its Democratic opposition in Congress.
WITH torrents of new cars pouring out of the automotive factories into a brimming market, the procedures used to dispose of them through retail channels have created much serious debate.

Harry D. Belock is a thin, intense 47-year-old who has put all his corporate eggs in the Navy's bomb basket. He looks forward to a lifetime of making increasingly better fighting devices for Uncle Sam.
MONTE CARLO, March 19-- A Belgian contract bridge expert, H. Finkelstein, went into the lead this afternoon in the 1955 Monte Carlo Invitation Individual World Championship Tournament.
