Three Bishops of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York donned white aprons yesterday and served dinners as table waiters at as many homes for the aged.

LONDON, March 19--A striking change has occurred in the position of the British royal family during the past quarter-century. No longer remote and secluded as royalty once was, the young Queen and her family have now in effect, come into national close-up--as is indicated by the close attention being paid to the possibility of Princess Margaret's marriage to Group Captain Peter Townsend.
While the art exhibitions opening this week in museums and galleries are not quite as numerous as in the recent weeks, several outstanding shows are among the events.

What may prove to be the most important oil discovery in recent years was made last week in the heart of the Amazon Basin in Brazil. Some 1,000 miles from the nearest operating well, the discovery opens some 500,000 square miles to further oil exploration.

MARATHON, Tex.--A plan is afoot for creating a vast international park south of here on both sides of the Rio Grande River in the Big Bend area. Big Bend National Park, the rugged 700,000acre preserve which lies within the great loop of the international river boundary, would constitute the United States portion of the international park.
MOSCOW, March 19--Never in any country have metropolitan newspapers printed so much material about agriculture as has been appearing lately in the Russian press.
LINCOLN, R. I., March 19 (UP) --Precious Stone, showing the benefits of a ten-week vacation, scored a three-length victory today in the $10,000 Woonsocket Handicap at Lincoln Downs.

OFF - BROADWAY ballets comprise the chief features of this week's schedule. At the Brooklyn Academy, the National Ballet of Canada, in two performances, is giving not only a full-length "Swan Lake," but also a new ballet by Antony Tudor called "Offenbach in the Underworld."

The foreign student is now an accepted part of American campus life. A record 35,000 students from every major nation of the world-- with the exception of the Communist bloc--are now studying in American colleges and universities.

SCULPTURE demanded its share of attention in the week just closed. Recent acquisitions at the Museum of Modern Art and shows by five individual artists in galleries arrived by coincidence to demonstrate anew the diversity of contemporary work from traditional to ultra-modern.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 18--A Connecticut farmer has opened warfare on land controls introduced on behalf of the "twoacre aristocracy" inhabitating this southwest corner of Fairfield County.

AN earlier sarcastic fantasy, "A Dog's Head," and an entertaining manual of seduction as yet untranslated, "Le Petit Don Juan," have revealed Jean Dutourd as one of the few masters of genuine laughter to have come to the fore in France in this age of anxiety and metaphysical torment.
HARTFORD, March 19 -- A major controversy over continuation of rent control in thirtysix cities and towns in the state has started in the Connecticut General Assembly.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will hold an Easter Sunday tea on April 10 at the SavoyPlaza for the benefit of its adoption service. Last year the organization found homes for more than 10,000 cats and dogs.

Former Senator Harry P. Cain is a Republican and a member of the Subversive Activities Control Board. This agency, set up in 1950 with a three-to-two division between the political parties, is supposed to determine whether designated organizations or individual members of such organizations are infected with communism.

FROM early summer until frost annuals can be relied upon to bolster the bloom from perennials. They fill gaps where some perennial plant fails completely or when a plant takes its own sweet time about living up to the description which prompted the gardener to try it.
This may be the year of decision for steeplechase racing.

WEED control is comparatively painless now on the average home property because modern gardeners are more apt to reach for a spray gun than a hoe. The chemical herbicides have become so numerous and so specific in their uses, that most weed problems are easily solved.
ARMONK, N. Y., March 19 --One of the largest private home communities in the East is taking shape here behind a walled-in tract of land dotted with red and white windmills.
WASHINGTON, March 19--Vice President Nixon at Los Angeles this week stated in concise terms the basic problem confronting the Republican party and President Eisenhower as its political leader.
Six persons were injured yesterday when a private automobile collided with a taxi at Park Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
ROCQUENCOURT, France, March 19--There is one point of international friction in the North Atlantic Alliance that the Communists have not yet tried to exploit.
Herbert Treadwell Wade, author, editor and publisher, died Friday night at his home in New Canaan, Conn., after an illness of seven weeks. He was 82 years old.

Arrangements are being advanced for the Schiaparelli Salute Luncheon to be held by the Greater New York Women's Division of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver on April 19 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
A proposal to construct a new United states District Courthouse in Brooklyn has been revived, but evidently has not reached the official planning stage.

A DISTINGUISHED general is dishonored after voicing critical opinions of high officials. Governmental intrigue and commercial corruption chart the chances of many for personal advancement. Abroad, the Germans persist in their refusal to submit to subjugation.
A NEW idea in educational television, designed to make serious learning palatable to a "spectacular" gorged audience, is being carried out each Saturday from 10 to 10:30 A.M. over WCBS-TV.

MIAMI, Fla., Sunday, March 20--Shortly before 12:30 this morning, Elston Howard belted his first homer of the Spring. The blow over the center field wall at Miami Stadium enabled the Yankees to gain an 8-6 triumph over the Dodgers.
LONDON, March 19 -- The British Government was professionally dismayed at the publication of the United States' version of the Yalta conference so soon after it took place.
Subject always to the views of Congress, the Adminisration has now proposed to spend more than $900,000,000 in the next twelve months to raise the standard of living in the "arc of free Asia."

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 19--Mister Black sped to the front late in the mile and a quarter Gulfstream Park Handicap today to win the $66,250 feature by four lengths. The victory was Hasty House Farms' fifth in big Florida stakes this season.

TENAFLY, N. J., March 19-- A picturesque residential development and the advent of spring are brightening East Hill here, a woodland area on the west slope of the Palisades overlooking Bergen County's Northern Valley.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 19 --The Arabian nations' antagonism toward United States recognition of Israel and their fear of growing Israeli power were voiced today at a day-long series of conferences on the Princeton University campus.

NOWADAYS a property doesn't have to be measured in acres to give the would-be grower an opportunity to raise his own fruits. If there is room for a boundary fence or planting, a need for shade on the lawn or even a sunny bank that is unpleasingly bare, he can provide these necessities and have his fruit too.
LONDON. THE total number of gramophone records announced for release in Great Britain this month already exceeds 550 disks. The total number released in March, 1950, was 180 disks.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) --Defense officials indicated today that they would try to strike a compromise with House leaders on compulsory service features of the Administration's Military Reserve Bill.
NEWPORT, R. I., March 19-- The Newport Jazz Festival, Inc., is still endeavoring to hold its second annual concert in this city on July 15 to 17.
With a pat on the back from President Eisenhower, the Boys Clubs of America will begin its annual National Boys Club Week throughout the United States tomorrow.
SETTING fire to food-- the cook calls it flaming --is an ancient culinary practice now having a heyday. Locally, for example, crepes suzette are in vogue for the festive dinner-in-arestaurant.

Department store sales in the United States in the week ended March 12 were 11 per cent greater than in the corresponding period last year, according to the Federal Reserve Board. In the previous week they were up 15 per cent and the gain for the four weeks ending March 12 was 8 per cent above the 1954 period.
The American Korean Foundation has made a nation-wide appeal to high school seniors to make a graduation gift in June that will help restore educational facilities in war-battered South Korea.
IN the hectic days of World War II the Office of War Information maintained a school on Long Island where overseas trainees were taught to operate portable printing presses and short-wave radio.
High school seniors making specific post-graduation plans for their life work will have available this spring a new and especially helpful publication, Health Careers Guidebook.

WITH production and sales a almost peak levels, the economy appears headed for new high ground before the middle of the year. The terrain on the upward path isn't all smooth by any means, but while business may stub its toe and stumble it will probably reach new height without a bad fall.

MIAMI, March 19--Whitey Ford is now a moderately serious young, man of 26, a man who is very much aware of his responsibilities. The qualifying word "moderately" is necessary because the imp in him has never been completely conquered. He isn't as brash or as cocky or as inordinately flippant as he was when he won a world series game for the Yankees as a rookie in 1950.
HARTFORD, March 19 -- Chester Bowles, former Governor and former Ambassador to India, is moving up as a possibility for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in 1956.
The first Finnish-flag service to the Great Lakes will begin next month, James W. Elwell Co., general agents here for the newly formed Finnish North America Line, announced yesterday.

MONTE CARLO -- Something new and very expensive is about to be added to this celebrated resort's Mediterranean oceanfront. It is a sand beach half a mile long. It will be built on more than a million square feet of land to be reclaimed from the sea and packed along the eastern sector of the principality where there are now such landmarks as the famous old Larvotto Bathhouses, and the Summer Casino.

NEW races of hybrid lilies, the result of American enterprise, promise to open up an entirely new aspect of lily culture. So promising are some of these strains that the future may see the lily as popular in the gardens of the world as the peony and phlox.

WASHINGTON, March 19-- Organized labor has lost more ground in the fight on so-called right-to-work laws. The battle is as emotional as the controversy over the Taft-Hartley law ever was, but it is spread over thirty states.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- With the release of its report on Government lending policies this week, the Hoover Commission pulled the plug on the long pentup controversy over the scope of its inquiries.

Laszlo Szabo of Hungary held a 6-1 edge after the seventh round of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata in Argentina yesterday. Szabo played a drawn game with Ludek Pachman of Czechoslovakia in a King's Indian defense of twenty-five moves.
BOWIE, Md., March 19 (AP)-- Guayana scampered to a threeand-a-half-length victory today in the Barbara Frietchie Handicap.

WASHINGTON, March 19-- For four years, at least, the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., has been beating the drums for something that the trade now calls G. A. W. The initials are short for guaranteed annual wage.

A 22-year-old factory worker, married but separated from her husband, was arrested early yesterday on a charge of kidnapping a 3-week-old boy. She had taken the infant to her mother's home, where she cared for him as her own child.
The future will be brought into the present this week at Boca Raton, Fla., for the electric utility industry.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 19 -- The City Council's move to "divorce" itself from a five-yearold "marriage" with the county in developing a port program may wind up as a nonsupport case in the courts this week.

AFTER a spell of fever the country has now returned to an almost normal temperature as it regards the problem of loyalty on the part of its citizens in high or sensitive places. Key cases have disappeared from the front page, the last of these being so patently absurd that it was ludicrous.
Washington indicated last week that American atomic weapons might be used like bullets against military targets in case of Communist aggression anywhere in the world.

MEXICO CITY, March 19-- Juan Miranda of Argentina upset the mighty Wes Santee with a fierce stretch run in the 1.500meter event today. But the United States finished the track and field phase of the PanAmerican Games in a blaze of glory.

SPRING is a season of new beginnings. Since it starts on a Monday this year few gardeners can inaugurate it properly by tilling the soil of sowing seed. The majority will have to content themselves with noting the golden crocus open on the lawn or the forsythia blooming in a city park.
After being rocked by a series of selling waves, the stock market regained some of its composure last week and erased the losses.

SMALL fruit plantings soon will require attention. And there is no time to lose if some more bushes are to be set out this spring. Plans should be made for replacing bushes and vines that are too old, too weedy, or have become so overgrown or weakened by disease that they are no longer productive.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 19 (UP)--A trader who allegedly once tried to corner the soybean market in Chicago was charged today with selling nearly $4,500,000 worth of nonexistent soybeans.

The seventh annual national brickmason apprentice competition will be held in Buffalo, N. Y., on May 19 to 24. The national finals in the competition will be held during the Union Industries Exposition at the Memorial Auditorium and under the sponsorship of the Bricklayers, Masons and Plasterers International Union, A. F. L.

TOMATOES are grown by more home gardeners than any other vegetable. The season here in the Northeast is too short to insure a yield of fruit from tomato seed sown in the open ground. It is necessary, therefore, to buy young plants or to raise them from seed started indoors or in a coldframe outdoors.

What happened at Yalta ten years ago this month is less important than what is going to happen this year and next year and ten years from now. The Yalta conference, concerning which readers of this newspaper have had the opportunity to read several hundred thousand words, was the result of forces then in operation.

SIX years ago, the New York Yankees brought back Bill Dickey as a coach with one specific assignment in mind. One of the greatest catchers who ever lived, the softspoken Dickey was given the job of making a catcher out of Yogi Berra, then a clumsy operative with two left feet and no finesse, only brute strength. The eager Yogi was delighted.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 19 --Troops worked within range of the guns of a French naval task force today to remove machinery from the big Hongay coal mines on the coast of Communist North Vietnam.
DETROIT, March 19 -- The guaranteed annual wage emerged this week from theoretical discussion.

THE long-awaited decision on the jet-tanker competition has unloosed a stream of rumors about production of an American jet airliner. The majority view in the industry seems to be that both Boeing and Douglas will be ready before long to take some orders for commercial jets.

COME Sunday and the theatre's annual merry round of pewter and plaquegiving commences. First in line, as usual since their inception in 1947, will be the American Theatre Wing's Antoinette Perry Awards, also known as Tonys. Honoring the memory of the Wing's devoted wartime chairman, the prizes will be announced at a dinner in the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP)--Val Peterson, Civil Defense Administrator, said today a $12,000,000 emergency fund sought by President Eisenhower would be used to develop "a complete package plan" for protecting ninety-two critical target cities against hydrogen bomb attack.

PEACE and friendly relations prevailed between Indians and white men of the Massachusetts Colony for forty-odd years after the Pilgrims landed at Plymouth. Westerly along the banks of the Connecticut River, a group of socalled "Strict Congregationalists" founded the remote community of Hadley in 1659.
CAIRO, March 19 -- Egypt's youthful rulers are ousting age from control of the country's finance and industry.

SPRING leads gardeners to a crescendo of enthusiasm for getting started early. This enthusiasm oftentimes runs wild in the acquisition of new paraphernalia. For there is a bewildering array of tools and appliances sorely to try the gardener's self-control.
1. Teheran--December, 1943; Yalta--February, 1945; Potsdam--July-August, 1945.

WHAT is it that delights the musicologist, impresses the discophile, provides the artist and repertory director with longterm projects, and endows record releases with fresh sales appeal? It's the magic word--"Complete."
Troops may use a Windsor knot when tying their neckties. --A United States general in Germany.
LONDON, March 19--British Government circles were impressed with the novelty of the appointment of Harold E. Stassen as a sort of Minister for Disarmament.

WASHINGTON--With normal weather, Washington this year will guarantee the most glittering celebration of the rites of spring since the first Japanese cherry blossoms appeared over the Potomac River Tidal Basin.

WASHINGTON, March 19--President Eisenhower indicated today that he might veto any postal pay rise bill more liberal than a measure to be considered Monday by the House of Representatives. Any additional increases "would give me the gravest apprehension," he said in a letter to Representative Tom Murray, Democrat of Tennessee and chairman of the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee.

GLOATING over the richly packed pages of current Schwann and Long Player catalogues, today's LP collector can muster ample evidence to prove that he lives in the most genuinely golden of all phonographic ages.

THE puzzle of what life will turn out like, centuries after the Last World War, is taken up in a sometimes humorously detached, sometimes chilling way by Margot Bennett in "The Long: Way Back." The descendants of the smoldering, terrified people of the time of "the big bang," as it is occasionally called, have made their homes in two separate areas of the devastated globe.
ALBANY, March 19--Two potential contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1956 met here tonight behind the Executive Mansion's closed doors.
DON'T be alarmed by the jargon of hi-fi. The technical terms are the invention of people who hate music.
TRENTON, March 19 -- The Republican-controlled Legislature will reconvene here Monday to receive a special message on mental health from Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

PERENNIALS are the backbone of the permanent garden. With a minimum amount of intelligent care, they come up year after year. Their period of bloom extends from the first primroses and dwarf iris in April through the chrysanthemums in November.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- Changes to meet objections to the design of a stained glass window have delayed the opening of a special room at the Capitol for prayer and meditation by members of Congress.

FERTILIZING and soil improvement can go hand in hand in most gardens. There are many organic fertilizers that can be used not only to add nutrients to the soil, but also to help build up its humus content and thus increase the water-holding capacity.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- House of Representatives forces seeking to upset the Eisenhower farm program today contended they had the backing of organized labor for the first time.
HARP concertos by Gliere and Handel will be heard on Urania disks to be released shortly. The Gliere concerto is played by Uta Zoff, harpist, with Rudolf Kempe and the Leipzig Philharmonic Orchestra.

THE title "Academic Freedom: An Essay in Definition" is sufficiently forbidding to discourage readers both within and without "the Academy." For those within, it would seem to offer one more dry-as-dust disquisition, of which our trade journals are full.
THE parade of the 1955 flower shows is already on the march. The city ones this month are followed by large, elaborately staged shows and many small, informal shows of local garden clubs.

Members of committees working in behalf of the seventh annual Spring Frolic, a tea dance, for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York will be guests of honor at a cocktail party to be given this afternoon by Mrs. J. Baird Magnus at the York Club.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 19 (AP) --The Iraqi Government insisted today it was still aligned with the Arab League even though it had signed a defense treaty with Turkey.

THE modern sculptor most in the news today is not Alexander Calder nor Pablo Picasso nor Henry Moore. It is Auguste Rodin, dead these thirty-eight years, whose work appears to be enjoying a notable revival. In January, two museums bought pieces of his.

Horticulturist, Arnold Arboretum NOWADAYS, a shade tree is no longer construed to be a mighty 100-foot monarch. True, such trees as the elms, beeches and sugar maples do make excellent shade trees and they are still to be seen along suburban streets and on lawns of old, established homesteads.

OAKLEY HALL (well-remembered for "Corpus of Joe Bailey") writes with a hyper-realism, at a sure, powerful narrative pace that brings an immediate fascination to his work. "Mardios Beach" is almost certain to get hold of you from the start.

"ALL the good people die," says Bart O'Breen, the heartless young man who dominates this book and everyone in it. Mr. Macken might indeed have taken these words for his novel's title, for by the time we are through with the families O'Breen and Baun of Galway no fewer than six characters have prematurely lost their lives and a seventh her sight-- and all of them "good people."

IT almost goes without saying the better the foundation the better the final result. And so it is true in gardening, the better the soil, the better the crop. The gospel of gardening preaches that soil must be guarded and improved, but too few gardeners really know the reason why, and therein lies an important tale.

LOS ANGELES, March 19 (UP) --Vic Hershkowitz of Brooklyn, the defending champion, today won his first-round match in the national handball tournament. He defeated Joe Polio, former Kentucky titleholder from Louisville, 21--10, 21--3.

A NEW form of creative editing --the profile in recordings --is beginning to take shape on long-playing disks. So far, most efforts in this direction have been retrospective collections of recordings by jazz musicians and popular singers that examine either the scope of a performer's career or a particular area of it.

Having been a loyal movie fan for the past twenty years or so, I feel justified in seeking an answer to the question, "Is there any relief in sight from the current exasperating, dizzying, even blinding practice of showing films on screens that were plainly not designed for them ?" Except for CinemaScope, projected on a bona fide Cinemascope screen, nothing fits any more.

A young democracy has growing pains. Some of them have just been pointedly described by Robert Alden in a series of dispatches to this newspaper from the Philippines. This is a close and candid view of aspiration, of effort, of trouble, of hope and of devotion.
A NEW nickel-hardened saw blade of chromed steel is said to last three times as long as regular circular saw blades and is discarded after dulling.

THE concept of a house swathed in plants has, for too long, been an accepted mode of American home landscaping. Determined more by formula and fashion than by any serious study of the elements involved, the result has been a mixture of plant forms and textures which not only oppose each other but in most cases are devoid of any relationship with the architecture.
Helicopters have been used in a new stunt that should cut the casualty rate in mine-sweeping.

In a couple more days we can arise bright and early, look at the sunrise, and exclaim, "What a beatiful day for the arrival of the vernal equinox!" We hope it will be such a day, but we'll lay odds that nobody, not even a weather forecaster, will put it exactly that way.

WHETHER great art is being produced anywhere in the world today, it certainly is not in the Soviet Union. Even the president of the Soviet Academy of Arts, who might be pardoned for pride in the work of his fellow -countrymen, makes no claim to greatness on their behalf.

PARSHALL, Colo., March 19 --Big-game specialists from the Colorado Department of Game and Fish recently completed an experiment that may lead to an easier and less expensive method of controlling this state's large deer and elk herds.

CAMDEN, N. J., March 19-- Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, said today that Congress apparently would "look with favor" upon the Administration's request for construction of a fifth super aircraft carrier, the Congress.

THE delegation of Soviet agriculturists scheduled to visit Iowa to study Midwest farming will get a picture of livestock production par excellence. But more than that the Russians will see what commercial, familytype, private-enterprise farming can do in producing the good things of life.

THE third annual New York Do-It-Yourself Show, opening tomorrow and running through next Sunday, will reflect what is probably the major trend in the field this year--the trend toward simplicity of operation and use of a wide array of products.

SKELETON keys to open the literature of our time can be bought almost as cheaply as the works to which they presume to give access. It would seem unnecessary to have a skeleton key to the books of one for whom (in his own words) "lucidity was always breaking in."
In the next few months millions of American citizens will take a close look at their public schools to see what makes them tick.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 19 --George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, was named tonight as the recipient of the University of Notre Dame's Laetare Medal for 1955.
LONDON, March 19--The conviction that Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill intends to retire before Easter, April 10, is spreading among Conservative members of Parliament and senior civil servants.

COLUMBIA has two big keyboard surveys in the offing. One is a three-disk album by Robert Casadesus, which will contain nearly all of Debussy's piano music. Another a three-disk album of sixty Scarlatti Sonatas to be played on the harpsichord by Ralph Kirkpatrick, who has not previously recorded for the company.
Mrs. Donald S. Stralem, chairman for the April 13 preview performance of "The Honeys" at the Longacre Theatre, has announced that a committee has been formed to work for the success of the event.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 19 --The Government has ordered the deportation of Erol Guney, a Turkish newspaper man employed as a French News Agency staff correspondent here. Mr. Guney, a naturalized Turkish citizen, was arrested yesterday and is being detained by the police.
Shareholders of the First National Bank of New York are poring over market data to determine where to invest the $165,000,000 that National City Bank of New York is offering them.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 19 --The loud noise the world has been hearing for decades about year-round sunshine, rugged mountain scenery and cooling fog has been popularly supposed to emanate from California.

WASHINGTON, March 19-- The House of Representatives has agreed to cut in half an Administration bequest for $8,000,000 for United States contributions to the United Nations' expanded program of technical assistance.

FOR those who follow the wild flowers through their native haunts, late March and early April are times to put on rubber boots and venture down into the lowlands. For even before spring arrives on the calendar or touches the windswept hillsides, it has come to swamps and to the banks of brooks.

THE extremes and the intensity of opinions about the quality of the film that has been made from John Steinbeck's "East of Eden" are evidence of one thing, at least: there is some galvanism in this picture that either strongly attracts or repels.
Predictions that reorganized Cabinet methods would set a precedent for future Presidents were made yesterday by two members of the Eisenhower Administration.

PARENTS who keep an eye on their youngsters' choice of comic books may have noticed recently a rectangular blackand-white seal on the covers of many. The emblem indicates that the books bearing it have been "approved by the Comics Code Authority," a body organized by a large group of publishers with the aim of setting their much criticized house in order.

ALBANY, March 19 (AP)--The Republican state chairman accused Investigation Commissioner J. Irwin Shapiro today of "smearing" John F. O'Connell, who resigned Tuesday as chairman of the State Liquor Authority.

TO THE EDITOR: IN his review of John K. Galbraith's "Economics and the Art of Controversy," Senator Paul Douglas makes an interesting point. He says about the "false friends" of such policies as collective bargaining and social security measures: "It is always possible to give verbal allegiance to a principle but to sabotage it in practice by inserting crippling technical details in the laws and by administering them in an indifferent and a hostile manner."
The New York City Opera presented Johann Strauss' "Der Fledermaus" yesterday afternoon as its third opera of the spring season. The production was light-footed, gay in spirit and expertly sung.

TOO often such vigorous growing shrubs as forsythia are placed in front of the one-story home, and in a few short years the plants are much too large. Of course, these plants can be restrained by careful pruning, but who does? The brush top cut is not the way to prune, and it only makes for a poor appearance.

WHEN planning a vegetable garden the average person, it seems, gives more consideration to types than to varieties. That is to say the distinction is, for example, between pole beans and bush beans or green podded and-wax podded, rather than a nice discrimination between the fine points that distinguish one variety within these groups from another.

MOSCOW, March 19--Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Communist party emphasized in a speech published here today that the Soviet Union's new decentralized system of agricultural planning was to take effect immediately.

Warmer weather early last week spurred a lagging readyto-wear market, resident buying offices report. Volume surpassed that of the 1954 week. Easter buying moved into its final stages and some items were in tight supply.

Mrs. Ralph J. Bunche, wife of the Under Secretary of the United Nations, and Mrs. Henry Fonda, wife of the actor, have been appointed co-chairmen of the committee arranging a theatre benefit for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People Legal Defense and Educational Fund.

UP until this time, flower arrangements in shows have generally been confined to niches viewed from the front, or free-standing table centerpieces. But at a recent show in Jacksonville, Fla., a new concept came into the field --that of mobile arrangements.

In this small formal garden blue and yellow flowers accent a brick terrace 10 by 16 feet. Dwarf marigolds in yellow and gold edge the small grass area and behind these are annual blue petunias and perennial daylilies also in shades of yellow and gold.

BONN, Germany, March 19-- The publication of the Yalta documents by the United States rudely awakened the Germans from their pleasant dreams and forced them to look on a moldering cadaver they had been trying to forget.
The celebration of the 300th anniversary of Jewish settlement in the United States will close in June, it was announced yesterday.
SAVANNAH, Ga., March 19-- The chairman of the Federal Maritime Board cited the nation's ports today as "the mainstay of our fighting forces."

PROVO, Utah, March 19--Another big step toward industrialization of the Great Basin, centering on the war-built Geneva Works of the United States Steel Corporation here, was announced this week. Big Steel's Consolidated Western division will begin production of large-diameter steel pipe at its new Provo plant in early April.

SAN CLEMENTE ISLAND, Calif., March 19--Two Navy fighter pilots had to parachute today after their planes apparently collided during maneuvers. They had to leap into the midst of heavy artillery fire on a mock battlefield.

EARLY spring is moving time for families as well as plants. But when a family moves into a new home at this time of year, there's no sound reason for rushing off immediately to buy seeds and shrubs for the grounds.

GARDENERS seem to be divided into at least two categories. Some like to grow flowers and let them complete their life cycle in the garden, while others like to grow them and cut them. I am definitely one of the latter, for one of my greatest pleasures is to bring flowers indoors where I can enjoy them at close range.

The same area is designed again along formal lines but becomes gay as a gingham dress because the accent is on red and white flowers. Petunias and zinnias, geraniums and fuchsias carry out the color scheme to which perennials and woody plants also are keyed.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 16-- Gov. George N. Craig left here this morning for three weeks of relaxation in Florida. The 150man Legislature he left behind scattered through the state's ninety-two counties in search of similar relaxation that may prove as short-lived.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- The party-line split over publication of the Yalta papers showed no sign of mending today.

MONTREAL, March 19--There was no eruption at the National Hockey League game at the Forum tonight. The Canadiens swept through to a 4-2 triumph over the New York Rangers before a crowd of 13,540 fans.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 19 --The aging but still formidable English setter, Ch. Rock Falls Colonel, grained another step in his pursuit of the world record for dog show top honors tonight.

Wall Street's friendliest students --the men and women who haunt brokerage offices watching the magnified march of the ticker across the price quotation boards--have worked out a coexistence policy toward the Senate Banking Committee's "friendly study" of the stock market.

BONN, Germany, March 19-- Pro-Government sources inclined today to the view that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer must prove that the shortest road to reunification is through West Germany's alliance with the Western powers.

KANSAS CITY, March 19-- San Francisco's Dons lived up to their No. 1 national ranking tonight. They administered a decisive defeat to La Salle's defenders and won the National Collegiate basketball championship. The score was 77--63.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) --Mr. Peterson released today a message he had sent to Mayor Wagner of New York praising the work of the Volunteer Civil Defense Planning Committee there. The text: "The work of your Volunteer Citizens Planning Committee, headed by Lieut. Gen. Willis Crittenberger, retired, is a fine job and constitutes a splendid example of American leadership at the community level.

AT a grandmotherly age, Berta Gersten, a Yiddishspeaking star on the Second Avenues of three continents, hopes she is on the threshold of a new career. Her optimism began blooming nicely Dec. 29, the morning after her English - speaking debut on Broadway as Menasha Skulnik's wife Esther in "The Flowering Peach," and it was rooted in a variety of experiences that can be roughly characterized as old, new, black and first-rate.

AS the start of the growing season nears it is time for the gardener to sharpen his tools and talents. Available to him in the latter respect are the labors of authors and publishers who have spent many of the past months gathering material and writing useful, informative books.
Air defense of the city against possible attackers highlighted week-end training of the National Guard in the metropolitan area yesterday.

WE have read with much relish and at least 60 per cent agreement the new book of Henry Pleasants, "The Agony of Modern Music," which already has kicked up a lot of indignation, especially on the part of certain of our composers.

A NUMBER of World War II writers went to Korea and Japan in the Nineteen Fifties and tried to capture the meaning of what It was like to the new young men. Too often they superimposed "their" war on the changed scene.
LONDON, March 19--Britain's top strategists are charting a long-term global strategy closely modeled on that adopted by the United States.

ISOTOPES-- The production and distribution of radioactive isotopes and equipment is a $60,000,000 business, according to Dr. W. Kelly Woods of the Hanford Atomic Products Operation. In 1946 there were only eighty-six users of radio-isotopes in the United States, last year 2,400.

IN the fifth year of her Television Age, Cuba appears to have surrendered quietly to the electronic invader. The convivial islanders, who hardly ever used to stay home at night, are settling down in their tiled living rooms, come what may.
The Administration of Governor Harriman in Albany stands squarely behind the bi-state Waterfront Commission in eliminating illegal port practices in New York.

DALLAS, March 19 -- Rabbi Elmer Berger, executive director of the American Council for Judaism, decried tonight the point of view that American Jews "form a separate identifiable community," with specialized interests.

The New York Public Library's popular perennial, the Wednesday noon to 2 P.M. recorded concert in the building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, is trying to catch up with a backlog of requests.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17--Scientific and field work by veterinary experts of the United Nations have saved millions of head of cattle and multiplied poultry flocks in the FaFr East during the past few years, K. V. L. Kesteven of Australia declared today.

A GARDEN is not "a sometime thing." Many people connect the outdoors and particularly gardens and terraces with spring and summer and daylight hours only. The cherished hours are those from early sun-up to twilight when dark shadows make everything indistinct and mysterious --a time to go indoors and pull drapes closed to shut out the night.

Mrs. Herbert Lloyd and members of her benefit committee are furthering plans for the premiere of J. Arthur Rank's film, "To Paris With Love," which will aid the Union Settlement. The picture, featuring Alec Guinness, opens here March 28 at the Fine Arts theatre.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19--A slipped spinal disc will force Vic Rischi of the St. Louis Cardinals to remain idle for the next four weeks. The right-handed pitcher made known that fact today after a consultation with the club physician.
SEOUL, Korea, March 19-- United States authorities are pressing South Korea to halt racketeering by Korean war veterans and others in the disposal of about $80,000,000 worth of surplus materiel.

An appeal for support of medical research to aid the cause of today's "forgotten children" was made here yesterday by Dr. L. Emmett Holt Jr. He is chief of the children's medical service of the New York UniversityBellevue Medical Center.
WAITSFIELD, Vt., March 19 --Erling Omland of the Watchung Amateur Ski Club led a field of forty-nine racers to win the Eastern veterans' giant slalom at Mad River Glen today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 19--John Glover, the Dartmouth captain, took sprint honors in the Eastern intercollegiate swimming championship. The husky athlete tonight added the 100yard free-style title to the one he had gained at 50 yards yesterday.
FRESNO, Calif., March 19-- Democrats of California searched today for a formula for victory in 1956.

FOR summer bloom certain of the tuberous plants as well as certain seeds must be started indoors in early spring in order to become established plants before they are set out in the garden in late May or June. Such is the case with tuberousrooted begonias, gloxinias, achimenes and the leafy caladiums.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, March 19--Organized labor is bracing for a fight this spring on the issue of its right to participate in the management of the basic steel and coal industries.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) --The question of the age at which an airplane pilot should retire was taken up today at a meeting of aviation medical examiners.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- What the Big Three decided at Yalta has been generally known since the end of World War II. In publishing the official United States record of the conference, the State Department disclosed no important secrets.

WHILE one federal agency is spending money to drain marshland, another is allocating funds to improve marshlands for use as a waterfowl habitat. This was uncovered by a recent survey of wetlands made by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
WASHINGTON, March 19-- The United States has decided to admit about twenty Soviet seamen who deserted their tanker when she was seized last year by the Chinese Nationalists.

To the Drama Editor: I DROPPED in at the "Bus Stop" last week. When Cherie (Kim Stanley) sang "That Old Black Magic," I just couldn't help but fall in love with her. What a delightful being she is! I watched her every move and hung on her every word.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 19 --Savings of about $5,000,000 in the construction of The Dalles dam have been accomplished through tests on a scale model. The model is in a rambling building a few yards from the Bonneville dam about fifty miles downstream.
WAITSFIELD, Vt., March 19 --Erling Omland of the Watchung Amateur Ski Club led a field of forty-nine racers to win the Eastern veterans' giant slalom at Mad River Glen today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 19--John Glover, the Dartmouth captain, took sprint honors in the Eastern intercollegiate swimming championship. The husky athlete tonight added the 100yard free-style title to the one he had gained at 50 yards yesterday.
MADRID, March 9--The first teacher in the history of San Pedro will find no illiterates among the eighty inhabitants of that isolated hamlet high in Spain's northwest Pyrenees.

Sands of Time This spring will see an attempt in the Great Harbor of Syracuse in Sicily to recover some wrecks from the Athenian and Syracusan fleets which fought a famous battle there in September, 413 B. C.

New York City is the electronic capital of the world this week as 40,000 engineers and scientists meet here for the proceedings of the Institute of Radio Engineers. The men who have made the electronics miracles of the post-war decade possible have come to swap ideas on such recondite subjects as transistors and random noise, sine waves and magnetic memories.

PARIS, March 20--An important increase in French aluminum production is expected in French industrial circles. The large companies of Pechiney and Ugines are going to establish a center in Cameroon's capable of producing 30,000 to 45,000 tons of aluminum a year.

Assistant Corporation Counsel Saul Moskoff issued a statement yesterday about the resolution adopted by the Board of Education Thursday. The resolution authorized Superintendent of Schools William Jansen to "direct" teachers to inform on others who have been members of the Communist party.

THERE are prizes for almost every kind of book--the best novel, biography, history, detective story and book by a native son or Ohio. But one prize is missing, which, if it existed, would do honor to a tribe of sorely underestimated men, the ghost writers who devote their professional skill with words to telling the stories of others who lack such skill.
The New York Public Library's Fifth Avenue building started spring cleaning early this year, for a special reason, and is now halfway through dusting off its 3,500,000 books.

MIAMI, March 20--The Yankees and the Dodgers played twenty-two innings in two games here over the week-end and got an even break. Last night the Bombers won in twelve innings. Today the Brooks won in the tenth, 9--8, before 12,244 Miami Stadium fans.
Secretary of State John Foster Dulles warned last night that it might be necessary in the future, as it had been in the past, "to forgo peace in order to secure the blessings of liberty."
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 20 --A desultory civil war is the most serious aspect of South Vietnamese Premier Ngo Dinh Diem's clash with armed Opposition religious and political groups.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. March 20 (UP)--Gary Middlecoff Memphis, sank a 30-foot putt on the final hole today to win the $12,500 St. Petersburg open golf tournament. He finished with a 274.

Two crossings of the Iron Curtain, one in each direction, made significant news over the week-end. In Germany the noted conductor Erich Kleiber abandoned his post as musical director of East Berlin's State Opera and went to West Germany, having concluded that artistic freedom is no more compatible with Communist rule than it was with Nazi dominance.
LAS ANIMAS, Colo., March 20--The great dry land farming areas of southeastern Colorado were on the verge today of another year of drought and dust.
NEWARK, March 20--Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell predicted tonight that the Government would take steps to regulate the country's $25,000,000,000 union pension and welfare funds.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 20 (UP)--Pat Lesser, the pre-tournament favorite from Seattle, and Wiffi Smith, 1954 national junior champion from La Canada, Calif., today gained the final round of the north and south women's invitation golf championship.

THERE were scenes of unbounded enthusiasm when Kirsten Flagstad, with Edwin McArthur conducting, sang a Wagner program with the Symphony of the Air last night in Carnegie Hall. And it cannot tie said, to use the negative mode, that these demonstrations, which greeted the singer before and after each of her performances of the evening, were undeserved!

Nineteen bones, a length of peach-colored batiste and assorted hooks, eyes and laces gave the woman of 1920 less figure control than do a few ounces of nylon elastic, a bit of peau de soie and a reliable zipper in today's foundation garment.
PANAMA, March 20--Former President Jose Ramon Guizado will go on trial tomorrow on a charge of instigating the slaying of his predecessor.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amounted to $71,644,240,803. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
EDIRNE, Turkey, March 12-- European Turkey is astir again after three generations of wars, earthquakes and governmental neglect.

WASHINGTON, March 20-- Harry Lundeberg offered today "subsidization" by his union to help United States shipping to cut into the foreign-flag bulk tramp ship-business and give more jobs to American seamen.
Rex Harrison and Julie Andrews are considering offers to co-star in the musical version of "Pygmalion."

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP)--A Congressional committee disclosed today how an Army general had spent $52,000 refurbishing a thirty-room German mansion. The committee said he had used fraudulent bookkeeping to hide his "waste and extravagance."
MAINZ, Germany, March 20 -- Three hundred historians, scientists and philosophers completed today a conference on Europe's place and mission in the world.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP)--Harold E. Stassen appealed to all Americans today to send him "ideas, suggestions and comments" that might help him in his new post as President Eisenhower's Special Assistant on disarmament.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with considerable interest the article that appeared in a recent issuer of The New York Times, concerning the so-called sculptural group that has been Installed in the new Los Angeles Police Headquarters Building.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 20--Dr. Paul Victor Keller, president of the Swiss National Bank, said last week that if the life of the European Payments Union had to be prolonged beyond June 30, drastic changes in its structure would be essential.
Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, received yesterday the annual award of the rimes Square Club for "outstanding service to American Education."
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) --Americans for Democratic Action today urged an immediate special session of the United Nations General Assembly to consider a trusteeship for Formosa.
CHICAGO, March 19 (AP)-- Montgomery Ward Co. management said today it was ahead of Louis E. Wolfson in the battle for control of the mail-order concern.
PITTSBURGH, March 20--If the influx of new steel business continues at last week's rate-- and there is every indication that it will--steel poured in March will approach the 10,000,000 -ton mark.
Hundreds of New York children must spend their formative years in hospitals, shelters and institutions because nobody wants them.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 20--Stock prices here, following the Wall Street trends, fluctuated sharply last week.
ELKHART, Ind., March 20 (AP)--Fort Wayne's Pistons defeated the Minneapolis Lakers today, 96--79, in the first game of the National Basketball Association's western division title play-off series.
Harvard captured the intercollegiate invitation court tennis tournament yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

STOWE, Vt., March 20--When a skier turns in a performance that almost defies belief, expert observers usually say: "That boy hit the waxes right." That was the story this afternoon as Wallace (Bud) Werner, 19-year-old Denver University freshman, won the American International downhill ski race.
A GRAPHIC and objective picture of efforts to improve race relations in Baltimore was offered yesterday on "The Search" over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

It took Sidney Jackson three tries to get himself arrested in connection with a Harlem holdup murder of more than four years ago. Twice he had sought to get someone in the Criminal Courts Building to listen to his story, but everyone said: "Go away. You're crazy."
DALLAS. March 20 -- The American Council for Judaism expressed hope today that Israel would become a secure nation for "citizens of all faiths and national origins."
WASHINGTON, March 20-- The English setter, Ch. Rock Falls Colonel, completed a perfect dog-show week-end tonight.
ALBANY, March 20--Democrats have decided to support three Republican "humanizing" amendments to the state income tax law.

Mayor Wagner reported yesterday that he might suggest remedial action on wiretapping to state legislators. The Mayor said the suggestions would be based, at least in part, upon a confidential report by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.

For the fifth consecutive year, revenues of Time, Inc., set a new high. The total of $178,155,775 for 1954 was an increase of "about 5 per cent from the $170,448,966 revenues of the year before, according to the thirty-second annual report of Boy E. Larsen, president, and Maurice T. Moore, chairman, released for publication today.

Maurice Stokes of St. Francis (Pa.), Dick Ricketts and Si Green of Duquesne, Johnny Horan of Dayton and Ed Fleming of Niagara have been named as The Associated Press 1955 all-star National Invitation basketball tournament team.

CHICAGO, March 20--Grain and soybean futures worked irregularly lower last week. An exception was the relatively strong market for March wheat. Bullish news received little consideration and professional sentiment continued bearish, despite the ominous political situation in China, and drought in the Southwest.

Rescue at Sea This winter has been busy with sea rescues-- more than 250 distress signals flashed across the North Atlantic alone. Most of us absorbed these harrowing experiences vicariously, seated safely behind our newspapers.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 20-- The new ball park in Kansas City will be ready by opening day. However, that is more than anyone can say for the ball club. Arnold Johnson bought a major league franchise from the Connie Mack family. He was unable to buy major league ball players with it.

The Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble presented a world premiere in its concert last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. This was Ralph Shapey's Concerto for Clarinet and Chamber Group, in which Stanley Drucker played the solo part, and the composer conducted the group of six instrumentalists.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) --Ralph H. Demmler, Chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has refused to tell a Congressional subcommittee whether he discussed the DixonYates power case with President Eisenhower before the commission approved its financing.

Whenever designers, manufacturers or decorators get together a favorite subject of conversation is the taste level of the average homemaker. The woman whose yes or no decides the fate of a product or pattern seldom escapes from the discussion with any credit for good taste.
SLOATSBURG, N. Y., March 20--Fire early today destroyed the historic Sloatsburg Mill, this community's principal industry, with a loss estimated at $2,000,000.
The rebuilt and enlarged organ at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, was dedicated yesterday morning.
East met West here yesterday without self-consciousness at an impressive funeral service and procession for Shavey Lee, unofficial Mayor of Chinatown.

WASHINGTON, March 20--Senator Homer E. Capehart charged today that the Senate committee investigating the stock market had called a witness who he said had written favorably of communism. He said this had been done through ignorance or by design "to discredit American industry and the American economy." The Senator quoted two paragraphs from a 1949 pamphlet written for the National Planning Association by Prof. John Kenneth Galbraith, Harvard University Professor of Economics.
The role of the individual in defending the nation and in maintaining atomic - era peace was emphasized yesterday by two speakers at Masonic dedication exercises.
SAN SIMEON, Calif., March 20--At daybreak tomorrow five thousand troops of the Second Infantry Division equipped with simulated atomic weapons will swarm ashore here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the discussion of our Formosa policy there is not enough emphasis on the intangible factors in the Asian situation. A war with Communist China, even if it were to remain a limited war, would probably alienate most of free Asia from us.

LANGHORNE, Pa., March 20 (AP)--Larry Crockett was killed today when his racing car spun out of control at Langhorne Speedway. The car crashed through a fence and rolled over into a field. The 28-year-old driver was from Columbus, Ind.
The award of thirteen Rome Prize Fellowships for one year each, beginning next Oct. 1, were announced yesterday by James Kellum Smith, president of the American Academy in Rome.
A New York investment house and three new shipping companies here have worked out an extraordinary maritime project to build ships without money.

MOSCOW, March 20--In Moscow's opinion the purpose of the United States in publishing the Yalta documents was to discredit the very idea of big-power negotiations and thus impede the lessening of international tension.

DETROIT, March 20--The Detroit Red Wings blanked the Canadiens of Montreal tonight, 6 to 0, and won the National Hockey League title. It was the final clash of the season for the teams, and the victory gave the Red Wings the championship by the margin of a single game.
WASHINGTON, March 20-- Dean Acheson, former Secretary of State, won another victory in the Supreme Court last week. He did it so quickly, however, that it did not attract much attention.

Ralph Erickson, better known to his students as "Moon," did a "double take" last week during Loomis' annual winter sports dinner. While he was discussing next year's basketball prospects, the Maroon's athletic director saw what he describes as a weird-looking figure.

JERUSALEM, March 16 -- About 40,000 Israelis have learned basic Hebrew in the last six months. This is the estimate of the Ministry of Education at the end of the first academic term of a nation-wide language campaign.
There are some disadvantages to feeding guests seated thousands of feet above the kitchen, but Sky Chefs, Inc., seems to have overcome most of them.

MEXICO CITY, March 20 (AP) --Jimmy McLane, a veteran of two Olympics, and Wanda Lee Werner, a ninth-grade student from Bethesda, Md., swept to upset swimming victories today for the United States in the PanAmerican Games.
A concept of God that is basically human was called for yesterday by Algernon D. Black, a member of the Board of Leaders of the New York Society for Ethical Culture.
With Cardinal Spellman presiding, the Rev. Michael J. Deacy celebrated the solemn mass of Laetare Sunday in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. Father Deacy is a member of the cathedral clergy.

ISIDOR PHILIPP, now in his ninety-second year, gave a concert with eminent colleagues yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall for the benefit of the fund-raising drive of the Friends of the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra.

President Eisenhowers unprecedented step in creating what might be called a Secretaryship for Peace in his Cabinet, and in naming Harold E. Stassen to fill this post, is an admission of failure as well as an expression of hope.

KAOHSIUNG, Formosa, March 20--In his winter hideaway on Sitzewan, the beautiful bay, outside southern Formosa's naval base at Kaohsiung, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek is getting rid of a cold and resting up away from the dank fog and nervous rumors on Taipei, his present capital.
A 'Gala Performance" consisting of acts from "Madama Butterfly," "La Boheme" and "Fledermaus" will be a feature of the twenty-first week of opera at the Metropolitan.

Two television panelists clashed yesterday on the proposed Republican rent control plan. They were State Rent Administrator Charles Abrams, Liberal appointee of Governor Harriman, and Joseph F. Carlino, Republican majority leader of the Assembly.
Rates in the ship charter market dipped more sharply last week than in any of the three weeks since they began retreating from their post-Korea peak.
FRESNO, Calif., March 20-- California Democrats today marked out a trail they hoped to follow to put this state back into the Democratic column and keep it there.

The Department of Air Pollution Control was thrown yesterday into the city's war against litter and litterbugs. Orders to this effect were issued by Commissioner Leonard Greenburg. Under the supervision of Chief Inspector Harold Glicksman, air pollution inspectors have been informed of the "target areas" throughout the five boroughs picked ay the Department of Sanitation for the opening of the anti-litter drive.

MONTE CARLO, March 20-- Thirty-six contract bridge experts representing eleven. European countries and the United States played the fourth of five scheduled sessions in the 1955 Monte Carlo individual championship this afternoon.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Monday, March 21--An American Airlines plane with at least thirtytwo persons aboard exploded and crashed late last night. The highway patrol said it appeared there were "eight to ten dead."
NEW ORLEANS, March 20-- President Eisenhower was asked here tonight to remove the Federal loyalty and security program from the realm of politics in the interests of civil liberties.

The proxies--stockholders' ballots--of the Louis E. Wolfson interests, which are seeking to supplant the management of Montgomery Ward Co., are in this morning's mail. They follow by a week those of the management headed by Sewell Avery, board chairman.
The betting is even that the make-or-break negotiations this spring for a guaranteed annual wage in the automobile industry will result in contracts without strikes.
LOS ANGELES, March 20-- Leo Durocher's Giants today gave an overflow crowd of 24,434 a sample of some of the big events of last October's world series with the Indians.

The move to bring the International Longshoremen's Association back into the American Federation of Labor ran into opposition yesterday from the union the federation set up to put the I. L. A. out of business.
HYDERABAD, Pakistan, March 20--The Speaker of the Sind Provincial Assembly and two Assembly members were arrested tonight in an alleged plot to assassinate Provincial Ministers.
ALBANY, March 20--A plan to provide state assistance in building new dormitories at private colleges and universities was announced today by the Republican legislative leaders.
Vivian Scott, who made her debut yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, gave the piano recital as the seventh award winner of JUGG, Inc., an organization that sponsors Negro artists.

The people of this state might well hope that the New York Legislature will have time, before it adjourns about two weeks hence, to discuss at some length the future of our State University. Presumably this opportunity will arise in connection with the proposition, broached on Jan. 27 by Frank C. Moore, chairman, of the university's trustees, for a $250,000,000 bond issue for capital improvements and expansion.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation last year had a consolidated net income of $74,623,256, or $6.04 each on the 13,042,038 common capital shares outstanding at the year-end, according to the 1954 annual report released for publication today.

Millions of New Yorkers sampled the sunny weather yesterday in the parks and avenues, or fled from the city by automobile, in anticipation of today's arrival of spring. The turn of the season came officially at 4:36 A. M. today, long after most of yesterday's strollers, sight-seers, boaters, anglers and drivers had returned to bed.

THE New York City Opera did a considerable amount of switching over the weekend. In Saturday night's "Traviata" and yesterday afternoon's "Faust" it changed a number of leading parts to different singers. And in last night's "Cinderella" it switched the Rossini opera from Italian to English.
TOWNSFOLK who slept through winter's departure and spring's entry at 4:36 o'clock this morning have a chance to watch a delayed version at noon on the Waldo Hutchins sundial bench in Central Park.

New Jersey's No. 1 unseeded tennis player is preparing for a busy campaign. The competitor is Gov. Robert B. Meyner, who is doing as much to popularize tennis in his area as President Eisenhower has done for golf in the nation.

Eintracht of the GermanAmerican Soccer League yesterday defeated the Uhrik Truckers of Philadelphia in the first of two home-and-home games in the Eastern final for the National Challenge Cup on the Eintracht oval in Astoria.
The New York subway system is an underworld of increasing crime against persons and property, according to a confidential report made to the Transit Authority.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20--A dual-purpose motion picture and electronic camera that makes it possible to transmit a live television show and record it on 35-mm. film at the same time is now a reality.
WASHINGTON, March 20--A Congressional panel charged today that Communists and their sympathizers received free rein to indoctrinate 8,000,000 American soldiers during World War II.
WASHINGTON, March 20-- Following are the votes of the delegations, from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the period March 10 through March 18:
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 20-- One cold clear night this winter the Chinese Communists lost a propaganda skirmish on the Southeast China coast.
WASHINGTON, March 20-- Military leaders are now more hopeful that the Administration may be willing to rectify what they consider a serious imbalance between atomic potential and conventional arms.

Week Ended March 18, 1955 It was a dull week in the foreign exchanges. Lacking the nervous movement of the two major units--British sterling and the Canadian dollar--as this revolved around Bank rate changes, only a fair business was reported with no significant price variations.
The recent power shift in the Soviet Union is unlikely to have any bearing on the future of religious freedom there.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since 1926, when the Court of Appeals decided People v. Defore, the rule in New York has consistently been that evidence is admissible though obtained through violation of law. Hence, there is no limitation on the use of wiretap evidence.

Westchester County, which has the reputation of housing more advertising men than any other area adjacent to New York (with the possible exception of Connecticut's Fairfield County) is to have an advertising campaign of its own.
BOSTON, March 20 (UP)--The Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Boston Bruins, 4--3, before 10,696 tonight at Boston Garden in the final game of the regular National Hockey League season for both teams.
WASHINGTON, March 20-- Senator Walter F. George advocated today a meeting of the heads of the major powers this year.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) --The House Veterans Committee declared tonight that the Veterans Administration had been so intent on building new hospitals it had neglected to keep up some of its old ones.

The Long Island team of Mrs. Betty Pearly of Roslyn Heights and Benjamin Mitchell of East Rockaway won the mixed pair event of the Eastern States Bridge Championship last night with a score of 395 1/2.
A series of Soviet newspaper articles has provided the first broad picture of the increasing use of radioactive substances in Soviet medicine, industry and science.

Commercial paper on the books of dealers at the end of February was down 1 per cent from the end of January and 2 per cent from the year-earlier level, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported over the week-end. The total on Feb. 28 was $703,000,000.
Three five-story store and apartment buildings at 108890-92 Second Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-seventh Street, have been purchased by an investing client of the Henry Baker Management Company.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 20 (UP)--The Chinese Nationalist official news agency reported today that the Soviet Union had turned over ten submarines to Communist China as part of a transfer of 100 Soviet vessels to Peiping's forces.

Max Liebman, producer of the ninety-minute color programs over the National Broadcasting Company television network on Saturday and Sunday evenings, will be relieved of the Sunday assignments next season.
WASHINGTON, March 20-- Senate-House conferees apparently are ready to hand President Eisenhower a victory, this week in his fight against the Democratic move to cut individual income taxes.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) --The report said that President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Frank Knox, his Secretary of the Navy, impaired the Navy's wartime security by permitting Communists to work as radio operators on American merchant ships.
CAIRO, March 20--Egypt indicated willingness today to keep her door open for eventual Arab defense cooperation with the West despite her campaign to keep the Arabs out of such arrangements.
RIDGEWOOD, N. J., March 20 --Ninety teen-agers from three states pooled their talents today for a bell-ringing ceremony in the West Side Presbyterian Church here.

Laszlo Szabo of Hungary retained the lead in the eighth round by the margin of half a point in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, according to a report received yesterday from Buenos Aires.
Geoffrey W. T. Atkins won the amateur racquets championship of the United States for the second successive time yesterday.
TRENTON, March 20 -- A broad program for improving and expanding state aid to the mentally ill will be submitted to the Legislature tomorrow by Gov. Robert B. Meyner.
ALBANY, March 21--A special state commission ruled today that the book "Russia" was not subversive.

LONDON, March 21--European industrialists are not wholly in favor of adopting the specialized training of chemical engineers provided in the United States. But they recognize the urgent need for technologists who can bridge the gap between scientific research and plant construction.
MOSCOW, March 21--Economic difficulties and "disproportions" in the Communist states of Eastern Europe were reported today in Pravda.

Homemakers who accompany their husbands to the Do-ItYourself show this week will find plenty to interest them while the men are trying out power tools or investigating a plastic car that comes in a kit.
GENEVA, March 21--The United States signed here today the documents necessary for its adherence to the revised General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 --The Secretary of the Interior declared here tonight that private citizens preached less loudly but practiced conservation of the nation's resources more actively than did "some bureaucrats" of the past.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial entitled "Judge's Report to Laymen," wherein Judge Peck recommends the elimination of the right to trial by jury in civil cases, is disturbing.
United Aircraft Corporation in its annual report made public yesterday showed an increase in net income from $21,193,733 in 1953 to $25,996,232 last year.
ALBANY, March 21--Governor Harriman indicated strongly today that he would ask the Legislature to delay the effective date of the compulsory automobile inspection law.
ALBANY, March 21 -- The Public Service Commission warned today that the bus industry faces a rocky economic road ahead.

DETROIT, March 21 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings, who haven't lost a National Hockey League game since Feb. 17, have been installed as 2 1/2-to-1 favorites to sweep to their second straight Stanley Cup championship.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 21-- Leo Durocher went back to playing his junior varsity today, a procedure that did not sit well with 3,433 spectators.
It is an axiom of the prizering that a good big man can beat a good little man any day.
ALBANY, March 21--A legislative committee charged today that the comic book industry's attempt at self-regulation and censorship had proved ineffective.
BOSTON, March 21--Harvey Matusow is the focal point of a Communist campaign to destroy the informant system of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today.
Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, chairman of the Transit Authority, said yesterday a transit police force of 852 could adequately protect subway riders and property.

Parents worthy of the name all have occasional insights into their relationship with their children which are both frightening and inspiring. We mean the awing shock of seeing one's children exhibiting one's own defects and virtues, returning one's own tendernesses and unthinking cruelties--seeing them grow into receptacles of the good and ill parents do them.

A record net income of $211,872,447, equal to $7.04 a share, was earned last year by the Standard Oil Company of California. The annual report of R. G. Follis, board chairman, and T. S. Petersen, president, is released today and discloses that expenditures in 1955 for capital and exploratory purposes are expected to exceed $300,000,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of March 13 on "The Earth Bomb" goes to the heart of the matter when it calls for "a policy which will protect at once freedom and peace." Downwind from the first column, however, the article on civil defense, "Shelter--'Right Now,' " fails to penetrate to the central point, namely, what can and should be done after we lift our heads from the sand.
TRENTON, March 21--The Republican - controlled Legislature moved today to extend daylight saving time from the last Sunday in September to the last Sunday in October.

The news from Saigon is not reassuring. The Government of the free southern half of Vietnam is faced with dissident movements that would be serious under any circumstances and are doubly so at this critical time. If Vietnam is to remain free its people must declare themselves at an election a year from next July.
A 79-year-old man was arrested twice yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, March 21 (AP) --The National Basketball Rules Committee today changed the bonus free throw rule to apply to the full forty minutes playing time and widened the free throw lanes from six to twelve feet.

IT is always pleasant to hear music of the pre-classic era performed on the instruments for which it was written. This pleasure was afforded to some extent last night by a group called Amor Musicae at Carnegie Recital Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21--The Moscow-Peiping motion-picture propaganda axis is taking a beating from Hollywood almost everywhere in the Orient.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Critics of the Administration's high-tariff policy on imported watches returned to the attack today.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- The House of Representatives refused decisively today to limit to an average of 7.5 per cent a proposed pay rise for 500,000 postal employes.
The liner Panama will be withdrawn from the passenger-carrying trade and operated as a cargo ship in the New York Haiti-Canal Zone service, effective with her sailing from here March 31.

BONN, Germany, March 21--The European Association of the Women Friends of Young Girls has protested against the operations of the American picture bride industry in Germany. The association's representative told Dr. Franz Josef Wuermeling, Minister of Family Affairs, that there was a regular export of German girls to become wives of Americans.

The third annual WNYC Book Festival will start April 1 and continue through April 7. Noted authors will participate in the more than 100 radio programs. The appreciation of books and all aspects of writing, production and criticism will be discussed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Hoover Commission Task Force report on federal medical services draws our attention to a fact long known in professional circles. Society is making a poor start when "one in every twelve children born in the country will spend some time in a mental institution."

A top spokesman for the savings and loan industry sounded a warning yesterday on the use of ultra-liberal mortgage terms to stimulate building. The warning came from J. Howard Edgerton, president of the United States Savings and Loan League and president of the California Federal Savings and Loan Association in Los Angeles.

The attention of the world is focused again on Paris, where the Council of the Republic begins tomorrow what should be the last crucial debate on the Paris pacts. These agreements have already been approved by the French National Assembly and by the Foreign Affairs, Defense and Economic Affairs Committees of the Council itself.
The Bethlehem Steel Company's Key Highway yard at Baltimore is the apparent low bidder for the conversion of four Mariner-class freighters.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 21 (AP)--Seeded women players came through as expected today in opening round matches of the Good Neighbor tennis tournament. Doris Hart of Miami was champion, lead the list of entrants.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 21-- The mystery of the opposite sex, a subject of interest to all ages, drew the full attention of teenagers today on Cornell University's campus.
BUENOS AIRES, March 21-- The Roman Catholic hierarchy of Argentina protested today measures taken by the Peron Government against the church.
SAN SIMEON, Calif., March 21--An amphibious force practicing new atomic warfare techniques landed on the heach here at daylight today.
CANBERRA, Australia, March 21 (Reuters)--Australia today announced cuts in import quotas ranging from 15 to 33 per cent, aimed at righting the country's lopsided foreign trade account.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 11,000 head: general trade active, butchers and sows unevenly strong to mostly a full 25c higher; bulk of choice 190 to 230 pound kinds, $16.50 to $17; latter
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., March 21 (AP)--Twelve persons were killed and twenty-three injured in an American Airline plane crash late last night.
STORMVILLE, N. Y., March 20--On a Sunday afternoon in May, 1951, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Zurhorst of Bronxville set out in their station wagon looking for land they might buy for a week-end retreat.
Judge Jonah J. Goldstein will rule today whether an unofficial investigator who exposes a scandal seemingly hushed up by the police can be compelled by a grand jury to name his informants.

TOKYO, March 21--Japan's apparent eagerness to welcome a Communist Chinese trade delegation has been dampened. The cause is a demonstration of Communist bargaining techniques while the Peiping economic mission is still 2,000 miles away.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) A witness at a Congressional hearing today accused Federal Judge James V. Allred of Texas of laxity in the enforcement of immigration laws against "wetbacks."

Year-round central air conditioning for the home moved a long step closer to the mass market yesterday. The General Electric Company introduced two new models of its Weathertron heat pump that will cost $300 to $600 less to install than previous models. The new units are the first designed by the company specifically for colder climates.
GLASGOW, Scotland, March 21 -- Billy Graham, American evangelist, opened an "all-Scotland crusade" tonight in Kelvin Hall before an audience of more than 15,000 persons.
PINEHURST, N. C., March 21 (AP)--Wiffi Smith, last year's United States junior champion, today beat Pat Lesser, 3 and 2, in the 18-hole final round of the North and South amateur tournament.

The proceeds of the annual dinner dance of Delta Phi Epsilon Sorority will aid in research and treatment for children with rheumatic fever at Irvington House, Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y. Irvington House's program of continued preventive treatment for other youngsters at its New York out-patient clinic also will benefit.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) --The House voted $2,337,522,262 today to run the Labor Department, and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, in the fiscal year starting July 1.
The New York State Power Authority threatened last night to go before the Supreme Court to keep private utility companies out of Niagara River power development.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)--An industry group has protested to the Department of Commerce that sales of Government - produced methylchloride are "having a serious impact upon the market."
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 21 --Reinforced Opposition groups today gave Premier Ngo Dinh Diem five days to reorganize his Government in accord with their wishes.
MOSCOW, March 21--Georgi F. Alexandrov was dismissed today as Minister of Culture of the Soviet Union. Nikolai A. Mikhailov, lately Soviet Ambassador in Warsaw, was appointed to replace him.
Common shares of the Axe Science and Electronics Corporation, a diversified management investment company, were admitted to trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
