The black radish, close cousin to the more familiar red and white varieties, may be a mystery to most shoppers, but not to those of Jewish, German or Russian background. Such-persons savor it as an appetizer, meat accompaniment, and even as a sweet.

The Board of Estimate has aproved "in principle" the $600,000,000 program designed to meet the arterial highway demands of the metropolitan area for the next two decades. The arterial scheme was worked out jointly by the Port of New York Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
Secretary of State Dulles declared yesterday that Chinese Communist tactics "may prove more dangerous and provocative of war" in the immediate future than those of the Soviet Union.
KANSAS CITY, March 21 (AP) --The East defeated the West, 90--77, tonight for its first victory in the annual East-West Shrine basketball game.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 21--The Federal High Court today backed the powers of Governor General Ghulam Mohammed.

Joe Rowan, 182, Phoenixville, Pa., gained a split decision over Wayne Bethea of the Bronx in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena; Brooklyn, last night. Bethea weighed 191 3/4 pounds.
How much does it cost to conduct a proxy campaign for control of a large corporation? Judging by the experience of such industrialists as Robert R. Young and Louis E. Wolfson--a lot.
MONTE CARLO, March 21-- The 1955 Monte Carlo individual bridge championship was won today by Frits Goudsmit, leading contract bridge expert of Holland.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- The State Department indicated today that it was sympathetic to Senator Walter F. George's call for a Big Four meeting after France approved the arming of West Germany.

Following are the texts of an exchange of letters between former Premier Pierre MendesFrance of France and Prime Minister Churchill of Britain. The Mendes-France letter was released by him in Paris and unofficially translated by The Associated Press.

Boris Karloff, recently seen on television in such sympathetic asignments as a wallflower a lonely hearts club and a kindly professor working on the side of the law and order, will revert to a menacing role in "The Lark."
Crime in the city could be reduced by 50 per cent if a "sufficient number of policemen" could be made available, Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams said yesterday.
BETHPAGE, L. I., March 21-- A shabbily dressed bandit, armed with a hunting knife, held up the woman manager and two tellers of a bank here this morning. He escaped with $38,000 in cash.
Although nature withheld its vernal grace from the arrival of spring yesterday, there was a more reliable confirmation: the circus is coming to town Sunday.
ALBANY, March 21--Republicans proposed their own alternative to Governor Harriman's emergency education program tonight.

LONDON, March 21--Prices of British Government securities fell sharply today, casting depression on the rest of the marcel. Halting of last week's rally was attributed to speculation that a general election was near.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- Egypt's demand that Israel cede the Negev as the price of her cooperation with Western defense set off a burst of speculation in Washington today.
PARIS, March 21 --The French Government began a legal offensive today against Pierre Poujade, who has been leading a tax revolt powerful enough to endanger the Cabinet.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 21 (AP)--Australia's Davis Cup team may not play in the United States national tournament at Forest Hills if that event precedes the Davis Cup challenge round.
TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council continued debate on conditions in Ruanda-Urundi under Belgian administration.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- Maritime Unions of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations split apart today.
LONDON, March 21--The Soviet Union, in the British view, is unlikely to agree on a conference with the West about Germany before the end of 1955.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 21--A long-standing Moscow offer to supply Soviet technicians or machinery to needy nations has been taken up by India and at least six other countries.

BONN, Germany, March 21-- The Federal Constitutional Court announced today it would rule next Monday on the admissibility of the Social Democratic party's petition challenging the legality of the Saar agreement with France.
After twenty days of hearings, testimony ended yesterday on the motion by thirteen secondary Communist leaders for a new trial.
ALBANY, March 21 -- Two Brooklyn judicial nominations were sent tonight by Governor Harriman to the Senate, which confirmed them soon afterwood.

LONDON, March 21 (AP)--Following is the text of a communique broadcast from Moscow tonight: IN THE MINISTRY OF U. S. S. R. FOREIGN AFFAIRS. Consultations in connection with the decisions of the Moscow conference.
Seventy-eight litterbugs and the city treasury began to feel the effects of the city's antilitter drive yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP)--The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy held a legislative meeting under water last night aboard the atomic submarine Nautilus, a member disclosed today.

Three floors in the twentyseven-story office building to be greeted at 20 Broad Street have been, leased by the law firm of Mudge, Stern, Baldwin Todd. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agents for the building, said the floors comprise 27,400 square feet of space and the aggregate rental amounts to almost $2,000,000.
Thirty-seven contract bridge teams began play last night for the Curt H. Reisinger trophy, which goes each year to the team-of-four champions in the Eastern States Bridge Championships.
After selected gains in early dealings, stock prices eased yeserday. Losses ranging to 3 points were spread through the list. Only a handful of issues showed important gains.

A relatively small financing transaction gave accent to a trend yesterday. Early in the century--when our British cousins were largely the creditors and we the debtors--the then old Manchester textile house of Doublers and Fine Spinners, Ltd., set up a subsidiary in the United States cotton belt, the Delta and Pine Land Company in Mississippi.

TO THE DEITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There have been innumerable explanations of the recent shake-up in the Kremlin. But, whatever the personal equation in this reckoning, there can be no doubt of the influence exercised on events by the Soviet fear of impending famine brought about by the disasirous failures of collectivization on the agricultural front.

STOWE, Vt., March 21 (AP)-- A group of American skiers planned today to file a protest with the United States Olympic ski games committee because Bill Beck was not selected to the regular American Olympic team for 1956.

IMPATIENT trout fishermen with warm blood, heavy clothing and a means of transportation can beat the opening of the state-wide trout season by more than a week by heading for the Finger Lakes tributaries.

An ownership of nearly twenty years has been terminated in the sale of the five-story apartment house with stores at 137 East Thirty-fifth Street by the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen. The property, on plot about 20 by 74 feet at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue, was acquired by an investing: client of John T. McCormick Jr., attorney.

Placing an ocean between themselves and their country has allowed three South African student-ministers to become friends here. One is a native Bantu. So what's happening at Union Theological Seminary wouldn't happen in Capetown.

On a December day in 1818 Peter Frederik Suhm Heering opened a cellar shop in Copenhagen to market his Cherry Heering, a liqueur of a warm red color and pleasant taste that had been made for many years in Denmark.
The school bell will ring for longshoremen on April 13 when an experiment in teaching industrial relations to dock workers begins under the auspices of Cornell University.
The latest Soviet Government change appears to point toward tighter Communist party control of the Soviet Union's intellectual life.

Apparently "Peter Pan" started a trend by switching from Broadway to television. It was disclosed yesterday that two Broadway productions--one still running and one recently closed --have been booked for television presentations.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 21--In a blazing sun at Holman Stadium today 3,727 fans watched the Yankees and the Dodgers. If they wanted to see plenty of hits, runs and unusual plays they got their money's worth.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) The Senate Banking Committee voted 9-to-5 today in support of the Administration's plan to sell twenty-four Government-owned synthetic rubber plants for $285,465,000.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 22--The Soviet Union and seven states of East Europe have agreed on the details of a unified military command to be established in the event West Germany is armed. Announcement of the agreement was issued here early this morning by Tass, Soviet news agency. The news had been broadcast to foreign countries several hours before.

CHICAGO, March 21--Sharp declines were registered in both Wheat and soybeans at the start today, and rallies met rather free selling. All soybean deliveries except March dropped into new low price territory. Corn was weak early but showed a relatively firm tone later.
To Them It's Harvesting Time There is a community of farmers around Long Island Sound and Peconic Bay who are oddly out of step with the seasons.

Pat Ward finished testifying yesterday in the vice trial of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke. Before she left the stand, however, she invoked the Fifth Amendment to block questions about her sex life since leaving the oleomargarine heir.
PANAMA, March 21 -- Jose Ramon Guizado went on trial today on a charge of homicide in the assassination Jan. 2 of President Jose Antonio Remon.

A bill to require the New York City Board of Education to return to an abandoned policy of admitting children to kindergartens and the first grade in February as well as September has been passed by the Assembly at Albany. The Board of Education opposes the bill, as does the United Parents Associations.
New issues of industrial securities valued at more than $38,000,000 will be offered to investors today.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) --A spokesman for independent oil producers said today that if "excessive" oil imports continued, consumers would become increasingly dependent on a "handful of international companies."

Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, will be named president of the Boston and Maine Railroad as well, if a B. M. stockholders' committee is successful in a proxy contest.
NEW ORLEANS, March 21-- Attempts to censor books in school and library collections were declared here today to pose a grave threat to the nation's democratic concepts.
Miguel Najdorf, Argentina's international star, tied Laszlo Szabo, Hungarian grandmaster, for the lead at 7--2 in the chess tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday.

WASHINGTON. March 21--A move to merge the International Longshoremen's Association with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., slowed down today. The two unions agreed, however, to meet again. The teamsters' union is taking a longer look at the proposal since the I. L. A. elected Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia a vice president.

Three five-story store and apartment buildings at 1088-9092 Second Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-seventh Street, have been purchased by an investing client of the Henry Baker Management Company. Assessed at $96,000 the property is 59 by 78 feet and was sold by Maurice Epstein, as president of the 44 East Fifty-third Street Corporation.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 21 (AP)--Bo Wininger of Oklahoma City led the pro division with a 69 in opening round of the twoday $10,000 Seminole pro-amateur golf tournament today.

William R. McAnulty Jr., a 15-year-old visitor from Pittsburgh, yesterday became the "Boy of the Year." The title became official after the 6foot-3-inch high school sophomore received the ninth annual Junior Citizenship Award from the Boys Clubs of America.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21--The traveling golf caravan shuffled into this bustling metropolis last week for the St. Petersburg Open, one of the final way stations of the winter tour. The tournament drew a strong field and goodly galleries. But the fellow who most intrigued the shuffleboard players, other transients and even the St. Pete natives was big Mike Souchak. It's understandable.

Although the 16,000,000 Negro citizens of the United States make up 10 per cent of the total population, Negro students still account for less than 4 per cent of the 2,472,000 enrolled in our colleges. This great disparity in educational opportunity has resulted in an acute shortage of college-trained Negroes in business and the professions.
ALBANY, March 21 -- A Republican bill to provide for state supervision of labor union welfare funds was submitted to the Legislature tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther said today the Soviet Union was probably able to overrun part or all of Europe, but would be defeated. He added, however, that the West would not win either.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation, Venezuelan affiliate of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, reported yesterday a record net income of $239,650,741 for 1954. Equal to $9.27 each on 25,865,310 shares outstanding, the net compared with the previous record of $228,997,006, or $8.85 a share, earned in 1953.

Forced liquidation resulting from the insolvency of a commodity trader dropped cottonseed and soybean oils sharply on the Produce Exchange yesterday. The soybean oil volume was the largest in more than two years and cottonseed oil registered many more trades than the 1954-55 high.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points (40 cents) higher to 20 points ($1) lower yesterday after heavy trading just after the opening.
Design principles were disclosed here yesterday for an "old-fashioned" space ship that would take a year and a half to two years to fly to Mars with a crew of ten men.
MEXICO CITY, March 21 (AP) --The United States added to its Pan-American swimming laurels today by defeating Argentina in the men's 400-meter medley relay race.
ALBANY, March 21--Governor Harriman urged Republican lawmakers tonight not to discriminate against upstate in extending rent controls.

BOWIE, Md., March 21 (AP)-- Bill Hartack, leading rider of the meeting, added three more victories today. He scored one of his triumphs with Olympia Wiz in a division of the featured First Robin Purse.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- The Administration was warned today it faced defeat on its plan to draft youths into the Reserves.
NORFOLK, Va., March 21-- The Tidewater Construction Corporation of Norfolk has been awarded the substructure contract for a new ore pier at NewPort News. The project will cost $8,000,000.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 21 (AP)--C. F. Morriss' Munchausen, in a warm-up for Saturday's $100,000 Florida Derby, defeated Hasty House Farms' Prince Noor by a neck today at Gulfstream Park.
Harry S. Truman, who once wrote a scorching letter to a writer who criticized his daughter's singing, is making his own debut in music criticism.
PARIS, March 21--Sir Winston Churchill has warned the French Government that the United States and Britain could and would defend West Europe without France if necessary.
The State of New York borrowed 50,715,000 in the public market yesterday to finance subsidies to local housing authorities developing low-rent public housing projects.
ALBANY, March 22--The Republican plan to legalize bingo by 1958 moved halfway through the Legislature today.
Albany, March 22--The legislative committee investigating wiretapping reported today that it had information on an illicit wiretapping syndicate in New York City.
A woman's umbrella was part of a bank robber's equipment in Queens yesterday. He used the umbrella to conceal his pistol from everyone but a woman teller, from whom he took about $2,000.
TRENTON, March 22--State Treasurer Archibald S. Alexander revealed today that seventeen more lease purchase agreements negotiated by the late Harold G. Hoffman were invalid.
Delay in enforcement of automobile inspection for one year was unanimously requested of the State Legislature yesterday by the City Council.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) --The Army today came out with a full defense of its women in uniform against what it called a widespread and sometimes vicious campaign of slander in World War II.
OTTAWA, March 22--The yen to fly downhill and the skis to do it with are about all you need to be a skier here. Lucky Ottawans can thank the Ottawa Ski Club for that.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- The Eisenhower Administration gave a perfect illustration today of why its purposes are misunderstood and misconstrued at home and abroad as a result of contradictory public statements on important matters of high policy.

The National Dairy Products Corporation in 1954 sold the largest volume of products in its history and achieved a new high record in earnings for the third successive year. The net profit last year amounted to $37,393,012, an increase of 21.3 per cent over the $30,837,169 earned in 1953.
CINCINNATI, March 22-- Merger of the Lincoln National Bank with the Fifth Third Union Trust Company has been voted by boards of the two institutions.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 22 (AP)--A single free throw by Max Zaslofsky gave Fort Wayne a 98-97 overtime victory over Minneapolis tonight. The triumph sent the Pistons ahead of the Lakers in their National Basketball Association Western division play-off, 2--0.
MONTREAL, March 22 (UP)-- The Montreal Canadiens, alternating two goalies, blanked the Boston Bruins, 2-0, tonight in the first game of their Stanley Cup hockey semi-finals.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) Loy W. Henderson, Assistant Secretary of State, testified today that the morale of Foreign Service officers was beginning to recover from the shattering effects of the Government's security program.
The New York Committee of the Frontier Nursing Service will hold its annual benefit spring cocktail party on March 31 in the roof garden of Manhattan House, 200 East Sixtysixth Street.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- The Secretary of Defense said today he would look into the circumstances of a forthcoming magazine story on the tests of the atomic submarine Nautilus, written by her skipper.

FOR eleven days now, stout green canvas has swathed the monument that covers the grave of Etienne Marie Bechet, the Sieur de Rochefontaine, just inside the fence off the Church Street side of St. Paul's Churchyard downtown.

LONDON, March 22--Prices continued to fall today. Further light selling, based on the uncertainty of a General Election date and the new Australian import cuts, lowered both Government and industrial shares. The former however rallied from their lowest prices of the day.
HOUSTON, Tex., March 22-- A dip in business possibly paralleling that of last year was forecast here today by John G. Forrest, financial and business editor of The New York Times.
A "built-in" sauce is among the most delicious of fish sauces, two culinary authorities said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 22--Business activity continued to gain in the first quarter of this year, carrying on the uptrend which marked the closing month of last year, the Government reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22--Warner Brothers and Leland Hayward no longer are looking for a newcomer to introduce as Charles A. Lindbergh in "The Spirit of St. Louis." The role will be played by James Stewart, it was announced today.

War, as seen by the surgeon, is the subject of two books on John. Day's autumn schedule. One volume will be Maj. Paul Grauwin's account of the seige of Dienbienphu in Indochina. The author was chief surgeon of the French forces there.

A young sergeant stationed at Fort Dix, Emanuel Hochfeld, and his team-mates led a field of thirty-seven teams of bridge experts at the end of play last night in the annual team-of-four contest for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- David Dubinsky reported to the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union today that reserves in health, welfare and retirement funds totaled $146,653,949. This is an increase of $17,000,000 over the previous year.
MIAMI BEACH, March 22 (AP) --Doris Hart of Coral Gables and Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, the top-seeded players, easily defeated their opponents today in the Good Neighbor tennis tournament.
PANAMA, March 22--The chief counsel of Jose Ramon Guizado, former President of Panama, expressed doubt today that his client would be acquitted in the assassination of President Jose Antonio Remon.

Nine rounds of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata were completed when an adjourned seventhround game was played yesterday, according to a report from Buenos Aires. Herman Pilnik of Argentina registered a draw against Boris DeGreiff of Colombia.

ALBANY, March 22--Republicans abandoned today their proposal to use a new valuation base for computing "fair" rentals for apartment houses. The change will enable hundreds of thousands of tenants in Brooklyn, Queens, Richmond and upstate counties to avoid substantial rent increases. It would have made little difference in Manhattan or the Bronx.

The prospect of early ratification of the Paris pacts by France promises to create a new situation in Europe. This situation will call for a new Western initiative to achieve the main objective of these pacts. This objective is not to wage war but to wage peace.
ALBANY, March 22--A bill offered as the state's major weapon against obscene and objectionable "comic books" was approved unanimously by the Assembly today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 20--The Dutch Government has embarked on a modest counter - inflation program. The aim is to preserve the broad base of prosperity, a stable economy and a high standard of living.

Many dinner parties will be given on Friday at the Bal des Berceaux in the St. Regis Roof. The event, under the auspices of the Committee of French American Wives, will further the organization's program of postwar relief in France and the Far East.
Newly adopted rule changes will be in effect during the EastWest college All-Star basketball game at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.
PARIS, March 22--Francis Perrin, French High Commissioner for Atomic Energy, said today that France would have an atomic power plant fully working by July, 1956.
PARIS, March 22--The fate of the agreements to arm West Germany within the Atlantic alliance probably will be determined here this week.

An elderly, gray-haired woman, identified tentatively as a housemaid, died under a crosstown bus last night clutching a paper shopping bag that contained $21,617 in cash. The straw-handled bag also held a loaf of bread and two deposit books showing $14,575 in savings accounts.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- Repeal of two costly "sleepers" recently discovered in last year's omnibus tax revision law was unanimously approved today by the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives.
The Prospect Park greenhouses in Brooklyn, built seventy-five years ago, will be closed and dismantled after the final Easter show in the park.

Walter Hautzig, Vienna-born pianist, was the soloist last night when the National Orchestral Association gave the third concert of its Tuesday evening series at Carnegie Hall. He played Prokofieff's First Piano Concerto and a minor Beethoven work that he had the enterprise to dig up himself.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)--Following is a list of those killed in the crash today of the Navy transport plane into a Hawaiian mountaintop, as released by the Defense Department: AIR FORCE ALEXANDER, A/1C Alvin, son of Mrs. Catherine Alexander, 43-06 Forty-fifth Street, Sunnyside, Queens, and of Antonio A. Alexander,
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 22-- Two more Arab attacks in Israeli territory north of the Jordanian rump were reported by the Army here today.
ALBANY, March 22 (AP)--The Norwegian motor vessel Heina, which delivered a cargo of goat hair from behind the Iron Curtain to Philadelphia last week, is under a security patrol in the Port of Albany.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- President Eisenhower was asked today to spare the White House gray squirrels.
MEXICO CITY, March 22 (AP) --Mrs. Pat McCormick, the Olympic champion, captured the women's three-meter diving title is the United States swept the first three places at the PanAmerican Games today.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- More than 40 per cent of American families have incomes exceeding $5,000 a year, the Commerce Department said today.
CHICAGO, March 22 (AP)--Buyers were eager to obtain various classes of livestock today as snow, cold weather and wind were expected to cut shipments to market in the next few days.

YESTERDAY (March 22, 1955) THE GOVERNOR Approved thirty minor bills. Vetoed two bills, including one to permit sale of liquor on credit by restaurants and bars. Had Eugene Black, president of the World Bank, as his luncheon guest.

Republican legislative leaders of both houses at Albany are backing a bill introduced on Monday dealing with the operation of union health and welfare funds--a stronger one than a Democratic administration measure already in the hopper.
A CONFLICT in program schedules deprived many viewers of an opportunity to sea two interesting plays on television Monday night.

LONDON, March 22--Two of the most powerful trade unions affiliated with the Labor party urged the party's National Executive Committee today not to expel Aneurin Bevan. The committee is to meet tomorrow to consider disciplinary action against the leader of the leftwing of the party.
SLOATSBURG, N. Y., March 22--Plans for a new textile plant to continue this community's principal industry were announced today. Fire destroyed the Sloatsburg Mill early Sunday.

TOKYO, March 22--United States policy on Formosa is compounded of two separate and conflicting elements, strategic interest and political emotion. The derivative, when stirred in the cocktail shaker of American internal politics, becomes confusing.
Television will be used for the first time next month to help select principals for the city's public school system.

A new issue of $20,000,000 of sinking fund debentures of the Joy Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of mining and other industrial equipment, will be placed on the market today by a banking syndicate headed by Hallgarten Co., R. W. Pressprich Co. and Adamex Securities Corporation.
A five-day Jail sentence was imposed yesterday on William J. Keating, who had exposed a wiretap scandal that he said had been hushed up by police and telephone company officials.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was most encouraging to read in The New York Times of March 18 the front page headlines, "President to Ask More Aid for Asia." It is good to know that at last the Administration seems to have agreed upon an Asian economic aid program, even though the Congressional approval and execution of it have yet to be worked out.
Mayor Wagner has appraised his first year in office as "a year of solid accomplishment," laying the foundation for better city government in the future.
UTRECHT, the Netherlands, March 22--The international Utrecht Trade Fair opened here today with the big pavilion of the Soviet Union dominating the foreign exhibits.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 22 (AP)--Arnold Johnson, the Kansas City Athletics' owner, today sold the Yankee Stadium to John M. Cox of Chicago for an undisclosed sum.
YESTERDAY (March 22, 1955) TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Council adopted recommendations on French Togoland. Concluded general debate on Ruanda-Urundi under Belgian administration.
New motion-picture equipment, including a screen sixty-four feet wide, is being installed in the Paramount Theatre to accommodate the VistaVision wide-screen process.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 22-- Many vitamin preparations contain substances not yet proved to have nutritional value, Prof. L. A. Maynard, director of the School of Nutrition, said here today.
WASHINGTON, March 22--A Republican foreign policy leader proposed today a five-point program of "partnership" assistance to underdeveloped countries.
The bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation provided a new transit headache for the Board of Estimate yesterday.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., March 22--Despite strong protests from American Legion leaders, the Board of Education here will permit two controversial motion pictures to be shown in the junuior high school Friday night.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) Senator John L. McClellan, chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, charged today that someone on the Army Personnel Board that handled the case of of former Maj. Irving Peress had been "derelict in his duty."
The Du Mont television network, which has aroused speculation by its sporadic cutbacks of live programs, is basing its future primarily on film shows.
LONDON, March 22--Sir Winston Churchill warned an old political foe today not to be misled by "the chatter in the press" about his retirement.

MONTE CARLO, March 22-- A French contract bridge team, led by the veteran star Pierre Albarran, took an early lead this afternoon in the 1955 Monte Carlo open team-of-four championship. M. Albarran and his team-mates, Henri Swarc, Roger Trezel, Pierre Jais and Boris Koytchou, earned ninety-one match points to outscore a field of thirty-four internationally known teams.
Bonwit Teller's warm-weather maternity clothes are so enchanting that it seems a shame to confine them just to expectant mothers.

ALBANY, March 22 -- New York City obtained today half of the legislative approval needed to tear down the Third Avenue elevated structure. The Assembly approved by a vote of 125 to 16. The Senate has still to act.

Newspaper advertising in fiftytwo cities in February came to 194,394,576 lines, an increase of 7.6 per cent over the 1954 month. For two months the total was 390,598,584 lines, an increase of 7.4 percent. The slightly sharper increase in February over the two-month rise indicates an uptrend.

The bizarre development of jazz--from its lowly origin in New Orleans in the early years of this century until it swept the country like wildfire--will be encompassed in a musical. The untitled show is scheduled for production next season by the Playwrights Company.

WASHINGTON, March 22--Senate Democrats began today an attempt to connect President Eisenhower with the Yalta conference. They suggested as well that another Republican, General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, had been involved, too.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 22--Most of the diplomats here, struggling to make ends meet, are irked because their Communist landlords are raising the rent.

DETROIT, March 22 (UP)-- Dutch Reibel and Gordie Howe blazed in two goals apiece tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 7-4 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the opening game of their Stanley Cup hockey semi-finals before a crowd of 12.190 at Olympia.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- The Supreme Court rescheduled arguments in the school segregation cases today to begin April 11.
How man cuts through the skin of the earth for the lifegiving fluid of the machine age --oil--is the plot of a new show opening here today.

The official report on the effectiveness of the Salk anti-polio vaccine, tested last year on 440,000 children in 217 areas in the United States, will be presented April 12. That date is the tenth anniversary of the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt.
The New York Rangers, once again an also ran in the National Hockey League this season, had a big hand in helping Bernie Geoffrion and Terry Sawchuk win the league's two top awards.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 --Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, predicted today a brighter era for West Coast shipbuilding.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- The State Department said today it was "in harmony" with Senator Walter F. George in his proposal for a Big Four meeting once France had ratified the Paris agreements.
The stock market recovered most of Monday's losses in quiet trading yesterday.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building for ninety-five families at 175 West Seventy-sixth Street, northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue, has been sold by Armino A. Campagna, builder, and Frederick Mortati, operator.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 22-- "Unless the Dodgers get all their arms broke, they gotta win the pennant," Chuck Dressen said today. Dressen's Senators then beat the Brooks, 4--3, in a teninning exhibition baseball game at Tinker Field.
YESTERDAY (March 22, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Talked with Republican leaders of Congress. Callers included John Sherman Cooper, Representative Frances P. Bolton and Harold E. Stassen.

SAIGON, March 22--Premier Ngo Dinh Diem was expected today to seek a political settlement of his differences with armed Opposition groups. It was plain, however, that he would have difficulty in arranging a deal without virtually turning over the country to his rivals.
Cotton futures declined 10 to 18 points (50 to 90 cents a bale) on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, March 22-- The National Council of Jewish Women urged today establishment of a single agency in each state to coordinate efforts to combat juvenile delinquency.

A fascinating o'pera, Monteverdi's "The Coronation of Poppea," which had its world premiere in Italy in 1642, was given an engrossing performance by the American Opera Society last night to Town Hall.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 22 --About 25,000 Government employes have been on strike for eight days. Rail traffic throughout the country has been paralyzed and vital public services, such as customs and prison administration, have been crippled.
Yesterday, as though it had been saving it for a rainy day, the Long Island Rail Road made a pleasant announcement. It is about to improve its daytime passenger schedules.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- United States citizens who lost money as a result of the Bolshevik revolution of 1917 may get some compensation.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey invited Congress today to raise the Federal gasoline tax to provide revenue for President Eisenhower's proposed $101,000,000,000 highways program.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- The House voted today to permit the Government to dispose of twenty-four wartime synthetic rubber plants at a sales price of $259,829,000.
MOSCOW, March 22 -- Three Soviet Foreign Ministry officials who are well known to Western diplomats were promoted today.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- Aviation circles reported today a trend to concentrate with Northwest Orient Airlines more than $15,000,000 worth of annual military airmail shipments across the Pacific Ocean.
Three teen-agers were rescued early yesterday morning from a cave under the Henry Hudson Parkway in Washington Heights where they had been accidentally entombed for more than two days.
HONG KONG, March 22--A new food austerity campaign is getting under way in Communist China amid continuing efforts to raise capital surpluses to their highest point for planned industrialization.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) --The Federal Power Commission asked today that Congress take away its power to set the price for natural gas sold by producers to interstate pipelines.
CHICAGO, March 22 (UP)-- Spring blizzards and windstorms dealt death and destruction in the Midwest and Ohio Valley today. Floods plagued the South.
BERLIN, March 22--The son of a Soviet Air Force officer has received political asylum in the United States sector of Berlin.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- The merger of the Boston and Albany Railroad and two smaller New England carriers into the New York Central System was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 22--A warning that "the mad scramble for volume" might result in some automobile dealer casualties was sounded here tonight.
A plea for "impartiality" by the United States in its dealings with the Arab states and Israel was made yesterday by Rabbi Irving Miller, chairman of the American Zionist Council.
A HIGHLIGHT of the program that the Composers Group of New York presented at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening was Judith Dvorkin's Song Cycle for Mezzo-soprano, based on poems of Mark van Doren.

HONOLULU, March 22--A Navy DC-6, seven miles off course on its approach to a landing at Hickam Air Base, crashed into a cliff near here today, killing all sixty-six persons aboard. It was the worst disaster in Hawaiian aviation history.

Commodity futures generally rose yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume improved in most markets. Cocoa, coffee, sugar, potatoes, cottonseed oil, hides, soybean oil and burlap advanced; copper and wool ended mixed, and rubber and zinc declined.

CHICAGO, March 22--The net income of Sears, Roebuck Co. after taxes was $141,343,003, equal to $5.82 a share, in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31. It compared with $117,882,302, or $4.87 a share, in 1953.
WASHINGTON, March 22--A plan to give bigger appeal to the new military Reserve program was put before Congress today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22--The New York Yankees got their first long look at Don Larsen in a Yankee uniform today.
Employes of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railroad are receiving less than the national wage standard, William F. Mathieson, vice president and general auditor, disclosed yesterday.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 22 (AP)--Top-seeded Katharine Hubbell of Conway, N. H., and second-seeded Mildred Thornton of Ormond Beach, Fla., today led the advance through the singles quarter-finals in the women's national indoor tennis championship.
THE great Dutch painter Vincent Van Gogh (18531890) is the subject of a large loan exhibition opening today at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixtyfourth Street.
Automatic equipment in factories, which is bringing about a new industrial revolution, was viewed by engineers yesterday as providing more and better products for more people at less cost.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22--The rookie crop has been a singularly lush one this spring and the harvest should be rich this fall. But the fellow who has excited the most conversation and the most extravagant praise--at least he has in this neck of the woods--is Kenton Lloyd Boyer, the 23-yearold third baseman of the St. Louis Cardinals.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 22-- Today was an open date in the Giant exhibition schedule. Not a wheel turned in camp. Most of the players loafed. A few took part in a golf tournament that Horace C. Stoneham, the Giant owner, staged at the near-by Paradise Valley Country Club.
CHICAGO, March 22--Irregular fluctuations marked trading in grain and soybean futures here today. March wheat and March soybeans showed strength, as holdings were evened in the expiring deliveries.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- Whatever may be wrong with the stock market, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee heard today, it is not lack of laws and regulations.
A man wielding an eight-inch butcher knife ran amok in the Bronx last night and allegedly stabbed five persons after a delicatessen owner turned down his demand for $5.

In his annual message to the City Council last year, a month after taking office, Mayor Wagner expressed the hope that "when I return to this chamber next year I will be able to report a record of accomplishment in which we can all take pride."
The Federal Communications Commission has denied a coastwise shipowner's application to replace radiotelegraph equipment with radiotelephone. The application was by Oliver J. Olson Co.

THE first major exhibition in America of work by Robert Delaunay (1885-1941) will open to the public today at the Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue. It has been assembled with considerable difficulty from public and private collections in Europe and in the United States.
Born of one investigation of the stock market, the Securities and Exchange Commission was in the spotlight of another yesterday.
There was all manner of work for Red Cross volunteers in Brooklyn yesterday as the borough chapter settled into its new $750,000 quarters.

ALTHOUGH the weather has done nothing to brighten prospects for the opening of the trout season, the correspondence flowing from anglers who plan fishing on the initial day--rain or shine--is as high as the Esopus with the portal open.

Plans for building a sixteenstory and penthouse apartment structure at the northwest corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Third Avenue were announced yesterday in connection with the leasing of a site there from the Rhode Island Corporation, representing the Robert Walton Goelet Estate.

ONE evening last summer when my wife and I went out to dinner at a friend's we met a young man whose first novel had just been accepted for publication. There was nothing remarkable about this because hundreds of first novels are published every year and a critic who does not lead the life of an anchorite is certain to meet a few of their authors.

GENEVA, March 22--Trade experts say Australia has provided a dramatic illustration of why world trade could become chaotic quickly if the leading Western nations did not adhere to a common set of rules.
A pelting rain, which later turned to drizzle and fog, brought a fall of 1.42 inches here yesterday. This made it the rainiest March 22 on record, surpassing a city mark that goes back to 1887.
Louis E. Wolfson brought his battle for control of Montgomery Ward Co. to New York yesterday. It proved to be one of the liveliest coffee get-togethers the Florida industrialist has yet staged.
LONDON, March 22--The United States Government changed its mind over the "untimely" publication of the Yalta conference documents, Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today.
Pennsylvania Railroad became yesterday the first Eastern railroad to order a new lightweight passenger train. Delivery is expected early in 1956 from the Budd Co.
WASHINGTON, March 22-- President Eisenhower warned today that the fight against communism would be lost unless freer world trade were achieved.

SYRACUSE, March 22 (UP)-- The Syracuse Nationals led most of the way tonight to beat the Boston Celtics, 110-100, in the first game of the Eastern finals in the National Basketball Association play-offs.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 22 (AP)--An atomic cloud sprinkled light radioactive particles on Las Vegas today. The authorities, however, said there was no danger to civilians or to Marines maneuvering at the test site.

LONDON, March 22--The Government, defeated today a plea that all nuclear tests be halted until an international scientists' conference had determined the cumulative effect of radiation on unborn generations.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The initiative of Senator Walter F. George in calling for early conversations with Russia is to be welcomed.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP)--The Senate decided today to postpone action on a bill to increase 1955 cotton acreage until cotton-state Senators could agree on what the increase should be.
The tempo in the Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke vice trial speeded up yesterday as three witnesses testified and Pat Ward, the principal prosecution witness, made a surprise return appearance.

Pakistan's Supreme Court in overruling a decision of the Provincial Court of Sind Province has wisely sidestepped some of the niceties of constitutional law and met the problem on a common-sense basis. The Governor General has dissolved the National Assembly and dismissed some of the provincial Ministers.

NOW that the flounder fishing is improving on Great South Bay and Peconio Bay and school stripers are being picked up at a few points on the western end of Long Island Sound, the salt water fishing season officially is open.

MIAMI BEACH, March 23 (UP)--Lionel Hebert of Erie, Pa., fired a 7-under-par 65 today to win top pro money in the $1,500 Miami Beach pro-amateur golf tournament. Hebert became one of the favorites for the Miami Beach open that gets under way tomorrow.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
TRENTON, March 23 -- The South Amboy Trust Company denied today any responsibility for the asserted disappearance of $300,000 in state deposits.
WASHINGTON, March 23-- President Eisenhower opposed today the use of the Yalta papers for partisan advantage.

A single case, statisticians warn us, is not necessarily representative and is a dangerous basis for generalization. Yet the single case of Valery A. Lysikov, the 17-year-old son of a Soviet lieutenant colonel, who escaped to the West in Berlin last week, has important and hopeful significance which even the most cautious must recognize.
WASHINGTON, March 23-- Congress was urged today to investigate "financial raiding" of old established companies.

Financial executives of advertising agencies were urged yesterday to acquire "a profound knowledge of what the modern agency aims to do for its clients." To the extent that a client ceases to be "a number in the ledger or a source of income," said Lawrence Valenstein, president of Grey Advertising Agency, better service will be rendered to the client and in turn to the agency itself.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of March 14 entitled "Freedom Agenda" is calculated to create considerable misunderstanding concerning the policy of the National Society, Daughters of the American Revolution, with respect to activities outside its immediate control.
Herbs should be used sparingly. They also should be bought sparingly, for a large collection of them can grow stale through lack of use.
The design of a computing device with intelligence enough to make mistakes and make a fool of itself, like a human being, is one ultimate goal in modern electronic computor design.
Spring cleaning was busting out all over Governors Island yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- New crop wheat deliveries showed strength today, with what appeared to be considerable backspreading between May and the new crop months. Buying was based on unfavorable reports from the Southwest, where damage is beginning to show up with growing weather.

MIAMI BEACH, March 23 (UP)--Unranked Jerry DeWitts of San Francisco upset the Mexican national champion, Mario Llamas, 4--6, 6--2, 1--5, today in the second round of the Good Neighbor tennis tournament.
ALBANY, March 23--Republicans are moving tomorrow for a showdown with Governor Harriman, a Democrat, on state aid for schools.

A five-story apartment house accommodating thirty-one families at 2554-2560 Hudson Boulevard in Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the 2554 Boulevard Corporation to Harry Some. The seller acquired the property about two years ago through J. I. Kislak, Inc., also the broker in the present transaction.

CHICAGO, March 23--The Art Institute of Chicago announced today acquisition of "The Crucifixion," a masterpiece painted by Francisco de Zurbaran. He was one of the four great names in Spanish art of the seventeenth century.

WASHINGTON, March 23-- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 16:
The net salvage value of rails, ties and bridges covering 660 miles of track of the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway was put at slightly over $2,000,000 yesterday.
CAIRO, March 23 -- Egypt's efforts to form an Arab defense grouping to counter the IraqiTurkish pact are close to failure, in the opinion of diplomatic observers here.

WASHINGTON, March 23-- President Eisenhower reiterated today this country would not use atomic weapons in a "police action" but declined to predict how he would characterize a fight over Quemoy and Matsu.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 23 (UP) -- John W. Roberts, the Southern senior golf champion, today defeated Tom Robbins, Larchmont, N. Y., in twenty-six holes. It was the longest match in the history of the American Senior Golf Association championship.
Sharp criticism of the uniform code of military justice has been expressed by the Judge Advocate General of the Navy, Rear Admiral Ira H. Nunn.
ST. LOUIS, March 23--The 103-year-old St. Louis GlobeDemocrat was sold today to Samuel I. Newhouse, owner of nine other newspapers in the East and one in the Far West.
Active cotton futures rose 10 to 12 points (50 to 60 cents a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
MOSCOW, March 23--Two young Americans have been stopping traffic in Moscow for the last two days.

Overcrowding in the city jails has produced "unspeakable and unprintable" conditions, Commissioner of Correction Anna M. Kross declared yesterday. With 8,000 prisoners in 4,200 cells, a census figure of last summer, and with one custodian to take care of 240 inmates, it is impossible even to know what is going on, she said.

Sixty-two bridge teams, representing commercial and industrial concerns, began play last night in cpmpetition for the American Contract Bridge League's Eastern Commercial Trophy. The event was part of the Eastern States Bridge Tournament, which began at the McAlpin Hotel last Friday.
ALBANY, March 23--The controversial issue of Panther Mountain Dam will go to the people next fall.

Malcolm Bersohn, who was released by the Chinese Communists Feb. 27 after three and a half years' imprisonment on charges of spying, arrived here by air yesterday. At New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, he read to reporters about two pages of a five-page hand-written statement in praise of the Communists.
More than a hundred girl students from Alfred, N. Y., have defied their boy friends while visiting here. All have had their hair cut.
YESTERDAY (March 23, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Signed Executive Order authorizing the Secretary of the Interior to approve obligation and spending of funds by the Virgin Islands Government.

Air-Way Electric Appliance Stockholders of the Air-Way Electric Appliance Corporation changed the corporate name to Air-Way Industries, Inc., at the annual meeting in Toledo, Ohioyesterday. They also authorized an increase in the common stock from 400,000 to 1, 200,000 shares and an issuance of 100,000 shares of a new $50 par value preferred stock.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Both houses of the Legislature voted unanimously today to grant larger personal income tax deductions for medical expenses, for the aged and the blind and for working mothers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have been reading with considerable interest the recent reports on the activities of Harris J. Klein in regard to the award of contracts by the New York City Transit Authority for consulting engineering work.
Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, was critical last night of the support President Eisenhower had given his own program for a liberalization of tariffs.
Adele Simpson shows suit jackets both long and short this spring--but neither tunic-length nor so short as to cause comment. Her waistlines are not pinched in and are seldom boxed, but gently molded.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 23--Albert William Kaline, then 15 years old, was dropped from his high school baseball squad as a pitcher. He later reported with the infielders and was cut again. But when one of the outfielders broke a leg, Kaline wangled his way back onto the squad. By the season's end this precocious youngster, a mere freshman, had been named to the all-state team, an honor he was to gain for four straight years.

Bertram D. Tallamy, chairman of the State Thruway Authority, yesterday urged rapid construction of the Federal interstate highway system. He said that the 40,000-mile route would help reduce accidents and would be a vital contribution to the national economy by accelerating traffic.

A group of six four-story store and commercial buildings on plot 127 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and East Seventh Street has been sold by a client of Robert Lands, attorney, to Harry Horwitz, operator.
A 45-year-old patrolman, paralyzed from the waist down by a bandit's bullet in 1939, was responsible yesterday for the arrest of a man charged with robbing his hospital room.
ALBANY, March 23 (UP)--The State Commerce Department received today the following reports from operators of ski areas: Bearpen Mountain -- 2-6 inches powder snow, 2-28 old; skiing fair.
LONDON, March 23--The stock markets were a little brighter today in quiet trading although early gains were not all held. Business volume dropped to the lowest point of the year.
BONN, Germany, March 23-- A principal member of the government's military planning organization has been dismissed in a disagreement over strategic concepts.
A Bronx homicide was "solved" yesterday for the second time in nine days.

LEWISTON, Me., March 23 (AP) --Consolidated Textile swamped the Bates Manufacturing stockholders' meeting with proxies yesterday and left no doubt it could shape Bates' destiny by dint of voting power.

BONN, Germany, March 23 (AP)--Allied officials have pieced together one chapter of the story of what happens to defectors from the West. This chapter deals with the Bautzen camp in East Germany, a camp described as a Communist indoctrination center.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) --Republican women leaders from eighteen states praised President Eisenhower today for appointing a "Secretary of Peace" to study world disarmament problems.
Sales and earnings of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., for the twentysix and fifty-two weeks ended on Jan. 29 were larger than those for the corresponding periods of the preceding year.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) The House voted today to overhaul the State Department's Foreign Service by weeding out "deadwood" and increasing pay and other benefits to attract top grade men.

The Brother Sewing Machine Manufacturing Company, Ltd.., said to be Japan's largest producer of sewing machines, will seek to sell $20,000,000 of its products a year in this country in the next two years.
Gold and silver and ivory treasure of the Near East will be on exhibition today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

PANAMA, March 23--Former President Jose Ramon Guizado said today that he knew there had been a plan to overthrow the Government of President Jose Antonio Remon but that he, Senor Guizado, had paid no attention to it.

What is described as the largest deal in the oil industry of its kind ever to be transacted took place yesterday in Philadelphia. Sinclair Oil and Gas Company, subsidiary of Sinclair Oil Corporation, completed acquisition of American Republics Corporation for $108,000,000.
SECURITY COUNCIL Council heard statements by Israel and Egypt on recent clash in Gaza area.
Children in the first and second grades in 1,058 city schools will receive injections of the Salk anti-polio vaccine starting April 25, if the serum is found to be effective.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 23 (AP)--Queen Hopeful chalked up the seventh stakes success of the season for the Hasty House Farms today. She defeated seven other fillies and mares in the $18,150 Suwannee River Handicap before 15,088 at Gulfstream Park.

In all but the strictly orthodox Jewish homes the can opener has replaced chopping bowls meat grinders and other tool that were essential when al Passover foods had to be prepared from scratch. Each year-- and this one is no exception-- more new canned and packaged products appear to reduce to a minimum home cooking for the happy holiday.

The much-studied legislation to provide New York with modern, uniform traffic rules still is bogged down in Albany. Although it has been endorsed by every major organization interested in highway safety and was recommended by Governor Harriman, there still is no indication that it even will be acted upon this year.
ALBANY, March 23 (AP)--The Assembly voted today to extend the harness racing season in New York State. The measure, passed previously by the Senate, was sent to Governor Harriman.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On the editorial page of your issue of Feb. 21 you ask: "If it is wrong to refuse to testify against one's self is it also wrong to object to unlawful search and seizure, to the taking of property without due process of law, to the deprival of trial by jury * * *?"
ALBANY, March 23--State University officials today urged Governor Harriman to support a $250,000,000 bond issue for university construction projects.
A system of collective bargaining for public school teachers was urged yesterday by the Teachers Guild, A. F. L.
WASHINGTON, March 23-- The Government today made 150,000,000 pounds of aluminum available to industrial users to relieve a tight situation in the domestic market for that metal.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23--Their biggest inning of the spring, an eight-run eighth, gave the Yankees a 10-4 victory over the Washington Senators today.
THE vast, slow-moving panorama of "Parsifal" was unfolded at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time this season.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP)--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy renewed today his angry dispute with Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker. The general figured in censure charges against the Wisconsin Republican last year.
ALBANY, March 23--A state elementary algebra examination is in preparation for use in high schools next June. It will be the first such test in many years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23--Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, first to follow Twentieth Century-Fox into CinemaScope, has decided to do some experimenting with the process. It will be used with black-and-white photography for "Trial."
Scandinavian Airlines System will increase its transpolar air service between Los Angeles and Copenhagen to three flights a week in both directions on April 19.

WASHINGTON, March 23--Sharp opposition to recent cuts in defense and to tax reductions while the Federal budget is out of balance was voiced today by Bernard M. Baruch. The 84-year-old financier and adviser of Presidents declared that the "tough plant of confidence" was nurtured first by the adequacy of national defense and second by the credit of the Government.

The coordinated campaign of city agencies against dirt is showing encouraging signs of gathering power and effectiveness. Special credit at the moment goes to Chief Magistrate Murtagh and his colleagues, who are imposing heavy fines-- mostly $25--on the several hundred offenders a day who are now receiving summonses.
ALBANY, March 23--Legislation permitting New York City to increase its taxes by $60,500,000 a year was approved tonight by the Assembly Rules Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The House of Representatives imposed upon its investigating committees today a minimum code of fair dealing with witnesses and those accused.
New light was thrown yesterday on the puzzle of how an 80year-old woman who had worked as a domestic for the last twenty years accumulated savings of more than $36,000.
ALBANY, March 23--Covernor Harriman announced tonight that an agreement had been reached on legislation to end sick-leave abuses in tha New York City transit system.

The New York City Housing Authority yesterday invited bids by March 31 for $5,440,000 of notes. The proceeds would provide temporary financing of Mill Brook Houses, a state-aided lowrent project in the Bronx. The notes will-be dated May 2 and will come due Nov. 28.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur said yesterday that he would have opposed seeking Soviet entry into the war against Japan at the "late date" of the Yalta conference. He said his views on the February, 1945, meeting of President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin had never been sought.

Following is the text of a statement on the Yalta conference issued yesterday by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur and distributed by The Associated Press: Neither directly nor indirectly did I have the slightest connection with the Yalta conference.
WASHINGTON, March 23-- The Senate Finance Committee delivered an ultimatum today to John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, on the reciprocal trade bill.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the reconsideration now being given to the question of medical service for veterans a vital point often seems to be overlooked.
MEXICO CITY, March 23 (AP) --Jimmy McLane and Frank E. McKinney Jr. splashed to two more championships for the United States today in the swimming competition of the PanAmerican Games.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The postal pay increase bill developed today into a major fight between the White House and Congress.

CHICAGO, March 23 (UP) -- Willie Pastrano, a 19-year-old fighter with speed to burn, scored his ninth straight victory tonight. He earned a unanimous ten-round decision over Al Andrews in the Chicago Stadium.

The First Army is sprucing up three of its camps. At Fort Dix, N. J., $3,100,000 is being spent to modernize 181 barracks buildings and to refurbish the mess halls. A spokesman at Governors Island said yesterday that the rest of a $3,600,000 allocation would be used at Fort Monmouth, N. J., and Fort Devens, Mass.
Communist China's expansion in Asia and the consequent dangers to world peace were discussed yesterday by Lindesay Parrott, former head of the Tokyo bureau of The New York Times.
Northbound vessels may now transit the Suez Canal with a draft up to thirty-five feet, it has been announced by the Suez Canal Company.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 23--The Dodgers had another big day at Holman Stadium today, beating Lou Boudreau's lowly Athletics, 15--4. But the important item for Manager Walt Alston was the pitching of Don Newcombe.
Liquidation of a veteran American shipping concern is nearing the final stage, according to Jerome A. Newman, president of Atlantic Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 23 (UP)--An underground atomic test explosion tore open the Nevada desert like a volcano today.

An increase of 529,000 barrels last week in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were again at a new high, 183,953,000 barrels, compared with 183,424,000 a week earlier, the previous high, and 177,620,000 a year earlier.

Five years after its most critical water shortage, New York City is swimming in water wealth. Its Croton and Catskill reservoirs were filled to 95.1 per cent of capacity yesterday. At 8 A. M. supplies were measured at 240,850,000,000 gallons. Capacity is 253,136,000,000 gallons. The driving rains of Monday and Tuesday added 2,585,000,000 gallons to the city's reserves in twenty-four hours.
WASHINGTON, March 23-- President Eisenhower supported today the idea of exploratory talks with the Soviet Union, Britain and France on all questions affecting world peace.
The probationary patrolman who killed a 15-year-old boy in Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on a charge of manslaughter in the first degree.

UNDER the title "Word Becomes Image," an exhibition of prints, drawings and illustrated books from the collections of the Metropolitan Museum has been arranged around the balcony of the great hall of the museum by Edward Fenton of the print department.

Prices of Commodities futures moved irregularly on the New York exchanges yesterday in generally dull trading. Sugar, potatoes, hides, rubber, silk, burlap and tin ended higher and cocoa, coffee, wool, zinc, copper, cottonseed oil and soybean oil closed lower.
Edmund A. Krider, president of Montgomery Ward Co., charged yesterday that Louis E. Wolfson was conducting "not a proxy contest" but a "raid" on the big mail-order house.
LONDON, March 23--Clement R. Attlee, leader of the Labor party, rescued Aneurin Bevan, his most formidable rival, from almost certain expulsion from the Labor party today.
The growing importance of plastic and synthetic materials for use in home furnishings was pointed up by awards announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 23-- The penguins captured by the Navy last month have been sentenced to "life" in a glass-enclosed, air-conditioned cell. But it is for their own good.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23--Israel asked Egypt today to renounce "useless hostility" and join her in a code for peace in the Middle East.

The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad is planning to sell a new issue of $35,000,000 of secured serial notes to raise money to help retire $40,000,000 of the company's outstanding collateral trust 4 per cent bonds due Jan. 1, 1865.
MOSCOW, March 23 (UP)-- The Soviet Union said today that the secret Yalta documents were released by Washington without the Kremlin's agreement.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 23-- The Giants today went back to putting the Indians in their place. That seems to be one of the Polo Grounders' easiest accomplishments.
A program to develop the fringe areas of Fifty-seventh Street to the same high standards as the main section of the thoroughfare has been started by the Fifth Avenue Association.
Women's increasing importance may be increasing men's ulcers.

DECAUSE of their generally pleasant air and their faithfulness to models, Isabella Markell's portraits and flower pieces at the Iolas Gallery, 46 East Fifty-seventh Street, are likely to appeal to a wide taste.

With a warning from Premier Faure that France faces a decisive moment in her history, the French Council of the Republic has at last plunged into the final debate on the Paris pacts creating a Western European Union and accepting a virtually sovereign and rearmed Germany as an equal partner in the North Atlantic alliance.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) --Following is a stenographic transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. All but the last question and answer was released for direct quotation and public viewing. The last question and answer are indirect discourse, according to White House rules.
The "Fulbright cloud," as one prominent Wall Street investment adviser called it, lifted from over the stock market yesterday.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 23-- Indian women, contrary to popularly held ideas, were powerful political and social forces, according to Dr. Erl Bates, Cornell University expert on Indians.
Tennessee Williams new play, "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," costarring Barbara Bel Geddes and Burl Ives, opens at the Morosco Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock under the auspices of the Playwrights Company.

Josette and Yvette Roman, French duo-pianists, gave their first local recital in five years last night in Town Hall. Their playing has not changed much in the interim. Ensemble remains perfect, musical approach is of a light, salon nature.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 23-- A former Navy landing ship is being loaded with a drilling rig here for use on the Texas Company's 2,500,000-acre oil concession in Peru. Another cargo of drilling equipment has just left here by air for Brazil.
The great migration to the suburbs has had far-reaching social and economic effects.

SEATTLE, March 23--A scientific conference, planned for April 7 and 8 at the University of Washington, has been called off because seven Eastern scientists refused to participate in it, the university announced today.

ON Sept. 18, Greta Garbo, a woman whose person (easily encompassed) and personality (never quite grasped) have probably evoked more rich, beautiful and foolish letters than any of her contemporaries, not excluding the late Ruth Snyder or the queasily gallant Iris March, will be 50 years old.
RABAT, Morocco, March 23-- Francis Lacoste, French Resident General in Morocco, returned today from consultations in Paris to face a critical situation.

Directors of Eastern States Corporation, Maryland investment concern, are proposing a recapitalization of the company to end arrears on the Class A and B preferred shares. The plan is to be voted on by company stockholders on April 13.

The problem of what The to do with the tree Problem stump is not a new Weighed one. It has been mulled over so thoroughly by everyone that conversations beginning without preamble, and cryptically referring to "it," are puzzling only to absolute strangers.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 23--Mrs. Agnes Caldwell Dunlap, clubwoman and historian, died here yesterday in her home at 40 Liberty Avenue. She was the widow of Charles J. Dunlap, lawyer, historian and real estate developer.
THE GOVERNOR Signed twelve minor bills. Held reception for Alan G. Kirk, former Ambassador to Russia. Visitors included a group of United States Savings Bond drive officials headed by J. D. Lockton;

MINNEAPOLIS, March 23 (AP) --Scoring 15 points in overtime, the Minneapolis Lakers tonight defeated the Fort Wayne Pistons, 99--91, in the third game of the National Basketball Association Western Division final play-off.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa has asked the city for more engineers and accountants.
Last year was the most successful in the history of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., which achieved record earnings, revenues and sale in 1954.
PARIS, March 23--Opponents of the treaties to arm West Germany are expected to concentrate on an amendment providing for control of the production, as well as the level, of armaments.

"Science Fiction Theatre," a filmed drama series produced by Ziv Television Programs, Inc., will make its debut over WRCATV on Tuesday, April 12, from 7 to 7:30 P. M. It will replace the "Ella Raines Show" in which Miss Raines plays Janet Dean, registered nurse.
WASHINGTON, March 23-- A little-remembered military operation of World War II that might have cost General Eisenhower his command was recalled by its originator today.

The annual report of the State Power Authority reminds Congress once again that New York is waiting for legislation to permit development of electric power from Niagara Falls and enhance the scenic resources. The issue is inherited from the 1950 International Niagara River Treaty which carried a rider requiring that Congress must pass upon the manner of disposition of additional waters made available to the United States for development of power.
ALBANY, March 23 -- The campaign for more efficiency and more judges in the state's courts cleared one hurdle today and encountered a new one.

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia gained ground in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday, according to a report from Buenos Aires. He triumphed over Hector Rossetto, former champion of Argentina, in the tenth round.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Representative Emanuel Celler called today for an end of Jusice Department wiretapping on its own authority.
WASHINGTON, March 23-- Stability is still the rule in consumer prices, the United States Consumer Price Index showed today.

AN audience of 2,200 assembled at Carnegie Hall last night for the only New York recital Rudolf Serkin is to give this season. Bach, Schubert, Beethoven and Brahms were the pianist's composers of the evening.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP)--Prices of hogs advanced sharply in early dealings today but by the time the last sale was completed about all the early upturn was lost. Prices were $1 higher at the top of $18.60. This was the best price set since Jan. 24 and was $2.60 above the top of two weeks ago. It was paid for one short deck.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 23 (AP)--Boston's five-game winning streak was snapped today by the St. Louis Cardinals, 5 to 4. In defeat, the Red Sox lost the services of Shortstop Milt Bolling for six to eight weeks.

The New York Legislature is showing signs of an increased awareness of the importance of public transportation and the need for taxation relief that will help save bus companies from extinction. Not all bus companies are in trouble, of course, but a recent report by a special committee set up in 1953 by Governor Dewey said that fifty had gone out of business in this state in the last two years.
NEW ORLEANS, March 23-- The United States Government was asked today to intensify its efforts to help develop economic and social stability, and political democracy throughout the world.

Tom Gola, La Salle College's three-time All-America basketball star, has turned professional. The Harlem Globetrotters disclosed yesterday that Gola would captain the College AllStars in a tour with the famed Globetrotters starting Sunday.

The entire ninth floor in the new twenty-two-story office building at 460 Park Avenue has been leased by the Shell Chemical Corporation, a subsidiary of the Shell Oil Company. The lessee will use the space for its agricultural chemical division now located in Denver, Colo.

The long-delayed arbitration of tanker contracts involving the Saudi Arabian Government, the Arabian American Oil Company (Aramco) and Aristotle Socrates Onassis, Greek-Argentine ship operator, is getting under way in Geneva, Switzerland.

MONTE CARLO, March 23-- With only one session remaining to be played, Austria now leads the thirty-four international contract bridge teams in the 1955 Monte Carlo open team-offour championship. Italy, in third place after yesterday's opening play, is now second, while France has dropped to third place.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23--Secretary General Dag Hamarskjold expressed the hope today that the foreign ministers of the sixty members of the United Nations would attend a commemorative meeting of the General Assembly in San Francisco next June.
ALBANY, March 23--The Temporary Rent Commission overrode Democratic objections today and approved a Republicandrafted bill to extend state rent controls for two more years.
ROME, March 23--The Chamber of Deputies speeded Premier Mario Scelba on his way to Ottawa and Washington by giving him its ninth vote of confidence today.
The stock market staged a general advance yesterday, with prices recovering to the best levels in two weeks.
TOKYO, March 23--Relations between Japan and her Communist neighbors improved on several fronts today.
MOSCOW, March 24--Further details of the Soviet proposals made at the secret conference of the United Nations disarmament subcommittee in London were published today in Pravda.

Thomas Smith, Rasmas Parrea and William Ramos won class championships in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior boxing tournament at the New York Athletic Club last night. Smith won the 112-pound title, Parrea the 119-pound and Ramos the 156-pound.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 6 to 9 points yesterday (30 to 40 cents a bale) with the far months showing the most strength.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The people of Korea welcome an opportunity or a measure taken by anyone on either side of the sea calculated to better relations between Korea and Japan. This is not due to any fear of the possible might of Japan, in the near future, or to any hope of momentary gain in exchange of goods between, the two peoples.

Louis E. Wolfson had his say in Wall Street yesterday. As a guest of a joint meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts and the Customers Brokers Association, he spent more than an hour answering questions about what he would do for Montgomery Ward Co. if he won control at the annual meeting on April 22. The meeting was held in Schwartz's Restaurant, 54 Broad Street.

George Sanders, president of the Hudson River Day Line, Inc., announced here yesterday that he had entered into an agreement with the New Jersey Highway Authority providing for the establishment of a ferry service between Cape May, N, J., and Lewes, Del.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 24--It was a silly thing to do. Being an intelligent young man, Del Crandall knew it at the time. But he was young, carefree and a little too proud, perhaps, of being a big leaguer. So he did a foolish thing and came perilously close to ending a career almost before it had begun.
Price changes in fresh foods this week have been largely in direction so welcome to housewives--downward.
MUNICH, Germany, March 24 (AP)--Dr. Otto Gessler, a German Minister of Defense, died of a heart attack at his Lindenberg home near here tonight. His age was 80.
FORT DIX, N. J., March 24-- Two Representatives ate soldiers' chow and marched almost as many miles as newly inducted buck privates during a fourhour tour here today.

LONDON, March 24 (UP)-- Judy Devlin of Baltimore, the defending women's singles champion in the all-England badminton championships, gained the semi-finals today with an 11-4, 11-1 victory over Miss J. R. White of Britain.
IZMIR, Turkey, March 24-- Work began today on western Turkey's first large multipurpose hydroelectric project, patterned after the Tennessee Valley Authority.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 24--A decision to buy the private Dunwoodie Golf Club in Yonkers wag reached this afternoon by top Westchester officials. It will be redeveloped into the first new county park since 1930.

Both the world and domestic sugar contracts were strong yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The 24,150 tons traded on the No. 6 market was the third largest volume of the year and the 18,550 tons exchanging hands on the No. 4 contract was the fourth highest number of sales.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- President Eisenhower will brief Congressional leaders of both major parties next week on foreign policy, including participation in a Big Four conference.
The Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., yesterday worked out the details of a new sick-leave plan that is expected to save $3,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) --Following is the 51-39 rollcall vote by which the Senate defeated today a bill that would have increased cotton and wheat acreage allotments:

The big piece on last night's program of the Philharmonic- Symphony, conducted by Guido Cantelli, was Beethoven's Seventh Symphony. The unusual one was an excerpt from Vivaldi's "The Seasons." Only two weeks ago Mr. Cantelli and his concertmaster, John Corigliano, presented the first two movements of the score, "Spring and Summer."
WASHINGTON, March 24-- President Eisenhower didn't put the finger on the White House squirrels for nibbling his putting green.
MOSCOW, March 24--Vyacheslav M. Molotov today, invited Austrian Chancellor Julius Raab here to discuss the long-pending Austrian state treaty.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Senators inquiring into the operation of union welfare and pension funds heard today how an insurance broker collected $353,530 in connection with a fund for laundry workers.

Sales of lipstick, eye makeup, cleansing tissues and hair tints and rinses have been going steadily up in the last eight years, but perfume sales have lagged. The perfume manufacturers themselves were charged with responsibility for this state of affairs yesterday by Elwood Whitney, executive vice president of Foote, Cone Belding, advertising agency, in an address to the Fragrance Foundation, trade group, at the Ambassador Hotel.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 24 (AP)--Art Larsen, San Leandro, Calif., halted Jerry DeWitts' streak today. Larsen defeated the San Francisco star in the quarter-finals of the Good Neighbor tennis championships, 5-7, 6-4, 6-2.

CHICAGO, March 24--The Chicago Daily News commented editorially today on the demand of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, that Secretary Dulles "tell just who in the State Department 'leaked' the secret Yalta report to one newspaper, The New York Times."
ALBANY, March 24--The Assembly today completed legislative action for this year on a Republican constitutional amendment to legalize bingo.
