THE salt water anglers who mark time until the arrival of the bluefish might find pollack fishing an interesting interlude. The pollack not only arrive earlier and are much larger but provide plenty of action on light tackle.

IF I had to live in the fictional world of Thomas Gallagher I think I would flee to a nice cozy life in the French Foreign Legion, or else cut my throat. Mr. Gallagher, who is young, earnest and immensely talented, has written only two novels--"The Gathering Darkness," which was published two and a half years ago, and "The Monogamist,"* which is published today.
The social importance of good family life was stressed yesterday by Msgr. James J. Lynch. He is director of Catholic Charities in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

YESTERDAY the sound of the peeper was heard in the land. It rose from the beaver pond marshes in the Zoological Gardens in the Bronx and made the air shimmer. Men and women let their eyelids droop as they warmed in the first benevolent spring sun.

From time to time it had been indicated that George Cukor, a film director of the upper echelon, would resume his Broadway directorial career after a gap of twenty-seven years. Apparently nothing seemed attractive enough to lure Mr. Cukor back.
DONIZETTI'S "Don Pasquale" was not "revived," as a previous statement narrated, last night at the City Center. It was performed there for the first time by the New York City Opera Company.

Laszlo Szabo lost for the first time in the eleventh round of the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday, according to a report from Buenos Aires. The Hungarian bowed to Oscar Panno, the champion of Argentina.
PITTSBURGH, March 24 (AP) --Directors of the Aluminum Company of America today approved a two-for-one split of its common stock and increased the dividend rate.
FOR Tennessee Williams and for the rest of us, the news could hardly be better this morning. For "Cat On a Hot Tin Roof," which opened at the Morosco last evening, is a stunning drama.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $772,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 24 --Premier Ngo Dinh Diem virtually rejected today the demands of armed Opposition groups that he reorganize his Government in accordance with their wishes.
LONDON, March 24 -- The Soviet Union has offered a new plan for world disarmament similar to the one it submitted to the United Nations General Assembly last Sept. 30.
MONTREAL, March 24 (UP)-- Jean Beliveau led the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-1 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight and a 2-0 lead in the Stanley Cup hockey semi-finals.
The development of a device to count particles much faster than can be done by the human eye was announced yesterday by the Allan B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc.
ALBANY, March 24--Republican legislative majorities passed their omnibus school aid bill today and dared Governor Harriman to veto it.

An attorney for a group of bondholders of the New York, Ontario and Western Railway contended yesterday that the trustee's plan to sell the bankrupt road seeks to minimize the property's value while at the same time it tries to picture profitable operation in the future.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24--Two pitchers were cut from the squad by the Yankees today. The departure of Wally Burnette and Jim Russell to the Denver club of the American Association left Casey Stengel with eighteen of the twentytwo hurlers who started Spring training here.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- The Peress investigation today stirred new clashes as Congress ground toward the end of the inquiry.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 24 (UP)--The defending champion, Judd Brumley, advanced to the semi-finals of the American Seniors Golf Association championships today on the nineteenth hole after losing a 1-up lead on the eighteenth.
ROME, March 24--Premier Mario Scelba and Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino left the Rome airport shortly after 8 A. M. for a visit to Ottawa, Washington and New York.

MONTE CARLO, March 24-- This afternoon Italy, in a driving third-session finish, captured the 1955 Monte Carlo open teamof-four championship from an international field of thirty-four contract bridge teams.

SYRACUSE, March 24 (UP)-- The Syracuse Nationals fought off a strong rally by the Boston Celtics in the second half tonight to gain a 116-110 victory. The triumph gave Syracuse a 2-0 lead in the three-out-of-five National Basketball Association Eastern finals.
Camp NYDA, an interracial, nonsectarian summer camp for needy diabetic children, will be the beneficiary of the Monday evening performance of "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," at the Morosco Theatre.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 24--Rain ruined the day for Branch Rickey and his Pirates today. The Bues' game with the Dodgers, halted twice, was called off by the umpires, Hal Dixon and Bill Jackowski, at 3:13 P. M.

With the conclusion of the first phase of the Fulbright committee's study of the stock market both the Senators on the committee and the public at large now have the opportunity to evaluate the results of these past few week's of testimony.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) --The Government withheld a report on the deadly results of hydrogen - bomb radiation for nearly three months for fear it would "adversely affect certain international situations," it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, March 24-- The big story in the world today is how the United States is going to get out of the QuemoyMatsu affair without loss of face or loss of blood, but the Senate is looking the other way.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 24--South Africa's Government will conclude its current fiscal year March 31 with a new surplus of u10,000,000 ($28,000,000).

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24--Movie makers were reminded tonight by Louis B. Mayer, that the future of the film industry is not going to be "influenced as much by the size and shape of the screen" as it will be by "the quality of the entertainment it presents."
BONN, Germany, March 24 --President Theodor Heuss signed today the bills of ratification on the Paris and Saar agreements.

TOKYO, March 24 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama refused today to renounce for Japan any ambition for possessing atomic weapons. However, he agreed with Socialist members of the Diet (Parliament) in opposing continued tests of atomic weapons.

WASHINGTON, March 24-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 656,117 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 10,431 cars, or 1.6 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week.
CLEVELAND, March 24--Organized charities were admonished today that contributors were beginning to revolt against a chaotic multiplicity of appeals.
The Chrysler Corporation's net earnings for the first two months this year topped those of all last year, the auto company's financial vice president reported yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, March 24-- The Argentine Ministry of Education, accused religious schools today of fiscal frauds.
ALBANY, March 24 -- The Senate approved unanimously today a bill permitting dismissal of an employee who invokes the Fifth Amendment at a hearing involving loyalty. There was no debate.
The State Congress of Industrial Organizations declared yesterday that the Legislature had compiled a "do nothing" record.
Opponents of water fluoridation were accused yesterday of waging a campaign based on fear, suspicion and hysteria.

CHICAGO, March 24--Trade in grains and soybeans was dull much of the session today. But there was a firm tone in wheat and May soybeans also displayed strength. Corn was firm early but reacted, and oats also sold down from the early tops.

The Investors Funding Corporation of New York, in a purchase for investment and further development, has acquired the six-story apartment house with fifty-three suites at 415 East Sixteenth Street in Brooklyn. The sellers were Louis Kroman and Tillie Meerbaum Alexander and Stuart Herman were the brokers and title was insured by the Security Title and Guaranty Company.
ITHACA, N. Y, March 24-- A wife and mother holding a full time job is not breaking tradition, a panel of working homemakers agreed today in a Farm and Home Week discussion.
CHICAGO, March 24--Extension of protracted sickness and accident insurance was approved today at a Blue CrossBlue Shield national meeting.
The recovery movement in the stock market continued yesterday for the third straight session. Gains of 1 to 3 points were numerous and a few issues moved up 5 to 7 points.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES : Does the gentleman who is so concerned over the welfare of our captive penguins give them human intelligence and the power of reasoning? They look human enough to talk, but that is the reason we should actually see them once in a while--to increase our love and admiration for all the "living things that moveth upon the earth."
"FATHER KNOWS BEST" continues to be the most appealing and believable family situation comedy on television.
LONDON, March 24--Mobilization of the Labor party machine for an early general election was ordered tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Wheat brought the downfall of cotton today as the Senate rejected a bill to increase the 1955 acreage of both. The final vote was 51 to 39.
The International Longshoremen's Association started doublebarreled action yesterday to prevent enforcement of the Waterfront Commission's new hiring regulations, due to become effective next Friday.
Governor Harriman declared last night that the State of Israel "will be defended if necessary with overwhelming help from outside."
OXFORD, Ohio, March 24-- Ford Konno of Ohio State became the first champion as the thirty-second annual National Collegiate swimming championships began tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I wonder when we will learn that the day is long since past when even local acts of national policy, let alone ones with foreign implications, can be committed by people with no more equipment than, a United States flag and a primer on international law.

WASHINGTON, March 24-- The White House-Congressional fight over pay increases for 500,000 postal employes went to the Senate floor late today. It was scheduled to be followed by another one, over salary rises for 1,500,000 classified Government workers.
A taxicab mounted the sidewalk and injured seven persons yesterday afternoon at the southeast corner of Fiftyseventh Street and Lexington Avenue.
ALBANY, March 24--Park Avenue proved today to be worth an extra $1,300,000 to New York City.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Small mistakes or omissions sometimes have grave consequences. What may seem like a small mistake in the proposed reclassification of nurses' positions in the New York City Departments of Health and Hospitals will have major effects on the health services of this city.
A blueprint fleet of tankers to be built with private financing for charter to the Navy appeared to be headed for shoal water last night.
Seven marines, armed with two flame-throwers, attempted to destroy sixty acres of weeds in the Bronx yesterday. They suffered an ignominious defeat.
LONDON, March 24--The stock markets improved slightly today as prices responded to a small selective revival of buying. But the volume of business continued to fall.
One hundred and twenty-five passengers boarded the Greek liner Nea Hellas yesterday, and a few hours later they sailed for Europe on the Greek liner New York.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP)--Producers unloaded 13,000 hogs on the livestock market today and prices for butchers dropped around 50 cents while sows lost 25 to 50 cents.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 24--Nearly a million, children cut classes today in Roman Catholic schools throughout Belgium to protest the Government's proposed cut in subsidies to the parochial schools.
PARIS, March 24--Premier Edgar Faure told the Senate today France must have a foreign policy that moved in a straight line. It must be free from the contradictions of the last five years, he added.

MEXICO CITY, March 24 (AP) --United States swimming and diving stars went on another gold medal spree today. They collected four of the six championships decided on the day's Pan-American Games program.

YESTERDAY (March 24, 1955) THE GOVERNOR Sent special message to Legislature urging year's delay in effective date of compulsory automobile inspection. Nominated Municipal Court Justice Thomas E. Rohan of Manhattan as chairman of the State Liquor Authority.
OTTAWA, March 24--Canada filed a demurrer today to United States policy in the Far East.
ALBANY, March 24--The Assembly voted today to grant New York City $60,500,000 worth of new taxing power and to make the 3 per cent sales tax permanent.
Negotiations for the production, by Twentieth Century-Fox of a series of one-hour television shows for General Electric are being made with the Young Rubicam advertising agency.

WASHINGTON, March 24-- Ardito Desio, a 58-year-old geology professor of Milan University, told today how he led the expedition last summer that scaled K2 in the Himalayas, second highest mountain in the world.

WASHINGTON, March 24--The House of Representatives moved today to correct two costly errors in the Eisenhower Administration's 1954 omnibus tax revision law. By unanimous voice vote, it passed and sent to the Senate a bill for repeal of provisions that promised to give business unintended tax relief estimated by Democrats at $1,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000.
TRENTON, March 24 --Gov. Robert B. Meyner has been urged to dismiss charges of malfeasance and misfeasance he preferred against a state official last June.
WASHINGTON, March 24--The Republican Senate leader, William F. Knowland of California, publicly rejected today President Eisenhower's efforts to tranquillize the issue of the Yalta Conference.

The five-story building at 153 West Forty-fourth Street, which is the "key" to the northeast corner of Broadway and Fortyfourth Street, has been sold by John Avrutis, attorney, to an investing client of Miss Naomi Ranson of House, Grossman, Vorhaus, attorneys.
NEW ORLEANS, March 24-- The Solicitor General of the United States, Simon E. Sobeloff, said here tonight that the American Jewish community was a full and participating force in American life.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 24-- Leo Durocher all but conceded the flag to his Giants today.

A feature of this year's convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers was a symposium on space ships and artificial satellites. The older, engineers who followed Dr. Ernest Stuhlinger as he described his ten-man "butterfly spaceship," which, is to focus solar rays, on a boiler and thus raise steam in what is now considered an old-fashioned way, must have marveled.
One hundred years ago, in the "pest houses" of hospitals in Scutari on the Crimean peninsula, a uniform that today is the attire of thousands of working women made its first public appearance.

PRINCETON, March 24-- Complete reorganization of New Jersey's motor vehicle licensing and registration procedures, long, advocated by Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, appeared tonight to be virtually assured.
Color, color and more color flows through a collection of couturier designs in corduroy, velvet and velveteen assembled by the Crompton-Richmond Company.
The Indifferent Male Women's hats never seem to be out of the news. Recently we read that the unions in the field were cooperatirig with the manufacturers so that the industry may stay healthy.
Negroes, and whites joined in Harlem yesterday to pay their last respects to Walter White, one of the American Negro's foremost leaders.
WASHINGTON, March 24-- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 14 per cent above sales in the corresponding week at last year.

Eight contract bridge teams completed last night the quarter final round of the contest for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy. The event was part of the Eastern States Bridge Tournament, which began last Friday at the McAlpin-Hotel.

The business loans of New York City banks continued to rise in the week ended Wednesday, but this was more than offset by a decline in loans to brokers and dealers for carrying other than United States Government securities.

Despite continued efforts in the French Council of the Republic to kill the Paris pacts with illusory amendments, the chances for their final ratification have improved greatly as a result of two new developments.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) --Chan Gurney, member of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said today that the dependence of the nation's airlines on mail pay and Government subsidies was declining.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24--India requested today the right to appear before the United Nations Disarmament Commission to explain her proposal for "an armament truce" pending establishment of a comprehensive disarmament program.

The National Council of the Metropolitan Opera voted yesterday to defray the entire $52,457.04 cost of the new production of Strauss' "Arabella." The council previously had agreed to contribute $40,000 toward production costs.

Eight contract bridge teams completed last night the quarter final round of the contest for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy. The event was part of the Eastern States Bridge Tournament, which began last Friday at the McAlpin-Hotel.

The business loans of New York City banks continued to rise in the week ended Wednesday, but this was more than offset by a decline in loans to brokers and dealers for carrying other than United States Government securities.

Despite continued efforts in the French Council of the Republic to kill the Paris pacts with illusory amendments, the chances for their final ratification have improved greatly as a result of two new developments.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) --Chan Gurney, member of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said today that the dependence of the nation's airlines on mail pay and Government subsidies was declining.
An imaginative subway conductor mulcted a woman fiction writer of $1,500 before his fancied career ended yesterday in a Brooklyn cell.

After a decade of intense competition between the Communist world and the free world it is now widely recognized that one of the key areas of this competition is the struggle for the loyalty of the world's intellectuals. Writers, artists, scientists, composers and other creative craftsmen exercise an influence in every country far exceeding their numbers --an influence relatively greatest in the undeveloped countries where masses of illiterates look to them for guidance and leadership.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24--India requested today the right to appear before the United Nations Disarmament Commission to explain her proposal for "an armament truce" pending establishment of a comprehensive disarmament program.

The National Council of the Metropolitan Opera voted yesterday to defray the entire $52,457.04 cost of the new production of Strauss' "Arabella." The council previously had agreed to contribute $40,000 toward production costs.
ALBANY, March 24--Governor Harriman asked the Legislature today to postpone for a year the effective date of the compulsory automobile inspection program.

WASHINGTON, March 24--Cash dividends paid out by corporations last month amounted to $261,000,000, the Government announced today. This was $17,000,000 more than in February, 1954. A report by the Department of Commerce said that dividends paid out in the first two months of this year totaled $982,000,000 and were 5 per cent higher than in the opening two months of last year.
The proposed merger of Bankers Trust Company and the Public National Bank and Trust Company became yesterday the first of three pending New York City bank mergers to receive stocklolder approval.
An impressive safety report on the small taxicab was given yesterday by the Police Department.
The Board of Estimate took the first major step yesterday in what Mayor Wagner called the city's "all-out fight against juvenile delinquency."
Improved economic conditions are making possible an increase in the retirement of bonds before they come due.
Fifteen hundred teachers carried their fight for higher salaries yesterday to the doorsteps of City Hall.
KANSAS CITY, March 24 (AP) --The National Collegiate Athletic Association's "compromise" plan for televising 1955 college football games has received overwhelming approval from the membership.
One of dog's best friends-- a boy--found himself a celebrity yesterday.

CHARLESTON, S. C., March 24--John W. Davis, Democratic Presidential nominee defeated by Calvin Coolidge in 1924, died today of pneumonia. He was 81 years old. Mr. Davis, a constitutional lawyer, also had been Ambassador to Britain.

Oil production continues to increase in Latin America. But, according to the current issue of Latin American Business Highlights, Chase National Bank's quarterly review, it is growing at a slower rate than previously.

DETROIT, March 24 (UP)-- Gordie Howe and Alex Delvecchio scored goals forty-five seconds apart, with two Maple Leafs in the penalty box, to give the Detroit Red Wings a 2-1 victory over Toronto tonight and a 2-0 lead in their four-out-of seven Stanley Cup hockey semifinal series.
BERLIN, March 24--Students at a Soviet school in East Berlin have formed an anti-Communist club known as "the Anarchists," according to a fugitive who says he was a member of the organization.
MIAMI BEACH, March 24 (AP) --Peter Thomson, British open champion from Australia, jumped into the first-round lead today as youngsters dominated play in the $12,500 Miami Beach open golf tournament.
Inflexible and time-consuming procedures are criticized as among the worst features of the new uniform code of military justice.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 25(UP)--The Belair Stud's Nashua and his jockey, Eddie Arcaro, loomed as an unbeatable combination to win $100,000 tomorrow in the $149,750 Florida Derby. A field of ten 3-year-olds will go to the post in the Gulfstream Park feature.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The $20-a-person income tax cut voted by the House of Representatives died quietly today in a joint Congressional committee. The House-Senate conferees, after eliminating that provision, quickly approved a bill to cancel $3,000,000,000 of corporation and excise tax reductions scheduled to take effect automatically on April 1.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday declined 8 to 12 points (40 to 60 cents a bale).
City employes should have the same right as workers in private industry to organize and bargain collectively, a majority of speakers agreed yesterday at a City Hall hearing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial on March 19 entitled "A Woman for Judge" gives much encouragement to the large number of men and women who have long believed that women should have greater participation in the area of social relationships.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 25--As automatic as the laundry chore has become with the advent of mechanical equipment, the homemaker still has to make decisions if she wants to get the best results on wash day.

Buffet Party Service, which has decorated birthday cakes for the President and served canapes to Dodger rooters at the Ebbetts Field Clubhouse, has a new home. With the move to a handsome shop on the southwest corner of First Avenue and Fifty-first Street, the catering concern has become even more ambitiously versatile.
A New Jersey dock boss was suspended yesterday by the Waterfront Commission as the agency continued its investigation into kickbacks at the Leonardo Naval Base at Earle, N. J.
CLEVELAND, March 25 (AP)-- The Glidden Company says it has bought the "assets of the Zapon industrial finishes division, of the Atlas Powder Company of Wilmington, Del."

LONDON, March 25--United States and French diplomats attending the Soviet-Western disarmament talks here sharply criticized today the "latest and most flagrant" Soviet violations of the secrecy rules.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 25 (UP)--Forty warplanes, flying too high to be seen from the ground, today carried out a preliminary test of a device apparently designed to blast an enemy airfleet from the skies in an atomic war.

That the latest Soviet moves with regard to Austria are looked at with suspicion among the Western nations is inevitable in view of the long and unhappy post-war Soviet record with regard to that country. Piling pretext upon pretext, for almost ten years since V-E Day, Moscow has prevented the conclusion of an Austrian State Treaty which would restore full Austrian sovereignty and permit the withdrawal of foreign troops from that country.
ANTIGUA, Guatemala, March 25--Censorship of the press still affects about 20 per cent of inhabitants of the Western Hemisphere, directors of the InterAmerican Press Association were told today.

The special counsel to the Board of Higher Education offered yesterday to resign if it could be proved that be had used the testimony of Harvey Matusow "or his ilk" as the basis for investigating college teachers.
St. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25--All the raves were for Johnny Kucks today as the Yankees downed the Dodgers, 5--1.
Governor Harriman threatened yesterday to keep the Legislature in session until it produced the program he wanted.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Secretary of Agriculture and the House Appropriations Committee accused each other today of political motives in the handling of farm programs.
A Congressional subcommittee heard the testimony yesterday of a civilian medical expert that the treatment of three Fort Dix, N. J., soldiers for acute meningococcemia had been "most excellent."

Owing to a lack of vocational planning the nation is facing its greatest shortage of "trained brains," educators said here yesterday. They also expressed the view that too many young people were going into the wrong jobs.

The proposed creation of ten new judgeships for the State Supreme Court in New York City has been approved by the executive committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. Allen T. Klots, association president, announced this action yesterday, stressing its importance as "a measure of immediate relief."
AINTREE, England, March 25 (AP)--English-trained Tudor Line was made the betting favorite tonight to break the Irish hold on the Grand National--the world's hardest test for steeplechase horses.

PATISH, Israel, March 25-- An Israeli Army statement said today that armed Egyptians threw bombs among wedding revelers here last night, killing a young woman and wounding eighteen others. This Negev village is ten miles from the Egyptian armistice lines.
A large subscription has been reported for the preview performance of the prize-winning British motion picture "Chance Meeting."
BERLIN, March 25--German archaeologists have found clay molds that they believe were used by Phidias to shape his gigantic statue of Zeus, one of the original Seven Wonders of the World.

TOKYO, March 25--About the most unpopular thing the United States could do, as far as Japan is concerned, would be to go to war with Communist China over the offshore islands, Matsu and Quemoy. Despite our defense agreement with this country we would get no real support in a fight arising from this specific issue.
The arts and their practitioners and the institutions that house them were analyzed yesterday by fifteen panelists and two moderators at Columbia University.

PANAMA, March 25--Special Prosecutor Jose N. Lasso de is Vega suggested today that an amnesty be granted persons who were involved in the alleged plot to overthrow the late President Jose Antonio Remon but not directly connected with his assassination.

Governor Harriman's request to the Legislature to postpone for a year the start of compulsory semiannual inspection of automobiles for mechanical safety is ill-advised. It stands to reason that a considerable number among the more than 4,000,000 cars and trucks registered in this state have mechanical defects that may prove fatal.
HARLOW, England, March 25 --This attractive new town, twenty-three miles from London, is rapidly fulfilling its function of helping to absorb the city's surplus population and industries.

Economics, some say, is the dismal science; other skeptics would not even call it a science. But there could hardly be better refutations of such views than the two excellent economists President Eisenhower has just nominated for the Council of Economic Advisers, Prof. Joseph S. Davis of Stanford and Prof. Raymond J. Saulnier of Barnard.
LONDON, March 25--A strike of maintenance men and electricians stopped the publication of London's newspapers today.

Webb Knapp, Inc., resold the one-story trucking and shipping terminal at 126 to 136 West Nineteenth Street, one of eight buildings acquired recently from Warner Hudnut, Inc. Charles G. Keller Co. were the brokers in the sale of the property, which is assessed at $155,000.

WASHINGTON, March 25-- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, advocate of an aggressive policy in the Far East, is slated to be reappointed chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff for another two-year term. His present term expires on May 13.

PARIS, March 25--With a number of important changes, the Finance Committee of the National Assembly today adopted the fiscal-powers bill submitted by Premier Edgar Faure. The bill, which was the cause of a critical debate last week, will come up in the Assembly Monday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 25--The Nationalist Administration moved today to make a basic change in the structure of the South African Government.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- For the second time this week the Government was urged to cut quotas on exports of copper scrap. Proponents of the move hope to embargo such shipments entirely.
The Senate was urged yesterday to restore $25,000,000 for maritime activities that had been eliminated from a $60,000,000 budgetary request in the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 25--A significant change in policy and defense planning is under consideration here in the belief Red China will begin its campaign to capture Matsu and Quemoy about the middle of April.
OZARK, Ala., March 25-- Army aviation--not to be confused with the Air Force--has quietly grown from a puddle-jumping infant into a Vigorous versatile teen-ager.
AT the New York City Opera Company's performance of "Cavalleria Rusticana" last evening, the soprano Rosa Savoia returned to the company, after several seasons' absence, to sing Santuzza.
WASHINGTON, MARCH 25 (UP)--Senators were told today that Louis B. Saperstein netted almost $2,000,000 from handling two union welfare funds.
MIAMI BEACH, March 25 (AP) --Sensational putting by Shelley Mayfield produced a record 64 today and gave him the secondround lead in the $12,500 Miami Beach open golf tournament.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 25 (AP)--The Illinois Supreme Court took under advisement today a case involving the plan of Louis E. Wolfson to gain control of Montgomery Ward Co. at the annual stockholders' meeting April 22.

IN choosing Maxwell Anderson's "Joan of Lorraine" for their fourth and final production of the season, the Equity Community Theatre players are back on solid ground. The first performance of this absorbing, if somewhat wordy, drama was acted last night at the DeWitt Clinton Youth and Adult Center in the Bronx where it will be repeated tonight.
The TV hearth is fast replacing the backyard fence as a favored spot for swapping recipes.
ALBANY, March 25 -- The Board of Regents chose today as the head of the state's school system a young expert on finance.
The city got a revenue of $23,670,574 out of its real estate dealings in 1954 and expects to do even better this year.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 25 --Brazil's military leaders will probably play a decisive part in this year's Presidential campaign. Elections are scheduled for Oct. 3.
WASHINGTON, March 25-- House hearings on the Administration's National Reserve plan ended today.
Sixty-two bridge teams representing forty-four commercial and industrial concerns completed play last night in the final session of the annual contest for the Eastern Commercial Trophy.

The World Calendar Association has not relaxed its drive for a reform of the year into four equal quarters of ninety-one days plus a "world holiday" on Dec. 31 to make it come out even. February would have thirty days.
WASHINGTON, March 25-- The White House conceded today that three golfing squirrels had been trapped and exiled.
CHICAGO, March 25--Rain in Kansas caused the wheat market to open sharply down today. The break in wheat cut support from other grains.
Three thugs held up a midtown loan office at 4:30 P.M. yesterday and shot two women employes while making their escape.
Mental illness costs this country's taxpayers more than $1,000,000,000 a year, Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25-- The "escapee program," to aid persons fleeing across the Iron Curtain to the West, was praised by President Eisenhower today. He said it was a positive aid to the cause of freedom.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) --Senate investigators voted today to close their books now on the Peress case and let the Justice Department determine whether anybody should be prosecuted for perjury.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 25 --A meeting today between Premier Ngo Dinh Diem and representatives of opposition groups improved prospects for a settlement between them.

TWO new novels cover the same theme: loyalty oaths on the American college campus. The subject is big enough for a dozen books, yet only a few of the major contemporary novelists have ventured into the troubled academic groves. It is difficult for fiction to compete with a running news story. And controversial topics hold little hope of subsidiary rights.

BOSTON, March 25 (AP)--The Weather Bureau issued today the following forecasts and listed these conditions as reported by operators of ski areas: Forecast--Mostly cloudy and cold tomorrow, with a chance of light snow over the south portion in the morning.
CLEVELAND, March 25--The big national voluntary health and welfare organizations were urged today to ease some of their competition for funds.

SEOUL, Korea, March 18-- President Syngman Rhee, who will be 80 years old March 26, is in the forefront of Asia's fight against communism. He shows today the vigor that has characterized his lifetime of struggle to free his country from tyrannies.
MOSCOW, March 25--Mr. Gromyko disclosed today that he and the Western delegates at London were at loggerheads on the issue of international control of arms reduction.
THAT the contemporary spirit in art inhabits a house of many mansions should be clear as day to any spectator making the rounds of local galleries at present.

Michael T. Florinsky, author of "Russia: A History and an Interpretation," is working on a new book on European union. It will be brought out by Macmillan in the fall. The work will discuss the steps that have been taken since the end of World Wat II to advance the economic, military and political unification of Europe.
On Thursday two "seats" were sold on the New York Stock Exchange. One brought $83,000, the other $84,000.
An Albany sleeper is not a night train to the state capital. It is a bill that is introduced in the Legislature unnoticed.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 25 (AP)--Iraq will receive about 72,000,000 dinars ($201,600,000) in oil earnings in 1955, according to an agreement signed yesterday between the Iraqi Government and the Iraq Petroleum Company and associated companies.
Among his other problems, Mayor Wagner will be pondering for the next few days the question: When is a gun a toy and when is it a too-realistic imitation?
One of the biggest mass bus rides in history began in Baltimore yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) --Canada and the United States began today a study of tolls to be charged after the St. Lawrence Seaway is opened to shipping in the spring of 1959.
TORONTO, March 25 (Canadian Press)--The Canadian General Electric Company, Ltd., had net income in 1954 of $7,139,759, compared with $11,044,537 in 1953, says the annual report released tonight.
NEW DELHI, India, March 23 --A legal and social revolution is giving to Hindu women the rights denied to them for thousands of years.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 25 (UP) --State Senator Jimmy Phillips broke the national filibustering record today with a twenty-threehour-and-thirty-five-minute argument for a "measly $2,000,000" appropriation for a hospital.

CHICAGO, March 25 (AP)--Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today: HOGS Salable hogs 7,500 head; trading moderately active; butchers and sows unevenly steady to mostly 25 cents higher; most sales choice 190 to 230 pound $17.25 to $17.75,
The role of railroads in the event of hydrogen bomb raids was studied yesterday at a symposium arranged by the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Association.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) --The Government gave top priority today to developing plans for mass evacuation of cities of 1,000,000 or less in event of atomic or hydrogen bomb attack.
TRENTON, March 25--Attorney General Grover C. Richman revealed today his office was preparing legislation to legalize wiretapping in New Jersey to combat bookmaking and numbers violations.

Quotation From a Cleric They were talking about architecture -- and what is happening to it now that so much of the building going on all around us has its outward expression in towering cliffs of glass and metal.

DETROIT, March 25 (AP)--The automobile industry is setting up another series of production records this week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. It listed the new marks as follows: qUnited States passenger car production 177,843, surpassing last week's record high of 176,194.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 25 --Roman Catholic and Socialist meetings on the explosive school subsidy issue were held without incident a few blocks apart tonight.
LONDON, March 25--Business dwindled further today, making volume for the week the lowest in three months. Nevertheless, prices remained reasonably firm.

The two-story loft building at 4241 Park Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Saul Mosner to the Charson Construction Corporation, represented by Stuart Halpern, attorney. The Investors Security Corporation was the broker and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, March 25--The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered a formal investigation into reports that the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was seeking control of the Boston and Maine Railroad.
WASHINGTON, March 25-- The Senate approved today a 10 per cent pay increase for some 2,000,000 Government employes.

Two major New York City bank mergers, scheduled to be placed before stockholders next week, are virtually assured of shareholder approval. It was reported yesterday that sufficient affirmative proxies for the proposed merger of Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company had already been filed with the respective managements.
A 31-year-old fire lieutenant fell four floors from a burning building in Brooklyn early yesterday with a small child in his arms.

The question of inviting Billy Graham to conduct an evangelistic mission here in the fall of 1956 will be taken up next month at a meeting of the board of directors of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

William Fancher, tax agent for the bankrupt New York, Ontario and Western Railway Company, estimated yesterday that the road's 541 miles of right-ofway were worth only $353,345. The railroad's land between populated areas has no value whatever, he said.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Opera must break out of its isolation in New York and spread to a dozen important centers if it is to develop properly in the United States, Rudolf Bing said today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 25-- Stan Hack and his Cubs moved in from near-by Mesa today sporting a six-game winning streak. Some two and a half hours later the Bruins went back to their lair fairly well convinced that beating Leo Durocher's Polo Grounders this year is going to be no easier than it was last summer.
DESPITE the recent rains, stream conditions in the Catskill area and the easterly portions of Pennsylvania, Connecticut and Massachusetts indicate the opening day prospects are brighter than usual.
The writer of the following letter, a Macedonian, is the author of "My American Pilgrimage" and other books.
Ernest D'Antonio's future seemed much brighter yesterday. Instead of having to serve fifty to sixty years as an alleged participant in a hold-up, there was a strong possibility that he might go free.
The police raided four premises last night where gambling with dice or cards was found in progress. Fifty-five men were arrested and taken to Night Court for arraignment.
YESTERDAY (March 25,1955) THE PRESIDENT Received Dr. William B. Adams, president of Aramaio Bible Foundation, and inspected rare fifth century copy of New Testament.
NEW DELHI, India, March 25 --India will ask the conference of Asian-African nations to put the problem of nuclear weapons on its agenda.
BOSTON, March 25 (AP)--Arthur G. B. Metcalf, president of Electronics Corporation of Amer-today projected a 61 per cent increase in sales in 1955 at the annual meeting.

The public market for new capital is continuing moderately active. In the corporate field, a wide variety of securities offerings is coming up, although not in heavy volume. In local government financing there seems to be a sizable slowdown, largely because of delays in toll turnpike financing.
Outlawing of sex-crime-horror comic books was demanded last night by six Protestant Episcopal dioceses in this state.

Those Americans, such as General Van Fleet, who know him best are deepest in their affection and warmest in their praise for Korea's President, Dr. Syngman Rhee. Today, on the occasion of his eightieth birthday, they will be sending him their messages of esteem and congratulation.
HONG KONG, March 25-- Communist China announced tonight that six more of its divisions were being withdrawn from North Korea.

Bob Baker enjoyed a workout at the expense of Julio Mederos of Havana at Madison Square Garden last night. The Pittsburgh heavyweight gained the unanimous decision in the feature bout of ten rounds, to the satisfaction of the crowd of 3,808.
The writer of the following letter, chairman of the American Zionist Committee for Public Affairs, was formerly adviser on Jewish Affairs to the United States Army in Germany.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 25 (AP)--Striking workers at the big Chuquicamata Copper Mine agreed tonight to resume work tomorrow and postpone their walkout ten days.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25--This is the story of a lover of baseball who took a new lease on life. He has been the key figure in the building of a city. He has done more than anyone else to make Florida the spring training center of baseball.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 25 (AP) --An Arkansas boy's blood was pumped for fifteen crucial minutes during a heart operation through a dog's lung that had been inflated to about the size of a football.
MEXICO CITY, March 25 (AP) --Beth Whittall, an 18-year-old Purdue University sophomore from Montreal, scored two brilliant swimming triumphs in the Pan-American Games today.
The combination of headlines and money provided the "irresistible lure" to get Harvey Matusow to say he had lied as a witness in two Communist cases, the Government charged yesterday.
Stocks pushed forward yesterday for the fourth successive session and, despite some irregularity, closed moderately higher.
Confectioners have postponed further reductions in the size of the 5-cent candy bar. Many even plan to use more cocoa and less substitutes in their chocolate.
WASHINGTON, March 25-- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 110.1 per cent of the 1947-49 level, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) --Following is the key 52-to-41 vote by which the Senate rejected today an Administration proposal to hold postal salary increases to 7.5 per cent. The vote came on a motion to table the Administration measure, which had been offered as a substitute for a Democratic-sponsored 10 per cent pay rise.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 25-- The University of Pittsburgh qualified four men for the semifinals of the twenty-fifth anniversary National Collegiate championships tonight.

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia and Miguel Najdorf of Argentina won their twelfth-round chess matches, according to a report received yesterday from Buenos Aires. As a result, the two remained tied for the lead in the international masters tournament at Mardel Plata.

CLEVELAND, March 25 (AP)-- Wes Santee, tall and talkative Kansan, thrilled a Knights of Columbus track meet crowd tonight. He set a meet mile record of 4 minutes 4.6 seconds--a second over the world indoor mark.
BERN, Switzerland, March 25 --The highest Swiss political officials are convinced that the neutral commission supervising the Korean armistice is a valuable institution.
TOKYO, March 25--Recognition of "two Chinas," the Communist and the Nationalist Governments, will be the keystone of Japanese foreign policy in Asia.
BERLIN, March 25 -- East Germany announced tonight it had begun to take "defense measures" in view of West Germany's approval of its armament and participation in the Western European Union.
OXFORD, Ohio, March 25--A record-breaking effort enabled Jack Wardrop of Michigan to retain the National Collegiate 220-yard free-style swimming title tonight.

One of the keystones of survival in these days is the simple but overwhelming truth that the human heart knows no boundaries, particularly national ones. Here in the city a volunteer agency--Operation Town Affiliations, Inc.--has been putting this thought to good use for the past eight years.

Cocoa prices were firm during most of the session yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange but fell as much as the 1-cent-apound daily limit in the last hour of trading. Final prices were 95 to 100 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower on 323 lots.
Governor Harriman underscored his opposition yesterday to the state's compulsory automobile inspection program.
Headed for Broadway next season is another television drama, "The Rabbit Trap," by J. P. Miller. It was staged successfully last month on the National Broadcasting Company "Television Playhouse."
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 25--Oklahoma and Westchester County are ready for a warm handshake across the nation.
WASHINGTON, March 25--A Fifth Century New Testament was transferred from a bank vault here to the Library of Congress this morning with Twentieth Century precautions.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- Metro-Gpldwyn-Mayer will team Robert Taylor and Stewart Granger in "The Last Hunt."
ALBANY, March 25--Strong opposition to the Jockey Club's "dream track" plan for Belmont Park developed at a public hearing on enabling legislation today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 25--Police Superintendent John A. Lyddy has forbidden, until further notice, the issuance of permits for "Rock 'n Roll" teen-age dance parties. Explaining that he was doing so because the situation was getting out of hand, he said today that he had acted upon the recommendation of Lieut.
WASHINGTON, March 25-- Lester P. Barlow, inventor of aerial bombs used in World War I, received a patent this week for a blasting method which, he believes, will prove a boon to iron mining.
PARIS, March 25--Gen. Paul Ely, French commander and High Commissioner for Indochina, left tonight for Saigon with plans to slow repatriation of French expeditionary forces.
WASHINGTON, March 25-- President Eisenhower was urged by an emergency board today to sponsor a revamping of the railroad wage structure for operating employes.
PARIS, March 25--Antoine Pinay, Foreign Minister, said today that to hold up the treaties arming West Germany pending negotiation with Moscow would be to fall into a trap.

Percy Roberts of Noroton, Conn., is off again on a worldcircling assignment to judge show dogs. He is flying to Australia and New Zealand for a task that would shake, many another experienced dog man.

TOKYO, March 26--With a new Government taking office today, Japan is still in an uncertain state. Seven years of foreign occupation and other catastrophic aftermaths of a disastrous war have left this ancient nation with a sense of being born again, and it still is not clear what direction the new Japan, is to take.

NEWARK, March 26--The New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners was told this week that 4,000 passengers a day would be without adequate transportation if the New York Central were permitted to abandon passenger service on the West Shore Railroad.

THE publishers have prominently affixed the label "a mystery novel" to Richard Parker's A KIND OF MISFORTUNE (Scribner's, $2.75); so I suppose it must perforce be reviewed in this department, and with the reluctant verdict that as a mystery novel it's a poor one--slow-moving, cluttered with irrelevancies, and abruptly and incomprehensibly "solved."

WASHINGTON, March 26--Senator Walter F. George of Georgia was sitting on the edge of a long green-topped table in the Foreign Relations Committee room of the Capitol this week talking about war and getting his picture taken. "We are burning daylight," he said quietly.

IT is good to get away from things in this hydrogen age. The primitive, today, has a touch of the Garden of Eden. Peter Mayne, the author of this wistful, delightful and informative book on the Pathans of the North-West Frontier and Afghanistan, tries to recapture a lost paradise of his war years.

A complex control system is used in the construction of the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle. The general contract work is a joint venture of the Walsh Construction Company, the George A. Fuller Company and the Slattery Contracting Company.

The United States will devote about twothirds of its foreign aid funds, in the year beginning July 1, to a broad band of countries running from Afghanistan to Japan. Vulnerable militarily and for the most part underdeveloped economically, these countries need help to resist internal subversion as well as outside attack.

THAT gleam in the eye of Moss Hart has been diagnosed. Mr. Hart, a man of no mean stature in our theatre, is headed back to the boards with a book for a musical, his first since the unforgettable "Lady in the Dark."

BUENOS AIRES, March 26-- For many persons Argentina means tangos and the vast estancias or ranches of the pampas over which wild herds of horses and huge herds of cattle roam, chased by picturesque gauchos.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 26--Thousands of demonstrators marched in Brussels today in a Roman Catholic protest against the Government's proposed cut in subsidies to parochial schools.

ROME. THE Italian Communists hate Premier Mario Scelba with an intensity that is almost pathological. He is their public enemy No. 1. He is the man who bluffed them out of starting a revolution in 1947 and who has made it increasingly difficult every year since then for them to resort to strong-arm methods in their quest for power.

ANTIBIOTIC-- Dr. S. R. Bose of Carmichael Medical College Hospital, Calcutta, reports in Nature, the British scientific weekly, that ordinary edible mushrooms contain a potent antibiotic. He gave the antibiotic to typhoid patients both in the form of a crude extract by mouth and in the form of a hypodermic injection into the muscles.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 26--Nashua, the equine "playboy" from New York, passed an important test in his young racing career today when he won the $148,750 Florida Derby over a sloppy track at Gulfstream Park.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --Speaker Sam Rayburn, declaring the Eisenhower Administration had "condoned and even encouraged" the concentration of economic power, called tonight for enactment of legislation to restrict bank holding companies.

DES MOINES, March 26--The debate in Washington over the parity percentage to be fixed for farm prices has its counterpart in the farm area. Iowa farmers are firm believers in high parity prices. In fact, they are in favor of 100 per cent of parity.

A site assemblage started years ago in the Lenox Hill area has just been completed. It involves a row of five buildings at 137 to 161 East Sixtyninth Street formerly owned some of the oldest families in the city.
CONCORD, N. H., March 26-- The first ripples of a rising tide in the college population are beginning to lap at the campus of the University of New Hampshire.
DARIEN, Conn., March 26-- Patsy Ann Smith, 16-year-old Katonah (N. Y.) High School junior, won the Alfred B. Maclay horsemanship event at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club's indoor spring show today.
The Left-Wing International Fur and Leather Workers Union began going through an anticommunist meat grinder last week.

AN enterprise as elaborate as the Ballet Theatre's forthcoming engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House, April 12-May 1, in celebration of its fifteenth anniversary, is not easy to clarify very far in advance as far as programs and casting are concerned.

IN a season which has put forward an unusual number of exhibitions retrospective in nature, the current comprehensive loan show of paintings by Robert Delaunay at the Guggenheim Museum performs a double service.

VOLUMES in the Heroes of God Series are now tumbling off the press at an accelerating tempo. Soon a dozen will have appeared; two or three times that number are contemplated in all, and when the series is complete, teen-agers will have available a lively collection of semi-fictionized biographies glorifying the gigantic figures of the Bible and Christian history.
LONDON, March 26 (AP)-- Third Division York City held Newcastle United to a 1-1 tie in the semi-finals of the English soccer cup today--and Newcastle was lucky to get the tie.
