MIAMI, March 26 (AP)--Allie C. Reuben, a serious, soft-voiced man, heads north soon with one of the most powerful teams ever to come out of Florida in the spring.

The writer of the following letter was consultant to the Legal Department of the United Nations Secretariat in 1948. He is Professor of Law and John Harvey Gregory Lecturer on World Organization at Harvard.
ALBANY, March 26--The cattle and badlands often designated as "Out Where the West Begins" are farther east than you may have realized, podner.

AN exposition entitled "Charles-Quint et Son Temps" (Charles V and His Times) will be held in the Art Museum at Ghent, Belgium, from next Saturday through June 30 to recall the fourth centenary of the abdication of Emperor Charles V as ruler of the Netherlands.

PATAN, Nepal, March 10-- The fourth grade of St. Xavier's School of Nepal was shouting out the school song: To the trees, to the skies, to the evergreen valley of Katmandu: To the snows, to the peaks, to the roaring streams and the winding paths.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., March 26 (AP)--Stanley Benham, former Olympic bobsled champion, said today he was withdrawing from the United States Olympic team "so that America may have a chance to be fairly represented."
CLEVELAND, March 26-- Walter P. Reuther expressed confidence today that the auto workers would be able to obtain a guaranteed annual wage without a strike.

THE raiding season has arrived officially. Two weeks ago the Pabst Brewing Company announced that it would switch its televised boxing bouts, effective June 1, from the Columbia Broadcasting System to the American Broadcasting Company.

More than 1,000 chronic veterans are being a ided in three New York and New Jersey hospitals under a program that is freeing beds in other hospitals to treat at least 12,000 acutely ill veterans each year.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H.-- There is a small row going on up here in New Hampshire. A proposal has been made to floodlight the Old Man of the Mountain in Franconia Notch for the benefit of night-time motorists and visitors.
CINCINNATI, March 26--The American people were called upon tonight to demonstrate a "supreme expression of faith" at a time when warfare could be more "devastating" than ever before in history.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- The United States lost no time today in welcoming the Soviet Union's professed "positive attitude" toward a four-power conference.

IF the reader will just keep words like Twain, Tarkington and Salinger firmly from mind he will get a full helping of fun out of the 15-year-old who plays the title role in "I'm Owen Harrison Harding." For Mr. Ellison's first novel about the random growing-up experiences of a boy in a small Michigan town during the final year of World War II deserves (and win probably get) its own audience.

The State Commission Against Discrimination has ordered a union to face a public hearing on charges of discriminating against Negroes. In its ten-year history the commission has processed more than 3,100 complaints. Only six or seven, according to a spokesman, have reached the public hearing stage, and none of these has involved a labor organization.

EACH one of John Caldwell's books seems to be better than its predecessor. And he was good to start with. "The Korea Story" was an angry book. "China Coast Family" was a gentle and loving book. "Still the Rice Grows Green" is made up of both love and anger.

ALBANY, March 26--In the closing days of this year's legislative session, Governor Harriman is making a new attempt to cast himself in the political role made famous by Alfred E. Smith, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Herbert H. Lehman, his Democratic predecessors.
MEXICO CITY, March 26-- Mexico's crack horsemen today won the classic Prize of the Nations as the second PanAmerican Games came to a close.

Approaches to book, magazine and advertising illustration and methods of reproduction and technique in the field of commercial art will he discussed on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. by James Ernst at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue Forty-second Street.

Domestic politics, including the necessity of finding another job for Harold E. Stassen, obviously played a part in his appointment as Special Assistant to the President for Disarmament. Although Mr. Stassen will have Cabinet status, only time will show whether he will obtain sufficient power in Washington--or results elsewhere--to justify the sobriquet, "Secretary for Peace."

Seven pianists, four violinists and two 'cellists will be introduced this year in radio station WQXR's annual series, "Musical Talent in Our Schools." They will be heard in five broadcasts, the first next Sunday afternoon at 1:30.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 26 (AP)--Martin Strolz of Austria and Madeline Berthod of Switzerland raced down Baldy Mountain to downhill victories in the fifteen Harriman Cup ski races today.

BEETHOVEN: Quartet in Eflat, Op. 74; HAYDN: Quartet in D, Op. 64, No. 5; American Art Quartet (Victor). These recordings of Beethoven's "Harp" Quartet and Haydn's "Lark" have been issued in Victor's Bluebird series, and the disk is still a bargain at $2.98.

PAINT manufacturers have made famous the slogan "Save the surface and you save all." A good postscript to that would be: make sure the surface is ready before you start saving it. Painting over an improperly prepared surface is a waste of time and money and a source of future aggravation.

Are Americans living too much "on the cuff"? In recent weeks several economists and other business observers have said yes to this question. They point to the record consumer debt as the dark cloud that hangs threateningly over an otherwise bright economic scene.

PERHAPS the oldest Christian site in England is Glastonbury, connected in story and legend with the Holy Grail and St. Joseph of Arimathea, with King Arthur and Guinevere, and connected, too, with one of the greatest of Anglo-Saxon saints, the tenth-century Dunstan, Abbott of Glastonbury, Bishop of London, twenty-fifth Archbishop of Canterbury.

MONTE CARLO, March 26-- One hundred and fifty-six European and United States contract bridge pairs played the second of three sessions this afternoon in an open pair championship. This is the final event of the ten-day Monte Carlo International Championship.
AREZZO, Italy, March 26-- This sleepy little city, lost among the gentle hills of Tuscany, is waiting for a motor speedway to breathe new life and a spirit of modernity into it.

Aerial tankers--the "milk cows" of the skies--have given our aircraft seven-league boots. In military terms, tankers help increase the range of our bombers and fighters and thus make them less dependent, in an emergency, upon exposed overseas bases. Already, aerial refueling has built up statistics of superlatives.
GARDENERS find little resemblance between the old - fashioned pansy of yesteryear and today's modern flowers. Hybridization has seen to that.

THE Louisville Orchestra not only commissions works from contemporary composers, it also records them. The first two in a series of disks devoted to Louisville commissions, with the Louisville Orchestra under Robert Whitney, have been released.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. said today that if President Eisenhower was able to recommend an income tax cut next year, "low-income groups" would benefit the most.
WASHINGTON, March 26--A report from the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee this week gave great impetus to a proposed three-year survey of all aspects of mental illness.
Citing the recent publishing of the Yalta documents, Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein declared yesterday that "our generation is characterized by a multitude of words."

City Manager Aaron Simmons of New Rochelle is understandably proud this spring. His is the latest municipality to plan a marina or yacht basin. Its formal opening has been scheduled, with appropriate dedication ceremonies, for Memorial Day.

A large subscription has been received for the performance of the Easter Show and presentation of the motion picture, "The Glass Slipper," Thursday night at the Radio City Music Hall for the benefit of the Home for the Aged.
OXFORD, Ohio, March 26-- Ohio State retained its team laurels in the National Collegiate swimming championships tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 26--Emergency measures were undertaken by the White House late this week to shore up and repair the dike of bipartisan foreign policy, in which gaping leaks had appeared.
New measures to tighten control over contractors who set fires to burn rubbish where buildings are being demolished have been ordered by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
PARIS, March 26--Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, this week answered the question of why NATO's military experts have demanded a German contribution to European defense.
THE newspaper has been full of interesting items about music in recent days. Most of them speak for themselves, but there are three that deserve further comment.

To the Music Editor: THE evaluation of Henry Pleasants' book "The Agony of Modern Music" in last week's Times held my attention from start to finish. Books of this nature serve a valuable purpose in making everyone concerned with music take a new look at what service it is rendering our civilization.

BURBANK, Calif. STEP by step the National Broadcasting Company's television "housing" project is spreading over a forty-eight-acre site in the San Fernando Valley. Eventually it is expected to become the center for all N. B. C. West Coast TV production operations.

IF the decorative, delphinium like spires of larkspur are to be part of the garden scheme this spring and early summer, seed must be sown immediately. This annual is not dependable in the latitude of New York City if sown after the weather has warmed up.

WHEN a gourmet-cook suggests that cereals be used more often in the main course, the kitchen beginner invariably comments, "How dull." Actually, this proposal, if worked out by a knowing hand, produces delicious effects.
No new Jaws seem likely to come out of the "friendly study" of the stock market by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency.
Floating debris in New York harbor is taking an annual toll of hundreds of thousands of dollars in broken propellers, twisted propeller shafts and hull damages.

IN "Sow the Wind," LaSelle Gilman, ex-newspaper man, orientalist, and author of "The Dragon's Mouth" and "The Golden Horde," creates and, happily, arranges for the bitter destruction of Mikhail Aldanov, a villain whose depredations are on a huge scale.
Quemoy and Matsu and other Nationalist-held islands off the China coast were still a friction point in Washington politics and international diplomacy last week.

MONTREAL, March 26--International Air Transport Association officials said today that a new system of air cargo rates between North America and Europe had been accepted by scheduled airlines on the North and Middle Atlantic routes.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 26 (UP)--The Boston Red Sox scored a 2-to-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox today. The game was one of the swiftest exhibitions ever played--taking 1 hour 34 minutes.

OMAHA, March 26 (AP)--The Strategic Air Command, the nation's long range striking arm, declared on its ninth birthday anniversary today that it had the ability to: qLift "anything we want to lift"--meaning the heaviest type of hydrogen bomb--in its intercontinental B-36's.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 26 (AP)--Howard's Clothes of St. Paul, Minn., with four of its five members bowling over 600, set an opening night team record of 3,015 pins tonight. The mark was established in the first open division session of the Fifty-second American Bowling Congress tournament.

Empire in Asia The National Commitee for the Independence of Eastern Turkestan has protested to the Colombo Powers, according to a Times dispatch from Ankara, Turkey, because "not one enslaved country of Asia or Africa has been invited to the [Bandung] conference," adding that "no imperialist country should have been invited, whereas the oldest and most tyrannical imperialist country, China, will participate."
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 26 --Tennessee Valley Authority supporters are prepared for a last-ditch fight against the Dixon-Yates power contract.
NEW DELHI, India, March 26--Burma's Premier plans to make a personal attempt to get the leaders of the United States and Communist China "understand" each other's fears.

The recently published report of the National Planning Association on the operations of the Philippine American Life Insurance Company shows dramatically that the operations of United States companies abroad can be both profitable and profoundly influential in building goodwill for this country.

ALTHOUGH Soviet Russia is the principal victim of "Silk Stockings," the tone of the new musical lampoon has a familiar ring. It recalls "Of Thee I Sing" and "I'd Rather Be Right" from the" Thirties when the wayward Government of the United States was toasted on the griddle.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N. H., March 26 (AP)--Brooks Dodge of the United States Army, an American Olympic ski team choice, broke the trail record today in winning his fourth Eastern downhill championship and Webber Cup.
The New York A. C. polo team defeated New Jersey in the Eastern 12-goal tournament at the Squadron A Armory last night. Herb Pennell scored seven goals to pace the Winged Foot riders 12-10 triumph.
TAMPA, Fla., March 26--The Redlegs scored three runs in the seventh inning just before rain ended their contest with the Dodgers today. A 6--6 tie at Al Lopez Field was the result.
Just One Break, Inc., a placement service for the handicapped, will benefit from a dinner dance, ''Preview to the May Wine Festival" on May 16 at Luchow's.'

IN 1216 King John lost wagonloads of gold ornaments, gold and silver plate, the Crown Jewels and the Regalia of England in the quicksands of an English estuary; nothing was ever recovered, in spite of repeated attempts. When twentiethcentury Peter, who tells this story, heard about the lost treasure, he resolved to make his own search, and got his friend Simon to join him.

FITTING into close places where a pipe wrench won't go, a, ratchet chain wrench is adjustable over a wide range of pipes (5/8" to 4 1/2") and grips any round or hex shape without slipping. Saves buying a full set of pipe wrenches, yet gives you the right size when you need it.
THE Eastern bridge tournament's last scheduled contest, the pair tournament for the Julian Goldman trophy, ends today and so does a busy spring season of tournament bridge for New York players.

THERE are two chief reasons for the unusual interest of these memoirs--and the very duality of the reasons enters into the unusualness of the interest. Vernon Duke's life itself is an uncommonly fascinating exercise in duality.

LOS ANGELES. THE attenuated bronze figures of a father, mother, son and infant daughter are causing a civic schism in Los Angeles. Designed to symbolize the objects of police protection and to adorn a seven-million-dollar Police Facilities Building soon to be completed.

One afternoon in East Fiftysecond Street, a 7-year-old member of the Kips Bay Boys Club was carrying some packages for Mrs. Colley E. Williams, president of the organization's women's board, after a meeting at the clubhouse.

ALONG the beautiful, rockbound Channel Shore of Nova Scotia life moves serenely. The dozen or so families in the community trust each other in almost everything except religion; they cut wood, till the soil, fish, gossip around the stove at Katen's general store and generally seek nothing more than to "leave their name on the land."

Next Wednesday evening the seven vice presidents of the First National Bank of New York will pick up their hats-- traditionally perched on their roll-top desks as a signal to others that they are in the bank --and bid good night to the guards, just as they've done for years.
LONDON, March 26 -- The crazy behavior of climbers suffering from lack of oxygen on the heights of the Himalayas is reported in this week's British Medical Journal.
CHARLESTON, S. C., March 24--Some of the country's richest soil is being reclaimed for agricultural and recreational purposes from this state's vast marshlands area.

The use of brick in the construction of dwellings is on the increase, according to Dr. Robinson Newcomb, market analyst for the Structural Clay Products Institute. He said brick is used in 29 per cent for the one-family houses being erected today.

Thanks to advances in preventive medicine, the medical services of the country's armed forces have achieved a record in reducing illness among military personnel, the general counsel of the Defense Department reported last night.
A briefcase filled with school books, aspirin and travel brochures point up the timetable life of a New York University student.
Heat pumps are about to invade the North.

BEIRUT, Lebanon--Highlight of this country's 1955 tourism year is a program, to bring many of Lebanon's 1,000,000 emigrees rack to their homeland for a visit this summer. Though the Tourism Department's work this year is aimed mainly at these sons of Lebanon overseas, the ordinary visitor will reap benefits too, in better hotel facilities, easier transportation, and a number of notable cultural events planned during the year.
There's an amateur publisher in town who has enough difficulties to be a real professional. He has: qNo staff. qNo printer. qReport card tests at deadline time.

CAIRO, Sunday, March 27-- Israeli troops, more than 100 strong, opened fire on Egyptian paratroopers in the Gaza strip early last night. According to Egyptian Army headquarters they penetrated into Egyptianadministered territory during a ninety-minute engagement.

WASHINGTON. WITH an indefinite period of unremitting competitive coexistence ahead of us, during which military officers will be our reserve troops, our diplomats will be in the front line. Moscow and Peiping, determined to alter the world balance of power in their favor, probably prefer to take us on not where we are strongest --in hydrogen bombs' and jet airplanes-- but where we are weaker--in limited engagements, political and economic warfare, propaganda and diplomacy.

MOST atom books start off with a placid discussion of the pre-bomb atoms at their innocent play. Then comes World War II. Then comes Los Alamos. Then come the A-bomb and Hiroshima. Then comes the Hbomb.

Duster costumes comprising full-length coats over dresses led the list of items ordered from manufacturers last week, resident buying offices report. Delivery on key popular-priced Easter dresses slowed further, as producers were not prepared to meet the rush of reorders.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) --Senator Walter F. George said today he saw "no grounds for complaint" that the White House had not cooperated properly with Democratic Congressional leaders.

AS the number of her successful novels attest, Pamela Hansford Johnson is a sensitive and extremely able writer: her last novel, "Catherine Carter," was deservedly praised. And now her latest, "An Impossible Marriage," is certain to be widely read and discussed, particularly since it is both controversial in implication and seriously thoughtful without being didactic or preachy.

Separation WE are all, in the last analysis, alone. And this basic state of solitude is not something we have any choice about. It is, as the poet Rilke says, "Not something that one can take or leave.

LONDON, March 26 --The British Government is considering whether to propose a control and inspection corps of "several thousand" officials, recruited from all over the world, to make international disarmament effective.

Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases has received a grant of $100,000 from the Fannie E. Rippel Foundation. The money is to be used over two to three years for "discovering and developing a sensitive diagnostic test for the early detection of human cancer."

Frictions Over Yalta The White House invitation to Democratic leaders to participate in this week's foreign policy, briefing was set down to two things-- the role which Senator George had played in urging a top-level big power conference; the deep anger of the Democrats over the Yalta papers.

FAIRLEIGH DICKINSON--Growth Fairleigh Dickinson (N. J.) College has completed plans for a new engineering and science building at the Teaneck campus. The building will be devoted entirely to laboratories, demonstration rooms and clinical facilities.

BOSTON, March 26 (UP)--The Boston Celtics overcame the Syracuse Nationals, 100 to 97, in an overtime game today at Boston Garden to keep their National Basketball Association play-off hopes alive. Boston lost the first two games in the threeof-five series.

THE story goes that an 8-year-old came home in tears one afternoon recently. "Am I so terrible?" he sobbed to his mother, "am I so terrible?" Mother assured him immediately that he was a wonderful lad.
Ground has been broken for a $400,000 office building in Freeport, L. I. It is scheduled to be completed in June.
MIAMI BEACH, March 26 (AP) --Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert fought their way into the final of the Good Neighbor tennis tournament today.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Raking lawns is more important than rolling them in spring. Rake every inch now to improve their appearance. Then spread fertiliser. In areas where grass is thin, loosen the soil, scatter seed thickly and firm with the back of the rake. Postpone sowing a new lawn until fall, and instead sow annual rye now.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy announced today the creation of a citizens' panel to help speed peaceful uses of the atom.

ON April 4 Trans-Canada Airlines will inaugurate service by turbine-powered Viscount planes between New York and Toronto. Although British Overseas Airways is already operating Viscounts in the West Indies and Capital Airlines will introduce them on its routes in the United States later this year, T. C. A., with its New York-Toronto flights, will be pioneering the service in North America.

HYBRID tea roses are pruned by the average gardener for one reason --to spur the production of flowers in quantity and quality. But pruning has several other effects. One of these is to stimulate new stems (canes) which in time will replace those that die off or outlive their usefulness.

HONG KONG. A SONG once popular with the Chinese Communists, but banned since they rose to power, has been used to introduce one of our radio programs beamed behind the Bamboo Curtain. It is called "Strange Song." Its words, as translated by a young Chinese in Hong Kong, are these: Few strange things happened in past years, But many strange things happened this year.
The Independent Tanker Association has reiterated a demand that 75 per cent of all oil imported into this country be carried on United States-flag vessels.
TRENTON, March 26 -- New Jersey will begin Friday to extend compensation to the victims of uninsured and financially irresponsible motorists.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, March 26--Plans for construction of Alaska's first church-created four-year liberal arts college received major impetus with the arrival here this week of thirtythree Methodist leaders.

The President has asked Congress for a special Civil Defense appropriation of $12,000,000 to be used to evolve "a complete package plan" for protecting ninety-two critical target cities against hydrogenbomb attack. Civil Defense Administrator Peterson states that this money would permit an immediate beginning on defense studies for the populations of eight to ten major cities and that "the City of New York with its enormous population concentration will be given the highest possible priority."

Start of construction work has been announced on The Riviera, a ten-story apartment house for sixty-eight families at 2601 Henry Hudson Parkway West in the Riverdale section of the West Bronx. The building is expected to be ready for occupancy late this year.

TRENTON, March 26--Samuel L. Bodine, Republican State Chairman in New Jersey, henceforth will handle the distribution of Federal patronage here. He will make the final recommendations to Washington in respect to such appointments.

THE jacket describes this book as "the real story of the real America from its beginnings to now." With all respect for its distinguished author, one might point out that it is not so much an account of American history as it is a Garrett's eye-view of our traditions and experiences.

Bell Telephone Laboratories and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced last week that their engineers had succeeded in transmitting television signals 200 miles without relay stations. This development is important because "line-of-sight" transmission between antennas placed on towers on the horizon (about thirty miles apart) was thought to be the only practical means of transmitting by radio the wide bands needed for television and multichannel telephone service.
JERUSALEM, March 26--Premier Moshe Sharett directed the attention of the United States and Britain today to the "seriousness" of the situation along the border of the Egyptian-held Gaza strip.
Bullish sentiment regained fervor in Wall Street last week and stock prices advanced sharply. The market scored its best rally since the November election week.

THE hotly discussed, frequently delayed but plainly inevitable wedding ceremony between Broadway theatre and closed-circuit television will be performed tomorrow night in thirty-two motion-picture houses from coast to coast. Altogether, these theatres have a seating capacity of 80,000, which, if there is a sellout, will yield an estimated $400,000.

HOBOKEN, N. J., March 26-- Minnie Marconi, prima donna statue of the New York World's Fair, added another chapter today to the saga of ill fortune that has pursued her ever since. Her legs were broken.
The Health Department must increase salaries if resignations from its professional staff are to be halted, the New York Academy of Medicine has advised the city.
This is the time of the year when many high school students are worried. They have sent off their applications for admission to the college of their choice, and now are anxiously awaiting acceptance.

THE principle of justice for all is deeply rooted in the American legal system and guaranteed by the Constitution. Yet the guarantee becomes a fraud unless there is someone qualified to advise the poor man of his rights and to take his part against a powerful antagonist.
WOODFORD, England, March 26--Sir Winston Churchill counseled his countrymen today to place "the safety and honor of our beloved country" above party.

MOST home owners, if they had to choose just one small deciduous flowering tree for their property, would vote for flowering dogwood (Cornus florida). Or they may choose the red flowering variety (C. florida rubra) which is more often pink.
The completely automatic factory --"real automation"--is possible today, a leading scientist said here last week.

IN this era of "planned parenthood" Thomas Byrnes and his wife, Ginny, are the parents of nine children. They planned it that way; they look upon them as luxuries and they can't "afford" them anymore than they can afford a new car.

Six mama kangaroos, with five babies peeping out of the mothers' built-in handbags, appeared yesterday morning at Broadway and Thirty-third Street, in a show window of the Gimbels department store. The sixth adult female is expecting the stork (or whatever bird brings baby kangaroos) in a day or two.

"I purchased an old house six years ago and began to undertake projects to keep my mind off business, as an escape from the printed word. I progressed by fits and starts, ending up with a completely remodeled house and grounds.

TO THE EDITOR: In his debate with Aaron Copland on modern music in your issue of March 13, Henry Pleasants relies heavily upon two misconceptions to justify his thesis. The first is that serious music was, in the past, of interest to the people in general; the second, that if serious music were regarded today (by the people) as being vital it would be financially successful, as it was in the past.

LOS ANGELES, March 26 -- "Aggressor," the United States' mythical enemy in armed service maneuvers, won another smashing victory this week. But as usual, the victory won't further his evil designs of conquest one bit.

FRIDAY is opening day for two new shows at the New York Botanical Garden located in Bronx Park, N. Y. The Easter Show will be unveiled in the Conservatory and the Museum Building will house an educational pruning exhibit.

GOOD Americans might as well face it, when contemplating a holiday in Europe. They are quite likely, for a while after arrival, or even on the way, to feel somewhat queazy. There is almost certain to be a need of adjustment for those industrious, patriotic servants, their bodies, on reaching foreign parts and taking up residence.

A tract at Poplar Avenue an Frederick Street in Little Ferry, N. J., has been purchased by Louis Marrone for improvement with twenty dwellings. The purchase was made from the Witson Realty Corporation through the Sonn - Saalberg Company, broker.

TO THE EDITOR: I'M afraid Mrs. Ball has rather misinterpreted the parts of my review she takes up in her letter. At any rate, she has changed some of what she quotes. I'll pass "the puzzling demands of society" as a condensation of what I wrote; but I did not run satire, bitterness, anger and violent humor together nor state that fiction should respond to its present environment with a melange of these qualities.
Sir Winston Churchill disclosed in a recent House of Commons debate that two years ago "I was struck down by a very sudden illness which paralyzed me completely physically."
WASHINGTON, March 26-- The House Appropriations Committee moved today to give Congress a firm day-to-day checkrein on public housing, slum clearance and urban redevelopment programs.

DURING Al Schacht's boyhood in New York City, Irish and Italian street fighters, and other critics, tried continually to kill him, but Schacht survived. During his young manhood beautiful and wealthy girls schemed to marry him, but Al escaped.

Danger-and Hope President Eisenhower's news conference last Wednesday reflected the preoccupation in Washington with the pervading problem: How to deal with the Communists in the thermonuclear age. Nineteen of the twenty-five questions put to him dealt with the cold war.

A LARGE statue of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek dominates the road approach to Pine Hill Airfield in Taipei, the capital of the Chinese Nationalists on Formosa. It looks out toward the lost mainland of China more than one hundred miles away across the Formosa Strait.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --Gerald C. Summers has received a patent for inventing a new means of finding oil by bouncing echoes through the bowels of the earth.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 26 (AP)--The managing editor of The Louisville Times said today that there was nothing wrong "with paying a good reporter an executive salary so long as he is worth it."
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Farm surpluses may force the Administration to ask Congress for $2,000,000,000 more this year for price-support operations.
MOSCOW, March 26--Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin expressed today a "positive attitude" toward President Eisenhower's ideas on holding a four-power conference.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 26--Columbia University, the Intercollegiate Association saber titleholder, won the team crown in the finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's fencing championships today at Michigan State College.

IN traditional as well as modern interiors today, the trend is toward a blend of several periods rather than exact reproduction of an authentic room from another time. One era is usually chosen for emphasis. There are elements from other periods and, perhaps, a touch of something modern.

A big and talented East squad routed the West, 83 to 68, in the ninth annual college All-Star basketball game at Madison Square Garden last night. Proceeds of the program went to the Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund.
A plea to end, or at least amend, the estate's Security Risk Law has been made by the New York Civil Liberties Union. The group is an affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) --A former bookkeeper for a Newark insurance agency said today the agency forwarded to an insurance company at least 20 per cent less than the amount paid in premiums by union employes.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- One of the services the Senate study of the stock market performed was to direct some attention to the state of the economy.
Civilization seems to have made young children and aged parents the greatest problems of the modern family.
Jeremiah M. O'Brien will quit reluctantly as the assistant postmaster of Brooklyn next Thursday after almost fifty years in the Government service.

LONDON--It is entirely possible for an American tourist to live comfortably in London, Paris or Rome on under $10 a day. A costs study by the writer, made over a fiveyear period, shows it can be done on a three-city average of $9.70.

Young men and women who are being treated for pulmonary tuberculosis at the Stony Wold (N. Y.) Sanatorium will benefit from the annual card party to be given by the Chi Kappa Club on April 21 at the WaldorfAstoria.
ALBANY, March 26--The Republican State Chairman urged today a program of tax relief for bus companies.

THEY may be amateurs in the do-it-yourself field but, more and more, they are educated amateurs. This is the running theme of comments by exhibitors and demonstrators at the New York Do-It-Yourself Show, which tonight ends its week at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

To the Travel Editor: WERE you laughing when you published that silly article about East vs. West by Senator Neuberger of Oregon? Maybe he is just discovering that the Appalachians aren't as high as the Rockies, but a lot of us Easterners have known it for years.

WHILE the stock market showed some signs of nervousness during the period formal hearings of the Fulbright Committee were under way, industrial activity kept forging ahead. It has in fact come so far that existence of a boom is discerned by many observers.

BERLIN, March 26--In a dramatic and emotional interview a lieutenant colonel in the Soviet Air Force and his wife met their son today at United States headquarters in West Berlin, but failed to persuade him to return to Russia.

Albany Home Stretch The 178th session of the New York State Legislature has been dominated largely by a political duel between Democratic Governor Averell Harriman and the Republicans in control of the Senate and Assembly.
Waxman Brothers, builders, today are opening Seaview Village, a development that will contain 2,000 homes in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.

STUDENTS are just like people, but as a rule they have less money. The result is that the post-war descent on Europe of Americans hungry for history, culture, high-life, international understanding and French bread has developed an important sideline known as student travel.
WHAT constitutes a good fishing camp?

WITH an influx of nearly 5,000 American college students over a fourweek period Bermuda's annual Easter capacity crowd of visitors was assured weeks ago. It is feared that the island will not look its best this Easter, florally speaking.
NEW HAVEN, March 26 -- Yale University has discovered a city 600 miles long with a population of 34,000,000.
HARTFORD, March 26--The Connecticut General Assembly starts next week the task of trying to balance the state budget for the two-year period beginning July 1. One propospal is a state income tax.
CHICAGO, March 26--Wes Santee set a meet record tonight and came within sixtenths of a second of the world indoor record in winning the Bankers Mile in 4:04.2.
One hundred sixty-eight pairs of bridge experts completed play last night in the first two qualifying rounds of the foursession tournament for the Julian Goldman Cup.
WASHINGTON, March 26-- Military predictions that the Chinese Communists might attack Matsu or Quemoy in mid-April were viewed with skepticism by diplomats here today.

Premier Mario Scelba of Italy, arriving in this country today and scheduled to visit this city on Wednesday, is warmly welcome. Signor Scelba has proved himself in a hard school. As Minister of the Interior in the third de Gasperi Cabinet, in 1947, he set up what the resentful Communists called a "police state."

TIRA, Israel, March 26--United States aid to Israel has resulted in water for the homes and fields of this Arab village. It is part of an improvement in the way of life here that seems almost revolutionary.
Six of the programs to be played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at the Berkshire Festival this summer will be devoted wholly to Beethoven.
KANSAS CITY, March 26-- For several years now coal has been called a "sick industry." But L. Russell Kelce, 57-year-old head of the Sinclair coal organization, doesn't see it that way.
OTTAWA, March 26--Premier Mario Scelba of Italy met with Canadian leaders today in a series of discussions on problems of mutual interest.

AINTREE, England, March 26--Irish horses placed first and third today in the Grand National steeplechase, the world's most grueling race. Quare Times, a 9-year-old owned by Mrs. William Welman of Mullingar County, Westmeath, Ireland, won at 100 to 9.

IT might almost seem that one of the qualifications for office in American public life is being a Philistine about art. Or, if the candidate is not downright antagonistic to the arts, that he be at least only a champion of what ex-President Truman referred to as "hamand-egg art," which bears the same relation to art as the Missouri Waltz does to Mozart. Or, maybe, like Churchill and President Eisenhower, that he be a dabbler.

Puerto Rican children of the Nativity Mission of New York City will spend part of their summer vacations at camps as a result of a cocktail party and tea dance to be given on April 9. The Latin American Court of the Catholic Daughters of America is sponsor of the benefit, to be held in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26--Harold E. Stassen special assistant to President Eisenhower, warned today against "unilateral disarmament" as a potential threat to peace.
The writer of the following letter, Associate Professor of Government at the City College, is author of "Charles Evans Hughes and the Supreme Court."

Elmira College, a woman's college in Elmira, N. Y., has begun an extensive business and industry survey among more than 600 of the nation's leading corporations. The survey is being conducted as part of the college's 1955 centennial program.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 28 --The Democratic minority of the Illinois Legislature this week retreated to prepared positions to ctave off legislative inquiry into Chicago's Democratic-dominated political affairs.
A psychiatrist called yesterday for harmonious family life as the best solution to the rising crime wave among juveniles.

A NEW electronic flash unit that reintroduces the nickel-cadmium rechargeable battery which has not been on the market for several years was announced here last week by Harry L. Parker, president of the American Speedlight Corporation.
Barnard College sophomores danced and hurdled to a victory over freshmen yesterday in the fifty-third annual Greek Games.

Communist China is "dizzy with success," Secretary of State John Foster Dulles asserted last week, adding that Peiping's tactics "may prove more, dangerous and provocative of war" than the more cautious techniques Moscow has used for expansion.

LONDON. WHETHER Generalissimo Francisco Franco likes it or not, the film version of Kate O'Brien's Spanish novel "That Lady" has given the film world a new star. As is well known, the critical acclaim and public acclaim of such an arrival are the second and third stages of the process.

Record financing for the sale of "used" houses in Northern New Jersey is reported by the J. I. Kislak Mortgage Corporation. The company said that its scattered loans division, in cooperation with 250 real estate brokers who required the funds to finance the sale of "used" dwellings, approved and committed more than $7,000,000 in mortgage loans during the first nine weeks of this year.

Succes Fou IT is entirely possible that the junior miss of French fiction, 18-year-old Francoise Sagan, is universally irresistible. Her "Bonjour Tristesse" captivated the quick hearts and minds of her countrymen critics right off.
American Federation of Labor seamen have won a "pooling of employment" system for seniority purposes, similar to their industry-wide vacation plan.

DENVER, March 26 (AP)--Jim Walsh, Phillips 66ers' captain, sank a long last-second basket tonight to gain a 66-64 victory over Luckett-Nix of Boulder, Colo. The victory carried the Oilers to the National Amateur Athletic Union basketball championship.

THE subtitle labels this book as "An Entertainment." Returning from a holiday in Ireland, Peter Weston becomes custodian of Daisy, a three-foot alligator with a blue silk bow around its neck. (Its owner, a retired seafaring man, decided to part with it rather than with his wife.)
AS a way-station on the road to marketing a house that builds itself, the purveyors to do-it-yourself have come up with paints that spray themselves.
DANBURY, Conn., March 26 --This city will go to the polls Monday to elect a Mayor and other municipal officials.

With a grant of $132,000 from the National Science Foundation, Harvard will build a sixty-foot radio "telescope," which is a sensitive parabolic receiver of radio signals that come from outer space. The instrument is to be situated at the George R. Agassiz Station of Harvard's observatory at Harvard, Mass.

THE recent decision of the country's biggest insurance companies to cut automobile liability rates 9 to 32 per cent for certain categories of women drivers under 25, while conceding practically nothing to men of the same age, is simply the newest manifestation of a phenomenon faced by the Romans.

PARIS, March 26--Aristotle Socrates Onassis, Greek shipping magnate, today endeavored to disparage charges of fraud against him in connection with his Saudi Arabian oil shipping contracts. The case will soon be sent to the courts for decision on whether there is ground for the complaint of fraud.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26--The Dodgers and the Yankees, perennial rivals in the spring and frequent rivals in the fall, continued their itinerant series here yesterday. They had squared off for two games in Miami, for one in Vero Beach, and then for the one here. They have now parted, but they will be reunited a fortnight hence at Ebbets Field and at the Stadium.

A three-year survey of the value and effectiveness of school health service in New York City is to be undertaken by the Board of Education. A grant of $159,940 from the United States Public Health Service will make this project possible. The study is designed to find ways in which the medical examination of school children can be improved and health defects can be remedied.
TO THE EDITOR: As a concert-goer, I should like to lead a cheering section for the criticism Henry Pleasants expresses on modern music.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Silver pieces are being counted carefully every night at the Corcoran Art Gallery. A "Fifty Years of Danish Silver" exhibition is on, and gallery officials are not taking any chances.

DESPITE the dirges that have been intoned for radio since its replacement by television in most American homes, there are some programs that can be done to greater advantage by means of the older medium.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 26--The Supreme Court announced this week that on April 11 it would hear oral arguments on the thorny problem of how to accomplish desegregation in public schools with dual race practices.

C.S. FORESTER has two skills which are admirably blended in "The Good Shepherd," a firstrate novel of World War II. He is able to make us identify ourselves with the tensions and the loneliness of man, this time a man in command of many men.

SLICK in style, sizzling in action, Oscar Schisgall's novel about the members of the executive suite of a big department store moves with express-train speed from first page to last. The man who sparks all this motion is appropriately named Paul Blaze, the dynamic newcomer called to the post of general manager by the board of directors of Selby's.
A three-acre site in New Rochelle, N. Y., has been selected for a new retail development. Kr as the Wykagyl Shopping Center, the project is sponsored by Sam Minskoff Sons, builders.
HARTFORD, March 26--Industrial problems besetting Connecticut will henceforth be handled by Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff acting de facto as his own Commissioner of Commerce.

WE listened with admiration and enjoyment to the performance of Monteverdi's "Coronation of Poppea" by the American Opera Society, sung in English translation, under Arnold Gamson's direction, last Tuesday night in Town Hall.
ST. LOUIS, March 26 (UP)-- Six St. Louis University freshmen are putting their heads together, electronically, to face the harsh reality of mid-semester examinations starting tomorrow.

THE amazing growth of American film production abroad has made the emergence of the "Hollywood-on - the - Continent" novel perhaps inevitable. It is a pleasure to report that this American novel about American film-making in Europe, while indisputably light-weight, is a thoroughly pleasant romp through the canvas trees and papier-mache rocks of Cinecitta.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 26 --Uneasiness and distrust here over United States plans on Quemoy and Matsu are growing.
Oscar Panno of Buenos Aires, chess champion of Argentina, won the only game played yesterday in the international masters tournament at Mar del Plata, according to South American news sources.

A SAMPLE of what photographic shows in the future may look like if predictions come true that color photography eventually will almost completely replace black-and-white, may be seen at the one-man all-color print exhibition by Eliot Porter which opened last week at Limelight Photo Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- An accelerated search for oil is under way all over the world, the International Labor Organization reports after a survey. Political factors have stimulated the hunt, the findings indicate.

THE old saw, "It's not the heat, it's the humidity," applies to houses as well as to humans. In the home, excess humidity shows up as condensation; walls sweat, pipes drip, clothes mildew and exterior paint blisters.
PARIS, Sunday, March 27-- France's long delayed acceptance of German rearmament came at 4:45 o'clock this morning.

Department store sales in the United States in the week ended March 19 were 14 per cent greater than in the like week last year, according to the Federal Reserve Board. In the previous week they were up 11 per cent, in the four weeks ended March 19 they increased 11 per cent and in the year to that date they were 8 per cent higher than in the corresponding 1954 period.

JAMES BLISH'S latest novel surpasses even the high Blish standards, and offers that very rare thing, a wholly new concept of the far future. Mr. Blish has concocted a revolutionary type of interstellar hobo; rather than the usual lone wanderer in space (or shipload of such), drifting from job to job, he has created vagabond cities!

THE peculiar significance of this book arises from the fact it presents the techniques, the hazards and the social importance of public speaking from the unusual point of view of one who has earnestly shouted for over half a century into the teeth of the gale of prevailing public opinion.

Readers of this newspaper may well have been startled by a Washington dispatch from Anthony Leviero, published yesterday. Their minds will not be relieved by James Reston's article on the Far Eastern situation, on this page today. Mr. Reston quotes Senator Walter F. George of Georgia, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.

Horse racing will return to New York Friday. Competition among the flat runners will begin at the Jamaica track in Queens County. The harness horses will open the season that night at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L. I.
WASHINGTON, March 26 --The citizens' panel established by the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy to study the impact of atomic power is charged by the committee with four main duties.

A white-haired man of 80 sat in an armchair before a television set in his Ozone Park, Queens, home yesterday afternoon. He was watching the running of the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park. And he was worried.
A Cabinet officer to represent the fine arts was suggested four times yesterday at the closing sessions of a Columbia University Student Council conference.

The 103 Better Business Bureaus in the United States and Canada handled 2,005,288 inquiries and complaints, a record number, in 1954. This was announced last week in a report issued by Victor H. Nyborg, president of the Association of Better Business Bureau, Inc.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 26 --The possibility of violence in the conflict between Premier Ngo Dinh Diem and armed opposition groups increased tonight.
TO THE EDITOR: I enjoyed the informative "Ghee Is for Good" (March 6), by R. K. Narayan, in which the author described that delicious Indian concoction derived from clarified butter.

NOT ALL the charm of daffodils lies in the perfection of Individual blossoms. The appeal of a mass planting that inspired Wordsworth--"A host of golden daffodils... tossing their heads in sprightly dance"--may be had at little cost.

TRENTON -- The establishment of an ocean-going ferry service to connect Cape May and the southern tip of the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey with lower Delaware came a step nearer reality last week.

MANY of the nation's orchestras are struggling under the disadvantage of having to play in inadequate halls. The Seattle Symphony is a case in point. It is obliged to give its concerts in the barnlike Civic Auditorium, which has a seating capapity of 6,000.

SELF-HELP devices and study aids are always popular. Therefore Remington Records ought to make out well with its new recording of the Viotti Concerto No. 23 in G Major, first release of a series of projected Young Violinists' Editions.

THE conclusion of last week's column has left me with an uneasy feeling. It was not my intention to suggest that literature, in order to be worth-while, must forswear realism and turn, with James Branch Cabell, to the life of dream.

ANN ARBOR, Mich. WITHIN the next two or three weeks, the eyes of the world will be turned upon a slowspeaking University of Michigan professor with thinning hair and a sandy mustache. His name is Dr. Thomas Francis Jr., and he will report on last year's trial of the Salk polio vaccine.
ALBANY, March 26 (AP)--Albany political writers entertained Governor Harriman tonight with a musical skit depicting him leading his followers on a march to Washington and "the Potomac Paradise."

The life of a robin, or of any early migrating bird, must be full of adventure and surprise. The things that can happen to a bird who comes north with the best of expectations while spring is only a promise would make most of us homebound humans very sorry for ourselves indeed.

"LITTERBUGS"--currently so unpopular with New York's Sanitation Department--were given their dubious title several years ago by a blond, blue-eyed cartoonist, Mrs. Amelia Opdyke Jones of East Orange, N. J., better known as The Subway Sun's "Oppy."
The highest percentage of deaths from polio has been noted among persons over 14 years old who were stricken after the onset of another case in the same family.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that $100,000,000 of state and city credit would be available on Jan. 1, 1956, for low-interest loans on cooperative and limiteddividend housing for middle-income tenants.

More-than-seasonal pick-ups in new orders and production again have been registered this month. This is interpreted by the National Association of Purchasing Agents as indicating a "boomlet" for the first half of this year.
Undeterred by the prospect of winter-like weather, thousands of youngsters and a good many of their elders will be out of bed early today to watch the circus come to town.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 --The question, "what is a firstclass hotel room?" has entered into preliminary planning for the Republican National Convention here in 1956.

THE official Hollywood emergence of Richard Egan as Twentieth Century-Fox' newest "hot property" offers a guide: Go south (from San Francisco) and hang on for dear life. Pocket appetite, pride and college degree over a lean four-year period, as just another greenhorn in one of the most competitive places on earth.

AS part of the Masters plan to produce thirty or so novels about the exploits of the British in India (which, at the author's age, calls for one or more a year), "Coromandel!" holds specimen interest. As a fifth link in the shiny chain which began in 1951 with "Nightrunners of Bengal" and included last year's "Bhowani Junction," it appears rather fragile.

Six college student panelists on the New York Times Youth Forum agreed yesterday on the need for formal religious training. They differed, however, on whether the acceptance of rigid principles or a more elastic individual concept should prevail.

CERTAIN peoples have natural affinities one with another, which are among the pleasanter constants of history. Such, for example, is the friendship between Poles and Scots, between French and Turks. Such, too, since long before the days when Richard I and Saladin vied with one another in courtesy, is the mutual affection between the English and the inhabitants of Syria, Arabia and Kurdistan.
Plans for Park City in Queens, probably the largest rental apartment development in the country, were announced in detail yesterday. It will cost $50,000,000 and will house 4,000 families.

TORONTO, March 26 (UP)-- The Detroit production line belted two first-period goals and great checking made them stand up tonight. As a result, the Red Wings pushed the Toronto Maple Leafs to the edge of elimination in their Stanley Cup semi-final series with a 2-1 victory before 12,831 fans.
Members of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association have arranged their annual benefit card party for the afternoon of April 19 in the ballroom of the Colony Club.
BONN, Germany, March 26-- Deputies of all parties are participating in the fight here to guarantee the West German citizen 65 per cent of his previous wages when he can no longer work.

HORICON, Wis., March 26 (UP)--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said tonight President Eisenhower should spend "less time with golf" and should give more attention to freeing American citizens held by the Chinese Communists.

Clivia is a plant which formerly was seen largely at the annual March flower shows. Of late gardeners, even in apartment houses, have been seeing it at closer range. Since it is gaining favor both East and West the experience of gardeners from these areas is given below.
Despite the official start of spring last Monday, the city and large parts of the nation were reminded yesterday that winter could still get in some good licks.

Stage, screen, radio and television stars will perform in a "Dream Show" as a special feature of the premiere of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on Wednesday evening at Madison Square Garden.

A skeptical storekeeper who does more than $10,000,000 worth of business each year lashed out last week at retailers "who seem to think big profits are assured for all mechants in fast - mushrooming suburban shopping centers."

QUEEN ELIZABETH dispatched Lord Essex to subdue the Irish rebels under Tyrone with the realization that her favorite could afford neither success nor failure. Success would only increase her suspicions that her young lover longed for the power of the crown more than for the aging woman who wore it.

LONDON -- When the liner Queen Elizabeth resumes her Southampton - CherbourgNew York run on Wednesday, she will be equipped with stabilizers that should make her one of the steadiest of the trans-Atlantic liners.

TO THE EDITOR: ELIZABETH JANEWAY in her review of my novel "Philippa" says that her reaction to the problems in it was "I couldn't care less." And she adds, "This disastrous reaction I have felt more and more frequently while reading current fiction."

Developments in world markets during the last several weeks indicate that sharp changes are taking place in the Soviet bloc's policy on trade with the non-Communist world. Both political and economic considerations seem involved in the shift.

"THERE'S no limit to how far you can go," he said expansively. "There's the Indian Hall, the Akeley African Hall and the North American Hall. It'll take years to finish them." This was the American Museum's famous Jimmy Clark back in early 1925 in the act of hiring Robert H. Rockwell, taxidermist.

A land mortgage department has been established as a permanent service by the Northern New Jersey Mortgage Associates after two months on an experimental basis. A revolving fund of $10,000,000 will be available to builders under the new plan.

ROME--The Sicilians were immensely cheered by the announcement that Sir Winston Churchill is going to spend his first real vacation in eighteen months on their island. Apart from political implications, his visit is the biggest break the ambitious Sicilian tourist industry has had since the day when it came under the care of the semi-autonomous regional government in Palermo.

JERUSALEM. THIRTY years ago on Friday the Rt. Hon. Earl of Balfour spoke to 7,000 persons on Mount Scopus. A little stooped with his 76 years, silver-haired, robed in Cambridge scarlet, the former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom seemed to many like an Old Testament prophet.
FROM the tropics and from the West Coast the vogue for brightly painted houses is spreading North and East. And it is creating new problems in landscape color harmony.

"ONCE upon a time," the innocent tale begins, and evokes an immediate expectation of wonder. Knowing how it is sure to end -"*** and so they lived happily ever after"--we settle down just as happily to listen. Among the writers of fairy tales, Hans Christian Andersen, whose 150th birth anniversary will be celebrated next Saturday, ranks foremost.

LONDON, March 26--The tumult and the shouting of British politics polarized this week around two great individualists, Sir Winston Churchill and Aneurin Bevan. The foremost British Prime Minister of the century, the peer of Pitt and Gladstone, moved toward the exit.

Britain to Polls? The House of Commons fell silent last Tuesday as Sir Winston Churchill rose to answer a question about newspaper reports that his retirement was imminent. He said: The right honorable gentleman really must not be led away by all the chatter in the press.

THE shock administered by Vincent Van Gogh to Western painting, that of a meteorite crashing into an orderly garden, has not yet, sixty-five years after his death, worn off. He has been much shown, and well, in this country but the exhibition of eighty paintings and thirty drawings now on view at Wildenstein for the benefit of the Public Education Association is by no means superfluous, and illuminates pointfully every stage of his career.

AT least nine excursions for rail fans have been scheduled or are being lined up for the next two months. Opening the season next Saturday is a trip by the Railroad Enthusiasts on which the cars will be pulled by a steam locomotive of the camelback type.
To the Art Editor: We will soon be having warm weather and visitors from abroad and all parts of the United States will be visiting New York City.
WHERE and how to spend the $101,000,000,000 recommended in President Eisenhower's highway improvement program will cause much brow-wrinkling in Congress when it comes to allotment of Federal funds.

LONDON, March 26--According to informed diplomatic sources the British Government would not approve or support full-scale attacks by the United States on the Chinese mainland if the Communists attempted an invasion of the Matsu and Quemoy Islands.

Home buyers are being offered a wide variety of new dwellings on Long Island. The split-level design continues popular with many of the builders who are showing new models this week-end. Ranch and Cape Cod styles also are available in some of the new developments. Some of the dwellings are in the $12,000 to $15,000 price class but others are priced higher.

TO THE EDITOR: In Bess Furman's article "Hostess to the Mostest" (Feb. 27) about Mrs. Victoria Geaney, the busy hostess manager at Blair House in Washington, the author writes that Mrs. Geaney is "apt to say" to the Government's guests, "Lincoln stood before this fireplace when he offered com-

THE imagination and the enterprise of the small recording companies have had an enormous influence on the whole record industry. Particularly has this been so in the matter of repertory, and one of the areas in which the small companies have led the way is that of folk music.
Fourteen Americans are leaving New York early next month to establish a scientific outpost at the North Pole.
Home builders in Suffolk County are speeding delayed plans for projects which will provide about 2,000 new homes in the Deer Park-North Babylon area.

MESA, Ariz., March 26--Willie Mays broke loose for the Giants again today. Feeling the urge to move into the spotlight after putting in a more or less quiet week, Willie the Wonder exploded two home runs for New Yorkers.

HOLLYWOOD. THE twenty-seventh annual running of Hollywood's favorite contest, the "Oscar" derby, will end Wednesday night at the Pantages Theatre here when the names of the winners will be taken out of sealed envelopes in the presence of television cameras.
CHICAGO, March 26--Wide bias in the hiring of students was reported this week on the basis of an Illinois college survey.

HARLOW, England, March 26 --The citizens of this new town are assuming full responsibility for the civic administration of their local affairs with the election today of their first Urban District Council.
A family rate system for offseason trans-Atlantic air travel has been proposed.

BOWIE, Md., March 26 (AP)-- Helioscope returned to the races in sensational form today. He set a seven-furlong track record while winning the $15,000-added Southern Maryland Handicap by three lengths over Ifabody.
DETROIT, March 25--A young executive from a big auto company here was talking about the record-breaking production pace in the industry.
A new step toward national uniformity in handicapping of players has been taken by the United States Golf Association.

In the course of the Embreo Foundation Lecture which he recently delivered at Yale Dr. L. A. DuBridge, president of the California Institute of Technology, added his protest to that of the Federation of American Scientists against the Government's attitude toward science.

THE role of recanting Government informers has recently been spotlighted by Congressional committees. Most spectacular of these informers is the self-confessed, liar Harvey Matusow. In this book Matusow purports to tell the truth about testifying falsely and wrongfully labeling many as "Reds."

A JAPANESE twin-lens reflex camera with interchangeable lenses, an f/1.2 Japanese lens for miniature cameras, a high-speed Ansco miniature color film, and a group of new Keystone movie cameras and projectors will be among many new products to be introduced this week at the Atlantic City convention of the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 26-- Oklahoma A. and M. College tonight won the National Collegiate wrestling championship for the second successive year.
The nation's farm program must be revised if an agricultural crisis is to be avoided, in the opinion of a number of experts.

HOBOKEN, March 26--Pier C the first component of the American Export Lines' new Hoboken terminal, operated this week at 60 per cent of capacity with two freighters loading at the 750-foot-long single-deck structure.
Veteran foreign traders had to reach back to 1929 last week for a parallel to the debate that has broken out over the Eisenhower trade program.

There was a long debate in the House of Commons last week on what could happen to mankind if too many atomic bombs are exploded. It was feared that there might be a dangerous increase in the normal background of radiation to which all life is subjected.

"IN the fields of observation." said Pasteur, "chance only favors the mind prepared." Nowhere in the history of science was this fundamental truth more strikingly proved than in the discovery of penicillin by Sir Alexander Fleming, who died just this month.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 26 (UP) -- Edward Randall of Rochester, N. Y., won the American Seniors Golf Association championship today. He beat the defending champion, Judd Brumley of Greenville, Tenn., 1 up, in the final.
Wild Bill Hickok would very likely be pleased with his descendants, who run a company that makes belts strong enough for his holster and six-shooter.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., March 26--Mother Ellen Marie, Mother General of the Sisters of Charity at St. Elizabeth's Convent, has received word from Rome that the Very Rev. Antonio Leguisa has been appointed postulator for the process of beatification of Sister Miriam Teresa, who died in 1927.

THIS is a book written by a man of God for men of God. As such it may also be of value to those men of goodwill as yet without God who would expose themselves to overhearing in the secular order what is being said in the monastery.

Col. Nicholas W. Campanole, U. S. A., retired, of Coronado, Calif., who was a veteran of the Philippine Insurrection and both World Wars and was with General of the Armies John J. Fershing in Mexico, died yesterday in the Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif.

BUENOS AIRES, March 26-- Much has happened since the halcyon days when Juan Domingo Peron came to power ten years ago and made what Argentines call the "implicit pact" with the Roman Catholic Church. The church supported him and he gave the church privileges, honors, positions, economic aid and educational advantages.

Veteran artists and newcomers to the exhibition field in one-man shows account for almost all the attractions scheduled to open in New York galleries during the week. Shows of paintings dominate the events.

ONE of the most coveted of plants outdoors, as well as indoors as a house plant, is English ivy. Perhaps it is coveted all the more because it does not always prove easy. This ivy is versatile in its manner of growth, creeping as a groundcover or climbing high outdoors, and trailing or climbing as a house plant.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 --The California Academy of Sciences has joined the fight against the Interior Department's billion-dollar reclamationpower program for the Upper Colorado Basin.

SEOUL, Korea, March 26-- Thousands celebrating President Syngman Rhee's eightieth birthday anniversary today heard a former United States Army commander in Korea assert that victory over the Communists could have been won early in 1953 if his suggestions had been followed.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 26--Prime Minister Mohammed Ali will announce early next week two decisions designed to stabilize and unify the nation. They were approved today at a secret session of the Cabinet.
MANY people are likely to take a second look at chemical soil conditioners this spring. It is fairly certain that those who try them will get something for their money this time.

WE probably know as much about Verdi's life as we are ever likely to know. Perhaps on one point only is it just possible that further light may some day be shed--his reasons for not marrying the admirable Giuseppina Strepponi sooner than he did.
MIAMI BEACH, March 26 (AP) --Setting a torrid pace in the third round, Eric Monti jumped from eighth place into the lead today in the $12,500 Miami Beach open tournament.

Gold and enamel boxes and other small objects by goldsmiths of the Russian Court will be in a collection of art property to be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

MOSCOW, March 26 -- "Culture" is a word in everyday use in the Soviet Union. The idea is the subject of constant attention from the Communist party and Government.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 26 --The strike of Finnish Government employes in the lowest salary brackets was settled today. The tie-up had been paralyzing the state-owned railroads for twelve days and crippling key industries.
TOKYO, March 26--Premier Ichiro Hatoyama called today for revision, of the anti-rearmament clause in Japan's Constitution.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26--Casey Stengel, the manager of the Yankees, must appear in court here Wednesday morning to answer charges that he used obscene language and kicked a photographer during a game at Al Lang Field yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 26 --Today, eight months after the end of the Indochina war, turbulence and confusion continue to mark conditions in the southern half of Vietnam left in nonCommunist hands by the Geneva agreements.
IZMIR, Turkey, March 25-- Planners at this easternmost Atlantic alliance headquarters are sleeping better since Turkey signed the Defense Cooperation Agreement last month with Iraq.
MOSCOW, March 26 -- Soviet citizens spend less than onequarter of their incomes for rent, direct taxes, transportation, entertainment and other intangibles.
IT is likely that more has been written about Greta Garbo, the moody movie star, than about any other performer of the stage or screen that has ever lived.

THE first scheduled turboprop airline service in this country got under way early this month. It is a modest operation, handled by the armed services. That is why it warranted nothing like the fanfare that will mark the April 4 introduction of the British-made Vichers Viscount of Trans-Canada on Western Hemisphere routes.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- Administration officials believe that the biggest obstacles to a Big Four conference of foreign ministers have been removed.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams told 6,000 members of the department yesterday that the force had compiled in the last year "one of the greatest records of any Police Department."

A plot 220 by 100 feet improved with a factory building at the northwest corner of Walton Avenue and East 140th Street, the Bronx, has been assembled by Washlands, Inc., and will be improved with a new building containing 60,000 square feet for occupancy by Linens of the Week, Inc.

The American Seal-Kap Corporation of Delaware and the subsidiaries it acquired before 1954 had net profits last year of $70,738, or 39 cents a common share, against $90,448, or 50 cents a share, in 1953.
Bill Brown, who has been coaching Andover's sailing team, cornered Fred Harrison, the Big Blue's athletic director one day early last fall.

The chief of the animal production division of the Food and Agriculture Organization has made an important report to the United Nations. Technical assistance missions in the Far East are winning the battle against rinderpest, a cattle disease that has taken a toll of as many as 2,000,000 animals yearly in East and South Asia.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amounted to $67,910,577,803. They consist of 'Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

The rector of a Greenwich Village church told his congregation yesterday that he had resigned as a director of the American Church Union. He said he had acted in protest against the union's sponsorship of a national puzzle contest.
Two private bus lines art seeking to take over five Manhattan routes from the New York City Transit Authority.
JERUSALEM, March 27-- Egypt was held responsible today for a "brutal and murderous act of aggression" in the attack Thursday on a wedding party at the village of Patish.
MIAMI BEACH, March 27 (AP) -- Eric Monti carded a lastround 68 today to win the $12,500 Miami Beach open golf tournament with a total of 270.
THOMAS SCHIPPERS, who has been active principally as an opera conductor before the public of this city, conducted the concert of the Philharmonic -Symphony Orchestra Saturday night in Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- American workers are slowly abandoning the unions with Communist-line histories. Democratic processes are at the root of it.

ANTIGUA, Guatemala, March 27 (AP)--The Board of Directors of the Inter-American Press Association has nominated twentyseven newsmen to fill fifteen places on the board. The nominees chosen here yesterday are:

Foreign exchange market passed through one of its dullest weeks in months. Business was extremely light and in the main represented balancing of accounts with no extended interest on either side of the market.

Several complex elements are making the situation in Vietnam even worse than it would normally be expected to be. Southern Vietnam is a newly independent state without the adequate machinery to operate an independent government. It is taxed, at the moment, with more than half a million refugees from the Communist terror to the north.
CHICAGO, March 27 (AP)--A group of conservative Republicans today announced the start of "a nationwide drive to wrest control of the Republican party from New Dealers and internationalists."

A selection of Theodore Roosevelt's writings about the outdoors will be published April 8 by Dial Press, entitled "The Hunting and Exploring Adventures of Theodore Roosevelt." The book is edited by Donald Day and has an introduction by Elting E. Morison, editor of "The Letters of Theodore Roosevelt."
Hearing on proposed tariff reductions for the benefit of Switzerland and Japan are scheduled to open in Washington today.

"What would it mean to you to drive a dear old lady, totally blind, to the Lighthouse, just so she could talk a while with the girls ? Or to drive a wounded veteran to his home and see two adorable youngsters dash from the house with outstretched arms, because their daddy was home?"
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- A steady improvement in the economic health of non-Communist nations in Asia was reported today by the United Nations.
TOKYO, Monday, March 28 (AP)--A Soviet maneuver failed to seat Communist China at the opening today of the annual meeting of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East.
Stanley Kramer's production of "The Caine Mutiny," presented by Columbia Pictures, was voted the best film of 1954 in the thirty-second annual poll conducted by The Film Daily.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 27 (UP)--A band of twelve robbers and rapists led by a murderer seized two guards and held them as hostages at knife point today in the Nebraska Penitentiary maximum security building.
TEANECK, N. J., March 27-- Boughten Damsel of Little Andely's, a greyhound owned by Mrs. Harding T. Mason of Cross River, N. Y., gained her first best-in-show tonight.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 27 (AP)--Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, defeated the United States singles champion, Vic Seixas, today in the Good Neighbor tennis final.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, named four "Eisenhower Republicans" today to set up and run the Republican Presidential nominating convention at San Francisco next year.

Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin's comment on President Eisenhower's statement of last week is obviously a move of key political importance. Its importance is heightened by the fact that it represents a shift in the Soviet assessment of President Eisenhower's position.

The prospects for laying a sound foundation for court reform in New York State brightened considerably last week when the Assembly passed, by a vote of 135 to 11, the bill to establish a Judicial Conference for more businesslike management of the courts.
Ship charter rates, still sagging, showed some signs of bounce last week. Observers believed that the expected levelingoff was at hand.
Governor Harriman voiced dissatisfaction yesterday with the record of the Republicancontrolled Legislature on rent control, school aid and lowerincome housing.

With the accent more on basketball than clowning, the Harlem Globetrotters defeated the college All-Americans, 67-- 63 and 72--70, in an afternoonnight double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
LONDON, March 27--Aneurin Bevan made a speech to a group of Yorkshire miners and their wives today but left unanswered the question whether he would toe the Labor party line.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) --The chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee rejected today nearly all of the Hoover Commission's proposed changes in veterans medical care and benefits.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) --The National Academy of Sciences today announced appointment of a committee to "counsel" with the Government on loyalty programs. The programs involve nonsecret, Federal-supported research by scientists in private institutions.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 27 -- Elizabeth, which dates back to the 1664 community known as Elizabethtown, marked today the 100th anniversary of its incorporation as a city. The program emphasized the city's patriotic, civic and religious heritages.

RIO DE JANERIO, March 27 --Rumors that the United States Government would buy $250,000,000 worth of Brazilian coffee for stockpiling had the effect of strengthening both the cruzeiro rate and the coffee price in the sensitive Brazilian market last week.

BOSTON, March 27 (AP)--The Secretary of Labor said today that the United States faced a critical labor shortage in the next decade. He urged local, state and Federal Governments to tackle the problem.
HOBOKEN, N. J., March 27-- Undaunted by sub-freezing temperatures, high winds and occasional snow flurries, 15,000 marchers opened this city's centennial celebration today.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 27 --The Finns are getting ready to cope with a renewal of last year's efforts by Moscow to have Finland identify herself with the Soviet Union's foreign policy.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 27 (AP) --The Fort Wayne Pistons eliminated the Minneapolis Lakers from the National Basketball Association Western playoffs tonight. The visitors won, 105--96, before 6,871 fans.

The morale of peoples dominated or threatened by Communist tyranny must be strengthened, in the opinion of participants on the New York Times Youth Forum yesterday. The program was televised over Channel 5 on the Du Mont Television Network.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 27--Ciba, A. G., of Basle, most powerful concern of the Swiss chemical industry, has just published its annual report, showing undiminished prosperity. The report indicated, however, that apprehension was felt at the swift comeback of all three successor concerns of the former German dye trust, I. G. Farbenindustrie.
Mayor Wagner is organizing a committee of outstanding citizens to help in the campaign to keep the city's streets free from littter.
Prominent personalities will be hired to serve as hosts of various segments of the National Broadcasting Company's new weekend radio series.
