CLEVELAND, March 27-- Walter P. Reuther described the automobile workers' 1955 contract negotiations today as a "crusade" to gear economic abundance to human needs.
Atomic Power Development Associates, thirty-three companies cooperating in research under a contract with the Atomic Energy Commission, have formed a nonprofit corporation to carry on that work.
Aluminium, Ltd., of Montreal, in its twenty-seventh annual report, issued for release today, showed a net income last year of $34,970,025, or $3.87 a share, on 9,036,382 shares.

The National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students, which helps qualified Negroes to get higher education in interracial colleges, will benefit from the April 12 performance of "Silk Stockings." The Cole Porter musical is playing at the Imperial Theatre.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 27 -- The winter championship sailing season ended on a note of inactivity at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today. Northwest blasts up to forty-five miles canceled the final frostbite session.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- Congress is preparing to dispose of pending routine legislation this week so that it can get away for a ten-day Easter recess starting April 4.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 27 (AP) -- Europeans completed their sweep of the fifteenth Harriman Cup ski races today. They captured the men's and women's slaloms and both combined championships.

The following new products may be of interest and assistance to the homemaker: Styrene plastic thermo tumblers, ideal for tall cool summer drinks, are available at Abraham Straus. Made by the Gits Molding Corporation, the handsome tumblers come in charcoal or in assorted pastel colors with a chalk white rim.
Ground will be broken later this spring for a new $3,000,000 library for City College.
Winter doubled back with a vengeance yesterday to lash the Eastern two-thirds of the nation with wind, snow and recordbreaking cold.
The attack on The Jockey Club's plan to construct a "dream track" at Belmont Park gained momentum yesterday.
LONDON, March 27 --The stock markets remain in a highlysensitive condition into which they were plunged a month ago by the raising of the bank rate to 4 1/2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 27--A new United States atomic weapon may be able to wipe out a formation of high-flying enemy bombers.

Lower trans-Atlantic air cargo rates, to go into effect July 1, will increase air shipments between this country and Europe by at least 50 per cent, Pan American World Airways predicted here yesterday.
PARIS, March 27--France's contribution to the North Atlantic Treaty Forces will receive close scrutiny from NATO this year.
Marshal Ivan S. Konev has apparently been promoted to Deputy Defense Minister of the Soviet Union, and is now the third highest ranking military officer of that country.

WASHINGTON, March 27-- Premier Mario Scelba and Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino of Italy arrived this afternoon to begin a twelve-day goodwill visit to the United States. They will call on President Eisenhower at noon tomorrow.

Busy with improvements in her forthcoming production of "The Honeys," Cheryl Crawford nevertheless has found time to acquire a new script, "Mister Johnson." Based on Joyce Cary's novel about life in a remote corner of West Africa, the drama has been fashioned by Norman Rosten.
OMAHA, March 27 (AP)--The Air Force's new independent recruiting program was hailed here today.
A Detroit truck union leader with a long police record has been denied a license to race harness horses in this state.

"ENTERTAINMENT 1955," seen over the National Broadcasting Company's television network last night, used its large cast of star entertainers to excellent advantage. The well-balanced program marked the dedication of N. B. C.'s new color studios, called "Color City," in Burbank, Calif.
ALBANY, March 27--Legislators of both major parties were expressing optimism today that the legislative session could be brought to an end this week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27--The U. N. Food and Agriculture Organization now can bank a $3 check it has held for two a half years because it lacked endorsement by the payee, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt. But it will never be cashed.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman, who voted against the mutual defense treaty with Nationalist China on Formosa, declared yesterday that "we've maneuvered ourselves into a very terrible mess."

FLORENCE, ITALY, March 27--To Florence, Italy owes her language, as well as a great number of sublime artists, poets, writers and thinkers. Florence has just added a new word, lapirismo, to the Italian language.

MOSCOW, March 27--What exactly did Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin mean when he said yesterday that his Government took a "positive attitude" toward President Eisenhower's idea of a conference of the great powers?
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27--Charlie Dressen breezed into St. Pete the other day with his Washington Senators. But it wasn't as a zephyr. Charlie is more of the tornado type. Lots of wind.

ALBANY, March 27--The Port of New York Authority's $300,000,000 arterial road plan to ease New York City traffic congestion is in danger of being passed over by the Legislature. A dispute between Mayor Wagner and authority officials as to how the city and the authority should share control over the program has raised the possibility that the lawmakers might adjourn the 1955 session without acting on the plan.
The Maritime Association of the Port of New York urged Congress yesterday to act favorably on a bill that would establish round-the-clock examination of ships entering the ports of the country.

ADELE ADDISON, young soprano from Springfield, Mass., who made a successful recital debut here three years ago, made a successful operatic debut yesterday afternoon with the New York City Opera at the City Center.

MONTE CARLO, March 27-- One of the United States bridge pairs moved up to seventh place today in the open pair championship of the Monte Carlo International Championships. A French team held the lead as 156 contract bridge pairs moved into the last session of the tenday tournament here.
"The Desperate Hours," which Joseph Hayes tossed off in less than eleven weeks, won the Antoinette Perry Award last night as the outstanding play of the Broadway season ended March 1.

TORONTO, March 26--Within the next ten days the Bethlehem Mines Corporation, a subsidiary of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, will bring into production one of Canada's least publicized iron ore projects.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- Motion-picture producers and exhibitors were warned yesterday by Herbert J. Yates against undue optimism over business gains made during the last year.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- Clint Pace, Director of the White House Conference on Education, is sending all state conference chairmen a mimeographed draft of a "work book."
If it is true that women are helping to cause ulcers in men-- as a Harvard anthropologist (male) suggested last week--it might be because men underrate the importance of motherhood.
THE circus unloaded at Harlem yards yesterday, but sixty-seven years ago experts thought it might not.
A plea for the reinstatement of $660,000 in the Federal budget for continued support of state maritime schools has been made by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.
BOSTON, March 27 (AP)--The Syracuse Nationals won the National Basketball Association's Eastern play-offs today, by eliminating the Celtics, 110--94, at the Boston Arena.
Whatever shortcomings the Kremlin's external propaganda may have, its propaganda system for its own people is very effective.
Scotland was described yesterday as the most prayed-for country in the world, bar none.

Cotton futures prices in the New York market held to a narrow trading range last week and net changes were for the most part insignificant. According to the New York Cotton Exchange, active contracts from May, 1955, through May, 1956, were unchanged to 8 points lower on the week.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 27--A new state of emergency was proclaimed today by Governor General Ghulam Mohammed. He has assumed supreme administrative authority throughout Pakistan.

WILLIAM PRIMROSE, violist, and Rudolph Firkusny, pianist, gave their first recital together Saturday night. Their program was the eleventh and final event in the annual subscription series presented by Dr. Benno Lee in the Hunter College Auditorium.
LONDON, March 27--France's transfer of two combat divisions from the Allied forces in Europe to French North Africa is disturbing United States and British defense officials.

It's Spring Again Spring is more than seeing the swelling buds, and bulbs' spears thrusting through the earth. Spring is hearing, too. It is hearing a song sparrow's cheerful torrent of light notes, the richer voice of a robin, the flutter of mourning doves' wings.

BOSTON, March 27 (UP)-- The Boston Bruins, playing sharp, aggressive hockey, defeated the Montreal Canadians, 4 to 2, before a capacity crowd of 13,909 at Boston Garden tonight. It was the Bruins' first victory in the semi-final Stanley Cup play-offs.

CHICAGO, March 27--Grain futures moved irregularly last week. There were spells of fairly active buying, but rallies failed to hold. Late in the week snow and rain in part of the wheat area caused a break in prices that spread to other cereal futures.
CHICAGO, March 27 (AP)-- Pete Beshara of Detroit took over eighth place in the $120.000 Petersen bowling classic tonight with an eight-game total of 1.538.
GLADSTONE, N. J., March 27 (AP)--Two young Methodist ministers --anxious to "understand the bum as well as the business man"--lived on New York's Bowery for four days last week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The publication of the Yalta documents, for which we feel indebted to the American Government, proves that the American principle of self-determination provides the only firm foundation, for international agreements aimed at lasting peace.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 27 (AP)--The aircraft industry's first electronically controlled milling machine -- expected ta sava as much as 85 per cent of time now spent on some parts--will be developed by the Convair division of the General Dynamics Corporation.

PITTSBURGH, March 27 -- There was evidence last week that April may be the peak month in steel this year, instead of March. Even so March's total steel production will probably represent the best monthly figure since March, 1953.

ESSEN, Germany, March 27 (AP)--Alfred Krupp said today that his industrial concern, barred by the conquering Allies from producing coal and steel, had regained a firm hold in the world market and was expanding its international operations.

BOSTON, March 27--A work that few of the world's opera houses have had the courage to attempt Berlioz' "The Trojans,"' was performed at the Boston Opera House this afternoon by the New England Opera Theatre under the direction of Boris Goldovsky.

OSAKA, Japan, March 27--Japanese policy shows definite signs of becoming both more nationalist and more neutralist. In other words, our influence is waning. Tokyo has already set about the business of trying to arrange its own relationships with the great Communist Powers, Russia and China.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 27 --Brazil's illegal Communist party published instructions today to fight all candidates friendly to the United States in this year's Presidential elections.

BERLIN, March 27--The Communists set forth today a program for countering West German armament by expanding East Germany's paramilitary organizations, but there was no call for universal military training.

The road bird is about to get a push into his own lane. The Ethyl Corporation, by way of marking its thirtieth year of national advertising, is scheduling advertising design to dispose of the birds and sell some of Ethyl's premium gasoline.
Louie Morino, one of New York's most colorful restaurateurs, will prepare his own version of bouillabaisse for a luncheon that will benefit the Henry Street Settlement on April 19.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- More than 5,000 Federal employes will deploy to thirty-five emergency headquarters locations in a simulated hydrogen bomb attack upon the Capital in June.

PARIS, March 27--Shortly before dawn today the Senate, or advisory Council of the Republic, completed legislative sanction of the main achievement of the recent Premier, Pierre Mendes-France. It did so by approving treaties that replaced the defeated European Defense Community plan. It has thus put an end to five years of argument on whether or how the West Germans should be armed.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 27 --Premier Ngo Dinh Diem appeared to have grained ground today in his difficulties with armed groups opposed to his Government.
Refinishing furniture can be a discouraging task when, after taking off layers of varnish and enamel, one finds a discolored or scarred surface.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 27--Although the stock market last week was irregular, there is a general impression that the large available reserves of uninvested funds preclude any serious setback.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 27-- The Giants decided to play it with finesse today. They collected only seven hits. Three of them didn't show up until the eighth. Only one of these blows was that homer, a belt by Willie Mays that cleared a lot of terrain but produced only a single tally.

Oswald Jacoby of Dallas, Tex., and Alfred Sheinwold of New York last night won the pair championship in the Eastern States Bridge Tournament. This was the fourth time Mr. Jacoby had won the Julian Goldman Cup in the twentyseven years of competition for the oldest pair-event trophy.
A five-year, $10,000,000 study of educational administration has developed improved methods to train school superintendents and principals.
Spectators doffed hats yesterday in salute to the hardy spirit of 15,000 men, women and children marching up Fifth Avenue in the annual Greek Independence Day Parade.
Mayor Wagner scored the McCarran - Walter Immigration Law yesterday as a violation of the nation's democratic concepts.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 27--Chalk one up for the United States Army over the Red Army in the noble art of skiing (Old Boys Division).
CINCINNATI, March 27-- Treatment of the Jews of the United States constitutes a "true barometer" of American democracy, Dr. Jacob R. Marcus said here today.
TAMPA, Fla., March 27-- Jim Rivera's ninth-inning home run and eleventh-inning double sparked the White Sox to a 4-3 victory over the Dodgers today.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- Thirty-three years ago seven western states signed a compact to end generations of war over the waters of the Colorado River.

BONN, Germany, March 27-- Final French acceptance of the Paris agreements brought an immediate semi - official reference here to the necessity for negotiation with the Soviet Union before the arming of West Germany actually went into effect.
WASHINGTON, March 27-- The most sought-after "limited edition" in town these days is the original galley-proof edition of the Yalta Papers released ten days ago by the State Department.
PARIS, March 27--Jean Sourbet, Minister of Agriculture, has announced a goal of doubling French agricultural exports to West Germany.

The American Metal Company, Ltd., had a record net income of $10,826,515 last year, equal to $3.32 a share. The earnings compare with $10,037,231, or $3.07 a share, in 1953 and with the previous record of $10,782,000 in 1951.

SEATTLE, Wash., March 27 (UP)--Survivors of the crashlanding of a luxury Stratocruiser in the Pacific Ocean told today the story of how three fellow passengers had drowned after "bobbing up and down just out of reach" of a liferaft for two hours.

The Very Rev. James A. Pike yesterday likened Senator Homer E. Capehart of Indiana to "those approaching danger ostrich-like." The Protestant Episcopal dean drew the comparison in speaking of the Senator's criticism last week of Prof. John K. Galbraith of Harvard University.
Nostalgia collided head-on with reality yesterday on the Third Avenue Elevated, and dreams were badly shaken by the profit motive.
MAYBROOK, N. Y., March 27 --A $60,000,000 industrial terminal has been planned here in an effort to lure factories from New York.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There have been frequent remarks and predictions concerning a possible "break-up" of the Arab League as a result of the differences between Iraq and Egypt on the Turkish-Iraqi pact of defense. Your Washington correspondent, Dana Adams Schmidt, in The Times of March 3 attributed such predictions to "authorities" on Arab affairs.

The new Europe, which the best Western minds have projected since the end of the last World War, has started to assume the outlines of reality as a result of the approval of the Paris pacts by the French Council of the Republic. Since the National Assembly has already approved the pacts, the Council's action completes French parliamentary ratification of them, now subject only to automatic signature by President Coty.

A protective committee of stockholders of the American News Company has been formed. It was organized by Harry Coffey, realty man and investor; Henry Garfinkle, president of the Greater Boston Distributors, Inc.; Manhattan News Company, Inc., and Garfield News Company, Inc. John M. Foley of 60 Wall Street is secretary.

Plans for a twelve-story apartment building to replace the old three and four story structures at the northeast corner of Tenth Street and Greenwich Avenue in Greenwich Village have been announced in connection with the sale of the property to a syndicate headed by Harry Klein.
The circus moved into Madison Square Garden yesterday after battling tide, wind and sub-freezing temperature. Circus men said it was one of the coldest arrivals they had ever made in New York.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27--No one seemed to mind the novelty of today's spring-training double - header between the Yankees and the St. Louis Cardinals.

Of the $399,000,000 spent here last year for welfare and health services to residents, New York City contributed $227,000,000, of 56.9 per cent. The Federal share was $74,000,000, or 18.5 per cent. The state contributed $98,000,000, or 24.6 per cent.

Lawn's Status: Poor The state of the lawn --or what last year was a lawn--is at present hopeless. The heavy rains of early March, followed by freezing weather, added to those heavings and saggings one has learned to expect to see in the lawn during the winter.
WASHINGTON, March 28-- President Eisenhower discussed East-West problems with Premier Mario Scelba of Italy today.

Henry W. Grunewald, Washington influence peddler and taxfixer, was found guilty last night of a $160,000 tax-fix bribery. A Federal jury here also convicted two accomplices. Two other defendants were acquitted.
ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Harriman sent a special message to the Legislature tonight urging approval of an eight-point housing program before adjournment of the present session.
LONDON, March 28--A dispute between two unions caused a walkout of thousands of dock workers in Liverpool, Birkenhead and Manchester today and threatened to spread to London and other ports.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 --The Matson Navigation Company is continuing to study the possibility of putting a second passenger ship in the West Coast-Hawaii service.
BONN, Germany, March 28-- The Federal constitutional court announced today it would consider the Social Democratic petition challenging the legality of the Saar agreement with France.
A store chain, buying what was said to be its first network radio program, will sponsor a one-hour weekly musical series beginning June 5.
WINDSOR, Ont., March 28 (Canadian Press) -- The Ford Motor Company of Canada has announced sales in 1954 were $59,000,000 below the record set in 1953.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. Two golden streams have been pouring into the Florida peninsula this winter in harmonious combination for the seekers of health or pleasure and those who supply the goods and services these require. The sun, after earlier periods in which it seemed resolved to put this area on the dole, has been lavish-- except for the last two days--in sharing its wealth with the tourists.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 28 (AP)--Two singles shooters blasted the new white pins of the American Bowing Congress tourney today. One registered the fourteenth 300 game since the first A. B. C. meet in 1901. The other rolled a series which would have won last year's championship.

On March 22 Mayor Wagner, in making his annual report to the City Council, set as a "Goal for 1955": "To develop a comprehensive and constructive program to deal more effectively with juvenile delinquency." On March 24 the Board of Estimate took what was described as "the first major step" in the fight against juvenile delinquency.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. and Harold E. Stassen urged the Senate Appropriations Committee today to authorize $8,000,000 as this country's contribution to the United Nations Technical Assistance Program.

OLEVELAND, March 28--The secretary-treasurer of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., pleaded today for building up a $25,000,000 strike fund. Emil Mazey, the official, said this would be a tool in the union's 1955 negotiations on the guaranteed annual wage.
WASHINGTON, March 28-- The Supreme Court rejected a plea today that it decide whether constitutional processes applied to proceedings in juvenile courts.

CHICAGO, March 28--The report of the Department or Agriculture on today's livesstock markets follows: HOGS Salable hogs 13,000 head: active, butchers steady to mostly 25c higher: sows steady to 25c up: most sales choice 190 to 230 pound butchers $17.75 to $18: around three decks

WHEN I was a boy I felt it my social obligation to shoot rabbits and prairie dogs. I didn't really want to hurt the poor things and fortunately I never hit one. Since then I have never had the slightest desire to shoot any creature. Nevertheless, I never have been able to resist reading African hunting stories.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, sought congressional backing today for what he termed the "desperately needed water development program" in the $1,000,000,000 project for the Upper Colorado Basin.

Trading in Wall Street was relatively dull yesterday. After a fast start, which briefly outpaced the ticker tape, industrial stock prices drifted irregularly lower. Railroad issues, however, moved ahead gradually until about 3 P. M. when they encountered profit taking.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 28-- The Giants played their farewellto-Phoenix exhibition game today. However, for a time, it looked as though they would never leave the place.
WASHINGTON, March 28-- The Supreme Court upheld unanimously today an Oklahoma law regulating the sale and processing of eyeglasses.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. Prices moved 4 points down to 9 points up in rather slow trading.

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia and Miguel Najdorf of Argentina won in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday, according to a report from Buenos Aires. As a result, Ivkov, with 11--3, maintained his half-point lead over Najdorf in the fourteenth and semi-final round.

Leading life insurance executives yesterday called on the Government to tighten up on both Veterans Administration and Federal Housing Administration mortgage loans. The group, the joint committee on economic policy of the Life Insurance Association of America and the American Life Convention, termed present thirtyyear, no-down-payment mortgage loans guaranteed by the V. A. "an open invitation to a boom-bust situation in homebuilding."
A merger to form the country's second largest bank was approved by stockholders of Chase National Bank and The Bank of the Manhattan Company yesterday.
LONDON, March 28 -- The stock market was narrowly irregular today, with a tendency toward dullness in the industrial section. Volume was small.

Danny Giovanelli of Brooklyn scored a technical knockout over Jimmy Martinez at Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, last night. Referee Barney Felix, with an "assist" from Dr. Samuel Swetnick, stopped the bout at 1:42 of the fifth round.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 29 --The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia today described persons who in the past put consumer goods ahead of the drive for heavy industry as "enemies of the people."

MELBOURNE, March 28 (AP) --Executive members of the Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games at Melbourne held an emergency meeting today to discuss the present work stoppage in the building of the main stadium.

The $55,000,000 atomic electric generating plant planned by the Consolidated Edison Company will use a force tested by the Navy. The generator will be powered by a pressurized water thorium-uranium converter reactor.

Dick Thomas yesterday received the award as the leading 1954 driver at Roosevelt Raceway. George P. Monaghan, New York State Harness Racing Commissioner, presented the trophy at a luncheon in Leone's.
MONTE CARLO, March 28-- For the second successive year, the Monte Carlo open pair bridge championship was won yesterday by Frank Bodier and Pierre Figeac of France.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The United States has begun "quite active consultations" with Britain and France on plans for a meeting with the Soviet Union. West Germany will be included in the preliminary talks.
BOWIE, Md., March 28 (AP)-- Companas Stable's Ros Clag got up just in time today to win the feature at Bowie, defeating the 3-10 favorite, Nick Jimmie, by a neck.
The general maintenance fund of the New York City Center Art Gallery will benefit from an Easter tea dance, which will be held on April 10 in the ballroom of the Ambassador.
WASHINGTON, March 28-- President Eisenhower does not share the view that war in the Formosa Strait is imminent.
TRENTON, March 28--The Republican-controlled State Senate moved today to reduce a rapidly expanding backlog of juvenile delinquency cases in North Jersey courts.

The April and May potato positions on the New York Mercantile Exchange soared the 1/4cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday. There were more than 1,300 unsatisfied bids at the close in the two months. Final quotations were 9 to 25 points (hundredths of a cent a pound higher) on 478 car lots.

Seven buildings on a plot forming an "L" around the northeast corner of First Avenue and Fiftyseventh Street have been sold by the Transcontinental Properties, Inc., to Gordon Gordon, real estate investors. M. L. Hess, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.
WASHINGTON, March 28--The Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, accused the right-wing Republicans today of "talking War." He warned against an "irresponsible adventure" in Asia.

TAMPA, Fla., March 28--The slickest trader in the baseball business has always been Branch Rickey. Whenever the Mahatma starts his spiel, other club executives stuff cotton in their ears, clutch their wallets and look frantically around for the nearest exit.

Members of the activities council of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled have arranged the annual Student Carnival in behalf of the institute. The event will be held the afternoon and evening of April 22 at the institute, First Avenue at Twenty-third Street.

Two of the nation's "big three" copper producers, the Phelps Dodge Corporation and the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, have increased the price of refined copper 3 cents a pound, to 36 cents, effective today.
Hanging on the tellers' windows in most banks are signs saying deposits up to $10,000 are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
The Tide Water Associated Oil Company has budgeted a record $127,000,000 for capital expenditures this year, D. T. Staples, president, disclosed in the annual report yesterday.
PARIS, March 28--The National Assembly opened debate today on powers asked by Premier Edgar Faure for fiscal and economic reforms.

Eight male city employes happily allow themselves to be henpecked in the interests of health. The eight are Health Department veterinarians whose jobs include inspecting 215 live poultry slaughterhouses here. If a health-conscious hand poked into a chicken crate brings outraged squawks and vigorous pecks, the birds will probably soon grace home, hotel and restaurant tables.

The possibility that a Brooklyn demolition company paid bribes to policemen, firemen and other city employes will be investigated by the borough's rackets grand jury, Assistant District Attorney Albert V. DeMeo revealed yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 28 --President Juan D. Peron of Argentina is holding in jail at his personal disposition 114 university students whose principle crime is that they opposed his dictatorial regime.

WASHINGTON, March 28--The Department of Agriculture says that the public is getting more for its food dollars. It opened an exhibit today to prove it, with stress on a comparison with, thirty years ago.
CHICAGO, March 28--Uneasiness over the Chinese situation put a brake on selling of wheat today. With some commission buying followed by short covering, wheat futures made a rather strong showing.
PROSPECTS are fairly bright for those who want to open the fresh water fishing season on All Fools' Day, if they are willing to travel from 200 to 500 miles.
In the kitchen of the Au Gourmet shop at Bloomingdale's tomorrow at 11 A. M., Helmut Ripperger will show how to prepare a savory Lenten dish of scallops and mashed potatoes.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., March 28 (AP) -- A Protestant Episcopal clergyman charged today that Bard College had swerved morally from its Christian purpose. Its president retorted that the clergyman was talking without facts.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 28 --The change of Rio de Janeiro from one of the world's important capital cities to a mere tourist center appears probable.
The 1955 "ANTA Album,' culled chiefly from the theatre's treasure chest of past and present highlights, went on a coastto-coast "tour" last night.

The Department of Agriculture is considering asking Congress for $2,000,000,000 in addition to previously authorized amounts to finance Government loans on farm surpluses. By early summer it is anticipated that the Government will have $8,500,000,000 or more tied up in surpluses, and if large crops are produced this year the Commodity Credit Corporation will have, to go over its present legal limit of $10,000,000,000 invested, in such surpluses.

The Bellerose Shopping Center at Hillside and Braddock Avenues in Bellerose, Queens, has been sold by Sam Minskof f Sons, Inc. The buyer is the Bahm Realty Company, an investing customer of Pearce, Mayer Greer, real estate brokers.
ALBANY, March 28--Jacob K. Javits broke with the Republican legislative leadership today on rent control and several key labor issues.
ALBANY, March 28--The Assembly approved tonight a resolution calling for final adjournment on Saturday.
NEWARK, March 28--A threejudge Federal tribunal denied today a state application for a preliminary restraint against abandonment of the Hoboken-Christopher Street ferry.

Fifty-seven housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration are calling for bids April 5 on issues of notes totaling $145,144,000. The proceeds will be used to finance temporarily low - rent public housing projects.
A union local charged yesterday that its members--apartment house superintendents and porters--had become the "scapegoats" in the city's anti-litter drive.
LONDON, March 28--Theodor Blank, West Germany's Defense Commissioner, flew here today to study British methods as a possible model for West Germany's defense organization.
FLORENCE, Italy, March 28 --Craftsmen of Florence, once the city's glory and boast, are in retreat before a rising tide of mass - produced, machine - made goods.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 28 (AP)--Universal Oil Products Company said today it has developed a revolutionary new refining process enabling refiners to supply motorists with gasoline of more than 100 clear octane.

Members of the Medical Society of the County of New York were urged last night to help prevent a black market in the Salk anti-polio vaccine if the findings on the field trials of last year show it to be effective.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 28 (AP)--Mrs. Charles Silvers' Hyphasis, one of the highest priced claims of the current Florida season, led throughout the $3,500 Palatka Purse before 13,660 spectators at Gulfstream Park today.
ALBANY, March 28--Republican leaders were reported tonight to be "inclined" toward delaying the start of compulsory automobile inspection for one year.

The contract bridge team lea by George Boehm of New York last night won by 2,370 points over the team led by Dr. Kalman Apfel of the Bronx in the final match of the annual contest for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The effort of the Sanitation Department to improve the conditions of the streets in New York City should be commended. It should be stated, nevertheless, that although the public is to a large extent responsible for the littering of the streets, the deplorable present state is not due to lack of cooperation of the public alone.

A BEAUTIFUL new song by Aaron Copland, "Dirge in Woods" received its United States premiere last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. It was hauntingly sung by Adele Addison at the second concert in a series of three being presented by the recently merged League of Composers and U. S. Section of the International Society for Contemporary Music.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 28 (UP) -- Nine convicts, holding two guards hostage in the strife-torn Nebraska state prison, today offered to end their day-old rebellion. They said they would release the guards if prison officials would act on their "grievances."
Alfred L. Smith, composer, sang from the witness stand and played a piano in Supreme Court yesterday. His audience included Justice Martin M. Frank and Irving Berlin, another song writer.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The Supreme Court reaffirmed today the superiority of Federal over state law in the labor relations field. It did this by overturning a Missouri Supreme Court decision in a union jurisdiction dispute.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28--With 167, more or less, well-chosen words, Casey Stengel, the manager of the Yankees, "apologized" today and l'affaire photographer came to a happy conclusion.
WASHINGTON, March 28-- The Controller General, Congress' watchdog on Government spending, assailed the Administration's road, building program today as financially "objectionable."
BONN, Germany, March 28-- Denmark is ready to write the final chapter in a long conflict with the Germans.

LONDON, March 28--Londoners were without newspapers for the fourth successive day today, although in Fleet Street journalists and printers were going through the motions of putting newspapers together.
Items like old newspapers, bottle tops, and even paper wrappings from oranges are being used for playthings the whole family can enjoy making.

Prospective costs of condemnation of land stood in the path yesterday of speedy approval by the Board of Estimate of vital parts of the $600,000,000 arterial highway program. The project has been put forward by the Port of New York Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

Leaders of the nation's oil geologists upheld the Federal security risk program yesterday. They deplored criticisms made by the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the country's largest scientific group.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 28 (Reuters)--England gained a dramatic victory over New Zealand in the second and final test match today. The tourists put out New Zealand for 26 runs, the lowest total ever recorded in the history of test cricket.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is now probable that there will soon be reported out for floor debate and vote the Assemblywoman Gordon -Senator Peterson bill for the appointment of a Temporary State Commission of twenty-three members, implemented with the usual powers, to make a comprehensive study of the problems created by marriage, the family and related matrimonial matters, the laws applicable thereto and their administration, and to recommend legislative solutions.

The sugar producers are sweetening their advertising. The American Sugar Refining Company, which packs the Domino brand, is scheduling copy on a continuing basis in most local newspapers in its market areas, together with full-page, fourcolor magazine copy.

DANBURY, Conn., March 28 --John A. Define Jr., 30-year-old real estate and insurance man, led the Democrats into a sweeping victory in today's city election, thereby ending a four-year Republican regime.

With commendable promptness, but also with the caution born of experience, the Western Powers have started to follow up French parliamentary ratification of the Paris pacts with preparations for a genuine peace offensive that could lead' to a new conference between the Western and Soviet heads of Government.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 28 --Prospects for peaceful settlement of the difficulties between Premier Ngo Dinh Diem and opposition groups seemed better today.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 28 (UP)--Rioting broke out in three new Belgian towns tonight in the bitter fight over plans to reduce Government aid for Catholic schools.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) --The House of Representatives voted today for the third straight year to give the Agriculture Department more money for farm programs than President Eisenhower had requested.

Koppers Company Capital expenditures of the Koppers Company in the next five years will be principally to increase sales in new growth fields and to stabilize earnings, Fred C. Foy, the president, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Pittsburgh.
Sean O'Casey's slightly autobiographical play "Red Roses for Me," dealing with the great Dublin strike of 1913 in which the author participated, will have its New York premiere on Oct. 20.
The National Football League's twelve-man, executive committee yesterday sidestepped its efforts for peace and opened a "wide avenue" for attack in the warfare with Canadian clubs.

The United States Golf Association, making an unusual change of sites, announced yesterday that the 1956 United States amateur golf championship would be held at the Knollwood Club, Lake Forest, III., instead of at Los Angeles. The dates at Knollwood will be Sept. 10-15.

There was a bit of cheer for the railroads yesterday in the report of the Atlantic Shippers Advisory Board. The board estimates the needs of shippers in railroad cars for New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Virginia, eastern Pennsylvania and Maryland and the District of Columbia.
Spring began yesterday to pull itself out of the week-end's wintry attack as a warming trend across much of the country slowly brought the season back into proper stride.
LOS ANGELES, March 28-- Doctors should withhold the truth from patients with mortal ailments such as cancer if it might distress them unduly, the Nation's family physicians heard today.
THIS week's art exhibitions and include shows by European and American artists, both contemporary jand of the immediate past.
BERLIN, March 28--East German church-state relations have reached a new crisis as a result of nation-wide Communist youth-pledging ceremonies on the last two Sundays.

The New York Legislative session which began in early January now moves into its final days. The end is near not because the Legislature has about completed its business or met its responsibilities but because the calendar says it is nearly April 1. Governor Harriman has threatened to keep the lawmakers longer at their desks, or to call them, back, but even he seems to be resigned to Republican, exodus from Albany.

THE GOVERNOR Signed a bill increasing the pilots' fees charged in the port of New York. Spoke at a legislative conference of the state Congress of Industrial Organizations. Entertained Dag Hammerskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, at dinner.
ALBANY, March 28--The Board of Regents urged today that schools devote frequent periods to the teaching of the country's moral and spiritual heritage.
Consolidated net income of the Chicago Corporation and subsidiaries last year rose to $5,320.750, or $1-51 a common share, from $5,131,965, or $1.45 a share in 1953.

FOR the third of its series of extra - curricular activities that it calls "Sideshows," the Phoenix Theatre last night presented Stravinsky's "L Histoire du Soldat." It had a completely new script by N. Richard Nash, a quartet of first-rate performers and an excellent little orchestra under the direction of Erich Leinsdorf.

The sharpest reduction in the price of titanium sponge since commercial production began in 1948 was announced yesterday by the Titanium Metals Corporation of America. The company said its price would be trimmed 55 cents a pound to $3.95 April 1.

A state of emergency has been proclaimed in Pakistan by the Governor General, Ghulam Mohammed. This is not an "emergency" in the usual sense. It is, rather, a legal and political move--within the powers of the Governor General under existing law -- designed to effect some changes in administration.

A new process for the extraction of sugar from its cane has been developed by the National Cylinder Gas Company, Chicago. It is said to be the first basic change in methods of extracting sugar from cane in more than 100 years.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 28--The three major Western powers asked today that Israel be condemned for the attack last month on Egyptian forces in the Gaza Strip.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 28--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that it would be "pleasant but unsound policy" to give special priority to women for top United Nations posts.
WASHINGTON, March 28--A report on how the Government may help the railroads is due to reach the Cabinet early in May.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28--Principal photography got underway this morning at the Paramount studio on Cecil B. de Mille's production of "The Ten Commandments."
The Civil Rights Congress was faced yesterday with a new investigation --because one of its contributors blundered.
LONDON, March 28--Britain, the United States and France are consulting on arrangements for meetings with the Soviet Union, Sir Anthony Eden disclosed today.

Staff members of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee began a series of conferences here yesterday to "explore the maritime labormanagement situation" and its bearing on the American merchant marine.
PARIS, March 28--As if freed of a great weight by their acceptance of West Germany as an armed ally, the French looked forward today to a new chapter in diplomacy.

GENEVA, March 28--In most parts of the world, the manufacture of cotton and wool textiles is an aging and feeble industry. In a study published here today, the secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (Gatt) discusses some of the reasons why
The most pressing problem in higher education for women is increasing the number who receive it, in the opinion of Dr. M. Eunice Hilton of Syracuse University.

CHICAGO, March 28--Joseph Kolodny, managing director of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, said today the major cigarette companies reported sales of $2,958,000,000 in 1954. This was a drop of about $162,000,000, or 5 per cent, from the 1953 total of $3,120,000,000.
A GOOD - SIZED, enthusiastic audience heard the recital played at Town Hall last night by Kenneth Gordon, violinist.

TOKYO, March 28--Premier Ichiro Hatoyama said today that Japan wanted to settle her reparations debts to the other Asian nations and to play an active role in the economic development of the Far East.

VALLEJO, Calif, March 28-- Vice Admiral Frank J. Lowry, U. S. N., retired, a naval hero of World War II in the Pacific and the Mediterranean, died Saturday night in the Mare Island Navy Hospital here. His age was 69.
WASHINGTON, March 28-- The Administration has stopped arguing about whether to have a Big Four conference with the Russians and has started preparing for it with the British and the French.

Opponents of New York University's prospective role in the redevelopment of Washington Square lost a round in court yesterday. But they will have a chance to put their case before a House of Representatives subcommittee in Washington.
A "band of teen-age boys forced their way yesterday into Evander Childs High School in the Bronx and beat two students in a classroom.
Two violinists and a pianist will make their debuts as soloists with the New York Philharmonic -Symphony at next season's concerts, the Philharmonic announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 28-- The White House announced today plans for a new expedition to the Antarctic in November. It will be headed by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, retired, who has made four previous trips to the Antarctic.

From the moment a husband and wife learn they are too become parents until the day their youngest is settled on a life of his own, it may be a toss-up who "grows" the most--the adults or the offspring. Successful childrearing, a group of specialists agreed yesterday, depends largely on the flexibility of parents and their ability to develop with the ever changing needs of their children.

WASHINGTON, March 28 --John Marshall Harlan was sworn in today as an associate justice of the Supreme Court. The New Yorker became the eighty-ninth man to sit on the high bench since the Federal judiciary was established in 1789.

The Hamburg-American Line cargo-passenger vessel Hannover arrived here yesterday afternoon on her maiden voyage. She is the largest post-war-built German ship of her type to call at the Port of New York.
LONDON, March 28--One of the last relics of World War II went by the board tonight when the House of Commons voted to dissolve the Ministry of Food.

In 1946, Andre Migot, a French physician and an authority on Buddhism, traveled across West China, the Sino-Tibetan frontier provinces and the eastern regions of Tibet. He has written an account of the journey in "Tibetan Marches," which Button will Issue June 9.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Adlai E. Stevenson lost an appeal to the Supreme Court today in his first case before it since he was the Democratic candidate for President in 1952.
WASHINGTON, March 28-- An Administration program to provide a military reserve of 2,900,000 trained men by 1960 was approved by a House of Representatives subcommittee today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 28--After an hour-long debate the Westchester Board of Supervisors voted 33 to 5 this afternoon to buy the Dunwoodie golf course in Yonkers. Fighting to the last sandtrap, the opponents had the unanimous backing of the Yonkers City Manager, Mayor, Common Council and banks.
Waldburger Co Inc. textiles, in the fifteen-story building at 125 W 41st St. which was recently remodeled by Tishman Realty Construction Co Inc. owner-- A. M. J. M. Hirsch Co. broker.
LONDON, March 28 -- Sir Winston Churchill paid tribute today to Lloyd George, his great predecessor and old associate, in terms that might stand as his own eulogy.
TAMPA, Fla., March 28-- Billy Loes, who has come up with a kink in his right arm and shoulder, will not be with the Dodgers on the homeward exhibition tour that starts tomorrow in Jacksonville.
TAMPA, Fla., March 28-- Billy Loes, who has come up with a kink in his right arm and shoulder, will not be with the Dodgers on the homeward exhibition tour that starts tomorrow in Jacksonville.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) --The Civil Aeronautics Board has been asked to reconsider its recent order reorganizing United States air routes in the Far East.

Belair Stud's 3 - year - old colt Nashua arrived at Belmont Park yesterday after a railway - car trip from Florida. At the railroad siding to meet him was his 80 - year - old trainer, Jim Fitzsimmons. The colt was taken by van to the Aqueduct track, where Fitzsimmons has his headquarters.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 (UP)--Manager Eddie Stanky of the St. Louis Cardinals today shifted Stan Musial to first base. Rookie Bill Virdon took over in center field.

SAIGON, Wednesday, March 30 (AP)--The United States opposes, any move to replace the present South Vietnamese Government by a regime controlled by the sects. United States officials contend the sects cannot unite the South against the threat of a Communist takeover from North Vietnam.
TOKYO, Wednesday, March 30--Japan's ambitions in international relations include "playing the role of a bridge between East and West," Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu declared today.
The Radio Corporation of America moved yesterday in Federal court for dismissal of the Government's civil anti-trust suit filed last Nov. 19.
CHICAGO, March 29 -- Wheat and corn futures rallied in the early trading here today, then declined, and finally rallied again near the close.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) --Two Civil Aeronautics Board examiners recommended today new regulations for nonscheduled air lines.
PARIS, March 29--The organization of the Broadcasting Foundation of America for the production and exchange of educational programs was announced here today.

IN Spain, where the dollar and even the pound go farther than in most European countries, the tourist business is flourishing. There the bulls are ceremoniously slaughtered in the afternoon and students of the works of Ernest Hemingway choke down their natural revulsion and applaud the spectacle. The little towns along the costa brava have become fashionable, and gigantio buses transport travelers from Santander to Cadiz.
WASHINGTON, March 29--A Naval Intelligence spokesman argued today that investigators of subversion should be allowed to tap phone wires without being held responsible for invasion of privacy.

LOS ANGELES, March 29--A decade's study of Hiroshima atom-bomb victims has produced no evidence that the radiation will affect their descendants, the head of the United States medical mission there reported tonight.
Two detectives were caught last night in the cross-fire of a teen-age gang war in East Harlem.

WASHINGTON, March 29--Secretary of State Dulles asked the Senate today to ratify the Paris agreements quickly to seal the "irreversible reality" of Western unity. The agreements, which bring an armed West Germany back into the defense of the West, will permit big-power conferences to be held "with greater hope," the Secretary said.
ALBANY, March 29--Following is the roll-call vote by which the Gordon-Peterson divorce study bill was defeated in the Assembly today, 85 to 61.

The "United States Steel Hour" will switch to the Columbia Broadcasting System television network on July 6. On that date and thereafter it will be presented on alternate Wednesdays from 10 to 11 P. M.

CHICAGO, March 29--Sales of electric shavers may reach $130,000,000 this year, against $114,000,000 last year, Louis V. Aronson 2d, president of the Ronson Corporation, said today. He made the statement at the twenty-third annual convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors.

A proposal for a $3,000,000 state-city program to expand the work of voluntary youth agencies was supported yesterday by speakers at a City Council hearing. Six bills and resolutions aimed at combatting juvenile delinquency were the subject of the session.

The Barber Oil Corporation will receive a net profit, after Federal income tax, of approximately $14,000,000 from the sale of its 25 per cent stock interest in the American Republics Corporation, Torkild Riebev, president of Barber, stated in the company's annual report for 1954.

Richfield Oil Corporation reported yesterday for 1954 a net income of $25,570,701, or $6.39 a share. This compares with $28,875,486, or $7.22 a share, in 1953. Sales and operating revenue were $223,310,969 a record, compared with $202,039,003 in 1953.

It is almost incredible that, with the New York Legislative session in its final week, Mayor Wagner and his Board of Estimate should have been wrangling until last night on whether to support legislation to permit the Port Authority to proceed with important bridge-building to relieve the traffic problem.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Premier Mario Scelba of Italy urged today that the North Atlantic Treaty alliance be developed from a purely military union into an organization for concerted economic, social and political action.
One of the giants of anthracite mining appears to be ready for diversification.
Mayor Wagner disclosed last night his long-heralded bill to reorganize the New York City Transit Authority.
The reinstatement of two more suspended Army employes at Fort Monmouth, N. J., was disclosed yesterday.
Joseph Curran battened down the hatches of his National Maritime Union yesterday in a move to keep out any backwash from Harry Lundeberg's controversial longer-work-week plan on the West Coast.
BOSTON, March 29 -- Six guards at the Massachusetts State Prison in Charlestown warned today of an "explosive" situation at the institution.
TAMPA, Fla., March 29 (AP)-- The Chicago White Sox stranded thirteen men, ten in the first five innings, but gained a 5-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox today.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Members of the Senate's Committee on Small Business expressed concern today over the continuing downtrend in profits of small business.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29--The idea was doomed to failure from the start. His parents named him Ulysses Brooks Lawrence. As the boy grew older, he grew tired of being called "Useless" or "Eucalyptus." So he just dropped the front end of his label with the philosophic remark, "The Greeks had a word for it but I haven't." He became Brooks Lawrence.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UP) --A bill to authorize the $1,500,000,000 Upper Colorado project was approved by the Senate Interior Committee today by an 11-to-1 vote. The committee defeated, 10 to 2, an attempt to eliminate Echo Park Dam from the project.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 29 --Regardless of whether there is anything to the talk that the Yankees are shopping for a pitcher, improvement in Bob Turley's hurling was evident today as the Yankees turned back the Detroit Tigers, 6-1.
The Eisenhower Administration is achieving the greatest advances in labor relations and working standards that the country has ever enjoyed, Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 29--A small item tucked away in the inside pages of Moscow's newspapers today suggested that the Soviet Union remained unwilling to discuss the reunification of Germany at any big power conference if the Paris agreements were ratified.
The stock market was generally dull again yesterday. A dozen issues--special situations --scored gains ranging up to 11 points, but the general list generated little enthusiasm.

An attempt to bring back "clean, wholesome burlesque" had rough going yesterday. Dictionary definitions notwithstanding, nineteen opponents held that to the public "burlesque" meant an indecent performance.

The project which is known as the International Geophysical Year and which is to be carried out in 1957 and 1958 calls for simultaneous world-wide studies that will add to what little we know about the earth, after having crawled over its surface for centuries.

The Park Avenue monument of the House of Seagram will comprise a thirty-eight-story skyscraper. Occupying the blockfront on the east side of the avenue between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets, it also will have two adjoining office structures of four and ten stories.

Decision was reserved yesterday on a union injunction petition based on the Waterfront Commission's refusal to defer new pier labor hiring regulations. The rules are scheduled to become effective Friday morning.

ROME, March 29--The Communists suffered a sharp defeat today in Turin, Italy's "Detroit." They lost control of the Fiat automobile works, the country's greatest industrial enterprise, in a shop stewards' election.
Nine teen-age boys will be arraigned today on charges of juvenile delinquency resulting from the raid on an Evander Childs High School classroom in the Bronx on Monday.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 29 (AP)--The United States Davis Cup stars, Vic Seixas and Tony, Trabert, won their opening matches today in the Puerto Rican invitation tennis tournament.
The United States still has forty to fifty billion barrels of oil to be discovered, an Oklahoma oil scientist estimated yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 25 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 13,000 head: market clow and uneven: steady to 25c lower on butchers; sows around steady; most choice 190 to 240-pound butchers. $17.25 to u17.75; a

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 29-- If there is one topic that gets more play than any other when sports fans gather in these parts, it involves baseball's $64 question. When will the majorleague brand of the game invade the Pacific Coast ?
Reorganization of the Police Emergency Service Division was announced yesterday. The changes will increase the number of light vehicles and reduce the number of heavy-duty truck units.
A split-second decision to leap from the cab of his overturning trailer-truck saved the life of a 29-year-old driver yesterday.

Lions in March The month of March arrived this year more like a lion in lamb's clothing than anything else. Now, as March ends, Manhattan is scheduled to be infiltrated by a vast company of aweinspiring beasts, including lions (perhaps a lamb, too), tigers, elephants, giraffes and a host of others, all of whom are guaranteed to be wearing their own proper clothing.

A block of 464,700 shares of Corning Glass Works common stock will be placed on the market today by a syndicate of 173 investment houses headed by Lazard Freres Co. and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc. The stock is part of the holdings of Amory Houghton, chairman of the board, and of related family interests.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 29-- As the Giants broke camp today for the long haul home, Leo Durocher gave one hasty inspection of the squad he has been training here for the past four weeks.

The Dauntless Towing Line became a part of the expanding Moran Towing Corporation yesterday. The purchase price was not disclosed. The transaction included the transfer of two powerful coastwise tugboats and four Diesel towboats especially designed for operation in the New York State Barge Canal and the Great Lakes.
Spring is bustin' out all over along Fifth Avenue. As far as the stores are concerned, it is Easter time, not March 21, that ushers in this loveliest of all seasons.
BUENOS AIRES, March 29 (UP) -- President Juan D. Peron announced today that Argentina and foreign oil companies had reached an agreement that would greatly increase the country's oil production.
BERLIN, March 29 -- Erich Kleibar, the conductor who recently left the East Berlin State Opera after having charged political interference, has refused to conduct in West Berlin on similar grounds.

The six-story office and warehouse building on lot 25 by 90 feet at 23 Leonard Street, between West Broadway and Hudson Street, has been sold by John A. Alban to Seymour Schrager, who is president of the D. E. Kesseler Company, hardware concern.

THEODORE HINES, bassbaritone, who made his New York debut at a joint recital in 1948, last night gave a dignified and conscientiously prepared program at Town Hall. It was his second solo recital in the auditorium. He sang there three years ago.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 30--The Federal Government today accused the General Shoe Corporation of violating the Clayton Anti-Trust Act.

Eudora Welty, novelist and short story writer, has been chosen to receive the Howells Medal of the American Academy of Arts and letters for her novel "The Ponder Heart." It was published last year. The presentation will be made May 25 at the joint annual ceremonial of the American Academy and National Institute of Arts and Letters.

On Monday the Inland Steel Company asked its stockholders to approve a new stock option plan. Under the proposal, some 18,000 employes would be eligible to buy 500,000 common shares at 90 per cent of the market value on the effective date.
ALBANY, March 29--Governor Harriman reached a compromise today with Republican leaders on juvenile delinquency legislation.

The State of Massachusetts borrowed $60,850,000 in the public market yesterday to finance highway, sewerage and other public improvements. The money was raised on bond issues maturing serially over thirty years. The borrowing cost the state 2.0569 in interest charges.

ALBANY, March 29 --Major changes in business and commercial rent-control laws applicable to New York City were proposed today. The revisions were suggested by the bipartisan Temporary Rent Commission headed by Assemblyman Joseph F. Carlino, Long Beach Republican.

Futures prices moved in regularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume lagged on most commodities. Cocoa, coffee, hides and copper closed higher; rubber and cottonseed oil eased, and sugar, potatoes, zinc, soybean oil and wool ended mixed.
VIENNA, March 29--Czechoslovak citizens, rarely able to talk freely to a Westerner, make no secret of their opposition to communism.
WASHINGTON, March 29--A civil rights fight today threatened legislation on Federal aid for school construction.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 5 to 18 points (25 to 90 cents a bale) yesterday.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 29 --Unless effective steps are taken after July 20 to hold a general election in North and South Vietnam the matter will be referred back to signatories of the Geneva agreement for further instruction. That statement was made today by the Indian chairman of the International Commission for Supervision and Control.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 29 (AP)--A line drive today almost ended the valiant comeback effort of Bobby Shantz, the Kansas City Athletics' little left-handad pitcher.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 29 (UP)--Security forces were doubled at the Nebraska state prison today when nine rioting convicts gave signs of trying to break out. The convicts still held two guards as hostages in the third day of their rebellion.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, March 30--Binh Xuyen and National Army forces clashed in the southern section of Saigon last night. Fighting raged for three and a half hours.

LONDON, March 29--Aneurin Bevan emerged smiling and unscathed from a Labor party loyalty test today. The decision will come tomorrow, but political opinion is that he will escape expulsion from the party.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- The Eisenhower Administration's war of nerves over Quemoy and Matsu may or may not be confusing Peiping but it certainly is confusing Washington.
Purse trouble is threatening to interrupt the local harness racing season that opens Friday night at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- Lyndon B. Johnson, Senate majority leader, said today that the President's reciprocal trade program "is in deep trouble and is getting in more trouble everyday."
WASHINGTON, March 29 --The Administration is taking a new look at its farm surplus disposal program because it has failed to move as rapidly as expected.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mayor Wagner, in his report to the City Council, went into an extended discussion regarding the shift of citizens from New York City to the suburbs. Actually, the primary reasons for this continuing exodus are few.

BOSTON, March 29 (UP)--Don Marshall scored a breakaway goal at 3:05 of a sudden-death overtime period to give a 4-3 victory to the Montreal Canadiens over the Boston Bruins tonight. A crowd of 13,909 Boston Garden fans saw Montreal gain a 3-1 lead in games in the semifinal Stanley Cup hockey playoffs.
SAN MARINO, March 29 -- The women of San Marino have the Communists on the defensive. They hope soon to have them on the run.

KYOTO, Japan, March 29 -- Spring comes early to Kyoto, Japan's old imperial capital, bringing with it the blossoming of plum, cherry and camellia trees and hordes of reverent sight-seers making obeisance to past glories.
7PARIS, Wednesday, March 30 --Premier Edgar Faure obtained from the French National Assembly today a grant of special powers to effect economic and fiscal reforms. The vote was 329 to 265.

Two of this city's most harried, hurried and worried groups are its motorists and pedestrians, who between them comprise all who are strong enough to walk or brave enough to drive-in short, practically everybody. Therefore, anything to alleviate the hard lot of motorists and pedestrians comes as good news to one and all.
VIENNA, March 29--The Austrian Government decided today to send a delegation headed by Chancellor Julius Raab to Moscow to discuss new ways of arriving at an Austrian state treaty.

FORM and color are fractured into bits and pieces in Harry Crowley's recent abstract paintings at the Salpeter Gallery, 42 East Fiftyseventh Street. His style tends to the nervous and fussy but he puts it to clever symbolic uses.
LONDON, March 29--Britain and Iraq have virtually completed talks on substituting for the Anglo-Iraqi defense alliance Britain's entry into the TurkishIraqi collective security treaty.
ALBANY, March 29 -- The Legislature beat down today a new attempt to revise the state's marriage and divorce laws.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29--Sam Spiegel, whose production of "On the Waterfront" is regarded as a leading contender for the best picture Academy award to be announced tomorrow night, has made a threepicture deal with Columbia.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 29--The Second Chamber of the Dutch Parliament, confident of swift ratification, opened its general debate today on the European security treaties and West German armament.
Two members of the Police Department's Narcotics Squad are under investigation by the Kings County rackets grand jury. They are charged with receiving graft from drug peddlers.
LONDON, March 29--Sir Winston Churchill returned today to his advocacy of East-West talks by heads of government as a starting point for the solution of world problems.

CHICAGO, March 29--The rapid advance in design and development of armaments poses a serious inventory problem for manufacturers who are active in the research phase of the business, members of the American Management Association were told today.

The Stockholders' Committee in Opposition to Present Management of the Boston and Maine Railroad asserted yesterday that the present price and yield of the road's best bonds "indicate grave fears that the $49,156,300 issue will not be paid or refunded at maturity five years hence."
ALBANY, March 29--The Senate approved today a $750,000,000 highway construction program and the taxes to go with it.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 29 (UP)--Two atomic bombs were exploded in one day for the first time today. One explosion was the biggest blast of the 1955 series of tests. It cracked a ceiling in Las Vegas, seventy-five miles away, and set off burglar alarms.
LONDON, March 29 --Last year wag one of marked economic progress for Britain at home. But there was a serious deterioration in her balance-of- payments position during the second half.
YESTERDAY (March 29, 1955) SECURITY COUNCIL Council voted unanimously to condemn attack by Israel on Egyptian forces in Gaza area.
CINCINNATI, March 29--Despite increasing reliance of both the civilian economy and national defense on technically trained people, the number of college-graduate chemists is dropping.

ALBANY, March 29--The Senate approved today a bill designed to encourage the private development of housing for families with moderate incomes. By its terms cities would be permitted to lend to private corporations up to 90 per cent of the cost of nonprofit or limited dividend housing and grant tax exemption up to 50 per cent of the value of the project.

ZELIDETH is a dark-haired girl, only 7 years old. Her sight is poor, or was until the Red Cross gave her glasses the other day. She is tiny and shy, as are many of the children of impoverished families who sit with, her in Mrs. Bertha P. Smith's second grade class in Public School 75 at 735 West End Avenue.
THE PRESIDENT Conferred with Republican leaders of Congress.

With French ratification of the Paris pacts virtually completed, the United States and other signatory nations, which had been waiting on France before taking final action themselves, have swung quickly into line to complete their own ratification.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Proposed new curbs on public housing, slum clearance and urban redevelopment programs received a probably fatal blow today.
ALBANY, March 29--The Board of Regents asked the State University today to postpone its request for a $250,000,000 bond issue for expansion.
"DOMINIQUE," the romantic comedy presented Monday night on "Studio One," was a delightful combination of superior writing, acting and technical skill.
RALEIGH, N. C., March 29 (UP) -- A "local option" school bill designed to let integration take place gradually in North Carolina classrooms became law today.
SHERBROOKE, Que., March 29 (AP)--A Quebec Central Railways passenger train, stranded in snowdrifts since late Sunday near St. Lambert de Levis, pulled into Sherbrooke early today.

Parents need fun as much as children do, a varied group of educators, including Dr. Benjamin Spock, agreed yesterday. It is as important for adults to meet their own needs for saisfaction in living, they added, as it is for them to provide the love and attention their children require.

PANAMA, March 29--The tenyear sentence of former President Jose Ramon Guizado, who was found guilty this morning as an accomplice in the slaying of his predecessor, has been reduced to six years and eight months. He also must pay the cost of his prosecution.

MANY anglers use the marlin, sailfish and bonefish as excuses for fleeing the rigors of the northern winter. When the weather at home is pleasant these sportsmen turn their attention to trout, bass and salmon.
NORWALK, Conn., March 29--Mayor Irving C. Freese was driving yesterday afternoon on West Avenue when a wind-blown banana skin slapped against his automobile.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The problems of Formosa and of the offshore islands are quite distinct. Formosa can and should be defended. Your editorial suggestion that a token United States force be stationed there to symbolize our opposition to any violent solution is therefore meritorious.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Powerful Congressional Democrats hope President Eisenhower will put a stop to what they term "irresponsible" war talk within his Administration.
The new luxury liner planned for the French Line will be a 56,000-gross ton vessel that will almost certainly be named the France, it was learned here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29-- Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that the "good-will and sense of responsibility" of Congress would guarantee payment of bonds issued to finance President Eisenhower's highway program.

we hope that the Waterfront Commission will finally get a chance to put its stringent new hiring regulations into effect. The bi-state agency has been trying for months to take some meaningful steps toward wiping out the corrupt employment practices that have enabled racketeers to victimize workers on the docks.

CHICAGO, March 29--Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley of New York completed today a whirlwind look at this city's efforts to solve its traffic and parking problems. It convinced him, he said, that New York's program was properly blueprinted to meet needs there.
Whether the New York Telephone Company may continue to collect half a million dollars a year in city sales taxes that it does not turn over to the city will he the subject of state hearings.

Julius Helfand, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday he was "satisfied and pleased" with boxing officials' actions that stopped the bout between Danny Giovanelli of Brooklyn and Jimmy Martinez of Phoenix, Ariz., at Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, Monday night.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of John K. M. Pryke, president of the New York Association of Consultant Engineers, published March 24, which criticizes my public statement, requires a reply.
WORK by two of the veteran artists holding shows of paintings this week stands in particularly strong contrast.
It was bargain day yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum. All through the day crowds trooped into the museum and then out again with assorted brown paper parcels. The sale will continue today.

A novel advertising campaign making use of well-known personalities, two at a time, is about to break in a list of magazines to promote the bottled cocktails and cordials of G. F. Heublein Bro., Hartford, Conn. The drive makes use of what Morton Freund, executive vice president of Lawrence C. Gumbinner Advertising Agency, which created it, calls a "softer and subtler" use of the testimonial technique.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 29--The Security Council voted today to condemn Israel's attack last month on Egyptian forces in the Gaza Strip.
Easter table traditions are not nearly so strong as those of Thanksgiving and Christmas. Hence the woman of the house is free to search out the unusually good, the piquantly new in flavor.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was distressed to discover that Bernard Baruch appears to subscribe to the "If you are so smart, why aren't you rich?" theory. Those among us who teach include other values in judging our successes and failures.
ALBANY, March 29--The Banking Committee of the State Senate approved the savings bank branch bill today. It is now due to come up in the Senate for a vote either Thursday or Friday.
LONDON, March 29--Deprived of the national daily newspapers by a strike, investors again seemed unable to take a decided view in the stock market today, brokers reported. Prices moved narrowly.

Auslander Brothers have purchased the automobile wash laundry at the northwest corner of Queens Boulevard and Fiftyfourth Street in Woodside, Queens, from Milton and Bernard Brand. The property occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet.

Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d will have the distinction of introducing Helen Traubel to Broadway in their forthcoming musical, "Pipe Dream." Rumors had indicated this possibility, but not until yesterday was Mr. Hammerstein in a position to confirm them.
CLEVELAND, March 29-- The United Automobile Workers convention voted today to create a $25,000,000 strike fund to bolster the drive for a guaranteed annual wage.

The city was credited last night with winning substantially the control it seeks over details of the plan for a $220,000,000 Narrows bridge between Brooklyn and Staten Island. The span is part of the Port of New York Authority project to ease traffic congestion.
City Councilman rose yesterday from both sides of the aisle to let the record show that they intended no special favor to former Mayor William O'Dwyer.
WASHINGTON, March 29-- An estimated $1,750,000,000 of proposed annual Government pay increases became entangled with a Congressional Easter recess today.

TRENTON, March 29--Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, angrily denied today knowledge of any deal in connection with confirmation by the State Senate of Alfred T. Davis, Democrat, as superintendent of elections in Hudson County.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 29--The Dodgers found sunshine and victory in Jacksonville's new ball park today. They beat Milwaukee, 5--4, the winning margin being an unearned run off Humberto Robinson, the Braves' starting pitcher.

TORONTO, March 29 (UP)-- The Detroit Red Wings eliminated the Toronto Maple Leafs from the Stanley Cup hockey play-offs tonight. Detroit fashioned a 3-0 shutout before 12,824 fans for its fourth straight victory in the semi-final series and extended its winning streak to a near-record total of thirteen games.
George Abbott, who has turned out scores of musical hits since he gave up acting in 1934, when he played the title role in "John Brown," will don the greasepaint again.

A copyrighted report in The World-Telegram and The Sun yesterday said that the newspaper had "learned from an unimpeachable medical source" that "not one child who received the Salk [polio] vaccine during last spring's nation-wide tests contracted the disease."

The New York PhilharmonicSymphony went to Riverside Church last night to assist in the celebration of the installation of the church's new organ. The orchestra playing in conjunction with the organ attracted more than 3,000 listeners.
ALBANY, March 30--A compromise agreement on state aid to education was announced today by Governor Harriman and Republican legislative leaders.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 30 (AP)--The Ivy Administrative Committee today announced a perpetual championship trophy for the formal Ivy Football League, which will start functioning in 1956. The committee is composed of the athletic directors of the eight member colleges.

GROTON, Conn., March 30-- The world's first atomic submarine had an "agonizing" debut when a suspicious "rubbing sound" developed in her starboard turbine. Later two small electrical fires flared during her first dive.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 30--When Granny Hamner was in the Army, he applied for a three-day pass. He knew that he wasn't entitled to one. But he was getting restive. The sergeant behind the desk told him he couldn't have a pass. Then the sergeant looked searchingly at him for a moment and casually tossed an idea over his shoulder.
Wage negotiations for 37,000 city transit workers were opened yesterday by the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

Three pigeons were released in the dress circle of Carnegie Hall last night during the first half of a concert by the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra. The orchestra's appearances in this country have caused protests by Jewish organizations.

REGARDLESS of his century, the sad young man will always be a favorite subject for the sad young novelist. Sometimes this hangdog hero will deceive you for a while. Like Sabatini's Scaramouche, he may seem born with a gift for laughter and a sense that the world is mad, all the way to Chapter Four.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- An angry complaint against Administration press policy on major news "leaks" was edited out of the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today and thus was not broadcast, televised or directly quotable.
CINCINNATI, March 30-- Chemical studies that pinpoint for the first time the crucial moment when cancer of one type starts to form in normal healthy tissue were reported here today.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- President Eisenhower defended the Administration's flexible farm price-support program today against charges that it was contributing to the drop in farm income.

Where is Georgi M. Malenkov? Has he been imprisoned or executed, as so many rumors in Western Europe these past few days have suggested? Or is he merely off on a routine trip inspecting the electric power stations with the control of which he is charged?
The Port of New York Authority rejected last night the demand of New York City for a final say on the condemnation of land for a lower deck on the George Washington Bridge.

Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad have authorized the purchase of a fast, lightweight train from ACF Industries, Inc. While ACF has not as yet received the actual order, Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the railroad, said yesterday he expected the train to be on the tracks by the latter part of this year.
