The biennial ocean race to Annapolis, for which the New York Yacht Club will be a co-sponsor, will begin from New London, Conn., instead of Newport, R. I. The date will be June 18.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Thursday, March 31--A twenty-four-hour truce has been declared in the fighting between Government forces and armed dissident groups. The truce was arranged by Gen. Paul Ely, French Commissioner General and Commander in Chief of French forces in Indochina.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Eisenhower took a skeptical view today of Sir Winston Churchill's idea that EastWest talks should start "at the summit" without an agenda.
Harry Payne Bingham, retired New York banker who died March 25, left more than $200,000 to educational and other institutions.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- President Eisenhower declared today the cause of world peace and tranquillity was not served by talk of imminent war in the Formosa Strait.

BABYLON, L. I., March 30--The strange case of the train that missed its passengers was being reviewed here today. The failure of the Long Island Rail Road's newest train to blow its own publicity whistle was believed to be one cause of a marked scarcity of passengers on the train's first day's runs between Babylon and Southampton.

After an ownership of a few days, the Realty Surplus Corporation has resold the blockfront on the west side of Eighth Avenue from Twenty-eighth to Twenty-ninth Streets consisting of fourteen three to five story buildings.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30--Marlon Brando and his father, Marlon Brando Sr., are making plans to become partners in a company to be named Pennybaker Productions.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 30-- The Giants and Indians, playing their last game in Arizona this spring, regaled a gathering of 4,127 with a weird variety show today. Six homers cleared the barriers. Five misplays added to the woes of the harried pitchers.
LONDON, March 30--Sir Anthony Eden, the Foreign Secretary, announced today Britain's decision to join the TurkishIraqi defense treaty.
ROME, March 30 -- Premier Mario Scelba faces a fight for his Government's survival when he returns from the United States next week.
The 118-year-old Christopher Street ferry passed quietly out of existence last night, a victim of competition from tunnels and tubes.

R. E. Casey, Australia's Foreign Minister, has written an analysis of present international affairs and the Michigan State College Press will issue it April 15. Called "Friends and Neighbors: Australia, the U. S. and the World," the volume is described as "definitely friendly to the United States."

Although the reasons are somewhat obscure, local transit has long been regarded as a matter of state concern, and the courts have so held. In 1953 Governor Dewey, confronted with New York City's perennial fiscal "emergencies," aggravated then by a transit operating deficit of $40,000,000 on the way to $50,000,000 a year, put through the Legislature the creation of a Transit Authority based on the principle that the fare must pay the operating costs.

Two payroll clerks were charged yesterday with stealing $92,000 from a West Side stevedoring concern. A twenty-fivecount grand larceny and forgery indictment was returned against them in General Sessions.
Washington, March 30-- Failure to ratify the Paris agreements would be "cataclysmic," Robert E. Anderson, Deputy Defense Secretary, said today.
Arkansas Power and Light Company raised $18,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of new mortgage bonds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Because New York City faces many serious problems today ranging from finance to traffic and litter to rapid transit, an altogether false and destructive notion is being promoted that this all spells some kind of undefined doom.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
TOKYO, March 30 (AP)--Major segments of one of Japan's biggest pre-war industrial combines, broken up by the American occupation, will be reunited on July 1.

The projected shift of the capital of Brazil to an inland city deep in the heart of the vast republic is many years old; but now at last the Brazilian Congress is preparing to consider tangible plans on the transfer. That is still not to say that beautiful Rio will cease to be the capital within a few months, or even years.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30--The Security Council called on Egypt and Israel today to cooperate in reducing tension along their border.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The organization of a Soviet unified command in Eastern Europe has completely overshadowed another significant development taking place there. Molotov announced in his speech of Feb. 8, 1955, "the preparation for the conclusion of a treaty of friendship, collaboration and mutual aid between the eight countries" which took part in the Moscow conference (U. S. S. R., Poland, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Albania).

PHILADELPHIA, March 30 (UP)--Louis E. Wolfson, chairman of the board of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, threatened today to close the Camden, N. J., shipyard unless "certain union leaders" stop "intimidating" union members and cease "trying to blackmail management into a wage increase."
Plans are being advanced to make the second annual New York Summer Festival the largest program of its kind ever held by any city. The 1955 festival will begin on June 21 and last until Sept. 5.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Those White House squirrels got into Washington's leading, guessing game today: Will President Eisenhower run for a second term in 1956?
ANKARA, March 30 -- The Western Big Three are seeking to halt what they regard as a dangerous deterioration in TurkishSyrian relations.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- A professional wire-tapper and eavesdropper told Congress today that scientific advances in his trade were making private conversation obsolete.
Principals of elementary schools will receive today the Board of Education's formula for deciding when a child is to be "graduated" from kindergarten into the first grade.

In pursuit of his long-standing policy of seeking peace President Eisenhower has initiated a new effort to win some kind of settlement, or at least a modus vivendi, with the Communist bloc--a settlement that would banish the specter of nuclear war.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 30-- A gang of nine sniveling young hoodlums, nervously smoothing their oily sideburns and ducktail haircuts, today admitted 300 house burglaries, the Nassau County police reported.

WHAT with pigeons in the hall, alas, pickets outside, and sidewalk speeches being made by officials of Brit Trumpeldor, a Zionist youth organization, the concert of the Berlin Philharmonic last night in Carnegie Hall had its share of extra-musical aspects.
The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency will meet in executive session this morning to determine the future course of its study of the stock market.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices declined fourtenths of 1 per cent between mid-February and mid-March.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 -- The Yankees and the Phillies, having struggled through twelve innings and twenty runs, could have continued today. But there didn't seem to be much point in going on.
ALBANY, March 30--Republican leaders said today that the Legislature was rejecting all proposed changes in the state's controversial weight-distance tax on trucks.
The Soviet Union has stored sufficient oil for the machinery of war, a former Russian oil geologist reported yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30 -- Ewell Blackwell, Tom German and Dick Kryhoski were sold tonight by the New York Yankees to the Kansas City Athletics.

ALBANY, March 30 (AP)--The State Commerce Department received today the following reports from operators of ski areas: Bearpen Mountain-9 inches settled, 11-41 inches packed snow; skiing good to excellent.
Four thousand employes of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York will ballot tomorrow on a trustee to represent them in the Reserve System's $160,000,000 pension fund.
Animals, wild and domesticated; color, gaudy and glittering; death-defying suspense and the fantasies of childhood reasserted their sway over the circus last night at Madison Square Garden.
FLY - FISHING convictions seldom have as much weight as an empty creel.
MOBILE, Ala., March 30 -- Tom LaSorda pitched three curve balls to Jim Pendleton in the ninth inning today and the Dodgers emerged with their first two-game winning streak of the spring.
A recent visitor to this city was Mrs. Marion Brown of Burlington, N. C., a 50-year-old grandmother whose petite figure belies both her age and her interest in fine food.
A six-run uprising in the sixth inning gave City College an 8-3 baseball victory over Columbia at Baker Field yesterday in the opening game of the season for both teams.

CAIRO, March 30 -- Egypt charged today that Israeli forces had provoked a two-hour exchange of mortar and machinegun fire across the armistice demarcation line in the Gaza area in which one Egyptian soldier was wounded.
Spring table settings might be brightened with some of the new accouterments several East Side shops have received from Europe.
Harry Gross, the bookmaker, parlayed two court appearances yesterday to win his freedom.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Congress gave final approval today to $745,000,000 of annual pay increases to the armed forces.

CHICAGO, March 30 (AP)--Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today follow: HOGS Salable hogs. 12,000 head: trading slow, steady to 25 cents lower on butchers, with late sales mostly 25 cents lower: sows around 25 cents lower: most choice 190-250 pound butchers.
James Reston, Washington correspondent of The New York Times, gave an appraisal yesterday of the first two years of the Eisenhower Administration.

Futures prices were generally lower yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges, in in sympathy with the decline in the stock market. Cocoa, potatoes, zinc, rubber, hides, silk, cottonseed oil and soybean oil eased; coffee and sugar closed mixed, and wool, lead and copper ended higher.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30--Old-fashioned motion picture artistry triumphed tonight over mechanical innovations that have changed the shape of the screen. "On the Waterfront," filmed by a standard camera in black and white, was voted winner of the best picture award by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for 1954.

CHICAGO, March 30--Wheat had a weak tone in the early trade, but reversed its trend and established good gains before the close. Reports of high temperatures and dust storms induced early buying of the new crop deliveries, while shorts were credited with buying in the May option.

A concert of French chamber music was presented last night at Town Hall. A small orchestra, under the direction of Harris Danziger, played what was announced as the first American performance of Andre Jolivet's "Delphic Suite."

PHILADELPHIA, March 30-- Harl McDonald also was a member of the board of directors of the Philadelphia Orchestra. He had been manager of the orchestra since 1939. Previously he had been director of the Department of Music at the University of Pennsylvania.
YESTERDAY (March 30, 1955) SECURITY COUNCIL Council called on Egypt and Israel to cooperate in carrying out reforms proposed by United Nations Palestine truce chief.

Robert R. Young, chairman of the New York Central Railroad, has undergone three days of questioning this week in a pretrial examination of the "Consolidated Zenn suit." The action was brought against him last May during the bitter proxy battle for control of the railroad.
CLEVELAND, March 30-- Walter P. Reuther and his slate of candidates were victorious today in elections at the convention of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O.
The probationary patrolman whose shot killed a 15-year-old boy will have the full backing of the Police Department and the patrolmen's organization in defending himself.
Columbia's Varsity C Club will honor 149 letter-winning athletes in six sports tonight at its thirty-fourth annual dinner at John Jay Hall on the Lion campus.
Charles Silver, president of the Board of Education, appealed yesterday to high school students to help him with the problem of juvenile delinquency.
Spaghetti and sauce, all eating surveys seem to show, stand high on the favorite dish list. Variations, though less generally known, can be as thoroughly appetizing.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., achieved record net earnings of $10,336,132 last year, more than doubling the $5,064,392 earned in 1953.

ALBANY, March 30--Mayor Wagner received assurances from Republican legislative leaders today that he would get a free hand to reorganize the New York City Transit Authority. The Republican leadership also agreed to passage of a bill requiring the Transit Authority to continue operation of the Third Avenue Elevated for another year.
LINCOLN, Neb., March 30 (UP) -- Eight rebellious convicts surrendered and released two hostage guards today after a sixty-five-hour revolt at the Nebraska State Prison.
ALBANY, March 30--A plan to modernize the state's courts won final approval in the Legislature today.

RABAT, French Morocco, March 30--French authorities in Tunis called attention to a persistent curse of North African affairs when they recently banned the nationalist weekly Al Irada for "inciting to racial hatred."
WASHINGTON, March 30-- The State Department said today publication of the Yalta papers helped pile up votes in France and Germany in favor of ratification of the treaties to arm West Germany.
Cunard's "Man with the White Carnation" will drop his last big name today.

The New York State central school district composed of Wawarsing and Rochester in Ulster County and Manakating and Fallsburgh in Sullivan County announced yesterday that it will receive bids on April 14 on an issue of $3,100,000 of bonds dated May 1, 1955, and due annually on May 1 from 1956 to 1984.
The First National Bank of the City of New York was sold yesterday to the National City Bank of New York for $165,000,000.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- Cotton state Senators today abandoned hope of increasing acreage allotments this year for small farmers hard hit by Government planting restrictions.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 30 --In front of South Vietnamese Army headquarters today Signal Corps soldiers of the National Army were stringing communication wire. The old wire had been chewed up in the crossfire of machine guns last night.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Cutbacks in defense orders are causing sharp losses to manufacturers of tools and dies, spokesmen for the industry have informed the Government.
Supreme Court yesterday sounded like a cross between an old-fashioned barber shop and Tin Pan Alley.
PROVIDENCE, March 30--Dr. Henry M. Wriston, for eighteen years president of Brown University, will retire as soon after next June as his successor is chosen.
The bachelor apartment of even the most expert professional designer for the home is unlikely to satisfy a wife, if one can judge from the experience of Paul McCobb.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- A House Armed Services subcommittee heard today that reports of a recent meningitis epidemic at Fort Dix, N. J., were "inflammatory" and "wholly unwarranted."
A General Sessions jury of ten men and two women will begin deliberations this afternoon in the case of Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke, who has been on trial on two charges of compulsory prostitution.

The House of Aronowicz has emerged with a spectacularly breezy collection for summer. The stoles, jackets and slender tunics paraded yesterday at the Pierre Hotel were featherweight and showed taste and imagination.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At a recent meeting of planners in New York it was stated that plans are now in the making to put the new court house for the City Court on Centre Street on the site of the old Criminal Courts Building north of the Health Building instead of on the west side of Foley Square, as originally planned.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Feb. 9 you say "Gorwekht [Gurweek] is only a name." Would it surprise you to know that your paper is read in Gurweek, although with disappointment?
ALBANY, March 30--Paul E. Lockwood, one-time secretary to former Governor Dewey, resigned today from the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- The Secretary of Defense ordered the armed forces today to reduce public information personnel by one-half or one-third. He also imposed restrictions on what officials could say or write.

MATSU ISLAND, China, March 30--This bleak island was feverish today with defense preparations. A craggy piece of rock jutting out of the East China Sea, Matsu is the largest of seven isles in a small group near the best harbor area on the mainland coast. It has an area of about six square miles.

An increase last week of 317,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 184,157,000 barrels, compared with 183,840,000 a week earlier and 178,626,000 a year ago.

NEW DELHI, India, March 30 (AP)--Miss Camilla Koffler, photographer of wildlife who used the professional name Ylla, died today of injuries received in a jeep accident. She was photographing animals as guest of the Maharaja of Bharatpur 100 miles south of New Delhi.
The International Longshoremen's Association continued yesterday its attack on the new hiring regulations of the Waterfront Commission--this time in Supreme Court in Staten Island.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 30--One hundred fifty Afghans were reported to have attacked the Pakistan Embassy today in Kabul, in protest against the "absorption" of Pushtoonistan into West Pakistan province.
ALBANY, March 30--The Republican bill extending rent control with some modifications for two years was approved in the Assembly today. The vote was 144 to 1.

Maine and Tennessee have joined Massachusetts in passing legislation to curb "bait and switch" advertising. Maine's bill became effective March 14 and Tennessee's last week. The Massachusetts measure has been in force since July, 1953.
Reports that frequency modulation broadcasting is on the wane are disputed by a recently conducted survey, according to Elliott M. Sanger, executive vice president of radio station WQXR.
ALBANY, March 30--Special programs for helping the state's flat and harness racing associations rehabilitate outworn and crowded tracks appeared to be headed for legislative approval today.
YESTERDAY (March 30, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Signed bill extending present corporation and excise tax rates. Conferred with bipartisan group of house leaders on foreign policy problems.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday. Closing prices were unchanged to 18 points net lower on the day, with the old crop months displaying the most weakness.

BONN, Germany, March 30-- The Security Committee of the Bundestag began today to delve into the case of Bolislaw von Bonin. A former colonel on the General Staff, Herr von Bonin was dismissed from the Defense Commissioner's Office March 22 for opposing the Atlantic high command's strategic plans for West German defense.

A fifteen-story apartment house is planned for the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Twelfth Street. The property has been purchased by Frederick Mortati, attorney and real estate operator, who also acquired the northeast corner of Third Avenue and Fourteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- President Eisenhower conferred with leaders of both parties from the House of Representatives today against the background of a somewhat shaken bipartisanship in foreign policy.
WASHINGTON, March 30--A stout defense of two recent appointments to major Federal posts was made today by President Eisenhower.
TURIN, Italy, March 30 (AP)-- Marcel Deat, a pro-Nazi member of the wartime French Government at Vichy, died here Jan. 5, physicians at Villa Dei Coll. Clinic said today. He was 60 years old.

ALBANY, March 30--Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx and Supreme Court Justice Charles S. Colden of Queens would be the principal beneficiaries of a bill approved tonight by the Assembly Rules Committee.
Nineteen thousand barrels of high-test aviation gasoline were parked for ten hours not far from Mayor Wagner's doorstep yesterday when a tanker ran aground off the northern tip of Welfare Island.
LONDON, March 30--Aneurin Bevan survived today an attempt to expel him from the Labor party.

Late and Wait The Metropolitan Opera people have taken a unique step, unique for them, in barring latecomers to Wagner's "Tristan and Isolde" from their seats until the important eleven-minute prelude is over.
Huge public funds are being expended on "artistically appalling" sculptures for Federal projects, an article in Art News declares.
PARIS, March 30 -- Premier Edgar Faure said today that "the great powers" should intervene to avoid war over Formosa or Quemoy and Matsu.
MANCHESTER, Conn., March 30 (AP)--Control of Cheney Brothers, 117-year-old textile company, and of two wholly owned subsidiaries has passed out of the hands of descendants of the founders.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, March 29--Highest priority has been given to a plan to strike at the roots of social unrest in the populous native quarters here. The idea is to bring the administration closer to the people, give the inhabitants a voice in their own affairs, reduce congestion and provide better medical and social facilities for all.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House has authorized direct quotation of the President in some sections. In others, as required by conference rules, the President's remarks are in indirect discourse.
The Hilton Hotels Corporation had a consolidated net profit of $4,954,853 last year. That was an increase of 17.5 per cent over the $4,218,450 realized from operations in 1953.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 30--Until the question of transportation is approached as a whole, New York's traffic problem will defy solution, in the opinion of C. McKim Norton, executive vice president of the Regional Plan Association.

To complete the new spring ensembles, shoes certainly will be noted down on the shopping list. And if they are to be as comfortable as they are goodlooking, the prospective shopper might heed advice of Dr. Milton Wolfson, president of the Podiatry Society of New York State.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Parents bringing children to Washington for the Easter holidays this year will find this city most crowded as usual.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- President Eisenhower signed today a bill extending corporation and excise taxes at present levels for another year.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Manufacturers' shipments and new orders increased in February, compared with the month before, the Department of Commerce announced today.

CHICAGO, March 30--The Commonwealth Edison Company in 1965 may be drawing part of its power from an atomic plant that could compete economically with coal, John W. Evers, president of the utility, said today.
Heavy selling hit the stock market in the last hour of yesterday's session. Although there was a minor rally just before the close, prices sustained the widest losses since March 14.
Pontiac, sponsor of the Red Buttons show, will drop the comedy program in the latter part of May and present a new drama series beginning Sept. 6.
What can one do with a can of beans besides open, heat and eat?

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. The tourists and the "winter people," their expensive suntans fading as they go, are now fully embarked on their annual migration from Florida. They are filling the highways, the airways and the railways.
Trans-Atlantic passenger steamship rates will probably be increased in 1956, John F. Gehan, executive vice president of the American Export Lines said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- President Eisenhower favors parceling out the functions of the Foreign Operations Administration between the State and Defense Departments.
BERLIN, March 30--East Germany applied pressure to West Berlin today by increasing more than eleven-fold the tolls on heavy trucking to the West. The new rates will take effect Friday.

LONDON, March 30--Volume of business dwindled further, in the continued absence of newspapers, when the new threeweek trading account opened on the London Stock Exchange today. Prices were slightly stronger in response to the end of the dock strike and yesterday's improvement in Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, March 30-- Proposed new curbs on public housing, slum clearance and urban redevelopment were eliminated from an appropriations bill today in the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 30-- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 23: Decreases of $865,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities, $656,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $1,579,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and $628,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks.

April has been designated as Cancer Crusade month by the New York City Cancer Committee in its quest for $1,400,640. This money will provide drugs, equipment, blood, transportation for treatment and visiting nurse service for our city's indigent cancer patients.

Col. Robert R. McCormick built up and headed a newspaper empire that at one time contained three major newspapers with a total circulation of about 3,500,000 daily and 5,750,000 Sunday. These were The Chicago Tribune, The New York Daily News and The Washington Times-Herald.

The late Sisley Huddleston was an eyewitness of the sorrowful events in France between 1939 and 1947. He left an account of what he saw in a book called "France: The Tragic Years." It will be published April 11 by Devin-Adair.
POCATELLO, Idaho, March 31 (AP)--Four defending champions turned in solid performances today and advanced into the semi-finals of the National Collegiate boxing tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) --A strange new thing has been added to the Smithsonian Institution's vast collection of oddities: Just about the biggest Balanoglossus in the world.
CHICAGO, March 31--Sewell L. Avery enlisted a new supporter from an unexpected source today in his battle to retain the chairmanship of Montgomery Ward Co.
Premier Mario Scelba declared yesterday that Italy now was strong enough to resist any conceivable internal onslaught by the Communists.
Perry Como, Columbia Broadcasting System singing star, has signed a long-term contract with the National Broadcasting Company. His association with C. B. S. will end July 1.

Around this time of year a youngster is almost as likely to get a case of sniffles as a new Easter outfit. Very likely, too, he will be put to bed. If so, his mother is almost certainly faced with keeping temper and temperature down and spirits up.

In the Federal Government the conscience of the people with regard to its children is the Children's Bureau. This is the department which, since its creation in 1912, has become a crusader for discovering the needs of our children and meeting them, for focusing on the conditions under which youngsters are living and growing up and improving those conditions.
COLORADO SPRINGS, March 31 (AP)--Although she was not up to her standard, Boston's Tenley Albright led all rivals today in her first appearance at the national figure-skating championships.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 31--Race prejudice was declared here today to be based on a sense of group position rather than on individual attitude stemming from personal experience.
Nine members of the Puerto Rican Nationalist party convicted of seditious conspiracy received prison sentences yesterday ranging up to six years.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Eisenhower and the Senate leaders of both parties met in bipartisan amity today for a long review of the world situation.

The manufacturers who want retail stores to sell their products at the prices suggested by the makers attacked yesterday the report to the Justice Department calling for an end to such price protection.

NEW ORLEANS, March 31-- Manager Walter Alston started another new line-up today, with Gil Hodges in right field, Junior Gilliam in left and Pee Wee Reese at second base, but the Dodgers lost a close ball game.
VICTOR RIESENFELD'S paintings at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, figures and landscapes, dusky in color and elaborate in texture, provide moody and thoughtful visual experiences.

The president of Queens College denied yesterday that he had visited Harvey Matusow to obtain information, about possible Communist activity at his institution. However, the educator testified that he had seen Matusow about "a private matter."

Spring has filtered right indoors on Thirty-fourth Street. The counters of the department stores in this area have blossomed virtually overnight with colorful Easter-time gifts at refreshingly low prices.

These almost incredible imbroglios that the city administration and the Port of New York Authority get into from time to time are destructive, unnecessary and time consuming. Examples of the damage they have done in the past were the delay in building the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue and in starting the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- President Eisenhower signed today the bill to give pay increases of $745,000,000 to 1,700,000 members of the armed forces.
An air of uneasy peace pervaded the port's docks last night as the controversial, thricepostponed hiring regulations of the Waterfront Commission finally became effective.
City policemen endorsed their bi-monthly checks yesterday with the words "under protest." This was to emphasize their campaign against what they call "inadequate pay."
ALBANY, March 31--The Assembly approved today a bill to create a Westchester County parkway authority. The Senate previously had passed the bill and now it goes to Governor Harriman.
NEW DELHI, India, March 31--Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru went before India's Parliament today to denounce the policy promulgated by the Western powers in almost every part or the world.

QUEBEC, Friday, April 1-- The 1955 shipping season in the St. Lawrence River system began officially at midnight as bright, revolving fingers of light shown out from more than sixty Canadian Department of Transport lighthouses between here and the Atlantic Ocean.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., March 31 --The chief contenders for national wrestling titles encountered little difficulty today as the sixty-fifth Amateur Athletic Union championships began at the Amityville High School gymnasium.

ALBANY, March 31--A bipartisan campaign to save the Third Avenue elevated put Mayor Wagner's bill to reorganize the Transit Authority in jeopardy tonight. The "save-the-el" fight, carried on by Third Avenue passengers for several years, now has won strong support here.

COMACCHIO, Italy, March 30 --Since time immemorial it has been considered highly meritorious to make two blades of grass grow where only one grew before. Here in the Delta of the Po, people are doing much better.
The largest tanker in the world, the 46,550-deadweight-ton Al Malik Saud Al-Awal (King Saud I), completed last year in Germany for Aristotle S. Onassis, will soon, enter commercial service.

President Eisenhower's "home county" Republicans urged "a draft-Ike movement" yesterday to re-elect him in 1956. The President is a registered voter from 60 Morningside Drive, where he lived as head of Columbia University.
Voluntary withdrawal of Sunday advertising of imported liquor seemed likely yesterday.
Had not Col. Robert R. McCormick become a successful newspaper publisher he might have been a lawyer, politician, soldier, military expert or writer and lecturer.
CLEVELAND, March 31-- Walter P. Reuther proposed today a nation-wide organizing drive by the unions of a unified labor movement.

The death of Joseph Pulitzer yesterday at the age of 70 naturally recalls not only his own achievements but those of his famous father. Two quotations from the elder Pulitzer perhaps tell something about the younger. One is a brief introduction which the father sent to an editor who was about to employ the son.
Twenty-four operas will be performed at the Metropolitan Opera during its 1955-56 season, Rudolf Bing, general manager of the company, announced yesterday.

A fight for control of W. J. Sloane, home furnishings drain, broke out yesterday with the claim of Benjamin Coates that he and unnamed associates had acquired a majority of the common and preferred stock in the 112-year-old concern. Besides its main store here at Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, the company operates eight other stores, five in the Northeast and three in California.

Large prepayments of public utility bonds lifted the total of bonds called for redemption in March before maturity to $124,678,000 from $82,357,000 in February. The March total was the largest for any March since 1952, when $230,970,000 in bonds was retired.

PARIS, March 31--Examples of the development of art in the United States during the last fifty years were displayed here today in a preview to the major opening attraction of America's "Salute to France."

In a move reminiscent of the Berlin blockade of 1948 the Soviets, acting through their East German puppets, have set out to impose new harassments on Western traffic to and from the German capital. Their first step has been to multiply by more than ten the toll on heavy trucks, carrying about 40 per cent of all freight entering and leaving West Berlin.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 31--George Breen, sandy-haired athlete from Cortland State Teachers College, won the National Amateur Athletic Union 1,500-meter swimming title tonight.
ALBANY, March 31--Continuation of residential rent controls for New York City was assured today.
Fair skies and warm temperatures yesterday found children and Easter rabbits getting a preview of each other, while gardeners got a preview of tulips never before seen in this country.
ALBANY, March 31--The Assembly agreed today that the state and New York City should share equally the cost of institutional care for juvenile delinquents.

The cost of borrowing money in the commercial paper market rose yesterday for the first time since Jan. 18. New York City commercial paper dealers raised their rates one- eighth of one percentage point.

Control of the Manor Apartments at the southwest corner of Seventy-fifth Road and 147th Street in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, has changed through a stock-sale transaction. The stock was sold by F. Fields Associates to an investing customer of Joseph R. Paretta, broker in the deal.
IN one of the week's few group exhibitions--most of the shows being one-man events--four artists are participating at the A. C. A. Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously requested Secretary of State Dulles today to explain at a closed session why the State Department released the Yalta papers.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $200,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Although the traditional leaders swung back and forth and ended almost unchanged, the stock market as a whole gained yesterday. Of the 1,187 issues traded, 579 rose, 352 fell and 258 were unchanged.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 31 -- The armed forces of a religious sect formally transferred their support from the Opposition front to Premier Ngo Dinh Diem today. The event represented an important success for the Premier in his clash with armed Opposition groups.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 31 (AP)--Vic Seixas and Eddie Moylan gained the semi-final round in the Puerto Rican tennis tournament today.

Eye on the Consumer The twentieth century has given birth to a creature who is as famous as he is anonymous. He is the consumer. Everyone is aware of him; his habits and preferences are scrutinized; his goodwill is carefully cultivated; his occasional displays of temperament strike terror in the hearts of multitudes.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters will risk almost certain and automatic suspension from, the American Federation of Labor if it takes in the International Longshoremen's Association.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges turned irregular yesterday. Coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, burlap and lead were higher; cocoa, hides, rubber and zinc closed lower, and sugar, potatoes, wool and copper ended mixed.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31 -- Expanded capacity of American cotton mills and the growth of cheap imports are keeping profits abnormally low, according to textile spokesmen.

CHICAGO, March 31--Dust storms were reported from eastern Colorado and northern Texas, as well as some Kansas areas. As a result there was support of the new crop deliveries of wheat May wheat was advanced sharply early, but met free realizing sales on the hard spots.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 31-- The Brazilian Senate has killed an effort to amend the oil laws so that foreign capital might be enlisted to help develop the country's petroleum resources.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- There is every reason to believe that the Soviet Union is working on an atomic-powered airplane, an informed source said today.

SAN ANTONIO, March 31-- In one of the most bizarre games of their long-standing spring rivalry, the Cleveland Indians vanquished the New York Giants, 14 to 11, today, amid considerable acrimony on both sides.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31--American travelers were reported today to have provided foreign, countries with enough dollars to pay for 10 per cent of all their imports from the United States.

A husband-and-wife geological team reported yesterday that microscopic fish fossils might provide clues to the location of oil. These endothyroid foraminifera enrich the deposits of Indiana limestone, a stone that faces many of Manhattan's buildings.

BONN, Germany, March 31-- The offices of the United States, British and French High Commissioners plan to protest to the Soviet High Commission against an East German ruling that would reduce the flow of materials between West Berlin and West Germany.

Ten years ago Air Force M/Sgt. Charles Badger was tail gunner in a bomber that helped to devastate Germany. Yesterday he made good some of that war damage by welcoming a young German widow and her son.

WASHINGTON, March 31--The Government should take steps to insure "the return of democracy to publicly owned corporations," Louis E. Wolfson asserted here today. Mr. Wolfson, who is fighting Sewell Avery for control of Montgomery Ward Co., said he stood for more, rather than less, Government regulation to protect stockholders.
LONDON, March 31--Sir Anthony Eden tonight expressed the belief that patient negotiations on disarmament and on the future of Germany would solve differences between the Soviet Union and the West.
KANSAS CITY, March 31-- The lofty aims of the Federal housing program have been overridden by political pressures, the American Institute of Planners was told today.
A $10,000,000-a-year increase in exports to the United States has been set as a goal by the Philippines, the leader of a trade mission from the island republic said yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 31--A gas turbine engine specialist said here today that another step has been taken in development of a practical gas turbine engine for automobiles.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31--Five players were dropped from the Yankees' squad today, leaving thirty-three in the group that headed northward this evening.
LOS ANGELAS, March 31-- American young people are forgetting how to walk. They jump into a car to go a block. The trend has already produced conspicuous changes in their physiques.
NOT everyone can afford a trip for Atlantic salmon, but fishing for landlocked salmon is available to anyone who can travel as far as New Hampshire or Maine.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31--The charge has been leveled against the New York Yankees that they have been prejudiced against Negroes. It has been made mostly by irresponsible persons who point to the fact that the Bombers have never had one on their squad. It also has been made by the sensitive and crusading Jackie Robinson. This tourist has never believed a word of it.
MONTREAL, March 31 (UP)-- The Montreal Canadiens overwhelmed the Boston Bruins, 5--1, tonight to sweep into the Stanley Cup hockey finals for the fifth straight year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31--Hollywood was patting itself on the back today, happy for a change over the handling of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences Awards ceremony.
BONN, March 31 -- West Germany revealed today that its gold reserve is now larger than it ever was in the much larger German Reich at any time between the two world wars.

SOME of the pretentious mumbo-jumbo that has accompanied the presentation of the film industry's Academy Awards in the past was absent from this year's ceremonies. As a result, the proceedings, as seen on television, were relatively informal and often entertaining.
Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the first quarter this year was the largest in twenty-five years. The total was 202,325,727 shares.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 9,500 head: market fairly active, strong to mostly 25 cents higher on all weights butchers: sows mostly 25 cents higher: most choice 190 to 240 pounds
WASHINGTON, March 31-- The United States, Britain and France plan a conference this spring preliminary to any meeting with the Soviet Union.
Public hearings on a proposed rule to curb excessive legal fees in accident cases were ordered yesterday by the Appellate Divisions of the Supreme Court, First and Second Departments.
Plans are being formulated by the Junior Auxiliary of the Grand Street Settlement House for an Easter dance to be held April 9 at the Plaza.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 1 to 20 points (5 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday. The near months displayed greater strength than the far months.

Plans for a new business building in the new City Coliseum area were announced yesterday in connection with a sale of the southwest corner of Broadway and West Fifty-fifth Street, a plot 113 by 105 feet.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 31 (AP)--Fred Haas Jr. of Claremont, Calif., and 25-year-old Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., carded seven-under-par 65's today to share the first-round lead in the $12.500 Azalea open golf tournament.

The consolidation of Dwight- Helmsley, Inc., and Spear Co., Inc., was announced yesterday by the presidents of the two realty concerns, Harry B. Helmsley and Maurice R. Spear. The new company, known as Helmsley-Spear, Inc., will be headed by Mr. Helmsley.
Everybody's face is red over the one - in - a - million parlay that brought Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower and another guest to a Washington party in similar dresses.
Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke was convicted early today on two counts of compulsory prostitution.
The French Ambassador to the United States, warned yesterday that the Soviet Union would continue to try to divide the Western powers.

The Horn Hardart Company will open a restaurant soon in the old Tiffany Building at 401 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Thirty-seventh Street. The corner store and basement space was leased through Tankoos Co., brokers, from the 401 Fifth Avenue Corporation, headed by Henry Goelet.
The renewed drive by the anthracite industry to recapture part of the residential market it has lost to oil and gas got up a full head of steam yesterday.

Like The Chicago Tribune, Col. Robert R. McCormick came by his Republicanism naturally. The Tribune was established in 1847. It helped found the Republican party, and backed Abraham Lincoln for President. The colonel's grandfather, Joseph Medill, bought a quarter interest in the paper in 1855 and ran it until his death in 1899.
CHICAGO, March 31 (AP)-- John Horne, 175 pounds, gained a decision tonight in the final bout to give New York a 4-4 tie with Chicago in the intercity Golden Gloves tournament.
TRENTON, March 31 (AP)-- Two buyers for the New Jersey division of Employment Security who admitted taking part in purchasing manipulations under the late Harold G. Hoffman were suspended today.
The lamps glowed as softly as ever last night in the dark-paneled lounge of the Town Hall Club at 123 West Forty-third Street.
JERUSALEM, March 31--The Israeli sector of this divided city is making notable advances toward becoming the nation's political and cultural center. The other sector of the city belongs to Jordan.

The Internal Revenue Service made public yesterday the days and hours, beginning tomorrow and continuing through April 15, when its offices in this area will be open to assist Federal income taxpayers in filing returns. The telephone numbers of the offices were given so a taxpayer with a single question or problem might call.

IT was a pleasure to attend and it is a great pleasure to write of the delightful and brilliant performance last night in the City Center of Nicolai's "Merry Wives of Windsor," sung in the excellent English translation of Josef Blatt.
ALBANY, March 31--Legislation paving the way for construction of a new "dream track" at Belmont Park was reported out tonight by the Assembly Rules Committee.
YESTERDAY (March 31, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Signed bill increasing military pay. Met with the National Security Council. Briefed Senate leaders of both parties on foreign policy problems.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 --A California judge today made enforceable in this state a $500,000 libel judgment awarded in the State of Washington against the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, unaffiliated.

STORM JAMESON, who says that she is as English as Yorkshire pudding, writes about France and the French with nearly as impressive authority as she does about her native country. Miss Jameson's first book was published thirty-six years ago. Since then she has written more than thirty others. Most are novels and those most generally admired deal with a shipping family in Yorkshire or with France in defeat and decline.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) --The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to call off or postpone its hearing to determine whether interests controlling the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad were trying to get control of the Boston and Maine Railroad.

CHICAGO, April 1--Col. Robert Rutherford McCormick, 74, colorful editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, died today. He had been in failing health for several years but remained active in his work until early last month.

For a large segment of our sports-going population the state of suspended animation has ended. Today at 1:15 thoroughbred horse racing will start at the Jamaica race track, and tonight at 8:40 harness racing will begin its local season at the Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L.I.

Newly added to Paul Gregory's list of great expectations is "Bleak House." It is being transferred into play form by John Patrick, recipient of the Pulitzer Prize and the Critics Circle award for his adroit approximation of "The Teahouse of the August Moon."
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Eisenhower recommended to Congress today a $75,900,000 cutback in atomic energy funds.
WASHINGTON, March 31-- Further hearings on the stock market will be conducted later this session by a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee.
The following letters are representative of the mail being received from Times readers discussing the defense of Quemoy and Matsu.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- "Junk" mail was barred from city and town post offices at midnight tonight.

A report of the American Iron and Steel Institute yesterday provided the first official figures of the magnitude of iron ore imports into the United States. In 1954 they were 17,700,000 net tons. That figure was the biggest in history, 42 per cent greater than the previous record set in 1953.

AT the same moment two days ago that Congress was petitioned to establish a Theodore Roosevelt Centennial Commission for 1958, the staff at Roosevelt Memorial House at 28 East Twentieth Street was examining 780 letters written by T.R. between 18701918 to his sister, Anna Roosevelt Cowles.

GENEVA, March 31 -- The first Conference of Nongovernmental Organizations associated with the United Nations was convened here today. Its full title, which largely explains its purpose, is the United Nations Conference of Nongovernmental Organizations Interested in the Eradication of Prejudice and Discrimination.

THEY weren't doing the mambo in the aisles at Carnegie Hall last night, but they might have been. Up on the podium Dimitri (call him the cool maestro) Mitropoulos was making up for this omission by leading and swaying with a mambo beat.

The Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission, yesterday sold a new issue of $9,100,000 of 2 1/4 per cent sewer system bonds due serially from 1956 to 1974 to Lehman Brothers and associates at a bid of 98.976. The next best bid, 98.86 for the same rate, was submitted by John Nuveen Co.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 31--The Government asked Afghanistan today to apologize for a "mob attack" yesterday on the Pakistani Embassy in Kabul.
Dr. Kaufman Schlivek, a retired Manhattan ophthalmologist, died yesterday in his home at 955 Park Avenue after a long illness. He was 74 years old.
The city and the Port of New York Authority were deadlocked last night over basic details of legislation to advance the $600,000,000 metropolitan bridge and highway program.

Members of the recently established Women's Auxiliary of the Alumni Association of Columbia College are furthering the success of the spring concert of the Columbia College Glee Club to be held on the night of April 16 at Town Hall.
A bitter dispute among the world's sugar interests is nearing a showdown.
Contrasts in new financing developed here in March and in the first quarter of 1955. Public flotations of bonds were the highest for many years, while stock offerings shrank.
ALBANY, March 31 -- The Legislature ordered a pay rise today for all school supervisors in the state.
Changes in the standard automobile liability and physical damage insurance policies to provide broader coverage at no additional cost were announced yesterday.

MANILA, March 31--A former Secretary of Justice, Oscar Castelo, was convicted today of murder and sentenced to death. Seven others were also convicted and received death sentences. The eight defendants had been accused of murdering Manuel Monroy in June, 1953.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 639,447 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 16,670 cars or 2.5 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 38,033 cars or 6.3 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 75,886 cars or 10.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 31--In a trip, just concluded, northward through Florida this correspondent found strong evidences of a mass psychology which demonstrated the hold on the people of the Presidency and of the President now in office.

In American newspaper history there have been many controversial figures, but few more controversial than Col. Robert Rutherford McCormick, powerful editor and publisher of that powerful and controversial newspaper, The Chicago Tribune.

In the usual frenzied and disorderly wind-up of the legislative session at Albany which is euphemistically called lawmaking we hope that certain bills will not only pass both branches but also receive Governor Harriman's approval. At this stage, so fluid is the situation, attitudes change overnight and what seemed safe or doomed last night may be the victim or the beneficiary of a reversal today or tomorrow.
LONDON, March 31--The stock markets remained firm today. Government funds lost part of their early gains but industrial shares closed at the best levels.
CINCINNATI, March 31-- Chemists here today were urged to press the search for new drugs that can give peace o mind to upset people.
The Chase National Bank and the Bank of the Manhattan Company received official approval to merge yesterday.

Shoppers will do well to buy eggs for Easter now. Supplies are plentiful, quality is good and prices are lower for the second successive week. Next week, as demand increases, prices are expected to rise.
Two insurance adjusters and four taxi drivers were arrested yesterday, accused of fraudulently obtaining $5,550 in insurance settlements.
Loans to business by twenty leading New York City banks in the week ended on Wednesday declined by $28,000,000, the first decrease in eight weeks.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and six pharmaceutical manufacturers yesterday described their backing of the Salk polio vaccine as "a calculated risk."

WASHINGTON, March 31 --Harold E. Stassen stirred a Senatorial hornets' nest today and was promptly stung with a Senate subpoena action. The Administration's foreign aid director angered the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations by laying down rules for Senatorial questioning of his employes.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) --Two former aides of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today contradicted sworn testimony of Brig. Gen. Ralph W Zwicker in the Peress case.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 31 --The Minister of War has warned ail senior officers that there must be no interference in the Presidential campaign. The campaign is expected to enter a more active phase now.
The lovefest between Sewell Avery and Dave Beck in Chicago yesterday is likely to raise new questions about the propriety of union excursions into corporate finance.
ALBANY, March 31--A one year's delay in putting last year's compulsory automobile inspection law into effect was assured tonight.
NEWARK, March 31--A jury awarded Rabbi Joachim Prinz $30,000 today on his charge of having been libeled by Conte McGinley, editor of Common Sense, in an article accusing him of communistic leanings.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York said yesterday that it had received $15,150,000 in contributions and pledges in its 1954-55 campaign.

SYRACUSE, March 31 (UP)-- Dick Farley, a former Indiana star, sparked the Syracuse Nationals in a fourth-period rally tonight for an 86-82 victory over the Fort Wayne Pistons. This was the opening game of the final round of the professional National Basketball Association's play-offs.
A model of a centralized pushbutton system that would automatically switch trains throughout the entire 400-mile trackage of the I. R. T. subway was demonstrated yesterday.
MOSCOW, Friday, April 1-- A wholesale turnover among chairmen of Soviet collective farms has been ordered by the Communist party and Government.
A motivation research study being compiled by Social Research, Inc., of Chicago, discloses some deeply held beliefs on the part of persons exposed to advertising.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 1-- President Carlos Ibanez said in in interview today that he did not intend to dissolve Congress or to establish a dictatorship.
Coppers, steels, oils and atomic issues took command of a relatively inactive stock market yesterday and scored long gains. Motors and electrical equipments followed them upward.

Col. Robert R. McCormick built up and headed a newspaper ampire that at one time contained three major newspapers with a total circulation of about 3,500,00 daily and 5,750,000 Sunday. These were The Chicago Tribune, The New York Daily News and The Washington Times-Herald.

Robert R. McCormick was a man born out of his century. His stanch loyalty to old traditions, his deep nostalgia for the past, blinded him to the fundamental changes that took place within his lifetime in the geographical position of the United States.

Bank of New York The Bank of New York reported as of March 31, 1955, total deposits of $403,113,028 and total assets of $461,786,743; compared, respectively, with $472,264,424 and $530,390,661 on Dec. 31, 1954.
CLEVELAND, April 1 -- A shorter work week will be the next goal of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., after a guaranteed annual wage is achieved.
VENICE, Italy, April 1-- Venice is built on 118 islands. Why not 119?
CLEVELAND, April 1--The United States Office of Education is overrun with partisan politics, two top school officials charged today.

The following are textual excerpts (with digests of the remaining parts) from Mayor Wagner's message to the Board of Estimate and the City Council in submitting the executive budget for the fiscal year 1955-56:
ALBANY, April 1--Legislation permitting savings banks to open branches outside their home office cities was approved today by the State Senate. The vote was 37 to 19.
MOSCOW, Saturday, April 2 (Reuters)--French Premier Edgar Faure has told Pravda he advocates Big Four talks, with certain safeguards, the Soviet Communist party newspaper said today.
New York's 196-day horse racing season opened at Jamaica yesterday. The first race was run at 1:15 P. M. but the opening didn't have the "official" stamp put on it till 4:03.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., April 1--The Veterans Administration Hospital here demonstrated today how contrived fantasy might help the mentally ill face reality.

BOSTON, April 1--Tony De Marco is the new welterweight champion of the world. The unheralded 23-year-old boxer from this city's North End section knocked out Johnny Saxton of New York in the fourteenth round at the Boston Garden tonight.

MOSCOW, March 24--Maria Molchanova, a country girl who has worked in Moscow for several years, is going back to the land. With her are going 165,000 other young Soviet citizens, most of whom have never lived on a farm before.

Wine flows from grape presses only when the soil and weather favor its production. But beer bubbles up with fewer demands on Mother Nature. It is not only brewed widely and well in this country, but it also comes into the United States from such far-flung points as Japan, Mexico, Switzerland and Israel Brewing is world-wide.

MANILA, Saturday, April 2-- Earthquakes killed nearly 200 persons in the southern Philippines yesterday. Thousands more were homeless. Several cities were without light and water. Damage was unassessed but was estimated in millions of pesos.
Leo Kers has purchased for Broadway presentation next September "Clerambard," a comedy of behavior by Marcel Ayme, one of France's foremost writers.
The American Tobacco Company will cancel its sponsors ship of the "Robert Montgomery Presents" drama program on June 27.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) --The Defense Department disclosed tonight that four persons had received eye injuries, two possibly permanent, at atomic tests in Nevada in 1952 and 1953.

An analysis of "the Horatio Alger myth" as it has affected American writing in the twentieth century is the subject of a book by Kenneth Lynn entitled "The Dream of Success." Mr. Lynn discusses the lives and works of five American novelists.
PHILIPPE ENTREMONT is a 20-year-old pianist from France who has appeared in this country under the exchange program between the National Music Council and the Jeunesses Musicales de France.
New Yorkers gave the regional Red Cross blood program 13,391 pints of Wood last month, Dr. William M. Markel, director of the program, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 1 (AP)--Today's report on the livestock market by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6.500 head: market slow, steady to 23 and lower on butchers: choice No. 1 and 2 lightweights mostly steady: sows steady early, later sales around 25 and
ALBANY, April 1--The Legislature advanced today several proposals designed to ease the financial plight of the state's hard-pressed bus industry.

There may be trouble ahead for the newly married person if he has been made to feel overdependent and is comfortable only when adored and praised by his parents. Dr. Luther Woodward stated last night.

WASHINGTON, April 1--A Los Angeles taxi driver patented this week an electric contrivance to remind a hackie when there are bags in the luggage compartment. Too often, Too often, according to the according to the patent, a driver rushes his fare to a train or airplane and discovers later that he has put the passenger aboard without impedimenta.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 1-- Roosevelt Raceway opened its sixteenth season of harness racing tonight with the largest first-night crowd in its history, 29,121. The previous high was 23,371 in 1949.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)-- Federal Judge Alexander Holtzoff today temporarily restrained the Interstate Commerce Commission from conducting a hearing into whether the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad might be attempting to gain control of the Boston and Maine Railroad.

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 1 (AP) --Top-seeded Vie Seixas reached the final of the Puerto Rican invitation tennis tournament today, but he had to go all out to get past Eddie Moylan of Trenton, in a scorching semi-final, 8-6, 1-6, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4.
WASHINGTON, April 1--Two key Government officials endorsed today the proposed repeal of "fair trade" laws.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 1 (UP)-- Oklahoma A. and M.'s representatives shattered the Texas Relays record in the distance medley today and came within onetenth of a second of the world sprint medley mark. The Aggies won titles in four events to dominate the opening of the twentyeighth annual event.
Mayor Wagner sent to the Board of Estimate yesterday an executive budget of $1,783,086,557 for the fiscal year starting July 1.
AMITYVILLE, L. I., April 1 --A 47 year-old campaign and a 15-year-old Ithaca High School sophomore captured the spotlight tonight in the National Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships.
Henry W. (The Dutchman) Grunewald was sentenced yesterday to five years' imprisonment and fined $10,000 for his part in a $160,000 tax-fix conspiracy.
PHILADELPHIA, April 1-- Adolf A. Berle Jr. deplored today what he called a growing tendency to bypass competent individuals because they had been found to be "controversial."
Active cotton futures rose 3 to 11 points on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, with the near month's showing the most strength.

MONTOUR FALLS, N. Y., April 1 (AP)--The trout season opened today on Catherine Creek and other Finger Lakes inlets and tributaries. Game wardens said the turnout on the creek appeared to be the smallest in ten years.
CINCINNATI, April 1--A new way to protect perishable materials such as vitamins against deterioration was described here today at the 127th national meeting of the American Chemical Society.
WASHINGTON, April 1--The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations tried this morning to serve a subpoena on Harold E. Stassen.

The four-story apartment house at 102 Drake Avenue in New Rochelle, N. Y., was bought by Wilfred S. Stachenfeld from a client of David Klibanov, attorney, and resold to an investing group headed by Irwin Halpern, attorney.
THE PRESIDENT Asked Congress for approximately $75,000,000 to rush Inter -American Highway to completion. Met with Cabinet. Left for week-end at Gettysburg Farm.
MONTREAL, April 1 (Canadian Press)--Horace Ashenfelter, a United States Olympic star, won the featured two-mile race at the Canadian indoor track championships tonight. His time was 9:06.3.
Longshore leaders fought desperately yesterday to prevent a port-wide strike Monday morning caused by the new hiring regulations just put into effect by the Waterfront Commission.

MANILA, April 1--After three years as United States Ambassador, Admiral Raymond A. Spruance left Manila today for home. He gave a piece of parting advice to the Filipinos on land reform, which he considers essential to the progress and orderly development of the nation.
ALBANY, April 1--The Legislature gave final approval today to three of the bills in the housing program backed by Governor Harriman.

JACKSON, Miss., April 1 (AP) --The Mississippi House of Representatives today condemned Hodding Carter, Pulitzer Prizewinning editor, as a writer of falsehoods about his state and its "citizens' councils."

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 1--Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies announced today the Government would send to Malaya as soon as possible an infantry battalion with supporting arms backed by reinforcements in Australia.
ALBANY, April 1--Republican legislative leaders agreed today to defer the State University's proposed $250,000,000 bond issue until next year.

WASHINGTON, April 1--The Interstate Commerce Commission dismissed today a Federal Government effort to recapture between $2,000,000,000 and $3,000,000,000 from American railroads for wartime military freight bills.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 1-- Brazil and Colombia are reported to be seeking an agreement of coffee producing countries to keep prices up by withdrawing surplus supplies fron the market.
HOUSTON, April 1--The traveling world series went completely haywire today before a startled gathering of 10,930 baseball enthusiasts.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's chief aide challenged yesterday the authenticity of an entry in the diaries of the late James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy during World War II.
A favorite subject among reporters and editors since the second decade of this century has been the secret of the success of The Chicago Tribune.
ALBANY, April 1--The Legislature cleared today all but one of the bills requested by Mayor Wagner to balance New York City's next budget.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 1-- The situation in South Vietnam deteriorated today. There was further delay in dealing with the country's dissident elements.

WASHINGTON, April 1-- Average primary market prices advanced 0.4 per cent over the week ended March 29, 1955, to 110.5 (1947-49 equals 100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Increases in average prices for livestock and meats were primarily responsible for the increases in the indexes for farm products and processed foods.

Automobile sales and production records continue to topple. The nation's dealers, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, sold an estimated 710,000 autos in March, the highest total in any month in history.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1 --The prevailing view of the textile industry is a rather gloomy one, but the head of the nation's largest retail house is downright optimistic.

A Wonderful Fairy Tale No fairy tale ever written is more full of wonder than the real one that started 150 years ago today. None of the circumstances surrounding the birth of Hans Christian Andersen in Odense on April 2, 1805, could have been more unpromising.
A bank robber, who could have been caught, escaped yesterday morning with $7,277 from a branch of the Marine Midland Trust Company in the financial district.
The world-wide search for uranium hag given an atomic twist to the old saw about the better mousetrap.

LONDON, April 1--The slight but discernible increase in the right-wing strength evident in results of the local elections today provided the Conservative party with an argument for an early general election.
ALBANY, April 1--The Jockey Club's plan for rehabilitating the State's flat tracks was bogged down today in a welter of typographical errors and inaccurate bill-drafting.

ATLANTA, April 1--For a fellow who delivered his first pitch in an exhibition game tonight, Don Larsen rates high in Casey Stengel's estimation. It is the contention of the Yankees' manager that the 6-foot 4-inch right-hander will win fifteen games for the Bombers this season.

Mayor Wagner's proposed executive budget for the 1955-56 fiscal year passes the billion and threequarters mark for the first time. At $1,783,086,557, it is up nearly $140,000,000 over the current cost of running the New York City Government. Of this the state would contribute, by the Mayor's estimate, 15.3 per cent and the Federal Government 4.3 per cent.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 1 --The Federal Government is operating in a vacuum on the larger issues of civil defense, planning experts asserted today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)-- President Eisenhower said today that in the deaths of Joseph Pulitzer and Col. Robert R. McCormick, "American journalism has lost the services of two of its outstanding publishers."
ALBANY, April 1--The Assembly voted today to give Jacob K. Javits, Attorney General, new powers against unfair trade practices and fraudulent advertising.
Had not Col. Robert R. McCormick become a successful newspaper publisher he might have been a lawyer, politician, soldier, military expert or writer and lecturer.
The deadline was passed yesterday for a major ban on "junk" mail. But that doesn't mean the nameless, unsolicited mail is dead.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 1-- Terrorists threw four grenades tonight in a new outbreak of anti-British attacks following sixteen dynamite blasts earlier today.

A RECENT meteorological phenomenon, characterized by Down-Easters as a cold snap, "set back" the opening of the angling season several days in parts of Maine. However, a few portions of Sebago Lake opened yesterday.
The birthday anniversary of Hans Christian Andersen was celebrated yesterday with a reception in the New York Public Library. The Danish author was born 150 years ago today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, April 1 (AP)--The weather produced dust, rain and cold north winds but Louise Suggs, two-time national champion, posted a two-underpar 75 for the first-round lead in Oklahoma City's $5,000 women's open golf tournament today.

Cheerful reports on steel production and profits came from two quarters yesterday. The Buffalo area was reported by The Associated Press as producing at a record rate of 104.9 per cent of capacity. And Joel Hunter, president of Crucible Steel, told the New York Society of Security Analysts that the company's first quarter earnings were about $2 a share, against 23 cents a share in the 1954 quarter.
WASHINGTON, April 1--Joseph Ratti, master stonecutter fell to his death today from a scaffold on the Washington Cathedral.

THE GOVERNOR Signed several minor bills. Vetoed six bills, including one that would have authorized town boards to license and regulate the collection of garbage. Sent messages to the Legislature urging passage of a uniform motor vehicle code and a county home rule amendment.
BUENOS AIRES, April 1-- The police offered no explanation today for their sudden release last night of 101 students, some of whom had been held in jail since October.
MOBILE, Ala., April 1 (AP)-- Waterman Steamship Corporation, once the biggest freight line in the country, today announced receipt of an offer to buy the company for almost $42,000,000.
The city and the Port of New York Authority settled their differences yesterday over condemnation of land for the proposed second level of the George Washington Bridge.
CHICAGO, April 1--United Air Lines plans to spend about $160,000,000 in the next three to four years for new planes, navigational aids and improved ground facilities.
WASHINGTON, April 1-- Congress was asked today to admonish President Eisenhowe not to fight to defend Quemoy and Matsu.
State Controller Arthur Levitt criticized the Dewey Administration yesterday as having lacked boldness in its capital improvement program.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am puzzled to read the recent letter by the president of the Pakistan League of America taking issue with C. L. Sulzberger. At a time when world tension is so intense and the relations between the Arab bloc and the West seem to be strained it is unfortunate that Ibrahim Chowdry should give expression to such a criticism of what C. L. Sulzberger stated.

CHICAGO, April 1--The rain and snow in northern Texas and Oklahoma was regarded here as doing more good than the winds did harm. As a result, another wave of selling yesterday broke the new crop wheat contracts to new lows for the season.

With the coming of spring, Winterthur, the Henry Francis du Pont Museum, about six miles from Wilmington, Del., offers an added incentive to visitors to the famed collection of native craftsmanship and art.
WASHINGTON, April 1--The Army upgraded tonight the secrecy classification of documents bearing on General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's view of the need for...

In another historic decision characterized by a remarkable display of solidarity the Senate has approved the Paris pacts for ratification by a nearly unanimous vote. In doing so it enabled the United States to make an even fuller contribution to the new Europe, to Western defense which involves our own, and to peace.
Hearn's at Fourteenth Street, one of the city's oldest department stores, may close its doors permanently a week from today.

THE veteran French painter and print-maker Jacques Villon is honored at Lucien Goldschmidt's, 33 East Seventy -fifth Street, with a distinguished and selective exhibition of his work from 1907 to the present.

New Yorkers basked yesterday in the warmest day of the year, and they could look forward to a week-end of the same balmy weather. The Weather Bureau forecast fair and continued warm for today and tomorrow, a happy contrast to last week-end's weather, when it was unseasonably cold, windy and even snowy.
WASHINGTON, April 1--The Senate approved today by a vote of 76 to 2 treaties that put an armed West Germany back into the Western community of nations.

CHICAGO, April 1 (AP)--Colonel McCormick's health had been impaired since he suffered an attack of pneumonia after returning from a European trip in April, 1953. He underwent an abdominal operation for adhesions Jan. 19.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) --Prof. John K. Galbraith said today that attacks on "nonconforming" witnesses threatened to impair the value of congressional hearings.
LONDON, April 1--Complete returns of the elections in twenty County Councils in England and Wales showed a faint general movement toward the Conservative party.

SYRACUSE, April 1 (AP)-- Chico Vejar, Stamford (Conn.) collegian, jabbed his way to an easy ten-round decision over Billy Graham of New York tonight. It was Vejar's second triumph in less than a month over the 32-year-old East Side welterweight.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 --Howard Hughes, owner of R. K. O. Radio Pictures, has settled his dispute with the Motion Picture Association of America over "The French Line."
WASHINGTON, April 1-- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for approximately $75,000,000 to complete the PanAmerican Highway to the Panama Canal Zone in three years.
American business men are betting a cool $27,100,000,000 on the national economy.

The sales of eight out of ten big New York department stores in March were greater than in the like month last year, a survey by The New York Times revealed yesterday. However, merchants emphasized that the showing was far from impressive.
MOSCOW, April 1 -- Two medals, one real and one verbal, were pinned today on writers who at one time could expect nothing but critical brickbats in this town.

Although the market for new capital has not been taxed overmuch in recent weeks, there is every sign that the spring season will be marked by a large variety and volume of financing, especially in the corporate field.
RABAT, French Morocco, April 1--There is reason to believe that the French Government will sees a new Sultan of Morocco.

The four-story store and apartment building at 301 East Fiftyseventh Street has been sold by Peter Doelger, Inc., to an investing client of Murray W. Greif, attorney. Emanuel G. Kleid was attorney for the seller and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The writer of the following letter, author of "Formosa Beachhead," has made a number of visits to Formosa in recent years. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There have long teen two schools of thought on China, and now there are two schools of thought on "two Chinas."
ALBANY, April 1--The Assembly voted today to limit workmen's compensation benefits for loss of hearing resulting from on-the-job noise.

The following statement, showing executive budget recommendations for the various city departments, all funds, for 1955-56, has been submitted by Mayor Wagner to the Board of Estimate and the City Council, with comparisons between the budget for 1954-55, as modified to March 15, 1955, and the executive budget for 1955-56.
WASHINGTON, April 1--The General Accounting Office threw another roadblock today before the controversial Dixon-Yates contract.

BERLIN, April 1--The Western Allies and East German Communists in effect said today that the problem of the elevenfold increase in truck tolls between Berlin and the West should be settled by the interzonal trade negotiators.

Like The Chicago Tribune, Col. Robert R. McCormick came by his Republicanism naturally. The Tribune was established in 1847. It helped found the Republican party, and backed Abraham Lincoln for President. The colonel's grandfather, Joseph Medill, bought a quarter interest in the paper in 1855 and ran it until his death in 1899.

WILMINGTON, N. C., April 1 (AP) -- Billy Maxwell of Odessa Tex., carded a four-under-par 68 for 133 today to take the lead in the Azalea open golf tournament. Maxwell was one shot ahead of Bob Toski, Livingston, N. J., whose 63 set a course record, and Mike Souchak, Durham, N. C., who registered his second 67.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 1 --Karl Spooner and Johnny Podres, the Dodgers' ace young southpaws, pitched today and neither did well.
OSWEGO, N. Y., April 1 (AP)-- This city on Lake Ontario is fashioning plans by which to win the title "The Port of Central New York."

The so-called "guaranteed annual wage" is now sure to be the great issue of 1955 in labor-management relations. The United Automobile Workers are taking the lead by making it their chief demand and the idea is spreading among other leading unions.
ALBANY, April 1--The Republican-controlled Legislature will leave a $75,000 "watch dog" committee behind to keep a continuous check on the Harriman Democratic Administration.

JOHN MASTERS is the Calcutta-born Connecticut Yankee (by adoption) who began in 1951 the formidable project of writing thirty-five novels at the rate of one each year to tell the story of the British in India. This is certainly the most extensive literary undertaking relating to India since the composition of the Sanskrit epics--and so far it is much more readable.

A plea for liberalization or United States trade policies was made here yesterday by Premier Mario Scelba of Italy. There is room, he said, for a useful expansion of trade between the two countries. But this will be possible, he added, only if the United States frees itself of fears of competition and burdensome administrative procedures that still hamper America's "fundamentally liberal" policies.
