The 1955 Legislature moves toward imminent adjournment of its rather lengthy session with a record that is mixed but far from barren of accomplishment. The stepped-up pace of the last few days has made its contributions, although it can hardly be put down as an ideal method of lawmaking.

LONDON, April 1--The stock market was cheered today by the budget surplus and Conservative gains in local elections. But Government funds eased under light selling and closed 2s 6d (35 cents) or 5 shillings (70 cents) down.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 1 --Bob Gawboy, a grandson of an Indian chief, set a world swimming record at the National Amateur Athletic Union championships tonight.

CHINHAE, Korea, April 1-- Surely the world's most bellicose octogenarian is Syngman Rhee, President of the Republic of Korea, a man with the face of a benevolent Buddha, hair like thistledown and the heart of a jingo. This is a time of aged statesmen--Churchill, Adenauer, Pope Pius, all of them old men in a hurry.
The annual celebration of the triumphal entry of Christ into Jerusalem will be conducted at Palm Sunday services tomorrow.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., April 1--Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa of New York inspected here today a shipment of 50,000 hypodermic syringes. They will be used after Easter to administer anti-polio vaccine to 280,000 New York City school children. The program will be carried out, however, only if the Salk vaccine is found to be effective.
POCATELLO, Idaho, April 1 (AP)--Led by Herb Odom, Michigan State took an early lead tonight in the National Collegiate boxing tournament.

In American newspaper history there have been many controversial figures, but few more controversial than Col. Robert Rutherford McCormick, powerful editor and publisher of that powerful and controversial newspaper, The Chicago Tribune.

LONDON, April 2 (Reuters)-- Chelsea, in sight of its first major trophy in fifty years of soccer, won by 4--2 at Tottenham today. The victory increased Chelsea's lead to four points in the English League's first division.

IN "The Good Shepherd" Commander George Krause of the destroyer Keeling has a sleepless and bad time of it escorting a convoy across the Atlantic. His tribulations seem nothing, however, to those experienced by C. S. Forester in bringing the journey to the pages of the novel.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The United States announced today that seventy-six Chinese students who had been refused permission to go home were now "free to depart."
PHILADELPHIA, April 2-- Was Pierre S. du Pont a legal resident of Delaware or Pennsylvania when he died last April 5 at the age of 84?

I first met the Russians in May, 1945, a few days after the Nazis capitulated in Europe. I was in Dresden, Germany, where my father, mother, brother and myself were under local internment by the Germans under protection of the Swiss Consulate, part of the 900 Americans caught there by World War II.

MARRIAGE by go-between, according to a recent news report from Tokyo, is still prevalent in Japan despite a greater freedom for women and a general "Westernization" of customs. Traditionally, Japanese parents choose a friend to bring about a suitable introduction for their children of marriageable age; if a match doesn't result in six months, say, the go-between tries again.
NO DOUBT last week saw a bitter, if not mortal blow, delivered to those who have been nourishing hopes for the closed-circuit telecasting of Broadway productions in theatres throughout the country.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 2 --Bob Grim became the first Yankee pitcher to go all the way this spring as he hurled the Bombers to an 11-1 victory over their Southern Association farmhands, the Birmingham Barons, today.

For Ages 7 to 9. MARY LOU'S grandfather has come to live with them, to her father's quiet happiness but to her mother's anxiety. Having Grandfather there to answer questions, with time to talk to her and occasionally to walk with her to the beech tree, seems wonderful to the 8-year-old child; his explanation of the old beech tree and its new shoots creates for her a picture of life's continuity.

Nineteenth century examples of "cigar-box art," together with old labels, trade cards and other pictorial material used to advertise tobacco, are in an exhibition in the Arents Collection of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
CLINTON, Conn., April 2 (AP) --Legislation to make public funds available for the development of privately owned shorefronts was urged today at a statewide beach erosion conference.

The Sara Delano Roosevelt Memorial House--the social, religious and intercultural center for Hunter College students-- will benefit from a reception April 19 at the house at 47-49 East Sixty-fifth Street.

This was the situation on the two main fronts of the world struggle last week: Over the Far East there was anxiety and uncertainty. The Chinese Communists appeared to have left no doors open toward a diplomatic settlement in Formosa Strait.
CLEVELAND, April 2--Everybody, it seems, loves the teacher. That is, when it comes to giving her a mess of free stuff to use in the classroom.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Labor unions are getting to be the real estate agent's best friend in Washington. And the building contractor's.

HONG KONG, April 2--Communist China asserted tonight four waves of United States planes had intruded into its "territorial air" yesterday. It charged the alleged flights by formations of two to eight aircraft were "military provocations."

The peripatetic Mr. Khrushchev, who must have set some kind of travel record for a Soviet leader this past year, got to the rich blackearth farming area of Voronezh last week and made an interesting announcement. Tens of thousands of collective farm chairmen are to be removed as rogues or incompetents.

ONE of the quickest green vegetables to grow from seed is chervil, a dainty little relative of parsley. Chervil seed can be sown as early in the spring as soil can be worked, and again in late summer for fall and winter picking.

THIS has been an age in which composers have been uncommonly articulate in prose. What they write about much of the time is the crisis through which music has recently been passing. Their writings, according to Henry Pleasants, seal their own doom.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) --Their own figures show that House of Representatives appropriations experts, who have been insisting they have cut the President's budget, actually have increased it thus far.
VENICE, Italy, April 1--A considerable part of Venice is a living denial of the law of gravity.

THE arguments of those who protest today at the aggrandizement of legislative power would be more persuasive if they had cried out with equal fervor two decades ago at the growth of executive power. Alan Barth's useful and vigorous book does not explain that the inordinate expansion of legislative power in the Fifties resulted in considerable part as reaction from two decades of strong executive government.

Aided by a grant from the American Cancer Society, Dr. William H. Sweet, neurosurgeon of Harvard's School of Medicine, and Dr. Lee Farr of the Atomic Energy Commission three years ago treated a dozen dying brain-tumor patients by injecting them with boron and exposing their heads to direct rays from an atomic pile.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The state of bipartisanship in foreign affairs is fairly healthy, all things considered.
The writer of the following letter, author of "The Family Revolution in Modern China" and "The Structure of Society," is Associate Professor of Sociology at Princeton.

An increased demand for income - producing properties throughout the country is noted by the C. B. Snyder Realty Company, Inc. In reviewing its office building sales during the past year, the firm reports sixteen transactions for a total of $16,103,000.

THE structure of Foster Rhea Dulles' work, which ought to be one of the most important themes in the Harper New American Nation Series, revolves about the "great debate" between isolation and alliance throughout the history of American foreign policy, climaxed by the diplomatic revolution of our day.
ONE of the most interesting but neglected methods of fishing shows an indication of increasing greatly in popularity duing the next few months. It's float fishing.
Despite increased corporate grants, half of the colleges and universities in the nation are operating at a deficit.
Among monuments to careers it would be hard to find one less inviting than the New York money market.

At the end of last week, as William S. White wrote for this newspaper: "The President did not know and could not yet know whether he would intervene militarily if the Communists attacked Quemoy and Matsu, just off the China mainland." We believe Mr. Eisenhower is honestly puzzled.
The first Pythian teen-age center, which will accommodate between 300 and 400 youths, was dedicated yesterday in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.
BONN, Germany, April 2-- The Government's draft law to slow the recartelization of industry has received a setback.

Neptune Storage Company, Inc., whose moving vans go all over the country, will start work soon on large terminal in New Rochelle, N. Y. It has had headquarters in New Rochelle for many years and it already occupies about five buildings in different parts of the town.

DARIUS MILHAUD'S "Medee," an hour-long tragic opera he wrote in 1938, will have its United States premiere on June 11 at Waltham, Mass. It will be the major effort of the third Festival of the Creative Arts to be held by Brandeis University, from June 7 to 11.
OKLAHOMA CITY, April 2 (AP)--Louise Suggs of Georgia shot a 3-under-par 74 to increase her lead in the second round of the $5,000 Oklahoma City women's open golf tournament.

THE awards handed out Wednesday night by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences had a special significance for more than one reason. Primarily the voting by the 1,600 Academy members served to demonstrate that the size and/or depth of the curve of the screen, a current Hollywood fetish, is not a yardstock for measuring cinematic artistry.

CO-AUTHOR of "Seeds of Treason" and author of "Spies, Dupes, and Diplomats," Ralph de Toledano has now written a novel on the themes that occupied him in those books --Communist espionage and the struggle against it.

SOMETIMES a writer is able to conceive a theme so close to the heart that, when coupled with true insight into human character, it yields a story that refuses to be banished from the mind. Such a fortunate concatenation is clearly the genesis of Miss Jameson's new novel, probably the best she has written in her long literary career.
LEXINGTON, Va., April 2 (AP) --Dr. George Hutcheson Denny, former president of two Southern universities, died here today at the age of 84.

To the Music Editor: We love and reverence the artist for the affirmation he gives to us of the dignity and beauty of humankind. This is not to say that the artist must live as the embodiment, himself, of dignity and beauty--but neither can he spit on and befoul those conceptions which above all others give meaning and value to human life.

TO THE EDITOR: I read the article "Senator George -- Monumental, Determined" (March 13), by William S. White, with amazement. Mr. White must still be living in the eighteenth century to think that men are judged and esteemed primarily for their manners, for most of his praise of Senator George is on this basis.
PORTLAND, Me., March 31-- The town meeting form of government appears to be up for review in some New England communities.
Cooperative apartments here are finding a ready market, with the demand greater than the supply, in the opinion of Harry J. Riker of Riker Co., realtors.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) --Representative Harlan Hagen said today that he was wrong in opposing the Administration's flexible farm program last year.

BONN. HAVING returned to Germany for the first time in something over fifteen years, this correspondent feels both confused and embarrassed. There is a sense of being at a loss, which is all the greater because one lived in this country for eight years before the war.

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP)--Champion Star Twilight of Clu-Mor, entry of Mrs. L. S. Gordon and her twin sister, Janet Bennett of Glenview, Ill., was named best of breed among the Yorkshire terriers at the international Kennel Club's show today.
It was goodwill day on the waterfront yesterday.

BOSTON, April 2--People in New England are acutely aware of the Far Eastern danger but have little to say about it. It is not a leading topic of conversation; letters to the papers on Formosa, Quemoy and Matsu are far behind the discussions of such local issues as rent controls in Massachusetts or a proposed gas tax increase in Maine.

BERYLLIUM-- Dr. James R. Arnold and H. Ali Al-Salih of the University of Chicago's Institute of Nuclear Studies report in Science that Beryllium 7 is born when bursts of cosmic rays from outer space transmute atoms of nitrogen and oxygen at about nine miles above the earth.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) --Edward O. Lamb, publisher and broadcaster, told a Federal Communications Commission hearing today he was the "victim of a horrible frame-up."
POCATELLO, Idaho, April 2 (AP)--Michigan State College won the National Collegiate boxing championship tonight.

Jefferson Caffery, former Ambassador to Egypt, considers that the part he played in the Anglo-Egyptian negotiations for a Suez settlement was "the most complicated" in his forty-fouryear career in the Foreign Service.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2--The United Nations reported today on its work for social welfare throughout the world in 1953 and 1954.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 2 --Residents of the Missouri Basin area are well aware of the tension in the Far East, and they are confused about what is supposed to be taking place there.

April is the year at its adolescent turn. April is a girl with a handful of flowers in her hair and stars in her eyes and love and laughter in her heart. April wears a party dress and an Easter bonnet--but she also wears rubbers and a raincoat, or keeps them close at hand.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 2-- A Dutch dike engineer took a two-month look last summer at a problem with which the San Francisco Bay area has been grappling for seventy-five years.
PROVIDENCE, April 2-- Rhode Island is planning a $1,330,000 new beach and beach improvement program for its coastal area between Narragansett Pier and Watch Hill.

Thousands of American students are today learning practical economics. Guided by teachers who have participated in workshops for economic education, these pupils of elementary and high school grades often conduct laboratory experiments in economic problems of communities and industries.

Reunion in Vienna? Chancellor Raab of Austria, on his visit to Moscow next week, will suggest to the Russians, a Vienna dispatch reports, that the muchdiscussed meeting of the Big Four Powers be held in Vienna.

TOKYO, April 2--The Japanese Government has decided to send Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu to Washington to "explain Japan's position" on various issues. This move, announced today, apparently caught the United States at a diplomatic disadvantage.
LONDON, April 2 -- Clement R. Attlee must remain Labor's "undisputed and unchallenged leader," Anthony Greenwood, left-wing Laborite Member of Parliament declared today.

Housing tracts in the Stamford area of Connecticut have been purchased by builders for early development. The activity is part of building work that has been carried on at a high level during the past five years in lower Fairfield County.

A little noticed but fundamental step in seeking answers to the increasing problem of juvenile delinquency occurred last Friday when the United States Children's Bureau fully activated its new Juvenile Delinquency Service.

IT is significant that Max Eastman's indictment of socialism begins with an autobiographical chapter, for his whole life has been an involvement with the Socialist idea, and compared with him most of the Left sympathizers during the Thirties were mere Johnnycome-latelies.

HAVING released, not long ago, Fidelio in a recording by Arturo Toscanini, the N. B. C. Symphony and some excellent soloists, Victor now adds to its catalogue still another version of Beethoven's only opera.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 27 --Archbishop Athenagoras, spiritual leader of Orthodox Christendom, reported today that organized religious activity in the Soviet Union was reviving rapidly.

TO THE EDITOR: I am shocked, as must be many other Chillicotheans past and present, that so erudite a writer as Stanley Walker would omit Chillicothe (Ohio, not Illinois, Kansas, etc.) from his list of cities that have provoked laughs over the years.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., April 2--Two men were killed and thirty-three other guests fled in their night clothes when fire wrecked the Ansonia Hotel early today.

MOSCOW, April 2 -- While foreign commentators have been busily speculating this week on the prospects for great-power negotiations, the newspapers of Moscow have been conspicuously taciturn on that subject.

--should be addressed to the Queries Editor. Inquiries must contain the name and address to the writer on the page with the query. All queries must be accompanied by postage. The Editor will publish those that seem to have the greatest general interest. Others are answered by letter.
ONE of the best investments a homeowner could possibly make is in a good straight ladder for outdoor use and a well-made folding step-ladder for indoor work.

THERE is a man in New York, long and intimately connected with do-it-yourself activities, who ventures the opinion that "there are as many electric drills in households nowadays as there are electric mixers for kitchens--maybe more."

At Amityville High School yesterday Dr. Melvin Northrup, a 47-year-old wrestler, won his fourth National Amateur Athletic Union title. Dr. Northrup wrestles because he has to--and he's a bit afraid of retiring.

THE drive to Jones Beach should be a nicer one this year, now that a two-year improvement program on Long Island parkways is nearing completion. In former days roads leading to the popular seaside playground were often jammed by bumper-to-bumper traffic moving at snail's pace.

NETWORK television coverage of the Easter Parade on Fifth Avenue has dwindled in the last two years and next Sunday it will be still less. So far no network has scheduled a single Easter program devoted wholly to Fifth Avenue crowds.
CHICAGO, April 2--Adlai E. Stevenson will decide in the next several days whether to go before the nation to express his views on the Formosa crisis.

AT 9 o'clock on the morning of Dec. 10, 1945, a housemaid let herself into the Chicago apartment of Frances Brown, 30, an office worker and former Wave. On an unmade bed, the maid noticed a bloody pillow.

WASHINGTON, April 2-- Harold E. Stassen said today he was determined to prevent a repetition of what he termed "Nazi and Communist" types of interrogations by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- The summary dismissal of teachers who refuse to answer questions about Communist affiliations was assailed today by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins.

There is no pre-Easter lull in the local art galleries this season. Group and one-man shows, by European and American artists, well known and less familiar, make up a wide variety of attractions to open this week.

ATHENS, April 2 (Reuters)-- Greece announced today plans to again seek United Nations action on the Cyprus dispute. Cyprus was swept yesterday by a new wave of violence against British colonial authorities.

WITH the advent of spring house plants seem to take a new lease on life. The longer days and stronger sunshine mean more growth and flowers, providing the indoor gardener with as colorful a display in the house as the outdoor gardener will have this summer.
VIENNA, April 2--On April 11 Austria's Chancellor will climb into a Soviet airplane on the Soviet flying field in Voeslau and fly to Moscow to seek a peace treaty for his country.
A LEVER - ACTION nail driver saves fingers while driving small nails and brads into tight places. A magnetized nozzle holds the nail and pressure on the handle of the "Rammer-Hammer" drives it.

Financing has been arranged by the Northern New Jersey Mortgages Associates for the 105-family Mayfair Acres development on Snyder Avenue in Ramsey, N. J. The ranch-styled buildings with three bedrooms are in the $15,990 price class.
NEW DELHI, India, April 2-- A threat by Jawaharlal Nehru today to resign as Prime Minister of India killed a bill to ban slaughter of cows.

More than 5,000 chemists and chemical engineers met last week in Cincinnati, Ohio, to discuss such widely different subjects as the effects of radioactive fall-out on rivers and lakes, respiratory protective devices to be used in civil defense and progress in the biochemical study of cancer.

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 2-- Tony Trabert, playing some of the finest tennis of his career, advanced to the final of the Puerto Rican invitation tennis tournament today. He defeated Herbie Flam of Pasadena, Calif., 4--6, 6--4, 6--3, 6--2.
The Great Lakes-Europe trade, now celebrating its twentieth anniversary, will be maintained by a record fleet of eighty-five shallow-draft vessels, or eleven more than during the 1954 season.

POSTMASTER GENERAL ARTHUR E. SUMMERFIELD hasn't had much time lately, what with considering wage increases for postal employes and a 4-cent first-class letter rate, to devote to strictly philatelic questions, such as what collectors can expect in the way of new stamps.

THOUGH every conquest of China begins by gaining control of great cities and the most important links of communication, it must ultimately consolidate itself by reaching out into the towns and villages, for China remains primarily an agricultural society; and the conquerors' final success or failure will in the end depend upon what happens in the minds of the rural populace.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The disturbing things about American political life these days is not so much that our officials do bad things but that they do good things so badly.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 2 (AP)-- An effort to reward Texas' war veterans has exploded as the state's biggest scandal since impeachment of Gov. James E. Ferguson in 1917.
After nearly a century of service to seamen, the old Navesink lighthouse off Sandy Hook, N. J., will give aid to airmen before the beacon goes into retirement.
The year 1954 was a poor one for the shipbuilding and ship repair industry, according to last week's annual report of the Sun Oil Company, parent concern of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

TO THE EDITOR: May I add a bit to the debate stirred by your recent debate on modern music-- "Modern Music: 'A Dead Art' " by Henry Pleasants and "Modern Music: 'Fresh and Different' " by Aaron Copland (March 13) ?
WASHINGTON, April 2-- March weather lived up to its traditional billing as tempestuous and inconsiderate.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently your special correspondent, Charles Grutzner, reported from Cleveland on the discussions of the National Conference on Solicitations. The principal item in this report was a warning that the American public is growing confused by the increasing number of appeals from charitable organizations.
The decision of President Peron of Argentina to permit foreign private capital to help develop the oil resources of his country is considered of farreaching importance to that nation's economy.

IF a hand-operated lawn mower is well built and is used with reasonable care it should be in fighting trim for several years between sharpenings, and should last as long as the strength of the man pushing it. To be certain that the machine can give such service, it would be well to look it over before it is put into weekly use this month.

IF the New York Philharmonic Symphony had not had the Westminster Choir College's Symphonic Choir at its disposal in the last decade and a half, it might have had to go out and invent something like it.
The military and political initiative along the China coast was still in the hands of Peiping last week.

LAST week Oswald Jacoby and Alfred Sheinwold won the pair tournament in the Eastern championships. Usually a winner has a stock of good results to report. The only Jacoby hands available were bad results.

ATHOUGH he already has two film projects on tap, Elia Kazan apparently is not the man to ignore another attractive property. Kazan, now wallowing in new laurels for "On the Waterfront" and Broadway's "Cat On a Hot Tin Roof," revealed that he was "highly interested" in "The Woman in the Suwanee Jail," a book by William Bradford Huie that Duell Sloane Pearce and Little, Brown have scheduled for publication in the fall.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 2 (AP) -- Adios Harry, the 1954 Little Brown Jug winner, won his 1955 debut tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. He posted an amazing early-season clocking of 2:01 4/5 in taking the $7,500 Westbury open class pace.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Finish dormant spraying of fruit and shade trees. Some vines such as euonymus and bittersweet and shrubs such as lilac require a dormant treatment for scale insects. Just before leaves unfold, spray elm trees with DDT to control elm leaf beetles which are the carriers of the Dutch elm disease.

ALBANY, April 2--The $600,000,000 traffic relief program for the New York metropolitan area won the approval of the Legislature tonight. The program was advanced by the Port of New York Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority with the approval of New York City.
The main Hearn Department Store on Fourteenth Street will close next Saturday at 6 P. M., Clement V. Conole, its president, said yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, April 2--A twenty-six-acre harbor site has been approved by the United States Department of Agriculture for a $2,000,000 wholesale fruit and vegetable market to serve south-central Connecticut. A report of the marketing research division of the Federal agency holds the filled-in land along the west side of the harbor is "geographically and financially sound" for the site.

TOMORROW night Pierre Monteux, on the occasion of his eightieth birthday, will conduct in Symphony Hall the major part of the program of the Pension Fund of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. The orchestra is one with which he has special ties, lasting from the five years of his directorship of that body from 1919 to 1924, and the many "guest" appearances he has made since and will make again as its leader.

A young "ambassador" from Hamburg, Germany, to Hamburg, N. Y., full of ideas about international friendship, was touring New York last week. After an early look around, 19year-old Gerhard Scheuer was vocal about his admiration for the metropolis.

As well-ordered in the pageant of spring as the blossoming of flowers and the leafing of trees is the return of the birds from the south. For in spite of unseasonable heat or cold and any delays of inclement weather, the birds adhere to a flying timetable, arriving on schedule in woodland, field and garden.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., April 2-- Hope for more financial aid from business and industry to American colleges, half of which are operating "in the red," came today from a conference of fiftysix business leaders.

THE increasing use of school buses throughout New York State has created traffic complexities and added to the potential of accidents for motorists, according to Lester B. Krick, assistant superintendent of operation and maintenance of the state's Department of Public Works.
Maj. Gen. George A. Wingate, retired officer in the New York National Guard and Surrogate of Brooklyn, died last night at his home, 200 Hicks Street, Brooklyn. He was 84 years of age.
VIENNA, April 2 (AP)--The Austrian police said today Russion soldiers had dragged four Hungarian refugees, three of them injured, from an Austrian hospital and carried them back to Hungary.
Premier Mario Scelba of Italy yesterday linked the western world's universities and Catholicism as major bulwarks against the spread of international communism.

Boston Doge did it again. Paul Andolino's undefeated dark bay colt won his ninth race in a row yesterday, making a show of his nine 3-year-old rivals in the $22,000 Experimental Handicap at Jamaica. A crowd of 39,572 cheered him.

WHITE PLAINS--The delights of Westchester County's woodland areas are this spring more accessible to hikers than ever. Scenic trails have been extended, picnic facilities have been improved, new wells have been dug and a new wildlife reservation, the Mianus Gorge Preserve, has been established.

IN "The Emerald Crown" Theodora McCormick (a whodunit writer under the name of Theodora DuBois) pushes through the mists of an almost legendary period. On the Continent Charlemagne had died in 814 A. D., in England Alfred the Great was still alive and kicking as the curtain rises.
The current tentative inquiry of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee into maritime labor-management relations may develop into one of the most important in the field of shipping.

The Latin-American coffeeproducing countries are trying to increase United States appreciation of a good cup of coffee. The growers reason that if the consumer drinks the "perfect" cup of coffee, he will drink more cups than he does now.
ATLANTIC CITY--De Jur Ansco exhibited lowpriced equipment in both the movie and the stillcamera field at last week's meeting here of the Master Photo Dealers' and Finishers' Association.
GIBRALTAR. A large-scale public works program to improve Gibraltar's port facilities and stimulate trade is being considered by the British Government.
ALBANY, April 2--More than thirty-five persons were injured early tonight when a crack New York Central passenger train slammed into a rockslide about fifteen miles south of here.

INCOME-TAX time has a way of bringing out the beast in a man. Rigidly respectable citizens suddenly fly into righteous rage when they start subtracting line 12 from line 6, 7 (c) or 8, whichever is least. This year the situation is even worse than usual because of the complexities of the new tax law, and the fact that the April 15 deadline gives taxpayers an extra month to brood about the whole baleful business.

IN this unpretentious volume Charles Munch, distinguished conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, sets forth at least a portion of his credo. Written with high sentiment, "I Am a Conductor" describes in capsule form some of Mr. Munch's musical experiences, his rise to fame as a conductor and his views on the delicate relationship between the conductor, the musician and the world of high art in which he functions.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Eisenhower accepted "with regret" today the resignation of Samuel W. Anderson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs.

FOR the amateur or expert ornithologist who would like a brief but general picture --one is tempted to say a bird's eye view--of all the knowledge of all the birds of all the world, this beautifully illustrated volume will provide much information and pleasure in its 200 fact-crammed pages.
For Ages 12 to 16. ALTHOUGH its title suggests a routine teen-age romance, this junior novel offers something more to girls who are pondering the questions of going steady and early marriage.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 2-- The Vietnamese Government is preparing a document in which French representatives here will be blamed for the failure to wipe out the gangster Binh Xuyen group.
Fourteen Protestant church leaders urged President Eisenhower yesterday to "stop the current drift toward atomic war."

BONN, April 2--The first German contingent of volunteer junior officers will be assembled at the Sonthofen training grounds in the Bavarian Alps within six months. The exact date will depend on the deposition of the instruments of ratification of the Paris agreements by the signatory powers.

A soft spring day drew thousands of New Yorkers into the country yesterday, while suburbanites toiled in their gardens. This was the beginning of what promised to be a pleasant weekend, the first mild and dry one in more than a month.

NEW ORLEANS, LOUISIANA, for many residents of the rest of the Union, is a state of mind called New Orleans, a magnolia-enveloped construction of iron grillwork before which passes a constant succession of Mardi Gras parades.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., April 2 --Representatives of Japan won three titles tonight as the sixtyfifth national Amateur Athletic Union free-style wrestling championship tournament came to a close at Amityville Memorial High School.
Ranch and Cape Cod houses vie with the split-level design in models being opened this week-end by builders on Long Island.

SALT LAKE CITY. AFTER a strange and tortured history, Utah's Mormons are giving abundant evidence that they have fulfilled and even surpassed the prediction of Mormon Prophet Joseph Smith that they would become "a mighty people in the midst of the Rocky Mountains."
Hand-carved frames and frame moldings by the dean of the master wood carvers, Maurice Grieve, will be auctioned or Tuesday in a sale of the stock of M. Grieve Company, Inc.

RETAILERS' prayers for warmer weather have apparently been heeded. Sales for the key week before Easter should show substantial improvement in areas that have been plagued by cold, snow and rain. On the whole, despite the weather, Easter business has been running almost 10 per cent ahead of a year ago.
The storm created by the State Department's release of the Yalta papers three weeks ago was still blowing strong last week.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 2-- This region's attitude toward war or peace in the Far East appears to be divided roughly three ways.

CLEVELAND, April 2 (AP)-- Attorneys for Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, appealing his seconddegree murder conviction, told Appeals Court today that his pregnant wife Marilyn was hacked to death in a sex attack.

"MOST of the talk was about Chaucer and Thomas Becket. I have nothing against either one. It's just that I feel more at home with Roy Campanella and Yogi Berra. Chaucer and I had a falling-out in English II at James Monroe High.

TWO men entering the Allegheny coal town of Canona, presumably in West Virginia, make an impact on its social life. The first to appear is Hamilton Sacks, engaged as a professional director by the ambitious Canona Thespians.

AT first sight it may seem unlikely that there is any connection between Swarthmore College's junior varsity soccer team of 1937-38 and the present rulers in the Kremlin. There is such a connection, however, for a former member of that team, Oleg A. Troyanovsky, is now the favorite interpreter of Khrushchev, Molotov and company when they meet with English-speaking visitors.

The Department of Languages at Lafayette College is planning to introduce new methods of teaching modern languages. Dr. W. Edward Brown, chairman of the department, said that the achievements in the new language techniques were so solid and so spectacular that there seemed no question but that any successful language teacher must be aware of these changes.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The Government's chief mediator is planning on lots of hard work this year.
Squadron A gained the final round of the Eastern 12-goal indoor polo championship last night at the Squadron A armory.

SINGAPORE, Sunday, April 3 --Two left-wing parties gained a slight lead over the conservative factions in the elections held under Singapore's new constitution yesterday. For the first time the voters selected a majority of the members of a legislative assembly.

TO THE EDITOR: Barbara Ward's "It Is Not Down the Drain" (March 13) [in which she challenged the wisdom of those who would smother economic aid to Asia --or do away with it altogether --Editor] argued that the people of this country may be far more in sympathy with foreign aid than our politicians realize.
STUTTGART, Germany, April 2 (AP)--The Stuttgarter Zeitung said today that the assignment of Gen. Christian de Castries of France to West Germany had caused alarm and indignation.

CHICAGO, April 2--The Yalta story continued this week to hold more public attention in the Middle West than the explosive Formosa question. Although Midwesterners through the columns of their newspapers were well versed in the controversies in Washington swirling around Formosa and the off-shore islands, letters to the editors and conversation remained centered on Yalta.

IN past years after delving into seed catalogues, I thought I should try everything. And since a vegetable garden is our family pride, that meant everything from radishes to cauliflower. Believe me, it's easy enough to plant the seeds, but to take care of the plants and the weeding is another matter.

HONG KONG. WITH the forbidding-- and forbidden--mountains of Red China at their backs, cloud banks threatening and sometimes charging from the sea, William Holden, Jennifer Jones, and a troupe of thirty other Hollywood actors and technicians recorded here on film the rising emotional temperatures of two lovers separated by custom and conscience.
Two weeks from next Friday, Louis E. Wolfson, 43-year-old Florida industrialist, will attempt to wrest control of Montgomery Ward Co. from its 81year-old chairman, Sewell Avery.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 2 --Former President Truman said today that the Eisenhower Administration should "stop making blunderers and traitors out of their predecessors and get on with planning for the national welfare."

THE tourist brings back from Florida a great number of vivid impressions, all calculated to be much more lasting than a fast-fading suntan. Having seen all thirteen teams and having talked to all thirteen managers in the Sunshine State, he finds his ideas taking shape, even though some skippers offer opposite views on the same subject.

AMONG the April-sown annuals that will brighten the summer border, few are more rewarding than nicotiana or flowering tobacco. A relative of the smoking tobacco (N. tabacum), this longstemmed native of the forests of Brazil is of no commercial value, but it is prized by gardeners in the North for ease of culture, profusion of bloom and especially the dusk-to-dawn witchery of its perfumed flowers.

THE wide dramatic statement of this novel is that twentieth-century man is a violent and self - destructive beast. More narrowly it concerns the flight of a neurotic Jewish intellectual from a society to which he cannot adjust and of his eventual destruction by the sadistic ItalianAmerican foreman of a construction crew on a volcanic rock in the Aleutians.
PALM BEACH, April 2-- Mechanized American farms cannot operate under a program of curtailed acreage and high support prices, Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, declared here today.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP)-- The nation's entire Army and Air National Guards, 398,000 strong, soon will be mobilized in a one-day surprise "alert" to test their combat readiness.

ATLANTIC CITY --American manufacturers and importers of German and Japanese photographic equipment and accessories presented a product show here last week that was notable for its variety, range and ingenuity, and the fact that it defined consumer trends as few shows have done before.
A flip of a coin brought Frank H. James into the men's hat industry.
MOSCOW, March 21 -- They say in Moscow that it has not yet been decided whether the Soviet Union will take part in the next Olympic Games in Australia. However, the Russians will be ready in '56.
HARTFORD, April 2 -- The Joint Finance Committee of the General Assembly began consideration this week of proposals to balance the state budget for the biennium beginning July 1.

LAST month's Roundup mentioned that the Rocky Mountains did not always mark the frontier of the West, that Kentucky was once known as the "Western Country" and that in 1800 the Mississippi was far West indeed.

All segments of the nation's highly competitive masonry industry have joined hands and formed the Allied Masonry Council to deal with its interrelated problems, which are mainly concerned with improving working techniques and cutting costs.

IN the nineteenth century music lovers had a hearty appetite for religious choral works. And their taste ran to works that were long, massive and dramatic. The composers of the century were not slow to furnish such works.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 2-- What the typical Southerner would like to know is: Where does the United States stand in the matter of defending the islands of Quemoy and Matsu?

SALT LAKE CITY, April 2-- While the Far-Eastern situation has not replaced the weather, crops or uranium as this region's chief topic of discussion, there is widespread public and press concern about the possibility of a Far Eastern war--and marked evidence of fatalism and resignation concerning the inevitability of such a war that is unusual in this usually optimistic region.

WITH the publication or this large, handsomely printed volume, American scholarship begins to correct an oversight which has been astonishing. This volume launches the world's first illustrated and scholarly catalogue of a major public collection of Japanese prints.

LAST August some 400 persons met in Washington, D. C., under the auspices of the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies, to exchange information and ideas about contemporary Africa.

MOSCOW has changed its mind about its dream of over-towering New York. From his pinnacle of power in the low-storied Kremlin, Nikita Khrushchev, Secretary of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party, has pronounced against skyscrapers.

To the Screen Editor: May I comment on your column dealing with "Blackboard Jungle," a movie and a book that have particularly concerned me because I used much the same material for a novel of my own, "The Invisible Island," published by Viking in 1948.

CLEVELAND, April 2 (AP)-- Dick Gonzales, 26-year-old Los Angeles ace, won the professional tennis championship tournament at the Cleveland Arena for the third straight year tonight. He defeated Francisco (Pancho) Segura, the Ecuadorian Mite, 21--16, 19--21, 21--8, 20--22, 21--19.

ALBANY, April 2 (AP)--Following is the list of injured persons taken to Albany Memorial Hospital here or Columbia Memorial Hospital in near-by Hudson: ADAMS, William H., 210 West 140th Street, New York.

DALLAS, April 2--Just eighteen years ago Bill Klem, one of the game's great umpires, on getting his first glimpse of Bob Feller in a Giant-Indian exhibition in Vicksburg, Miss., exclaimed: "the greatest bit of pitching in the raw I ever saw."

THE calendar we use dates from the time of Julius Caesar. Some changes were made by Pope Gregory XIII in 1583. Nevertheless, the calendar remains virtually the only object in daily use which has not changed in 2,000 years.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission today confirmed a hearing examiner's order requiring the New York coffee exchanges to halt the use of "restrictive contracts" in the buying and selling of coffee for future delivery.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 2--The burgeoning suburbs are moving slowly but relentlessly toward correcting a hodgepodge of zoning.
WASHINGTON, April 2--The resolution expressing the opposition of Congress to the use of United States forces in the defense of Quemoy and Matsu seemed today to be headed for defeat.

Denmark THE other day we ran into the youthful director of one of Denmark's largest publishing houses and we got an earful. Otto B. Lenhardt is the director and Gyldendal is the firm, and if it weren't for some complicated notions we have about the different shapes of different societies, we'd be suffering right now with inferiority complex.

TAIPEI, Formosa, April 2-- There are numerous indications here of growing distrust and suspicion of the United States. They are based mainly on the fear that Washington is quietly plotting two campaigns, both of which are bitterly opposed by the Chinese Nationalist Government.

MOSCOW, April 2--Moscow has not reconciled itself to the Paris agreements for the arming of West Germany. According to authoritative statements published here today, it still thinks it possible to prevent implementation.

The amateur Savoyards of the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd., have little spare time on their hands these days. They are rapidly putting into shape their production of "Utopia, Ltd.," which will be presented from April 13 through April 16 in the Hunter College Playhouse.
The two antagonists in the battle for control of Montgomery Ward have been making some unusual labor news of late.
The Ballet Theatre Foundation will be the beneficiary of the opening of the Ballet Theatre's fifteenth anniversary season on the night of April 12 at the Metropolitan Opera House.
The stock market coasted during most of last week and ended the period with only minor price changes on the average.

MANILA. The busiest Government office in all the Philippines is found in one corner of the ground floor of the Presidential Palace of Malacanan. Here are the constant jangle of telephones, the chatter of Teletype machines and the bustle of people rushing in and out of doors that never seem to stop swinging.

THE National Ballet of Canada from Toronto paid us a brief visit a week or so ago over at the Brooklyn Academy and showed itself to be a very creditable young organization. In a mere two performances it could not possibly show all its dancers to their best advantage or all its repertoire, but presumably what it did show was a representative cross-section.
The writer of the following letter is a member of the House of Representatives from California.
CAIRO, April 2 (AP)--A spokesman for the Yemen Legation here said the Imam had abdicated for "health reasons."
Young people have "the moral right to demand a new look" at the problem of the abolition of war, Rabbi Israel Goldstein declared yesterday.

Murray Hill gets another apartment development under plans announced yesterday. Excavation work has been started at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street for a twenty-story building to house 226 families.
TRENTON, April 2--The Republicancontrolled State Legislature reconvenes here Monday for its last session prior to the April 19 primary election.
Tangier, the boom city of yesteryear, is now a building contractor's nightmare.

April and May theatre parties have been planned for the benefit of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. The 103year-old institution recently established a program to give more intensive and thorough therapeutic treatment to emotionally disturbed and severely injured boys.

PARIS, April 2--Premier Faure's interview with Pravda, published today, was a French effort to sound out Moscow about a four-power conference. Pravda's comment indicated that Moscow still hoped to block German rearmament, possibly by proposing the neutralization of Germany.

MADRID. STUDENT Prince Juan Carlos of Bourbon has just as much trouble in finding the square root of whole and fractional numbers as the next boy. For him however, there may be a kingdom in it. The consensus is that he is being groomed by Premier Francisco Franco as the next King of Spain.

On Easter Sunday many socially prominent New Yorkers will attend luncheons, fashion shows and tea dances, planned for the hours following church services. Patronage of these Easter day events will assist many organizations active in charity work.
COLUMBIA, S. C., April 2 (UP) --The Cincinnati Redlegs and the Washington Senators played a 3-3 tie today in a game stopped by rain and wet grounds after seven innings.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 2 --The skippers who delight in sailing dinghies all winter long at Larchmont Yacht Club tried something different today. The idea was to find out who was the best sailor, regardless of who had the fastest boat.
A five-year study of educational administration has developed improved methods of training school superintendents and principals.

KIM STANLEY, who set some sort of precedent by demoting herself from the stardom she had attained earlier this season in "The Traveling Lady" to featured billing in "Bus Stop," is a prey to perfectionism.

WHEN the circus returned to television last week after a seven-year absence, it provided an hour of lively entertainment. It also showed that there is a new philosophy toward video on the part of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey entrepreneurs.
The Communist Governments of Eastern Europe are following the Soviet Union's lead in ordering a shift to corn-and-hog farming as a means of trying to solve their agricultural difficulties.
The housing boom, credited with a hero's role in reversing last-year's "mild recession," is rapidly becoming a villain in the eyes of insurance executives.
AUSTIN, Tex., April 2--Wes Santee set an American record for the mile at the Texas Relays today, but lacked half a second of his ambition--a four-minute mile.
LONDON, April 2--A Londoner who stopped at his news agents Wednesday to pick up a reserved copy of the Manchester Guardian was informed that his wife had just collected it.

HELSINKI--That Finland has the capacity to receive visitors, even exacting ones, was amply proved during the summer of the Olympic Games in 1952. Since then it has continued to expand and improve its tourist facilities.

FOR many years the seasonal displays in the Channel Gardens at Rockefeller Center have been an oasis of bloom and fragrance in the heart of the concrete canyon known as Manhattan. Located in midtown's hustling network of offices on Fifth Avenue between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, these parallel planting beds, though small in area, have offered pleasure and joy to thousands throughout the day.

TOO many gardeners wait for the displays of the fruit trees and the daffodils late in April to begin to enjoy spring and its flowers. This unduly prolongs winter. The early bulbs are now flowering in many gardens, so right now is the time to look around and make plans to put in some of these small bulbs next fall.

THIS is an excellent example of a kind of travel literature a wise tourist takes with him on plane or ship--or, if he is wiser still, reads at home before he starts. The formula includes a bit of history, a description of the selected spot or area as it is today, and a few pointers as to what to see, how to see it and how much it will cost.
"Dancing takes a lot of time -- and space. Since most of our ideas for new dance routines occur away from the studio, generally at home, Marge and I work them out and rehearse them there, too.
Pension improvements have not ended the reluctance of many workers to retire when expected to do so. The persistence of this attitude is raising new problems for pension planners.

MOST frontier heroes get something named after them--a mountain, a river, a fort--and their names are ever after on the tongues of the people. Gen. Randolph B. Marcy was not so fortunate. And yet his explorations and discoveries rank with those of Pike, Long, Fremont and were every bit as important to the development of our nation.

A FEW days ago I was asked what, in my estimation, is "the most fascinating word or phrase in the English language," and, if possible, to state the reasons for my choice. Although my correspondent did not mention the purpose of his query, I suspect he has in mind a compilation of the answers he receives.

Manhattan families who need and can afford large suites are being neglected by some apartment house builders, according to Martin Fisher of Fisher Brothers. His company is putting up a twenty-story structure at 50 Sutton Place South which features seven-room units.

For years yachtsmen have been known as a strange and wondrous breed of extroverts. They love to garb themselves in jaunty caps and double-breasted sea-going uniforms. They love to wear gold insignia including stars that mean different things in different yachting bodies, fouled anchors, tridents and other mystifying emblems that are usually unknown to landlubbers.
Sheller L. Steinwender has been named vice president of the Permutit Company, water conditioning specialists.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP)-- Democrats in Congress opened a new drive today against the Dixon-Yates power contract.

THE native qualities of British art, its poetry; its association of a view with a thought and of a thought with a sentiment; its refusal to follow theory to a sublime dead end, transgress the stringent intellectualism of much advanced twentieth century painting and sculpture.

SOME of the more combustible pro-Arab contributions to the heated literature on contemporary Israel have been made by non-Jewish writers with missionary or theological influences in their personal backgrounds. Canadian-born William Lovell Hull, director of a Bible mission in Jerusalem for the past twenty years and still on the job, is at least as positive--but with a totally opposite bias.

MANILA, Sunday, April 3 (UP) --President Ramon Magsaysay today called an emergency Cabinet meeting to plan relief and rehabilitation, work in the Mindanao earthquake disaster area in the southern Philippines as the death toll mounted toward the 400 mark.

For half a century adventurous men have sailed southward to the world of ice and snow beyond Australia, Africa and South America. They have set forth to explore that region with dogteams, with ponies from Siberia, Manchuria and Mongolia, with captive balloons, motorized sleds, a "snowmobile" and finally the airplane.

THE small stature of rock plants makes new additions possible without a general reorientation of the area given over to this type of garden. And often charm and interest are contributed in the way of unusual different species or a new variety of an old favorite.

ENGLISHMEN who have not attended Eton have a story about old-school-tie types who have. When one of these, the story goes, is notified that his wife has home a son, his fatherly behavior is easily predictable. He will dash off a letter to the registrar entering his young heir for admission some ten or twelve years hence.

The 1955 session of the New York State Legislature has been dominated by maneuvering for political advantage between Averell Harriman, the state's first Democratic governor in twelve years, and the leaders of the G. O. P.-controlled Legislature.
WASHINGTON, April 2 US)-- A three-judge appeals court voted 2 to 1 today to permit a hearing involving control of the Boston and Maine Railroad.
FRESNO, Calif., April 2 (UP) --Long Lon Spurrier, the star who broke the world record for the half mile a week ago, was hampered by gusty winds today.

SYRACUSE, April 2--The Syracuse Nationals, aided by Dolph Schayes' last-period spurt, made it two straight over the Fort Wayne Pistons today in the National Basketball Association's final playoff series.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 2-- Six Israeli soldiers were injured today when Egyptians attacked a routine patrol along the Gaza Strip armistice line, Israeli Army headquarters reported here.

ALTHOUGH they are few in number the flowering, broadleaved evergreens will create a lavish display of color in the spring garden. Basically the group consists of rhododendron, laurel, azalea and pieris.

PARIS THE death of Matisse has been an immense loss to the world, as if a light had been extinguished. He was more than a great painter: he was an intellectual force. Such force can be expressed in form as well as in words.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 2 --The director of the Poliomyelitis Vaccine Evaluation Center here said today it had not reported on the effectiveness of the Salk vaccine.
GUATEMALA, April 2--Guatemala had one of her best foreign trade years last year in spite of the political difficulties and social unrest ending in last June's anti-Communist revolution.
CHATTANOOGA, April 2-- Walt (Smokey) Alston the Dodgers' manager, has "a pretty good idea" what his opening line-up of the season will be, but he "ain't talkin'."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 1--Swedes have been deeply shaken by the Finance Ministry project to "dry up" some of $250,000,000 of their purchasing power by compulsory saving. The Ministry would freeze private and corporation earnings for three and a half years, beginning in the middle of this year.

The great library systems of the metropolitan areas of the United States are abundant sources of liberal arts and technical knowledge. Their resources are at the disposal of rich and poor, young and old, scholarly and unlettered. The material the libraries provide is so great that the average urbanite forgets that all communities are not favored with similar services.

ATLANTIC CITY--Items of miscellaneous news were seen in remarkable abundance at last week's photographic convention and trade show here. Kling displayed a $69.50 underwater photoelectric exposure meter, a projector for Minox camera slides, and announced that Kodak Tri-X film would be available in Minox fifty-exposure loads.

HONG KONG, April 2--Before the Chinese Communists turned them into fat black headline terms, Quemoy and Matsu islands were pretty much complete blanks so far as most Westerners were concerned. Few had ever heard of them and fewer still knew where they were.

PARIS, April 2--Wage increases and accompanying measures were announced today by the Government. The plan will be submitted to the union boards next week. The government of Premier Edgar Faure will seek in the next few weeks to keep the wage situation from becoming a prelude to a wave of strikes.

THE helicopter has become a familiar sight in recent years, especially since proving itself in the Korean War and going into mass production. Yet there are comparatively few people outside the helicopter field who have any clear idea how the plane is flown.
ALBANY, April 2--The Legislature adjourned for the year tonight.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 2 --Ford Konno, a 22-year-old Hawaiian, added another swimming title to his list tonight.
Scoring an unearned run in the eighth inning, Manhattan College's baseball team topped Columbia, 6 to 5, at Baker Field yesterday.
PRE-RECORDED tapes continue to appear on the market--in limited quantity. Tape-recording and play-back equipment are a pleasant adjunct to a high-fidelity system, but they also run up the cost.

WASHINGTON, April 2--Congress heads for a ten-day Easter holiday unwearied by the leisurely pace it has set itself so far in this session, and unpressured by the demands of the schedule that awaits its return.

WASHINGTON, April 2--The Army asked the Defense Department today to make available to the press official documents bearing on the Soviet Union's belated entry into the war against Japan. Defense officials, however, put off their decision until next week.

IN the three years since they were first opened to the public, the Ida Cason Callaway Gardens have established themselves as one of the major tourist sights of the South. The gardens, two miles below Chipley, Ga., on U. S. 27, cover approximately 2,500 acres and contain in addition to flower trails and scenic drives facilities for boating, fishing, golfing, picnicking and swimming in season.
WILMINGTON, N. C., April 2 (AP)--Billy Maxwell clung shakily to his one-stroke Azalea open golf tournament lead after fiftyfour holes today, despite a threebogey finish.

BOWIE, Md., April 2 (AP)-- Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Joe Jones, capably ridden by Conn McCreary, crossed the winning line two lengths in advance of six rivals today in capturing the thirty-eighth Bowie Handicap before 21,336 racing fans.

WASHINGTON--If going through historic old houses is the aim of a trip to Washington, Saturday, April 16, is the time to take it. On that day four famous houses built in the early Eighteen Hundreds, all of them hitherto barred to the public, will be opened as a benefit for the National Trust for Historic Preservation, a private foundation set up to preserve historic sites.

DALLAS, April 2--Department store sales during the first three weeks of March took a "more than usual upturn" after having held about normal through late February, the Federal Reserve Bank reported Thursday in its monthly summary of business conditions in the Eleventh District.
Following are excerpts from comments on some of the shows reviewed in The Times during the week just closed. A full list of shows opening this week appears in the news section today.
AN American family tour of France -- when the boys are 3 1/2 and 7, respectively -- is an enterprise only for the brave, the lusty and the adaptable. But once undertaken, it can be something special.

A FINE pastry cook may cock a quizzical eyebrow at an American cake mix, but whether he approves or not, it may be used as the basis for those delicious, little, decorated sweets that the French call petits fours.

JERSEY CITY, April 2 -- Charlie Hoxie of Niagara Univsity led a quintet of New York State college basketball AllStars to an 83-69 triumph over a similar squad from New Jersey tonight at the Jersey City Armory.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd is to visit Antarctica for the fifth time in November. It will be his task to carry on the preliminary work of the icebreaker Atka, which was sent to South Polar regions to locate sites for stations at which observations will be made in accordance with plans laid down for the International Geophysical Year of 195758.

CINCINNATI, April 2 (AP) -- Youthful preoccupation with television, comic books and "lurid" science fiction have contributed to creating a shortage of scientists and engineers in this country, a prominent industrialist said tonight.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 2--Hans Christian Andersen, who was reputed to be a bit vain, would have been proud and moved today. Almost a hundred countries from China to his beloved Denmark remembered and commemorated the 150th birthday of the author of fairy tales.
Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "Plain and Fancy," a musical comedy, on the night of April 19 at the Winter Garden Theatre for the benefit of the Berkshire Industrial Farm.

ELEMENTARY gardening is among the most popular subjects in many schools in Tampa, Fla. Classtime for junior gardening activities is allotted on a regular basis. The over-all project is sponsored by the Tampa Federation of Garden Club Circles, and lessons are taught by members of adult clubs assisted by classroom teachers.
The National Parking Association has called for a revision of "horse and buggy" building codes as a step toward getting the nation's parking program off the ground floor.

WITH a quantity of reading material running these days toward historical novels with bouncy heroines, to sadistic murder mysteries with glibtalking private eyes and psychiatric on-or-off-the-couch books, this off-pattern period piece comes not only as a surprise but as a refreshing change.
KATMANDU, Nepal. In the ancient cities of the Valley of Katmandu, Nepalese arts that had been stagnating for centuries are slowly coming to life anew.
BOSTON, April 2 (UP)--The Senate Committee on Government Operations is considering an investigation of Governmentoperated businesses.

TO THE EDITOR: In his excellent article arguing the need for revision of loyalty clearance procedures and adoption of a program to protect against subversion without violating basic rights --"To Make Our Security System Secure" (March 20)--Dr. Vannevar Bush does pull one punch badly.

THE basic theme of this romantic novel seems to be that courage, especially when wielded by a woman, conquers all. If ever a woman had pluck it was Lora, a doctor's daughter in a border town in the opening years of the Civil War.

THE Women's Army Corps did not get off to an easy start. Public skepticism and masculine hostility were directed at the corps during the first years of its existence. And within the Army there was a conservative element that had scarcely recovered from the shock of mechanized cavalry when it was confronted with the militarized woman.
KINGSTON, N. Y., April 2 (AP) --A petition by New York City to upset last year's reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road was rejected here today.

A new office structure is to rise in the downtown insurance district. The twenty-five-story building, to be known tas 120 William Street, will replace the offices now at 120- 126 William Street and 79-81 John Street as the result of a purchase and lease arrangement just concluded by Samuel Friedenberg and Son.
Behind the glitter of the account executive is a backstage world without which the advertising stars out front could not operate.
PARIS, April 2--A Soviet desire to block German rearmament by proposing to neutralize the nation was inferred today by experts here from comment in Pravda.

HERBS were once generally thought of as plants suited only to planting in a traditional rectangular plot or in a crisscross pattern with paths leading to a sundial. Not so today, for many gardeners have discovered, to their joy, that herbs may be combined in the perennial border, tucked away in soil pockets near the terrace for evening enjoyment, or set in a patch near the kitchen door for easy access by the cook.

TO believe life an irremediable disaster, the heavens and earth an imbecility, is to my way of thinking hard indeed. Since I am not prepared to believe the world a misery-goround, a torture-chamber, a furnace of senseless affliction; since I am not prepared to believe the fiery, invincible soul a by-blow, a lamentable accident, I prefer to put my trust in the larger vision of the poets.
MIAMI, April 2 (AP)--His doctors were dubious and so were horsemen, but Jockey Billie Thompson rejoined the winner's circle today after ten years.

ALGIERS -- French North Africa, well known for its fine winter resorts, is generally regarded as a place to stay away from during the sweltering summer months. But the traveler taking the southern route to Europe this spring or summer will be richly rewarded if he visits North Africa as part of his trip.
Recently some stockholders of the Minute Maid Corporation were startled to learn that although sales last year attained a record, profits declined sharply.

YESTERDAY (April 2, 1955) THE GOVERNOR Lunched in New York with Premier Mario Scelba of Italy. Returned to Albany by plane. Issued messages of necessity to permit passage of bills introduced or amended within the last three days.

For the first time since 1949, when the armistice agreements between Israel and the Arab states were signed, the dim hope of getting a de facto settlement in Palestine seems to be improving. This is a paradoxical development, for the latest frontier incident cost the lives of thirty-eight Egyptian soldiers in the Gaza strip, and was found to have been a premeditated attack by Israeli regulars.
Apartments are becoming more plentiful on the East Side, according to a survey by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.
Years of careful research on a disagreeable by-product of paper manufacturing are paying off handsomely in economical raw materials for a wide variety of products.

Department store sales in the United States during the week ended March 26 were 2 per cent higher than the corresponding week last year, according to the Federal Reserve Board. The rise was influenced by the fact that Easter was on April 18 last year but will be April 10 this year.

WASHINGTON, April 2-- Hundreds of people throughout the world have been writing him their ideas for peace, Harold E. Stassen, Presidential assistant charged with developing policies for disarmament, said today.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Among policy-making officials here there is on the whole less enthusiasm for the idea of a four-power conference than in other capitals. These officials recognized as early as last December, when the French National Assembly was debating the Paris accords, that once ratification was completed the clamor in Europe for one more attempt at negotiation with the Soviet Union would probably have to be heeded.

WASHINGTON, April 2--Despite a tendency to look the other way whenever the question arises, Congress is heading inevitably toward another battle over increasing the statutory limit on the national debt.

LOS ANGELES, April 2--The fightingest word in the Los Angeles civic vocabulary, UNESCO, is resounding again in a battle for control of the city's Board of Education. A showdown will come in a municipal election Tuesday.

While a strike of maintenance men kept the London press silent last week the Manchester Guardian on Thursday appeared with this headline-- SIR WINSTON WAITS FOR NEWSPAPERS This story was promptly--and authoritatively--knocked down.
LONDON, Sunday, April 3 (Reuters)--The British Conservative party said early today it had wrested two counties from Labor party control in elections yesterday.

EVER since the Stone Age, man has used the device of caricature both as a branch of artistic creation and as a weapon of invective or ridicule. But it is rare indeed that a single statesman becomes prominent so young and remains prominent for so many decades that we can study the development of caricature in a highly concentrated personal form.
WASHINGTON, April 2--By summertime, when the first of the 1955 crops begin climbing out of the soil, the Government will have at least $8,500,000,000 invested in supporting farm prices.

IN "Run Silent, Run Deep," the silent service is heard from. This beautifully titled novel is by Comdr. Edward L. Beach, who participated in ten consecutive submarine patrols against the Japanese merchant marine during the war and is now Naval Aide to President Eisenhower.
WITH the production of "Cat On a Hot Tin Roof," Tennessee Williams has completed his first decade on Broadway. "The Glass Menagerie" introduced his unique talents to New York on March 31, 1945.

THIS book of photographs, by its combination of subjectmatter and art, belongs among the very best of such collections. It gives more than visual pleasure; it documents. It does more than inform; it creates an esthetic experience.

During the winter months many cherished perennials and tender shrubs were safely tucked under various and sundry mulches-- evergreen boughs, salt hay, straw, pebbles or even soil. But now that spring is beginning to appear more like itself, the protective coverings can gradually toe removed and added to the compost pile.

GREER GARSON is not waiting for her debut in American television drama tomorrow night to decide whether television is here to stay. She knows it is. Her decision dates to 1938 and it was not based on any extra-sensory glimpse into the future.

OMINOUS reports of dust storms from the southern Great Plains prove once again that the lesson of the Thirties has even yet not been learned. When the spring winds began to blow last month, great clouds of dust--the topsoil of millions of acres of farm land, much of which should never have been turned by the plow--darkened the Colorado skies to the southeast of Denver.
OZARK, Ala., March 24--The Army is speeding development of aerial mobility with a traditionbreaking system for training helicopter pilots.
The Cunard Steam-Ship Company has announced two more cruises for the Caronia.

BOSTON, April 2--Tony De Marco is willing to defend his welterweight championship of the world as soon as possible. The new 147-pound king made this point known today to Jim Norris, president of the International Boxing Club.

IT had never occurred to this reviewer that Cinderella might be explained as a clear case of maladjustment, until "The Glass Slipper" came along. ALBANY, April 2--The Jockley Club's plan for building a "dream track" for horse racing at Belmont Park squeaked through the State Legislature by a nose today.

Young patients at St. Luke's Hospital will benefit from an annual luncheon to be given April 12 in the ballroom of the Pierre. Funds realized will help provide equipment for the solarium and playroom in the children's wing of the hospital's new Clark building.
Important new light on the magnitude of the inflationary pressure now plaguing the Soviet Government has been provided by Pravda, the Communist party newspaper.

"DIKLIATSCHE," literally "The Mare," but here given the title at "The Nag," written by the man who became known as the "grandfather" of modern Yiddish literature, was first published in Vilna in 1873. One of Mendele's masterpieces, it is the second of his novels to appear in an English rendering within recent years, the first having been "Travels and Adventures of Benjamin the Third."

AN old and professional hand at murder and suspense chillers, John Dickson Carr has once more added a dash of history to his formula of quick deaths cleverly solved. The scene is Paris and Boulogne, the time is 1805, the climax of Napoleon's bold preparations to invade England.

Sponsors of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service have arranged a dinner for the night of April 12 in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria to mark the tenth anniversary of the merger of the Spence and Chapin nurseries.

THE next dance event of novel interest will be the local debut of the newly formed Dance Drama Company of Emily Frankel and Mark Ryder next Sunday at the Lexington Avenue "Y." The program consists of especially commissioned works by four choreographers.

Cold winds chilled business in the ready-to-wear market last week, but buying improved with the weather during the last few days, according to resident buying offices. Tunic dresses were in good demand. Many departments were planning early June promotions, especially in coats.

IT'S common for critics to say that an unusually well-written suspense story is "more than a suspense novel"; and of course they've been saying that about Anne Chamberlain's THE TALL DARK MAN (Bobbs-Merrill, $3).

TO THE EDITOR: IT is questionable whether William Watson lost the Poet Laureateship because of his magnificent book "The Purple East," as your correspondent Mihran Y. Costikyan writes in the Letters page.
COLORADO SPRINGS, April 2 (AP)--Californians dominated the gold and silver dance events today in the final round of the four-day national amateur skating championships at the Broadmoor Ice palace.
Robert Alexander Inch, chief judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District, is 82 years old today.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., April 2-- Supporters of the Levittown Public Library were mustering forces today to defeat a proposition which, they charge, would abolish the library. Taxpayers will vote on it at the annual meeting of School District 5 on May 4.
Retail stores arc preparing to capitalize on an old tradition-- the coloring of eggs.

The market for suburban Westchester apartment properties has shown "surprising strength" over the corresponding period a year ago, according to a survey conducted by John R. White of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

THE exhibition of selected Japanese prints of three centuries at the Yale University Art Gallery is not only highly provocative; it presents a strange historical irony and calls up long thoughts on the relation of the East and West in art.

THIS book takes its title from a speech in which Benjamin Disraeli asked whether man is ape or angel, and replied to his own question, "I am on the side of the angels." William Irvine's study aims at a portrait of the era that gave birth to the theory of evolution, and the apes and angels-- Victorians all--that were at the center of the resulting controversy.

POLYETHYLENE plastic film, already a familiar household product, has also invaded the home garden field. After several seasons of testing and limited use, it has "come of age" as a plant wrapping material and will be seen this year on many more local nursery deliveries and on an even greater percentage of mail order plant shipments.

Vice President Nixon, returning from Central America full of enthusiasm for the long-projected, long-delayed completion of the PanAmerican Highway, has won the President over. On Friday Mr. Eisenhower asked Congress for something like $75,000,000 to complete the highway within the next three years.

LOUISVILLE, Ky.--The mint julep and horse racing season begins April 14 in the portion of Kentucky known as the Bluegrass, that section around Lexington which is a stronghold of thoroughbreds, Tattersall vests, and Kentucky Colonels.

AMERICAN music, Gilbert Chase makes clear, needn't have anything to do with Columbus, Hiawatha, or Niagara Falls at sunset. Our native muse has been known to prefer the company of a tailgate trombonist on a New Orleans bandwagon; she has joined the shouting at camp meetings, where sin was on the way out; she has appeared on Tin-Pan Alley to murmur soft and low into a song plugger's ear.
NEWBERG, Ore., April 2-- The old frame house here in which Herbert Hoover lived as a boy will be opened as a memorial and museum Aug. 10.

IOWA--English Classes Students in Iowa high school English classes spend much less time than their parents did with classics like "Silas Marner" and "Julius Caesar," their examinations tend to be shorter but more frequent, and they write fewer "themes," but more letters.
An increasing number of mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations are raising the dividend rate they offer on cash deposited with them.
The Admiral Corporation's 1956 refrigerator line includes many design innovations as well as a selection of pastel colors.
King Coal was the merry old soul of North Atlantic shipping last week, pushing up charter rates in robust fashion after their retreat of the last several weeks.
BOSTON, April 2 (AP)--TextronAmerican, Inc., huge textile combine, has entered an agreement with two New England industrialists for the sale of ten plants of the former American Woolen Company.
CHICAGO, April 3--The Democratic organization exuded confidence today that it would sweep Tuesday's election and keep control of the nation's second largest city.
The Easter "pinching" of the nation's florists will start blossoming into cash dividends this week.
PARIS, April 3--The larger French nationalized banking institutions recently have increased their capital funds to get on even footing with the big private banks.
The Climax Molybdenum Company achieved a record net income last year of $15,605,599, an increase of 60.6 per cent over the $9,717,000 earned in 1953.

ROME, April 3 (AP)--Pope Pius XII, appearing fit and vigorous after last winter's illness, made his first Palm Sunday appearance in two years today. The Pontiff, 79, took part in ceremonies opening Holy Week, held an audience for 1,000 persons and made a long address.

Week Ended April 1, 1935 Interest in the foreign exchange market receded, to its lowest ebb in months. Turnover was small, especially after month-end requirements had been completed and closing rates showed no substantial change over the preceding week.
Christian churches over the world paid tribute yesterday on Palm Sunday to the founder of their faith and His triumphal entry into Jerusalem.

PAUL RAPIER RICHARDS moves with such deceptive lethargy that it seemed he would be the easiest of managers to pin down. Instead, he proved to be the most difficult-so hard that his Baltimore Orioles became almost an afterthought to a Florida excursion.
The Commerce and Industry Association of New York injected itself yesterday into an unpublicized fight for power between Budget Director Abraham D. Beame and Dr. Luther H. Gulick, City Administrator.
