WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)-- Senator Walter F. George said today it was "highly important" to the cause of peace that a toplevel big-power conference be held soon even if the Soviet Union should refuse to participate.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 3--Long Gene Conley gave the Dodgers short shrift today. Charley Grimm's first pitcher to go eight innings, Conley held the Dodgers to five hits as the Braves won, 5--1 at Engel Stadium.
WASHINGTON, April 3--The seventh anniversary of the day President Truman put the Marshall Plan into operation by signing the Economic Cooperation Act passed almost unobserved today.

Spring's Displaced Person Many an ordinarily talkative man finds himself in this season of the year left behind by the conversation of his friends and fellow workers. He spends more and more time rocking gently from his heels to his toes, or counting his change, while the talk bubbles around him.

Governor Harriman assailed the Administration's Formosa Strait policy last night as disregarding "the sensibilities of either our Asian or European friends and allies." However, he contended, there is still time to bring together all the countries involved "not only in the East but in Europe in order to internationalize the defense of Formosa, so vital in our own and free world security."

LONDON, April 3--For a city such as London to be suddenly and unexpectedly deprived of newspapers has been a novel and unpleasant experience, especially to the financial community. It had, however, no appreciable influence on the stock markets, although the large body of investors was deprived to a large extent of current financial news, upon which the daily behavior of markets is as a rule largely based.
The National Institute of Arts and Letters announced yesterday the selection of Edward Hopper, 73-year-old artist, to receive its annual Gold Medal for Painting.

The revolution of 1952 in Egypt is the subject of two books to be published on April 14. Doubleday will issue "Egypt's Destiny: A Personal Statement," by Mohammed Naguib, a leader of the revolution and former President of Egypt.

The fifteen-story office building at 33 Rector Street and adjoining five-story structure at 55 West Street have been purchased for cash by Aaron Levine, an investor, in a deal negotiated by Louis Smadbeck, vice president of the Charles F. Noyes Company. The property is 56 by 89 feet and is assessed at $340,000.
BUENOS AIRES, April 3 (AP) --Two pro-Government newspapers today attacked Roman Catholicism's status as Argentina's state church.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 3-- Brazil's forthcoming Presidential campaign appeared today to have become a contest mainly between a liberal general and a politician who depends on an assortment of forces, mostly of the Left.

TOKYO, Monday, April 4-- The Kyodo news agency, which serves Japanese newspapers throughout the nation, said the Government's first reaction to Secretary Dulles' rejection of the Foreign Minister's visit was one of "shock."
The Bank of New York reported, as of March 31, total deposits of $403,113,027 and total

SINGAPORE, April 3--Singapore, post-war keystone of British power and trade in Asia, today began digesting the prospect of having a Socialist-led government for the next four years. The outlook made many persons with a stake in stability and the status quo unhappy.
CHICAGO, April 3--Ten nominees for the Merchandise Mart's Hall of Fame for American merchants were announced today.

The deal between Dave Beck, president of the Teamsters Union, and Sewell L. Avery, chairman of the Montgomery Ward Company, raises a serious issue which both labor and the public authorities are now called upon to face. Mr. Avery, after a spectacular record of antiunionism, has signed a pact which recognizes the Teamsters Union as bargaining agent for 15,000 Ward employes, with assurances of wage increases to come.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., April 3-- William KerslaKe of Cleveland retained the national amateur Greco-Roman heavyweight wrestling title tonight at the Amityville Memorial High School. He eliminated his two opponents in the final round-robin in two minutes twenty-four seconds.

WASHINGTON, April 3-- Perry M. Shoebaker, president of the Lackawanna Railroad, is chairman of the task force that prepared the preliminary studies for the transportation report of the (Hoover) Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Administration's decision to use tactical nuclear weapons is a sad and discouraging aspect of our thinking about the atomic age, however "realistic" it may be in order to balance Russian military power.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP)-- Former President Harry S. Truman plans to return to the Senate later this month. This time it will be in the role of witness.
The "watchdog committee" created by the Legislature to check on the Harriman Administration was denounced and defended yesterday by two state officials on opposite sides of the political fence.

VENICE, Italy, April 2--The region of which Venice is the capital has treated the Communists so badly in all post-war elections that they make up proverbs about it. "In Venetia you sow beans and what grows is Christian Democrats," the Reds say ruefully.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 3 (AP) --The youngsters slugged it out for dear old Navy here today, but it all came out a draw as it has for the last thirty-seven years.
The state overhauled its labor code yesterday to protect workers against the hazards of the atomic age.

WASHINGTON, April 1-- Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the period March 26 through April 1: The Senate On approving the German rearmament treaties, restoring the sovereignty of West Germany and bringing her into the NATO Alliance, Agreed to, 76 to 2, on April 1.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3 (AP)-- Francis G. (Bo) Wininger, 32year-old star of the winter circuit, was invited today to compete in the nineteenth Masters golf tournament. The bid to Wininger completed the field for the event starting Thursday.
GRAPHIC and interesting presentations in good taste dealing with three religious faiths were seen yesterday afternoon in successive television programs.
CAIRO, April 3 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser said today that the defense pact between Turkey and Iraq was a bad bargain for its Western sponsors.
Several Representatives in Congress have asked the Maritime Administration to revise an adverse ruling that stymied proposed construction of a fleet of tankers under private financing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3--Seven international experts recommended today that a systematic and uniform appraisal be made of the world's reserves of iron ore. Prospects for consistent future expansion of consumption make it advisable, they said.

WASHINGTON, APRIL 3 (AP) --The program for building up defense industry hit the thirtybillion-dollar mark today with the granting of tax assistance for a forty-million-dollar titanium plant at Johnsonville, Tenn.

A GOOD argument could be made that the two most important events of the nineteenth century were the issuance of "The Communist Manifesto" in 1847 and the publication of "The Origin of Species" in 1859. Marx intended to convulse the world and did not succeed quite so much as he expected to, but enough to plague the lives of everyone alive today.
ZURICH, Switzerland, April 3 --A meeting of common stockholders of Interhandel, A. G., called by the Spiess group, was held here on Thursday to protest management actions.
PARIS, April 3 -- An exhibition of modern United States art has drawn conflicting reviews in the Paris press.

The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade was upheld yesterday in a business study as a commercial "counterpart of our military alliances." The pact, usually referred to as GATT, now links the United States and thirty-three other nations.

CHICAGO, April 3--Many of the marriages taking place today among high school youths are neither psychologically nor emotionally sound. They might have been prevented, though, had the couples met with fair success in their family, school and social life.

NOORDWIJK AAN ZEE, the Netherlands, April 3--The State Department brought a broad, historical picture of the United States South to the Netherlands this week-end, but Dutch interest fastened almost exclusively on the contemporary issue of Negro-white relations.
The only way to cook a steak of anything but the best quality is to confuse the juices, Arthur William Dana said the other day.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $68,916,860,803. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
WASHINGTON, April 3--The Government's transport functions --land, sea and air, at home and abroad--need an overhaul, the Hoover Commission reported today.
In an unusual spurt of activity, Kermit Bloomgarden aims to bring three attractions to Broadway next season, all within a three-week span.
The elements conspired yesterday to spoil Palm Sunday for the weather man as well as many New Yorkers who had planned to go strolling.
The writer of the following letter was formerly United States Ambassador to India.
The opening general session of the second annual American Film Assembly will take place tonight in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
PITTSBURGH, April 3-When the final steel production figures for March are in they will be hardly a whisker off 10,000,000 tons.

When the Town Hall Club was incorporated thirty years ago its by-laws set forth its purposes as "to develop a finer citizenship, to further the cause of good government, to improve social conditions and to promote literature and the arts; to establish and maintain club rooms, a library and other facilities which will provide a center for men and women who desire to cooperate in the accomplishment of these purposes."

The expansion of the use of motion pictures for instruction and information is one of the quieter cultural movements that was greatly precipitated during and after World War II. From the vast use of films to train technicians in the military and industrial services, and also to agitate the thinking of soldiers and civilians alike, a great system of audio-visual education and stimulation has emerged.

WASHINGTON, April 3--Lifein-Washington-Is-Mighty- Rough Department: Senator J. Strom Thurmond used his most recent newsletter to tell his constituents about a serious problem he and his wife were facing in the capital.
ALBANY, April 3--Governor Harriman and the Senate Republican leader reported tonight that the legislative session ended yesterday had resulted in some gains and some failures.
CHICAGO, April 3 (AP)--The College All-Stars tonight defeated the Harlem Globetrotters, 81--71, after losing in an afternoon game, 69--63.

ALBANY, April 3--Following are the texts of statements by Governor Harriman, a Democrat, and Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, Republican majority leader of the state Senate, on the accomplishments of the legislative session that ended last night.

ALBANY, April 3--The Legislature took the following principal actions during the 1955 session, which ended last night: New York City Approved a series of fiscal bills requested by Mayor Wagner that would: Permit the city to levy real estate taxes for operating expenses at the rate of 2 1/2 per cent of the five-year average of assessed valuations instead of 2 1/4 per cent to increase the yield by $27,600,000.
Palm branches borne in procession behind purple-draped crucifixes broke through the solemnity of Lent yesterday morning at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
The Stolypin prison car, borrowed by the Communists from Czarist times, is named after an early Minister of Interior. It is a fiendish but quite efficient method of prisoner transportation.
Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Opera saw a variety night, consisting of excerpts from three operas. It also saw some high jinks on stage. These took place during the second act of "Fledermaus."

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP)--Ch. Frejax Royalist, an English springer spaniel owned by Fred Jackson of Oak Park, Mich., was selected best in the all-breed show of the International Kennel Club which closed tonight at the International Amphitheatre.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 3-- Twenty residents of the metropolitan area are among the 159 young men and women who have received Woodrow Wilson Fellowships for the coming academic year.

WILMINGTON, N. C., April 3 (AP)--Billy Maxwell rallied on the last nine holes today to win the $12,500 Azalea open golf tournament by a stroke from Mike Souchak. Maxwell shot a 69, giving him a tournament record total of 270 and first money of $2,200.
WINNIPEG, April 3 (AP)--The Western Interprovincial Football Union has amended its bylaws to prevent any of its clubs from signing any player under contract or option in the National Football League.

A model could once be identified among hundreds of attractive Manhattan girls by the hatbox she carried. It contained items she needed for posing before the camera. Today she transports her equipment in a huge tote bag.

General of the Army Douglas MacArthur said last night that he was opposed to any "partial and selective" release of Army documents bearing on his views on Soviet military support of the war against Japan.

WASHINGTON, April 3--The Congress-White House clash over the rates of Federal pay increases had reached mounting bitterness when Congress began its Easter recess. Congress will not be back until April 13. At once, it is expected, the payroll battles will be resumed.
Cotton priced closed last week with a show of firmness after losing some ground early in the period.
Portugal is preparing a program aimed at doubling its present $30,000,000 volume of exports to the United States, it was explained yesterday by Antonio Mendoca, a leading Portuguese industrialist.

Five high school students who said they used to read comic books but had outgrown them expressed the opinion yesterday that some comics were not so bad and some were educational. But they said that those filled with brutality and obscenity should be banned.
COLORADO SPRINGS, April 3 (AP)--Tenley Albright of Boston has run her string of national figure skating championships to four straight. Hayes Alan Jenkins of Colorado Springs has won three in a row.
Christ's entry into Jerusalem to keep the Passover that ended in His crucifixion was commemorated yesterday at Palm Sunday services in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The Marshall Chess Club defeated the New York Academy yesterday, 6 1/2--1/2 with one game adjourned, in the fifth round of play for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams told New York's "average citizen" yesterday that it was time he changed his attitude toward the members of the police force.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)-- L. Richard Guylay of New York is the new director of public relations for the Republican National Committee. He formerly had been associated with the campaigns of the late Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

CINCINNATI, April 3 (AP)-- A Massachusetts scientist said today he believed science was learning how to use chemicals to improve soils for engineering purposes, such as making better and cheaper roads.

The men's clothing industry operated at 86 per cent of capacity in February, as compared with 82 per cent in the 1954 month and 88 per cent in 1953, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.
Yesterday afternoon's "Rigoletto" presented by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center saw three debuts.
ALBANY, April 3--Eleven issues will be submitted to the voters Nov. 8 as a result of the 1955 Legislature's decisions.
NEW ORLEANS, April 3 -- The Giants finally got around today to putting a firm restraining hand on Al Lopez Indians.

Idaho became a territory in 1863 and a state in 1890. It covers 83,557 square miles of land and water and its western borerd stretches nearly 500 miles. It is the twelfth largest state; you could squeeze New York, South Carolina and Delaware into it, and still have room to throw out your chest.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)-- The Census Bureau said today a survey of 4,000 state and local governments had turned up public works plans that would mean the expenditure of $27,750,000,000 if carried out in full.

Members of St. John's Church in the Village (Protestant Episcopal), Eleventh Street and Waverly Place, were urged yesterday to volunteer for a Greenwich Village project to combat juvenile delinquency.

ST. LOUIS, April 3 (AP)--The Los Angeles Danish-American team, after gaining a tie in regulation distance on a penalty shot, romped past Simpkins fo St. Louis today, 5--2, in the western divsion cup soccer final.
OKLAHOMA CITY, April 3 (AP)--Louise Suggs suffered numerous putting lapses today, but settled down to shoot par golf on the final three holes to take the $5,000 Oklahoma City open golf tournament.

CHICAGO, April 3--Conflicting price currents developed in the Board of Trade commodity markets last week, largely owing to technical readjustments. For May wheat there was an active demand, and at times also buying of the near wheat delivery and sales of deferred months as spreading propositions.

Winifred Cecil gave a charming vocal recital last night at Town Hall. It was the American soprano's first solo appearance there since November of 1951, and admirers of her artistry were out in force to greet her.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 3-- Most of the factors that make for a problem in implementing public school racial integration are amenable to educational processes, a Negro educational leader said today.

WASHINGTON, April 3--Existing anti-trust laws are broad enough to cover anti-trust violations in foreign commerce, according to findings of the Attorney General's National Committee to Study Anti-Trust Laws.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Senate hearings on the Administration's plan to reduce the armed services 300,000 men by mid-1956 are expected to be the feature of an otherwise quiet Easter recess period this week.

LANSING, Mich., April 3 (AP) --At least 1,000,000 voters are expected to go to the polls tomorrow in the state's spring election. That would be about 200,000 more votes than were ever before cast in the spring balloting.

JOHN LA MONTAINE and Paul Des Marais were the composers who presented music and answered questions Saturday night at the seventh Composers Forum of the season at the McMillen Theatre of Columbia University.
SEATTLE, April 3 (AP)--Ralph Miller of Hanover, N. H., and the United States Army, won the national giant slalom today on Barrier Mountain. His competition included three other Olympic skiers.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 3-- For its size South Korea is America's most expensive stepchild. The $700,000,000 we are contributing this fiscal year represents about half the Republic's gross national product. In exchange our security is reinforced by a courageous army of twenty regular and ten reserve divisions.
CLEVELAND, April 3--The quality of American public schools is suffering because of overcrowded classrooms, financial neglect and poor teacher morale.

ROME, April 3--The police have arrested ten persons for looting Etruscan tombs. They are said to have formed one of several gangs operating north of Rome and supplying a flourishing black market in antiquities.

The log-rolling techniques of a quarter of a century and more ago have shown themselves in the current Congressional discussions of the President's proposal for a threeyear renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act. The Senate has now gone home for the Easter recess without taking a vote on the measure, which passed the House on Feb. 18.

VANCOUVER, April 1 (Canadian Press)--A new steel and cement industry for British Columbia involving an eventual expenditure of $100,000,000 by a group of British and European companies was announced here today.
Two detectives receive honorable mention and a third is cited for exceptional merit in the latest Police Department awards list.
JERUSALEM, April 3 -- Two Israeli soldiers were killed and nineteen wounded today in fighting with Egyptian troops.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) --The Labor Secretary, James P. Mitchell, announced today a series of conferences with union, employer and state representatives on the "urgent" need to raise workers' skills.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)-- The roaring construction boom put more new buildings in place in the first three months of this year than in any previous January-March period, the Commerce and Labor Departments reported today.

VIENNA, April 3--Chancellor Julius Raab said today that his government was ready to agree to give additional guarantees against anschluss (union) with Germany. He made the condition that Austria would not be required to accept obligations that would limit her sovereignty or endanger her independence.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 3 (AP)--Navy, first in yesterday's race and second in today's finale, captured the McMillan Cup Regatta.

THE annual Sponsors' Concert of the Robert Shaw Collegiate Chorale was conducted last night in Carnegie Hall by Dr. Paul Sacher. "Isaiah's Vision" by Willy Burkhard, a Swiss composer, was played for the first time in America.
FORT LEE, N. J., April 3-- Officials of this community at the New Jersey end of the George Washington Bridge may be forced to make a financial sacrifice to history.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3(AP)--Two persons close to the late James V. Forrestal have vouched for the authenticity of his diary entry saying General of the Army Douglas Mac Arthur had favored Moscow's entering the war against Japan, The St. Petersburg Times said in a copyright article tonight.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 3-- French officials have promised to try to induce the dissident Binh Xuyen group to give up the National Security Police building to Government forces.
Frustration hovers like swampmist over "Short-Term Economic Forecasting."* just published by the National Bureau of Economic Research.
Two members of the New York Coast Guard headquarters staff have retired.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 --Batjac Productions has filed claim to the title "Earthquake McGoon" with the film industry Title Registration Bureau. This was the nickname given to James B. McGovern, American pilot who was killed while flying a cargo plane to help the besieged French troops at Dienbienphu in Indochina.

In this country we delight in extolling the merits of free enterprise and free competition on every possible occasion. In practice, however, many of us seek to evade the rigors of free enterprise and free competition and to gain "protection" by Government action of one sort or another.
Juvenile delinquency cannot be curbed by curfew regulations or making parents responsible for acts of vandalism by their children, Correction Commissioner Anna M. Krosa declared yesterday.
The American Radio Association, C. I. O., declared yesterday that it had "torpedoed" Harry Lundeberg's controversial longer work week plan.
LONDON, April 3--The United States has quietly notified Britain that it prefers to wait for Middle East affaiis to cool before joining the new TurkishIraqi-British defense alliance.
Soviet production of aluminum, lead, zinc and other nonferrous metals has risen rapidly since 1950, Izvestia reports.
GUADALAJARA, Mexico, April 3--Nine cars of a passenger train packed with Holy Week vacationers dropped into a 600foot canyon tonight. One newspaper report here said 300 persons were believed killed.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) --Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, today branded as "irresponsible" any talk that radioactive fallout from the Nevada atomic tests had caused human injury.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 3 --Thirty-nine persons, mostly children, died tonight in a fire that destroyed a motion picture theater at Sclessin, near Liege.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 3 (UP) --Fort Wayne's Pistons defeated Syracuse, 96--89, tonight before 3,200 Coliseum fans to stay in the running for the National Basketball Association championship. They now trail the Nationals in the best-of-seven series, two games to one.

The Medical Building, a threestory structure at 165 North Village Avenue, Rockville Centre, L. I., has been purchased by a syndicate of investors for a reported price of $1,200,000. Sydney M. Siegel Co., Forest Hills brokers, negotiated the sale.
"Do you mean you actually have baseball teams?"

MEMPHIS, April 3--No one is going to become unduly excited over a 13-1 victory against the Memphis Chicks of the Southern Association. But good pitching is good pitching no matter against what class of opposition.

The State Department has at last decided that it will be safe to let seventy-six Chinese students now in this country go back to Communist China, despite the fact that they have some knowledge of atomic physics. These young men, as they supposedly are, are the remainder of some 5,000 who were studying in this country when the Communists took over the Chinese mainland.
Virtually all the ground lost in last year's recession has been recovered, according to the First National City Bank of New York.

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 3 (AP)--Tony Trabert defeated topseeded Vic Seixas, 8--6, 5--7, 5--7, 7--5, 6--2, in the final round of the Puerto Rican invitation tennis tournament today. It was his seventh straight tournament victory.
WASHINGTON, April 3--Secretary of State Dulles informed the Japanese Foreign Minister tonight that he could not arrange immediate talks requested by the Japanese.

New York University, in recognition of the American Jewish Tercentenary, awarded honorary degrees of Doctor of Humane Letters yesterday to five prominent Jews. They included Abba S. Eban, Israel's Ambassador to the United States.
CLEVELAND, April 3--Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared tonight that there was no war party in the United States.
The writer of the following letter is a member of the Department of Economics of Rutgers University.

DETROIT, April 3 (UP)--The Detroit Red Wings registered three goals in the final seven minutes tonight to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 4--2. The Victory, in the opener of their Stanley Cup championship series, tied a National Hockey League record.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 3--There now seems little chance that Unilever shares will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
ALBANY, April 3 (AP)--Four wrecking cranes worked at top speed today to clear New York Central tracks after the wreck last night of a westbound passenger train.
There is a strong possibility that the American Tobacco Company will end its long-time sponsorship of the Jack Benny radio show after this season. It would continue the comedian's television program.

For perspective on our own problems and trepidations it is often helpful to try to see how the world looks to the other fellow. For all of us today the most important "other fellow" is the group which rules in Moscow, particularly Mr. Khrushchev. Like ourselves the men in the Kremlin must be worried about war, particularly an all-out nuclear war.

The Hills Brothers Company, packer of food products, will allow grocers 3 cents a unit for each coupon handled in introducing three new cake mixes. Hills is the first national advertiser to heed distributors' complaints that a 2-cent payment does not cover handling costs.

Following is the text of a statement last night by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, as distributed by The Associated Press: I have been asked by the press to clarify certain points of discussion with reference to any alleged connection I may have had with the Yalta decisions.
ELEMENTAL forces that once affrighted men or excited them to awe are entrapped today in vinyl for Atom Age entertainment.
The president of Western Theological Seminary of Pittsburgh warned yesterday of a danger in the current return to religion.
Twenty "Hiroshima Maidens," badly disfigured by the atomic explosion of Aug. 6, 1945, will be flown to New York this month for plastic surgery and medical treatment.
CHICAGO, April 3 (UP)--The American Farm Bureau Federation said today the referendum choice facing wheat farmers this summer was not "realistic" and should be corrected immediately by Congress.

BERLIN, April 3--Neues Deutschland, the newspaper that is the chief voice of East Germany's Communists, called today on all party members and candidates aged 18 to 22 years to enlist in the embryonic armed forces.
Mr. Protestant Minister of 1955 is the best-educated preacher in American history. Yet, never before has he had to face such a multiplicity of problems.

ST. LOUIS, April 4--Following is the editorial signed by Joseph Pulitzer Jr. in today's Post-Dispatch: THE TIDES OF TIME A flame of integrity was extinguished at the death of my father, Joseph Pulitzer, but its light will always radiate to newspaper men of conscience everywhere.

The increase in yields on commercial paper spread yesterday to paper issued by large finance companies. The rise in interest on short-term securities was said to be the chief reason for the higher rates on these shortterm unsecured notes.
BOSTON, April 4--The I. C. C. began today threading through a maze of legal switches and sidetracks in the recent purchases of Boston Maine shares.

Two buildings containing eighty-four apartments at 320 and 328 East 180th Street, the Bronx, have been purchased by R. S. R. Associates, Inc., from Selfred Realty Company, Inc., headed by Frederick Lese. The property was sold subject to mortgages of $197,500.
JERSEY CITY, April 4--This city will ask the Port of New York Authority and the New Jersey Turnpike Authority to reimburse it for tax losses and for services it provides them.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company reported as of March 31, 1955, total deposits of $122,498,975 and total assets of $159,897,872, compared, respectively, with $105,075,462 and $143,162,206 on Dec. 31, 1954. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $38,005,210 against $27,596,547; holdings of United States Government securities to $81,221,933 against $85,045,118; and loans and advances to $12,263,327 against $4,658,999.
ALBANY, April 4--Governor Harriman signed without comment today three bills that will enable the City of New York to raise an additional $57,200,000 in local taxes in its next fiscal year.

Although a titleholder only three days, Tony De Marco of Boston signed to defend his world welterweight crown yesterday. His rival will be Carmen Basilio. The bout will be held in Syracuse on June 10 over the regulation 15-round route.

ATLANTA, April 4 (UP)--The president of a striking telephone workers local resigned and returned to work today in apparent protest against the violence that has marked a twenty-twoday communications walkout in nine southern states.

Summer Tan returned to racing yesterday and showed championship quality. Mrs. John W. Galbreath's colt made his first start as a 3-year-old a winning one as he streaked to a fourteenlength triumph in a mileand-a-sixteenth allowance race at Jamaica.
BOHEMIA, L. I., April 4-- Three veteran airline pilots took a routine qualification flight today, and the test cost their lives.
TRIESTE, April 4--This beautiful Adriatic seaport is again pervaded with suspicion of Yugoslavia and her motives.
OTTAWA, April 4--The Canadian Government wound up the fiscal year 1954-55 with a budgetary deficit estimated at $148,300,000. It was the first deficit since 1946.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 4--The New York Central Railroad's attempt to close the Millwood station on the Putnam division was opposed today by Westchester officials. They feared it might be the first step toward other curtailments.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed from 12 points up on the near May to 23 off on the far July.

CLEVELAND, April 4 (UP)-- The just-completed "world" professional tennis championship here junked the tradition-honored system of scoring. Not all the players voiced approval, but enough praised it and the system will be used again next year.
Newly appointed transit policemen were advised yesterday that the city was counting on them to help curb crime in the subways.
Late selling wiped out early gains on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and prices closed almost unchanged.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 4 --Down the years these transcontinental spring exhibition tours of the Giants and Indians have given birth to more than one budding "phenom" who subsequently attained stardom. Particularly so with the Cleveland club.
The British Isles expect to play host to 250,000 American tourists this year, Sir Arthur Morse, chairman of the British Travel Association, declared here yesterday.
Savings bankers here expressed disappointment yesterday over the Legislature's failure to pass a bill that would have given them greater latitude in establishing branches.
It was all peace and harmony along the waterfront yesterday morning as thousands of longshoremen reported for work-- and their union leaders were all over the harbor to make sure they did go to work.
WASHINGTON, April 4--The Supreme Court held memorial services for Associate Justice Robert H. Jackson today.
LEWISTON, Idaho, April 4-- One of the nation's longest and bitterest battles between champions of public and private power went into a new round today.

Fordham University set back Brooklyn College, 7--3, yesterday in a baseball game at Brooklyn College Field. The Rams got four-hit pitching from Jack McQuade. Eight errors by the Brooklyn nine helped the Rams.

One of the last-hour decisions made at Albany was to defer putting to a vote of the Legislature, and of the people at next November's election, the proposition of issuing $250,000,000 in bonds for building up the State University's plant.

"One Man In His Time," the autobiography of N. M. Borodin, the Russian scientist, will be published next Tuesday by Macmillan. It is an account of his forty-two years in Russia--of his life under the Czar and the Soviets.

With proper rehabilitation and placement, the physically handicapped make fine workers, with a production rate slightly better than the normal, Dr. Howard Rusk said last night. He is chairman of the Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University School of Medicine and associate editor of The New York Times.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 4--A warning that "in our haste to stamp out cancer by indiscriminate use of extensive surgery we are forgetting the patient and even disseminating disease," was given today at a regional health conference.

WASHINGTON, April 4--Congress went off today on a nine-day Easter recess and left behind a great amount of work and a record largely yet to be made. The Senate met for half a minute, with only a few members present, and then adjourned until April 13.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 (AP)--Archie Moore, light heavyweight boxing champion, has "as normal a cardiovascular system as anybody could wish." This was stated in an examing physician's report, released today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission today renewed its efforts to have the Alleghany Corporation, holding company controlling the New York Central Railroad, returned to S.E.C. jurisdiction.

The First National City Bank of New York reported yesterday net current operating earnings in the first quarter of $9,077,186, or 91 cents on each of the 10,000,000 shares outstanding. This compares with $8,411,255, or 84 cents a share on the same number of shares, in the first quarter last year.

PARIS, April 4--Plans for a $5,750,000 building to house the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have been submitted to city planning authorities of Paris. If they are approved, work on the project will begin this summer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Lewis Mayers, in his letter in your March 24 issue, severely criticizes your editorial views on the Fifth Amendment expressed in your Feb. 21 issue. He condemns "the unfounded notion that the privilege against self-incrimination is an ancient and hallowed one" and asserts "that there is reason to believe that it was not well established in our law even as late as our own Revolution."

ATLANTA, April 4 (UP)-- Senator Estes Kefauver said today that "there is absolutely no need for the Dixon-Yates contract --except for the desire of this Administration to wreck T. V. A. and give Messrs. Dixon and Yates a fat bonanza of profit."

WASHINGTON, April 4--The Democrats in Washington are unhappy about the Administration's handling of the defense of Quemoy and Matsu, but in retrospect they are almost as dissatisfied with their own record on the issue.

The work of Greer, a children's community at Hope Farm, N. Y., will be outlined to women who will attend a tea to be given by Mrs. Leonard Clark Feathers on Thursday at her home, 630 Park Avenue. Mrs. Ward Melville will serve as co-hostess.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, renewed his attack today on the appointment of Edward Corsi as special adviser to Secretary of State Dulles on refugee and immigration matters.
Fifty youngsters of Public School 187 set out in the bright April weather yesterday afternoon to clean up their hilltop neighborhood in Washington Heights.

An opportune arrival among recently published books on cookery is Miss Leah Leonard's "The Jewish Holiday Cook Book" (Crown. 184 pp., $2.50). Home cooks preparing for Passover, which begins tomorrow, will find in this volume menus and clear, carefully constructed recipes for dishes traditional for the Festival of Freedom.

CONTEMPORARY French painting is featured in two new exhibitions. That at the Galerie de Braux, 131 East Fifty-fifth Street, is the more conservative in character and boasts the better-known names, but not necessarily the better pictures.

LONDON, April 4--The stock markets here, although still inactive and moving narrowly, were generally firm in tone. Government stocks registered small rises, although tending downward toward close in expectation of March's gold and dollar reserves statement.
MEXICO CITY, April 4 (AP)-- Mexico's Government - operated railways counted today thirteen dead and 107 injured in two express derailments, 450 miles apart, that came during the Palm Sunday week-end.

The week's first play, "Teach Me How To Cry," by Patricia Joudry, opens at the downtown Theatre de Lya tonight at 8 o'clock. It is a family drama dealing with the relationships between two adolescents and their parents. The action takes place in a small American community during 1919.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 4--Israel asked today for an "urgent" meeting of the Security Council to take up new charges against Egypt.

A call to producers and distributors of 16-mm, non-theatrical films to maintain a free exchange of ideas and to avoid the pitfalls of dogmatic use of their medium was made last night by Bosley Crowther, film critic of The New York Times.
LONG BEACH, Calif., April 4 --The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union is not planning to merge or affiliate with any other labor organization.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 4--Andy Carey walloped three triples and Mickey Mantle collected three singles in the thirteenhit offensive that gave the Yankees an 11-8 victory over the Chattanooga Lookouts today.

WASHINGTON, April 4--An official historian said today General of the Army Douglas MacArthur had "emphatically" stated that a United States invasion of Japan should not start "until three months after the Red Army had attacked in Manchuria."

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- The Department of Commerce said today that a February rise in factory payrolls--the hardesthit income category during the 1953-54 business turndown--had raised personal income by $1,000,000,000 on an annual rate basis.
WASHINGTON, April 4-- President Eisenhower will mix Easter eggs and baseball next Monday.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., April 4--A pair of elegant white swans, known locally as the Chief and his mate, preened in the warm sunshine today near their lakeshore nest of eight eggs at the Valley Stream State Park.
WASHINGTON, April 4-- Harold E. Stassen rode up to Capitol Hill this morning and made a temporary truce with the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

The property at 188-192 Avenue of the Americas, near Spring Street, containing six stores and fifty-nine apartments, has been sold by the estate of Jerome Petillo to a syndicate headed by Harry Klein. The new owners plan to remodel the building into modern apartments.
WASHINGTON, April 4-- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, stood firmly today behind the projected reduction of 150,000 in military manpower by June 30, 1956.
BOSTON, April 4--An 80year-old registered voter from Hancock, Me., conducted the Boston Symphony Orchestra tonight in a Beethoven program.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 4 --The Dodgers broke their losing streak with the Braves today, beating them, 10--8, at Sulphur Dell.

Governor Harriman had his way, and the Legislature enacted a year's delay in the effective date, originally set for Sept. 1, when all automobiles registered in New York State must begin showing proof of passing semi-annual inspection for mechanical safety. This does not mean, however, that a license has been granted to abandon inspection, nor should the administration wait until next year's legislative session to decide what its policy is going to be.
PARIS, April 4--Premier Edgar Faure announced today that at the end of March France had a surplus of $26,200,000 in the European Payments Union.

CHARLOTTE PAYNE JOHNSON is young, pretty and Southern. Judging solely by her picture, one might be tempted to think that the most serious problem she ever had to consider was whether she preferred to be elected queen of the Cotton Carnival or of the Mardi Gras ball. Nevertheless, appearances are deceiving, particularly in the South, where literary talent these days is busting out all over.
HONG KONG, April 4--Kao Kang, former Communist regional boss in Manchuria and one of Red China's original Vice Chairmen, was officially reported tonight to have committed suicide.

The corner druggist and the local grocer are up in arms. Their target is the report made last week by the Attorney General's Committee to Study the Anti-Trust Laws, which urges changes in the Robinson-Patman Act and the repeal of Federal fair trade laws.
The Hoover Commission's criticism of the maritime policy of the Department of Defense was hailed yesterday by Francis T. Greene, executive vice president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

Fifty years of fine craft work will be marked today with the opening of the golden anniversary exhibition of the New York Society of Craftsmen. On view in the Artists Equity Gallery, 13 East Sixty-seventh Street, the show will display the works of sixty-five members until April 15.
YESTERDAY (April 4, 1955) THE PRESIDENT Conferred with Arthur F. Burns and Gabriel Hauge, his economic advisers. Talked with Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
The wordl's first turbine-propeller airliner, the Vickers Viscount, brought a new look and a new sound to commercial air operations in this country yesterday.

Coffee prices soared as much as the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit in the deferred months yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. There was a pool of bids at the limit rise at the close. Final quotations were 90 to 200 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher on 113,500 bags.

GENEVA, April 4--The conference of nongovernmental organizations on means of eliminating discrimination and prejudice in the world ended today after having indicated what it thought needed to be done.

LONDON, April 4 (Reuters)-- Sir Winston Churchill, with his sense of history and drama, stage-managed his farewell dinner tonight so that the scene in the huge dining chamber was almost like a painting from the days of the first Queen Elizabeth.

Victor F. Condello, the man who for six years has had the job of piloting New York City bills through a politically hostile Legislature, yesterday was sworn into the $13,000-a-year post as Assistant to the Mayor.

THE reports on the recent Pan-American Games in Mexico City were a bit on the skimpy side along the Grapefruit Circuit. But when a tourist got a chance to catch up on his reading, he discovered to his astonishment that the footracing fraternity contributed quite a few eye-poppers.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The following tables show briefly the status of major legislation in Congress and summarize the key votes thus far: The Major Bills FARM POLICY--Bill providing for rigid price supports has been reported out by the House Committee on Agriculture.
New York City's vast fashion industry will have a $6,000,000 show case by mid-1956, industry leaders were assured yesterday.
Humphrey Bogart, who played his first "tough guy" part twenty years ago in "The Petrified Forest," will recreate the role for television. The cast will include Lauren Bacall and Henry Fonda.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP)-- The Federal Trade Commission today announced creation of a thirteen-member task force to pinpoint corporation mergers that might have an adverse effect on the nation's economy.
LONDON, April 4--Sir Anthony Eden, the Foreign Secretary, told the House of Commons today that Britain would help guarantee any settlement that might be worked out between Israel and the Arab states.

The city and county of San Francisco borrowed $6,900,000 in the public market yesterday. The bonds, which mature from 1956 to 1970, were awarded to a group headed by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association.

Following the sound principle that conferences between statesmen of different nations require adequate preparation, Secretary Dulles has asked Foreign Minister Shigemitsu to postpone his proposed visit to Washington until talks now being held in Tokyo have led to a preliminary understanding.
ANKARA, Turkey, Tuesday, April 5--Turkey and Lebanon pledged early today to seek "complete collaboration" between Ankara and all Arab countries with a view to ensuring Middle Eastern security.
LONDON, April 4--Britain's gold and dollar reserves fell by $14,000,000 last month, leaving the country with a total of $2,667,000,000.
The Dravo Corporation and its subsidiaries had in 1954 a net income of $3,526,646, equal to $6.92 a common share, compared with $4,365,900, or $8.63 a share, earned in 1953.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Unions lost an important picketing decision in the Supreme court today.

The big bombers of the Strategic Air Command are the nation's first line of defense in the nuclear age, the Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson, told the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense yesterday.
CAMDEN, N. J., April 4 (AP)-- Campbell Soup Company today announced plans to acquire C. A. Swanson Sons of Omaha.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, largest in the city, in its first report yesterday showed net operating earnings for the first quarter of $10,623,000, or 88 cents on each of the 12,000,000 shares outstanding.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren refused today to interfere with a Government investigation of a fight for control of the Boston and Maine Railroad.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4 --There will be no black-andwhite pictures made in CinemaScope until Twentieth CenturyFox, which grants licenses for use of the trade name, lifts its contractual requirements that all CinemaScope productions must be in color.

THE Musicians' Guild presented its fourth and final concert of the season at Town Hall last night. The novelty of the evening was the first performance of a Sonata for Viola and Piano by Jacques de Menasce, played by Lillian Fuchs, violist, with the composer at the piano.
Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, the perpetual - motion heavyweight from Far Rockaway, gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Archie McBride of Trenton last night at the St. Nicholas Arena.

Braniff Airways Charles E. Beard, president of Braniff Airways, Inc., informed stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that directors are expected to approve the sale of additional common stock which would provide about $6,000,000 in new funds.

The annual meeting of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation started out in the grand ballroom of the Commodore Hotel yesterday with strong support for the company and wound up two and a half hours later in something akin to turmoil.

TRENTON, April 4--Bills designed to reorganize New Jersey's motor vehicle licensing and registration procedures were approved unanimously today by both houses of the Republicancontrolled State Legislature.
CLEVELAND, April 4--The nation's leading school officials got a tough homework assignment today from a noted financial expert.

ONE of the merits of Richard Strauss' "Arabella" is that its characters are all human beings. And the strongpoint of the performances of the two singers who assumed new roles in the opera last night at the Metropolitan was that they enacted them so humanly.

CHICAGO, April 4--Reports of violent dust storms in the Southwest, which may have dissipated all the benefits of recent rains, caused a relatively strong tone in the new crop wheat deliveries today. May wheat was under selling pressure at times.

WASHINGTON, April 4--The opening sentence under the heading "Organized Labor" in the study of antitrust laws by the Attorney General's Committee made it plain that no light would be cast on the basic social-economic issues raised by labor's legal immunities.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 4--Leo Durocher, beginning to show concern for his pitching, went in for some experimentation today. It didn't work out very well.

The inauguration of the new pier hiring rules last week and their observance since then by both workers and employers mark an outstanding victory for the Waterfront Commission--and for the public whose interests it is pledged to protect.
The El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries had a substantial increase in operating revenues in 1954, although net income declined, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Dr. Hart Van Riper, medical director of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, said yesterday he did not believe that the predicted shortage in Salk polio vaccine, in case it proves effective, would materialize.

The premium offer--a bonus that the consumer gets by sending in a coupon or a boxtop, along with cash--is beset with pitfalls for the unwary merchandiser. Consider the case of the Kraft Foods Company: Kraft, through J. Walter Thompson Company, is running advertising in national media to offer a $1 retail value in men's socks for 50 cents and a Velveeta boxtop.
The National Foreign Trade Council declared yesterday that considerable misunderstanding recently has been created on benefits of United States private investments in Latin America.
WHEATON, Ill., April 4 (UP)-- Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, was buried with military honors today on the grounds of his country estate.

Stockholders of the Riegel Paper Corporation will be asked to approve certain major corporate changes at the annual meeting on April 26. John L. Riegel and Walker Hamilton, chairman and president, respectively, so notified wrote the shareholders yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets nere by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 12,000 head: market slow, fully 25c lower: some sales as much as 50c lower on butchers: sows moderately active, weak to 25c lower: most choice 190 to 230
Soviet slave camps are sometimes thought to be reserved for the enemies of communism, but the prisoner complement of Vorkuta read more like a "Who's Who" of the Communist world.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 4 (AP) --Jug Chief, a 4-year-old Chief Abbedale pacer owned by the Newport Stock Farm of South Plainfield, N. J., won the $2,500 Garden City pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The time was 2:07 1/5.
Wall Street took up arms over the week-end to fight for preservation of the tax cuts for dividends voted in the Revenue Act of 1954.
ST. LOUIS, April 4 (AP)--Joseph Pulitzer Jr. became editor and publisher of The St. Louis PostDispatch today. He succeeds his father, who died last week.

THE trout fishing purist who shuns contact with bait fishermen or spinning addicts again will have four stretches of water in New York State where he can be assured of competing only with other fly fishermen.

A prisoner accused of being an international narcotics peddler escaped from the United States Courthouse at 12:20 P. M. yesterday shortly before he was to appear before a grand jury. Two hours later he was picked up by narcotics agents at Newark Airport.
Maurice T. Moore of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine Moore was elected yesterday chairman of the trustees of Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, April 4--The Supreme Court found today that former Representative Ernest K. Bramblett had been legally convicted of padding his office payroll.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- A group of southern mills won a court fight today against nationwide setting of minimum wages on Government contracts.

WASHINGTON, April 4--President Eisenhower has booked commencement addresses at his old alma mater, the United States Military Academy, and at Pennsylvania State University, where his brother Milton is president.
SINGAPORE, April 4--In nonCommunist Vietnam a United States expert on land tenure has encountered a strange land reform problem.
ALBANY, April 4--Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly, accused Governor Harriman, a Democrat, of political plagiarism today.
Jews throughout the world will usher in tomorrow night the Passover season--Judaism's traditional celebration of freedom.
Wanamaker's, which closed its fifty - eight - year - old store at Broadway and Ninth Street less than four months ago, may be quitting suburban Great Neck, L. I., soon.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- Mrs. Mary Jane Keeney was acquitted today on a charge of contempt of Congress.
The writer of the following letter is executive director of the Free China Fund for medical and refugee aid.
TOKYO, April 4--Opposition parties are trying to make political gains from Secretary of State Dulles' refusal to agree to conferences in Washington this week with Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu.
MOSCOW, April 4--United States authorities in Germany were accused here today of trying to make political capital out of a mixed-up Russian Kid.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture reported today its investment in surplus farm products reached a record high of $7,440,156,000 at the end of February. This amount compared with $6,252,461,000 at the same time last year.

NEW DELHI, April 4 (AP)-- An eight-man British steel mission has arrived by plane to negotiate the building of a millionton steel plan for India. The group was led by Sir Eric Coates, deputy chairman of the British National Coal Board.

A Queens County grand jury indicted a food freezer club and five men yesterday on charges of grand larceny. They are accused of selling $235 freezers for about $700, with the aid of television and radio advertising and telephone solicitation.
WASHINGTON, April 4--The Tennessee Valley Authority proposed today that the agency get its own pocketbook to finance expanding power needs.

A Play on an Old Trial A note on the theatrical pages the other day disclosed that Herman Shumlin, preparing for the task of directing "Inherit the Wind," is devouring all pictorial and written material available on the trial that took place in Dayton, Tenn., thirty years ago.

A permanent mortgage loan of $900,000 has been placed M. L. Spies Associates Inc. brokers, on the Shop City shopping center going up near Teall Ave and Grant Blvd in Salina, adjoining Syracuse, N. Y. Upper New York Realty Corp. headed by George W. Cregg. is sponsoring the project.
NEWARK, April 4--Hearings on the application of the New York Central Railroad to end passenger service on the West Shore line, from Weehawken to Albany, will be continued on April 20 through 22.
Efforts to divide labor and management into "warring and irreconcilable factions" were condemned last night as a form of "group hatred" by Benjamin F. Fairless.
The typical Protestant minister in the United States is 40 to 45 years old, lives in a mediumsized Midwest city, has two children, a car and a rather slim bank account.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 4-- The split between the South Vietnamese Government and the French here seems to be widening.

Gil Turner halted Gene Fullmer's winning streak at twentynine last night. The Philadelphian gained a unanimous decision over the West Jordan (Utah) fighter in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.
CINCINNATI, April 4--A $2 atomic age gas mask for civilians and a "do-it-yourself" kit to build a simple decontaminated air room at home were described here today.

Operations of the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries last year resulted in net earnings of $1,415,695, or 72 cents a common share, the company announced yesterday. This compares with net income amounting to $1,531,823, or 81 cents a share in 1953.
The United States Court of Appeals unanimously but reluctantly upheld yesterday the right to grant immunity to a witness in a case involving the national security.
LONDON, April 4--On the eve of his retirement Prime Minister Churchill entertained Queen Elizabeth II and his old friends in war and peace at 10 Downing Street tonight.

THE PRESIDENT Proclaimed Oct. 24 as United Nations Day. Wished Sir Winston Churchill good luck in his retirement. Vistors included Secretary of Interior McKay, Director Streibert of United States Information Agency and Joseph C. Satterthwaite, new Ambassador to Burma.

Four employes on two trucks of Circulation Associates reported yesterday they had been kidnapped in Manhattan. The trucks were stolen and they were taken for long rides in Brooklyn, they said. The company, a direct mailing concern, has offices at 226 West Fiftysixth Street and a warehouse at 243 West Sixty-seventh Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It may be that nothing more important to the future of mankind (or to the duration of its future) has appeared in print than your leading news story of March 26. I refer especially to the following sentences:

Louis Abramowitz has sold the five-story building containing sixteen apartments and five stores at 1745 Bathgate Avenue, the Bronx, to a client of Abe Solomon, attorney, for cash over mortgages of $47,000. The property is assessed at $54,000.
LONDON, April 5--Sir Winston Churchill declined a dukedom today to remain in the House of Commons.
Greek Line passengers now have a chance to finish their voyage with a heavier cargo of cultural luggage than they had when they began their journey.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 5 (AP) --T. O. F., a bay horse owned by the Virginia Stables of New York, won the Mineola Pace by a length from Hughie Boy in a 2:06 mile tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Warren Dennis drove the winner, a 14-1 shot.

TRIESTE, Italy, April 5--Six months ago Trieste was ringing with cheers and pervaded by a frenzy of patriotic fervor. It had just been announced that Italy and Yugoslavia had signed a Memorandum of Understanding in London and the citizens of Trieste were celebrating their impending reunion with Italy.

A plan aimed at persuading supermarkets to increase the number of frozen food products they handle was advanced yesterday by Paul M. Jacobs, vice president of Gorton-Pew Fisheries, Ltd., Gloucester, Mass. Gorton-Pew is one of the leading producers of fish sticks.

Hotel men evidently expect hearty appetites of Easter paraders who will be coming to their establishments for brunch next Sunday. They have planned elaborate menus with more emphasis on the "unch" (lunch) than the "br" (breakfast).
MIKE SOUCHAK set his lips in a grim, determined line. But there was a wistful look in his eyes when he spoke.
The Republic Pictures Corporation, maker of many stirring epics of stockmen and nesters, cowboys and rustlers, Indians and the United States Cavalry, may have another kind of battle coming up.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 5 --The groups fighting Vietnam's Government warned tonight that continued United States support of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem might lead to civil war.
SHEBOYGAN, Wis., April 5 --The strike of members of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O. against the Kohler Company went into its second year today.

CHICAGO, April 5--Another selling wave hit the wheat market today and all deliveries except the May registered new lows for the crop. The May was weak, too, but it still has a good way to go before making a new low.

In 1934, the night after the assassination of Sergei Kirov, Elizabeth Lermolo was picked tip by the Soviet secret police. Although she had no connection with the murder, she was sentenced to prison after torture and endless interrogation.
WASHINGTON, April 5--Secretary of State Dulles said today that if there was war in the Formosa Strait it would be the Communist Chinese who started it.
At 8 o'clock this evening, the Plymouth will receive the twicepostponed "3 for Tonight."

It will take more than "millions of dollars of efficiency" to balance New York's budget, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday. He discussed the city's financial policies and problems before 300 members of the Bond Club at a luncheon at 120 Broadway.
COLUMBUS, Ga., April 5-- Manager Leo Durocher's pitching cares, along with sundry other worries, were eased considerably today.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Admiral Robert B. Carney denied today that he predicted last month that war would break out in the Formosa Strait about April 15.

A Broadening Movement The Do-It-Yourself Show, which brought thousands to a local armory, marks another milestone in the burgeoning do-it-yourself craze. The movement broadens all the time; if things continue at the present rate, sales of materials and equipment will reach the ten-billionmark by 1960.
Trans World Airlines--and the airlines as a whole--should have an even more prosperous 1955 than the highly satisfactory 1954, according to Ralph S. Damon, president of T. W. A.

The First National Bank in Yonkers, N. Y., reported as of March 31, 1955, total deposits of $45,009,407 and total assets of $49,366,128, compared, respectively, with $47,975,117 and $52,176,949 on Dec. 31, 1954. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $7,395,089, against $8,415,666; holdings of United States Government securities to $14,267,571, against $13,584,792, and loans and discounts to $12,888,082, against $12,879,135.
HONG KONG, April 5--Peiping heaped additional abuse today on Kao Kang and Jao Shushih.
NAHAL, OZ, Israel, April 5-- Premier Moshe Sharett said today that Israel's patience was "not unlimited."

For a half decade before this week Communist China had seemed to be the great exception among Communist states in one major respect. There had been no very high level purge publicly among its leaders, no former great figure transformed into an ideological devil to join Trotsky, Rajk, Slansky and their fellow "traitors."
Columbia University's baseball team ended its ten-game losing string yesterday with an 8-7 triumph over New York University at Baker Field. The Lions' skein included eight 1954 losses.

CHATSWORTH, N. J., April 5 --It's a rare man who can lay hands on a will-o'-the-wisp, especially if it's motor-powered. Yet that's what State Trooper Leonard Miller did under a bright moon last night.
Preliminary plans for evacuating the metropolitan area in the event of hydrogen bomb raids were discussed yesterday by civil defense officials from New York, New Jersey and New England.

Vorkuta seethed with discontent. We slave laborers were fed up with the inhuman conditions, the abject monotony, the incessant work, the M. V. D. informers, the terrible cold, the persecution by the murderous criminal blatnoi and the hopelessness.

OTTAWA, April 5--The Canadian Government decided tonight to cut taxes. The national debt will be increased in the interest of national prosperity. Indirect and direct personal and corporate income taxes were cut to increase purchasing power and investment capital, with the advance knowledge that the Government would be collecting less than it plans to spend.

BOSTON, April 5 (AP)--The Weather Bureau issued today the following forecasts and listed these reports of conditions as received from operators of ski areas: NEW HAMPSHIRE Forecast-Increasing cloudiness and mild tomorrow, with showers likely at night.
MORMONS in New York will mark, this coming Sabbath, the 125th anniversary of the founding of their Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints.
Secretary of the Navy Charles S. Thomas criticized the Hoover Commission yesterday for a forthcoming report on food waste in the armed forces.

Californians take their investing the easy way--by mutual funds--according to results of a survey of 1954 sales of open-end investment company shares conducted by the National Association of Investment Companies.

William J. Keating, staff counsel to the New York City AntiCrime Committee, accused District Attorney Frank S. Hogan last night of "a campaign to discredit" a witness. The witness, he said, was now giving important information to a grand jury investigating illegal wiretapping and police abuse of legal wiretapping.
The inventiveness of eighteenth century designers of furniture and decorative adjuncts shows up in a new collection of antiques at Bergdorf Goodman's.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 5--South Africa has withdrawn from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
BERLIN, April 5 -- Plans to reconstruct aircraft plants in East Germany and build atomic piles to produce energy for "peaceful uses" were made public today.

The Buckley Country Day School has sold its property at 51 Steamboat Road in Great Neck, L. I., to the Kings Point Country Day School and has purchased the large mansion of the former Frederick Lunning estate and eighteen acres on I. U. Willets Road in North Hills. The double transaction was negotiated by the Fred Berger Company as broker.

The 1954-55 appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund brought $408,966.16, which has been divided among the seven cooperating agencies. The annual meeting of the membership corporation was held yesterday.
The steady growth of the tobacco industry was interrupted by temporary obstacles during the past year, H. A. Kent, chairman of the P. Lorillard Company,
LONDON, April 5--London newspapers, silenced by a strike, were unable to publish their tribute to Sir Winston Churchill. Instead, some of them supplied their texts to the press associations.
IT must be said that "Minus Three Thousand," the first installment of the new Sunday television series called "Appointment with Adventure," tried an original approach.

IN keeping with the Easter season, the Philadelphia Orchestra brought a performance of Bach's "St. Matthew's Passion" to Carnegie Hall last night. It was an unaffected, touching performance that conveyed the spirit of simple faith Johann Sebastian Bach brought to his musical setting.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 6 --The Soviet Union has rejected Japan's request that negotiations be held in New York on a peace treaty. Moscow has suggested instead that preliminary conversations be held in Tokyo.
MOSCOW, April 5 -- Pravda said today that at least 30,000 city workers would be sent into the Soviet countryside this year to take charge of backward collective farms.
An office tower building costing $30,000,000 will rise at Park Avenue and Fifty-third Street, opposite Lever House.
LONDON, April 5--"Winnie retired?" said a London waitress tonight. "Why?"

WASHINGTON, April 5--President Eisenhower declared today that leaders of the free world were bound to ask Sir Winston Churchill's counsel and advice, even in retirement. Democrats and Republicans joined the President in personal tributes to the retiring British Prime Minister.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 5 (AP)--Twenty extra-base hits, including nine home runs, turned a double-header into a batting practice session today. The Philadelphia Phillies emerged with a double victory over the Boston Red Sox, 17--12 and 8--2.

Parisians have been flocking to the exhibition of American art and design sent abroad as part of the "Salute to France" festival, Rene d'Harnoncourt, director of the New York Museum of Modern Art, reported yesterday.
That was the way the milkman of 1840 peddled his wares on the streets of New York.

HONOLULU, April 5--The Japanese Government certainly lost face when the United States rebuffed its abrupt project to send Foreign Minister Shigemitsu to Washington. This affront to prestige was surely not the intention of the American cold shoulder.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Top uniformed officers of the Navy and Marine Corps supported the President's reduced armed services budget today. At points they appeared to be salting loyalty to the Commander in Chief with reservations.
LONDON, April 5--Clarissa Spencer Churchill Eden, who will be 35 this year, is a complex mixture of political hostess and intellectual.

Who can think of Easter without faintly sensing the fragrance of the first spring; flowers? Transforming church altars and street barrows, rooms and gardens, their spendthrift colors reflect the joy of Easter Day and put a formal end to winter.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP)-- Louis E. Wolfson threatened today to take "legal steps" against Montgomery Ward Co., Sewell Avery, chairman of the board, and eight other directors for "the greatest sell-out in corporation history."

LONG BEACH, Calif., April 5 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated, expressed today a determination to resist Federal anti-subversive measures as attacks on organized labor.
HACKENSACK, N. J., April 5--The proposals to carve up Bergen County with new arterial highways has alarmed a substantial part of the county's population.
DETROIT, April 5 (AP)--Democrats were leading for five state offices and Republicans for three tonight in the unofficial count of Michigan's closest spring election in history.
Detroit, Mich., yesterday sold bond issues totaling $11,416,000 to finance sewerage and other public improvements.

DETROIT, April 5 (UP)--Ted Lindsay scored four goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings routed the Montreal Canadiens, 7-1. The Wings gained a 2-0 lead in the four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup final series between the two National Hockey League teams.

WASHINGTON. April 5 -- The American National Red Cross announced today that it had relaxed its rules so that under certain conditions local chapters could participate in Community or United Fund raising drives.
New issues of corporate securities totaling more than $75,000,000 will be placed on the market today.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) --Scott McLeod has told Congress that he believes President Eisenhower's program to admit 214,000 refugees can be completed successfully by the end of next year.

Inventories of gasoline and other refined petroleum products are piling up, according to the American Petroleum Institute. It reported yesterday that gasoline stocks as of March 26 were at a record 184,157,000 barrels. This was 5,531,000 more than a year ago.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 5-- The Ministers of Finance and Communications and the president of the Bank of Brazil resigned today. The Government crisis of which the resignations are a part is a result of preliminary maneuverings in the Presidential campaign.

Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner will go ahead soon with the appointment of a committee to make a long-range study of state-city fiscal relationships. It Is possible that funds will be sought from a private foundation for the study.
HARTFORD, April 5 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff has ordered speed in acquisition of land for the Greenwich-Killingly Expressway. The cross-Connecticut superhighway will be 127 miles long.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5 --Audrey Hepburn's next film appearance will be in the costarring role of Natasha in the Ponti - deLaurentiis - Paramount production of "War and Peace."

LONDON, April 5--Although idle with the approach of the Easter holiday, the stock markets were firm today on the strength of sterling following the unexpectedly small decline in the gold and dollar reserves last month and the Conservative gains in local elections.
Last night the New York City Opera Company presented Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalicr" at the City Center.

Awards for the best use of advertising in business publications in 1954 were announced and presented yesterday by the Associated Business Publications at a luncheon of the Sales Executives Club in the Roosevelt Hotel. In presenting the awards Judson Sayre, president of the Norge division of Borg-Warner Company, commended business papers for the power of their advertising.
The State Congress of Industrial Organizations called on Governor Harriman yesterday to veto a bill that would let municipal transit workers pick their own grievance representatives.
BALTIMORE, April 4 (AP)-- The Air Force announced today it would build a super-power radio station at Camden, N. Y., to guide airplanes.
Sir Anthony Eden, who is slated to be Britain's next Prime Minister, has carried forward British foreign policy in several of Britain's gravest hours of peril.

CINCINNATI, April 5 (UP) -- Major league baseball, player representatives took time out from their spring training today and voted to ask club owners that no player be compelled to begin conditioning before March 1.

ROME, April 5--Pietro Nenni, the leader of Italy's Left-wing Socialist party, has offered collaboration with the Christian Democrats. Former Premier Amintore Fanfani, Christian Democratic national secretary, rejected the offer today.

LONDON, April 5--Now that the speculation over Sir Winston Churchill's plans has ended, most politicians are trying to figure out the date of the next general election. The dates most frequently heard are May 26 and June 16.
CAIRO, April 5--Imam Seif el-Islam Ahmad was reported today to have been restored as ruler of Yemen.
Radar to catch speeders will go into operation here within sixty days.

Central heating will be required in all flats in the city after Nov. 1, 1956, if the City Council adopts amendments listed yesterday. They have been proposed for the Wagner Administration's Multiple Dwelling Bill.
Maj. Gen. Courtney Whitney challenged last night a declaration by an Army historian that General of the Army Douglas MacArthur had favored a preYalta plan to obtain Soviet military aid against Japan.
Sir Winston Churchill's political career covered more than half a century of modern history.

BALBOA, C. Z., April 3--Modification work at Gatun Locks that will increase the dependable capacity of the Panama Canal by six lockages a day during overhaul periods was completed at the end of March.

NOW that spring is here, things are naturally looking brighter all over. "Teach Me How to Cry," which opened last evening, is the pleasantest item the Theatre de Lys has put on display in several months.
Frank Costello's income tax evasion conviction was unanimously upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, wife of the Vice President, will head the Honorary Sponsors Committee, comprising thirty-six state governors' wives, which has been formed for the ninth national exhibition of Amateur Needlework of Today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 5--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today he was still trying to obtain the release of United Nations prisoners in Communist China. He added that it would be "unwise" to fix a dateline for ending his efforts.

In the happy tradition of British parliamentary government, which knows no prolonged Cabinet crises, and with the inevitability of an almost dynastic succession, Sir Anthony Eden is slated to become the new Prime Minister of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and first adviser to the Queen as head of the Commonwealth and Empire.

The price of zinc was advanced one-half cent a pound yesterday, to 11 1/2 cents, East St. Louis basis, by the St. Joseph Lead Company. At least two other major suppliers matched the new price, but others left quotations unchanged, so the domestic zinc price ended the day "split."
LONDON, April 5--Sir Winston Churchill resigned as Prime Minister today. Age has done what Britain's enemies and his political rivals could not accomplish.

THE American Watercolor Society will hold a preview reception this evening at the galleries of the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, to inaugurate its eighty-eighth annual exhibition. More than a score of awards and citations will be presented.
A last-minute attempt will be made to keep the headquarters of the nation's principal engineering societies in the city.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 5 (AP) --The Fort Wayne Pistons took command in the first half and outscored the Syracuse Nationals tonight, 109--102, to even their four-out-of-seven championship finals in the National Basketball Association at two games apiece.

A battle for the world welterweight championship between Tony De Marco, the new titleholder, and Carmen Basilio of Canastota, N. Y., received the sanction of the State Athletic Commission yesterday. The bout will be on June 10 in Syracuse.
There was rather a "heightof-the-season" atmosphere at the Jamaica race track yesterday. The crowd of 23,325 booed Jockey Eddie Arcaro after he had won a race with a 13-10 favorite.

Come spring furs should be fun. Such is the thinking of Gunther Jaeckel, which showed a Paris-inspired collection of mink, sable and broadtail stoles and jackets yesterday.

A research study sponsored by a substantial sum from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation promises to help improve methods of preparing the nation's educational leaders. This project, known as the Cooperative Program in Educational Administration, recognizes the need for top caliber educational leadership to handle problems involved in increasing school enrollments, teacher shortages, expanding criticisms of education and the growing responsibility of the schools in serving the entire community.

New York's pre-eminence as a fashion center of the world would be dramatized and strengthened by the interesting plan for building a headquarters for the industry on the West Side of Manhattan. A tenstory air-conditioned building to cost about $6,000,000 and be situated north of the garment center and south of the new Coliseum at Columbus Circle is proposed.

I KNOW a man who owns a beautiful house on a beautiful tropical island where he spends vacations snatched from his successful and Important business career. The house overlooks a white beach and a blue sea and is cooled by the trade winds most of the year. In that house are sixteen novels by Nevil Shute.
CHICAGO, April 5--Richard J. Daley, a 52-year-old veteran of the political wars of Illinois, was elected Mayor here today.

If Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of Vietnam should be overthrown by the combination of gangsters, cultists and French colonialists who have been gunning for him, the Communists will have won a significant victory in their efforts to gain control of all Indochina.
THIS is the month of migration and emergence for some of nature's children. Sportsmen greet this season as the end of a long, if not hard winter.
