WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP) -- Senator Harley M. Kilgore, Democrat of West Virginia, announced today that a Senate judiciary subcommittee of which he is chairman would conduct a "full-scale investigation" of antitrust policies and monopolies.

To live with one of the truly great men of history is a privilege for which future ages will envy us. Winston Spencer Churchill is one of those figures who have transcended the bounds of a country and even of the age in which they have flourished.
WASHINGTON, April 5--The Western Big Three cautioned Austria and the Soviet Union today against making bilateral commitments on the terms of an Austrian state treaty.

Reflecting a 42.9 per cent rise in sales, net earnings of the General Tire and Rubber Company in the fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28 increased 20 per cent to $2,236,310 from $1,851,515 earned a year before.
Under the leadership of Bethlehem Steel, which gained 5 1/4 points, and Kaiser Aluminum, which gained 5 3/4, the stock market moved ahead yesterday.
"Continued progress" is reported in discussions involving the new hiring regulations of the Waterfront Commission.

First-quarter sales and production of Rayonier, Inc., set a new high record for the chemical cellulose producer, Clyde B. Morgan, president, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday. Sales of chemical cellulose increased 32 1/2 per cent to 148,436 tons from 111,067 tons in the 1954 quarter.

Coffee prices tumbled the 2cents-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The sharp drop followed two days of trading in which the maximum rise was registered. Volume was 83,750 bags.

Six hundred and thirty-five pounds of City Councilman found themselves uncomfortably squeezed recently into the back seat of one of the new small taxicabs. In front, the seat next to the driver beckoned, empty and inviting. Under the law, nothing could be done about it. The Councilmen had to stay put.
VIENNA, April 5--The Austrian Cabinet will issue a statement tomorrow commenting on the Western Big Three declaration about the forthcoming talks in Moscow.
CLEVELAND, April 5--America's teachers hit back at their critics today.
Fourteen Protestant leaders who asked President Eisenhower on Saturday to "stop the current drift toward atomic war," were denounced yesterday as appeasers.
New York City was depicted yesterday as being at the crossroads in attempting to solve its traffic problem.
The eggs of Carl Federer may not be cheaper by the dozen, but they have other definite attractions for the homemaker.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 5 --Radio waves from the giant planet Jupiter have been detected by astronomers at the Carnegie Institution in Washington.
A new health insurance program that will include complete payment of doctor bills and allow for a free choice of physicians will be offered soon by Group Health Insurance, Inc.

BUTTE, Mont., April 5 (UP)-- Sandy Saddler, the world featherweight champion, scored a technical knockout over Kenny Davis of Los Angeles in 2:57 of the fifth round of a non-title fight tonight. The bout had been scheduled for ten rounds.
Parke, Davis Co. Parke, Davis Co. expects the price of polio vaccine to be reduced by the end of this year, H. J. Loynd, president, told the annual meeting in Detroit yesterday.
Fifty-seven local housing authorities received bids yesterday on $145,144,000 of temporary loan notes maturing on various dates between Oct. 7, 1955, and May 4, 1956.
The Board of Education of the City of New York and station WCBS-TV are contemplating another series of programs for children.
CHICAGO, April 5--The management of The Chicago Tribune today passed to three men long associated with the newspaper.

Textron American, Inc., has purchased Ryan Industries, Inc., Detroit, it was announced yesterday. Ryan makes a variety of electronics products for the Air Force. It has been acquired as another step by Textron American in its nontextile diversification program. It is the fourth non-textile enterprise in the organization.
PASCO, Wash., April 5--Senate proponents of a Federal high-level dam at Hell's Canyon were accused today of setting put to silence the Federal Power Commission "for political advantage."
A $6,000,000 plant that will produce furfural from a byproduct of sugar cane was formally opened yesterday in the Dominican Republic.

New York City said "No, thank you," yesterday to the New York Central Railroad's gift offer of its seven Weehawken ferryboats. The offer was made on March 24 by A. E. Penman, president ot the New York Central System, which has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to discontinue the Hudson River service.

The twelve-story loft building at 11 West Twenty-fifth Street has been purchased by Harry Horwitz, operator, for cash over mortgages amounting to $115,000 in a deal negotiated by Williams Co., brokers. It is assessed at $160,000.

A change in the American protective tariff structure would force the Government to alter many related laws, according to Hugh Comer, chairman of the board of Avondale Mills, Sylacauga, Ala. Passage of House Resolution 1, the bill to renew the reciprocal trade agreements and provide for the lowering of tariffs, might force Congress to reconsider the minimum wage and hours regulations and the present tax structure, he said.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5 (UP)-- Sam Snead sounded his annual warning to the Masters field today by firing his second straight under-70 practice round.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 5 --Bob Turley, determined to change from a "thrower" to a pitcher, took a long stride in the right direction today.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 5-- Advances in medical skills tend to burden the national economy with greater public dependency costs unless there is a parallel vocational rehabilitation program.
Senator William F. Knowland warned here yesterday that surrender of Quemoy and Matsu might eventually lead to a third world war or piecemeal surrender of the entire frea world to communism.

WASHINGTON, April 5-- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson disclosed today that an over-all policy on trading farm surpluses with Iron Curtain countries was being held up pending conferences with other free countries.
YESTERDAY (April 6, 1955) SECURITY COUNCIL Council heard Israel and Egypt on Israeli complaint, and adjourned to wait findings of Egyptian - Israeli mixed armistice commission.

CHICAGO, April 6--Further declines were registered in all wheat deliveries today, but after the morning recession a stronger tone developed with some recovery. Corn and oats also declined and deferred futures of soybeans were lower, while the May was relatively strong.
Storm clouds reappeared on the waterfront yesterday and a borough-wide work stoppage on the Brooklyn piers loomed for this afternoon.
American Viscose Corporation, largest producer of rayon staple in the United States, will expand its textile staple output by 40,000,000 pounds a year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 --Warner Brothers has completed negotiations to purchase film rights to the hit Broadway musical, "The Pajama Game."

The art of bank hold-ups, which has found an increasing number of practitioners since 1950, probably set a new cash haul record yesterday. Three men escaped with $305,243.17 from a Woodside, Queens, bank.

The Rayvale Realty Corporation has increased its holdings in the Plaza district through the purchase of the five-story building at 56 East Fifty-sixth Street. The property abuts 555 Madison Avenue, which is owned by the buyer.

TOKYO, April 6 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama and his Foreign Office were in apparent disagreement last night. The issue was whether peace talks with the Soviet Union should be held in New York, as the Foreign Office has insisted, or in Tokyo or Moscow, as the Russians have proposed.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 6-- The Government will conduct a series of police actions to root out hidden arms caches within Saigon and to arrest those illegally possessing weapons. The raids will begin tomorrow night.

Henderson, Ky., announced yesterday plans for the sale of $5,385,000 of electric light and power revenue bonds. The city will receive bids on April 21. The bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1954, will come due serially on June 1 from 1957 to 1985.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday with prices unchanged to 14 points (70 cents a bale) lower than Tuesday. The far months showed the greatest weakness.
The Zenith Radio Corporation accused the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday of "arbitrary and unwarranted censorship" and canceled its sponsorship of the "Omnibus" television program.

Alfred Vanderbilt's 3-year-old filly Sometime Thing tried stakes racing for the first time at Jamaica yesterday. She gave a top-quality performance and won first money of $17,000 in the six-furlong Prioress Stakes.
The area of "genuine political dispute" in Congress is growing smaller, a veteran Capital newspaper man observed yesterday, but there is no lessening of partisan feeling.

A motion for a declaratory judgment and an injunction to prevent the Ritz Towers, 465 Park Avenue, from being turned into a cooperative apartment was filed in Supreme Court yesterday in behalf of forty tenants.
Passover -- Judaism's festive holiday of freedom that commemorates the liberation of the ancient Israelites from Egyptian bondage--began at sundown yesterday.
Mayor Wagner and Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams promised yesterday to provide more adequate police protection for the city.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Lively discussions are taking place regarding the wisdom of publishing the Yalta papers. The weight of the arguments criticizing this step is such that it may seem useless to add to the controversy.
The recent trend to ornamentation of home furnishings or, as it has been called, "the new Victorianism" embraces table accessories as well.
JERUSALEM, April 6--Israelis gather tonight for the Passover feast with a general feeling that their present troubles give fresh significance to the 3,000-year-old rites.

The apartment house for twenty families at 163 West Tenth Street in Greenwich Village was sold after an ownership of sixty-five years by the estate of Charles Linder to a client of Walter Scott Co. Victor Spitzer was the broker.

A prominent educator has canceled a speaking engagement at a state education conference because, she charged, the meeting is to be held at a place that has practiced discrimination. Dr. Alice V. Keliher, Professor of Education at New York University, said yesterday that she had withdrawn from the scheduled meeting of the New York State Association for Supervision and Curriculum Development because it was being held at the Lake Placid Club, Lake Placid, N. Y.
RECENT paintings by Biala, in her second show at the Stable Gallery, 924 Seventh Avenue, include a number of canvases in subdued key with conspicuously effective use of blacks.
Among the 144 European refugees who arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, in two planes from Munich, Germany, were two men interested in the number 1,000.
George Washington, acclaimed as commander of land forces in the Revolutionary War, was praised yesterday by another military service. He was proclaimed "a naval strategist of great merit."
WASHINGTON, April 6--Carl Erskine, named this afternoon by Manager Walt Alston as his opening-day pitcher, tonight proved his fitness with something to spare.
WITH only reasonable cooperation from the weather man between now and Saturday, streams in a hundredmile radius of this city should be in excellent condition for the opening of the trout season.

White House Meeting A report of absolutely no international, though possibly some human significance, came in from Washington the other day. The First Lady, greeting guests at a reception, suddenly found herself face to face with a visitor wearing a dress identical to her own.

WASHINGTON, April 6--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety -four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 30:

Finch College's scholarship fund will benefit from the proceeds of a nightcap supper and a performance of "Silk Stockings" on May 2. The supper will be held in the Rendez-Vous Room of the Plaza following the musical's performance at the Imperial Theatre.
New issues of corporate securities totaling $12,151,000 will be offered to investors today.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that it was producing a revolutionary jet training plane for the Navy.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 9,000 head: market fairly active, generally steady to strong, in some instance as much as 25 cents higher on butchers: sows steady to strong: most...

DOVER, Del., April 6 (AP)-- Bryant W. Bowles, president of the National Association for the Advancement of White People, was fined $300 today. He was convicted on two counts of violating the school attendance laws of Delaware in his fight against integrating whites and Negroes in public schools.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 6--The sidewalk superintendents of the past are railborne now.
The $305,000 bank robbery in Queens yesterday exhibited the general technique developed by Willie Sutton, the most notorious of modern bank robbers.

From London comes word that Roger Stevens, acting in behalf of the Playwrights Company, has engaged Tyrone Guthrie, distinguished British Director, to stage "Marlowe," the Leslie Stevens drama based on the life of Christopher Marlowe.

WASHINGTON, April 6-- United States officials are studying a sharp decline in the volume of Chinese Communist "Formosa liberation" propaganda. They are also watching the Chinese Communist purge for hints as to the future course of Chinese foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP)-- Frieda B. Hennock, Federal Communications Commissioner, said today the agency should refuse licenses to television stations that grind out a "deluge of crime, brutality, sadism and outright murder."
One of the bitterest fights in the history of American industry is being quietly settled.

There is more than a small suggestion of desperation in the latest Soviet panacea for its serious farm problems. Some 30,000 urbanites-- party and Government officials, economists, engineers and the like-- are to be given short training courses in agricultural matters, sent out to work on farms for two months and then installed as chairmen of the one-third of all Soviet collective farms which Moscow considers to be backward.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 6 -- Too often patients and physicians are gripped by needless fears concerning possible cancer of the breast, a conference here was told today.
The Maritime Administration has approved the sale of four American-flag ships, two of them to foreign registries.

Profits from nuclear power activities will be restricted for the next few years because of the high cost of research and development in this field, Alfred I. Iddles, president of Babcock Wilcox Company, declared yesterday.

BALTIMORE, April 6 (UP)--A Federal grand jury today indicted fourteen of the nation's best known distillers, three stat liquor associations, seven wholesale firms and thirty-one individuals on charges of conspiring to fix Maryland liquor prices.

Allie Reynolds' exit from baseball now is official. On receipt of a wired request by the Chief from his Oklahoma City home, the Yankees yesterday formally placed their pitching ace of the last eight seasons on the voluntarily retired list.
PORTLAND, Ore., April 6-- The Governor of Washington today denounced a proposed Federal high-level dam at Hell's Canyon as a "phony" and said it would be "a monument to governmental error."

PARIS, April 6--The economic progress of West Europe since the beginning of the Marshall Plan is graphically shown in the sixth annual report of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, published today.

SINGAPORE, April 6--David Marshall, Labor Front leader, succeeded today in forming a Cabinet for Singapore's first experience at popular government. His ministry is based on a coalition between the Labor Front and the Chinese-Malay Alliance party.
Ham for Easter is as traditional as a gay new bonnet. And when glazed and garnished, the meat is first choice as an entree for the festive dinner.
Ignorance of the way Stock Exchanges treat dividends can be confusing to investors.
WASHINGTON, April 6--The Administration was pictured by White House sources today as being confident the Senate would pass the reciprocal trade bill "without crippling amendments."
The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., has decided that a Transit Authority in the hand is better than one in the bush, even if the second authority is politically more to the union's liking.

Officials of the American Red Cross Know that New Yorkers, like Americans everywhere, recognize the importance to themselves, their families and their communities of such of the Red Cross services as its blood program, its disaster relief and preparedness program, its welfare work for men in uniform and service families, and its training program in first aid and other health and safety skills.

If the Easter week-end brings sunny days, home cooks will not want to spend much time indoors preparing meals. With a little planning, culinary chores can be simplified, even if there are going to be guests, as well as the family, to serve.

A college professor, who has given Congress solicited advice on small business, assailed yesterday the recommendation for abolition of "fair trade" made last Wednesday by a sixtymember select committee.

LONDON, April 6 -- The change of Prime Ministers, widely discussed in advance, produced little or no effect on the stock markets today. Prices opened firm but later reacted and closed irregular in narrow pre-holiday trading.
WASHINGTON, April 6--Copper -base alloy ingots were placed under export quotas today by the Government.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 6 (AP) --The president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation today predicted a year of continuing high sales for the corporation along with rising new orders.
The first day of the strike at Vorkuta, about 300 soldiers were deployed around our camp gates in newly dug trenches. We could see the machine guns and mortars being put in place.

An increase last week of 1,125,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Intsitute. At the week-end, supplies were at a new high of 185,282,000 barrels, compared with 184,157,000 barrels a week earlier, the previous peak, and 179,674,000 a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Eisenhower is still saying maybe-he-will-and-maybe-he-won't oppose a Communist conquest of Quemoy and Matsu, but the atmosphere in which he must make this decision has changed radically.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6--Israel charged today that Egypt was embarked on a relentless siege of border violence that threatens the six-yearold Palestine armistice.
The thirty-year-old Town Hall Club gave up yesterday its battle to keep going. Evicted from its quarters at Town Hall and in debt for more than $19,000, the club began proceedings in bankruptcy.

Dr. Thomas Francis Jr. of the University of Michigan, who directed the independent evaluation of the Salk polio vaccine used in the 1954 field trial, will report his findings to physicians on a closed-circuit telecast next Tuesday.

LONG BEACH, Calif., April 6 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated, projected today a campaign in behalf of its prosecuted leader, Harry R. Bridges, extending to the White House and the United Nations.
LONDON, April 6--Sir Anthony Eden was appointed Prime Minister and First Lord of the Treasury today and a new era in the political life of Britain began.
The cooperation of more than thirty New York civic and trade associations has been pledged toward the success of the city's 1955 Summer Festival.
WHY is Harry Belafonte so magnificent in "3 For Tonight," which opened at the Plymouth last evening?

The use of radar to impede speeding has proved itself in many localities, and its forthcoming introduction into our city is welcome. Highway radar works in two ways, both subtle. It clocks car speeds electronically and it impresses motorists psychologically.
Two outstanding physicists disclosed yesterday that they had declined, after first having accepted, a Soviet invitation to a scientific meeting now under way in Moscow.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, April 7--A watchdog committee on Communist infiltration and subversion in Southeast Asia is being created by the Manila pact powers.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 6 --The Parliament of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg and the Belgian Senate approved today the Paris agreements on arming West Germany within the Atlantic alliance.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 6-- The Giants ran into some of Cleveland's high-powered pitching today and were brought up short.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents vate elementary and high scho of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Winners in the Golden Reel Festival of the American Film Assembly were anounced last night at a dinner in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. The second annual nontheatrical motion-picture convention will end its fiveday session tomorrow.

The National Association of Citizens Crime Commissions has thrown its moral support behind William J. Keating. He is under jail sentence for refusing to divulge to a grand jury his sources of information about the wiretap scandal.
Stocks pushed ahead to the best levels in a month yesterday and then receded, closing with modest gains.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 6 (AP) --Prince Eton scored his second successive victory, at Roosevelt Raceway tonight when he finished fast to take the one-mile Hempstead Pace by a length in 2:06 3-5. True Kitty was second and Dandy Dick third.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Harold E. Stassen went before the Senate Investigations subcommittee to shake hands and make up today. But peace seemed elusive.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)-- Carl W. McCardle, Assistant Secretary of State, said today it would be "an affront to Congress" to comment on a report that he would be named by Secretary, of States Dulles as the man who gave the Yalta papers to The New York Times.
Family councils, highly touted by "the experts" as the democratic way of reaching family decisions, are just so much wasted time in the opinion of at least one group of children.
WASHINGTON, April 6--New York City was described today as on the "borderline" of an adequate water supply.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Attorney General's National Committee to Study Antitrust Laws, although composed of "experts," seems to have renounced basic economies as applied to capitalism, notably in relation to price discrimination in commerce, at one point speaking slightingly of "a purely theoretical economic" interpretation of such discrimination.

Scott McLeod, administrator of the Refugee Relief Act, said on Jan. 13 that he doubted that the goal of 214,000 immigrants to be admitted under the program would be reached by the time the law expires at the end of next year. Less than a month later, in testimony that has just been made public, Mr. McLeod reversed his position and said he thought the goal could be achieved.

Sewell Avery, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., won assurance "yesterday of another 105,000 of the company's 6,700,000 shares being voted in his behalf at the annual stockholders' meeting on April 22. Louis E. Wolfson, financier, is conducting a proxy fight in an attempt to wrest control from Mr. Avery.

The do-it-yourself vogue is producing considerable advertising lineage. With this month set aside as National Hobby Month, sponsored by The Hobby Guild of America and National Do-ItYourself Week set for April 16 through 23, a goodly number of manufacturers are tying in.
Three top hat designers have left off making new bonnets long enough to tell readers how they may perk up their old ones. This information comes from Mr. John, Adolfo of Emme, and Gustavo.

LONDON, April 6--Sir Winston Churchill gave a farewell party at 10 Downing Street today for a hundred telephone operators, charwomen, guards and messengers who had served him in his years as Prime Minister.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles praised Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden today as a friend and statesman.

Saw-tooth charts of market price changes don't tell the whole story. Looked at through binoculars instead of reading glasses the ups and downs--in some instances at least--show a fairly steady long-range rise.
WASHINGTON, April 6--The Chief of Staff of the Air Force warned today that Communist air power had become the major threat to United States security.
A strong first-quarter rise in United States commercial exports may be sharply reversed during the remainder of the year, a trade group heard yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April, 6 -- Brazil today sank deeper into a political crisis. The crisis was caused by bargaining between the President of Brazil and the Governor of Sao Paulo over Presidential candidacies.

LONDON, April 6 (Reuters)-- Following is the text of Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden's address to the House of Commons today: I must first try to acknowledge the very generous terms which have been used by the right honorable gentleman, the leader of the Opposition, and all those who have spoken in the House this afternoon-- well deserved terms about my right honorable friend, the member for Woodford [Sir Winston Churchill].
WASHINGTON, April 6--The Pentagon is experiencing one of the greatest internecine battles since the big conflict over unification of the armed forces ended in 1947.
The United States Lines plans to purchase the South, Atlantic Steamship Line of Savannah, Ga.
PHILADELPHIA, April 6--A leading industrialist warned here tonight that the future of the American economy depended upon increased production by every available worker.
NEW DELHI, India, April 6-- A conference of Asian nations organized on a nonofficial basis opened here today.
LYNCHBURG, Va., April 6-- The S. P. C. M. L. (Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Minor Leagues) would do Well to investigate the reason for the presence here today of the Yankees.

American Tobacco Dollar sales and domestic unit cigarette sales of the American Tobacco Company were higher in January and February of this year than in the corresponding months of 1954, Paul M. Hahn, president, reported at the annual meeting in Flemington, N. J., yesterday.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 6 --America's newest atomic weapon, a mighty guided missile that could down a fleet of enemy bombers even with a miss, was exploded for the first time with a thunderous roar six miles over Nevada today.

JACKIE ROBINSON is a man with a fierce pride and a consuming will-to-win. He is one of baseball's finest competitors, but he never would rank as one of baseball's outstanding diplomats. Being an outspoken man who finds it congenitally impossible to do other than speak his mind, Jackie flared up against his manager, Walter Alston.

LONDON, April 6--Hugh M. Palin, director of the British Cycle and Motorcycle Manufacturers and Traders Union, sale today that it was "absolute nonsense" for American bicycle manufacturers to talk as if they had to fight for survival.

ALBANY, April 6--Governor Harriman faces a major political decision on his return here next week from a vacation in Florida. It could have an important bearing on his future relations with the Republican-controlled Legislature.

A new era dawned over Britain yesterday when Sir Anthony Eden succeeded Sir Winston Churchill as Prime Minister and began to shape the policies he will pursue. Inevitably he will labor at first under the shadow of his titanic predecessor.

St. Regis Paper Co. The St. Regis Paper Company has announced the acquisition, of all of the capital stock of Michigan Molded Plastics, Inc., Dexter, Mich The acquired concern, henceforth to be known as Michigan Panelyte Molded Plastics, Inc., will be part of St. Regis Paper's Panelyte division and will continue to operate under its present management.
WASHINGTON, April 6--A new kind of iron curtain, Pentagon model, is being tried out in Washington this week.
ST. LOUIS, April 6 (AP)-- Trusts in the estate of Joseph Pulitzer, for forty-three years editor and publisher of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, were established in his will filed today.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6--A contrast between golfers, young and old, was presented at the Augusta National Golf Club today.

MONTE CARLO, April 6 (UP) -- Art Larsen, Gardnar Mulloy and Budge Patty advanced today to the quarter-final round of men's singles in the Monte Carlo tennis tournament. Two other Americans, Hugh Stewart and Tony Vincent, were beaten.
GARRISON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., April 6--Ten-year-old Helen Chmela lives in a fortytwo-room, "broken-down castle on the top of a mountain here.
CLEVELAND, April 6--It's not easy to be a schoolteacher these days.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 6-- National officers of the Masters, Mates and Pilots of America, A. F. L., voted today to repudiate the recent action of their president in walking out of the conference of American maritime unions.

BOSTON, April 6 (AP)--The Weather Bureau issued today the following forecasts and listed these conditions as received from operators of ski areas: NEW HAMPSHIRE Forecast-Partly cloudy tomorrow, with daytime temperatures in the 40's.

BERLIN, April 6--Plans are being drafted by the forthcoming United States Antarctic expedition to make an airstrip near Little America so that some of the heaviest planes in existence can land with wheels on snow 800 feet deep.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) --The Defense Department told today how it was curtailing or stopping its coffee roasting, ice making, tree growing and rope manufacturing.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (HP) --Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's new expedition to the Antarctic next November will be used to train United States military men in cold weather supply, construction and flight operations, the Defense Department said today.

A biography of Sir Anthony Eden by Alan Campbell Johnson will be published by Ives Washburn next month. The author has been working on the manuscript a year. He will emphasize Sir Anthony's political role from 1923, when he first entered Parliament, to the present.
LOS ANGELES, April 6--A battle for control of the Los Angeles Board of Education was in a temporary stalmate today as the result of a municipal election yesterday.

The answers to the gloomy prophets of doom as to New York's future come in installments, but gathered together they are impressive, cheerful and reassuring. Yesterday's installment was the news story reporting that a $30,000,000 office tower building, of thirty-five floors, would be built at Park Avenue and Fifty-third Street, occupying almost an entire block.

The Transit Authority hedged yesterday on its decision to discontinue service on the Third Avenue elevated on May 12. One member of the five-man board held that it had received a "mandate" from the State Legislature to continue operation.

WASHINGTON, April 6--The Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting a national campaign to stem what J. Edgar Hoover, its director, calls "a rise of feverish proportions" in the number of bank robberies.
PHILADELPHIA, April 6--A ntional committee of Mayors is being formed to fight Federal decontrol of natural gas prices.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 6--Combining a thirteenhit attack with seven Princeton errors, the Rutgers baseball team defeated the Tigers today, 13--4. Wally Olson limited the visitors to three hits while going the route for the Scarlet.

WASHINGTON, April 6 --The Fourteenth Amendment is the law in Maryland as in the rest of the Union, but it still lacks the formal approval of the "Free state." At the legislative session in Annapolis, just concluded, a proposal that Maryland formally approve the amendment, which it declined to do in 1867, was rejected by the State Senate.
Yesterday was a good day for robbers and a bad one for honest men.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Times gave excellent coverage on April 1 to Dr. Charles P. Larson's talk on the importance of replacing "political coroners" with a well-organized medical examiner program for purposes of crime detection.
CAIRO, April 7--The EgyptianSudanese negotiations on partition of the Nile River waters broke down today in a dispute that endangered the vital irrigation projects.
Proceeds from the sale of antiques at the Opportunity Shop booth at next week's New York Antiques Fair will go to the Community Service Society, a private, nonsectarian family and health agency here.

The industrial property at 5761 Front Street in Brooklyn, known as the Zarega Building, has been purchased by Nat Freedman, real estate operator. Joseph Schreck Co. were the sellers and the transaction was negotiated by William DeGoods and Dallas Smith as brokers.

LONDON, April 7 -- Harold Macmillan was named Foreign Secretary and Selwyn Lloyd replaced him as Minister of Defense in the two most important of the eleven ministerial changes announced by Prime Minister Eden tonight.
LONDON, April 7--A theatrical producer casting an Edwardian Guards officer would go no further than Harold Macmillan, Britain's new Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.

MONTREAL, April 7 (UP)-- Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion scored three times tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in the third game of the Stanley Cup hockey finals before 13,572 fans at the Forum.
Beardsley Ruml, New York financier, joined Mayor Wagner yesterday in an appeal for funds with which to educate qualified Puerto Ricans in New York City.
MILAN, Italy, April 6--The people of Milan are preparing to see a battle of two giants in their city and region.
TOPEKA, Kan., April 7-- Movie censorship will end in Kansas June 30.

Although chicken costs more this year than at any Easter since 1951, ham, eggs and turkeys are unusually thrifty buys. Ham has not been so cheap in eight years, reports a major chain, and eggs are the lowest for any Easter since 1950.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 7-- Metin Toker, independent editor and critic of the Government Was sentenced to nine months and ten days in prison today on charges of slandering Dr. Mukerrem Sarol, Minister of State.
WASHINGTON, April 7--Walter P. Reuther expects the guaranteed annual wage to be adopted by industry generally and to be regarded as an aid to economic stability.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 28 -- A technical establishment financed by the United States will begin work soon on the problems of air defense. The Supreme Allied Commander in Europe recently called this "probably our major weakness."

Martin Mayer, author of "The Experts," a novel that was published in February, has a work of non-fiction on Harper's list for April 27. Titled "Wall Street: Men and Money," the book discusses the stock exchanges and brokers, the over-the-counter market, underwriters and other facets of finance.
WASHINGTON, April 7--The Army Engineers announced completion today of Boulhaut Air Base, the last of a complex of four Strategic Air Command bomber bases in French Morocco.

EDGEWATER, N. J., April 7--The unusually chilly spring is being blamed by Hudson River shad fishermen for the late spawning run of the silver-sided fish. With the Lenten season ending Saturday the time when the demand drops appreciably, shad catches for the last week have been running about one-third lighter than normal at this time of year.

BONN, April 7--Official reports indicate that state capitalism is the most important single factor in West Germany's heavy industries. This has given rise to a movement, among industrialists to induce the Parliament to liquidate the Republic's industrial holdings.
WASHINGTON, April 7--Department store sales last week were 11 per cent higher than in the corresponding week of last year.

TRENTON, April 7--Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, today asked State Auditor Frank Durand, Republican, to investigate "reports of irregularities" in the office of the Superintendent of Elections n. Hudson County.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday gained 13 to 18 points after overcoming early weakness.

DIMITRI MTTROPOULOS evidently believes that Mahler's Sixth Symphony is a work of towering stature. He conducted it in its American premiere in 1947 and he returned to it last night at Carnegie Hall even though he must know that at least part of the public resists these lengthy symphonies.

PITTSBURGH. April 7 (AP)-- A former Army lieutenant, Aldo Icardi, accused by the Italian Government of the World War II slaying of his superior officer, was arrested today. He was charged with trying to influence a witness in a Federal court trial.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 7 (AP)--Shelly Mann, a 17-yearold high school senior from Arlington, Va., opened the National Amateur Athletic Union women's indoor swimming meet with a double victory today.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 7-- West Coast seamen have chosen an American Federation of Labor union as their bargaining representative.

WASHINGTON, April 7--The Atomic Energy Commission today announced plans by four private and public groups to build demonstration nuclear reactor plants capable of producing 455,000 kilowatts of electrical power.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 7-- A dissident faction of the Social Democratic party has formally chosen Etelvino Lins, former Governor of Pernambuco, as its candidate for President. He will presumably have the backing of a group of forces opposed to Juscelino Kubitschek for the Presidency.
BUENOS AIRES, April 7-- About 150,000 Roman Catholics defied the police today in a gesture commonly accepted as support for the Church in its difficulties with the Government.
Representatives of major trucking interests and Eastern railroads denied yesterday that an agreement had been reached to withdraw a $250,000,000 suit against the roads.

The Kingdom of Norway registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday an issue of $15,000,000 of external loan bonds payable in United States dollars. The issue would be offered publicly in this market around April 20 by a syndicate of investment houses headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., Lazard Freres Co. and Smith, Barney Co.
The nation's leading scientific body will undertake a "broad appraisal of present knowledge about the effects of atomic radiation on living organisms."

The seven major New York newspapers are enlarging their linage gains over 1954 as this year goes on. A compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures indicated that the papers had 39,170,753 lines of advertising in the first quarter, against 35,822,615 lines for the 1954 period.
ICE-OUT is only a matter of a a few days on several New Brunswick rivers that will be open to spring salmon fishing as soon as the waters are clear.
ALBANY, April 7 -- Nearly $2,000,000 has been made available by the Legislature for special studies and investigations of state problems and operations.
LISBON, Portugal, April 7-- Portuguese legislators have asked the Government to improve the living conditions of workers who, they say, are victims of "social injustice."
MOSCOW, April 7--So far as the Soviet Union is concerned, Sir Winston Churchill's long career as a British Government leader and international statesman has ended on a sour note.

The Third Avenue El has been dying on its wheels, and the sooner it is put out of its misery the better. It is a costly, noisy, unsightly nuisance, of transportation value to a rapidly diminishing number of New Yorkers. They are diminishing so rapidly, in fact, that only 70,000 fares are now collected daily --representing a mere 35,000 individual round trips.
The writer of the following letter is director of the Institute of Far Eastern Studies, Seton Hall University. He was formerly a legislator of the Republic of China.
On record net sales of $24,923,415 Coro, Inc., fashion jewelry manufacturer, last year realized a 32 per cent increase in consolidated net income. The 1954 earn-

The statement issued here by the National Academy of Sciences on its proposed study of atomic radiation follows: The National Academy of Sciences will undertake a broad appraisal of present knowledge about the effects of atomic radiation on living organisims and will seek to identify questions upon which further intensive research is urgently needed, it was announced by Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of the National Academy.

Boiling the Egg Glance at the mail order catalogue, or along the household gadget counter of a department store, and you will come upon an unnerving thing. Displayed there for all to see, and presumably for all to buy, are innumerable devices to aid in the boiling of eggs.
A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" on the night of April 19 at the Morosco Theatre for the benefit of the Fountain House Foundation.

Loans to business by twenty leading New York City banks declined $80,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday. This was the second weekly decline in a row and the largest drop this year, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

John H. White Jr. has been elected president of the Uranium Corporation of America, filling the vacancy created by the resignation of Ramon N. Bowman. Mr. White formerly was president of Climax Molybdenum Company of Pennsylvania, a subsidiary of Climax Molybdenum Company.

DONT look now but the baseball season is so close that you can almost reach out and touch it. The Dodgers and Yankees return to home territory this week-end, playing against each other at Ebbets Field tomorrow and at the Stadium on Sunday. After that the deluge. Yep. The season opens in New York on Tuesday.

BERN, Switzerland, April 7 (AP) --The Swiss Government published today a wartime letter from President Roosevelt asking the Swiss to cease trading with Germany and "deprive the Nazis of further assistance."

CHICAGO, April 7 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department at Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,500 head: market moderately active and uneven: butchers under 230 pounds barely steady, others steady to strong: weights over 300 pounds and sows steady to 25 cents higher: most choice
This is the time of year when little girls home from the circus dream of growing up to become glamorous stars in spangles and tights, performing feats of daring while crowds applaud.
An error that let in two runs cost Columbia its baseball game with Rutgers at Baker Field yesterday. The Scarlet, playing its third game in three days, won, 5 to 3.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 7 --Greater love hath no man than to lay himself down across the railroad tracks for a friend. That is the way a 25-year-old laboratory technician got a friend aboard a Manhattan-bound Long Island Rail Road train here early today.

NEWARK, April 7--A railroad detective was ushering three teen-agers off the Erie Railroad track at the Verona crossing here this afternoon when he was attacked from behind with an eleven-foot bullwhip.

The electron is doing more to revolutionize American industry than atomic energy. Automation --the harnessing of electronic brains to mechanical muscles-- is making normal concepts of mass production obsolete.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 7 --The Giants and the Indians brought their 3,000-mile "spring world series" tour to a close today with an equal division of the spoils.

Two commuter trains of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad were twenty-one and thirty minutes late, respectively, yesterday in leaving Grand Central Terminal toward the end of the evening rush hour.

The leading engineering societies should be convinced by now of the sincerity and fervor of New York City's desire to keep them here. Their headquarters building on West Thirty-ninth Street having become inadequate, the half-dozen societies looking for a new home have been, wooed from afar by other cities.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Jove must have nodded when your editorial writer, under the heading "State University Tuition," advocates that the municipal colleges of New York City abandon their hundred-year-old tradition of free higher education.
A paroled slayer was being sought last night for questioning about Wednesday's $305,243 bank hold-up in Queens.

New Yorkers' gifts to the Greater New York Fund last year are helping 3,000,000 of their fellow citizens. John A. Coleman, chairman of the board of the fund, noted in his annual report, issued yesterday, that these gifts totaled a record $6,280,000.

The leading feminine role in "The Dazzling Hour" is being weighed by Celeste Holm. By the end of next week, Gilbert Miller expects to know whether it is suitable for her. A. Broadway production of Ann Bonacci's Parisian success, adapted by Nancy Mitford, is scheduled for next season.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 340 East Fifty-seventh Street has been sold by the Egoro Corporation of America, Edward Wallach, president, to Stanley Stahl for investment. It occupies a plot 116 by 72 feet and contains sixty apartments with three and four rooms.

BONN, Germany, April 6--A federal Defense Council and a Defense Minister responsible to Parliament have been suggested by the Free Democrats. The plan for these is part of the machinery to insure civilan control of the future West German armed forces.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 7 (AP) --Stanley Dancer drove Bear Cat to victory in the one-mile Roslyn Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:06.

A petite woman, physician from India is making the rounds of the patients at the New York Infirmary this year. An interne from Benares, Dr. Kaushalya Sanwal fits into the huge organization neatly. She is never nonplused by methods or equipment in use here, she said yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 7--Eveningup operations for the long weekend comprised a good share of the grain and soybean Trading here today. Wheat was stronger, as the April Government report due on Monday is expected to be fairly bullish.
DETROIT, April 7--The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., began today one of the most crucial labor-management negotiations in the history of the auto industry.

DETROIT, April 7 (UP)--Gov. G. Mermen Williams ordered the state police today to "locate" every ballot box from the closefought state elections Tuesday. Another state official said a recount was "certain" in the only two partisan races the Democrats lost.

The First National Bank of Yonkers sold its building at 928 McLean Avenue in Yonkers to Benjamin Kuchnick and then took back a twenty-five-year lease with two twenty-five-year renewal options. The two-story structure contains the bank's office and stores.

Average stock prices were virtually unchanged in March, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday. Using only shares listed both at the end of February and the end of March, the Exchange found a drop of only 0.34 per cent, from $54.27 to $54.09.
An aluminum equestrian group, one of the largest yet cast in that metal, will begin today a 3,100-mile journey from Jersey City to Madrid.

Dean Rusk, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, announced new appointments and changes in organization yesterday. The main effect will be to eliminate previous divisional units and to place responsibility for the foundation program in the hands of five directors.
A week-old strike of 33,000 workers in nineteen plants of the United States Rubber Company ended last night.

WASHINGTON, April 7--Next Tuesday Senator Hennings of Missouri will open hearings before his subcommittee on Privileges and Elections in an effort to get fuller disclosure of the amounts spent in the process of choosing the holders of elective federal office.
LONDON, April 7--Trading was small before the Easter holidays, but the stock market closed firm today.

There is good reason for the Manila Pact Powers to set up a "watchdog" committee under the Bangkok Secretariat. The Southeast Asian countries pledged themselves to continuous consultation and action, if necessary, within their respective constitutional limits, to meet not only external aggression but internal subversion.
WASHINGTON, April 7--Harold E. Stassen's on-again-offagain quarrel with the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations was today mostly off-again.

THE three City Fathers whose combined 635 pounds gave them some discomfort in a small taxicab on Tuesday are as babes in arms to the staff in Sig Klein's Fat Men's Shop in Third Avenue between Tenth and Eleventh Street.

RICHMOND, Va., April 7-- The jump from Class B to triple A did not slow down the Yankees today. They trounced the Richmond Virginians of the International League, 17--4, as easily as they had crushed the Piedmont League's Lynchburg Cardinals, 19--2, the day before.
Solemn services commemorating the Crucifixion will be held today in churches throughout New York.
Edward Corsi, a liberal Republican of many years' standing, was Governor Dewey's State Industrial Commissioner from December, 1943, until the end of his Administration last year.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- The broadcasting industry struck back today at critics who say TV underworld thrillers are leading youthful viewers into crime.
The mercury dipped early today to the freezing mark, but the weather on Sunday is expected to be fair and "seasonable" for the Easter paraders.

PARIS, Friday, April 8--The texts of the laws authorizing the French President to sign the Paris agreements bringing West Germany into the Atlantic alliance and establishing West German sovereignty were published today in the Official Journal.
WEDNESDAY night's television version of "Stage Door" was a rapidly paced, sometimes ragged but generally entertaining production.

The classrooms' loss will be Macy's gain next week. Freed from school for their spring holidays, the city's youngsters have been invited by the Herald Square store to take part in a six-day festival that will offer them the chance--among other opportunities -- to catch their own goldfish in a "mountain stream," eat free cupcakes, learn to make brownies, shoot pool and try their skill as disk jockies with professionals to coach them.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., April 7-- The Mellon family pledged a new gift of $500,000 today for scientific research as an added incentive to the major engineering societies of the United States to locate their national headquarters here.

BOSTON, April 7 -- The Weather Bureau this afternoon issued the fololwing forecasts and list of conditions furnished by the operators in the ski areas: NEW HAMPSHIRE Forecast--Fair weather tomorrow with temperatures rising from below freezing levels in the morning to the forties over lower elevations in the afternoon.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 7 (AP)-- Four new steps in fighting cancers --three by X-rays and one by a hormone--were reported today by scientists of the University of Minnesota.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 7 --The output of steel and coal in Western Europe last month was far greater than it ever has been before.
"Monitor," a round-the-clock week-end radio feature, will make its debut June 12.

LONDON, April 7 (Reuters) --Following is the list of British Cabinet members following changes announced tonight by Sir Anthony Eden, the new Prime Minister: Prime Minister and First Lord of the Treasury--Sir Anthony Eden.
Trading on the New York commodity exchanges was dull yesterday, on the eve of the three-day week-end. Most of the volume was limited to evening of holdings.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7-- With a five-under-par 67, Jack Burke took a four-stroke lead in the opening round of the Masters golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, April 7--President Eisenhower completed today ratification of the Paris pacts. These give sovereignty to West Germany and arm that country in concert with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 7 (UP) --The Fort Wayne Pistons withstood a last-period rally by the Syracuse Nationals for a 74-71 victory tonight to take a 3-2 lead in games in the final National Basketball Association play-offs.
A threatened strike on Monday of 2,000 deckhands and officers on ferries and carfloats of eleven railroads operating here, appeared to be headed off yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused for a second time to halt its investigation into whether control of the Boston and Maine Railroad may possibly pass to interests associated with the New York, New Haven and Hartford.
WASHINGTON, April 7-- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $403,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced plans yesterday for its largest financing operation.
Gas, as a fuel, continues to gain favor. February sales of gas by the utility and pipeline industry reached 7,591,000,000 therms, which was 22.7 per cent more than the volume in the 1954 month.

WASHINGTON, April 7-- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 659,059 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 19,612 cars, or 3.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 59,757 cars, or 10 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 45,458 cars, or 6.5 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 7--Concrete encouragement came from the Federal Reserve System today for a growing revival in the use of bankers' acceptances-- handy credit instruments of particular value to foreign traders.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 --Rita Hayworth and Columbia Pictures were involved today in a new contract dispute, ending the three months' armistice since their last prolonged controversy.

Bill Crowley, making his debut as a varsity starter, pitched Fordham to a 3-to-0 victory over City College on the Rams' diamond in the Bronx yesterday. The triumph was the season's third for the unbeaten Maroon.
MOSCOW, April 7--Secretary of State Dulles was charged here today with seeking to delay a conference of the Big Four powers.

LISBON, Portugal, April 7-- Portuguese military authorities in Goa and other Portuguese territories in India have standing instructions to shoot if India attempts to annex the territories by armed force.
WASHINGTON, April 7--Reestablishment of Government controls over its use would precede any action releasing stockpiled copper for civilian purposes, defense officials said today.
Brazil's political crisis is a more than likely to have adverse effects on United States exports.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 7-- A Government spokesman said tonight Premier Ngo Dinh Diem was not likely to wait six days before acting against the dissident Binh Xuyen army in this city.
A plan to redevelop a rundown area of twenty-five acres north of Columbus Circle has been drafted by the Mayor's Slum Clearance Committee.

Edwin Holton's Trisong made it look easy as she won the feature race at the Jamaica track yesterday. With Hedley Woodhouse guiding her, the 4year-old daughter of Spy Song had a margin of almost two lengths at the finish of the sixfurlong test.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- State Department officials explained that the department made two types of appointments --ninety-day appointments, which precede security check, and regular appointments, which are not announced until the security check had been completed.

EUDORA WELTY, the Mississippi marvel, is one of the most brilliantly gifted and one of the most disappointing of modern authors. Ever since her first collection of short stories, "A Curtain of Green," burst upon the literary scene in 1941 Miss Welty's position as the second most important writer in her native state has been uncontested.

WASHINGTON, April 7--Every work day is a church day in the Pentagon. On the top floor of the great structure in which nearly 30,000 persons are concerned with the problems of defense, hundreds gather every day for prayer.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)-- A Senate Banking subcommittee received testimony today for and against a bill to limit cumulative voting in the election of directors for national banks.
WASHINGTON, April 7--Edward Corsi said today he had been advised he would be dismissed Sunday from his post as special assistant to Secretary of State Dulles on refugee and immigration problems.
A general slowdown on the Brooklyn waterfront is expected today as longshoremen obey an order for strict observance of the working contract.

GENEVA, April 7 (AP)--The first stage of the arbitration in the tanker dispute between Saudi Arabia and the Arabian American Oil Company (Aramco) has ended after two weeks of delicate negotiations without agreement.
New York City is as good a place as any to investigate the case of the disappearing dining room.

WASHINGTON, April 7--The State Department's Office for International Exchange reported today its activities for the six months ending last June 30. It said 3,882 persons from seventysix countries were brought to the United States to study, teach, do research, gain practical experience and observe American life.

CHICAGO, April 7--A full scale twenty-four-hour test o Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company's underground storage field near Herscher, Ill., was made last month with highly successful results, James F. Oates, Jr., chairman, disclosed today al the company's annual stockholders' meeting.
W. R. Grace Co. is planning a public sale of up to $30,000,000 of twenty-year convertible debentures. It would be the first public financing by the company since its corporation fifty-six years ago.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 7-- Chile's inflation continues unabated, and there are no signs that any elements in the Government, the Congress, industry or labor are doing anything about it.
Record sales of $274,500,282 were achieved last year by M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., despite lower prices. The previous sales high of the textile organization was set in 1953 at $268,187,763.
NEWARK, April 7--A Federal grand jury will begin on Monday an investigation of New Jersey's 'on - again - off - again" gasoline price war.

WASHINGTON, April 7--Although both teams worked out until dark, the game between the Washington Senators and the Brooklyn Dodgers scheduled for Griffith Stadium tonight was called off because of cold weather.
HONG KONG, April 7--The official Chinese Communist party newspaper rejected today the British idea of a plebiscite to solve the Formosa issue.

WASHINGTON, April 7-- The State Department checked through its files today and discovered it had at least thirtytwo unused and almost forgotten treaties for the promotion of peace, including one with Russia.

Mayor Wagner deserves support in his latest move in the battle against the dirt of New York--the coming appointment of a committee of outstanding private citizens to organize an intensive campaign of public education for a cleaner city. Since the start of the administration's all-out effort against litter, the emphasis has been--as it should be--on enforcement of the law.

The symbolic meaning of Passover was coupled in sermons here yesterday with democracy's efforts to preserve liberty throughout the world. Rabbis also called for support of Israel's position in the Middle East as a democratic nation.

Chemicals, neglected by stock buyers since the start of the year, joined rails yesterday in leading the market into higher ground. Despite weakness in aircrafts, The New York Times' combined average climbed 1.09 points to 280.96.
SPOKANE, Wash., April 7-- Education officials were called upon today to rid the publicschool system of emotionally disturbed, "obsolete" teachers.
WASHINGTON, April 8--The Administration told the Commerce Department today to take a "second look" at its decision to continue restrictions on the export of iron and steel scrap.
WASHINGTON, April 8--A demand for the removal of Edward F. Howrey as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission was made today by the National Federation of Independent Business.

WASHINGTON, April 8--The General Motors Corporation obtained an important patent on the automatic choke this week--twenty-three years, three months and twentyseven days after the application was filed.
Special services marking the dawn of Easter will be conducted tomorrow in many of the open spaces of the country and in theatres.

Bernard Gimbel is a small-town boy who not only made good in New York City, but also did good. It is a pleasure to salute him on his seventieth birthday, which occurs tomorrow. As a merchant his name is, of course, a retail by-word here and in many a city.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 8 (AP)--Plans for two atomic explosions tomorrow were made by nuclear weapons testers after a forecast today indicated clearing weather.

WASHINGTON, April 8-- President Eisenhower tackled today a task that defeated all his predecessors in the twentieth century. The job is to provide suitable and adequate White House space for the Executive Office, both at present and for the future.
Mrs. Helen Rogers Reid resigned yesterday as chairman of the board of The New York Herald Tribune but will continue as a board member.

HONOLULU, April 8--Communist China is now strong enough to take the offshore islands from Chiang Kai-shek unless the United States intervenes. However, the tiny territories involved have little strategic importance. Therefore, should the United States gamble on such intervention and assume it would not provoke Soviet reaction and World War III?

Exploratory work conducted for the proposed Mountain Sheep and Pleasant Valley dams on the Snake River have turned out better than expected, Kinsey Robinson, president of the Pacific Northwest Power Company, reported yesterday at Spokane, Wash.
A thousand banks were put up for over-the-counter sale last week through a clearing house in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
DANVILLE, Va., April 8--The pinch home run, a weapon the Giants used with deadly effect last year, is still working in excellent order for them.
BRISTOL, N. H., April 8 (UP) --A teen-age couple, trapped since Wednesday night in a halfsubmerged motor car in the frigid Smith. River, were rescued by firemen today and rushed to a hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- The chairman of the House Agriculture Committee said today it "is not in any hurry" about considering bills seeking to raise marketing quotas for domestic cane and beet sugar.

Like understudies watching their stars perform, thirteen teen-agers had their eyes fixed on United Nations delegates in debate this week. After five days of sessions and briefings, they will go home to Indianapolis to enact similar roles at a junior United Nations meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) --Attorney General Herbert Brownell announced today that an anti-trust indictment had been returned against the National Cranberry Association of Hanson, Mass., and others, charging conspiracy to suppress competition.
The proposed slum clearance to provide a Manhattan campus for Fordham University north of Columbus Circle is awaiting Federal approval of a $200,000 grant to make a study of the project.

BOWIE, Md., April 8 (AP) -- Four of the East Coast's best handicap thoroughbreds will race tomorrow in the John B. Campbell Memorial Handicap. They are Helioscope, Fisherman, Social Outcast and Joe Jones.

JERSEY CITY, April 8--The use of women in crime detection work, the introduction of lie detector tests and the establishment of a nation-wide police radio network are some of the recommendations that fourteen Egyptian police officials will take back to their country.
MOSCOW, April 8--For the first time since the pre-World War II years, a foreign airline has started regularly scheduled flights in and out of the Soviet Union.

The sixth at Jamaica yesterday was a happy little number for Jess Higley. The score on the Belair Stud's Golden Gloves was the first for the 39-year-old jockey since he suffered a broken leg in a workout-hours accident at Aqueduct last July.
VANCOUVER, B. C., April 8 --Communist control of the executive bodies of important unions in British Columbia is causing increasing concern to responsible labor leaders.

Tomorrow's Easter parade may not be held under sunny skies after all. The Weather Bureau, which had been predicting sunny and mild weather, began to hedge a bit yesterday afternoon. The outlook now is for some cloudiness and warmer. The temperature is expected to exceed today's, when a high of 55 to 60 is expected.
The taxpayer and his money are not soon parted, tax collectors reported yesterday.
Purchases of realty for investment formed the bulk of realty trading reported yesterday in Manhattan.

The management of the Boston and Maine Railroad yesterday denounced as "misleading" statements sent to the railroad's shareholders in a proxy letter of the Stockholders Committee in Opposition to the Management.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP)--The Allstate Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck Co., has thrown its support to the management side in the proxy battle for control of Montgomery Ward Co. The Ward's annual meeting will be held two weeks from today.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- Railroad earnings more than doubled in the first two months of this year compared with the same period a year ago, the Association of American Railroads said today.

Today, for many men, women and children, the continual pressures of politics, work and onerous school tasks will be firmly put aside, for this is the opening day of the fishing season. Today, and for days to come, they will be happily splashing about in streams and ponds that still retain winter's chill.

The Mystery Writers of America have established a special prize to be presented to the book publisher whose art department has created the best jacket for a mystery novel. The award will be in the form of the "Raven" prize given in fields outside the writing of mysteries.
There are indications that the Soviet Government bought last year close to $200,000 worth of American books and magazines dealing with scientific and technical progress.

Small boys are not alone in their fondness for popcorn and crackerjack. Peacocks and elephants like them too, according to William Bridges, curator of publications at the Bronx Zoo. Elephants are also partial to ice cream and are "the greatest beggars in this zoo," he says.

M. and Mme. Jacques Devys of Paris have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie-Claude Devys, to Stephen B. Rubel. He is a son of Mme. Andre Rubel of 1070 Park Avenue, formerly of Paris, and the late M. Rubel.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8--With a spectacular 65, Cary Middlecoff took a four-stroke lead in the Masters golf tournament today.
New York churchgoers by the thousands paid tribute yesterday to the Crucified Christ as they filled and refilled midtown churches for the solemn Good Friday Three Hours service from noon to 3 P. M.
TODAY is the occasion for the major angling ceremony of the year, and the streams of eastern and southern New York hold bright prospects for the anglers attending the opening of the trout season.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- The Customs Bureau today announced regulations under which it will determine the fair value of imported merchandise in considering "dumping" charges.

JERUSALEM, April 4 -- Excavation of Herodian buildings on Masada, the fortress rock that towers 1,200 feet above the Wilderness of Jeshimon, is being planned following return here of leaders of an archaeological survey expedition.
JERUSALEM, April 8 (AP)-- Christian pilgrims of many nations marched on the Way of the Cross through the cobblestoned streets of Jerusalem today.

The writers of the following letter are respectively minister of The Community Church of New York and member of the Social Science Faculty at Brooklyn College. The latter was a bombing analyst for the War Department on the United States Strategic Bombing Survey at the end of World War II.

MOSCOW, April 8--Throughout the Soviet Union a campaign is under way to stamp out immorality among Communist party members in particular and Soviet citizens in general. Especially being condemned are cads and bounders, bigamists and alimony dodgers who desert their wives and children and betray unsuspecting maidens.

BONN, Germany, April 8-- The West German Government has contended before the Federal constitutional court that the tribunal has no right to pass on the constitutionality of the Saar agreement. This agreement in effect gives the Saar a semiautonomous status.

George Heron, at 61, still has a pomegranate pink in his cheeks. When he came to this country in 1922 to take the job as golf pro at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury, L. I., he had a sly smile and a burr in his speech.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., postponed yesterday a strike set for Monday against eleven railroads that operate passenger ferries or freight-car floats in New York Harbor.
Telephone threats have been received by some employes of the Queens bank that was robbed Wednesday of $305,243, telling them they had "better keep your trap shut if you know what is good for you."

Rice may become an important weapon in this country's fight against the spread of communism in the Far East. Administration officials are reported to be seeking methods of using our surplus rice to counter Red China's determined effort to win the major Indian and Japanese rice markets away from Burma and Thailand -- nations friendly to the United States.

BOSTON, April 8--The Boston Weather Bureau today issued the following forecasts and list of conditions furnished by the operators of the ski areas: NEW HAMPSHIRE Forecast--Tomorrow partly cloudy and somewhat warmer with temperatures

LONDON, April 8--The British Broadcasting Corporation retracted today a statement attributed in its last night's news bulletin to the Archbishop of Canterbury. He was reported yesterday to have said on his arrival in South Africa that there was "no truth" to the rumored engagement of Princess Margaret and Group Captain Peter Townsend.

Major league baseball--or a reasonable facsimile thereof-- will return to this city today after an absence of more than six months. The scene of action will be Ebbets Field, with the Dodgers opposing the Yankees in the opener of a two-game home-and-home exhibition series that will conclude the pre-season training activities of both clubs.

St. Louis, April 8 (UP)--Ralph (Tiger) Jones of Yonkers scored a technical knockout over George Johnson of Trenton after 2 minutes 1 second of the fifth in a scheduled ten-round middleweight fight tonight.

Elia Kazan, currently represented on Broadway by two plays and two movies and certainly deserving of a well-earned vacation, nevertheless will be devoting some time to scouting stage and film material on his visit to Southeast Europe.
An 11 - year - old girl was in Flushing Hospital and her mother was in jail last night because the child fell while escaping from her Queens home at 1 P. M., yesterday.
There's a young patient uptown who is going to be aging rapidly if festivities continue as usual in his hospital ward. He is Robert Brown, at the Hospital for Joint Diseases, and his problem is this:
Two experts on food offer today a menu for home bridge luncheons and similar gatherings of women. The menu is springlike, unusual and not too taxing on the home cook.
WASHINGTON, April 8--Secretary of State Dulles offered regrets and a new job to Edward J. Corsi today and politely dismissed him as immigration expediter.
A store in New York can be a baby - sitter, chef or angel of mercy. It will pack your trunks for you, throw a shower party and keep track of the women in men's lives.

A few tickets are still available for the Wednesday evening performance of "3 For Tonight" for the benefit of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. The musical revue, with Marge and Gower Champion and Harry Belafonte, is at the Plymouth Theatre.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N, J., April 8 -- The venerable radio transmitting station on Canal Road here is at last going out of existence. Built in 1913 by the Marconi Wireless Telegraph Company of America, it once was this country's most powerful trans-Atlantic station.
CHICAGO, April 8--Adlai E. Stevenson will give a major foreign policy speech by radio Monday night.
In the roomy recesses of Columbia University is a towering skylighted room that apparently had not been serving any useful purpose until an artist with a space problem discovered it.

Her name was actually Theodosia Goodman and she was born in Cincinnati and not, as rumor had it, in the Sahara Desert, or, for that matter, any other desert. She made up the name Theda Bara by shortening Theodosia and adding one of the names of her maternal grandfather, Francis Bara de Coppet.
ATLANTA, April 8 (UP)--Local authorities in Alabama today asked Gov. James E. Folsom to send National Guard troops to Birmingham, the scene of repeated labor strife.
ALBANY, April 8--A rabid cat named Fluffy brought the Mayor of a Rockland County village on a hurried 125-mile flight to Albany with a precious cargo today.

CAIRO, April 8--The resignation of Premier Fazlollah Zahedi of Iran and the appointment of Hussein Ala as his successor seem to this correspondent, who formerly covered that country, to have increased the political power of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.
The St. Regis Paper Company has arranged to acquire the Pollock Paper Corporation through an exchange of stock, according to Roy K. Ferguson, chairman of St. Regis.

ELEVEN painters and a sculptor are represented in the current group exhibition at the Riverside Museum. Guest artists include Franz Kline (big black symbols like scaffolding), Milton Avery (gentle lyrical expressionist landscapes) and Kenzo Okada (lyrical color in abstract canvases).
Easter shoppers in the New York area probably won't buy quite as much this year as they did in 1954, merchants predicted yesterday.

YOUNG America took over Carnegie Hall last night. About a hundred young men and women, members of the University of Michigan Symphony Band, crowded the stage and rocked the hall with some of the most enthusiastic --and also best integrated-- band music heard hereabouts in some time.

LONDON, April 8 (Reuters)-- The race for the first division championship in English soccer tightened today when Chelsea, the league leader, was held to a 1-1 draw by Sheffield United. Today's program opened a threeday series of Easter week-end games.
A small woman wielding a stapling machine and other tools yesterday routed an armed robber.

Scientific opinion is not unanimous on the effects of the devastating blast, the intense heat and the powerful radiation that accompany the explosion of an atomic bomb. Hence the need of the broad appraisal that the National Academy of Sciences will undertake, with financial support from the Rockefeller Foundation.

NEWARK, April 8--Fanned by a gusty wind, a four-alarm fire raged out of control for ninety minutes in Port Newark today. It sank three barges, destroyed a fire truck and caused serious damage to a 1,000-foot pier.
PARIS, April 8--A FrenchGerman industrial project related to the Western European Union will be ready to function when the Paris agreements have been ratified by all the nations in the union.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest your editorial "Emergency in Pakistan" which appeared March 29. Being a Pathan (Pushtun) by race, I could not suppress the urge to write and explain to you that patriotic sentiments and ethnic aspirations cannot be legislated or decreed out of existence.

TAIPEI, Formosa, April 8-- Nationalist China announced tonight that the Chinese Communists were operating a jet fighter-bomber base at Lukiao, about 220 miles northwest of Formosa. It is on the mainland just opposite the Tachen Islands.

As a reply to critics of children's television programs, the National Broadcasting Company has created the industry's first Children's Program Review Committee. Its function, according to N. B. C. spokesmen, will be to maintain "high program standards for the millions of youngsters who watch television."
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- The Post Office Department said today that military mail flown to the Far East on the Great Circle air route from Seattle might be increased gradually.

WASHINGTON, April 8-- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent in the week ended April 5 to 110.3 (1947-49 equals 100) according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The decreases in average prices for farm products and processed foods were responsible for the decline.
WASHINGTON, April 8--The Defense Department announced today it would issue "relevant" information on the Soviet Union's entry into the Pacific war.
SPOKANE, Wash., April 8-- School teachers of the Northwest cannot be blamed if they leave here confused.

MILAN, Italy, April 8--Msgr. Giovanni Battista Montini, Archbishop of Milan, could not have chosen a more favorable moment than now to fight a last-ditch battle for the allegiance of the workers in this region of Italy with communism.
PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- Four prominent American Baptist ministers have received invitations to visit Moscow and preach to Baptist congregations in Russia this summer.
Thousands of Brooklyn longshoremen began a demonstrate slowdown yesterday, with mixed results.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 --Rita Hayworth took her contract dispute with Columbia Pictures into Federal Court in Los Angeles today.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 8 --Richie Ashburn and Del Ennis collided at full speed while chasing a drive by Mickey Mantle today. Both Philadelphia outfielders fell heavily to the ground and lay there while Mantle circled the base paths for an inside-the-park homer.
New public financing by corporations and local governments will continue at a moderately active rate next week. The backlog of new issues in the corporate field is continuing to increase, however.
HOBOKEN, N. J., April 8--A five-year spree of getting the Federal Government to refund income taxes that never were paid came to an end here today.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP)-- The Air Force announced today that Gen. Benjamin W. Chidlaw, commander in chief of the Continental Air Defense Command, was retiring next month.

A statue of Mohammed that stood for more than fifty years on the roof balustrade of the Appellate Division courthouse on Madison Square has been quietly removed. The action was advised by the State Department after requests by some Islamic governments.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 8-- The nomination of Etelvino Lins as Presidential candidate in opposition to Juscelino Kubitschek was widely criticized today.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 8 --The first step was taken today to inform parents whether their children had been inoculated with Salk vaccine or a control substance called placebo.
WASHINGTON, April 8--The ties of friendship between the United States and the Philippines will be empasized tomorrow at ceremonies marking the thirteenth anniversary of the fall of Bataan.

Sir Anthony Eden has reorganized his Cabinet in a manner which suggests that a new pattern of government is beginning to emerge in Britain.
