Three key men emerge in this pattern: the new Prime Minister himself, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, R. A. Butler, and the new Foreign Secretary, Harold Macmillan.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 8 (AP)--Three 1954 winners retained titles today in the National Amateur Athletic Union women's indoor swimming and diving meet. A protest kept one result in doubt for half an hour.
The joyful story of the Resurrection and its promise of eternal life will be told tomorrow in Christian churches over the world.

WE had the late J. Stalin's word for it: the Chinese Communists were not really Communists. And from other sources, no less reliable, we learned that these presumed Communists were only agrarian reformers, peaceful and selfless humanitarians. Such fables, if never very convincing except to those firmly dedicated to conviction, were yet a long time dying.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Saturday, April 9 (UP)--Unidentified terrorists bombed the headquarters of an Opposition leader early today, wounding a guardsman and shattering the peace of an uneasy truce in this divided country.
BONN, Germany, April 8--A program presented this week by the Ministry of Transport calls for a revolution in West Germany's economic geography.
The celebration of the Resurrection, which will begin at dawn tomorrow outdoors in many places, will shift to churches later in the morning.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 8 (AP)--Stanley Dancer continued his excellent driving at Roosevelt Raceway tonight when he had three more winners. They included both horses in the daily double.
WASHINGTON, April 8-- French officials here called off today immediate plans for a United States-French meeting on Indochina problems.

If President Eisenhower has ever wondered why it is sometimes difficult to get first-class citizens to serve in important jobs in his Administration let him look at the treatment meted out to Edward Corsi, former Industrial Commissioner of New York.

The seventy-family apartment house at 455 Jackson Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Abraham Langsdorf to a client of Kurzman Frank, attorneys. The property is assessed at $200,000. Louis Aronson was the broker in the deal.
Foes of desegregation are said to be losing a new economic war against Negroes in Mississippi.

BUENOS AIRES, April 8 -- Tramp tonnage chartered for March loading here dropped more than two-thirds from last year's figures, J. E. Turner Co., shipping agents, reported today. The comparative figures were 97,100 tons against 362,700.
KANSAS CITY, April 8 (UP)-- A chartered plane, decorated with pennants, baseballs and bats throughout the cabin, will bring the Kansas City Athletics home from the East Monday.
BERLIN, April 8--German plans to place a weather station at the South Pole during 195758 were announced in Munich today.
United States recognition of Communist China, in return for appropriate concessions, would improve this country's international position, in the view of Arthur H. Dean.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 8-- An official of the United Nations predicted today more than two dozen foreign ministers might attend the tenth anniversary meeting: of the organization here June 20-26.

ST. LOUIS, April 8 (AP)-- U. S. District Judge George H. Moore severely criticized T. C. Davis, board chairman of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, before naming him as one of five men to carry out the reorganization plan for the railroad when it is finally approved.
ROME, April 8 -- Premier Mario Scelba and Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino returned today from the United States. They voiced satisfaction over the success of their visit.
Who Will Cut It? It is not too early to begin thinking about who Will cut the grass next summer. To be sure, the yard at the moment looks as though there never will be grass to cut.
MONTE CARLO, April 8 (AP) --The Wimbledon champion, Jaroslav Drobny, threw his racquet across the court and walked out today during his quarterfinal match with Vladislav Skonecki.
LONDON, April 8--The Labor movement was urged today to compose its differences and to concentrate on preparing for a general election.
The test of any business structure will always rest on its efficiency as a business instrument, according to Norman Tishman, head of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc.
HONG KONG, April 9 -- As practitioners of the grim business of revolution by "struggle" for more than three decades, the Chinese Communists are not exactly unfamiliar with purge and violence.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) --The Army reported today that its investigation of fraud in dependency claims had netted monthly savings of about $1,225,432 over a twenty-sixmonth period.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 9-- Hofstra's baseball team gained its first victory in five games today by routing Manhattan, 14--4.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Seasonal gift plants have been brought to a flowering peak for Easter. To enjoy bloom as long as possible, do not place in full sun. Water soil thoroughly once a day, and hydrangeas perhaps twice a day to forestall wilting. Roses, most azaleas, hydrangeas and even Easter lilies may be planted out of doors next month.
MEXICO CITY, April 9--Mexico, approaching the first anniversary of its peso devaluation, has achieved what is considered here a spectacular economic recovery.

Elmhurst College in suburban Chicago is offering $800 scholarships and grants to undergraduates, made available by the American Hungarian Studies Foundation. Elmhurst maintains the only department of Hungarian studies in the country. The foundation is planning to build a Hungarian museumlibrary building on the campus.

The Metropolitan Opera closed its seventieth season yesterday. The opera in the afternoon was Gluck's "Orfeo ed Euuridice," and the work that brought down the final curtain, in the evening, was Johann Strauss" Fledermaus."
TOKYO, April 9--Japan has settled Thailand's $375,000,000 claim on her for $41,666,666.
ATLANTIC CITY--The largest presentation of electronic flash units at a single trade show was offered at the recent annual meeting here of the Master Photo Dealers' and Finishers' Association.

To the Screen Editor: The constructive criticism and reservations made by Bosley Crowther about "Blackboard Jungle" should surely be made also against ''On the Waterfront." Because of the number of awards deservedly given to this picture, it is likely to receive even wider attention at home and abroad.
Famous names in the history of early American crafts will come up on Friday and Saturday at an auction sale that turns the spotlight on rare native silver.

TO THE EDITION OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In view of the widespread discussion of the segregation issue and the attention that it has had in your columns I wonder if I might put down a few observations prompted by a stay of nearly a month in Louisiana, Georgia and South Carolina.
THE airlines, which brought mass tourism to the Caribbean in the first place, are busily expanding operations in the area to keep up with the spectacular traffic growth.
Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden, the tournament chairman, announced yesterday the season's schedule of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association.

A new-style indoor television antenna, done up neatly in an oblong box, is about to be introduced nationally. Its manufacturer says it will help to pluck signals from the air as simply as a radio receiver brings in commercial announcements.
Spring, which was a little late this year, is expected to more than make up for its tardiness today.

CHICAGO, April 9--Steel production in the Chicago area set a record in March with estimated output of 1,866,300 net tons, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. The previous high mark for monthly output was set in May, 1953, when 1,853,100 tons were produced.

A NUMBER of spring courses for beginners in photography are scheduled to start this week in the metropolitan area. In addition a special course in color-slide work is being offered at the Berkshire Museum in Pittsfield, Mass.

NOT since his "State Fair" of 1932 has Phil Stong come so close to recapturing the richly human appeal of that memorable novel as in this solid story of a week-end of bitter storm in Southeast Iowa in 1954.
John J. Lynch observed his twentieth anniversary yesterday as the operator of the news and cigar stand in the lobby of the United States District Court in Brooklyn.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 9 --Dr. Thomas Francis Jr. has been working far into the night all week.

With six weeks of preliminary skirmishing out of the way, the major league baseball teams will begin shooting for keeps this week. Quite a few will go down early. Only two will survive for next autumn's world series. The guessing as to their identities already is going on at a terrific clip.

TEN years after his death on that warm April afternoon in 1945, all that is left of Franklin Roosevelt is off the main traveled roads. Much traffic which used to go by--and often stop at--the library, the home and the grave on the old Albany Post Road has been diverted to the Taconic Parkway to the east and the New York Thruway across the Hudson on the west.

A NEW project that may well prove to be of major importance to the modern dance field is the Juilliard Dance Theatre, a professional company under the direction of Doris Humphrey. It is to make its debut in a pair of performances in the Juilliard Concert Hall on April 19 and 20.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 6-- The personalized system of dictatorship developed by President Juan D. Peron of Argentina appears to have little future.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 9-- The appointment of a new Minister of Finance has aroused widespread and contradictory speculation on Brazil's future financial policies.
As another yachting season looms just over the horizon, owners of gasoline-powered craft can thank their lucky stars that the legislators in most states have provided for refunds of state taxes.

ALUXURY hotel roving through tropic seas, equipped with its own pool and other sports areas, its sundecks and cinema, has come to be the choice of many thousands of Americans for a springtime vacation.

LEADING the little group that was stumbling painfully downtown between the rails of the silent subway, young Arthur Temmer found time to wonder what had hit New York. There had been a succession of deafening blasts followed by the crash of falling steel and stone and the roar of rubble choking the exits at 107th Street, and then the dust had settled, leaving four dazed survivors--a girl, a fat man, a GI and Arthur.

I RETURNED from a recent trip to Asia profoundly impressed with the progress being made in India and Burma, and in certain respects, in Pakistan. The picture in India is particularly heartening. The Indian economy is growing stronger and more productive year by year, the Nehru Government is as stable as any in Asia, the Communist party has suffered serious reverses, and everywhere there is a sense of sober confidence about the future.

In a game that required three hours to complete, New York University's nine defeated City College, 9--6, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was an uphill struggle for the winners, who trailed by 5--1 after two and one-half innings.
The Ford Motor Company is conducting a special study of coastal and inland port facilities in this country in an effort to improve distribution of Britishbuilt Ford automobiles.
LOS ANGELES, April 9--For several dozen California coastal oil-producing cities, the state Supreme Court leveled its legal guns this week and shot Santa Claus.

Robert J. H. Kiphuth, the Yale coach, will conduct swimming clinics in Israel this year. Kiphuth has been the swimming coach at Yale since 1918. His teams have won almost 500 dual meets while losing only twelve.
WEST HARTFORD, April 9 (UP)--The Penn-Texas Corporation of New York won control of the $45,000,000 machine tool concern of Niles-Bement-Pond today.

Easter Sunday finds the world apprehensive about the possibility of a hot war. For more than a month there has been a virtual cease-fire in the Formosa Strait. But signs are increasing that a show-down between the United States and Communist China might not be postponed much longer.

There were some flossy mutuels at the Jamaica track yesterday, including $83.60 in the third race and $142.70 in the fourth. After the feature, backers of the winner went to the cashiers' windows to get $34.10 in exchange for each $2 on-thenose ticket.

FOR the handyman-of-the-house, spring is a season of high hopes and earnest resolutions, and a time of wishing for rainless week-ends. But as in all undertaking's there is something better than hoping, resolving and wishing. And that is doing something about it.
WASHINGTON, April 9--Administration advisers are striving to complete a Presidential wartime powers bill by April 25. But they still have not agreed on how far the measure should go.

CHICAGO, April 9--A longdistance battle between the Distillery Workers Union, A. F. L., ere and the office of New York's District Attorney Frank S. Hogan broke out after the robbery yesterday of records from the offices of the international's president.

THE history of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, it was said years ago, is the story of four Johns: Carroll, England, Hughes and Ireland. Today, and even if we consider only churchmen now gone to their reward, we should have to enlarge the Johannine quartet with at least a James (Gibbons) and a George (Mundelein).

WASHINGTON, April 9--The Easter recess of Congress has brought the Democrats a brief, troubled respite from the hard dilemma on foreign policy with which they are confronted. Soon they must try to resolve it or, more likely, simply resolve to live with it.

WASHINGTON, April 9--The White House and the Capitol are about a mile from each other, and for most of the year the intervening airs are alive with two-way vibrations. These come steadily from the President to Congress and from Congress to the President--some making a smooth transit, some rough in their impact, and some without producing any reaction at all.

HONOLULU--Hawaii, its celebrated hospitality at a new peak, is expecting a record number of guests this spring and has made ready for them by increasing its accommodations for visitors by a calculated 43 per cent over last year (when it seems, unhappily, some people just simply couldn't jet in).
Zenas Colt showed the way with seven goals as the New York A. C. retained the Eastern twelve-goal indoor polo championship by beating Squadron A, 14 to 12, at the Squadron A Armory last night.

TAMPA--For those who enjoy swimming in placid water, instead of heroically confronting high surf, the beaches of Florida's west coast rimming the Gulf of Mexico are unusually appealing in April and May.
MONTE CARLO, April 9 (AP) --Budge Patty and Vladislav Skonecki reached, the final of the Monte Carlo international tennis tournament today and Jaroslav Drobny made peace with the tourney officials.

EUDORA WELTY'S characters --from the town oracle boasting, "Ah, I'm a woman that's been clear around the world in my rocking chair," down to and including the untamed shrew who speaks every salty syllable of "The Ponder Heart"--have till now been found no farther than a whoop and a holler from Jackson, or at farthest, Natchez or Vicksburg, Miss.

WHILE the records of Yalta are still lively in our thoughts, consultations start for another conference "at the summit." How keenly it is to be wished that the lessons of one experience of this sort could be milled into a few short inferences, guaranteed to make the next one turn out well! Human affairs defy such historical alchemy.
BONN, Germany, April 9 -- West Germany has become involved in conflicting claims of church and state, which recently erupted in violence and demonstrations in Belgium.
"OMNIBUS," concluding its third season on television today, certainly cannot be dismissed as a program that has adhered to a tired, conventional formula.

NOTING that the stamp of Sir Thomas Malory is "inescapable," Mr. Borowsky has set his novel of King Arthur in the Middle Ages--but his moyen age is not the time of the chivalry-loving Sir Thomas. It is rather the Middle Ages of Wat Tyler, Jack Strawe and John Ball, the Middle Ages of the stirring proletariat when England for the first and perhaps only time smelled the smoke of social revolt.

TO THE EDITOR: IN his review of Edgar E. Robinson's "The Roosevelt Leadership" Henry Steele Commager insists that the unconditional surrender demand presented to the Germans did not stiffen "every resistance," did not give "power to the extremists," as Mr. Robinson had concluded.

Fifteen hundred youngsters from the city's five boroughs pushed wooden eggs across the Great Lawn of Central Park yesterday. The event was the ninth annual egg-rolling contest of the Department of Parks, with equipment and prizes supplied by Arnold Constable.
LONDON, April 9--The end of the Churchill Era finds Britain prosperous and reasonably confident of her future.
WASHINGTON, April 9--To the Washington-attuned ear, the Capitol suddenly sounded last Monday like a giant piece of machinery that had run down over the week-end.

SALT LAKE CITY--At the risk of tangling with a member of the United States Senate in the person of the erstwhile travel writer Richard L. Neuberger, I feel it my duty, as a transplanted York Stater, to rise to the defense of Eastern scenery--if not of Eastern railroads.

FORT DIX, N. J., April 9 (AP) --Allegations of medical laxity and mistreatment in connection with the death of Pvt. Irwin Weinrib are without foundation, the office of the Army's Inspector General reported today after a month-long investigation.

FERNS have been around for a long time as is easily proved by the abundance of fern fossils found in rocks of the coal-formation era. And throughout these billions of years ferns have been adapting themselves to grow in all types of locations.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am doubtful whether your editorial of April 3 was well advised in asserting" that the last three months rill enter into our economic history as three months of great prosperity."

BIG, comfortably upholstered men have a special problem making careers in motion pictures. Unlike their tall, lean brothers they are not regarded as romantic figures by Hollywood standards. So the hefty fellows usually wind up playing character roles.

IN his sixteenth novel Nevil Shute attempts what is for him a new technique, but his old skills save the day. The new technique involves the reconstruction of an English girl's life, after her suicide at an Australian sheep station, and it is a device in which the old master is extremely uncomfortable.

On Tuesday the eyes of the world will be focused on Ann Arbor, Mich.--the inquiring eyes of scientists, the hopeful eyes of physicians and the anxious eyes of parents. On that day, the tenth anniversary of the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt, founder of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, the question will be answered: "Is the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine effective ?"

The forty-two story SeconyVacuum Building is to have windows specially designed to withstand heavy rain and winds of greater than hurricane force. About 3,200 of these window units will be installed in the building.
BATON ROUGE, La., April 9 (AP)--A secret group called the "Southern Gentlemen's Organization" is attempting to rally Louisiana white persons who are determined to keep racial segregation.
The Immigration Service is planning to scrap the dull green garb of its inspectors for modish, blue-gray uniforms, it was learned yesterday.
MANILA, March 25 -- The gravest economic problem facing the Philippine Islands today is caused by a rapidly expanding population. Each year there are a half million more persons to feed.

The basic United States immigration law--the McCarran-Walter Act of 1952, passed over President Truman's veto--in effect restricts immigration mainly to Anglo-Saxons. The quotas (number of visas) which the law allots to each country are based upon the balance of national origins in the U. S., with the result that few Eastern and Southern Europeans and only a handful of Asians can get in.

THE Martha Washington geranium (Pelargonium domesticum) makes an annual appearance as a gift plant for Easter and Mother's Day. In May also it may be found in greenhouses or roadside nurseries along with the standard zonal geraniums and other bedding plants.

A new market is available in New York for the resale of onefamily dwellings built within the past ten years. It has been created by a change in the New York State Savings Bank Law which permits more liberalized financing by savings banks or the older single - occupancy houses.
HAVING gone through an unusually heavy fall and winter schedule of oneman shows the art season now enters its spring-phase with more attention to group exhibitions rather summarizing in nature.
BATON ROUGE, La., April 9 --One of Louisiana's most palatial antebellum homes, Richland, will be taken over shortly by the Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson.
A FEW years from now it may be virtually impossible to touch or own a piece of electronic apparatus for home use that does not in some way utilize transistors.

DAYTONA BEACH--This resort area, including Ormond Beach, five miles to the north, and New Smyrna Beach, fifteen miles south, is coming into its biggest season of the year--from now to Labour Day--and is making extensive plans for the entertainment of visitors.
VIENNA, April 9--Imre Nagy, Premier of Hungary and father of her now discredited "new course," was attacked as a Titoist today by the Hungarian Communist party organ Szabad Nep.

MIAMI--To stimulate interest in spring vacationing in Florida, Miami and Fort Lauderdale are staging festivals on a big scale this year. The Festival of Venice at Fort Lauderdale is scheduled to run to next Sunday.

On Dictionary Making If there were an opinion poll to determine the dullest task in the world, such things as door-knob polishing, library cataloguing and inventory-taking in a pin factory would get high ratings.

THE present popularity of the little roses might be called a hobby within a hobby. For everywhere more and more people are becoming acquainted with these elflike cousins of the large garden favorites.

Members of the New York City Committee of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation will hold their annual tea and meeting in behalf of the organization on Tuesday afternoon in the home of Mrs. Thomas J. Watson, 4 East Seventy-fifth Street.

In some respects Easter is the most beautiful of all the Christian observances. Its central concept, the dedication to the resurrection of Jesus, lies at the very core of the Christian faith and is its most sublime and triumphant achievement. This is the time at which men may rejoice in the victory of life over death, of light over darkness, of hope over despair.

The Federal Housing Administration plans to move its metropolitan district office from Jamaica to new and larger quarters at 205-07 Hillside Avenue in the Hollis section of Queens on May 1. Additional space is needed to handle increased business in small home financing, the agency said.
HARTFORD, April 9--The "worst log-jam the General Assembly has ever known" was predicted this week.

ANY weekday the husky, wellgroomed Bernard F. Gimbel can be found pressed into a restive subway herd, swaying as happily from a strap as though the fares were being funneled from turnstiles to the coffers of his twenty spacious stores strung across the nation.

BALTIMORE, April 9 (UP)-- Saul Rogovin, making a bid to return to the big leagues, gave up only one scratch hit in four scoreless innings today to start the Baltimore Orioles off to a 4-3 exhibition victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Split-level houses are offered by Jersey builders in three new developments in Teaneck, Oakland and Bloomfield.

Caution is advised by Carl Hagerstrom in the planning of shopping centers. Mr. Hagerstrom, a member of the executive board of the Feist Feist realty organization in Newark, N. J., said that of every five centers planned only about two are constructed.
ALBANY--I have had the good fortune to travel all over the United States and most parts of the world. I know Senator Neuberger's state intimately. His pride in it is natural and completely justified.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 9-- Four thousand publications ranging from Dr. Albert Einstein's latest writings on space and relativity to T. S. Eliot's "The Cocktail Party" are listed in a bibliography published this week by the Institute for Advanced Study on its twenty-fifth anniversary.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 9 (AP) --Victory Mon, driven by Hugh Bell, led all the way tonight to win the $7,500 Easter Handicap at Roosevelt Raceway. The trotter raced the mile in 2:04 1/5.
MILWAUKEE, April 9 (UP)-- Larry Doby accounted for both runs with a sacrifice fly and a homer today in a 2-0 victory for the Cleveland Indians over the Milwaukee Braves.

The big New York City commercial banks, which for the most part have traditionally shown only mild interest in home mortgage investments, are pumping out increasing amounts of cash to help people buy houses.

ONCE upon a time in an apartment house in a middle-sized city there lived three families who were somewhat alike in many ways and much alike in one. The parents of all three were powerfully sure that they wanted their youngsters to grow up free of prejudice.
City school officials will turn their eyes to Albany this week, and while they are waiting they will be worrying.
SUMMIT, N. J., April 9-- Charles Otto Lenz, a leading consultant engineer in the fields of steam and atomic power, died here yesterday in Overlook Hospital after a long illness. His age was 86.

One of a series of interviews with people in various lines of work who find pleasure and profit in the do-it-yourself field. Today's interviewee is Hu Chain, writer, director and producer for TV and radio.
THE time has come, the Walrus said, to talk of many things: of shoes and ships and sealing-wax, of cabbages and kings. Especially the kings, the longs of diamonds.
MOSCOW, April 9--Moscow voiced its belief today that it would be possible to conclude the Austrian state treaty after Austrian Chancellor Julius Raab's talks here next week.

AT this time of year it does not take a 4,000-mile, sixteen-day circle tour in order for the motorist to catch up with an advance showing of spring. But for the Eastern motorist with the time and desire to test his mettle and that of his vehicle after a long, hard winter, such a trip affords thrilling days on the highway and delightful new vistas.

ONE of the greatest draftsmen of all time, Goya is also one whose drawings find particular response today. His means were audacious and forceful. His themes were, on the one hand, those of human folly, cruelty and stupidity and, on the other, the enigmatic and disquieting images of fantasy and paradox and dreams. He believed in reason, without which passion, prejudice and superstition ran cripplingly rampant.

COLORADO'S Trail Ridge Road makes for a thrilling ride as it twists and turns, giving vast vistas of great valleys and snow-capped ridges. But the road is closed for seven or eight months per year! I visited in July, the best month of the year, or so they told me.
BREWSTER, N. Y., April 9-- That festival of the fishes, known as the opening day of the trout season, was observed by thousands of celebrants on the heavily stocked streams near here today.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 9-- Turkey strongly opposes an early four-power conference because she fears the Soviet Union would exploit such a meeting to cripple Turkish efforts to forge a Middle Eastern defense system.
ATLANTA, April 9 (AP)--The Alabama state patrol and courts of three states today moved against mass picketing in an effort to halt violence in the strike of Southern Bell Telephone company workers.

TOKYO, April 9--Japan's abortive plan to send her Foreign Minister to Washington a few days ago has spotlighted the disputes between the United States and her wartime enemy who is now an important free-world bastion in the Far East.
THE article by Senator Neuberger of Oregon has led me to hope that a few words from me might bring to him a great deal more of enjoyment as he travels about our country.

Newspapers in fifteen states and the District of Columbia will be represented tomorrow at the opening session of the first seminar for newspaper promotion executives at the American Press Institute at Columbia University.

NEARLY twenty years have passed since the Spanish civil war broke out. Those who were grown up then will remember the passionate feelings it aroused in all democratic countries. For some it was the first bout of a world war between fascism and democracy; for others it was a struggle between the Catholic Church and Red atheism; in reality its issues were much more complicated.
RADIO and television are planning special coverage for what will be a top news story Tuesday--the longawaited report on the Salk antipolio vaccine.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. --A top United Nations council prescribed a cure last week for countries suffering from chronic dollarshortage. The remedy: Develop tourism!
The coming of the Kingdom of God on earth will depend upon the united efforts of human beings and their worthiness, Rabbi Julius Mark declared yesterday.

Next Tuesday Dr. Thomas Francis Jr., the distinguished epidemiologist of the University of Michigan, where the result of last year's mass trial of the Salk anti-polio vaccine was evaluated, will present a report.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 9--Westchester County is perplexed by a mushrooming maze of philanthropic fund-raising campaigns.

SINCLAIR LEWIS' literary output, which has been a source of screen material before ("Arrowsmith," "Docsworth"), has been tapped again, it was learned last week. This time it is scenarist-director Richard Brooks, who, on the eve of his departure for London, revealed that he had acquired an option on nothing less than "Elmer Gantry," the Nobel Prizewinner's 1927 novel about the colorful career of a hypocritical minister.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 9 (AP) --Atom testers set off an infant device today, then paused for the Easter week-end.
SINGAPORE, April 9--Singapore's new left-oriented Government will not seek immediate cancellation of the emergency laws for combating Communist subversion.

SPOKANE, Wash., April 9--During the week the nation's school superintendents, school board members, college professors and classroom teachers have discussed the immediate problems that face America's public schools. At Cleveland the session of the American Association of School Administrators early in the week was attended by 9,000 school men.
PITTSBURGH, April 9 (UP)-- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced plans today to construct a multi-million dollar atomic "reactor center."

CAIRO, April 9 -- A United Nations truce commission condemned both Israel and Egypt today for a battle fought on the Gaza Strip frontier last Sunday in which two Egyptian and two Israeli soldiers were killed and four Egyptians and four Israelis wounded.

THE 1954-55 twenty-two week season of the Metropolitan Opera Association came to an end last night. This season had a number of distinguishing features. The level of the new productions, revivals, and of many performances was higher than that of the season previous.
HARTFORD, April 9--Democrats will take over control of Connecticut's minor court system July 1.

Buyers are offered a wide choice of prices and designs in new dwellings on Long Island. Although considerable emphasis is still placed by some builders on the split-level style, the Cape Cod and ranch houses are available in either conventional or modified layouts. Additional bedrooms and baths are stressed in cases when an appeal is being made to larger families.

BAINBRIDGE, N. Y., April 5 --The word "sap" in central New York means a business-- it is not an insult. And this farm community of Chenango County is illustrative of an industrial revolution for converting tree juice into money.

OVER many years Scotsmen and Americans of contrasting (often conflicting) viewpoints have interpreted the story of the sometimes misty yet not the less fascinating Flora MacDonald, her career on her native terrain and in Revolutionary North Carolina.

Department store sales in the United States during the week ended April 2 were 11 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year, according to the Federal Reserve Board. The increase was partly due to Easter falling a week earlier this year.
LOS ANGELES -- Well, the swallows returned to Capistrano on schedule all right, leading off the impressive annual profession of vernal phenomena in the nation's Southwest.
MIAMI BEACH--This is the time of year on Florida's Gold Coast for dreaming--for preparations for the forthcoming spring and summer season and for planning bigger things for next winter.

ENCINO, Calif., April 9 (AP)-- Al Piantadosi, who wrote "I Didn't Raise My Boy to Be a Soldier"--a song of World War I--died last night at his home here. He was 71 years old.

Plans have been advanced for the backgammon, bridge and canasta party, known as an Evening of Games to be held on April 18 in the main ballroom and the adjacent Baroque and Crystal Suites of the Plaza for the benefit of the Children's Memorial Cancer Fund.

Easter selling has reduced stocks in department stores and specialty shops. With several weeks of spring weather ahead, demand has been strong for many lines of men's, women's and children's apparel.

The Transport Workers Union charged yesterday that members of the Transit Authority were acting as "willing tools" of "clever real estate manipulators" in a campaign to raze the Third Avenue Elevated.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9--A late X-ray examination revealed today that Outfielder Del Ennis of the Philadelphia Phillies had suffered a broken left leg in a collision with Richie Ashburn. He may be sidelined for four to six weeks.
WASHINGTON, April 9--Five men in uniform--the Joint Chiefs of Staff--were in the spotlight and on the griddle this week.
The men's clothing industry is straining to make 1955 the third best year in its history.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- More than 3,000 Democrats were expected to attend a testimonial dinner here next Saturday for Speaker Sam Rayburn of the House of Representatives.

SUMMER in the--South, for as long as I can remember, has been Gloriosa time. And these gorgeous climbing lilies, produced from sweet potatolike tubers, are winning new fame throughout the warm climate sections of the country.

RICHMOND, Va., April 9 (AP) --Democles breezed to victory today in the twenty-third running of the Deep Run Hunt Cup steeplechase. The 6 - year - old gray gelding set a track record for the three-mile test over post and rails.

THE cymbidium orchid has become one of the most popular of the 15,000 species of orchids, and I think deservedly so. Here in Southern California they are a frequent sight in many gardens. And, of course, elsewhere in this country they are grown under glass by florists and hobbyists.
Baseball made a spectacular return to these environs yesterday, with the Dodgers supplying the chief fireworks.

IT is strange that no biography of James Freeman Clarke (1810-88) has been published until now. Though overshadowed by such contemporaries as Ellery Channing, Ralph Waldo Emerson, Theodore Parker and Oliver Wendell Holmes, he was none the less a thinker of stature and a representative man of his era.

WASHINGTON, April 9-- Portraits of President Washington and Lincoln have been placed inside the White House entrance foyer where pictures of Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman formerly hung.

Molotov to British Ambassador Sir William Hayter today on the Austrian state treaty, as broadcast from, Moscow (similar statements were made to United States Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen and to the French Charge d'Affaires):

WASHINGTON, April 9--To much of Washington Easter is a new hat, a cloud of pinkish blossoms around the Tidal Basin, a long week-end between Good Friday and the formal opening of the baseball season on the succeeding Monday.

BUTLER--Richard Austen Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, is, after Sir Anthony Eden, the most important man in the Government. The authority of the Chancellor in economic and financial planning always is greater when, as at present, the Prime Minister's chief interests are in foreign afairs.

TO THE EDITOR: In "Revival of Rodin--And of Sentiment" (March 20) Aline B. Saarinen gets at a far more important matter than the renewed interest in the French sculptor. It is the long existence of what she calls "the influential group-- certain museum men, art writers, dealers, avant-garde artists and collectors -- that shapes the program and prejudices of tastes in art, [and that] gave Rodin a virtual goby."

SPRING brings delicacies that delight the epicure. The largest of the herrings, the silvery shad, swims up rivers on both coasts, moving north as the weather warms.

GEORGE LEWIS is a small, thin, infinitely gentle and greatly talented jazz-playing clarinetist who was born in downtown New Orleans on July 13, 1900, nine days after Louis Armstrong. He is currently leading what may very well be the last of the authentic New Orleans jazz bands, a powerful and spirited organization, in a dark green cavern in Times Square known as Childs Paramount Restaurant.

A FILLIP to the already vigorous market in latexbased paints has been given by the introduction of a new method of color blending. A leading manufacturer in this field has just offered a system by which the addition of just one tube of concentrated color to any of twenty-six basic paints (including two whites) will give one of 130 standardized tints.

The Soviet Union is too busy trying to straighten out its agricultural "mess" to think about waging a war against the West, seven editors said yesterday upon their return from Moscow.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., April 9--This Republican stronghold went Democratic in a town election for the first time in 100 years this week, and everyone is trying to figure out why.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- United States officials today interpreted Moscow's latest diplomatic moves as part of a new effort to present the Soviet Union at home and abroad as the world's prime promoter of peace.

ARDENT worshipers of Gilbert and Sullivan, both inner and outer circles, may reach for their pencils and note the morning's major intelligence: The D'Oyle Carte Opera Company, its forthcoming American tour already announced, now lets it be known that it will be stopping in our town for nine weeks.
Airline trip insurance policies are now available to passengers who fly on helicopters, jet aircraft and turbo-prop aircraft of the scheduled airlines.

HAMILTON, Bermuda--Off to a slightly slower start tourist-wise last January and February than in 1954, Bermuda expects to go ahead of last year's figures by the end of this month. On the basis of advance bookings, travel during April is likely to be over that of April last year when some 12,580 visitors came here.
A yeast made from tree sugars will be manufactured extensively by the Red Star Yeast and Products Company of Milwaukee and the Charmin Paper Mills of Green Bay, Wis., starting today.

Language problems faced by the increasing number of foreign students in American universities and colleges are being solved at the Georgia Institute of Technology with a special course for such students. It integrates spoken and written language with an understanding of American life and ideals.

In a spring burst of activity local art galleries will open nearly thirty exhibitions tomorrow, most of them one-man shows.

Chile gives the impression these days of enjoying her inflationary spree with no idea of paying the piper. The apparently easy but always deceptive way of dictatorship is fortunately barred. President Ibanez can be believed when he says he has no intention of trying to set up a military dictatorship, and anyway democracy is deeply ingrained in Chilean character.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 9 (UP)--The Syracuse Nationals deadlocked the National Basketball Association play-off championship series at three-all today. They rallied in the final period to defeat the Fort Wayne Pistons, 109--104.

The Virginia Quarterly Review, which is published at the University of Virginia and in a West Range office once designed by Thomas Jefferson as a student dining hall, is thirty years old and celebrates its birthday with a Spring Anniversary Number.

NEW ORLEANS--Today, Easter Sunday, marks the traditional opening of New Orleans' "rival to the Mardi Gras" in its appeal to thousands of travelers--the annual Spring Fiesta. HYDE PARK, N. Y.--Any mention of Franklin Delano Roosevelt--small matter whether pro or anti--tends to increase the flow of visitors to the family home of the thirty-second President of the United States.

The fear that growers may defeat stringent controls on the planting of wheat in the July referendum has resulted in a movement to change the price support and production setup Under present legislation, the wheat price program virtually would collapse if less than two-thirds of the growers polled should vote for controls.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 7-- Senate subcommittee hearings in the Northwest this week on Hell's Canyon Dam legislation have left these distinct impressions: The project will be an issue in the 1956 campaign in this region, as it was last year.

Stock prices touched new highs for the recovery movement last week, although trading was curtailed by religious holiday influences. Wide swings in special issues and a stronger tone in heavy industry groups featured the advance.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 9 (AP)--Dave Singer's Hangover registered his sixth victory in nine starts this year in the $7,500 Hollywood Handicap before 14,262 fans at Gulfstream Park today.

THIS ia the First full-length book about Dwight D. Eisenhower since he entered the White House, and it is a very readable volume indeed. It comes from the typewriter of the veteran United Press White House correspondent who has been watching them come and go since 1941.

THE quarter-inch portable electric drill is usually the first power tool added to a home workshop. It is so convenient and adaptable that, by adding inexpensive attachments, it does the job of a dozen individual tools.

Dr. Louis F. Raymond or East Orange, N. J., told the Aero Medical Association that at supersonic speeds an airplane compresses the air at the nose. Hence light is not refracted in the usual way. Objects ahead are apparently displaced. Dr. Raymond says that a supersonic flyer may be fooled in another way.

CONTRACT bridge seems to be a casualty occasioned by the Communist regime in China, according to a reliable informant, Wellington I. T. Sun, who is now a resident of New York City. However, contract bridge is in good company.
If the first quarter is a true Indication, American business is roaring along toward the best year in its history.

THE Caribbean lands no longer sleep the summer away. Most hotels keep open at reduced rates. The weather now and then becomes tourist spectacle and in the burst of sunshine after a brief tropical downpour, the wonders of the Caribbean shine in greater glory.

DUKE SNIDER of the Brooklyn Dodgers was prodded one day this spring into recognizing the de facto existence of an odd situation in New York baseball. Each of the three resident ball clubs has a prodigious centerfielder. At the moment, for reasons that may be only temporary.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9--After the third round of the Masters golf tournament today, Cary Middlecoff still led Ben Hogan by four strokes.

Air-conditioning is planned for the main office building of the Bankers Trust Company at 16 Wall Street. The bank occupies the first twelve floors and two basements of the thirtyone -story structure.

Radio astronomy has scored new triumphs which were discussed at last week's Princeton meeting of the American Astronomical Society.

An aftermath of the Pakistani announcement that the whole of West Pakistan was to be reorganized into a single cohesive province, replacing the present four provinces, three states and the tribal areas, has been an explosive protest from Afghanistan. ALBANY, April 9--For the present at least, Averell Harriman has cast himself in the role of understudy to the star in the political drama that will be spread before the voters in next year's Presidential campaign. Well-known members of the worlds of society, the theatre and the arts will participate in the pageant "Salute to Lafayette," which will be a feature of the entertainment at the April in Paris Ball Friday night in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.
IF Isaak Walton had seen the fevered, eager anglers who thronged the banks of scores of New York trout streams yesterday, the classic of angling literature would never have been written.

Accommodations for families in the middle-income class will be provided in a six-story apartment house at 27 Claremont Avenue in Mount Vernon, N. Y. Work has been started on the building, which is scheduled to be ready for occupancy in the early fall.
Stewards on the Cunarder Queen Elizabeth are delighted with the new anti-rolling devices that were fitted recently to the world's largest liner and are now receiving their first real Atlantic test.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 9 (UP) --France and Communist North Vietminh today announced each would withdraw her troops from the other's territory by May 16, or ten days before the Geneva truce deadline.

HERBERT J. YATES, president of Republic Pictures, focused attention on the unpredictable nature of the movie business by declaring that, under present circumstances, it will be more profitable for the company to devote all its studio facilities to the production of films for television.
ROME, April 9 (AP)--Church bells in Rome and fireworks in Florence ushered in the Easter vigil for Roman Catholics today. Holiday tourists poured into Italy at the rate of one every fifteen seconds.
Bill Hanrahan pitched a threehit shutout yesterday and Fordham won its fourth game in as many starts.
PARIS, April 9--After six weeks in office Premier Edgar Faure now has a month, with Parliament in recess, to consolidate his domestic and foreign policy positions.

Edgar William Stewart, head of Catalina, Inc., manufacturer of swimming suits and sportswear, and a director and member of the executive committee of Julius Kayser Co., Inc., manufacturer of women's accessories, died yesterday of a heart attack in his suite in the Barclay Hotel.

CORNWALL, N. Y., April 9 (UP)--Four cadets from the New York Military Academy have admitted stealing cars and burglarizing a small candy store on expeditions from their dormitories after taps, the police reported today.

BEFORE having reached the age of 50, reports the great Yiddish writer Sholom Aleichem, he had already come face to face with the Angel of Death. This chastening experience led him to a characteristically gay conclusion: it was time to write his autobiography.

Time was when an American citizen wishing to go abroad made steamship reservations (this was before the transoceanic airplanes began operating) and went. A few benighted countries required passports. Now a citizen or other inhabitant cannot depart until he has proved he was born and has complied with a number of other requirements.

NEWARK, April 9--An efficient probation and parole system not only will help restore criminal offenders to respectable lives, but it may prove a money saver as well, according to a report issued today by the New Jersey Law Enforcement Council.

TO THE EDITOR: In Ray Bradbury's imaginary interview with Jules Verne--"Marvels and Miracles --Pass It On!" (March 20) Verne recalls Paris "swept with the fever of men giving all and anything to--sail their balloons."

It was the first Baron Rothschild who observed that the way to make money was to buy cheap and sell dear. Having developed his own system of communications, which included carrier pigeons, the Baron, operating in Great Britain and the Continent in the early nineteenth century, managed to sell profitably not only commodities he owned but also contracts to deliver goods at a later date.
In the sedate halls of an old brownstone in Brooklyn Heights where "Yankees" and "Giants" are as cuss words 525 members of the Brooklyn Club will mark its ninetieth anniversary this month.

LONDON, April 9--The elegant figure of Sir Anthony Eden strode through the Cabinet rooms of 10 Downing Street while his countrymen accustomed themselves to the unusual political situation in which Sir Winston Churchill was neither a member of the Government nor a dominant figure in the Opposition.

HOBOKEN, N. J., April 9-- Commemorating the diamond jubilee of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, a plaque will be unveiled here next Saturday in the auditorium of Stevens Institute of Technology.
ALBANY, April 9--The State Tax Commission is speeding a $500,000 drive against tax dodgers.

IN the winter of 1854, Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, delivered six lectures at the University of Chicago under the auspices of the Charles R. Walgreen Foundation. A few months later, when spring thaws had sent vast sweeps of water tumbling down the river beds, Mr. Clapp learned that he had been "washed out" of the famous river-resource agency after twenty-one years continuous service.
CHICAGO, April 9--Chicago Democrats are preparing to perform on April 20 rites that for them require no rehearsals.

A CHARGE frequently leveled at contemporary composers is that they are too top-lofty to write for the market. Perhaps the fact that refutes this most effectively is the will with which those composers have turned to composing chamber operas, now that the new phenomenon of the opera workshop has created a demand for such works.
Proposed contracts for the first sale of St. Lawrence River power provide major portions to an aluminum plant in Massena, N. Y., and to the State of Vermont.

LISBON FALLS, Maine. NEWS has filtered down from ancient Quebec Province that the rocking chair has been converted to le sport, with athletically minded adventurers competing for the title in carefully judged contests called "bercethons."
LONDON, April 9 (AP)--Fullback Peter Sillett slammed in a penalty goal today to give Chelsea a 1-0 victory over the Wolverhampton Wanderers in a match that may decide the English soccer championship.
Stocks have climbed considerably above the prices prevailing when the Senate Banking and Currency Committee began its "friendly study" of the market.
JERSEY CITY, April 9--The Municipal Authorities Research Committee met for the first time this week.

The expressiveness and spontaneity that children at play can bring to paper through brush and paints will be shown in an exhibit opening Thursday in the children's room of the Hudson Park branch of the New York Public Library, 10 Seventh Avenue South.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 9 -- Ngo Dinh Nhu, brother and closest adviser to Premier Ngo Dinh Diem, said today the Government was about to get a broad political base.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 9 (Reuters)--Iran's new Premier, Hussein Ala, presented his Cabinet today to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.
POSTMASTER GENERAL ARTHUR E. SUMMERFIELD made available last week a photograph of the design of the 3-cent stamp to be issued on May 21--Armed Forces Day--in honor of the Armed Forces Reserve.
RICHMOND, Va., April 9 (AP) --Virginia told the United States Supreme Court today that it considered integration in its public schools "impossible at this time."
BERLIN, April 9 (Reuters)-- Following are the texts of letters exchanged by Marsha Kappelman of Baltimore and Valery A. Lysikov, a Russian boy who changed his mind about living in the West:

Plans are announced by the National Association of Real Estate Boards for its second annual rehabilitation contest for members as part of its Build America Better program. The contest is designed to demonstrate the business opportunities available in the sound rehabilitation of residential properties.

A LOT of young writers today think they, have it tough. With publishers sitting on the uneasy seat, they are finding it harder than it was to get a hearing. That figure of our childhood arithmetic, the lowest common denominator, plays a larger and larger part in the choice of what can be offered for popular consumption.
PARIS, April 9 -- Official sources said today the Soviet Union's steps toward abrogating the French-Soviet treaty of Friendship would not prevent or delay French ratification of the Paris agreements.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP)-- George C. McConnaughey, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that crime programs on television, "could very-easily contribute to juvenile delinquency."
WASHINGTON, April 9-- "Pitchfork Ben" Tillman would have howled. "Uncle Joe" Cannon might have goggled.
To The Screen Editor: SOMEWHERE in the trash heap behind Hollywood's Pantages Theatre there must surely have been some ghostly ballots, written in invisible ink, in as yet unopened phantom envelopes.

SINCE this is proving to be one of Broadway's most bountiful seasons, it is not surprising that the recording companies are losing no time in transferring its bounties to disks. Two of the least fallible composers for this medium-- Cole Porter and Harold Arlen-- are represented in the latest group of original-cast releases.

With the success of the Paris defense pacts the Russian Government has thought it necessary to carry out the dire threats that it made in case the West European lambs organized inside their corral to keep out the East German or other Communist wolves.

PATRICIA JESSEL, who, as a most unpredictable wife in "Witness for the Prosecution," has raised death to theatrical haute couture, testified the other day on techniques and tribulations of the professional femme fatale.

MILAN, Italy, April 8--This cold and foggy city in the valley of the Po, now basking in unseasonably warm sunshine, is the New York of Italy, her industrial and commercial capital. It hopes to transform itself before 1965 into the most modern and efficient business center in the world.
It takes more than ice cream and cake to conduct a successful party for children.
Four thousand four hundred Easter worshipers crowded two services yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (UP) -- Archbishop John F. O'Hara, head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Philadelphia, said today that a conspiracy against Catholic education now exists in the United States and abroad.
A brush fire in the Bronx tied up the main line of the New York Central Railroad for an hour and thirty-two minutes yesterday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 10 -- The Government of South Vietnam moved today to create unified law-and-order machinery throughout the country.

An appraisal of the successes and failures of the United Nations during the last ten years has been written by Clark M. Eichelberger. The author was a member of Sumner Welles' Committee of Five that in 1942 prepared the first American draft of the United Nations Charter.

ATHENS, Ga., April 10 (AP) -- Winners of the George Foster Peabody radio and television awards for 1954 were announced today by Dr. John E. Drewry, dean of the University of Georgia's Henry W. Grady School of Journalism.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Federal prison officials say Alcatraz prison may be closed and inmates transferred to a new institution within there or four years.

A CONCERT devoted to the music of Alfredo Catalani took place in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. The principal offering was the Italian composer's "Mass of Peace," written in 1872 and, it was stated in the program, never previously heard in this country.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 (AP) -- The first laboratory evidence of a link between viruses and human cancer was reported today by a University of California medical researcher.
LONG BEACH, Calif., April 10 (AP) -- Joseph Alston, South Pasadena, Calif., and Wynn Rogers, Arcadia, Calif., won the Men's Doubles honors in the American Badminton Association open tournament.
Athletic teams at most schools open their spring schedules this week.
PARIS, April 10 -- Gen. Joseph -- Pierre Koenig, Minister of Defense, today ordered a military investigation into the French defeat in Indochina a year ago at Dienbienphu.

NEW DELHI, India April 10 -- The Communist-sponsored conference of Asian and African nations concluded its deliberations today after calling for universal disarmament. It also proposed a ban on production and experiments in nuclear weapons and endorsed the principles of peaceful coexistence and noninterference.
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox overcame a 3-0 deficit to beat the Chicago Cubs, 9 -- 7, in the second and last city series game before 19,504 at Wrigley Field today.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, April 10 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, America's No. 1 ranked player, added a tennis trophy to his collection today but not before he had been extended to a grueling twenty-four-game opening set by Luis Ayala.
Fluoridation of public drinking water to prevent tooth decay has become one of the country's fiercest controversies.
JERUSALEM, April 10 (AP) -- Thousands of Easter pilgrims thronged Jerusalem today to worship at Christendom's holiest shrines.

William F. Burrows has been appointed general manager of the new Diesel engine division of the White Motor Company. Acquisition of the division by purchase from the National Supply Company has been ratified by National Supply directors.

SYRACUSE, April 10 (UP) -- The Syracuse Nationals, driving behind their six-year jinx over the Fort Wayne Pistons, won their first National Basketball Association play-off championship today. They defeated the Indiana team, 92 -- 91, in a bitterly contested game.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 10 (UP) -The eyes of the medical world turned on Ann Arbor today, with the momentous announcement of the results of the year-long Salk polio vaccine test only two days away.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 10 -- Jack Sutphen, piloting Rum Dum, scored a 29-point decision in the final regatta of Larchmont Yacht Club's winter championship season today. However he failed to qualify to defend his Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association Frostbite dinghy championship.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- A former Government lawyer has been described as once saying that he felt it better to indict a State Department employe on flimsy evidence than to face the questions of Senate Red hunters.
ZURICH, Switzerland, April 10 -- A newspaper here has just charged the Swiss holding company Interhandel with "camouflaging" Nazi holdings in the General Aniline and Film Corporation.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 -- The essential difference between United States policy and that of our Asian allies, South Korea and Nationalist China, is this: They are anxious to provoke war while we are not. Syngman Rhee would welcome any opportunity to start a conflict, since he realizes this is his one chance of unifying Korea before he dies.

Remember way back when -- at night games the arc lights showed clouds of smoke and gnats hanging thick over the field, the roar of a low-flying plane smothered the yells of the crowd, the feel of peanut shells being crunched underfoot. Remember -- the ushers with their dusting mitts, hot-dogs being passed along the rows, the spectacular coin-catching ability of the venders, the "excuse me, please," of a latecomer getting to his seat.

The Continental Telephone Company is offering to stockholders rights to subscribe to 243,060 new common shares at $19 a share, at the rate of one new share for each four held. The offer, which will end on April 20, is underwritten by investment houses headed by White Weld Co., First Boston Corporation and W. C. Pitfield Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- A group of educators reported today that American women were confused and emotionally upset as a result of trying to act as mother-housewife, career woman, glamour girl and culture bearer all at once.

A restaurant in a theatre -- it boast of being the only one in this country -- closed Saturday night, and its Swiss-born chef, Willie Muller, went off to Bermuda. Louis Sismondo, the manager, locked the door with the feeling of a job well done.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- All - You - Have - To - Do - Is - Holler-Department: Last week Senator Strom Thurmond, Democrat of South Carolina, noted wistfully in his weekly letter to constituents that he and his wife Jean just could not find any yellow hominy grits in Washington.
OCEANPORT, N. J., April 10 -- A Norfolk, Va., man and his 9-year-old son were missing after a boating mishap here this afternoon. The man's 11-year-old daughter and the owner of the boat were saved.
PITTSBURGH, April 10 -- Those steel officials who looked for a marked let-down this summer have definitely changed their minds.

BALTIMORE, April 10 (AP) -- A wild peg to first by Pitcher Vernon Thies on a bunt by Don Leppert let Bob Young in with the winning run in the last of the ninth in Baltimore's 4-3 victory over Pittsburgh today.

Peck Peck, specialist in women's sportswear, announced over the week-end the election of Frederic C. Peck as president to succeed A. Wells Peck, who assumes the new post of chairman of the board.
HUNTSVILLE, Ala., April 9 -- For a group of German-born men and women here April 14 will be a day of signal significance.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Cheap new devices to ward off biological warfare attacks can now be manufactured commercially, the Army Chemical Warfare Corps said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 -- Warner Brothers, which announced last week formation of Sunset Productions as a television film subsidiary, is conducting discussions with the American Broadcasting Company for further participation in the industry.

FRIEDRICH WILHELM HEINRICH ALEXANDER VON HUMBOLDT, 1769-1859, was probably more famous in his lifetime than any scientist who ever lived. His reputation was so prodigious that he seemed "the embodiment of the widest possible range of human faculties." His works were published in many languages.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 10 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics swept their two-game exhibition series with the Philadelphia Phillies with a 14-5 victory today. The Athletics pounded four Phil hurlers for twenty hits, including four home runs.

A Brooklyn man and his son were charged with homicide yesterday in the slaying of the president of a plasterers union local. The slain man was Amiello Russo, 45 years old, of 209 Stone Avenue, Brownsville, Brooklyn, and the men booked were his stepfather and stepbrother.
With last week curtailed by the holidays, the ship charter market still was able to finish with higher rates than were paid a week earlier.

Mrs. Edna Hume, 81 years old, was found slain yesterday in her furnished room at 35 West, Eleventh Street in Greenwich Village. She had been beaten and gagged. Dr. Milton Helpern Chief Medical Examiner, listed her death as homicide by asphyxiation.

If there is any "week" that eight million New Yorkers would like to see extended for the entire year, it is Noise Abatement Week, which has been proclaimed for the period April 10 to April 16. The unnecessary blaring of automobile horns, the clatter and bang of garbage cans in the early morning, the merciless cacaphony of late-hour radios--all of these discordant sounds and many more inflict a peculiar torture of their own.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks said today the Administration was studying a stand-by control bill to be presented to Congress in case of war or other emergency.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Army Secretary Robert T. Stevens, back from an inspection trip in the Far East, said today he did not believe the Chinese Communists had any immediate plans for an offensive in the Formosa area.

Pay revisions for nurses in New York City's employ are now being considered, and reconsidered, in the established routine through which career and salary plan proposals pass en route to the Board of Estimate. COLUMBUS, Ohio., April 9 (UP) -- Pure Oil Company stockholders authorized today a 2-for-1 common stock split, effective on April 19. The action came at the forty-first annual meeting of shareholders. There are somewhat more than 4,000,000 shares outstanding.
Sunshine and a throng of worshippers filled the nave and transepts of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) for yesterday morning's Easter service.
Pravda has revealed that a Soviet Arctic expedition is operating at a point 180 miles from Greenland.

NEW DELHI, India, April 10 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and Pham Van Dong, Deputy Premier of North Vietnam, issued a joint statement today pledging their fullest support to the Geneva agreements on Indochina.

Several dinner parties will be given in advance of the Wednesday evening benefit performance of "Silk Stockings" at the Imperial Theatre. Grosvenor Neighborhood House, 321 East Forty-ninth Street, will be the beneficiary.

Budget Director Abraham D. Beame cautiously predicted yesterday that the city's operating budget would expand at a lesser rate in the next few years. It has averaged an annual increase of $100,000,000 since 1951-52.
Strollers were all smiles yesterday in the Easter sunshine, but misery was the mood for most of the motorists.

DETROIT, April 10 (UP) -- Gordie Howe registered three goals tonight as the Detroit Red Wings set back the Montreal Canadiens, 5 -- 1. This gave the Wings a 3-2 edge in games in their four-of-seven Stanley Cup championship series.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Washington Senators ended their exhibition series with fifteen victories, seven defeats and a tie against major league opponents by defeating the Cincinnati Redlegs, 5 -- 2, today. The Senators have won ten times and tied once against the Redlegs.

The National Homes Corporation had sales of $31,377,178 in the six months ended Dec. 31, representing an increase of 68 per cent over those in the corresponding period of the preceding year. For the calendar year 1954, sales totaled $50,874,206, compared to $34,319,573.
THE Metropolitan Opera has closed its doors for yet another season, but its vastness is not dark -- and almost never is, year round.

MILWAUKEE, April 10 (UP) -- Danny O'Connell hit a two-run homer in the ninth inning and Henry Aaron matched it in the tenth. As a result, the Milwaukee Braves scored a 6-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians today and squared their "world series preview."
KANSAS CITY, April 10 (AP) -- You might think the pennant winner was coming to town tomorrow instead of the eighth place Kansas City (nee Philadelphia) Athletics.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -President Eisenhower worked this week-end on a message to Congress outlining plans for foreign aid in the fiscal year of 1956, beginning July 1.
William J. Clermont Jr., a chief officer with a surgeon's touch, has been commended by the Coast Guard for his expert bone-setting.
LONDON, April 10 -- Sir Winston Churchill's relinquishing of the Prime Ministry had been expected and had no noticeable influence on the stock markets here.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday the awarding of 226 citations to members of the police force for meritorious service.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)--The Border Patrol's crackdown on Mexican wetbacks has reduced crime and disease rates and demands for public welfare funds in United States communities along the Mexican border, it was disclosed today.

THREE special programs offered over television yesterday afternoon were supposed to represent a new high-minded approach in the real spirit of Easter.

PALO ALTO, Calif., April 10 -- A flying machine that defies gravity without rotor blades, wings, tail or ordinary propellers was shown here today. At a distance it looks in the air like an airborne manhole cover with a man standing on top.

Abba Eban, Israel's ambassador to the United States said last night that the United Nations report on the clash near the Gaza strip had borne out his country's contention that Egypt was at fault in the incident.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- An administrative court of the United States to deal with judicial phases of tax, labor and trade regulations was recommended today by the Hoover Commission.
In the presence of a congregation estimated at 6,000 persons, Cardinal Spellman offered the solemn pontifical mass of Easter Sunday in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

A contract calling for the employment of union musicians by WOR and WOR-TV is to be signed soon, it was announced yesterday by Gordon Gray and Al Manuti. Mr. Gray is general manager of the stations, and Mr. Manuti is president of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -The Americans for Democratic Action declared today the Democratic majority in Congress had made "little progress'' in enacting "liberal" legislation in the current session.
Three hundred members of the Metropolitan Opera left last night for Cleveland, the first stop of the company's annual spring tour. They departed from Grand Central Terminal at 10 o'clock.

The National Committee for Labor Israel held its twenty-third annual "Histadrut Third Seder" last night at the Commodore and Waldorf-Astoria Hotels. Abba S. Eban, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, was guest of honor.
JERUSALEM, April 10 -Egypt and Israel were admonished today "that the series of events in the vicinity of Gaza, which has resulted in a deteriorating situation can and should be ended."

The Very Rev. Germanos Liamadis was consecrated here yesterday as an Auxiliary Bishop in the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America and as Titular Bishop of Constantia. The latter is an inactive diocese on the Island of Cyprus.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 10 -- The new president of the Bank of Brazil will be Alcides da Costa Vidigal, a Sao Paulo banker, according to a Meridional news agency dispatch from Sao Paulo.

ROME, April 10--Pope Pius XII appealed today for international talks to achieve "progressive disarmament" and "lasting understanding" between power blocs. The main part of his traditional Easter message, in which he imparted his blessing to the world, was devoted to the hopes and terrors...

The remarks of the Metropolitan Opera's Rudolf Bing at the National Press Club luncheon deserve wide applause. Opera must be made more available to the public and there must be steadier employment and greater opportunities for our artists.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Government prosecutors knew more than three years ago that the turnabout witness, Harvey Matusow, had a "mild but acute form" of psychoneurosis while in the Army, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Supreme Court will be advised this week to permit a gradual end to racial segregation in the public schools.

A two-story business building on plot 50 by 90 feet at 1706 Bronxdale Avenue and an adjoining lot measuring 20 by 100 feet on Van Nest Avenue in the Bronx were sold by the Bronxdale Avenue Realty Corporation to Minnie Sassone in a deal negotiated by Henry Waltemade, Inc., broker. The property which will be occupied by the buyer, was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $16,000.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Senate Small Business Committee announced today it would hold public hearings on Thursday and Friday on the report of the Attorney General's National Committee on the Anti-Trust Laws.

UNIONDALE, L. I., April 10--William C. DeKoning Jr., son of the jailed former labor leader in Nassau County, has returned to his home at 335 California Avenue here at the end of his one-year suspended sentence.

HAVING defied all laws of logic by picking Milwaukee to win the National League pennant, a slightly flustered and addled selector feels he should at least be consistent in making known his American League choices. INDEPENDENCE, Mo., April 10 (UP) -Former President Truman had a good laugh today.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Justice Department has reported that about 1,000 cases of alleged housing frauds are awaiting prosecution.

The Easter lily, long a symbol of the springtime feast, has faded in importance this year. According to the Florists Telegraph Delivery Association, the azalea outstripped the lily in popular appeal and was the best-selling Easter plant.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, April 10 (AP) -- Critics of Gov. Archie A. Alexander began a coordinated campaign over the week-end to have President Eisenhower recall him. Republicans and Democrats joined in the attack.

PARIS, April 10 -- French federalists have not abandoned hope of a European union. With the "European" sponsors in the other countries they are laying plans to use the Paris agreements for the Western union as the foundation for a counter-drive for greater European unity.
Louis E. Wolfson charged yesterday that Sewell Avery, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., had misrepresented the financial position of several Wolfson enterprises.
Robert R. Young, in his first annual report as chairman of the New York Central Railroad, pledges his best efforts to make it "the most dynamic unit in a newly expanding railroad industry".
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 10 -- There was no Easter parade in Saigon today.
The Resurrection -- supreme festival of Christianity -- was hailed yesterday by thousands of worshipers at Easter Dawn services in New York and neighboring communities.

Today our Government is considering the advisability of entering into a Four-Power conference of which the Communist Soviet Government would be a party. WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Voice of America plans to offer eleven Soviet student editors a chance to tell the world "whatever they wish to say" about their first-hand impressions of the United States.

A most important meeting opens in Moscow Tuesday. Headed by Chancellor Julius Raab, a four-member Austrian delegation will start discussions with Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. BERLIN, April 10 -- Newspapers in West Berlin have recently reported rising unrest in East Germany that has erupted in scattered strikes, student revolts and open grumbling.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The United States and its North Atlantic Treaty allies plan a historic meeting in Paris about May 11 to welcome Western Germany as the fifteenth member of the defense pact, diplomatic officials said today.
