BERLIN, April 10 (UP) -- West Berlin newspapers criticized today the United States handling of the case of Valery A. Lysikov, Russian youth who fled to the West and then changed his mind and returned to his parents.
DOLGEVILLE, N. Y., April 10 -- The home run craze has decreed the slender silhouette for this season's bats.
Hirshon-Garfield, Inc., and the Peck Advertising Agency, Inc., will join forces as of May 1. The merged agency will be known under the name of the latter.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- James Marsh Douglas of St. Louis, former Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Missouri, headed the task force that prepared the studies on which the Hoover Commission reported today on the Government's legal services and procedures.

A Youth Misses His Mark In one of those unexpected bursts of muscular enthusiasm the young man delivering the morning paper overshot his mark -- i. e., the front porch -- and tossed the folded journal upon the porch roof, where it lay hidden from view below.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- Cary Middlecoff won the Masters golf tournament today by a record seven strokes.
BOSTON, April 10 -- The Giants wound up their 1955 exhibition campaign against major league opposition today with a grand flourish. They polished off Pinky Higgins' Red Sox, 6 to 4.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 9 -- A special session of the Alabama Legislature has finally passed Gov. James E. Folsom's request for additional taxes on out-ofstate corporations doing business in the state and on insurance company premiums.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that exports of United States agricultural products increased 7 per cent in value in 1954. They lagged 11 per cent below the 1952 level, however.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- More than 350 products of American industry will be on display to foreign buyers from Tuesday to April 27 at the Milan International Samples Fair, Roy F. Williams, director of the Office of International Trade Fairs of the Department of Commerce said today.

MOSCOW, April 10 -- By next Friday, when Austrian chancellor Julius Raab is expected to leave Moscow to return to Vienna, it should be clear whether, after ten years' delay, a settlement of the Austrian question is now possible.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Irregular price fluctuations were the rule in the grain markets last week. Short profit-taking operations have been extensive and there have also been periods of further liquidation of long lines.

RAMIRO CORTEZ, 21-year-old composer who won the tenth annual George Gershwin Memorial Award, was on hand when the New York Philharmonic-Symphony presented his prize-winning "Sinfonia Sacra." Dimitri Mitropoulos conducted the score on Saturday evening in Carnegie Hall.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 11 (Monday), (Reuters) -- Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, indicated dissatisfaction with Melbourne's preparations for the 1956 Olympic Games when he held a final press conference here today.

Home at last, the Yankees treated their followers to a dynamic display of long-range hitting yesterday. It brought a 7-3 victory over the Dodgers at the Stadium. Extra-base slugging, including homers by Joe Collins and Yogi Berra, highlighted the final spring training exhibition game for Casey Stengel's Bombers.

LONDON, April 10--Britain's Christian leaders called on the people to face the atomic age without fear, in Easter sermons that stressed the hydrogen bomb threat and the recent change in the British Government.

A four-story office building with stores and two rooming houses on plot 92 by 183 feet at 2121 Broadway, northwest corner of West Seventy-fourth Street, were sold by the Seventy Fourth Street Manhattan Corporation to investing clients of Walter Scott Co., brokers.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 7 -- A good way for Americans to try to grasp what life is like in Argentina under President Juan D. Peron is to imagine the answer to this question: "How would you feel living under a system of government in which there is no justice?"

One more obstacle to Japan's reentry into the comity of Far Eastern nations has been surmounted. An agreement has been reached with Thailand under which Japan will make certain money payments and give some contribution in goods and services to balance the account that Thailand had brought because of the Japanese occupation.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered the United Electrical Workers Union today to show why it should not lose its rights before the board because a union officer had not filed a non-Communist affidavit.
If one may take the word of Dr. H. M. H. A. van der Valk, the economic future of Canada rests squarely on the exhaustion of United States resources.

Restrictions imposed by the last Congress have nearly halted the low-rent public housing program, but there has been no corresponding shrinkage yet in the flow of housing bonds to market. This is because the financing of a project often is not completed until most of the tenants have moved in.
The State of New York intends to use its aviation industry as a nucleus for balanced industrial economy, Edward T. Dickinson, Commissioner of Commerce, declared yesterday.

Cotton prices moved irregularly last week. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed with mixed changes ranging from a gain of 12 points to a decline of 31 points (60 cents up to $1.55 a bale down), compared with the week before. The only net gains were in the two nearest deliveries.
When Frank Hughes got out of the Army, he and his wife Dorothy began to look for an apartment. Now, some ten years and five children later, they have found one.
HONG KONG, Monday, April 11 -- The highest Chinese Communist leaders were warned yesterday that henceforth they, too, would be "strictly" watched in the interests of party discipline.

Five members of the New York City Opera assumed new roles with the company over the week-end. Since all of them were young Americans and since all of them did well, it was a heartening demonstration of this country's developing wealth of operatic talent.
CINCINNATI, April 10 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs will oppose the Chicago Cubs in the National League's only game of the day.

ATLANTA, April 10 (UP) -- Senator Walter F. George's decision to seek his seventh Senate term today put former Gov. Herman Talmadge in the toughest spot of his spectacular career. It might set up a political fight that could seriously affect American foreign policy.

ST. LOUIS, April 10 (AP)--Red Schoendienst drove in four runs with a homer and single as the St. Louis Cardinals, first blowing a 6-1 lead and then overcoming a 9-6 deficit, gained a 10-9 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken championed at Riverside Church yesterday what he called the "pie in the sky when you die" theme of Christianity. The topic of his sermon was "Easter: But Who Wants to Live Forever?"
Worshipers at Christ Church Methodist, were advised yesterday to look upon the triumph of Easter as an inspiration in overcoming the fear of death, as well as the fact of death.

MARIA ELENA, Chile, April 3 -- The Chilean nitrate industry, like the copper industry, is reaching the end of a road. Either the Chilean Government must alter its antiquated and short-sighted legislation and encourage new investments, or the industry will sooner or later be strangled as it nearly was twenty-five years ago.
NEWARK, April 10 (UP) -- Fifty forest fires, aided by warm, dry weather and shifting winds, raged through New Jersey today. They swept 37,072 acres.
Thomas Cook Son has posed a new problem for summer sailors who probably have enough to do getting ready for their seasonal peregrinations.

Skeptics, cynics and scoffers to the contrary, advertising carries "a tremendous amount of weight with the great majority of the American public." This is the finding of Social Research, Inc., Chicago research organization, in a study the details of which were released yesterday.
The Cities Service Oil Company signed an agreement with the Maritime Administration yesterday for construction of a third 30,000 - deadweight - ton supertanker.

BAYONNE, N. J., April 11--The aircraft carrier Bennington steamed out of the naval supply depot here today for her first shakedown cruise since being modernized and repaired. The 27,100-ton vessel, will spend the summer on the...
A dozen survivors of the Nazi concentration camp at Buchenwald, Germany, observed last night the tenth anniversary of their liberation by American troops.

The National Broadcasting Company revealed yesterday that Claude Rains would not star in "Darkness at Noon" on television May 2 as it had announced last week. It said Lee J. Cobb would be starred instead.
CHICAGO, April 11--Adlai E. Stevenson called tonight for a joint declaration by the United States and its allies condemning the use of force in the Formosa Strait.
HONG KONG, April 11 -- An airliner carrying an eleven-man Communist group bound for the Asian-African conference in Bandung, Indonesia, crashed today in the South China Sea.
A reorganized bipartisan group announced yesterday plans to carry the case against admission of Communist China to the United Nations to President Eisenhower and to Allied nations in West Europe.
ALBANY, April 11 -- Hearings on ney state equalization rates established last February for 522 villages will be held here April 19 and 20. The rates are tentative until after the hearings.

FILMY white nylon scarf, top left, shelters spring nosegays in its poufed ends. This fill-in, which also comes in pastel shades, will perk up dark suits and dresses on balmy days. It is washable when flowers are removed.
An eight-year-old boy took the wheel of the family car yesterday and navigated busy Brooklyn thoroughfares to pay a call on his grandmother.

The twelve-story loft building at 840 Broadway has been resold by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, to a client of Adler Schwartz, attorneys. The property occupies a plot about 50 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of Thirteenth Street and is assessed at $200,000.

This was the wrong time of year to be home with a cold. At a good many other seasons, a cold has merit. Not now. At other times it is pleasant to have all meals in bed, and to receive other niceties of service and attention.
Harold W. Scott of Dean Witter Co. was nominated yesterday to serve a second one-year term as chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange.

It is ten year today since Franklin D. Roosevelt died. His memorials are not in bronze alone, nor in stone. They are in international policies which grew out of those he followed. They are in the United Nations, to which he gave the name and to whose principles, forecast in the Atlantic Charter and outlined at Dumbarton Oaks and in what was good in the Yalta agreements, He subscribed.

A Congressional showdown on farm policy is approaching. On one side will be the supporters of President Eisenhower's policy of flexible farm-price supports. On the other side will be the Congressional farm bloc, which is trying to scrap the flexible program and reinstitute the old system of rigid, high Government support of farm prices for major crops at 90 per cent of a mythical "parity."

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Supreme Court struck down today the Virgin Islands' "quickie" divorce law. Justice Felix Frankfurter, writing the majority opinion in a 5-to-3 decision, said that the law exceeded the authority delegated by Congress to the Legislative Assembly of the Islands.

The six-story apartment house for forty-nine families at 706 Lefferts Avenue in Brooklyn was purchased by the Estate Securities Company from Jerry Estates, Inc., through Milton J. Weinstein, broker, and was immediately resold to Abraham Feinerman.

In a recent publicized speech a distinguished educator listed six "major attributes" which a teacher should possess. It was interesting that there was omitted from desirable attributes of a teacher a love of children. This would seem to be a most essential attribute if the teacher is to have a wholesome effect on pupils and is not to raise unconsciously the hostility of pupils toward teachers, schools and education.

"Gate of Hell," the Japanese drama that won an Academy Award and the New York Film Critics prize as the year's best foreign-language film, will set an all-time record today at the Guild Theatre, when it enters its eighteenth week.

The first bloodmobile visit to the new headquarters of the Queens North Shore Chapter of the Red Cross at 42-22 Union Street, Flushing (FLushing 9-6464) will take place today. The hours will be from 1:30 to 7:30 P. M.

LONDON, April 11 -- Criticism of the Conservative Government's policies and demands for wage increases marked the final sessions today of the traditional Easter week-end conferences of trade unions and other organizations affiliated with the Labor party.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The American Institute of Homeopathy today opened its convention celebrating the centennial of the birth of Dr. Samuel Hahnemann, organizer of the homeopathic system of medicine.

PERHAPS in nostalgic mood as the season runs its course, Samuel Kootz has recalled for showing at his gallery, 600 Madison Avenue, a score of paintings and sculptures that have passed through the gallery and are now in public or private collections.

The same Chinese Communist party conference which recently purged Kao Kang and other former leaders also adopted a revised version of the Five-Year Plan for 1953-1957. The precise nature of the revision and the causes for it have not been made public, but an editorial in the Peiping Communist newspaper People's Daily hints strongly that economic difficulties and disappointments lie behind the revision.

CAMDEN, N. J., April 11 -- Superior Court Judge Vincent Haneman voided today a published list of 3,450 ineligible Cape May County voters. He ruled, in effect, that the persons named in the list could vote in the primary election next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby today marked the second birthday of her Health, Education and Welfare Department by presenting twenty awards to outstanding employes.
DOLE, France, April 10 -- Premier Edgar Faure now seeks another vote of confidence, this time not from the National Assembly but from his own canton.
Crime has been reduced 40 per cent in the Twenty-fourth Precinct since the force there was increased to 392 patrolmen eleven weeks ago, Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams said last night.
Opposition within the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity is said to be the main obstacle to fluoridation of the city's drinking water.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 11 -- The answer to the "superman theory" was declared here today to be the Christian insistence that freedom lies with God.
The City of New York was accused yesterday of neglecting its children through inadequate provisions for them in the proposed 1955-56 budget.

Ernest D'Antonio, 21 years old, took a big step forward to freedom yesterday in Kings County Court when Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz vacated a fifty-to-sixty-year prison term and then dismissed a robbery indictment.

Two performers, a pianist and a violinist, have been selected as joint winners of this year's Edgar M. Leventritt Award. They are John Browning, Denver-born pianist, and Betty-Jean Hagen, a violinist of Edmonton, Alberta.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 11 -- A couple of miles from the center of Saigon a bridge guarded by cannon of armored river barges leads to the headquarters of one of the world's strangest and most dangerous armies.

Teddy Atkinson will ride William Woodward Jr.'s Nashua in the $100,000 added Wood Memorial at Jamaica a week from Saturday. The assignment was made yesterday by Nashua's trainer, Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, after word from Bowie that Eddie Arcaro had received a suspension there.
Having completed its 1954-55 New York season last Saturday, the Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday issued its statement on operations for 1953-54.

International commerce moving through the Port of New York as reflected by customs collections, increased almost 25 per cent last month, as compared with February. The movement of inbound and outbound ships, planes and passengers also rose sharply.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- John Barr, vice president and secre-] tary of Ward, today accused Mr.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Children of all ages, as the man in the circus puts it, gamboled on the White House lawn today. President Eisenhower personally welcomed them.

ROME, April 11 -- The Dominican Order elected the Rev. Michael Browne, a leading Irish theologian, its master general today. He is the first Irishman to head the "Order of Preachers" since its founding by St. Dominic in the early part of the thirteenth century.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation operated at a profit in March for the first time since the two old-line auto manufacturers merged last October. James J. Nance, president, made this statement yesterday in a progress report to a management group of the two divisions.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 11 -- "Melbourne has no time to waste; not enough has been accomplished. You need half a dozen of the biggest men in the city to take charge of the plans," said Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, in a blunt statement today.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The United States has told Czechoslovakia it could not violate its "traditional practice" of granting asylum to political refugees.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan revealed yesterday an exchange of correspondence to support his charge that the Distillery Workers Union, A. F. L., was defying his investigation of its financial affairs.

CLEVELAND, April 11 (AP) -- Aluminum Company of America said today it will begin operating May 5 a new $40,000,000 U. S. Air Force press plant designed for precision production of massive airframe parts.
A detective's tenacity and a chemist's knowledge are being combined these days in the Health Department's new Poison Control Center.

Abraham J. Engelman of 120 East Eighty-eighth Street, an insurance consultant, collapsed and died yesterday while pursuing the avocation that made him an institution at public hearings on the municipal executive budget.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- When Scott McLeod, administrator of security for the State Department, suggested to Secretary Dulles that Edward J. Corsi would be a good choice to oil the wheels of the immigration act of 1953, it was hailed in the department as a happy thought indeed.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, April 12 (AP) -- Melbourne newspapers today gave wide play to Avery Brundage's blast on Melbourne's lagging Olympic construction. A leading columnist called for the resignation of the head man of the city's Olympic Games Committee.

CARDIFF, Wales, April 11 -- The emotional radicalism and evangelistic fervor that fired British socialism half a century ago still burn bright in the valleys of South Wales, and Aneurin Bevan is an honored prophet in his own country.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Bob Porterfield of the Senators made his third opening day start his first such winning performance today. He scattered six hits and helped his own cause with some sound hitting and fielding.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Supreme Court let stand today a ruling that an employer in negotiations must furnish, on union request, the names and wage rates of employes.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Sherman Adams, President Eisenhower's chief assistant, blames Federal employes held over from previous Administrations for "leaks" of present Administration policies.
Participants in a labor-management lovefest yesterday heard a new definition of the word "boss."
MOSCOW, Tuesday, April 12 (AP) -- Pravda printed today a strong attack on the State Prosecutor of the Soviet Union and said he was not doing his duty.

The reconvening of Congress tomorrow after the Easter recess marks the opening of the second half of the session -- though, judging from the amount of work still to be done, the second half may prove to be considerably longer than the first.

CINCINNATI, April 11 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs hit for distance today against wobbly Cincinnati pitching. Two home runs plus five doubles sparked them to a 7-5 victory over the Redlegs in the opening game of the 1955 National League pennant race. The game was played before 32,195 fans.
TOKYO, April 11 -- Premier Ichiro Hatoyama forecast today an eventual Japanese move to revise agreements with the United States.
JERUSALEM, April 11 -- One thousand former prisoners held a reunion in a former jail yard here today to honor their erstwhile prison chaplain on his seventieth birthday.

Stocks started firm yesterday, weakened and then recovered toward the close. The session ended with negligible changes in the averages. However, steels and aircrafts were soft, while pharmaceuticals, chemicals and communications made gains.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- Richie Ashburn and Del Ennis, slightly battered and well padded -- but still suffering some pain -- were declared available to play for Philadelphia in tomorrow's opener if Manager Mayo Smith wants to use them.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Eisenhower threw a grounder today to open the major league baseball season.
Beaches began to figure noticeably in the news yesterday as the temperature in the city rose to 79.8 degrees at 2:40 P. M.
"Champagne complex," a farce by Leslie Stevens, whose first play "Bullfight" had a successful off-Broadway engagement last season, opens at the Cort Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's winter wheat crop at 662,252,000 bushels -- down one - sixth from last year's.
TRENTON, April 11 (AP) -- State Fire Warden William J. Seidel said tonight that all forest fires in the state were either out or under control.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The sounding of a burglar alarm thwarted a hold-up yesterday in a branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company, at 799 Blake Avenue, Brooklyn. However, the bandit escaped in a car driven by a confederate.

LIMA, Peru, April 11 (UP) -- Delegates representing sixteen countries, including the United States and Canada, attended the opening today of the fourth Inter-American Radio Congress, which will consider the adoption of a code of ethics for radio.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Twenty-one additions were made today to the Attorney General's list of subversive organizations, putting the total at 303.

The world-wide organization of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) last year produced and sold more oil than ever before, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Despite this, the company said, its crude oil reserves increased during the year.

CAMDEN, N. J., April 11 (AP) -- Subpoenas were served today calling for all communications bearing on the purchase of stock in the New York Shipbuilding Corporation by a group of stockholders suing the Camden company.
The following story was written by Tom Phillips, sports columnist of The Daily Herald, London.
Philadelphia announced yesterday plans for borrowing $12,000,000 on school district bonds. Dated June 1, 1955, the bonds will come due serially on June 1 from 1957 to 1980.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Government went to the United States Court of Appeals today for the second time in its long effort to sustain a key perjury indictment against Owen Lattimore.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Following are excerpts from the text of an address given tonight by Secretary of State Dulles:

I have read with great interest and satisfaction the letter of Robert W. Dowling, president, Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., which you published on March 31. The members of the Real Estate Board of New York believe that those who are currently moaning over the future of New York City are unduly pessimistic.
GROTON, Conn., April 11--The world's first Submarine Library was opened here today.

Natalie Ryshna, young American pianist who made a promising New York debut three years ago, last night gave her second local recital at Town Hall. She confirmed her gifts and showed that she has continued to develop.

The Investors Funding Corporation of New York has purchased the four-story apartment house for forty families at 143-154 to 143-156 Roosevelt Avenue and 40-10 to 40-12 Parsons Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, from Little Neck Investors, Inc. Sidney M. Siegel Co. were the brokers and Albert Hlavac was attorney for the seller.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Good rains in parts of the drought section of Oklahoma caused wheat prices to decline early to day. However, there was broader buying on the recession, and a partial recovery around midday.
New York hopes this summer to win a major share of iron ore imports which now move chiefly through Baltimore.
The secrets of the structure of the protein molecule may finally be known to man within three to five years, it was forecast here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today denied Oklahoma the right to fix minimum prices on natural gas sold at the Panoma Corporation gasoline plant in Texas County (Okla.) to the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America for transmission to Chicago and other Illinois areas.
Roy Wilkins became yesterday the new executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 11 -- Shortly after 10 A. M. tomorrow the answer to the question mankind has been anxiously waiting for will be given.
Following is the text of the radio speech by Adlai E. Stevenson last night as recorded by The New York Times:
ATHENS, April 11 -- Sophocles Venizelos announced tonight that he would head a new political combination, the Liberal Democratic party.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) Carl Stockholm, president of the Navy League, protested tonight that under new Defense Department restrictions on information, discovery of a Communist infiltration of the armed services could not be revealed.
Admiral Arthur Radford cautioned the nation last night against complacency about its "qualitative lead in air power."
Danny Giovanelli, Brooklyn welterweight, scored a unanimous decision over Chris Christensen of Denmark in the main event of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP)--This year's graduates of the Reserve Officer Training Corps may obtain deferment from the draft for two years, the Army announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Retail store sales in March were 8 per cent ahead of a year ago, the Department of Commerce estimated today.
Unseasonable cold weather and snow over much of the central area of European Russia are adding new difficulties to this year's high-priority Soviet drive to raise farm production.
MILWAUKEE, April 11 (AP) -- Milwaukee became the newest port on the inland waterway system yesterday when a specially designed barge was pushed up the Milwaukee River from Lake Michigan.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- Allie Reynolds, former pitching star of the New York Yankees, filed suit for $235,250 against the Philadelphia Transportation Co. today for injuries allegedly suffered in a bus accident here on July 7, 1953.

The drift of bond investments to higher yields and lower prices is one reaction of financial markets to the biggest first quarter in business history. In recent weeks, however, there has been some firming in the prices of the tax-exempt interest obligations of local governments.

BOSTON, April 11 -- Mr. Wolfson told Ward stockholders here today that he had turned down a "deal" with a British namesake who sought a place on the Ward board. The deal was contingent on Mr. Wolfson's gaining control of the company.
PARIS, April 11 -- The French Army has begun to reorganize its active divisions without waiting for an Allied military decision on the ideal form of the "atomic" ground force.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 11 -- The long-awaited battle between the Town of Greenwich and the Greenwich Water Company opened today. The opposing forces met before the Public Utilities Commission in Town Hall.
A 23-year-old mother who is expected to give birth soon to twins, or possibly triplets, was saved yesterday from a prison sentence on the promise of placing the unborn children for adoption.
The first public hearing on a projected state code to protect workers against radiation produced many suggestions for revision yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 11 -- Kansas City extended a major league welcome to its first major league baseball club today.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Following are the texts of statements issued today on the dropping of Edward J. Corsi as State Department adviser on immigration. They are a letter from Mr. Corsi to Secretary of State Dulles and a statement by the department.

First quarter sales of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. totaled $470,000,000, about 17 per cent above the initial three months last year, and about 3 per cent better than the final quarter of 1954. The figures were disclosed by Crawford H. Greenewalt, president, at the annual meeting of shareholders held yesterday in Wilmington, Del.
The city is looking into the possibility of reducing from 50 per cent to 25 per cent the pension contributions of 115,000 city employes. This was disclosed by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

MONTREAL, April 11 -- Clement R. Attlee, leader of Britain's Opposition Labor party, said here today that he would press for an early meeting "among leading statesmen" should the Laborites win the next election.
NEW DELHI, India, April 11 -- United States Ambassador John Sherman Cooper defended today the series of military alliances that have been forged by his Government since the end of World War II.

A stockholders' fight was indicated yesterday over the future of Reo Holding Corporation. The holding company is all that remains after the sale last year of the physical assets of Reo Motors to the Bohn Aluminum and Brass Corporation.
ROME, April 11 -- The police in Vercelli used tear gas today to break up a group of about 3,000 Po Valley farmers who were marching on the prefecture to protest taxation.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 11 (AP)--Premier Hussein Ala's new Government sacked Mayor Ghollambussein Estehaj of Teheran today after deputies had accused him of slackness and of being responsible for the rising cost of living.
MOSCOW, April 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Ministry of Agriculture has dismissed two state farm directors and ordered them to make good a big loss in cattle that died from neglect.
A new testing and information center aimed at improving techniques in fabricating textiles into apparel will be established next month by New York's Fashion Institute of Technology.

LONDON, April 11 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers today rebounded into the race for English League soccer honors by downing Aston Villa, 1 -- 0. The Wanderers regained second place behind idle Chelsea.
The traditional courtesy inaugurals having been put on yesterday at Washington and Cincinnati, the way has been cleared for the 1955 major league pennant races to go into full swing today.
The Marine Midland Corporation, which owns a chain of ten banks in New York State, is reported to be negotiating with the Jamaica National Bank, Jamaica, L. I., for a possible merger.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Edward J. Corsi refused today to take a new State Department assignment as a substitute for the immigration post from which he was ousted.
In Pakistan a good cook follows her nose to culinary success.

The problem of unwanted children will not be solved by making birth-control information available to all families, as suggested in your columns on April 6 by Marie Perry Price of the Planned Parenthood Association.

Two biographies of Sir Anthony Eden, the new British Prime Minister, are being prepared for publication this season. One is by Alan Campbell Johnson, tentatively titled "Eden: The Making of a Statesman." It will be issued by Ives Washburn.
BELLEAIR, Fla., April 11 -- Labor's demand for a guaranteed annual wage was condemned today as a "straightjacket" that could destroy the country's "sound and expanding economy."

DON'T be overly impressed by the fact that Chicago is leading the National League standings this morning or that Washington is on top in the American League. Each of these gun-jumpers has 153 games to go and that's a long, wearying stretch.

In a note to the Communist regime of Czechoslovakia the United States declares again that it continues to honor the right of political asylum. We reject Communist demands for the return of persons who flee from that country for political reasons.

Potato prices rose the daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The spot April option was up 1/2 cent a pound and the other months rose 1/4 cent. The volume was only 134 car lots (45,000 pounds to a car) but more than 3,400 cars were wanted at the limit up at the close.
The interest of the college rowing world will be centered on Princeton's Carnegie Lake this week.

BERLIN, April 11 -- Fifty thousand former inmates of Buchenwald and their families met today at the concentration camp site to celebrate the tenth anniversary of its liberation. The site is in the Soviet Zone, near Weimar.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Department of Justice is again under fire in Congress for delays in the retrial of the espionage case of Judith Coplon.
CAIRO, April 11--Six leaders of the abortive coup against Imam Seif el-Islam Ahmad of Yemen are reported to have been condemned and publicly beheaded.

In May, 1937, planes landed four Russian scientists and technicians on an ice floe at the North Pole. After drifting until February, 1938, toward Greenland the four were taken off only after the floe was cracked and melting but with important observations to their credit.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 8 -- Argentina under Gen. Juan D. Peron is a country in economic distress. This conclusion is inescapable after a study of the situation there made by this writer in February and March.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Proposed postal pay rises found a dozen mail-worker unions split three ways today.
The Ford Motor Company expects to publish its "financial and operating facts" this year for the first time in its fifty- two-year history, Ernest R. Breech, chairman, said here last night.
Operations of the nation's steel mills are estimated at 95 per cent of capacity for this week, The American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday production of 2,292,000 tons was forecast.
Greater use of Presbyterian Hospital by the public and richer benefits from its scientific researches than ever before are cited in the institution's annual report.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Secretary of State Dulles warned tonight that the "craven purchase of peace" could lead to consequences more terrible than modern war.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today tightened its rules on the finances of securities brokers and dealers.
A man who criticizes his wife's appearance should "pay up or shut up." according to Richard Willis, beauty consultant.
MOSCOW, April 11 -- Austrian Chancellor Julius Raab arrived in Moscow today in a snowstorm for talks on Soviet proposals for concluding an Austrian state treaty.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Lawyers for two states and the District of Columbia urged the Supreme Court today not to order racial segregation in the public schools ended "forthwith."
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Eisenhower announced today that he would ask Congress to approve a special program of "economic aid to the free nations of South and East Asia."

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 11--Premier Pibul Songgram said today Thailand was looking forward to participating in next week's Asian-African conference, but that she still placed the greatest hope for peace in the Southeast Asia Collective Defense Treaty.
The nation's growing army of "do-it-yourself" fans may be having lots of fun, but a safety expert says they are exposing themselves to a horde of new hazards.
THE trout were elusive and uncooperative on most of the Catskill streams on opening day, but Sunday and yesterday proved fairly productive for persistent anglers.
WEST POINT, N. Y., April 11 -- The New York Giants ended their spring exhibition schedule today by defeating Army, 14 to 1, before an overflow crowd of nearly 8,000 at Doubleday Field.
"Patience" while attempts are being made "to work things out" on the New York waterfront was urged last night by Maitland S. Pennington, director of operations for the Robin Line.

Church groups, secular agencies and religious leaders expressed puzzlement and "deep dismay" yesterday over the dropping of Edward J. Corsi from his job as special immigration adviser to the Secretary of State.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11 -- Israel sought today to speed up United Nations consideration of her charges that recurrent Egyptian border assaults threatened peace in the Middle East.
A new and different version of "The Telephone" ran for one performance yesterday morning. But it was more like television's "Our Miss Brooks" than the Gian-Carlo Menotti opera.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 11 -- The Rev. Dr. Douglas Horton of New York has been appointed dean of the Harvard Divinity School. He has been minister of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches.

A group of fourteen table settings now on view at McCutcheon's stresses pleasant color arrangements and informality. Black and white checked gingham trims a stark white cloth for one setting. A butter mold patterned cloth gives a country air to another table.

Macy's, at whose corporate courage experienced parents must marvel, has invited the city's boys and girls to a weeklong whing-ding at its Herald Square store. Yesterday, some 100,000 youngsters made the most of opening day.

JERUSALEM, April 11 -- An Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman said tonight in a broadcast in Arabic that if Egypt would pacify her border with Israel, a basis for "coexistence" of the two nations would be found.

CLEVELAND, April 11 (UP) -- Al Lopez, who in seven years as a baseball manager never finished lower than second place, was given a new two - year vote - of - confidence contract by the Cleveland Indians today. It calls for an estimated salary of $45,000 a year.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 11 -- David O. Selznick has started negotiations to cast the lead role in his first film for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, "The Accident."

The newspaper strike in London raises questions with which only the publishers and the unions involved can deal; but as the days lengthen, and the strike continues without interruption, the spectacle of a great national and international capital deprived of its most complete and authoritative source of information becomes more and more astonishing and depressing.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 11 (AP) -- A state official, notified that his wife and three children were being held hostage in their home here today, flew fifty miles and killed the intruder, a crazed gunman.
CLEVELAND, April 11 (AP) -- Rise Stevens sang the title role of "Carmen" in Public Hall tonight as the Metropolitan Opera opened its 7,000-mile, two-month tour.

Stadium Concerts, Inc., announced yesterday the names of twenty-two of the soloists who will be heard this summer at the concerts at Lewisohn Stadium. Many are artists who appear there regularly, but one, Rudolf Serkin, has not played at the stadium in fifteen years.
PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- The State has been asked to take part in the hearings on two suits to compel Girard College to enroll Negro pupils.

A group of fourteen table settings now on view at McCutcheon's stresses pleasant color arrangements and informality. Black and white checked gingham trims a stark white cloth for one setting. A butter mold patterned cloth gives a country air to another table.

Macy's, at whose corporate courage experienced parents must marvel, has invited the city's boys and girls to a weeklong whing-ding at its Herald Square store. Yesterday, some 100,000 youngsters made the most of opening day.

The first vaccination in any way comparable to modern practice was made on May 14, 1796, by Edward Jenner, an English physician.

PITTSBURGH, April 12 (UP) -- The assistants whom Dr. Jonas E. Salk credits with major roles in the development of his poliomyelitis vaccine average less than 40 years of age.
A robber chose a dramatic setting for a hold-up yesterday -- a century-old house once owned by Boss Tweed, on a wooded and rocky acre of hillside overlooking the Hudson and Harlem Rivers.

President Eisenhower is expected to send to Congress soon a comprehensive message on our aid program for Asian states in the "arc of freedom." There will be discussion of the amount that is to be appropriated, of the various objectives to which it is to go, and of the administrative agency or agencies that will have the control of the spending.
Bear pin awards for outstanding service in extra-curricular activities were presented to seven Barnard College seniors yesterday at the annual undergraduate association installation assembly.

A close, understanding relationship between parent and nursery school teacher will provide the most valuable benefits a child can gain during this first important group experience, Eleanor Brussel said here last night.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that a special appropriation of $100,000 would be made to speed the city's polio vaccination program.
A plea for recognition of the advertising manager as a member of top management was made last night by Stuart Peabody, chairman of The Advertising Council, a public service organization.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today Adlai E. Stevenson advocated "as original ideas" the same steps toward peace in the Formosa Strait that the Administration was exploring.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- Eugene W. Castle has testified that he had seen only one of a dozen United States Information Agency films he criticized as "pure propaganda" and "a waste of money."
ROME, April 12 -- Pope Pius XII appeared on television screens in six West European countries tonight.
The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., yesterday broke off subcommittee negotiations for a new wage agreement with the Transit Authority. The action cleared the way for discussions at top level.
The State Education Commissioner warned the City of Yonkers yesterday that it would lose its state grants to aid education unless it improved its public school system.

This is to express appreciation for the fine article concerning the "Cooperative Program in Educational Administration" which appeared in the April 3 issue of The New York Times under the name of Benjamin Fine, and for the editorial headed "Educational Leadership" which appeared in The Times of April 6.
Russeks is sheltering a bevy of gay young cotton dresses. Junior-sized and styled by Kay Windsor, they are in the unharried price range of $8.95 to $12.95.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- When two distinguished and experienced public servants such as Secretary of State Dulles and Adlai E. Stevenson criticize each other publicly in the midst of the China crisis, it is a fairly good bet that something has gone wrong with the machinery of consultation between the major political parties.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12 -- Officials of the World Health Organization hailed the report on the Salk poliomyelitis vaccine today as "extremely encouraging."
TRENTON, April 12 -- The inoculation of nearly 300,000 school children with the Salk polio vaccine will begin Monday in New Jersey. The program will be started in Bergen County.
LONDON, April 12 -- Prime Minister Eden presided today over the first meeting of his reconstituted Cabinet.

Operations of the International Business Machines Corporation in the first three months this year resulted in a net income of $11,401,947, after estimated Federal income taxes, the report disclosed yesterday. In the initial quarter of 1954 the company had a net income of $10,134,429.

The Salk triple anti-polio vaccine is designed to protect the individual against the crippling effect of the three types of virus known to cause polio. It provides its immunity by stimulating production in the bloodstream of three types of antibodies, each specific for one of the three types of polio virus.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 -- An apparatus devised for performing brain operations with inaudible sound waves of extremely high pitch instead of with the surgeon's knife was pronounced ready for use on patients today.

Stockholders of Philip Morris Co. Ltd., Inc., shortened the corporate title yesterday to Philip Morris, Inc., and elected as a director Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority. He fills a board vacancy left by his brother, the late Joseph F. Cullman Jr.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Advocates of right-to-work laws said today that states that have these laws on the books generally have outstripped the others in economic gains. Right-to-work laws prohibit compulsory unionism.
Tennessee Williams' controversial play "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" won yesterday the New York Drama Critics Circle designation of the best American play of the 1954-55 season.
April is the peak month of the year for annual meetings of corporations. These meetings serve to promote better understanding between companies and their stockholders.

Two members of the Police Department's narcotics squad were indicted yesterday for first-degree perjury. The Kings County rackets grand jury made the charges after investigation of alleged tie-ups of policemen and peddlers of narcotics.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Former President Truman denied tonight a published report that he would seek to run for Vice President on the Democratic ticket next year.
Stocks pushed forward vigorously, yesterday and came close to establishing a new high for the year.

The first is an abstract of the report by Dr. Thomas Francis Jr., and the second is the full summary of Chapter 3 of the report on the vaccine's effectiveness.
The cost of borrowing money on a short-term basis continued its upward movement yesterday.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., April 12 (AP) -- A plan it is estimated would net the average New York milkshed dairyman another $18 monthly has been approved by the United States Secretary Of Agriculture, it was reported today.

It again seems time to call attention to the precarious existence of Manhattan landmarks. Perhaps the best way is merely to name the buildings or groups of buildings that only a few years ago had a place on the Municipal Art Society's index of architecturally historic structures worthy of preservation.

This is Brand Names Day, when we give honor to the thousands of products we hear about and use every day of our lives. Testimony to the ingenuity of the American merchant, many of these names have traveled the length and breadth of the world.
Joseph Benenati, 33 years old, key witness in a murder trial scheduled to open next Monday in Queens County Court, has disappeared, the Queens District Attorney's office reported yesterday.

PARIS, April 12 -- High circles in the French Army are dissatisfied with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's criteria of battle-readiness as applied to French land forces. These criteria do not give sufficient weight to France's highly organized mobilization system, French Army leaders believe.
Supplies of the Salk vaccine to take care of the heavy expected demand will be large enough before very much time has elapsed.
In half a century, medical science has virtually eliminated in some parts of the world afflictions that had plagued mankind through the ages.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Eisenhower's "atoms-for-peace" plan, voiced in 1953, was in the nature of a master stroke, according to testimony given to the House Appropriations Committee.

A thirty-one-acre tract in Brooklyn, formerly occupied by the Boulevard Housing Project, was sold at auction by the city yesterday for $405,000. The high bidder was Milton M. Steinberg, president of the Dodger Realty Corporation of Brooklyn. The new owner plans to improve the parcel of 682 lots with several hundred dwellings.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 9 -- There is probably no phase of United States policy toward Latin America that has aroused so much controversy as the openly and strongly pro-Peronist attitude of the State Department and the United States Embassy in Buenos Aires.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 12 -- The Salk vaccine for poliomyelitis will be made available for the immunization of children as rapidly as possible, but it is expected to be in short supply temporarily. The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis announced today that vaccine already purchased for 9,000,000 immunizations (three inoculations a child) would be turned over to state and territorial health officers.

MELBOURNE, April 12 -- Work ceased on the Melbourne waterfront today because of the strike of dock workers. Forty-four ships were idle. Work also stopped on thirteen other ships at Hobart, owing to a similar strike.

Joseph M. Roebling had two horses competing at Jamaica yesterday and he saw them both win. The Harbourton (N. J.) sportsman was among the 17,412 who attended the program, which was featured by a six-furlong purse called the Ceres.

SYRACUSE, Sicily, April 12 -- Sir Winston and Lady Churchill arrived this evening for a vacation in this ancient and picturesque seaport. They have rooms reserved for two weeks but are expected to stay longer.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- United Air Lines announced today at its annual stockholder meeting in Chicago that it has ordered twenty-six four-engined aircraft costing about $42,500,000 from Douglas Aircraft Company, Santa Monica, Calif.
Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "3 for Tonight" on April 28 at the Plymouth Theatre for the benefit of the Washington Square Home for Friendless Girls.

DON COCKELL, the British heavyweight who is to meet Rocky Marciano for the world heavyweight championship in San Francisco on May 16, whisked into town and out of it yesterday. But he paused long enough to lighten Gene Leone's groaning board.
Dr. Jonas E. Salk is a shy, quiet scientist 40 years old. He is a native New Yorker and the father of three boys.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- On a dreary day when the New York Giants were rained out of their scheduled opener with the Phillies; Larry Jansen made the news for the world champions today. He quit them to accept a pitching post with Seattle in the Pacific Coast League.
PARIS, April 12 (Reuters) -- The United States report on a successful anti-polio vaccine stimulated mass vaccination plans throughout Europe.

Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad have authorized the leasing of 200 light-weight, low-center-of-gravity flat cars of new design for "piggy-back" operation. The cars are expected to be in service by the end of this year.
NEW DELHI, April 12 -- Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Premier of Egypt, arrived here today en rout to Bandung, Indonesia, to attend the African-Asian conference beginning next week.

Near-by potato options were strong in active trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The market opened the limit higher, then eased, but rallied in late trading. May positions closed the 1/4-cent-a-pound limit higher with more than 400 unsatisfied bids.

CLEVELAND, April 12 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner's first American League home run and Bob Lemon's air-tight pitching helped as the Cleveland Indians got off on the right foot today in defense of their league title. They defeated the Chicago White Sox, 5--1.

MONTREAL, April 12 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadians bounced back for the second time and squared the Stanley Cup hockey finals at three games each as they downed the Detroit Red Wings tonight, 6 -- 3.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 12 (Reuters) -- Australia's lair-conscious travelers now have the choice of the newest airliners as three major companies compete for customers.

Elinor Glyn, author of many successful novels, including "It," "Three Weeks" and "Man and Maid," is the subject of a biography that Doubleday will publish June 30. Titled "Elinor Glyn," it is written by her grandson, Anthony Glyn.

GREENSBURG, Pa, April 12 (AP) -- Three Westmoreland County judges found six newpaper men and a free-lance photographer guilty of criminal contempt of court today for having defied a court ban against taking photographs.

A young handyman, whose love for good art led him to shift a small painting from a storage closet in an East Side duplex to a spot of prominence in his own apartment, interested a special audience of connoisseurs yesterday. The police, with a critical eye of their own for art, arrested him for taking a 420-year-old portrait valued by the owner at $8,000.

HARLEM was lushly green and more or less semi-rural sixty-four years ago when the community's genteel ladies took over the Haarlem Philharmonic Society. Their husbands had started the venture two years before, in 1889, but had not done too well at it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12 -- Dr. I. I. Rabi, Nobel Prize winner in physics, will serve as one of the six vice presidents at the United Nations conference on peaceful uses of atomic energy to be held in Geneva in August.
The Guaranty Trust Company is heading a group of about twenty banks which will purchase $35,000,000 of Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company secured 3 1/2 per cent serial notes.
MILAN, Italy, April 12 -- Uncle Sam, who has appeared to foreigners in many guises, took on the personality of a wise helpful cousin to European business men at the Milan Fair, which opened today.

Glitter and gilt dazzle the eye as one enters the native Indian bazaar just installed on the first floor of the Museum of Modern Art. It will remain there through June 12.

Stymied by the rain yesterday, the Yankees and the Dodgers will try to launch their 1955 campaigns today at the Stadium and Ebbets Field. Their respective opponents will be the Washington Senators and the Pittsburgh Pirates.

BONN, Germany, April 11 -- The United States Seventh Army in West Germany is so strong that it is now planned to defend every inch it holds in the event of a Soviet attack. This strategic decision was imparted today by Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe, commander of the United States Army in Europe.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, who brought Eskimo pies and cornflakes back from the United States in 1936, said tonight he was afraid he would not recognize the United States if he returned now.

Cotton futures held in a narrow range yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices closed 4 points (20 cents a bale) higher to 1 point (5 cents) lower than on Monday.

HOLLYWOOD, April 10 -- Millions of people in this world know nothing of the United States save what they see in the movies. Hollywood is the looking-glass in which is reflected the American way of life, its philosophy and ideology. Willy-nilly the film industry has come to be a signally important arm of policy. For its unconscious propaganda effect upon foreign minds is immense.

A two-story business building at 133 Seventh Avenue South running through the block to 165 West Tenth Street has been sold by Saul Wasserman to Pietro Diero Jr. for occupancy as an accordion school It is assessed at $30,000 and was bought for cash through William Alfred White, broker.

KABUL, Afghanistan (via Peshawar, Pakistan) , April 11 -- The Soviet Ambassador was reported today to have offered help to Afghanistan's Premier. The aid was to be military support if Pakistan or her Western allies "threaten aggressive interference" in Afghanistan's demand for a plebiscite in the adjoining North-West Frontier Province.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- In the presence of senior leaders of the Soviet state, Charles E. Bohlen, United States Ambassador, offered a toast this evening to the speedy restoration of Austria's independence and freedom.

A chamber orchestra composed of members of the Philharmonic-Symphony played a concert last night under the direction of Remus Tzincoca. The program was given in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12 -- Arkady A. Sobolev today presented to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold his credentials as permanent representative of the Soviet Union at the United Nations. He thereby assumed the post left vacant by the death of Andrei Y. Vishinsky.

CHICAGO, April 12 (UP) -- Dee Fondy batted in five runs with a double and a single today as the Chicago Cubs defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 14 -- 4. The Cubs opened their home season before 26,153 fans by getting eighteen hits off five Cardinal hurlers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 12 -- "Nedra," described as a drama of "the exaltation of human nature over tragedy, told against a musical background," will be the first independent film effort by Armand S. Deutsch.

The strike-shut Brooklyn Eagle was put up for sale yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- It was open war today between John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, and his former "old friend," Edward Corsi.

On Monday, the first day of the two Insurance Weeks of the regional Red Cross blood program, 173 pints of blood were given by insurance concern employes. The donation center is the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street, where the collection will continue today. Monday's total was 299 pints.
The city's two largest banks -- the Chase Manhattan Bank and the First National City Bank of New York -- elected vice presidents yesterday.

LAST night was a gala night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the Ballet Theatre was not only opening its first extended engagement in New York in two years, but it was also celebrating its fifteenth anniversary, with a host of guest artists listed in the program and four of them on this bill.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, has set up a study committee to advise him on labor-management problems at atomic energy installations.
More than 6,000 New York physicians received a visual digest last night of the preliminary report on the immunization against poliomyelitis.
Judge John Clark Knox announced yesterday that he would retire on April 30.

The Department of Health has announced that children in the first and second grades in New York public, private and parochial schools as well as children who participated in last year's field trial with Salk vaccine but were not inoculated, will receive free injections -- provided their parents:
LESLIE STEVENS, author of last year's "Bullfight," has now written a thin farce with a bright surface, "Champagne Complex," which was acted at the Cort last evening.

An eight - story mechanical parking garage for 322-328 West Fifty-seventh Street was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The owner is the 316 West Fifty-seventh Street Corporation, of which Samuel Lehrer is president.
A sound track one-thousandth of an inch in diameter and three miles long, capable of reproducing eight hours of uninterrupted music, had its first showing in this country yesterday.
The three types of polio virus, from which the triple Salk anti-polio vaccine is made, are grown in tissue culture flasks containing minced monkey kidney tissue.

It is more than three months since President Eisenhower first proposed that the United Nations intervene to avert a new crisis in the Far East by attempting to arrange a cease-fire in the Formosa Strait. The Security Council promptly undertook such a move, but suspended action on it when Communist China bluntly rejected its invitation to join in the effort.
HARTFORD, April 12 -- The State Health Department is planning an immediate program to vaccinate Connecticut school children against polio.

HOBOKEN, N. J., April 12 -- A Dutch grocer and his family landed here today to start a new life in America. It was the result of their having sheltered, at the risk of their own lives, five Jewish refugees from the Nazi invaders of the Netherlands in World War II.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 12 -- The formal verdict on the Salk vaccine was disclosed today amid fanfare and drama far more typical of a Hollywood premiere than a medical meeting.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The chairmen of the two major political parties agreed today that the ceiling on campaign spending should be raised.
The press, the armed services, the Department of Defense and the White House share the blame for the current Washington tempest about security and public relations.

Infantile paralysis or poliomyelitis, the dreaded, crippling disease of childhood, has been know by agonized parents for many centuries. It is believed that some cases of paralysis mentioned in the Bible were caused by polio.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., April 12 (AP) -- Governor Harriman placed a wreath on Franklin D. Roosevelt's grave today and said the President who died ten years ago "will be remembered long after his critics have been forgotten."

The continued improved outlook for carloadings should result in net earnings for the Erie Railroad this year of more than $2.75 a common share before capital and sinking fund charges, Paul W. Johnston, president, told stodckholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, April 12 -- Kansas City made a festive, happy bow into major league baseball today. To the boundless delight of an overflow crowd of 32,844 at the sparkling new Municipal Stadium, the transplanted Athletics turned back the Detroit Tigers, 6 -- 2, in their opening game.
ATLANTA, April 12 (UP) -- Gov. Hugh White of Mississippi proposed today a conference of Southern Governors to discuss means of ending a southwide communications strike.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today the nation's shrinking farm income should reach "considerable stability" this year.

" Meet the People -- 1955" will be introduced at 8:30 tonight in the Cafe Theatre, 237 West Forty-sixth Street, once occupied by the Diamond Horseshoe, Billy Rose's night club in the Paramount Hotel. Warning: Latecomers will not be seated until intermission. Besides the revue, food and refreshments will be served at tables, seating 740, and smoking will be allowed.

Chamberlain Brown, veteran artists' representative, was indicted yesterday by a New York County grand jury. He is accused of taking money from aspiring actors on false promises that he could get them jobs in summer stock companies.

The home cook planning to buy a new refrigerator considers carefully the relative merits of various models before making up her mind. Equal deliberation should precede the purchase of kitchen knives, as food preparation cannot proceed efficiently without good ones.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 13 -- Archbishop Makarios blamed the British today for recent bomb outrages on this island -- thirty-five in all.

Alfred Rainer is a furrier out of Vienna and of that generation of gentlemen who can kiss a lady's hand gracefully. His small, thick-carpeted sale at 17 East Fifty-fifth Street has an aura of what the fashion world calls "subdued elegance." So has his spring and early fall collection of furs, shown yesterday.
THE prospects for the opening of the trout seasons in Connecticut, New Jersey and Pennsylvania are not so bright as those that faced New York anglers last week.

World champions for the first time since 1933, the Giants will make their 1955 home debut today at the Polo Grounds. It will be Leo Durocher's high-flying monarchs versus Walt Alston's determined Dodgers, with game time pushed back to 1:45 P. M.

Some member houses of the New York Stock Exchange send to their customers lists of stocks grouped under "Buy," "Hold" and "Sell." Others follow the practice of Hemphill, Noyes Co., which divides them by groups, naming only a few individual issues.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 13 -- Newly developed radar equipment will soon start relieving traffic jams on airplane routes in and out of New York.
Cook County, Ill., announced yesterday that it will offer for sale on April 26 an issue of $13,000,000 of tax anticipation warrants.

The two-story and mezzanine building at 2710 Broadway has been purchased by Stanley Stahl, real estate operator. The property, assessed at $285,000, occupies a plot 71 by 69 feet at the southeast corner of 104th Street.

Arnold Constable would like to see every woman looking like a little boy this summer. The store's Loomtog collection of play clothes, shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, has gone all out for tomboy fashions.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 -- President Eisenhower sent a series of nominations to the Senate today. He also worked on a special message to Congress on freer trade with the rest of the world.

" American Literature in Parody: A Collection of Parody, Satire and Literary Burlesque of American Writers Past and Present" will be brought out this month by Twayne Publishers. Edited by Robert P. Falk and illustrated by Burges Green, the volume contains brief pieces that trace in caricature the nation's literary history and give "the great men of letters" a humorous "going-over."

KANSAS CITY, April 13 (UP) -- The Detroit Tigers presented to their manager, Bucky Harris, his 2,000th managerial victory today. The Tigers staged two big rallies in defeating the Kansas City Athletics, 10 -- 2, and squaring the two-game series.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 -- A new approach to the study of cancer was suggested today.
The labor situation on New York's docks seemed closer to the explosion point yesterday. The source of conflict continued to be the Waterfront Commission's new hiring regulations.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Federal Reserve Board officially recognized recent increases in borrowing costs today. It did so by giving its sanction to a rise in the discount rate charged by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City.

BONN, Germany, April 13 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, will meet in Bad Godesberg April 29 to remove the last obstacle to implementation of the Saar and Paris agreements. M. Pinay is expected to spend two days in conference with the Chancellor.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The United States has urged more frequent contact between Western ambassadors in Moscow and the Kremlin leaders as a means of improving East-West relations.
THE Bach Aria Group, William H. Scheide, director, presented its final concert of the season at Town Hall last evening.

NEWARK, April 13 -- The tactics employed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and his staff in their investigation of security risks at Fort Monmouth are condemned in a report to be submitted to the New Jersey Bar Association next month.
There were ten wet, cold, mud-spattered jockeys on the premises after the running of the Rosedale Stakes at Jamaica yesterday. But Paul Bailey had unspotted silks.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund is still growing.
Columbia College's highest alumni award, the Alexander Hamilton Medal, was presented posthumously yesterday to Frederick Coykendall, former chairman of the trustees of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 6: ...

LIMA, Peru, April 12 -- President Manuel Odria said today he did not intend or wish to remain President after his elected term ends in July, 1956. He said Peru must and would have democratic elections next year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 13 -- Four violations of personal rights committed by Soviet agents were called to the attenion of the Human Rights Commission today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In his eloquent speech on the critical situation in the Far East Adlai E. Stevenson was handicapped by more than the usual difficulty of an opposition leader who came late into the forum.
Nothing assures us more that spring has finally arrived than the appearance of the door-to-door salesman. Understandably, the harsh days of winter often discourage him from plying his trade.

IT'S unfortunate that no one thought of it in time. But the most appropriate touch for the opening-game ceremonies at the Yankee Stadium yesterday would have been a parade of penguins to the flag pole instead of baseball players. The penguins would have been much more at home in the Antarctic weather than the sterling athletes. Brrrr! It was cold.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Administration spokesmen spent three trying hours today endeavoring to explain that a record 75,000 bankruptcies forecast for the coming fiscal year had little to do with the general health of business.
LONDON, April 13 -- Copper shares declined sharply today on the announcement that the British Government would sell 45,000 tons of copper from its stockpile over the next twelve months.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday. Active months rose 11 to 18 points (55 to 90 cents a bale).
ALBANY, April 13 -- Governor Harriman approved today without comment a bill designed to tighten the state's annulment laws.

A cheering note was sounded by Agriculture Secretary Benson in his recent testimony before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee. This year the Secretary envisages "considerable stability" in farm income as compared with last year's 10 per cent decline.

Major finance companies increased the rate they pay on commercial paper by one-eighth of a percentage point yesterday. This action followed a similar increase by some commercial paper dealers the day before.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 13 (UP) -- Australian Olympic officials, still squirming under Avery Brundage's blunt criticism of Melbourne's preparations for the 1956 games, suffered another setback tonight. Carpenters working at the cricket stadium threatened to resume their strike next Wednesday.

A national campaign is about to be put into action to promote waxed paper as a wrapping for enriched white bread. The advertiser is the Waxed Paper Merchandising Council, an organization created by fourteen manufacturers of the product, and the agency is Ruthrauff Ryan.
The Board of Health was directed yesterday by Mayor Wagner to make a "careful re-examination" of the study of water fluoridation. The findings are to be reported to the Mayor.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 13 -- The United States has forwarded to seven countries a draft of the constitution of the proposed international atoms-for-peace agency.
MOSCOW, Thursday, April 14 -- An Austrian-Soviet agreement on the terms of an Austrian state treaty seemed to be in the air today. Some diplomats said they could "smell it."
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Eisenhower directed the State Department today to give to the world full information about the Salk anti-polio vaccine.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 13 -- Scattered opposition developed yesterday and today among Negroes to the South African Government's new educational policy for them. In Germiston, twenty-two were arrested for trying to stop children from entering schools.

Commodity futures prices closed irregular yesterday on increased volume on the New York exchanges. Potatoes and sugar were mixed; cocoa, zinc, wool, cottonseed oil and soybean oil rose, and coffee, copper, rubber, hides and silk eased.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Kansas State Democratic chairman suggested today that politicians be ousted from office if they spent more than the law allowed to get elected.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Americans still differ about the school segregation issue, but there is not likely to be much argument over the care and dignity with which the Supreme Court is studying the question.
Vice Admiral Arthur D. Struble said last night that any new Chinese Communist aggression might kindle war throughout the Far East.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Brig. Gen. Kenneth E. Fields, director of the division of military application of the Atomic Energy Commission, will be promoted to the position of general manager on May 1.
The first mass blood donation at the new North Shore Red Cross Chapter House of Queens brought 178 pints to the regional program on Tuesday. The chapter house is at 44-22 Union Street, Flushing.

At Ebbets Field yesterday afternoon it was cold, it was raining and a dense fog descended on the field. But all was sunshine for the 6,999 Flatbush fans when the Dodgers won their delayed opening game from the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6--1.
Michael J. Quill, fiery leader of the city's unionized transit workers, got a cold bath from one of his constituents yesterday.
DETROIT, April 13 -- Parke, Davis Co. has begun shipping small amounts of the Salk polio vaccine to its branches throughout the nation for commercial use.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- The Government has blacklisted almost 1,500 new companies and individuals in the last twelve months for alleged unethical practices in home repair work, the Federal Housing Administration said today.

Eric Johnston was re-elected president of the Motion Picture Association yesterday at the first quarterly meeting of the board of directors. Geoffrey Shurlock, who directs the Production Code Administration of the group, was elected vice president. Stanley R. Weber was named treasurer and Thomas McNamara assistant treasurer.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith named the Ford, Carnegie and Rockefeller Foundations yesterday as winners of its 1954-55 America's Democratic Legacy awards.

Two 9-year-old Police Athletic League champions, winners in a field of 50,000, were crowned "King and Queen of Sports" yesterday. At the coronation, held at league headquarters, 400 Broome Street, they also received bronze-figure awards from Deputy Police Commissioner James B. Nolan, president of the P. A. L.
PITTSBURGH, April 13 (AP) -- A coal-burning gas turbine -- said to run a railroad locomotive $40,000 a year cheaper than Diesel models -- was described today to the nation's coal men.

Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, representing the Mayor, greeted a thousand Girl Scouts attending their eleventh annual conference here yesterday. She wished them "every success" in their discussions of juvenile delinquency and other community problems.
ALBANY, April 13 -- The legislative leaders pledged financial support today for "any sound and reasonable" program for using the Salk polio vaccine in the state.
HONG KONG, April 13 -- Red China announced tonight it would be represented at the Bandung conference by a fiveman delegation headed by Premier Chou. The other members of the Peiping delegation are:

Congratulations are in order for Governor Harriman, the Republican and Democratic leaders in the Legislature, Senator MacNeil Mitchell, Mayor Wagner and State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray for their success in obtaining legislation that provides for state and city loans for private construction of much-needed middle-income housing.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Brig. Gen. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr., soldier and Ambassador to the eight governments-in-exile in World War II, will retire from the Army Monday. He will become Adjutant General of Pennsylvania, head of the National Guard.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 13 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, declared tonight that "either the Communist Chinese must come to the United Nations or the United Nations must go to them" if the disputes of the Far East are to be settled.

It was hardly an afternoon to raise the curtain on the local 1955 major league baseball season. Biting cold, a drizzle, dampness and haze combined to mar the opening at the Stadium yesterday, but nothing stood in the way of a 19-1 victory for the Yankees over the Washington Senators.
The building of social conditions under which all children would be protected was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.
With little excitement and only moderate volume, the stock market pushed ahead yesterday to new highs.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 13 (AP) -- Chief Justice George W. Bristow said today the Illinois Supreme Court would announce its decision in the Montgomery Ward Co. case at 9 A. M. Friday.
LONDON, April 13 -- A Government court of inquiry reported today that the strike against London's newspapers was "precipitate." It advised a return to work and further negotiations.

A decline last week of 2,097,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. This is the first major drop in several months and brought supplies at the weekend to 183,185,000 barrels, compared with 185,282,000 a week earlier and 179,729,000 a year ago.

The Queens District Attorney's office breathed easier yesterday when a "missing" murder trial witness turned up safe and sound. The witness, Joseph Benenati, had been the object of a search when he could not be found at his last known address.
So far as home cooks are concerned, the veal market could not be better, John O'Neil, local reporter of the United States Department of Agriculture, said yesterday.
It must be that God guides this country, for its citizens are too apathetic in political matters, New York Secretary of State Carmine G. DeSapio declared last night.
An attorney for the brewing industry said yesterday that brewing companies did not discriminate against Negroes in their hiring practices.

The sixty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Pan American Union -- since 1948 the permanent secretariat of the Organization of American States -- is a good time to take stock of what might be called the Pan-American year.

A shopping center in the Islip Township area of Long Island has passed to new ownership. The property occupies a triangular plot on Bay Shore Road and Ocean and Bay Shore Avenues, about one-half a mile north of the last exit of the Southern State Parkway at the Babylon-Islip town line.
The Federal Communications Commission plans to go ahead with its investigation of the broadcasting industry if Congress provides the funds.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 13 -- The Government indicated today that it would not attack the Bien Xuyen rebel army before April 20. But a spokesman for Premier Ngo Dinh Diem warned that after that date the South Vietnamese Army might be used to oust the rebels, commanded by Gen. Le Van Vien, a former river pirate, from the National Police building.
Issues of new industrial and public utility securities valued at more than $17,000,000 will be placed on the market today by investment banking syndicates.
American shipbuilders were told yesterday that developments in 1954 had "turned out better than we had any real reason to hope for a year ago."

NICE, France, April 13 (UP) -- The Wimbledon champion, Jaroslav Drobny of Egypt, and a French star, Paul Remy, paced the advance of favored players today in the first round of men's singles in the Nice tennis tournament.
Consolidated sales of the National Biscuit Company in the first quarter increased 6 per cent to $94,200,000 from the $88,700,000 volume in the period a year ago, but earnings declined.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The appointment of a one-time advertising man, the Rev. Theodore Henry Palmquist of Los Angeles, as minister of Foundry Methodist Church here was announced today. He succeeds the Rev. Dr. Frederick Brown Harris.
