A new block of $111,980,000 of Federally subsidized housing bonds was marketed yesterday to further the financing of low-rent projects by eighteen cities in nine states.

PARIS, April 13 -- Premier Edgar Faure made clear today that France had no intention of making the hydrogen bomb or entering the international competition in nuclear arms. He said instead that the French must compete with the foremost nations in developing atomic energy for peacetime use.

GILBERT RUSSELL who made his debut with the New York City Opera Company on Tuesday evening as Ernesto in "Don Pasquale," did not even have a full day's rest before resuming operations. Last night he was heard as Fenton in the company's lively new production of Nicolai's charming "The Merry Wives of Windsor."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 13 -- The Nassau Chapter of the Association of General Practitioners established a ceiling fee here today for administering Salk vaccine.

The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday that it had developed an improved and simplified 21-inch metal color tube as the "answer to low-cost color television." The R. C. A. plant in Lancaster, Pa., is being equipped to turn out the tubes at the rate of 30,000 a year within twelve months.

I am a teen-ager. I've never committed a robbery, taken drugs, nor beaten up a defenseless old man. I've never been in trouble with school authorities or the police. In short, I'm just like 95 per cent of the teen-agers in the country today.
RIO DE SANEIRO, April 13 -- Jose Maria Whitaker took over the critically important job of Finance Minister today and pledged to fight inflation and to liberalize Brazil's foreign-exchange policy.
Addressograph-Multigraph Corp, addressing and duplicating machines, floor in 444 5th Ave -- Cushman Wakefield Inc, brokers.
ALBANY, April 13 -- The State issued a record-breaking 4,549,252 motor vehicle registrations in 1954. This was almost twice the figure in 1944.
Young booklovers who come to browse in Queens public libraries this week may one day find themselves on the other side of the counter.

Copper prices dropped sharply on the London Metals Exchange yesterday. The Associated Press said that the drop came after the Board of Trade announced that up to 45,000 tons of refined metal would be sold from British Government stocks.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 13 -- The man who wrote the contract calling on Greenwich to share its water supply for seventy-five years with Rye and Port Chester, N. Y., testified today that New York State authorities had wanted the arrangement to be in perpetuity.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Southern states continued today to plead for a gradual adjustment to racially integrated public school systems. They also warned the Supreme Court that an abrupt end to segregation might mean trouble.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Secretary of Labor, Jam s P. Mitchell, made a bid tonight for a closer working relationship with the labor unions.

Building and permanent loans totaling $1,560,000 have been arranged by M. L. Spies Associates, Inc., brokers, for 118 ranch and Cape Cod homes going up at 148th Road and 241st Street in Rosedale, Queens. The houses are priced at about $13,500 to $14,250.
MERSA MATRUH, Egypt, April 11 -- A joint United States-Egyptian team has succeeded in restoring a 25,000-acre tract near here as year-round grazing land for sheep and cattle.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Grain and soybean futures were irregular in the early trade today, but demand broadened on the setbacks, with May wheat leading the early recovery. Later corn and oats took the lead on general buying.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that it planned to install a 300,000-kilowatt generator in its Astoria, Queens, plant. This would be larger than any power unit now in operation in this country and would match a unit the Detroit Edison Company expects to have in operation about Oct. 1, 1957. The local unit is scheduled for operation in 1958.

CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- A strange play in the third inning of yesterday's game, in which the Chicago Cubs beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 14 -- 4, will bring a bulletin of clarification from the National League president, Warren Giles.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- A Hoover Commission official promised today to give House investigators all evidence of military waste dug up by the commission.

BOSTON, Thursday, April 14 (AP) -- Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New Haven Railroad, early today won control of the Boston and Maine Railroad, subject to Interstate Commerce Commission approval.
Parents everywhere were asking yesterday where, when and how they could get the new Salk anti-polio vaccine for their children.
A saxophone player allegedly turned burglar was captured yesterday by detectives in Brooklyn. He was accused of stealing $100,000 worth of jewelry and furnishings in concert with his wife.

The report of the Hoover Commission on the legal and judicial activities of federal administrative agencies raises an issue that goes to the roots of our Constitution and form of government. It also offers a challenging program by which the issue may be met.

RANGOON, Burma, April 13 -- Communist China's Premier, Chou En-lai, kept the Burmese Government in suspense today as to the time of his arrival here on a brief visit. He has been slated to stop here on his way to the African-Asian conference in Bandung, Indonesia.

Insurance companies yesterday were studying closely the report on the effectivenes of the vaccine developed by Dr. Jonas E. Salk. One company announced cancellation of its extra premium for polio coverage.
The Fire Department's new flying squad will go into action Saturday at 9 A. M. in a drive to reduce the damage caused by fires in Harlem.
CHICAGO, April 13 -- Inoculation of approximately 140,000 Chicago school children with the Salk vaccine will start on May 2. Dr. Herman N. Bundesen, Board of Health president, announced today.
PARIS, April 13 -- France's supplies of gold and hard currencies, exclusive of the gold reserves of the Bank of France, are said here to be rising at a rate approximating $1,000,000 a day.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Communist party appealed to the Supreme Court today to set aside an order requiring it to register with the Attorney General as a Communist-action organization.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- General Biddle was designated by Governor Leader on Jan. 13 as Adjutant General in his administration.

Stockholders of the Western Union Telegraph Company approved a four-for-one stock split yesterday. Earlier at their annual meeting, they learned that first-quarter earnings were double those of the 1954 period.

A row of ten four-story buildings occupying the blockfront on the east side of Second Avenue between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets has been sold by Beth David Hospital. The buyer is an investing client of Tenzer, Greenblatt, Fallon Kaplan, attorneys.
Two of New York City's major commuting railroads -- the Long Island and the New Haven -- predicted yesterday substantially higher profits for 1955.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Democratic Congress returned today from the Easter holiday in a challenging partisan spirit that signaled stormier times for the second half of this session.

A 39-year-old private detective, Charles Lester, who shares office space with John G. (Steve) Broady, veteran investigator, was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions as a material witness in the current wiretap inquiry.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- Robin Roberts, the Phillies' ace right-hander, came within two outs of achieving one of baseball's rarities -- a no-hitter on opening day.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (UP) -- The world middleweight champion, Carl (Bobo) Olson of San Francisco, floored Joey Maxim of Cleveland in the second and ninth rounds for counts of 8 and bulled his way to a ridiculously easy ten-round decision over the former world light-heavyweight champion tonight.
PARIS, April 13 -- The United States-Atlantic alliance agreement on releasing atomic defense information to the Allies will be most immediately useful to the allied command in Central Europe.
Schools in the New York metropolitan area communities are spending $400 a pupil, compared with the national average of $260.
The Diamond Jubilee Tea Dance will be held April 29 in the Crystal Pavilion of the Sherry-Netherland to mark the sixtieth anniversary of the founding of Union Settlement.

Dogs as friends and therapy will be enjoyed by blind children as a result of the twentieth annual tea dance of the New York Young Women's Republican Club. The dance will be held May 1 in the Palm Terrace Suite of the Roosevelt Hotel.

Those who have known John Clark Knox will deeply regret his decision to retire on April 30 from active duty as Chief Judge of the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York. His thirty-seven years of distinguished service on the bench have set lightly on his spirit.

The totally unrealistic laws limiting expenditures in federal elections are getting a going-over at hearings opened' .fbi, week by Senator Hennlngs of Missouri. Since universal evasion of any law encourages disrespect for all law, the present ineffective leg-ltinn on eaznpaign spending ought to be revised in confortuity with conditions as they actually exist.
Smokers who prefer king-size cigarettes will undoubtedly have to pay a penny more a pack for several brands soon.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Following is the draft of an agreement for the exchange of information on atomic weapons among members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, together with the text of letters from Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, to President Eisenhower and from the President to Senator Clinton P. Anderson, chairman of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service is seeking 400 Border Patrol inspectors to help prevent the smuggling and the illegal entry of aliens across the southern border.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The following tributes were paid tonight to General March:

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long lines department announced yesterday it had applied to the Federal Communications Commission for authority to construct new telephone facilities to cost about $27,000,000.
The undercover struggle between City Administrator Luther Gulick and Budget Director Abraham D. Beame for budget control broke into the open yesterday.

TO "Meet the People" (1955 model) you have to go down to the cellar of the Paramount Hotel into a bustling restaurant called the Cafe Theatre. Billy Rose did business there for years without giving any trouble.

Both Ohrbach's and the Census Bureau predict a bumper crop of American babies this year. The Census Bureau just counts the little ones as they come along, but Ohrbach's plans to get there first and clothe the expectant mothers.

Much delay is caused by the fare-paying transaction at the entrance to buses; passengers are delayed in entering, drivers miss the lights and buses pile up in twos and threes. This fare-collecting activity of the drivers also makes for accidents. Driving requires complete concentration.

AS the first novelty of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Ballet Theatre last night presented Valerie Bettis' "A Streetcar Named Desire," based on the Tennessee Williams play and with a score adapted from Alex North's music for the movie.

The State Education Commissioner's warning to Yonkers that it will be deprived of state financial aid unless the city supports its schools properly is a salutary use of governmental power. Of what constructive use is state aid unless it encourages and assures acceptable standards of education ?

A new cushioning device for freight cars has been developed by the Southern Pacific Railroad in conjunction with the Stanford Research Institute. D. J. Russell, president of the line, reported yesterday that the improvement was now being tested by the railroad.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- Mel Ferrer will appear opposite his wife, Audrey Hepburn, in the film version of "War and Peace" being made by the Italian producing company, Ponti-deLaurentiis.

Several thousand passengers on a Philadelphia-bound Pennsylvania Railroad train were delayed for almost two hours yesterday morning when its electric locomotive stalled in the Hudson River tunnel. The breakdown occurred shortly after 8 A. M., when the train left Pennsylvania Station.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 13 -- The framework for the first electrically lighted overhead road signs in Westchester County was installed today. The porcelain directional markers, spanning two of the county's three north-south parkways, are to be in operation by May 7.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The House of Representatives tried today to expedite an appropriation bill that sought to save $33,133,685 out of $450,398,227 of budgetary estimates. One member, Representative H. H. Gross, Republican of Iowa, withheld the measure from the floor through intricate parliamentary tactics.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 13 -- Prominent educators put the country's schools and colleges under the academic microscope today, and found them wanting in many respects.

DETROIT, April 13 (AP) -- One of the smaller auto producers, American Motors Corporation, said today that it hoped to work out a new labor contract this year different from the rest of the industry and tailored to its own needs.

Andy Griffith, who never has played on the Broadway stage, has beau signed for the central role of Will Stockdale, the Georgia draftee whose naive conduct virtually unbalances his military superiors in "No Time For Sergeants."

TORONTO, April 13 -- Premier Leslie Frost of Ontario today announced that his Government planned to provide free injections of Salk polio vaccine for this province's population between the ages of six months and 20 years.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 -- President Eisenhower approved today an agreement between the North Atlantic Treaty powers to share information on atomic weapons.
A distinction must be made at present between executive and legislative investigations and the rights of witnesses before each, members of the Brooklyn Bar Association were told last night.

NEW DELHI, India, April 13 (AP) -- Authoritative sources said today that India had called an eleven-country conference on the regional use of new United States economic aid. The new aid is expected to total $200,000,000.
The New York Heart Association received $733 from a showing yesterday of three model apartments in the new Brevoort Building at 11 Fifth Avenue.
A steady trend toward greater land greater restriction of information within the Pentagon has worried both the press and the individual armed services.

Although there is growing understanding of the importance to the United States of our official overseas information programs, much more needs to be done to make the American people realize how such programs can contribute to our national strength.
YONKERS, April 13 -- This city took another step today apparently aimed at preventing a possible transfer of the 1955 Yonkers Raceway program to Roosevelt Raceway.
The Philadelphia Warriors exercised their territorial rights and took La Salle College's Tom Gola at the National Basketball Association's annual draft of collegiate stars yesterday.

As speculation mounts over chances for a Big Four conference, emphasis invariably is placed on such vital European issues as German unification. Any mention of Asian matters is usually confined to the Formosa Strait. Meanwhile the Korean question, more dangerous than before despite its disappearance from the news, seems virtually overlooked.

State-supervised banks last year showed little change in operating earnings but sharply improved their results on securities transactions, according to figures released yesterday by George. A. Mooney, Superintendent of Banks.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- John Paton Davies Jr., a career diplomat dismissed by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles last November, asked the State Department today to reconsider its decision barring him from a life pension.

An American ship operator proposed yesterday an increase of $100,000 in the cost of every new vessel built here. He said such an investment in safety features would be repaid many times over during the life of a vessel.
YONKERS, April 13 -- City officials here were smarting today from the state's warning that the school system would lose its state aid next year unless conditions were improved.
The happy state of textile design in this country was underscored yesterday by the results of the annual Home Furnishings Design Competition.
BERLIN, April 13 -- Allied officials in West Berlin predicted today a new wave of "show trials" in East Germany following the arrest of 521 persons alleged to be Western agents.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles again called on Communist China today to renounce the use of force without giving up its claims on Formosa.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- With Congress back from its Easter recess, the case of Edward Corsi erupted anew today. The result was a spew of bitterness, name-calling, charges and counter-charges unequaled in ferocity during the present Congressional session.

NEW DELHI, India, April 13 -- The Indian Government made it known today that a ban on the export of monkeys imposed last month would not prevent availability to foreign countries of a sufficient number for genuine medical research.

The Brand Names Foundation elected Edward R. Taylor, vice president of Motorola, Inc., Chicago radio, TV and electronics concern, as chairman of its board yesterday at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He succeeds Barry T. Leithead, president of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., who will continue on the board as an honorary director.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Supreme Court took under advisement today the question of the decrees it should issue to end racial segregation in the public schools.

IT was a mite on the moist side for the Giant-Dodger game at the Polo Grounds yesterday with somber gray clouds hanging so low that they almost seemed to rest on the grass tops. But the brutal, penetrating cold of the Yankee opener the day before was missing. It made for a more bearable and infinitely more pleasant afternoon.

In a drastic reversal of tactics which could put new fluidity in the frozen relations between East and West the Soviet Government has reached a bilateral agreement with Austria on a formula purporting to facilitate the conclusion of the long-delayed state treaty that would end the ten-year occupation of that liberated country and would restore it to full independence and sovereignty.

VIENNA, April 14 -- The Hungarian Government has resumed its policy of dismissing civil servants to force them into heavy industry or agriculture, according to two announcements today by the Budapest radio.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 14 -- Laos has complained to the International Commission that a "small army" of dissident Laotians is being organized on the soil of the kingdom by "a foreign country."
ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Harriman approved today with satisfaction a Republican education bill that he had called "utterly inadequate" less than a month ago.
The Armed Forces Day Committee for New York, New Jersey and New England met yesterday to discuss plans for celebration of the day on May 21.
The Du Mont network announced yesterday what it called "an entirely new concept of network television."

ELVAS, Portugal, April 8 -- A visitor who motors through Portugal may feel that her people are living a patriarchal life. It is bare and simple, but detached from the pressures and strains of the modern cities.
ATLANTA, April 14 (UP) -- Violent rain and wind squalls blew out to the Atlantic today.
ACCRA, Gold Coast, April 2 -- According to Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah, the Gold Coast will strive to become a republic within the Commonwealth once it is fully independent of Britain.
" APPOINTMENT With Adventure," the new Sunday night dramatic show on the Columbia Broadcasting System network, deserves encouragement on the basis of its second effort.

A report to be submitted to the New Jersey Bar Association was criticized yesterday by Roy M. Cohn, former chief counsel to the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, as one-sided and unjustified.
The first of a fleet of eight Lockheed Super-G Constellation airplanes is on its way to Germany for the revived German airline, Deutsche Lufthansa.

PITTSBURGH, April 14 (AP) -- Herm Wehmeier, helped by a three-run Philadelphia rally in the second inning, stopped the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4 -- 3, on six hits today in the season's opener at Forbes Field.

Today is the deadline for filing the 1954 Federal and state income tax returns. This is the first year that both taxes have been payable on the same date. Officials reported that there was little confusion because of the simultaneous filing time.
DETROIT, April 14 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings won the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world professional hockey championship, with a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland of California, asked today for a Senate inquiry into the Administration's failure to free fifteen United States airmen from Communist China's prisons.
The American Merchant Marine Institute announced yesterday that it had named Francis T. Greene president.
President Eisenhower has taken a detailed and active interest in publicity releases from the Pentagon and speeches by Defense Department officials.
Shipments of refined copper to domestic users rose sharply last month to the highest level since June of 1953. And refined copper production swelled to what the trade believed to be a record high.
Governor Harriman was pictured yesterday as having left the door open for eventual enforcement of the compulsory automobile inspection law.

CINCINNATI, April 14 (UP) -- Jimmie Dykes, who spent thirty-five seasons in the American League as a player, coach and manager, shifted to the National League today. He signed as a coach with the Cincinnati Redlegs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- Another television creation destined for motion-picture theatres is "The Rack," which was presented Tuesday night on the "U. S. Steel Hour." Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has purchased the drama written by Ron Serling and has cast Glenn Ford to play the leading role.

Another venture has been added to the constantly expanding agenda of the Playwrights Company, chiefly through the efforts of Roger L. Stevens, undoubtedly the firm's most active partner. Mr. Stevens has commissioned Jerome Moross and Edward Eager to go ahead with "Gentlemen, Be Seated!" an original musical comedy with a Civil War background.

The ideal advertisement on a cost basis, from the advertiser's standpoint, is the copy that tells the entire product story with a picture in the least possible space. Robert M. Marks Co. had a problem of that nature in planning Father's Day copy for its client, Swank, Inc.
The nation's chain and mail-order stores chalked up a 12.1 per cent sales gain last month over the March, 1954, level, according to a survey by The New York Times.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- During the week ended yesterday, member-bank reserves increased $50,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Metropolitan Opera Association has decided to make a determined effort to get a new home.

In 1946 E. W. Kevin Walton went to the Antarctic as a member of the Falkland Islands Dependencies Survey. The party established a base within the Antarctic Circle at Marguerite Bay in Graham Land. There they trained to live and travel in that difficult country.
Most of the gas ranges now in use in this country are more than ten years old and cost about $100 at the time of purchase.
The fog turned in a repeat performance here yesterday as a meteorological nuisance.

Insurance company employes gave 206 pints of blood on Wednesday at the National Board of Fire Underwriters, 85 John Street. This week and next, Monday through Friday, are Insurance Weeks for the regional Red Cross blood program.
Consolidated net income of the Republic Steel Corporation in the first quarter this year rose to $18,192,265 from $11,079,012 earned in the 1954 period.
STRATFORD, Conn., April 14 (AP) -- The Avco Manufacturing Corporation has assembled a team of scientists as part of its defense production organization.

ALTHOUGH the fishing season for trout and landlocked salmon officially opens in the six northern counties of Maine today, most of the lakes are firmly locked in a blanket of ice. Only a few waters are open for fishing.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The United States is in for the best year in its economic history, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, told a news conference today.
A search through Southern cemeteries and old family Bibles has led to the discovery in a Georgia sanitarium for the poor of a twenty-sixth heir to a $1,500,000 fortune.

One of the bright stories in New York is the story of the Henry Street Settlement, whose offices are at 265 Henry Street, New York 2. Through the settlement's doors annually come 10,000 persons of all ages. Children, teen-agers, mothers and fathers use the informal programs of education, recreation and the clubs.
Citizens and the dental profession of New York were called upon last night to protest against uninformed opposition to fluoridation of the city's water supply.

BERLIN, April 14 -- Efforts to cut the high East German tolls on truck traffic between Berlin and West Germany seemed tonight to have broken down. The attempt had been made by the East and West German trade negotiators.
CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows;
DETROIT, April 14 (UP) -- Al Smith and Jim Hegan hit home runs today to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 5-3 victory and spoil the Detroit Tigers home opener before 42,684 fans at Briggs Stadium.
Many parties will be given at the seventh annual Spring Frolic, a tea dance, for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York to be held this afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
Mayor Wagner declined yesterday to express a view on the advisability of continuing the Third Avenue elevated after May 12.

BOSTON, April 14 -- Harvard University, which gave the world a breed of impeccable gentlemen known as Boston trustees, is being accused of compromising its corporate integrity as a guardian of its own sacred obligations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- Refugees from nine countries protested today against the "planned displacement" of the population of the Moldavian Republic in the Soviet Union.
It may be that the Dodgers spent a deal of their time this spring afightin' and afeudin' among themselves, with their manager or with most anyone who happened to get in the way.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- Three Democrats rose in the House of Representatives today to defend Andrew Jackson after a Republican had labeled him "an inept politician."
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday it had increased its discount rate from 1 1/2 per cent to 1 3/4 per cent, effective today.

A GROUP known as The Fifty American Artists, "who are united in their belief in the sound principles of art expression as handed down through the ages," is showing work at Arthur Newton's, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street.

With the fight against polio apparently won the spotlight can now be thrown on the fight again cancer, John Reed Kilpatrick declared yesterday. Research and public support of research, which helped to conquer polio, can also "beat this great enemy of mankind -- cancer," he said.
Macy's has followed Horace Greeley's advice and gone West. The store's much-traveled buyers have struck gold in California, returning with a rich lode of summer cottons.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The United States was guardedly optimistic today about the outcome of the Moscow talks on the terms of an Austrian state treaty. The State Department has been kept informed on the progress of the Austrian - Soviet negotiations through Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen in Moscow.

Cocoa prices soared the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The volume was 326 lots, the seventh highest of the year. There were unsatisfied bids at the limit up in almost every position at the close.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14 (AP) -- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, in a ringing defense of President Eisenhower, said tonight the cause of peace would not be served by any United States declaration on whether this country would defend the Quemoy and Matsu islands.

While the average reader is going through this brief editorial the population of the United States will have increased by half a dozen or more. This does not mean merely that that many babies are being born. It means that births minus deaths and departures and plus arrivals of permanent residents amount to over 7,000 a day, or very nearly 3,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Antagonists in the fight over subscription television clashed publicly today.
WASHINGTON, April. 14 -- The American Nurses Association endorsed today the Administration bill for a $9,000,000 five-year program of Federal aid for the training of practical nurses.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14 -- President Eisenhower has directed his Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare to organize a voluntary system of allocating the Salk vaccine against poliomyelitis.
A $100,000,000 expansion program was announced yesterday by the Plymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation.
MILWAUKEE, April 14 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson scored a technical knockout over Ted Olla tonight, when Referee Dauber Jaeger stopped the bout in 2:15 of the third round.
ATLANTA, April 14 (UP) -- Southern Governors were summoned to an emergency meeting today to consider "a plan of action" for ending bitter, month-old rail and communications strikes.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Eleven editors of Soviet student and youth publications may not, after all, make their planned visit to the United States.
They are shooting from all angles with claims for production and sales records in the automotive field.
There is a chance that the house flag of the Arnold Bernstein Line will be flown again on the North Atlantic after an absence of almost two decades.

It's spring now, and even the calendar says so. Buds are everywhere, on trees, shrubs and early flowers. Peepers are in the swamps. Robins, tanned from the South, strut about. Shad nets are in the river, for the taking of roe.
Governor Harriman declared last night that his administration had promoted unity in the state after years of "political efforts to set one section against the other."

Ground was broken yesterday for a $720,000 building for St. Luke's School at Greenwich and Christopher Streets. The school, an adjunct of St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Chapel (Trinity Parish), was opened ten years ago in converted dwellings.

With the Senate fight still ahead on extending the reciprocal trade act, Congress yesterday received a new appeal from President Eisenhower for a demonstration to the free world of "our active interest in the promotion of trade among the free nations."

As the Assistant Attorney General who was concerned with problems arising from President Truman's initial Executive order of March 21, 1947, dealing with the loyalty of Government employes, I have followed closely the development of the security-risk program which is now causing the American people the deepest concern.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace plan was the subject of a secret diplomatic exchange today between the United States and the Soviet Union.
RANGOON, Burma, April 14 -- Communist China's Premier, Chou En-lai, reached Rangoon today in the midst of Burmese New Year celebrations.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The question raised by Adlai E. Stevenson this week as to the wisdom of leaving to "any man" the decision whether a Communist Chinese attack on the offshore islands will mean or not mean that "at some later date the enemy will attack Formosa" disproves one long-held concept of a sure means to achieve durable bipartisan foreign policy.
Two tankers locked horns for two hours in the Lower Bay yesterday afternoon. Although no one was reported hurt in the collision, one of the vessels received a large gash in her hull.
Charles W. Chapman, deputy commissioner of the State Liquor Authority, which is under investigation, committed suicide yesterday.
A wholesale redesign of jobs to provide increased employment opportunities for older workers was urged last night by Governor Harriman's special assistant on problems of the aging.
The Greater New York Fund will open its eighteenth annual campaign at a dinner in the Sheraton Astor Hotel on April 25. The goal is $9,000,000.
ALBANY, April 14 -- The Court of Appeals upheld today six captains in the New York City Fire Department who challenged temporary assignments to posts as battalion chiefs.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Disorderly and unpredictable rate increases are threatening to price natural gas out of the Northeast, a Congressional committee was told today.
Stock price movements were irregular yesterday. Although The New York Times' combined average of fifty stocks rose slightly, declines outnumbered advances on the Big Board.

The Prime Minister of Barbados, B. W. I., was received in style at City Hall yesterday by Mayor Wagner. Later he saw his first baseball game at the Polo Grounds and turned out to be a rooter for the Dodgers.
LONDON, April 14 -- The educational future of thousands of British children is largely determined at the tender age of 11.

LONDON, April 14 -- After a firm opening the stock markets closed irregularly today. The approach of the budget announcement restricted business in most sections. With sterling maintaining its strength, Government issues did little more than hold yesterday's advance.
VIENNA, April 14 -- Chancellor Julius Raab sent a message to the Austrian people from Moscow today saying that "Austria will be free."

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles told Latin-American nations today that the United States was pouring dollar aid into Europe and Asia in defense of the entire Western Hemisphere.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today asking approval of United States membership in the thirty-four-nation Organization for Trade Cooperation:

Five young women dedicated to playing one of the first musical instruments invented by man -- the harp -- arrived in New York yesterday. They are here to give another of the old-fashioned musicales they have been presenting in towns and villages throughout the country.
Chelsea District longshoremen were enjoined yesterday from continuing their "illegal" work stoppage at the Grace Line's North River terminal. These are Piers 57 and 58 at West Sixteenth Street.

The fight for control of A. M. Byers Company entered another round yesterday. The management of the company asked for a court injunction to prohibit holding of a special meeting demanded by insurgent stockholders.
BAYONNE, N. J., April 14 -- Two men were fatally injured by an explosion on the top of a fuel tank at the refinery of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey here at 1 P. M. today.
City agencies, which have long smarted under criticism that New York is a dirty city, are going to conduct a study to find out just where all the rubbish comes from.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A Los Angeles builder testified today he had received inside information from the Government-hired engineer on the job while bidding on a $2,400,000 foreign aid project. He denied any pay-off was involved.
The fight to put back the date for the national grass court tennis championship, instead of holding them immediately after the Davis Cup challenge round, apparently has been won.
The Appellate Division cleared the way yesterday for a quick decision on the right of the city to redevelop Washington Square Southeast.
BONN, Germany, April 14 -- A matter of four miles has thrown a slight shadow over the visit of Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer April 29.
BUENOS AIRES, April 14 -- The teaching of Roman Catholic religion and morals was stopped today in all Argentine schools receiving Government support.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to authorize membership in the Organization for Trade Cooperation to advance freer trade.
MILAN, Italy, April 14 -- Italians of all classes have rather suddenly come to believe that Italy has a tolerable and possibly even bright economic future.

Since Juan D. Peron is now rounding out ten years of domination in Argentina an inquiry into his role in that nation and the nation's role in the world was apt. The Times has now presented the results of such an inquiry by Herbert Matthews.
No matter who wins the Avery-Wolfson fight for control of Montgomery Ward Co. at the annual meeting of stockholders next Friday, arithmetic is sure to be one casualty of the contest.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis announced yesterday that the 9,000,000 children to be immunized at its expense with the Salk triple anti-polio vaccine would get only two shots this year. Three were administered last year.
A proposal for commercial slum clearance that would provide fourteen sites for factory construction in the city was put forward yesterday by City Council President Abe Stark.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A Nike guided missile, misguided, supersonic and loaded to kill, ran away from its launching platform at near-by Fort Meade, Md., this afternoon. The explosion occurred about three miles away. The altitude was not known.
MOSCOW, Friday, April 15 -- Austria and the Soviet Union have agreed to sign a state treaty ending the ten-year occupation of Austria, Deputy Austrian Chancellor Adolf Schaerf said today.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Labor leaders have agreed to remain experimentally on an advisory committee to James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor.

BOCA RATON, Fla., April 14 (UP) -- Bradshaw Mintener, Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, conceded today that many violations of the Pure Food and Drug Act, "perhaps serious ones" go undetected each year.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- After the sharp upturns in corn and oats yesterday, there was free realizing by longs in those grains, with prices receding a little. However, on small dips commission buying was in evidence.
MOUCHARD, France, April 14 -- Pierre Poujade came here today to challenge Premier Edgar Faure in his own bailiwick.

It is a good idea to be reminded, from time to time, of the type of mentality and morality with which we are dealing in the case of Red China. An Indian airliner takes off from a British port with some minor Red Chinese officials aboard. The plane crashes and some lives are lost.
Traditional Eastern Orthodox Holy Thursday services were held yesterday, marking the approach of Easter in the calendar of Eastern Orthodox churches.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 14 (UP) -- The International Cycling Union has withdrawn its approval of the 250-meter board track that is being constructed for the 1956 Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development today disclosed organization plans for a fifty-six-nation investment agency that would help underdeveloped countries build up their industries.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 14 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, said tonight that the West must demonstrate to Asia that it had something more than plumbing to offer in exchange for philosophy.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Sandy Consuegra's three-hit pitching and a ten-blow attack, including a homer by Bob Nieman, swept the White Sox to a 7-1 home-opening victory over the Kansas City Athletics today.
NEW HAVEN, April 14 -- The morality of modern college youth today drew high praise from the Rev. Clarence P. Shedd, Professor of Christian Methods at Yale Divinity School.

CINCINNATI, April 14 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs scored their third straight victory today when they defeated the Cincinnati Redlegs, 6 -- 4, on home runs by Ransom Jackson and Ernie Banks in the tenth inning.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- One of the most sensitive and widely used barometers of economic conditions is the Federal Reserve Board's monthly index of industrial production. Accordingly, it is being watched with special interest in the current period of business recovery.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Secretary Hobby late today called a conference on distribution of the vaccine for April 22 in Washington.
The Health Department will offer two free Salk vaccine shots to 281,853 eligible school children before the poliomyelitis season starts.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- Beta rays produced from an isotope of the chemical element yttrium were reported today to be more promising than surgery for removal of the common form of brain cancer known as glioma.

The factory property of the American Steel Foundries at Avenue L and Herbert Street in Newark, N. J., has been purchased by the Federal Pacific Electric Company. Frank H. Taylor Son, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.

BOSTON, April 14 -- An executive committee of six took over the operating of the Boston and Maine Railroad today. One of its first objectives is to obtain legal approval for the election of Patrick B. McGinnis as president of the road.
MILWAUKEE, April 14 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves today sold Pitcher Jim (No Hit) Wilson to the Baltimore Orioles of the American League.
Chuck and sirloin steaks, lamb legs and pork loins are the attractive meat buys for this week-end.
SAN JUAN, P. R., April 14 (AP) -- Measures aimed at stabilizing the world coffee market were approved today by the Central American and Caribbean Coffee Federation.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14 -- President Eisenhower laid before Senator Walter F. George today his plans for shifting the foreign-aid program from an independent agency to the departments of State and Defense.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 14 -- It takes six R's -- not just the traditional three -- to be a good classroom teacher, a Roman Catholic college president declared here today.
New Orleans borrowed $3,300,000 in the public market yesterday to finance street and sewer improvements.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Congress appeared unenthusiastic today toward President Eisenhower's request for legislation to put the United States into the Organization for Trade Cooperation.

NICE, France, April 14 (UP) -- The four favorites -- Gardnar Mulloy, Jaroslav Drobny, Vladislav Skonecki and Paul Remy -- today gained the men's singles semi-finals at the Nice international tennis tournament with straight set triumphs.
LONDON, April 14 -- About 23,000 printers and other non-editorial employes of London's strike-bound newspapers were losing their jobs tonight or tomorrow. The strike entered its fourth week.

IN its fifteenth anniversary season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Ballet Theatre last night came up with a "Giselle" that was a real cause for celebration. With Alicia Alonso in the title role, Igor Youskevitch as Albrecht, Lupe Serrano as Myrtha, and a corps de ballet that knew what it was doing, here was a performance with body and substance.
Another small link in the letters of Thomas Jefferson has turned up in, of all places, a local thrift shop.

The "do-it-yourself" movement has increased the danger of children's developing lead poisoning by chewing on items touched up with inappropriate paint. This danger adds importance to a safety standard for paints recently approved and distributed by the American Standards Association.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 14 (Reuters) -- A labor dispute that has held up construction of a new stand for the main stadium of the 1956 Olympics today threatened to spread to other building projects for the games.

Dr. Jacob Werne, on leave from his post as assistant medical examiner, hanged himself yesterday in his home at 82-53 164th Street, Jamaica, Queens. His wife, a pathologist, found the body at 9 A. M., suspended by a bathrobe cord from a hinge of his bedroom door.

In a deal in the Times Square area, the twelve-story store and office building at 140 West Forty-second Street has been sold by Daniel D. Cantor, broker, for the Murlou Realty Corporation. The Salva Realty Company was associate broker in the transaction.

BOSTON, April 14 -- Still without Ted Williams, the Boston Red Sox didn't need the Splendid Splinter to achieve a successful home opener before 22,246 fans at Fenway Park today. Sammy White and Jim Piersall took over Williams' specialty, the home run, and the Bosox downed the Yankees, 8 -- 4.

The victory of Mrs. Jan Burke's Dedicate was one of the notable occurrences at the Jamaica race track yesterday. The 3-year-old colt opposed five others of his own age in the mile-and-a-sixteenth feature race, and won by a length and a half.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14 -- Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today he believed Soviet overtures toward an Austrian treaty were another effort to delay or block the arming of West Germany.

" Accidental sabotage" in the form of carelessness can be just as dangerous to the nation's port facilities as "sabotage by intent," Vice Admiral, Alfred C. Richmond, commandant of the United States Coast Guard, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The House of Representatives voted for $450,398,227 today to run the State and Justice Departments, the Judiciary and related agencies. The appropriation is for the coming fiscal year. The Senate will act next.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A national conference on automation listened today to conflicting views on the blessings and threats of modern technology.

My usual Sunday enjoyment of The New York Times was rudely disturbed by a statement in Topics of The Times on your editorial page. In the first sentence the writer of this column says: "If there were an opinion poll to determine the dullest task in the world, such things as door-knob polishing, library cataloguing and inventory-taking in a pin factory would get high ratings."

Events today: Haarlem Philharmonic Society, Waldorf-Astoria,, 11 A. M., and Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting; Frances Yeend, soprano; Martha Lipton, contralto; David Lloyd, tenor; Mack Harrell, baritone; Westminster Choir; Carnegie Hail, 2:30 P. M.

The average rate of interest charged by New York City banks on short-term business loans in the first half of March was 3.24 per cent, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was virtually the same as the rate charged in the first half of December.

THE final Thursday night concert of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Society, which took place last night in Carnegie Hall, began with the first performance anywhere of Jan Meyerowitz' work for chorus and orchestra, "The Glory Around His Head," and concluded with Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. Dimitri Mitropoulos conducted.

Today's new film is "A Bullet for Joey," a United Artists melodrama starring Edward G. Robinson and George Raft, at the Palace. Samuel Bischoff and David Diamond are the producers. Lewis Allen directed from a screen play by Geoffrey Homes and A. I. Bezzerides and an original story by James Benson Nablo.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senate investigators of the Edward Corsi case voted today to begin public hearings tomorrow morning on Washington's hottest political issue.
ROME, April 14 -- Official cir cles in Italy are disappointed at the ouster of Mr. Corsi.
The virtues of adversity were extolled yesterday morning in a Passover sermon by Rabbi Israel Goldstein. He spoke at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street.
Evidently the writer of your editorial "The Antiquated El" is not too familiar with the transit situation on the East Side of New York City.
LLANDUDNO, Wales, April 14 -- The British Liberal party, encouraged by the schism in the Laborite movement, met today in an atmosphere of unusual optimism to prepare for a general election.

The long lean line, popular in women's spring fashions, is also evident in sofas and upholstered pieces introduced this week. Nine- and twelve-foot lengths are common. Fabric covers, pulled tightly over cushions, arms and backs, are decidedly on the slim side.
Daniel A. Bolich, former assistant commissioner of internal revenue, was sentenced yesterday to five years' imprisonment and fined $15,000 for conspiracy in a $160,000 tax-fix case.
Home cooks find themselves returning repeatedly to pork these days. Record supplies have depressed prices in a way welcome to all who operate on a budget (or try to).
Loans to business by seventeen New York City Banks declined by $23,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. It was the third week in a row to show a decline.
ALBANY, April 14 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that a car owner could not be convicted of speeding on the evidence of an unattended photographic "speed trap."
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 14 -- Joao (Jango) Goulart has become a center of controversy through his apparent intention to run for Vice President of Brazil.

JERSEY CITY, April 14 (AP) -- A Hudson County grand jury said today it had not found sufficient evidence to warrant an indictment against Louis J. Messano, former public safety director. He had been under attack for his handling of an inquiry into the bombing of the headquarters of Local 1247 of the International Longshoremen's Association at 329 Grand Street in 1951.

For a long time I have been in favor of daylight-saving time. But if an extension of the daylight-saving period is considered to be an advantage, would not there be a far greater benefit by putting the extension ahead of, instead of behind, the usual period?
Home cooks find themselves returning repeatedly to pork these days. Record supplies have depressed prices in a way welcome to all who operate on a budget (or try to).
Loans to business by seventeen New York City Banks declined by $23,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. It was the third week in a row to show a decline.
ALBANY, April 14 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that a car owner could not be convicted of speeding on the evidence of an unattended photographic "speed trap."
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 14 -- Joao (Jango) Goulart has become a center of controversy through his apparent intention to run for Vice President of Brazil.

JERSEY CITY, April 14 (AP) -- A Hudson County grand jury said today it had not found sufficient evidence to warrant an indictment against Louis J. Messano, former public safety director. He had been under attack for his handling of an inquiry into the bombing of the headquarters of Local 1247 of the International Longshoremen's Association at 329 Grand Street in 1951.

For a long time I have been in favor of daylight-saving time. But if an extension of the daylight-saving period is considered to be an advantage, would not there be a far greater benefit by putting the extension ahead of, instead of behind, the usual period?
The new $6,500,000 vertical lift bridge between Long Island City, Queens, and Welfare Island will begin trial operation next week.

VIENNA, April 15 (UP)--Following are the highlights in the history of the negotiations for an Austrian state treaty: Oct. 31, 1943 -- The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union sign declaration recognizing Austria as a victim of Nazi aggression and pledging re-establishment of a free Austria.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 15 (UP)--An atomic explosion more powerful than that at Hiroshima ripped into more than $1,000,000 worth of military equipment today in a test of the bomb's effects on supply centers.
WASHINGTON, April 15-- The State Department first moved to drop Edward Corsi two days after Representative Francis E. Walter had asked Secretary of State Dulles to "dispense with his services."

The recent loans to Spain through the Export-Import Bank and the Foreign Operations Administration here have enabled that Government to settle 8,000 new farmers on their own land, Rafael Cavestany, Minister of Agriculture of Spain, declared yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 15--The Organizing Committee for the 1956 Olympic Games at a special meeting tonight appointed Lewis Luxton as full-time deputy chairman of the committee. He will have overriding authority to expedite the preparations for the international meet.
VIENNA, April 15--The Austrian delegation returned from Moscow today with the draft of a new state treaty.

"The Spy Web," by Francis Noel-Baker, will be published April 22 by Vanguard Press. It is a collection of short pieces about Soviet spies, who and what they are and what leads them to do espionage for Russia. It also tells how the spy machine "breaks down."

LLANDUDNO, Wales, April 15 -- The Liberal party will contest ninety-three seats in the coming general election. Party officials believe that candidates for twenty-nine other places will be found before the nominations close.

WASHINGTON, April 15--The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations will hold a closed hearing Monday on "all aspects" of the capture and imprisonment of fifteen American airmen by the Chinese Communists.
OCEANPORT, N. J., April 15 (UP)--The richest stakes program in the history of Monmouth Park for the meeting opening June 11 was announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Electric power production in the country would be expanded almost 50 per cent by 1958 under a program offered today by the Office of Defense Mobilization.
DETROIT, April 15 (UP)--Herb Score, making his major league debut, pitched the Cleveland Indians to a 7-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers at Briggs Stadium today.

BOSTON, Saturday, April 16 (AP)--Some 25,000 New England cotton textile workers struck at 12:01 A. M. today. The dispute was over a management request that they take a 10 cents an hour cut in wages and fringe benefits.
Commodity futures fluctuated sharply on New York exchanges yesterday but closing quotations showed little change from Thursday's final levels.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 --W. Somerset Maugham's "The Painted Veil," filmed originally by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer with Greta Garbo in 1934, will be remade with Ava Gardner.
PAINTINGS of Paris by Robert Sivard, at the Midtown Gallery, 17 East Fiftyseventh Street, are most ingratiating though they outrageously flatter the spectator's eye and sense of humor.

What can hats do for a woman ? They can make her life happy and prosperous, support her in a strange country when bad times come and keep her young and self-respecting at the end of three-score years and ten.

Chief Justice Warren's statement yesterday is typical of the straightforwardness and candor which the country has long since learned to expect of him. In it he has taken note of the fact that his name was mentioned prominently in a poll of possible choices for the Republican Presidential nomination in the event that Mr. Eisenhower should not choose to run again.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 15-- For a change, parents rather than teachers received an oral spanking today. They were asked to do some soul searching of their own.
Governor Harriman yesterday signed new laws extending state anti-discrimination regulations in Federally aided housing.
WASHINGTON, April 15-- The State Department wants to know definitely whether the eleven fingerprint-shy Soviet editors are coming to the United States or staying at home.
WASHINGTON, April 15-- The Atomic Energy Commission reported to Congress today that comprehensive investigations had failed to show any harmful effects from atomic tests in Nevada.
GREENSBORO N. C., April 15 (AP)--Ed Furgol and Art Wall Jr. carded four-under-par 66's today to share the first-round lead in the $12,500 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In view of the great interest taken by your paper in South African affairs I should like to be permitted to deal with some aspects of those affairs.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15--The United Nations' principal truce officer in Palestine reported today that Egypt and Israel had accepted some of his proposals for curbing border troubles.
For the eighth successive session stocks rose yesterday and for the third day The New York Times' industrial average touched a new historic peak.

Paul Douglas has been suspended by Actors Equity as the result of derogatory remarks about the South he was said to have made in February. His actual suspension, however, was suspended, and he was put on probation for a year.
Arguments as to prices for natural gas depend upon which end of the pipeline the views come from.
WASHINGTON, April 15-- Radioactivity in Reno, Nev., was piped into a Congressional hearing room today.
Five hundred Chelsea district longshoremen yesterday defied a State Supreme Court injunction ordering them not to interfere with the hiring policy of the Grace Line.

THE chief feature of last night's program by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was a revival of Antony Tudor's "Romeo and Juliet" with Alicia Markova and Hugh Laing as guest artists in the roles they created.
The number of New York City school children who will be offered free Salk anti-polio shots before June 1 was increased yesterday by 184,915.
BEAUMONT, Tex., April 15 (AP)--Betty Jameson of San Antonio startled the rest of the field in the Babe Zaharias golf tournament today with an eightunder-par 65.
The backlog of new financing and the pace of new offerings both reflect a taxing of the new capital market in a manner not uncommon to spring.

A nation-wide "Dress for Success Week" to be conducted at the local level was proposed yesterday by the Philadelphia Clothing Manufacturers Association. The Philadelphia group reported the results of a test campaign they conducted in Hartford, Conn., during the week of March 27 to the board of directors of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers at the New Yorker Hotel.

VAN WYCK BROOKS' "John Sloan"* is a discerning tribute from one distinguished artist to another. In this memoir of a friend's lifetime from 1871 to 1951 Mr. Brooks, dean of American critics, sketches serenely the tumultuous world behind Sloan's celebrated paintings and adds one more memorable panel to his own superb panorama of the lives of creative artists in America.

In New York, Mr. Wolfson told newsmen he was "confident" that he would take control at the annual meeting next Friday. But he added that he was not predicting victory on the basis of proxies now in hand.
RANGOON, Burma, April 15 --Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China wasted no time today in launching a diplomatic courtship of Egypt's Premier, Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Naaser.
archy and mehitabel, Don Marquis' bizarre brainchildren, will be the subject of a Broadway musical to be produced early next season.

LONDON, April 15--The Foreign Office welcomed today the news of the Soviet-Austrian agreement on terms for an Austrian state treaty. Its satisfaction was subject to fuller information than was given in the communique issued in Moscow.
ALBANY, April 15--State officials agreed today to buy $1,000,000 worth of Salk vaccine, half of which is to be used for free inoculation of third and fourth grade school children.

Some horses are whizz bangs on wet tracks. One such animal is the 4-year-old colt Duc de Fer. Yesterday at Jamaica, where the racing strip was muddy, he won with ease in the $10,000 Sgt. Byrne Handicap.
TORONTO, April 15 (Canadian Press)--Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., had net profit in 1954 of $14,243,319, or $8.58 a share, compared with $20,029,513, or $12.07 a share in 1953.

Railroad wages present an issue which may grow into a national crisis later this year. Fortunately, the federal Railroad Labor Law provides plenty of time for negotiations and agreement even if a deadlock is first reached over specific union demands.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Adlai Stevenson's speech of April 11 on our Asian policy was misleading, politically partisan and potentially dangerous. He offered nothing constructive that the Administration has not already been attempting to achieve, but he did raise great doubts before the whole world about the American people's solidarity in backing up the decisions of the President.
PITTSBURGH, April 15--One of America's most progressive merchants, Mr. Kaufmann was also one of the key figures in this city's billion-dollar redevelopment program.
A two-year series of scientific tests has failed to show that cloud-seeding can change the weather over a wide area.
Prices of cotton futures turned irregular on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closed 9 points lower to 7 higher than on Thursday. The weakness was in the near months.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 15 (AP)--Prince Eton scored his third victory in three starts this season at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. He won the Flushing Pace.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- United States officials remained on guard today against premature conclusions about restoration of Austrian freedom and independence.

WASHINGTON, April 15--Chief Justice Earl Warren took himself fully, firmly and finally out of any reckoning for the 1956 Republican Presidential nomination today. Moreover, he declared in a formal statement that when he had taken his seat at the center of the high bench of the Supreme Court he had said good-by to politics forever.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 15--Charles B. Harris of Lebanon, Neb., was killed today in the Jerusalem No Man's Land by a Jordanian guard's rifle shot.

A one-story building occupied by a Bohack supermarket at the southwest corner of Main and McDermott Avenues in Riverhead, L, I., has been sold by the Willis-Harris Construction Corporation, builder, to Morton Rosenfeld and H. Lawrence Herring.

Three thousand officers and men of the Fire Department marched yesterday from the Battery to City Hall, where Firemen's Day was celebrated. They brought with them on floats antique pieces of fire-fighting apparatus from the department's museum in Long Island City, Queens.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation "busted" a "rear admiral" yesterday.
Federal and state income tax collectors here were pleasantly surprised yesterday. The expected last-minute deadline rush of those filing 1954 returns failed to materialize at any of the offices.
BOSTON, April 15--For his part in yesterday's dispute with Umpire Bill McKinley, Irv Noren of the Yankees today was suspended indefinitely.

LONDON, April 15 -- With budget proposals to be announced Tuesday and expectations -- later fulfilled -- that Prime Minister Eden would announce the date of a general election, the markets were quieter than ever today.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 15--Ch. Kashdowd's White Rock of Coolyn Hill, an imported white bull terrier owned by Mrs. Z. Platt Bennett of Dallas, Pa., today was named best at the Charlottesville Kennel Club show.
The Bell System had its biggest first-quarter on record this year in sales and earnings, Cleo F. Craig, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 15-- Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, who fled Norway before the Nazi invasion, made a comeback today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 15--Suspension of regular commercial air traffic between France and Sweden looms over a divergence in French-Swedish views on how the passenger flights between the two countries should be handled.
CHICAGO, April 15--Edmund A. Krider, president of Ward, said the court decision "does not change the basic issues of this proxy contest."
CHICAGO, April 15--Wheat futures were under pressure in the early part of the trading session here today but there was a fair recovery from the low spots.
A concern headed by Louis E. Wolfson, Florida financier, shared the low bid for constructing part of the powerhouse at the $600,000,000 St. Lawrence power project.
The suicide on Wednesday of Dr. Jacob Werne, assistant medical examiner, led to a suicide attempt on Thursday night by a former aide who owed him a deep debt of gratitude.

The seven-story apartment house at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Eightyninth Street has been sold by the Doegler interests to Samuel and Milton Brause, operators, in a deal negotiated by Walter Samuels, brokers.
WASHINGTON, April 15-- The country's railroads sought authority today to continue permanently 1952 temporary freight rate increases that have been producing $1,000,000,000 in annual revenues.
So far as the Giants are concerned, the 1955 championship season hasn't opened yet.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15-- A growing tendency of some observers to label all Americans "conformists" was criticized today by a New York University psychologist.
TOKYO, April 15 (AP)--Communist China and private Japanese fishing interests agreed tonight to end five years of conflict over harvesting the rich marine life of the Yellow and East China Seas.
A new Navy crew will seek to extend the longest winning streak in intercollegiate heavyweight competition as the Eastern rowing season opens this afternoon.
A photographic copy of the suicide note left by Charles W. Chapman, deputy commissions of the State Liquor Authority was turned over yesterday to Investigation Commissioner J. Irwin Shapiro.

WASHINGTON, April 15--The outlook for the President's reciprocal trade program was confused further today by proposals of Senator Styles Bridges to limit the President's independence in revising tariff rates.

Cardinal Spellman issued yesterday a pastoral letter urging all Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of New York to contribute at least one day's wage to the thirty-sixth annual New York Catholic Charities appeal.

Weston Electrical Instrument The directors of Daystrom, Inc., and the Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation have agreed on terms under which Weston would be merged into Daystrom. The agreement calls for the issuance of one share of Daystrom stock in exchange for each share of Weston.
The Associated Press reported yesterday that news--good or bad--could now travel faster than ever all over the world.

Those belonging to the Eastern Orthodox Church in this city, roughly 100,000 people, tonight start a celebration that leads tomorrow into their Easter. That joyful spring feast comes a week later for this small group of New Yorkers, whose church uses the Julian rather than the Gregorian calendar.
TRENTON, April 15--The State Public Utility Commission today granted the Erie Railroad the right to replace its passenger train service between West Orange and Newark with buses.

THREE contemporary works, two of them heard for the first time in this city, were presented by the New York Concert Choir last night in Town Hall. Margaret Hillis conducted the program, which was the ensemble's final one of the season.
Leaders of all religious faiths have been urged by the American Cancer Society to take part today and tomorrow in promoting the society's national educational and fund-raising campaign.

The least populous and least developed of the three Indochinese states, Laos has repeated its charge to the International Commission that its security is threatened by Communist Vietminh activities in its northern area. Specifically, the international group--made up of representatives of India, Poland and Canada--has been informed that a "dissident army" is being formed on Laotian soil by a "foreign country."

Stanley Dancer, who'll be 28 years old in July, is now rated on the income tax rolls as an upper-bracket man. His net earnings as a driver-trainer in the harness horse racing business last year were close to $30,000.
DETROIT, April 15--Automobile and truck production in the United States is expected to reach another new peak this week.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 15 (AP)--Louis E. Wolfson gained strength in the Illinois Supreme Court today for his showdown battle with Sewell L. Avery for control of the $700,000,000 Montgomery Ward Co.

WASHINGTON, April 15--Dr. Peter Schlumbohm, a New York inventor, got a basic patent this week on his revolutionary electric fan that uses thin sheets of paper instead of blades. At rest, the fan looks like an electric motor wearing a limp paper cap.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Democratic high command called on the party today to carry the attack directly to President Eisenhower and declared he could be defeated in 1956.
Report cards are as much a problem to the Board of Education as they are to some pupils and their parents.

Although business and Government are paying more for credit now than six months ago, the consumer is still paying the same interest on money he's borrowing for a new car or television set. Moreover, he'll probably continue to pay about the same rate.
BOSTON, April 15--Bob Turley, in his official debut with the Yankees, put them back on the winning beam today at Fenway Park.

WASHINGTON, April 15-- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 110.5 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for farm products more than offset a drop in the index for processed foods and accounted for the increase.

For those interested in the slow and intermittent but inevitable progress of Latin America toward democracy a ray of light is to be seen on the Peruvian horizon. Presidential elections are coming in the first half of 1956 and there is hope that they will mark a decided step toward political freedom.
BERLIN, April 15 -- The Western High Commissioners in Germany asked the Soviet High Commissioner today to discuss with them increased highway tolls for traffic between Berlin and West Germany.
NEW DELHI, India, April 15 --Mr. Nehru left this morning in an Air India Constellation for Rangoon en route to Bandung to attend what he described as a "unique and historic" conference.
ALBANY, April 15--Governor Harriman today authorized New York City to take over a Bronx veterans' cemetery that has been allowed to become a "vandals' playground."

Arthur H. Bienenstock, a builder and investor, contracted to buy a lot at 247 Broadway, southwest corner of Murray Street. In the process, he acquired a parcel that has been a mystery in the area for many years.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15-- The president of the American Association for Cancer Research called tonight for legislation on the "ethics" of the use of unsubstantiated, anonymous material collected during investigations of American scientists.

WITH everyone interested in trout fishing hip deep in a New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut or New Jersey stream, this should be the right moment for a discussion on the contest between the angling sexes.

Without any fanfare India and Pakistan have signed an agreement to restore full rail connection between the two neighboring countries. This is an important gain to both and a significant easing of one of the points of tension in Asia. It is a further move toward the restoration of normal and friendly relations between the two states.

MOSCOW, April 15--Austria and the Soviet Union reached an understanding early today on the disputed points of the Austrian state treaty. In a joint communique they expressed their hope that the United States, Britain and France would join them.
Arthur Godfrey dismissed nine artists from his Columbia Broadcasting System radio and television shows yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 9-- Down in Chillan, about 200 miles south of Santiago, a successful Point Four pilot project has quietly taken shape. The American name for it is the Concepcion Area Development Plan, but Chileans call it simply Plan Chillan.

A-sittin' and A-rockin' A dispatch from the Canadian North the other day reports that young woodsmen there have been taking to their rocking chairs lately--only with a heartiness that is typical of their breed.
BONN, Germany, April 15-- The Soviet Union's offer ostensibly to liberate Austria in return for complete Austrian neutrality seemed today to be having the effect here that Moscow presumably expected.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today the Justice Department had abandoned the practice of retaining fulltime "consultants" on communism, at guaranteed salaries.
Trustees of the State University of New York decided yesterday that something should be done about providing additional higher education facilities in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

LONDON, April 15--The Foreign Office announced today that Antoine Pinay, the French Foreign Minister, had accepted an invitation to visit London April 21 for private discussions with Prime Minister Eden and Foreign Secretary Harold Macmillan. The visit will last one day.

LONDON, April 15--The Foreign Office announced today that Antoine Pinay, the French Foreign Minister, had accepted an invitation to visit London April 21 for private discussions with Prime Minister Eden and Foreign Secretary Harold Macmillan. The visit will last one day.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 15 --An era increasingly favorable to the Negro was pictured today as the National Urban League's board met.

WASHINGTON, April 15--Further attacks upon escalator clauses by which natural gas producers can force price increases upon buyers marked testimony again today before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

LONDON, April 15 -- In the coming general election about 35,000,000 Britons will be qualified to vote but only about 70,000 will have the right to vote for or against Sir Anthony Eden, the Prime Minister. Similarly, only about 50,000 will choose or reject Clement Attlee, the Labor party chief.
Banking interests and the police lice have adopted plans for stronger anti-robbery methods, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, April 15--According to an American scientist's theory, man's intellectual development exceeds that of all other animals because of the longterm evolutionary effect of relatively large quantities of uric acid in his blood stream.
Pan American World Airways and Northwest Airlines reopened yesterday their long-standing dispute over one of the world's most important airline routes-- across the Pacific.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., threatened the city yesterday with a "spontaneous" full-scale strike. But Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, chairman of the Transit Authority, characterized the threat as "more of the same."
A champion of inter-American democracy called last night for "intervention" against foes of freedom in Latin America.

Indignant affirmations of good faith punctuated a twohour-and-ten-minute hearing yesterday on burlesque. The session was the third held by License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey on application of Thomas J. Phillips for a license to offer a burlesque show at the Orpheum Theatre, 574-78 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.
BUENOS AIRES, April 15-- The Permanent Commission of the Argentine Roman Catholic Episcopate clarified its position today in the Peronist campaign to separate the church from the state.
Representative members of the worlds of society, diplomacy and the arts attended the fourth annual April in Paris Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 15--A witness bent on correcting his first story to Congress admitted today that he had given inside information to a friend who had won a large Government contract although apparently the highest bidder.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 15 --Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, the Philippine delegate to the Asian-African conference, arrived here today prepared to defend the principle of collective security against attacks expected from the neutralist and Communist camps.

The coining use of atomic heat in the generation of electricity will not make existing utility facilities obsolete, Harold Quinton, president of the Southern California Edison Company, said at yesterday's annual stockholders' meeting in Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, April 15--The first concrete result of the agreement to rearm West Germany within NATO is the accord on Austria. After ten years of unabashed dillydallying Moscow has agreed to honor its pledges.

The prospect of a Four-Power conference on Austria that could be a prelude to new negotiations on Germany has brightened considerably as a result of the agreement between Soviet Russia and Austria on an independence treaty for the latter country.

WASHINGTON, April 15-- Two operating railroad unions today called a strike against the Louisville and Nashville Railroad. They are the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, both unaffiliated.
LONDON, April 15 -- Prime Minister Eden announced tonight that a general election would be held May 26.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 16--A mythical United States First Army of 475,000 men will counter-attack along the Rhine River in Germany next week-end without leaving near-by Camp Kilmer.

CINCINNATI, April 16 (UP)-- Johnny Logan made five straight hits and drove in three runs as the Braves beat the Redlegs, 9--5, in a battle of home runs today. It was the fourth straight defeat for the winless Redlegs, who hit five homers to tie a major league record.

WHETHER it be redbud trees or crabapples, dogwoods or rose bushes, thousands of trees and shrubs will be set out this spring along the nation's streets, roads and highways in widespread community plantings.

ANNUAL vines have a lot of charm all their own, and they can often be used to fill in while slowergrowing permanent vines cover a trellis, arbor or porch. Or instead of playing second fiddle to other plants, the annual climbers can be given a site along a fence or a wall where they alone bloom.

Scheme THE newest book club to rear its head is The Paper Editions Book Club, and it deals with paper books only, natch. The club bases its raison d'etre on two observations. It claims that (1) hundreds of excellent paperbacks are often hard to find in bookshops or on newsstands; and (2) mail order marketing is the logical method of selling older titles.

THE Civil Aeronautics Board will open public hearings Tuesday in Seattle in search of answers to some sticky questions about the recent ditching of a Boeing Stratocruiser in the Pacific. Among the questions that will be investigated are: What set up the severe buffeting that, in the words of the Pan American World Airways pilot, "shook the plane like a reducing machine?"

A quartet from St. John's Prep provided the highlight yesterday in the fifth annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association's relay carnival at Randalls Island. The Redmen ran one of the fastest Eastern interscholastic two-mile relays ever recorded. They were timed in 8:04.1.

THE New York season of the Philharmonic - Symphony Society ends with this afternoon's concert in Carnegie Hall. In a period of approximately seven months the orchestra has given the enormous number of 152 concerts, thirty-one of them out of town.
