UTRECHT, The Netherlands, April 16 (AP)--The United States table tennis team kept pace with the defending champions from Japan today. Both squads remained unbeaten in the first day's play for the Swaythling Cup.

SINGAPORE. THIS coming week, in Bandung, the Prime Ministers of most of the independent nations of Asia and Africa are meeting to exchange ideas, discuss common problems and get better acquainted. Since this is the first time high officials of these two great continents have come together on their own initiative, with the West deliberately excluded, the Bandung Conference is a historic gathering.
Recipients of awards from the Education Writers Association for outstanding achievement in educational journalism during 1954 were announced yesterday by Leonard Buder, the organization's president.

In the general satisfaction over what seems now to be a long forward step toward an Austrian peace treaty there is, of course, the inevitable scanning of the Soviet motives. The Communist desire to bring pressure upon Germany in this way to resist the agreed program for rearmament and orientation toward the free world is only too obvious.
The monsoon winds are diminishing in the Formosa Strait region this month, and between now and July, when the typhoon season opens, the weather favors air and amphibious operations.

MOSCOW. YOUR correspondent laid out nineteen rubles of the company's money the other night and went to the Central House of Culture of the Railway Workers on Komsomol Square to attend a concert by the oldest and bestknown popular music combination in the Soviet Union-- Leonid Utyosov's Gosudarstvennyi Estradnyi Orkestr.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 16 --The Legislature at Hartford will be asked next week to assure Greenwich "an abundant supply" of water, irrespective of what may befall in Rye and Port Chester, N.Y., which have shared the water supply since 1883.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 16--Columbia's crews scored a sweep over Rutgers today on the Raritan by capturing four races.

THEY say that there can be no new plays in baseball. Yet it's quite possible that Jackie Robinson produced a new one on Wednesday. No baseball man this inquiring reporter questioned had seen it before and not all agreed on what should be done about it.

THE old-fashioned belief that landscape painting is the expression of an emotion felt for landscape itseif and not for its associations is strurdily upheld by Maurice Grosser in his paintings of Greece, at the Iolas Gallery.

IN "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," named the best American play of the 1954-55 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle last week, the gargantuan character who roars mightily through the play is a plantation owner named Big Daddy.
France's proposed new $75,000,000 liner will conform to the trend of the latest additions to the North Atlantic passenger fleet and cater primarily to tourist trade.

WAVE after wave of Mozart will be breaking over American audiences next season. Many of the gathering combers already have been sighted. Here are some more. The Salzburg Mozarteum Orchestra, led by Ernst Marzendorfer, will come here for an eight-week tour in February and play at Princeton, Rutgers, Smith, Wellesley, Winthrop and the state universities of Maryland, Indiana, Wisconsin and Minnesota.

Magnesium, the lightweight metal made from sea water, is fast becoming recognized as one of industry's most effective weapons in the battle against corrosion -- and particularly against corrosion in sea water itself.

WASHINGTON, April 16--Adlai E. Stevenson, the titular leader of the Democratic party, had three principal purposes in making his speech this week on the situation in the Far East: (1) To add his protest to those mounting in the country against armed defense by the United States of the offshore Chinese islands in the event they are attacked by the Chinese Communists.
Devotees of the art of needlework from all over the country have entered samples of their workmanship in the Ninth National Exhibition of Amateur Needlework of Today, Inc.
HONG KONG, April 16--A Peiping Government official said today that Communist China and India would soon begin negotiations on establishing a joint airline.

ROY CAMPBELL is what anybody would call a man of action. He has been a horse trader, "a professional bullfighter and wandering circus performer in Provence, a fisherman off the southern coast of France, a soldier in both wars, [he has] fought with Franco * * *."

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., April 16--A Roman Catholic church here will lend a school building without charge for one year to burgeoning Central School District 2 of Bedford, New Castle and Pound Ridge. The building will avert a classroom crisis for the public schools and end double sessions.

TO THE EDITOR: It was encouraging to read Vannevar Bush's article, "To Make Our Security System Secure" (March 20) in which he lays open the hysteriabased foundations upon which our loyalty system is based.

HOBOKEN, N.J., April 16-- The growth of mechanical engineering in the last seventy-five years and the responsibility of the engineer in the present day were outlined here today at Stevens Institute of Technology. The occasion was the seventyfifth anniversary celebration of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

FISHING is outdoor chess. And while it is true that the angler's finny opponents, in accordance with a law of Darwin, are growing wilier and harder to outwit, so are anglers becoming more resourceful and more filled with guile.
WASHINGTON, April 16--Harry S. Truman, fresh from an ambidextrous double-header with the Kansas City Athletes, arrived in the capital this week-end and threw hisc beanball at the press.

APRIL is the month that brings on the daffodils, and on Wednesday the Horticultural Society of Jew York, Inc., will have its anual show devoted to this golden flower. It is to be held in the Colonnades Ballroom of Essex House, 160 Central Park South from 1 to 4:30 P.M.
The soul of America "faces the prospect of being stifled by an overabundance of wealth," Rabbi William Berkowitz declared yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 16--A statement of the Soviet Foreign Ministry confirmed tonight that eleven editors of student papers had canceled their trip to the United States rather than submit to fingerprinting.

Connecticut and Massachusetts youngsters rode a train of their own to the Bronx Zoo yesterday. After stops along the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad from Springfield, Mass., to Norwalk, Conn., the three sections drew into the Van Nest yards in the Bronx at 10:45 A.M. The thirty-six coaches carried 2,500 children, a few stout-hearted adults, a deodorized skunk, an opossum, an alligator and a boa constrictor supplied by the zoo.

Governor Harriman joined Mayor Wagner yesterday in an appeal to the Engineering Societies to remain in this city. The engineers, who have had their headquarters here for half a century, are at 25-33 West Thirty-ninth Street.

An hour and thirty-nine minutes after its activation yesterday at 9 A.M. the Fire Department's new flying squad had its first run.
An organized effort to register 100,000 Puerto Ricans to vote in New York City in the 1956 election was mapped here yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, April 16--A thousand observers will converge on Las Vegas, Nev., next weekend for the most elaborate atomic demonstration in the five years of continental nuclear tests.

SPRING, according to the dictionary, is the "season of the year when plants begin to vegetate and grow; the season beginning with the vernal equinox and ending with the summer solstice." Signs of growth finally are evident almost a month after spring's announced arrival.

WITH an eye to tourists who want to combine travel and study, a United Nations agency has come out with a listing of vacation courses, educational tours and work camps. Studytravel opportunities in forty-five countries are covered in the 1955 manual released by UNESCO.

Five model homes are being opened today at the Broadlawn in Livingston colony on East Mount Pleasant Avenue, two miles beyond the Pleasant Valley Way, in Livingston, N. J. The houses are priced at $22,500 to $25,990.

IF ever I am deprived of space for a real Vegetable or flower garden I am sure I will somehow find a way to grow at least six herbs--basil, chives, dill, fennel, marjoram and savory. A window box on, an apartment house fire escape or a couple of round wooden cheese boxes on the doorstep of a suburban home will provide ample growing space for these practically indispensable seasonings.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Former President Truman maintained his usual pace on his usual early morning walk today. But, he revealed to reporters, he has cut down the mileage.

THE music publishing business is free to toot trumpets of joy this morning. Abe Burrows, who was to embark on a lampoon of the trade in his next musical, "Top Ten," has put the project wide, temporarily at least.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, April 1 --Now that independence from Britain is virtually assured in the Gold Coast and eventually Will be in Nigeria, nationalists of both countries are able to focus their efforts on broader objectives.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- The State Department said today that it regretted the cancellation of the editors' thirty-day tour of educational centers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16--The Kent School eight-oared crew defeated the Yale 150pound varsity today under ideal weather conditions. Rowing downstream, and aided by a slight tail wind, Kent negotiated the mile course in 4 minutes 44 seconds. Yale was time in 4:47.5.

Coffee producing countries are concerned about the possibility of another runaway market. In Latin America, producers believe that neither they nor consumers benefited last year when prices soared to more than 90 cents a pound for green coffee beans.

NORFOLK, Va., April 16-- The Fifth Coast Guard and Naval District gave a special demonstration this week of the latest communications system employed in widespread search and rescue operations.
ROME, April 16--An American and a Canadian are among the fourteen persons whose appointments to the Pontifical Academy of Science were announced today by Pope Pius XII.

ALL of Paul Gregory's productions have dispensed with scenery. All of them have been successful.

A ninth-inning rally extended Fordham's undefeated baseball streak to six games yesterday. The Rams defeated Rutgers, 3--2, on Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.

HOLLYWOOD. THE Warner Brothers-- Harry, Jack and Albert-- demonstrated last week that they haven't lost their pioneering spirit. They are going into television on a scale unmatched by any other major motion picture studio.

Although change is the rule in many phases of gardening today, the popularity of certain flowers remains constant. Six in particular--dahlias, daylilies, gladiolus, iris, chrysanthemums and peonies--are so widely favored as to rate being called "hobby flowers."
WASHINGTON, April 16-- The great debate on foreign policy is not so much a debate anymore as an intent struggle for the mind and will of a man, President Eisenhower.
Communities faced with the prospect of future growth and expansion should seek new ways of controlling proposed subdivisions in the opinion of a Cornell University planning expert.

CLEVELAND, April 16 (UP)-- The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers announced today it had authorized a strike against the New York Central Railroad tomorrow morning but had quickly called it off after the Government stepped into the dispute.

The end of the boom in apartment house construction on the East Side of Manhattan is nowhere in sight. The demand for new and expensive residential space apparently is not even declining although the rentals these apartments bring are about as high as the market will bear. Builders and mortgage lenders continue to look optimistically on new projects involving investments of many millions.
LONDON, April 16--Lord Kirkwood, once a stormy labor agitator and pacifist, died today in Glasgow, Scotland. He was 82 years old.

A large tract in Queens is among sites on Long Island where housing developments are being opened today with the display of model dwellings. Fortyfive houses priced at $28,890 are planned for the Surrey Oaks colony on Sawyer Avenue and Springfield Boulevard in Holliswood.
The local art season continues its pace with a wide variety of group and one-man shows opening this week in the galleries.
R. H. Hodgson has been named retail sales manager of the Eastern Fertilizer division of Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, Baltimore. G.D. Baerman has been appointed manager of insecticide sales.
The Government's Voluntary Home Mortgage Program has achieved success in the first few months of operation, it was announced by the administrator of the Housing and Home Financing, Agency.
TOKYO, April 16--Japan and the United States have virtually completed a new defense agreement. The accord will substantially increase the island nation's military strength this year.

ONE of the strangest gaps in Confederate history has been the lack of a first-rate biography of Pierre Gustave Toutant Beauregard. TO THE EDITOR: Jonathan Daniels' "Appraisal of F.D.R.--A Decade Later" (April 10) was a dispassionate, yet affectionate, summing up of the late President. With 2,4-D able to eliminate most broadleaved weeds, crabgrass has become the undisputed Number One lawn pest. In fact, so much attention has been focused lately on chemical control of crabgrass that the average home owner must be thoroughly confused by all the possibilities offered.

We are honored with the presence in our midst of two of India's outstanding musicians, Ali Akbar Khan, who plays the sarod, and Chatur Lal, who will play the tabla, or drums.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 16--This mountain city of 800,000 people has been renovated, redecorated and put on its best behavior for the Asian-African conference. It is bulging with visitors and when the twentynine-nation parley opens Monday, Bandung will have done its best to prove equal to a great event.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Finish promptly the animal clean-up and putting in order of the lawn. The sooner seed is sown to fill in bare spots, the better its chance to survive hot weather. For a brand-new lawn, sow rye or buckwheat to last until August.

Murrow on "See It Now."

Eleven months ago today segregated education -- the division of school children according to the color of their skin--was outlawed by judicial decree. But to declare it unconstitutional was one thing; to decide upon the method of wiping it out in areas of the country where it has existed for many generations is another.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 16--An atmosphere of excited anticipation and confusion prevails in this sunny mountain city of 800,000 inhabitants. The mood is one that is characteristic of all host cities of great interntional gatherings.
WASHINGTON, April 16-- A Democratic party advisory group recommended today abandonment of the "loyalty oath" that caused a split of Northern and Southern delegates at the 1952 National Convention.

FOR thousands of years India has been famous for her fabrics, costumes and craftsmanship. In ancient Rome her muslins were known as "woven winds." This expression reflects the Indian concept of cloth, for the Veda sees the fabric of the world as woven by the gods. Decorative objects and jewelry, too, often have a religious inspiration, meaning or purpose.

ONCE more there has been a sounding of tocsins and shattering of welkins over the dangers the home handyman faces every time he tackles a job. DEVELOPING a seaside garden presents difficulties not faced with an inland garden. And the closer to the shore, the more the difficulties increase. Naturally plants that will thrive at the shore can be expected to thrive some distance from it.

Louis E. Wolfson won a tactical victory last week in his campaign to unseat Sewell Avery as chairman of Montgomery Ward Co. He has his chance now to seek control of Ward, instead of just a minority position on the board.

A current trend in European city planning is reported to be the opening up of the centers of cities by building plazas, parks and extra-wide streets and locating residential dwellings at city edges.

WITH its current issue, the Virginia Quarterly Review celebrates its thirtieth anniversary. CASABLANCA, French Morocco, April 4--The visitor walking through the teeming streets and market places of the Nouvella Medina, one of Casablanca's largest Arab quarters, finds little to suggest that this Is a terror-stricken city.
VIENNA, April 16--Heads of the Austrian Government have returned from Moscow with an Austrian state treaty draft to which it is believed the West is likely to assent.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 16 --Premier Chou received a hero's welcome from thousands of Indonesia's Chinese on his arrival here today.

CHICAGO, April 16 (UP)-- Walt Dropo hit a grand-slam home run today to spark the Chicago White Sox to a six-run inning and a 9-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians. The game was played before 14,120 Comiskey Park fans.
LISBON, Portugal, April 6-- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar announced this week that an additional $43,000,000 would be appropriated to finance a six-year development plan launched in 1953.

BASEBALL The undefeated Brooklyn Dodgers downed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6--0, yesterday for their fourth victory. Russ Meyer pitched a two-hitter in registering the first major league shutout of the season.
DETROIT, April 16 (UP)--Jim Delsing and Harvey Kuenn hit home runs to lead the Detroit Tigers to an 8-3 victory over the Kansas City Athletics today at Briggs Stadium.

WHILE The Ballet Theatre is recovering from the hosannas attendant upon its fifteenth anniversary and the rest of us are attempting to separate the wheat of its season from the chaff of its guest artists, there is still time to turn attention to the two-week season of American dance to be presented by the B. de Rothschild Foundation at the ANTA Theatre beginning May 3, on the very heels of The Ballet Theatre's engagement.

GILBERT STUART is probably best known for what has long been the standard portrait of Washington, the socalled Athenaeum portrait. But the figure of the painter which emerges will seem an utter contradiction to the portrait.

THERE is no quiet on the "War and Peace" front. There was a time when "War and Peace" simply meant the classic novel by Tolstoy. Now, in addition to five active and inactive plans to turn the massive work into a feature film, comes word that a sixth variant may bloom yet.
Tickets are still available for the Tuesday evening benefit performance of "3 for Tonight" for the Child Study Association of America, Inc.

The American Future I CANNOT say that I am in the slightest degree impressed by your bigness, or your material resources, as such. Size is not grandeur, and territory does not make a nation. The great issue, about which hangs a true sublimity, and the terror of overhanging fate, is what are you going to do with all these things?
MILAN, Italy, April 13--The great annual trade fairs are a tonic to the European economy They cannot cure any major ills but they can make a convalescent patient feel much better.
RANGOON, Burma, April 16 --The suddenness of the departure today of Chou En-lai for the Asian-African conference in Bandung surprised even Chinese members of his delegation.

ANTHROPOLOGISTS are very interesting folk--someone should do a study on the anthropology of anthropologists. What drives them to go and live with remote peoples, often in considerable discomfort, to peer into the private lives of their fellow-men?

THIS, the third of Wolf Mankowitz's pithy and original books, is quite different in style and intention from "Make Me an Offer" and "A Kid for Two Farthings." both of which sprang from real life. "Laugh Till You Cry" is the stylized story of his adventures, told by a shipwrecked salesman of the Rantz Joke Company.

A FRIEND who had just struggled for the first time with the replacement of a window pane says he tried the old trick of rolling the putty into a long, thin cord, as he had seen glaziers do. The result was putty everywhere but where he wanted it.

DALLAS, April 16--Tony Trabert overpowered Dick Savitt and Vie Seixas eliminated Tom Brown in the singles semi-finals of the Dallas Country Club invitation tennis tournament today. The victors will meet in the final tomorrow.
THE superb voice of Renata Tebaldi is heard in two new full-length operatic recordings from London Records, La Traviata (three disks) and Manon Lescaut (three disks).

Real estate investment in diversified properties through limited partnership operation is proposed for a number of new apartment buildings on the East Side. Herbert Tenzer and Louis Greenblatt, attorneys, have joined with Urban Housing Associates and the H.R.H. Construction Corporation in working out the details of the plan.

Aided by glowing reports of business activity in key industries, stock prices last week reached their highest level since October, 1929. The gain was the widest in three weeks; filing of income tax returns had no adverse influence on the market.

WASHINGTON, April 16--Immigration policy is one of the basic conflicts of twentieth century politics in this country, which accounts in large measure for the outsized storm that has been churned up in the last two weeks over Edward Corsi and the administration of the Refugee Relief Act.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 16--India will oppose dealing with the Formosa issue in formal sessions of the Asian-Africa conference here. Indian delegates, however, are expected to make an intensive effort to promote a peaceful solution of the problem in informal talks outside the conference.

Debate on Far East Administration policy on the Quemoy and Matsu question has gone through three phases since passage of the resolution last January authorizing the President to defend Formosa and "such related positions" as he deemed necessary.

PHILADELPHIA. THIRTY years ago in the heat-ridden town of Dayton, Tenn., twelve shirtsleeved jurors heard a misdemeanor explode into a world-famous trial. Four days hence a smartly groomed audience, at the National Theatre will sit in judgment on the Broadway debut of a play based on that incomparable legal duel between William Jennings Bryan and Clarence Darrow.

PITTSBURGH, April 16-- Beating the Dodgers appears to present insurmountable difficulties. They won their fourth straight today by downing the Pirates, 6--0, behind the twohit pitching of Russ Meyer. It was the major leagues' first shutout of the season.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- Despite Congressional prodding for direct action, the State Department has no present intention of taking out of United Nations channels the matter of the fifteen United States airmen imprisoned in Communist China.

LIKE many thousands of other families, the John Does have moved into their first home in the suburbs and, for the first time, are confronted with a lawn. They are a little worried because they know this is the season when the householder ought to busy himself in the yard--but just what should they be doing?

It was generally expected that Dr. Jonas Salk's vaccine would be a success. The success eclipsed expectations. Yet only fifty years ago poliomyelitis was regarded as a mysterious and hopeless affliction. In fact, not until Dr. Karl Landsteiner in 1909 announced that the cause of poliomyelitis was a virus did medical scientists begin to see what kind of research was demanded before anything like a preventive or a cure could be developed.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 16 -- President Jaao Cafe Filho inaugurated an oil refinery today at Cubatao between Santos and Sao Paulo that is in a sense symbolic of Brazil's determined drive for industrialization.
MOSCOW, April 16--A Pravda editorial hinted today that the Germans might find it advantageous to take up a position of neutrality.
Legislation to control oil imports should be deferred until the recommendations of the Cabinet Committee have been given a fair trial, in the opinion of some in the industry.

To the Photography Editor: In reading the summary of Mr. Miller's talk last Sunday in which he encourages the photographer to forsake the cliches of the "ash-can" school and to encompass in his vision some of the brighter aspects of life, several questions come to my mind.

VIENNA, April 16--The three Western High Commissioners heard from Foreign Minister Leopold Figl today the details of the Austrian negotiations in Moscow. The Austrians reached an agreement with the Russians on the basis for a draft of a new state treaty under which Austria would regain her autonomy.

ABOUT seventy-five years ago the wheatland belt of the Dakotas and Alberta, Canada, awoke to hear a strange tongue, an archaic Tyrolese dialect spoken by a newly arrived group of religious immigrants.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower conferred with Admiral Felix B. Stump today on the Far Eastern situation. He arranged to review the world picture generally with Secretary of State Dulles tomorrow.
BONN, Germany, April 16-- British and German schoolboys may soon be told how Europe bluadered into war through fear in 1914.
BESIDES the multiple activities of the Ballet Theatre at the Met, the week has as a special feature the debut of the new Juilliard Dance Theatre on Tuesday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 16 --A decision to undertake a major program of activity in the South appeared today to be emerging from the deliberations of the National Urban League's board convention.

DURING the past few years gardening tools have undergone a number of rather revolutionary changes. There was a time --not so long ago, either--when weight and sturdiness were emphasized as the main features. But the new tools, like the modern automobile, are being built for the comfort of the user.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16-- The Sierra Club charged today that the Upper Colorado River project was "unsound if not nearly obsolete" and that its proponents were trying to rush the legislation through Congress to prevent this discovery.

WASHINGTON as a site on the big, slow bend of the Potomac is more or less an accident. It could have been anywhere, and it very nearly was up on the Delaware River. But Washington as the Federal city was no accident. The founders had that in mind and provided for it in the Constitution --Article I, Section 8, Paragraph 17: a "seat of government" with "needful buildings."
H. Russell Burbank has been elected chairman and Morrie Chaitlen president of Rockwood Co., chocolate manufacturer.
LONDON, April 16--Although the general parliamentary election will not take place until May 26, nearly six weeks in the future, the general feeling in Britain is one of relief.
GREENSBORO, N.C., April 16--Art Wall Jr. posted a 68 today for 134 and a one-stroke lead after 36 holes of the $12,500 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.
A Queens patrolman died yesterday after an accident on a borrowed motorcycle while he was in pursuit of a fleeing car.

NEW peaks in production, stock prices, consumer income, and construction have been taken in stride by the business community. The near-term outlook is excellent, in the opinion of business executives and economists, but few care to predict how long the boom will last.
DETROIT, April 16--Four sets of negotiations on the issue of a guaranteed annual wage are now under way here, but no one is saying much about what is going on behind the closed doors.
IT is often much easier to get a "rise" from an angler through the medium of an un-baited phrase than it is from a trout or salmon.

HALLELUJAH in the title of this book is not a jubilant cry but the fictitious name of a composite town in northeast Mississippi where Louis Cochran grew up during the early Nineteen Hundreds. His reminiscences of the people and customs known in his childhood are set down in a series of briskly paced, informal essays.

THE regional novel often consists of a cast of characters so busy throwing local color and delightful idioms at the reader that they have no time to be themselves. Anton Fereva hasn't written one of those. His book creates the milieu of a California valley town tautly through the emotions of its inhabitants.

When the echoes of today's drumbeatings, trumpetings and angry words have died down, and assuming that these relatively small noises do not culminate in a loud and final bang, one process that helped save the world may be recognized.

THIS is not Just another book on Africa. David Unwin's first novel deftly conveys the many shades of the great blackwhite drama. The setting is an imaginary British protectorate and an adjoining republic. Though Bandaland and Equatoria will not be found on the map, they are no Erewhons invented by the author.
MOSCOW, April 16--The Soviet Government condemned today Western-sponsored military alliances in the Near and Middle East as a threat to its security.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16 (AP) --President Eisenhower's headquarters said today his three grandchildren and Vice President Richard M. Nixon's two daughters never have had Salk polio vaccine inoculations.

ELECTRICAL BRAIN-- "Push-button" living rats that run and stop under the control of an electric current are being used in brain research at the University of Washington, Dr. Frederick W. Maire told the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology last week in San Francisco.
Good retail business immediately before Easter cleared stocks and forced merchants to place rush orders to build inventories or post-holiday activity, resident buying offices report.

A few simple traffic regulation reforms have helped to transform the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. In addition, the completion of three major facilities during the last year have virtually eliminated congestion and snarls on the thoroughfare.

Department store sales in the United States during the week ended April 9 were 8 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year, according to the Federal Reserve Board. The increase was partly due to Easter falling a week earlier this year.

TURN we now to something apposite to the rising sap engendered by spring--a new recording of Walton's Facade, recited by Dame Edith Sitwell and Peter Pears, played by the English Opera Group ensemble conducted by Anthony Collins (London).
BOWIE, Md., April 16--Boston Doge continued unbeaten today in winning the $34,800 Governor's Gold Cup. It was his tenth straight triumph.
TRENTON, April 16--New Jersey voters will flock to the polls on Tuesday to select candidates for eleven seats in the State Senate and all sixty in the Assembly.

JERUSALEM, April 16--It is an auspicious day for the Middle East when messages from Gaza and Beersheba come into United Nations headquarters here "N. T.R."--nothing to report. It is one day along the path that can bring tranquility.

LONDON--The opening today of the new Control Building at London Airport, with its advanced and comprehensive traffic control systems, brings to the halfway mark the ten-year plan to make the field the safest and most upto-date in the world.

"WHO SAID THAT?," the panel show that was revived three months ago with John Daly as moderator, has encountered rating trouble. It probably will be replaced within the next month or so by a new quiz program offering maximum cash prizes of $10,000.
A leak in an underground water pipe caused a section of the asphalt roadway to collapse yesterday on Fifty-ninth Street between Madison and Fifth Avenues.

Moderately sized firms and some branches of larger corporations are having a difficult time finding space in new smaller buildings because the construction industry seems preoccupied With only large-scale work.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 16 --Bill Sanford, a right-hander, pitched and batted Hofstra's baseball team to a 2-0 victory over N.Y.U. today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16 --Yale's baseball team today captured its eighth victory in twelve games by trouncing Pennsylvania, 11--1, in the Eastern Intercollegiate League opener for both teams.

TO THE EDITOR: Albion Ross in "Germany-- Report on a Perplexing People" (April 3) seems to me to voice some perplexing conclusions about the Germans he is examining directly for the first time in some fifteen years.

WITH spring weather again living up to its reputation of being unpredictable, gardeners are facing the usual dilemma of "to plant or not to plant" now. This state of affairs was pointed out by Harvey Gray, instructor at the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute, Farmingdale, who said "Because of weather changes-- everyone is questioning what they can do or what they should do."
ADAM: Giselle; Anatole Fistoulari conducting the London Symphony Orchestra (Capitol). Adam's pleasant, old-fashioned ballet score is expertly conducted by Mr. Fistoulari.

"American and French Modern Masters," a benefit exhibition of sixty paintings representing the best art produced in the two countries during the 1920-40 period, will have its preview on the night of May 4 at Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 16-- Scientists reported here today that they had induced cancer in animals with cigarette tar from which all nicotine had been removed.
Public housing projects should not be undertaken in piecemeal fashion, regardless of population and employment trends, according to C. McKim Norton, planning expert.

HONORS for Edward Steichen and Wayne Miller led a list of awards presented at the recent installation of officers of the American Society of Magazine Photographers. Mr. Steichen was cited for his achievement in creating "The Family of Man" exhibition and Mr. Miller for his contribution as assistant in the project.
LANSING, Mich., April 16-- Michigan State College in East Lansing was redesignated as Michigan State University by the Legislature this week.

WALLINGFORD RIEGGER will be 70 on April 29 and has grown accustomed to swimming against the current. As a composer who has used the twelve-tone technique a great deal in the last three decades, he is well acquainted with neglect and antagonism.

NOWHERE outside the worldwide United Nations itself would it be possible to find a more varied aggregation of national leaders than that which will assemble tomorrow in Bandung, Indonesia. The delegates to the Asian-African Conference (twentyfour are shown) represent about half the world's 2.5 billion population.

CZESLAW MILOSZ is a Polish man of letters-- poet, essayist and translator-- who, without joining the Communist party, functioned in the diplomatic service of the Communistcontrolled Polish Government from 1946 to 1951, when he broke with the Warsaw regime and took refuge in France.
WASHINGTON, April 16-- Perfect relief pitching by Tom Morgan marked a 5-2 victory for the Yankees over the Washington Senators tonight at Griffith Stadium.

YALE--Poor English A Yale faculty member, Dr. Edward J. Gordon of the English department, vigorously assailed the English courses offered in most American schools. He said that they fail to teach students how to read or write.

ON July 4 Arthur Howes, director of the Organ Institute, will set off for Europe with a party of organ-fanciers. They are going on an "organ tour." It will take them to the Netherlands, Denmark, Germany, Austria and Switzerland and they will listen to organs in each country.

CHICAGO, April 16--Business conditions in the Chicago area have been showing steady improvement since the first of the year, the monthly report of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago showed. On March 31, 65 per cent of the replying members said business volume was better than the previous month.

THERE is a trend today toward injecting a baroque element into an otherwise simply decorated room. Often this ornate note is reminiscent of eighteenth-century Venice. Proof of the present popularity of Venetian styles is the simultaneous appearance in several shops of accurate reproductions to supplement costly antiques.
LONDON, April 16--Bitterness flared today between the unions that are staging the newspaper strike, now in its fourth week, and non-striking unions.

ADD a welcome new name to the small roster of crime novelists who have had professional experience as policemen: George Young. From 1944 to 1946 Mr. Young was a Deputy Superintendent in the Palestine (which is to say British) Police Force; and he recalls with clarity and authenticity the problems of those turbulent days in his first novel, THE MAN CALLED LENZ (Coward-McCann, $3).
It pays to encourage employes to relax--on their own time, of course.
Details of Sutton House, the latest development to join the rapidly growing colony of luxury apartments in the Sutton Place section of Manhattan, were announced yesterday.

LONDON. THE time is the first decade of the twentieth century, the high noon of the British Empire. The Mediterranean Fleet is anchored under the guns of the fortress of Malta. Seven-year-old Louis Battenberg, the future Earl Mountbatten, is carried aboard H.M.S. Implacable, commanded by his father.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The historic debate on the vexing problems posed by the privilege against self-incrimination of the Fifth Amendment will continue. But one chapter in our developing constitutional law was concluded last year in the enactment of an Immunity Act which the Circuit Court of Appeals has now held valid.

RUSK, Tex., April 16 (AP)-- Eighty criminally insane inmates rioted today at the Rusk State Hospital and held a superintendent and two other persons hostage at knife-point for six hours before giving up.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 16 (AP)--Daisy Astra won the $6,000 Baldwin Handicap in 2:03.4 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

"Every crime has a pattern all its own," says Dr. Paul L. Kirk, Professor of Criminalistics at the University of California. Data that he is gathering will help criminal investigators establish the patterns of many future crimes. He is now collecting information on the nature of various substances that often constitute part of the physical evidence in crimes.
BALBOA, C.Z., April 16-- Commercial ship traffic through the Panama Canal set three new monthly records during March, according to statistics released this week.

The installation of hot water and steam heating systems in new dwellings set a record in 1954, according to the Institute of Boiler and Radiator Manufacturers. A tabulation by the institute showed that home heating systems using boilers of all types were installed in 30 to 35 per cent of the new dwellings built in 1954.
"THE TALES OF HOFFMANN," restored to the repertory in this spring season of the New York City Opera Company, was performed yesterday at the City Center.

LOWU, New Territories, Hong Kong, April 11--A Chinese Communist infantryman, a burp gun at the ready, stepped aside from the tracks on the Shumchun River bridge today to let an engine bring the daily mail coach into Red China.

With Drawings by SUSAN PERL THE fact that women are superior to men--long known by women, suspected by men and shushed by both sexes for the sake of each-- has at last been accorded the imprimatur of print. In the past two years book after book, article after article-- all by men--has said that women are biologically and spiritually superior to men.

"A GRAND MAN" is the grand book to give to your cherished elderly aunt or uncle suffering from virus flu or even to take to bed yourself. It's rare, these days, to find the right uncommon story to read against the common cold.
There is a man in Wall Street who has much to say about how traders play the market, but few care to hear from him.

THE name of Konrad Z. Lorenz has been known for many years and held in high regard in scientific circles because of his studies of the behavior of birds and animals. With the publication, about three years ago, of "King Solomon's Ring" he reached a considerably larger American audience who were delighted with his charming account of the birds and animals that lived with him and his family at Altenberg, Austria.
WBSC, an independent and intramural "radio station," presented its premiere broadcast one night last week.

LOWU, New Territories, Hong Kong, April 11--A Chinese Communist infantryman, a burp gun at the ready, stepped aside from the tracks on the Shumchun River bridge today to let an engine bring the daily mail coach into Red China.

With Drawings by SUSAN PERL THE fact that women are superior to men--long known by women, suspected by men and shushed by both sexes for the sake of each-- has at last been accorded the imprimatur of print. In the past two years book after book, article after article-- all by men--has said that women are biologically and spiritually superior to men.

The installation of hot water and steam heating systems in new dwellings set a record in 1954, according to the Institute of Boiler and Radiator Manufacturers. A tabulation by the institute showed that home heating systems using boilers of all types were installed in 30 to 35 per cent of the new dwellings built in 1954.
"THE TALES OF HOFFMANN," restored to the repertory in this spring season of the New York City Opera Company, was performed yesterday at the City Center.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 16 (AP)--Daisy Astra won the $6,000 Baldwin Handicap in 2:03.4 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 16-- By next October the last of the British armed forces will have quit the Suez Canal Zone for the newly created Middle East headquarters in Cyprus.
BONN, Germany, April 16 -- The successful mission of Julius Raab, Austrian Chancellor, to Moscow has reopened the question of Germany's future orientation.
The New York Athletic Club defeated Squadron A in a national senior polo tournament match last night, 13 to 7. A crowd of several hundred witnessed the contest at the Squadron A Armory.
BOSTON, April 16 (AP)--Faye Throneberry, successor to Ted Williams in left field for Boston, drove in two runs and scored three today as the Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 6--5.

A Pravda editorial last Thursday indicated that no new era of one-man rule had begun in the Soviet Union. The principle of collective leadership enunciated immediately after Stalin's death apparently remains in force.

A Medical Milestone On May 14, 1796, an English country doctor named Edward Jenner took some germ-filled matter from the hand of a dairy-maid stricken with cowpox and inoculated it into the arm of an 8-yearold boy.

THIS week B. Jay Becker, who is one of the group of experts who teach at the Card School in New York, will prove himself as intrepid on the lecture platform as he is at the bridge table. He will begin a series of lectures on the use of mathematical knowledge in the play of the cards--what the bridge player usually calls "playing percentages."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17--Montgomery Clift has accepted Columbia's offer to star as Paul Morel in its adaptation of the D. H. Lawrence novel "Sons and Lovers."

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 17--Secretary of State Dulles reported to President Eisenhower today a greatly intensified build-up of offensive air power by the Chinese Reds opposite Formosa. Mr. Dulles said the newly discovered activities increased materially the Communists' capabilities-- if not intentions--of imminent attack. He said the build-up on the China mainland had "grave implications."
BEAUMONT, Tex., April 17 (AP)--Betty Jameson played a cautious 1-over-par 74 today to win $1,000 first money in the Babe Zaharias open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) --The National Planning Association recommended today that regulated investment companies be permitted to pass on to shareholders the tax-exempt status of income from state and municipal bonds.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Task Force that obtained detailed data for the Government surplus report of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of Government was headed by Gen. Robert E. Wood, former chairman of the board of Sears.

WASHINGTON, April 17--The telephone rang about 10:30 this morning in a suite at the Mayflower Hotel and the occupant carried on a short, fond conversation. He chuckled, and then called to his wife: "Bess, Baby wants to talk to you, from New York."

Cotton futures prices last week stayed within a relatively narrow trading range, active contracts rising as much as 13 points and losing as much as 25 points over the period. The only net losses were in the two nearer deliveries.
Judge William B. Groat asked yesterday that members of the Department of Correction and their guests thank God that Catholics, Protestants and Jews had been able to sit down together and break bread.

CHICAGO, April 17--Grain traders placed a generally bearish construction on the Government's April wheat crop forecast, while no bullish deductions were possible from the estimates of stocks of the grain on the farms on April 1.
The United States Military Academy Roman Catholic Choir of sixty voices sang the musical setting of the solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. It was Rossini's "Orbis Factor."
Two experts spoke yesterday of adequate centers for the care and rehabilitation of emotionally disturbed children as the "most pressing need in the whole child welfare field in this city."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 17--The Larchmont Yacht Club, which has not sponsored a long distance race in more than thirty -five years, tonight completed plans for an overnight cruising contest for the week-end of June 10.

NORTHPORT, L. I., April 17-- It's southward ho for Albert and Jo Vrana. The young couple will be off next week on the sort of adventure that at one time or another has beguiled almost every wishful thinker. They are casting off all ties and setting sail for the West Indies to find a new home.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) --The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (F.D.I.C.) said today that in 1954 it had had to protect the depositors of only two failed banks.

The chances of saving South Vietnam from chaos and communism are slim. Brooding civil war threatens to tear the country apart. And the Government of Ngo Dinh Diem has proven inept, inefficient and unpopular. Almost from the start the French wished to get rid of the little Premier.

VIENNA, April 17--Foreign Minister Leopold Figl confirmed today that Austria would invite representatives of the four occupation powers to come to Vienna to sign a state treaty giving the nation independence.

MADRID, April 17--Top Falange party officials were reported today to have held a series of meetings with prominent Monarchists to discuss how the totalitarian regime in Spain may continue to function after the restoration of the power of the monarchy.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 17--The National Urban League rededicated itself today to the ideal of equal opportunity for all Americans.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- Lefty Ed Lopat, who would be the first to admit it, had nothing today at Griffith Stadium as the Yankees bowed to the Washington Senators, 7-3.

BEFORE a fellow has a chance to forget any impressions, he would be wise to get around to discussing the sport of jai alai, which he saw for the first time in the fronton at Tampa, Fla., a few weeks back. Many years ago there was an abortive attempt by Uncle Mike Jacobs, the boxing impresario, to introduce this Latin pastime to New York.
DALHART, Tex., April 14 -- Dryland farmers in the Panhandle areas of Texas and Oklahoma were ahead of the wind this week in the struggle to prevent their fields from blowing away.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 17 --The Essex Troop C team of Lieut. Thomas Glaccum, Sgt. Peter Haigh and Sgt. Hilton Jarvey won the championship challenge trophy in the Junior Olympics horse show at the Thomas School of Horsemanship today.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, Monday, April 18--President Sukamo of Indonesia hailed the new force represented by the nations of Asia and Africa in a speech opening the twenty-nine-power Asian-African conference here today.

PITTSBURGH, April 17--The steel market has all the earmarks of a boom in demand with no let-up in sight. Furthermore, it seemed clear last week that the April steel output would top the almost 10,000,000-ton month of March.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 17--Another step toward restoration of Amsterdam as an international financial center took place last week. Dutch residents now can buy foreign securities--including dollar securities -- for guilders through banks or brokers.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Government letter writers were asked today to stop avoiding plain English.

BOSTON, April 17 (AP)--The Boston Red Sox moved into undisputed possession of first place in the American League today. The Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 14-5 and 12-9, in the rain and cold at Fenway Park.
Betty and Jane Kean are returning to the local stage in "Ankles Aweigh," a musical comedy opening at 8 o'clock this evening at the Hellinger.

WASHINGTON, April 17--The need for more women probationary officers to help rehabilitate youthful first offenders was cited today by a San Francisco judge as an important way to reduce juvenile delinquency.

Official word that Cowan Dengler, Inc., will be dissolved on June 1 came yesterday from the Bankers Trust Company, one of the agency's clients. This turn of events was indicated last week with an announcement that Horace W. Dengler, executive vice president, and Stuart Cowan Jr. would become vice presidents of Donahue Coe, Inc., on that date.
CHICAGO, April 17--The Bulletin of Atomic Scientists reported today that "signs are beginning to break through the long-unrelieved darkness of our loyalty-security policy."
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) --The Commerce Department said today that United States foreign aid last year declined by about one-fourth--to $4,669,000,000.

ARTHUR GODFREY has chosen an odd way to start his comeback. His decision to plow-under a few of the little Godfreys is no special surprise, but the form of his spring housecleaning would seem to suggest that he is neither the most tidy nor tactful soul in television.

DETROIT, April 17 (AP)--Al Kaline blasted three home runs, two of them in the sixth inning, to tie a major league record and lead the Detroit Tigers to a 16-0 romp over the Kansas City Athletics today.

THE NEW YORK CITY OPERA, which has been hospitable to Negro singers, choristers and dancers, opened its doors still further yesterday, the final day of its spring season. For the first time it gave a conducting opportunity to a Negro conductor.

The decision of the National Infantile Paralysis Foundation to follow Dr. Jonas Salk's advice and reduce the initial injections of antipolio vaccine to two and to give a third several months later has the great merit of making it possible to confer immunity on 13,500,000 children instead of the 9,000,000 called for in the earlier program.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- Savings of billions and progress toward ending Government deficits are possible through more efficient disposal of Federal surplus property, the Hoover commission said today.
The Reynolds Metals Company, sponsor of "Mr. Peepers" for three years, will drop the show in June.
The Coast Guard has advised operators of wooden craft disabled at sea to hoist on a halyard or to place aloft otherwise any metallic object that will assist their detection by radar.

LONDON, April 17--The Foreign Office declined to comment today on the attack made yesterday by the Soviet Foreign Ministry on the Middle East defense arrangements being made by the Western powers and other states.

Zionist leaders scored the United States Government's Middle East policy yesterday as endangering the security of Israel. They also called for a greater effort by American Zionists to combat "propaganda activities of the anti-Israel forces" in the United States.
LONDON, April 17--The stock markets are maintaining a remarkably firm appearance in face of the many distracting factors in the immediate outlook.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 17--The tide of young nationalism was at the full here tonight.
PANAMA, April 17--Roman Catholic Church leaders began an eight-day congress today designed to raise the standards of the "spiritually and materially underprivileged rural population of the world."
Mayor Wagner asserted yesterday that the time for studying the problem of juvenile delinquency "is about over" and that "the time for action is at hand."
WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Administration may find out this week how much of its reciprocal trade program can be salvaged from a generally critical Senate.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 17 (AP) --Following is the text of a statement issued by Secretary of State Dulles after a two-hour conference with President Eisenhower today: I gave the President a review of recent developments in the field of our foreign relations.
Peace descended yesterday upon two of the "warring factions" of the Wagner Administration --the Fire Department and the Traffic Department.
The supermarket, home of frozen pizzas and canned baked beans, is going into the fashion business.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) --Republicans hit back at former President Truman today for charging "political fraud" and trickery in the Eisenhower Administration's conduct of foreign affairs.

BRUSSELS, April 14--A projest to build hydroelectric plants with a total capacity of 20,000,000 kilowatts near Isangila on the lower reaches of the Congo River was officially announced here today. The sites are between Leopoldville and Matadi in the Belgian Congo.
LONDON, April 17--The British Government has told the Chinese Communists that it does not accept any responsibility for the crash of an airliner in the South China Sea last week.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development recommended today a $530,000,000, five-year development program for Syria.
Coal again set the pace in the world charter market last week as the shipping industry bettered its rates for the most part.

Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, the chess champion of the United States, was one of eighteen players who appeared yesterday for the opening of the international jubilee tournament arranged by the Argentine Chess Club in Buenos Aires.

BOMBAY, India, April 17 -- Three survivors of the Air India Constellation believed that the explosion and fire that caused the aircraft to crash "emanated from an extraneous source wholly unconnected with the structure of the aircraft," Air India International said in a statement today.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (AP)--Evidence indicating that a Soviet atom bomb blast in Siberia produced a radioactive fall-out in the United States was reported today by an American expert.

During the first month of the city's cleanliness drive the various departments concerned have stepped up commendably their inspection and enforcement work. But each has gone about the job without the close coordination and integration with all the others that is an absolute essential to success.

DALLAS, April 17 (UP)--Tony Trabert overpowered top-seeded Vic Seixas in straight sets today to win the Dallas Country Club tennis singles title. It was the fifth straight time the Ohioan has defeated his Davis Cup partner.
A four-year course in marriage and parenthood was proposed yesterday for the city's high schools by Domestic Relations Justice Nathaniel Kaplan, chairman of the City Youth Board.
PARIS, Monday, April 18--A contraction of Communist support in several large centers was reported today as a result of yesterday's French cantonal elections.

A teen-ager bent on an acting career remarked yesterday that he was glad never to have been a child actor. And another teenager on the New York Times Youth Forum expressed her disapproval of child musical prodigies.

Herbert M. (Fido) Kempton, athletic director and football coach at Mercersburg (Pa.) Academy, was encountered in the tool shop behind his home. He was working on a small chest or jewel box. He wasn't happy.
Aches Blooming in Spring Make no mistake: The spring is the most rousing time of year for aches and pains. They are at their best just then, in a morbid sense being both lush and beautiful.
AKARI is what Isamu Noguchi, Japanese-American sculptor, calls his lantern-like lamps with metal bases and pleated paper shades.

A steady demand for spot sterling featured last week's trading. Turnover was not heavy but persistent enough to lift it to $2.79 7/8, a new high since last November, and a gain of 11/32 cent over the previous week. Scarcity of spot was reflected in widening of futures, with 90 days' at $2.78-13/16. Transferable sterling closed around $2.7725 /.35.
Last Friday Joseph C. Dey Jr. was in Nashville. On Saturday he was in Philadelphia. This morning he'll be in his New York office for a few hours, and then he'll go to Harrisburg, Pa.
The election of officers and three board members was announced here yesterday by Alexander P. Chopin, acting chairman of the New York Shipping Association.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am an exchange student from Argentina. I believe I can make a contribution to the exchange student program, which essentially means "understanding," by stating my impressions about the first of four articles by Herbert Matthews appearing in The New York Times.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 17 (AP)--Sam Snead birdied the last hole today to win the $12,500 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 273. He beat Art Wall Jr. and Julius Boros by 1 stroke.

Igor Gouzenko has been chosen winner of Canada's top fiction award, The Governor General's Medal, for his novel "The Fall of a Titan," published last year by Norton. The presentation will be made at the annual dinner of the Canadian Authors' Association at Queen's University in June.
Housing formed the bulk of Bronx property reported passing to new control over the weekend.
More than 100 written statements of personal beliefs have been received by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell in response to a proposal he made on the first Sunday in Lent.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Monday, April 18 -- The Communist party removed Imre Nagy from the Premiership of Hungary and all his party posts today.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 17-- A rare Renaissance bronze relief, unrecognized for years in a collection here, was sold yesterday to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
WASHINGTON, April 17--The Subversive Activities Control Board dismissed today a Government petition that the American Slav Congress be required to register as a Communistfront organization.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- Sixteen states have raised their maximum unemployment insurance benefits so far this year.
WASHINGTON, April 17--Edward Corsi, the deposed State Department aide, charged today there was not a top official in the department who wanted to liberalize the nation's immigration laws.
If there are two things State Conservation Commissioner Louis A. Wehle cannot abide they are "Milquetoast trout" and "Fauntleroy pheasant."

Former President Harry S. Truman arose at a dinner in Washington on Saturday evening to say a few richly deserved kind words about Speaker Sam Rayburn. He went on to assert that the Federal Government had been ''badly managed" for about two years; that he hadn't "seen such cynical political behavior in any Administration since the early Twenties"; but that the newspapers threw a "cloak of protection" around these goings-on.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 17 --Two of the three parties that backed the late President Getulio D. Vargas have united behind Juscelino Kubitschek, a Vargas protege, as candidate for President in the October elections.

The business property at 56 to 62 East Fourteenth Street, between Fourth Avenue and Broadway, has been resold by Jack Brause, realty operator, to an investor who has named the Harry Leeds Management Corporation as managing agent of the three and six-story buildings.

At this hour representatives from twenty-nine Asian and African states have met in a conference at Bandung, Indonesia. They are there at the invitation of the five so-called "Colombo Powers," India, Indonesia, Burma, Pakistan and Ceylon. Their declared objective is to discuss problems of common interest and through their discussion to promote cooperative efforts toward advancement and peace.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., April 17--An imported miniature poodle, Ch. Fircot L'Ballerine of Maryland from the Seafren Kennels, Devon, Pa., won best-in-show honors at the Fredericksburg K. C. event today. Heywood Hartley judged the final.
WASHINGTON, April 17--The State Department this week-end studied diplomatic dispatches from Moscow and Vienna for a possible joker in the agreement on an Austrian state treaty draft.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 17--An English-bred white and brown wire-haired foxterrier, Ch. Travella Superman of Harham, took best-in-show honors at the eighth Twin Brooks Kennel Club event today. The fixture was held in the Orange Armory.

BENIAMINO GIGLI sang again in this country last night after an absence of sixteen years. From the behavior of the audience you would have thought that no mere mortal had returned, but a tenor combining the best features of Tamagno, DeReszke and Caruso.
PITTSBURGH, April 17--The Dodgers flattened the Pirates twice before a shirt-sleeved crowd of 20,499 at Forbes Field today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 14--Charges that Interhandel Industrie und Handelsbeteiligungen, A. G., was a Swiss cover for German interests were described today not only as untrue hut also as damaging to Switzerland.

The New York Central Railroad Company's proxy statement for the annual meeting of stockholders shows that Robert R. Young has altered his position on proxy contest outlays and methods of voting for directors.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- Bills carrying the most controversial part of the year's $1,750,000,000 increases in Government pay were scheduled for progress in Congress this week.

A former Austrian doctor has won an appeal that, in effect, orders his admission to the Medical Society of the County of New York. Two emotion-filled membership meetings had excluded him in disputes over his denials of past membership in the Nazi party.
THE greatest fishing whangeroo in human history, one not likely to be challenged for some time, closed in Macy's pet department on the store's fourth floor last Friday night.
ROME, April 17--Four French Jesuit missionaries and fifty-two Chinese priests and laymen who lost their lives in the Boxer Rebellion of 1900 were beatified today in St. Peter's Basilica.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Atomic Energy Commission's careful attempt last week to convince the public there really is not any undue danger from atomic bomb tests nearly got blanketed out of the headlines.
SINGAPORE, April 17--Dr. Lin Yutang departed from this British colony today declaring that the Chinese schools here lived in an "atmosphere of intimidation and terror" fostered by Communist China.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two adjacent articles in The Times of April 13 point up the fact that when the Secretary of State of the United States is cornered he has a peculiar reaction. I of course refer to his remarks on the dismissal of Edward Corsi and the Formosa speech of Adlai E. Stevenson.
The Girl Scouts are hunting for more than natural history specimens these days. They are out to recruit 300,000 women to serve as troop leaders.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, Monday, April 18--Eight Arab states early today reached unanimous agreement on Middle Eastern problems at the Asian-African conference. However, they were still divided between the neutralist and pro-Western camps on other issues.
Millions of Americans now destined to die of cancer could be saved if present resources were more fully utilized, the American Cancer Society declared in its annual report yesterday.
The first intimations of the twenty-first century are disturbing the quiet old Hudson city of Yonkers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article by Paul Crowell which appeared in The New York Times of April 14 on the city budget hearing highlights some of the shoals that still lie ahead before modern management for New York City's government can become a reality.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $68,566,036,278. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
Minnesota conducted its annual "hunting season" in this area last week.

Three shops, revisited recently by this department, can be recommended to anyone with a sharp curiosity about foreign foods. One establishment specializes in German and Hungarian delicacies, another in the exoticisms of the Near East and the third offers Spanish and South American foods.

RESOLUTE BAY, Northwest Territories, Canada, April 16-- The Royal Canadian Air Force completed today a record airlift to the five joint United States-Canadian outposts on the Queen Elizabeth II Island. Flying around the clock in the continuous daylight of these latitudes, three C-119's (Flying Boxcars) completed eighty trips in eleven days.

Once again the New York community has an opportunity to assist the Joint Defense Appeal, fund-raising arm of the American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, among the nation's oldest and largest community relations organizations.
Several of the nation's biggest motor fleet operators are saving money by using the New YorkBuffalo Thruway rather than parallel free highways, the State Thruway Authority said yesterday.

CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP)-- Ted Kluszewski delivered a runscoring single with two out in the ninth inning today to give the Cincinnati Redlegs their first, victory of the 1955 National League season. It was a 6-5 triumph over the Milwaukee Braves in the second game of a doubleheader.
The heads of thirty city departments and agencies have been asked by the City Planning Commission to keep within "realistic" limits their request for capital budget funds in 1956.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, April 17 (AP)--The United States men's table tennis team remained in the running for the Swaythling Cup when it posted its third and fourth straight victories in the world championships today.

IT was a busy week-end at the Metropolitan Opera House, where the Ballet Theatre gave us a great deal of very fine dancing by both its regular company and its guest artists, together with the restoration of an old work or two to the repertory.

OXFORD, England, April 17-- Britain's bipartisan foreign policy will be abused ands strained in the coming election campaign and Americans can expect to read some highly critical comments about the United States role in international affairs.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 17-- South Vietnam issued an appeal today to hold back the calendar for persons who want to leave the Communist-ruled northern part of the country.
ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP)-- Larry Jackson, 23-year-old righthander, broke into the major leagues with a four-hit pitching job today.
NORFOLK, Va., April 17--A campaign is being planned for the deepening of inland channels between Norfolk and Jacksonville, Fla.
Wall Street is a lot of fun to Gerald M. Loeb. The reader of "The Battle for Investment Survival,"* now in a new edition, gets a feeling of participating in an absorbing game.

PARIS, April 17--Opening the international fair at Lyon, Andre Morice, Minister of Commerce and Industry, declared today that the Government intended to develop the reconversion program introduced by ex-Premier Pierre Mendes-France.
The Giants dropped both ends of a frostbitten marathon double -header at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Mayor Wagner urged again yesterday that some Federal control of distribution of the Salk anti-poliomyelitis vaccine be instituted.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP)--Bob Lemon of the Cleveland Indians and Jack Harshman of the Chicago White Sox tossed a pair of five-hitters today as the two teams split a doubleheader. The Sox took the opener, 3-1, and Cleveland the afterpiece, 4-2.

Yesterday was the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray's thirty-second anniversary as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (The Little Church Around the Corner), Twenty-ninth Street east of Fifth Avenue.
George Meany slammed the door yesterday on moves to take the exiled International Longshoremen's Association back into the American Federation of Labor.

The Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity of the city said yesterday that he frequently woke up horrified after a nightmare in which 5,000 miles of water mains sprouted geysers all over the five boroughs.
CAMP IRWIN, Calif., April 17 --Task Force Razor will leave this Armored Combat Training Center tomorrow for a rendezvous with an atomic explosion.
Charles S. Colby, chairman of the Citizens Committee for Improving the Yonkers Public Schools, asserted yesterday that "political reasons are behind impoverishment of the Yonkers school system."

The Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity of the city said yesterday that he frequently woke up horrified after a nightmare in which 5,000 miles of water mains sprouted geysers all over the five boroughs.

Governor Harriman has been asked by the Citizens Union to veto a bill that would compel the city to reimburse Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons for $20,000 in salary cuts taken without protest during the depression years of 1934-37.

THE CONCERT ARTISTS GUILD, founded in 1951, inaugurated yesterday afternoon in Town Hall what it is hoped will be an annual concert. The guild presented two young artists--Evelyn Lear, soprano, and Stanley Babin, pianist--in their New York debuts.
Stocks rose yesterday for the ninth successive day, and the gain was the largest of the nine.

CHICAGO, April 18--The increasing gravity of the Chinese situation, as outlined by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, started free buying of grains and soybeans today, with much short covering in evidence. May soybeans led the upward move as shorts covered freely, while decreasing stocks at Chicago increased the concern of the short sellers.

Normal operations are scheduled to be resumed this morning at the Grace Line's North River terminal Piers 57 and 58 at West Sixteenth Street--after a six-day work stoppage, but the reason is not clear.

LAUREL, Md., April 18 (AP)-- Wille Hartack hogged the winner's circle in the first five races at Laurel's opening today and then missed by only a neck in the Capitol Handicap, won by S. D. Gottlieb's First Served.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- Senator Clinton P. Anderson Urged the Administration-backed Upper Colorado River storage project today as "probably the most important single piece of legislation" in the history of Federal reclamation.
ALBANY, April 18--Governor Harriman approved today a housing program he predicted would "achieve great good for a great number of people."

A family of five, including a baby four-days old and a child of eleven months, were overcome in a tiny two-room Brooklyn apartment yesterday by lack of oxygen. All were revived after an hour's work by a Police Department emergency squad and were reported in fair condition.

KANSAS CITY, April 18 (AP) --Larry Doby's three-run homer with two out in the ninth inning tonight gave the Cleveland Indians an 11-9 victory over the Kansas City Athletics. The Athletics lost despite a fourteen-hit attack that included five home runs.

Brunswick-Balke-Collander Brunswick - Balke - Collender Company has decided to defer any dividend action until later in the year, R. F. Bensinger, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday. The company has paid no cash dividends on common stock since March 15, 1954.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)-- Sale of the Waterman Steamship Company, one of the country's largest water cargo carriers, met today a temporary restraining order.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- William Henry Taylor, accused of Communist party activities, has asked for a full public hearing after eight years of "suspicion, unfavorable publicity and harassment."
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Two bills aimed at preventing a black market in the Salk polio vaccine were introduced today in the House of Representatives.

TRENTON, April 18--New Jersey voters will go to the polls tomorrow to nominate candidates for the November election. At stake are eleven seats in the State Senate, all sixty in the Assembly and numerous county and local offices.
HONG KONG, April 18--A Hong Kong Government trade report disclosed today that licenses were issued here last month for the importation of 1,885 tons of galvanized iron wire from Communist China.
YESTERDAY (April 18, 1955) ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Narcotic Drugs--Opened session and elected officers. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

The snag that has been holding up the Government-sponsored tanker construction program may be removed in Washington Thursday at an open hearing arranged by Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- State and Defense Department officials reported in a closed Senate committee session today on the plight of 500 American prisoners held by Communist China.
PASADENA, Calif., April 18-- Smog is becoming a nation-wide and international problem. Its exact causes are still mysterious. But "electric brain" computing machines may help fathom the mystery.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Former President Truman suggested today that the United States take to the United Nations General Assembly "the current threats to world peace."

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) --The Federal Trade Commission charged today that two international labor unions and three trade associations had entered into illegal agreements aimed at outright control of a $40,000,000 industry.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 18-- President Eisenhower wants Dr. Jonas E. Salk to be the first recipient of the Congressional Medal for Distinguished Civilian Achievement.

Adlai E. Stevenson left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday for a combination business and sightseeing trip to Africa. He was accompanied by William McCormick Blair Jr., an associate of many years' standing.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, Tuesday, April 19--The Asian-African conference entered its second day with controversies and ruffled tempers threatening to disrupt and delay its progress.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- The House Rules Committee decided today on a second showdown on the floor for a bill to raise postal workers' pay.

BALTIMORE, April 18--Firstrate modern air defense might require the construction of flying saucers. Indeed, the design of three-dimensional saucers to be called "flying spheres" was contemplated here today.

DESPITE far from satisfactory conditions on most of the popular trout waters of Connecticut, New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania, the results were fair on most of these streams over the opening week-end.
PANAMA, April 18--The social doctrines of the Roman Catholic Church were carried to the "grass roots" in dramatic fashion here today.
Broadcasting and motion picture theatre leaders have accepted invitations to debate the question of subscription television.

William Horne, who has not given a recital for some years, returned to Town Hall Sunday night with a program that consisted of only two works--Handel's "In Praise of Harmony" and Schubert's enure song cycle, "Die Schoene Muellerin."

The progressive consolidation of France, already evident in an improving economic situation, is further demonstrated by the results of Sunday's cantonal elections, which are analogous to elections to our State Legislatures. The results must be completed in run-off elections next Sunday, and are in any case affected by purely local issues and parties.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18-- The unbeaten Dodgers tonight rallied to defeat the Phils, 5--2, at refurbished Mack Stadium.
TRENTON, April 18--Failure to receive an expected shipment of Salk polio vaccine forced temporary postponement today of a program to innoculate nearly 300,000 New Jersey school children.
Chinese Communist offensive air power is in the midst of an extensive build-up on the mainland opposite Formosa, Secretary of State Dulles announced over the week-end.
BOSTON, April 18--The Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O., drew up a set of demands tonight on twenty-three New England cotton and rayon mills that have been on strike since Friday midnight.

Two housing developments in Westmont, a suburb of Camden, N. J., have been bought by a New York syndicate represented by Roy Berlin, attorney. Known as Haddon Hills Apartments North and South, the properties contain thirty-eight garden-type buildings with 432 apartments.
Examples of human and financial magic worked by rehabilitation services were presented at an all-day conference at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, President Eisenhower's special representative in South Vietnam, has been recalled for consultation.

When the atom bomb exploded with a blinding flash over Japan it did more than bring the greatest war in history to a triumphant end. It flashed to the minds of men the most spectacular proof of the Einstein Theory of Relativity, which provided the key to the vast treasure house of energy within the atom.
LAMAR, Colo., April 15--For the second straight year the southeastern corner of Colorado has taken a vicious beating from the wind.
At the next Republican state convention New York City's reppresentation will be sharply reduced. Instead of 40.2 per cent of the total delegates the city group will have only 31.7 per cent.

Reports that the Chinese Communists were building up offensive power opposite Formosa firmed almost all commodities yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, cocoa, sugar, hides, rubber, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc, lead and copper were stronger.
YESTERDAY April 18, 1955 THE PRESIDENT At Augusta, Ga. His advisory committee on transportation policy made public its recommendations. THE SENATE
The stock market has again entered a period of dangerous speculative activity, Senator J. William Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, warned last night.
VIENNA, April 18 -- Andras Hegedus, former Minister of Agriculture and Deputy Premier of Hungary, was elected Premier at a special session of the Parliament at Budapest today.

The President is expected to send a special message to Congress soon recommending that it approve the membership of the United States in the International Finance Corporation, proposed affiliate of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

BALTIMORE, April 18--The Baltimore Orioles dropped their sixth straight game tonight, a 6-0 decision to Whitey Ford and the Yankees. That was not so remarkable. But the fact that 35,372 fans turned out on a cold night to see it happen was rather unusual.
PARIS, April 18--The Communists lost ground in the cantonal elections yesterday, according to official returns reported to the Cabinet today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 18--Egypt informed the United Nations today that military authorities "very soon" would place barbed wire emplacements along the Egyptian-Israeli border to prevent frontier incidents.
HOUSTON, April 18 (UP)-- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Vic Seixas of Philadelphia scored easy opening victories today in the twenty-first annual River Oaks invitation tennis tournament.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was impossible in the heat of the recent debate on rent control to assess all its intricacies with dispassion.
