TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES By spotlighting the part our surplus can play in curbing communism in the Far East ("Rice Weapon," April 9), The New York Times once again demonstrated outstanding grasp of our international problems.

IMAGINES that nothing interesting has developed in the field of musical comedy for the last ten or fifteen years. There you have "Ankles Aweigh," which opened at the Mark Hellinger last evening. It leaves off where modern musical comedy began, before the cold war started chilling the world.
A stepped-up program to teach road safety to high school students was opened yesterday by the Board of Education.
Drug manufacturers refused yesterday to guarantee New York City enough vaccine for proposed free inoculation of all 5-to-9-year-old children against poliomyelitis before schools close this June.

Marianne Moore, whose poetry has won every major American prize, has a volume of prose on Viking's list for May 12 publication. Called "Predilections," the book contains the "best" of Miss Moore's essays written over a period of thirty years.
World leaders, in expressing sorrow at the death of Dr. Albert Einstein, paid tribute yesterday to his greatness as a man as well as to his scientific achievements.
MILWAUKEE, April 18 (AP) --Eddie Mathews produced a double when most needed today --in the eighth--to drive in two runs and push the Milwaukee Braves to a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

Invoking the Fifth Amendment is characterized in an article in The Fordham Law Review, published yesterday, as an indication of guilt. The author, C. Dickerman Williams, is a director of the American Civil Liberties Union.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18--Warner Brothers has filed claim to the title "The Triumph of Dr. Jonas Salk" with the motion picture industry Title Registration Bureau.
TOKYO, April 18--The Japanese Government has promised the United States that Japan's defense outlay will be increased progressively year by year.
LINCOLN, R. I., April 18 (AP) --Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Social Outcast today won the $58,300 Lincoln Downs Special by a length and a half before a closing-day crowd of 31,340.
A patrolman's wife was seriously wonded Sunday night while struggling with her husband for possession of his service revolver. She had threatened to kill herself, the police reported.
THE Brooklyn Society of Artists is making its yearly invasion of Manhattan, its thirty-ninth annual exhibition being held in the Mosaic Room of the New Yorker Hotel.
The spring of 1954 will be marked down by historians of the future as the Great Divide in the life of Yonkers.
Just when things were beginning to look more than a mite forlorn for the Giants, a kindly schedule came to their rescue. It brought the Pirates to the Polo Grounds yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Joe Adonis, gambler and racketeer, lost an appeal to the Supreme Court today from his conviction for false swearing as to his birthplace.

The City was urged yesterday to bar "company unions" in the civil service. The advice was given by an American Federation of Labor representative at the second of a series of eight City Hall hearings on a proposed labor relations code for municipal employes.

TOKYO, April 18 -- Hundreds of rebellious prisoners have beer machine - gunned to death by Soviet guards in Siberian slavelabor camps during large-scale uprisings over the last two years, according to Japanese repatriates.

DETROIT, April 18--The Ford Motor Company appears to be making a bid for a bigger share of the nation's auto business. The company announced today that the LincolnMercury division would be split in two and that a new special products division would be formed.

A long shot and a favorite registered victories in the Correction Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The $25,000 added race, presented for the sixteenth time, attracted so many fillies and mares that it had to be run in two divisions.
Eight new-style pedestrian control signals with "a punch" will be put in operation today at Seventh Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street.
If they hadn't been painted chalk white, there'd have been some red faces yesterday morning on the clowns of the greatest show on earth.

Of many anecdotes told of Einstein there is his own explanation of relativity. His secretary, much annoyed by interviewers who wanted her to tell them what relativity really meant, asked the professor for a readymade explanation.

A letter that appears to be a preliminary to a proxy fight is being sent to shareholders of the American Investment Company of Illinois. A. I. C., a specialized finance company, is incorporated in Delaware and has its main offices in Missouri.

Great-grandmother painstakingly stitched "God Bless Our Happy Home" on her samplers. Today's needlewomen or men are still picturing the happy home, but now it's likely to have a swimming pool alongside.

City agencies, searching for the sources of dirt, took a peek under the municipal rug yesterday. What they found was eighteen tons of assorted debris in lots, courtyards, cellars, and back yards and on roofs and fire escapes in two blocks in congested East Harlem.

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service moved yesterday to avert a threatened strike of 270 scow captains, whose boats transport sand, gravel, traprock and other building material in the metropolitan area.
The nation's largest producer of chemicals, E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., earned $2 a common share in the first quarter this year, compared with $1.56 a share in the 1954 first quarter.
The domestic steel industry has scheduled production this week at 95.5 per cent of rated capacity--the highest rate so far this year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) --Following is the prepared testimony given by former President Truman today before a Senate subcommittee on revision of the United Nations Charter: Senator George, members of the committee, Senators: It is a pleasure and a privilege for me to testify before you today.
JERUSALEM, April 18--Israel and Jordan established today an arrangement designed to prevent firing and other hostile acts in the Jerusalem area and to halt any armed clashes.

WASHINFTON, April 18--A $750,000,000 to $1,000,000,000 program to expand training facilities for a military Ready Reserve of 2,900,000 men was approved unanimously by the House of Representatives' Armed Services Committee today.
The Lake-Dwelling Bait-Caster The lake at 4:30 A. M. is a fisherman's solitary Eden, overgrown with reeds five feet tall and with lily pads like a pattern of embedded flying saucers.
One hundred and thirty-eight one-year fellowships were awarded yesterday to college and university faculty members by the Fund for the Advancement of Education of the Ford Foundation.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Nathan Witt told the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today that he had arranged the financing for Harvey Matusow's book, "False Witness."
Lawyers clashed yesterday over whether courts should or could limit legal fees in accident cases.
LONDON, April 18--The stock market began weakly today on the threat of a railway strike, but rallied and closed fairly firm. The turnover was small as investors awaited tomorrow's budget.

Two hundred and five vacant parcels containing 576 lots on Staten Island were sold at auction yesterday by the city for $315,825. It was the first part of a four-day sale involving 968 vacant and improved properties on the island.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) --Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, today applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to assume the presidency of the Boston Maine Railroad.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) --Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that he believed the Administration had no set policy on using atomic weapons in local wars.

An investment banking syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $50,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Philadelphia Electric Company at a price to yield 3.12 per cent.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 11,000 head; market slow and uneven, 25 to 50c lower on butchers; around 25c lower on choice No. 1 and 2 grades under 220 pounds; sows, 25 to 50c lower;

A measure that could appropriately be called the Hull-Eisenhower bill to extend the Reciprocal Trade Act will start on its way out from the Senate Finance Committee today. This bill, representing the views of the present Republican Chief Executive, is based on the philosophy that a Democratic Secretary of State, Cordell Hull, first persuaded Congress to accept as the foundation-stone of American international trade policy twenty-one years ago.

According to one of the world's highest authorities on space there probably will be no way to travel to Mars or Mercury for several centuries. It was Sir Harold Spencer Jones, British Astronomer Royal and director of the Greenwich Observatory, who threw cold water on interplanetary jaunts yesterday when he arrived in New York aboard the Cunard liner Britannic.
Milo Savage of Salt Lake City, scoring repeatedly with overhand fights, won a unanimous decision from Bobby Boyd of Chicago in ten-round fight at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)-- The State Department strongly opposed today a move by Senator Matthew M. Neely, Democrat of West Virginia, to restrict petroleum imports. It said such restrictions would be "contrary to the national interest."

WASHINGTON, April 18--If James F. Byrnes, Robert F. Kennon and Allan Shivers, or any of them, come accredited as delegates to the Democratic National Convention of 1956 their credentials will instantly be challenged and a strong effort made to deny them their seats.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, urged Congress today to establish a standard work week of thirty-five hours and a minimum wage of $1.25 an flour. He also proposed bringing millions of more workers under the law.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 18 (AP)--Hot Tip, a 7-year-old bay owned by William Lehner of Woodbury, N. J., and driven by Wade Cotter, won the featured Levittown Pace in 2:06,3 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Hot Tip returned $46 for $2.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody is offering a new issue of $2,500,000 of callable school revenue bonds of the Hollidaysburg Community High School Authority, Blair County, Pa.

Prices of cotton futures lost 6 to 20 points (30c to $1 a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The close was virtually at the lows of the day. The decline was largely influenced by weakness in the May option.
The Board of Higher Education late last night created the position of chancellor of the municipal college system.
BOSTON, April 18--Lloyd J. Kiernan of Washington, D. C., was elected executive vice president of the Boston and Maine Railroad today.
Dr. Albert Einstein was respected above all others by scientists the world over as the outstanding intellect in modern timers.
Federal income tax directors here reported yesterday receipt of $3,194,639,000 over the weekend. That was only part of the money expected in settlement for the 1954 tax year.

Albert Einstein was born at Ulm, Wuerttemberg, Germany, on March 14, 1879. His boyhood was spent in Munich, where his father, who owned electro-technical works, had settled. The family migrated to Italy in 1894, and Albert was sent to a cantonal school at Aarau in Switzerland.

IT was in June of the fateful summer of 1209 that Gaston, Baron of Belleperche, held a tournament in honor of his approaching marriage, his third. Several distinguished knights, barons and men of ancient lineage attended. But poor young knights were present, too, ambitious young men with little or no land hoping to win honor and to pass the time pleasantly at Gaston's expense.

THE program presented last night at Carnegie Recital Hall was played "by the numbers." It was offered by the joint League of Composers and by the United States section of the International Society for Contemporary Music.
"All In One," a program composed of a musical satire, a solo dance and a short play, will open at the Playhouse tonight at 8 o'clock under the auspices of Charles Bowden and Richard Barr.

The maneuvering of the International Longshoremen's Association to join the Teamsters Union and gain readmission to the American Federation of Labor is an example of a redemption-by-merger movement now going on among American unions.
LONDON, April 18 -- Union leaders patched up their differences sufficiently today to agree on a new approach to the publishers of London's strike-bound newspapers.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 18 (AP)--Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo of Indonesia told delegates to the Asian-African conference today he had received a letter from fourteen Americans who "wished the conference well."

BUENOS AIRES, April 18-- A stock offering of 164,934,000 pesos made by Industrias Kaiser Argentina was oversubscribed by 40 per cent, officials of Kaiser's subsidiary here reported today. At the official rate of exchange the offering amounted to approximately $11,780,000.
Two five-story buildings containing a total of twenty apartments at 160 and 162 West Sixtysixth Street have been purchased by Commonwealth Investors, Inc.
Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., achieved the highest first-quarter sales and earnings in the 106-year history of that drug and chemical producing firm.
Newspapers are gobbling up newsprint at a record rate. Meanwhile, producers are turning out the material at an equal pace.

John R. Newell, president of the Bath Iron Works Corporation, denied yesterday the rumors of a possible merger with the General Dynamics Corporation. He declared that there was "absolutely no connection" between the two.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 18--The opening day's meeting of the Asian-African conference was marked by bright splashes of colorful Oriental and African native dress and the hot temper of Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) --The Civil Aeronautics Board said today the probable cause of an Air France emergency landing in a field at Preston City, Conn., last Aug. 3. was "inadequate in-flight planning."

In 1904, Albert Einstein, then in obscure young man of 25, could be seen daily in the late afternoon wheeling a baby carriage on the streets of Bern, Switzerland, halting now and then, unmindful of the traffic around him, to scribble down some mathematical symbols in a notebook that shared the carriage with his infant son, also named Albert.
The Government's case in a $17,400,000 income-tax evasion trial suffered a severe blow yesterday as the result of a court decision.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) --Former President Truman said today he would not have survived the Presidency without a sense of humor.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 18 --Dr. Albert Einstein, one of the great thinkers of the ages, died in his sleep here early today.

THE Cards beat the Braves last Thursday, five homers to two. There were other tallies, but the shots into the seats were the eye-catchers. A couple of days later the Braves outscrambled the Redlegs in a game which offered eight homers--plus four doubles, a triple and fourteen puny singles.

Man stands on this diminutive earth, gazes at the myriad stars and upon billowing oceans and tossing trees--and wonders. What does it all mean? How did it come about? The most thoughtful wonderer who appeared among us in three centuries has passed on in the person of Albert Einstein.
The suburbs should be all the brighter this spring for the new life that is being infused into a wine shop in Stamford, Conn., at 197 Bedford Street.

Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation and subsidiaries yesterday reported gains in operating revenues and net income for three and twelve months ended March 31. Sales of electricity for the March quarter increased to 4,100,000,000 kilowatt - hours from the 3,900,000,000 reported in the like 1954 period.

Non-Communist South Vietnam has issued an appeal to the United Nations to extend the date by which refugees may come from the Communistcontrolled north. Under the terms of the Geneva agreements this movement was to cease by May 16 of this year.
ST. LOUIS, April 18 (UP)-- Gus Bell led the Cincinnati Redlegs to a 7-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight. Bell drove in three runs with a single and a double.

If employment conditions continue their present trend, the summer job picture for teenagers should be brighter this year than last. Caroline Green, a vocational placement consultant for the New York State Department of Labor's Employment Service, made this prediction in an interview yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, April 18 (UP)-- Gus Bell led the Cincinnati Redlegs to a 7-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight. Bell drove in three runs with a single and a double.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 18-- Rebel machine-gunners opened fire today on soldiers of South Vietnam's national army. French and United States officers were working in an attempt to prevent Saigon's shaky truce from collapsing.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- President Eisenhower's Advisory Committee on Transportation urged today fewer Government controls in the transportation industry.
The suburbs should be all the brighter this spring for the new life that is being infused into a wine shop in Stamford, Conn., at 197 Bedford Street.

Sales of electricity for the March quarter increased to 4,100,000,000 kilowatt - hours from the 3,900,000,000 reported in the like 1954 period.

Non-Communist South Vietnam has issued an appeal to the United Nations to extend the date by which refugees may come from the Communistcontrolled north. Under the terms of the Geneva agreements this movement was to cease by May 16 of this year.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) --A resolution calling for "immediate abandonment" of President Eisenhower's atoms-forpeace project today was laid before the sixty-fourth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' statement to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today on the recent publication of the Yalta documents:

THIS is the way the story began: "Forty thousand people journeyed to the plains of Hempstead yesterday to see for the first time the newest and the biggest thing in the world of racing--Belmont Park, the successor and heir of beautiful Morris Park, known and loved by every man and woman to whom sport is anything more than a name or a fine horse more than a beast that draws a Tenderloin hansom."
The brain of Dr. Albert Einstein will be dissected and studied at Princeton Hospital.
THE salmon season is now open in twelve Atlantic Coast counties of Nova Scotia, and satisfactory fishing conditions have been reported on several rivers.

The Bandung conference of twenty-nine Asian and African countries, attended by some of the major participants for the purpose of indicting the West for its alleged "colonialism, racism and imperialism," has started with a dramatic turnabout which dispels any notion that Asia and Africa speak with one voice, or that any one leader dares presume to speak for them.

Cocoa prices tumbled the 1cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Volume was 240 contracts and there were forty-one unsatisfied offerings at the close. Trading was influenced by lower London prices and renewed offerings by the British Marketing Board.
PARIS, April 19--The French in negotiations with the United States here and in Washington are pressing for a decision on the future of Ngo Dinh Diem, the South Vietnamese Premier.

The need of having a single, professionally trained, educational officer to coordinate administration of the four municipal colleges in New York is a long-felt want. Creation of the office of chancellor has been suggested many times through the years in various studies.
PHILADELPHIA, April 19-- Don Zimmer's first major league home run and first hit of the season helped keep the Dodgers' winning streak alive at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.
An engine manufacturer is working on a new device to cut jet-plane noise to that of propeller aircraft.
Passenger and freight business is making a better showing this year than in 1954 on the route from the Mediterranean to the United States, Joseph A. Thomas declared yesterday.
A new competitive disadvantage for the American shipowner is seen in a recent Supreme Court decision. It makes the owner liable for shipboard assault by one seaman on another.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, Wednesday, April 20--Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China, said yesterday his country desired friendly coexistence with all nations of the world.

"Guys and Dolls," in its first Broadway revival, will be ushered into the City Center at 8 o'clock this evening. It represents one of three fortnightly revivals, all to be put on by William Hammerstein, general director of the civic emporium's Light Opera unit.
The American Export liner Constitution arrived here yesterday morning, picking up the harbor pilot, a passenger and a problem at the same time.
ALBANY, April 19--Governor Harriman disapproved today a bill that would have barred members of the Communist party from serving on juries.

Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Health Commissioner, suggested late yesterday that a proposal for rigid city controls on poliomyelitis vaccine be deferred until after a White House conference Friday. The capital session is expected to bring out data on national supplies.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 19--Indonesia has taken elaborate precautions to protect her guests at the Asian-African conference here from unparliamentary action by their domestic political enemies.

TAIPEI, Formosa, April 19-- The Chinese Nationalist Air Force announced here tonight that reconnaissance over the mainland during the past few days had disclosed the presence of a number of two-engined jet light bombers based in the vicinity of the Shanghai-HangchowNingpo complex.
ANKARA, April 19--The Government authorized business men today to import gold and a wide range of goods without obtaining foreign exchange allocation from the Central Bank.
THE music of India is as remote from our experience as another era and civilization might be, and at the same time it has something of the free, improvisatory quality of the best in jazz.
ALBANY, April 19--Governor Harriman revealed tonight that almost one out of ten automobiles in a state survey had been found to carry no liability insurance.
WASHINGTON, April 19-- Eighteen Senators joined today in sponsoring an Administration bill to establish a Medal for Distinguished Civilian Achievement, as proposed by President Eisenhower.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 19 (AP)--Ima's Watson, a 4-year-old black horse, won the one-mile Floral Park Pace in 2:04 3/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway by a length from Buffalo Street. The favored Jug Chief was third.
Cotton futures declined 7 to 24 points (35 cents to $1.20 a bale) on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Business was slightly more active than it has been recently.

Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov has made an indirect appeal to President Eisenhower for peaceful coexistence with the Soviet Union. His suggestions were contained in a message the Soviet Defense Minister sent to the annual awards dinner of the Overseas Press Club in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

Baseball managers sometimes welcome postponements. On other occasions, deferring a game puts a pilot in a dilemma. The latter was the case with Leo Durocher yesterday when the Giants' scheduled contest with the Pittsburgh Pirates at the Polo Grounds was called off.

With speed that bears evidence of political maneuvering the Senate has suddenly taken up the Administration's billion-dollar Upper Colorado Basin storage and power project containing authorization for the bitterly controversial Echo Park Dam.

The thirteen-story apartment house for forty families at 420 West End Avenue has been sold by the Guaranty Trust Company, as trustee, to the Investors Funding Corporation of New York. The corner plot, 77 by 100 feet, is at West Eightieth Street.

BEFORE the television opening of "the Damon Runyon Theatre," there reportedly was quite a party at Toots Shor's. Holding an opening night party before the premiere would seem something of an innovation but in this instance it was an altogether felicitous move.
A shipyard in Portland, Ore. apparently was the low bidder yesterday for the job of transforming two ships into fast trans-Pacific liners for the Oceanic Steamship Company.

EVERY now and then advance rumors sweep through the world of booksellers, critics and publishers that a "big book" is coming. A "big book" is not necessarily a good one. Frequently it is a bad one. But somehow long before the general public has heard of it the tinkle of cash registers begins to sound and the compilers of best-seller charts begin to sharpen their pencils.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 19--The second half of South Africa's Parliamentary session has opened here with a defense of his Government by Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 19-- President Eisenhower completed work today on the $3,530,000,000 foreign aid message he will send to Congress tomorrow. He did some redesigning on it intended to lose no friends of the United States at the Asian-African conference at Bandung.
Members of the legal profession continued to express opposing views yesterday on a proposal to limit legal fees in accident cases.

Broadly it is the case that where communism has advanced westward into Europe it brought with it a reduced standard of living. But where it has moved southward or eastward into Asia the opposite is true. While there are exceptions to this proposition, it can be argued the essential logic is correct.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 19--Ceylon is reported to be planning to propose that Communist China renounce all rights to Formosa.
TOKYO, April 19--The Soviet Union is understood to have proposed peace treaty negotiations with Japan in a third country other than the United States.
AMMAN, Jordan, April 19-- King Hussein of Jordan took as his Queen today Sherifa (Princess) Dina Abdel Hamid elAoun, his distant cousin.
WASHINGTON, April 19-- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, set today a fivemonths floor of $4.75 a hundredweight to farmers for Class I fluid milk in the New York milkshed.

THE sixteenth annual exhibition put on by the National Serigraph Society at its gallery, 38 West Fifty-seventh Street, is truly an international and perhaps the most colorful event the organization has yet tried.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP)--L. L. Colbert, president of Chrysler Corporation, told stockholders at the company's annual meeting today more than a million orders had been received for Chrysler's 1955 model cars.
MARRAKESH, French Morocco, April 18--The Pasha of Marrakesh warned today that he was determined to frustrate any move to oust the Sultan of Morocco.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 19--Camera Vision, a photographic system that combines a television camera and a standard motion picture camera, was demostrated today at the Republic Pictures Studio.

MOSCOW, April 19--The Soviet Union called today for a Big Four Conference to conclude a state treaty with Austria. A meeting of the foreign ministers in Vienna in the "nearest future" was proposed.

THE city's grating anglers are a rather odd group. They're more than a little careless in their dress; they shuffle rather than walk because they make so many stops in their grate-scanning, and they're inclined, almost unanimously, to be somewhat on the misanthropic side.
A $225,000,000 Federal - city housing program to provide 14,915 apartments for low and middle-income families was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
Yesterday in the British House of Commons Richard A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, opened his fourth budget since he assumed that post under the Conservative Government.
LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., April 19--Ninety-three hundred workers on electronic equipment for the armed forces struck here today in the face of a Government plea to stay on the job.

WASHINGTON, April 19-- Senator Walter F. George of Georgia took a calm view today of "the extensive build-up" of Chinese Communist military forces. On Sunday Secretary of State Dulles had reported such a mainland concentration.
Former President Truman on Saturday night criticized the Republican party and accused much of the nation's press of throwing a "cloak of protection" around the Eisenhower Administration.
WASHINGTON, April 19-- Opponents of the Washington Square Southeast Slum Clearance Project asked Congress today to intervene to block the $25,000,000 plan.
The supermarket does not sell a great many case lots of various items each week, as many persons suppose. It depends instead, on carrying thousands of items and selling small quantities.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) --House investigators decided today to ask Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas to testify on his recent statement that 58,000 wiretaps were ordered in New York City alone in 1952.

The Lester Manor Stable's Affrighted won the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. Showing gradual improvement, the 4year-old gelding scored by threequarters of a length over Scotsmans Bond of the Calumet Stable in the mile and a sixteenth event.

WASHINGTON, April 19--The constitutionality of the Government's procedures in loyalty cases was challenged and defended in the Supreme Court today. Lawyers for Dr. John Punnett Peters, Senior Professor of Medicine at Yale University, asserted that secret information could not be used "to pin the badge of infamy on an American citizen."
SECURITY COUNCIL Council refused Israel's demand that it condemn Egypt for recent border violations, but appealed to both to cooperate in curbing frontier incidents.
Michael J. Quill charged yesterday that a city employe was using his position in the Manhattan Borough President's office to recruit transit workers for an American Federation of Labor union.
The visit of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony to Athens during its forthcoming European tour has been made possible by a contribution from Basil Peter Goulandris, a GreekAmerican philanthropist.
A scroll reaffirming the Bill of Rights, now being circulated by student organizations, at Columbia University, has become the center of a campus controversy.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) --A spokesman for the radio and television industries today opposed giving national political candidates free radio and television time to air their campaign speeches.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold expressed opposition today to consideration now of the Formosa Strait issue by the United Nations.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, gave the first New York performance of Randall Thompson's orchestral fantasy, "Trip to Nahant," at its final concert of the season in this city,last night in Carnegie Hall.

Plans have been advanced at recent meetings at the St. Regis for the annual Spring Festival of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church. The fete will be held April 28 and 29 in the Parish House of the church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street. Proceeds will be donated to the New York Episcopal City Missions Society.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 19 --Governors of thirteen states affected by railroad and telephone strikes demanded today that the strikers return to work immediately.

With the aid of a number of large corporations and trade associations, the brokerage house of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane is sponsoring a "How to Invest Show" from May 24 to 30. It is to be held in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

The new Juilliard Dance Theatre, with Doris Humphrey as its director, made its debut last night at the Juilliard Concert Hall, and a very charming debut it was. This is a group of young modern dancers, selected competitively last fall by Miss Humphrey, and organized with the aid of a grant from the B. de Rothschild Foundation with a hope for permanence.
THE ballet, the bullfight arena and the circus tent are the sources of Daniel Rasmussen's black-and-white drawings at Maynard Walker's, 117 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 19 -- The Westchester County Center, which was built a quarter of a century ago to house the then flourishing Westchester Music Festival, celebrated tonight its twenty-fifth anniversary. Fittingly enough, the anniversary celebration took the form of a music festival.
H. Struve Hensel, Assistant Secretary of Defense, declared last night that President Eisenhower's proposal for authority to negotiate tariff reductions was "in serious danger in the Senate."
HARTFORD, April 19--Legislative hearings opened here today on the water supply dispute between Greenwich and villages in Westchester.

Dr. Conyers Read, Professor Emeritus of English History at the University of Pennsylvania, has received the $1,000 Folger Library Prize for 1955. The award was made for his manuscript, "Mr. Secretary Cecil and Queen Elizabeth," which Knopf will publish on June 13.

Herbert Lieblein has sold the four-story store and apartment building at the northwest corner of Franklin Avenue and Bowne Street, Flushing. Queens, to Eduardo Skornicki. On a plot 100 by 109 feet, the property contains seven stores and thirtythree apartments.

SAINT CLAUDE, France, April 13--In the Department of the Jura a committee has been formed to plan for what in France has come to be called "reconversion." This means the readaptation of old industries to new conditions and, in extreme cases, the substitution of new industries for old ones.

LONDON, April 19--Prime Minister Eden assured the House of Commons today that the Government was doing everything in its power to speed preparations for talks with the Soviet Union on the future of Austria and Germany.

Front of the Place Rakes and wheelbarrows are in heavy use these days, and shovels, mattocks and old bushel baskets. The time for cleaning the yard has passed, and in its stead has come the time for permanent improvements.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, April 19--Gov. Sir Edward Twining today opened this British -mandate territory's new Legislative Council in which those of British, African and Asian origin have parity representation.

The United States Rubber Company set a new record in first-quarter earnings this year. A net exceeding $9,500,000, equal to $1.55 a common share, was reported by H. E. Humphreys Jr., chairman, at the annual meeting here yesterday.
The brain of Dr. Albert Einstein, to be studied with the most up-to-date methods, may shed light on one of nature's greatest mysteries--the secret of genius.

LONDON, April 19--London's newspaper strike was ended tonight. Employes of the struck national dailies are to return to work tomorrow, and the newspapers will reappear Thursday morning after an absence of almost four weeks.
State Senator Mark Anton, Republican of Essex County, was renominated yesterday in a key contest in the New Jersey primary election.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 19--The Security Council declined Israel's demand today that it condemn Egypt for recent frontier incidents. Instead, it made another appeal through its president to both to push ahead with a program to avoid future border clashes.
BALTIMORE, April 19 -- A Biblical verse tonight was brought into the engineering formulae being discussed here at the meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

LONDON, April 19--Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler announced sweeping tax concessions today. These will remove 2,400,000 persons from the tax rolls, cut basic rates and increase personal and child allowances.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The United States welcomed today the Soviet call for an early meeting of the Big Four foreign ministers on the restoration of Austria's independence.

After nine successive days of gains, stocks ran into selling at the opening yesterday. But prices soon steadied and then moved little for the rest of the session. The market showed a negligible loss at the close.

A loan of $1,100,000 was placed by Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., broker, on the twenty-story office building at 40 East Forty-ninth Street. Longchamps Restaurants and Hattie Carnegie, Inc., dresses, are major tenants there.

Throughout its existence the New York Community Trust has been an admirable means of protecting money bequeathed to charity. The founder of any fund left with the Community Trust dedicates it, permissively, to a particular philanthropic purpose and, necessarily, to a broader charitable use.
CHICAGO, April 19--Bulges registered in grains yesterday failed to hold today, and there was a reactionary tendency during much of the session in all pits.

CHICAGO, April 19--The principals in the battle for control of Montgomery Ward Co. issued contradictory estimates of the situation today. Edmund Krider, president, said: "We have an unchallenged majority now. Mr. Wolfson may have two directors." Louis E. Wolfson, the challenger, replied: "This thing is so close we can't tell whether we have control or they have control.
YESTERDAY (April 19, 1955) THE PRESIDENT At Augusta, Ga. THE SENATE Debated the Colorado River storage project. Recessed at 6:07 P. M.

PARIS, April 19--Leading art critics of the French press expressed enthusiasm today at the preview of the exhibition of nearly 100 masterpieces of French nineteenth century art. The works have been lent by American public and private collections as part of the "Salute to France" program.

WITH THE ARMORED TASK FORCE RAZOR, DEAD MAN'S PASS, Calif., April 19--This task force heading for the first atomic bomb test of an armored force plowed today through the desert and mountains into bivouacs in the Black Mountains.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., April 9--The General Electric Company's stock option plan for executives was challenged here today at the sixty-eighth annual meeting.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a specialist in the study and reporting of contemporary Turkish affairs I am both worried and frightened by the growing emphasis placed by American policymakers and administrators on the military development of Turkey to the near exclusion of her economic and social development.

Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, urged the Eisenhower Administration last night to Adopt a bolder, firmer policy against communism. She called for a change from what she said had been a negative, pessimistic, defensive foreign policy based on fear of Russia, to one of positive initiative based on a direct approach and confidence in ourselves and friendly nations.

San Diego County, Calif., borrowed $8,400,000 yesterday to finance construction of a courthouse and jail. An issue of serial bonds maturing from 1956 to 1975 was sold to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Phelps, Fenn Co. at an interest cost of 2.21 per cent.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., April 19 --Behind the strong pitching of Bill Nickel, a junior right-hander, the Hofstra College baseball team defeated Columbia, 5--0, on Hofstra Field today.

Mayor Wagner looked for the city's silver lining yesterday and lad no trouble finding it.

An offering of 100,000 shares of new $2.40 cumulative preferred stock of the General Telephone Company of Michigan is being made today. The underwriting group is headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis and the Stone Webster Securities Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) --A silver-haired grandmother told Senators today she had posted $10,000 bail for Harvey Matusow, the turnabout witness. She said she had done so because she was worried over what was happening to freedom in the United States.

A new variety show, produced by a company partly owned by Paramount Pictures, is tentatively scheduled to start June 12 over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 19 (UP) --Only the upset of Sweden's Ulf Schmidt marred the general parade of favorites through the third round of singles play in the River Oaks Country Club tennis tournament today.
Hunter College will establish a coeducational graduate School of Social Work to help meet the critical need for trained personnel in the field.

The City of New York sold 212 more tax-delinquent realty parcels on Staten Island yesterday for $410,700. This brought the total at the end of two days to 417 parcels and $726,525. The entire sale, involving a total of 968 vacant and improved properties, will continue today and tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 19--Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C. I. O., asked Congress today for a minimum wage of $1.25 an hour to curb "unfair competition."

WASHINGTON, April 19-- The Senate Finance Committee voted 8 to 7 today to reject a Republican move to limit the President's reciprocal trade bill to two years instead of three.

New Yorkers can learn something of what is cooking abroad by visiting the International Food Show, now at the Kingsbridge Armory. The exhibition of imported delicacies and some American products, first of its kind to be attempted here, opened yesterday and will continue through Sunday.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., April 19--Among those who feel the pang of having lost a personal friend in Dr. Albert Einstein's death are the thirty-five boys and girls of the fifth grade in the Main Street School here.
Arthur B. Bisguier, United States champion, was held to a draw yesterday in the second round of the Argentine Chess Club's jubilee tournament, according to a news report from Buenos Aires.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) --Eugene W. Castle today renewed his charge that films made by the United States Information Agency for distribution overseas were "a waste of money." He is the author of a book critical of the agency.
PASADENA, Calif., April 19 --Scientists still have no evidence that ordinary urban smog is injurious to healthy people. But it nevertheless is under suspicion as a possible factor in lung cancer.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, April 20--Headquarters of the South Vietnamese Army came under rebel attack yesterday about eight hours before a truce expired at midnight.

Sales of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation for the first three months of this year were 19 per cent above those of the year-ago quarter and at $263,041,109 represented a first-quarter record for the corporation.

BOSTON, April 19 (UP)--Hideo Hamamura, a 26-year-old Japanese civil servant, won the fifty-ninth annual Boston Athletic Association marathon today. He covered the gruelling twenty-six-mile 385-yard course in a record 2 hours 18 minutes 22 seconds.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, April 20--Headquarters of the South Vietnamese Army came under rebel attack yesterday about eight hours before a truce expired at midnight.

LONDON, April 19--Although details of the budget proposals were not disclosed during official business hours, the stock markets generally were good today in anticipation of the Chancellor's statement.
The Kingdom of Norway is raising money again in the United States capital market, for the first time since 1947.

New signal controls for both pedestrian and vehicle traffic went into operation yesterday at Seventh Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street, one of the world's busiest intersections. The installations were the first in a program to provide separate guides at thirty-seven congested crossings.
The state moved yesterday to dissolve a Brooklyn household equipment corporation accused of swindling housewives out of $500,000.

ST. LOUIS, April 19 (AP)-- The St. Louis Cardinals today gave up on Vie Raschi, a star pitcher with the New York Yankees for many years. The Cards announced they were asking for waivers for the purpose of giving Raschi his unconditional release.
Everybody but the three pinochle players was excited yesterday when Mayor Wagner visited the Henry Street Settlement.
