New signal controls for both pedestrian and vehicle traffic went into operation yesterday at Seventh Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street, one of the world's busiest intersections. The installations were the first in a program to provide separate guides at thirty-seven congested crossings.
The state moved yesterday to dissolve a Brooklyn household equipment corporation accused of swindling housewives out of $500,000.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 8.500 head; market fairly active, strong to mostly 25c higher on butchers: sows steady to 25c higher: most choice 190 to 250 pounds butchers $17 to

ST. LOUIS, April 19 (AP)-- The St. Louis Cardinals today gave up on Vie Raschi, a star pitcher with the New York Yankees for many years. The Cards announced they were asking for waivers for the purpose of giving Raschi his unconditional release.
Everybody but the three pinochle players was excited yesterday when Mayor Wagner visited the Henry Street Settlement.

Strange Metropolitan Paradox News that private companies are seeking permission to operate several metropolitan cityrun bus lines serves to remind New Yorkers of a paradox in the progress of their surface transportation system:
An endless parade of "petty Munichs" purchased the moral bankruptcy of the New York waterfront, Samuel M. Lane declared last night.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) --Willard Nixon out-pitched Chuck Stobbs tonight, yielding only five hits in leading the Boston Red Sox to a 1-to-0 victory over the Washington Senators.
WASHINGTON, April 20-- Disclaiming rancor, Edward Corsi today attacked Scott McLeod as a "security gang" leader who had turned the nation's refugee program into "a national scandal."
A New England Irishman who hardly ever swims spent a nervous afternoon yesterday because he was to receive swimming honors at night.
THE excitement of opening day was over. Therefore it was possible to find angling solitude on some stretches of several northern New Jersey trout streams yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) --Senators William F. Knowland and Hubert H. Humphrey said today they would urge the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to make public all of Secretary of State Dulles' latest testimony on the Yalta papers.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 1,321,000 barrels last week, it was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies totaled 181,864,000 barrels, compared with 183,185,000 a week earlier and 178,923,000 a year ago.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 20 --Communist China bid strongly today for the goodwill of the Arabs by supporting their claims in the Palestine dispute. This was the first concrete issue considered by the twenty-nine-nation Asian-African conference.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- There is general agreement in Washington that the Soviet change of tactics over Austria is one of the most important diplomatic moves of the post-war period. There is no agreement, however, about what motivated the change.

A stockholders' suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court on Foley Square to enjoin Louis Wolfson, financier and industrialist, from using funds from two corporations he controls in his proxy fight to gain, control of Montgomery Ward.

The decision of the Subversive Activities Control Board that an organization cited by the Attorney General as a Communist front had actually gone out of existence and therefore was not subject to the sanctions of the Internal Security Act raises some interesting points.
preview of a winsome show paintings by children from thirty-three of the city's private schools was held yesterday in parish house of St. James testant Episcopal Church.
The nation's National Guardsmen, air and ground, rushed to their posts last night in the first coast-to-coast test of their combat readiness.
More free air time was set aside yesterday for the question of toll TV.

LONDON, April 20 -- The months-old dispute between the American controlled ArabianAmerican Oil Company and the Saudi Arabian Government will submitted to international arration in Geneva on June 15, was announced here today.
There are signs that "the worst crisis in American, internal freedom in our generation is passing," John B. Oakes of The New York Times editorial board told city teachers yesterday.

A struggle for control of Federal patronage coming to New York is raging within the Republican party. The principal point at issue is the amount of influence former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey should exercise.
PASADENA, Calif., April 20 --Air pollution has become a problem of such national proportions as to call for a Federal coordinating body, a chemical industry spokesman said today.
Additional facts were made public yesterday on a revolutionary development that promises to become standard equipment on most airplanes.

ADVENTURES IN BROTHERHOOD, by James E. Pitt (Farrar, Straus, $3.50). An account of the National Conference of Christians and Jews and its work. All ABOUT THE PERENNIAL GARDEN, by Montague Free (Doubleday, $5.95).

The aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange at the close of business on April 15 was 2,929,587 shares. This was almost exactly the same as average daily turnover in March, the Exchange reported yesterday.

FIRST thing you know lit'ry critics will be turning up in ten-gallon hats. They may even give up their limousines in favor of mustangs for riding through the canyons of Manhattan's windowed mountain ranges. They'll talk passably about the passes through the Rockies and invite you to smile when you say anything, stranger.

Anti-poliomyelitis inoculations scheduled to start for 725,000 children here and in upstate New York were ordered temporarily postponed yesterday. Indications, however, were that this part of the program still had ample time to be fulfilled.

ROME, April 20--Pope Pius XII opened today an exhibition of Fra Angelico's paintings. The paintings will be shown in the Vatican until this summer to commemorate the 500th aniversary of the artist's death.

CHICAGO, April 20--The agenda for Friday's showdown meeting of Montgomery Ward Co. stockholders was announced yesterday. It promptly touched off a new battle of words between the rival groups contesting for control of the company.
Stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday authorized the largest private financing operation ever recorded, the issuance of up to $650,000,000 in convertible debentures.
New York University scored its second Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference victory of the campaign yesterday. The Violets defeated Manhattan College, 9-4, at Ohio Field in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, April 20--A bipartisan bloc of Western Senators gained Senate approval today of the $1,500,000,000 upper Colorado River storage project. The vote was 58 to 23.
"BALLPLAYERS are lucky stiffs," remarks the guy in the bleachers, his voice laced with envy. "They make all that big dough while they still are young."

Broadcham Equities, Inc., headed by David Rappoport, obtained a first mortgage loan of $1,300,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for ten years through Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc. on the old Sun Building at 280 Broadway. The loan replaces a mortrgage of $900,000 which the owners obtained in 1951 when they bought the property through the Noyes company.
BONN, Germany, April 20-- The United States instruments of ratification of the Paris agreements were deposited today in Bonn.

NEWARK, April 20--Competitive transportation on bus lines and highways has forced the New York. Central Railroad to seek abandonment of passenger service on its West Shore Division, a company official testified today.
DALHART, Tex., April 20 (AP) --Rich topsoil swept aloft by one of Colorado's worst dust storms cast a hazy curtain over parts of the Southwest today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) --With President Eisenbower's approval, the Civil Aeronautics Board acted today to improve air service between New York and South America by: Authorizing a northward extension of Braniff Airways' Latin-American route, from Havana to Miami, to make possible an exchange of equipment with Eastern Air Lines over Eastern's Miami-New York route.
One hundred and fifty-five vacant realty parcels in the South Beach and Dongan Hills sections of Staten Island were sold at auction yesterday by the city for $155,175.
THE PRESIDENT Returned from his Augusta, Ga., holiday. Earlier he had sent $3,530,000,000 foreign aid request to Congress.
The first comprehensive attempt to find out how many New Yorkers are mentally ill will be started this year.

Everett Clay, secretary of Hialeah Park and press agent for the Florida Thoroughbred Breeders Association, should have been at Jamaica yesterday. He would have sent champagne to the press box and a bucketful of lump sugar to the winner enclosure.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- The House of Representatives voted, 324 to 85, today to give 500,000 postal workers a pay rise aggregating $172,000,000 a year. This was done in the face of a threat that President Eisenhower would veto an increase higher than $160,000,000.
The atomic power industry that is estimated for 1965 will produce radioactive waste products equal to the radiations given off by 3,000 tons of radium.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- Winners of awards for outstanding" work in journalism, radio, television and journalistic research in 1954 were announced today by Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalistic fraternity.
MOSCOW, April 20 (AP)--The Soviet Union called on its people and the people of Communist China and Eastern Europe today to increase their economic and defense capacities and unite more closely.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) --Harvey Matusow wound up his latest stint on the witness stand today by admitting new lies and liaisons in the past--but loudly asserting he was nowhere near as big a liar as Roy M. Conn.
LYONS, France, April 19--The Governments of Red China and the United States are participating for the first time in the annual international fair in this industrial center.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) --The Defense Department asked Congress today for authority to spend $2,354,352,300 on construction projects.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 20-- The South Vietnamese Government of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem is facing its deepest crisis since it took office ten months ago.

The General Services Administration in Washington has written a pamphlet, "Plain Letters," to help Government workers get the gobbledygook out of their communications. "Needless words," the agency says, "pile up needless costs, and foggy meanings exact their tolls from the tax bin."
A Cabinet Advisory Committee on transportation policy, headed by Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, has just filed its report with the President.

With a sudden display of haste the Soviets have now called for a Big Four Foreign Ministers conference in Vienna "in the nearest future" to conclude a treaty for the restoration of an independent Austria. After ten years of Soviet delay this haste, whatever its motives, is a welcome change.
WASHINGTON, April 20--A committee of newspaper editors expressed concern today about restrictions on the flow of unclassified Government information on security ground.

An upper East Side industrial property has passed to new control. A syndicate of investors bought the former Consolidated Edison Company plant occupying the blockfront on the east side of First Avenue from 110th Street to 11th Street.
LAST night saw the first of three scheduled performances of "Giselle" by Alicia Markova with the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House.
A king-size mobile crane capable of lifting disabled aircraft off runways was demonstrated yesterday at the Naval Air Station at Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn.

Sales of W. R. Grace Co. last year exceeded the $400,000,000 mark for the first time in its 100-year history. Earnings rose 17.5 per cent over 1953, according to the annual report issued for publication today.

The soundness of New York City's future in many respects, social and economic, depends on the clean-up of slums and the satisfactory supply of decent housing. Hence we welcome the $225,000,000 housing plans, combining federal and city aid, approved by the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, April 20--Democrats here were deeply stirred by the forecast of Stephen A. Mitchell that there will be an ouster movement in the national convention of 1956 if delegates of 1952 who bolted the party ticket that year appear with credentials from their state organizations.

GRANT JOHANNESEN gave his first Town Hall recital in two years last evening before a sold-out house. The talented young American pianist achieved some moments of strong playing, though it must be said that he had achieved a higher standard in previous appearances.
The majority of the Joint Chiefs of Staff believes that atomic weapons should be used if Quemoy and Matsu are to be defended.
People still are saving money and buying houses at a great rate.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation announced yesterday that its earnings for the fiscal year ended Jan. 29 declined to $4,847,753, or $3.06 a common share, from $5,097,410 or $3.10 a share in the preceding twelvemonth period.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 --Samuel Goldwyn gained possession today of the old United Artists studio.

Revenues of American Airlines, Inc., rose 14 per cent in the first quarter of this year compared with the same months last year the company reported yesterday. Net income increased to $2,483,168 from $746,292.
TOKYO, April 20 (Reuters)-- The British Embassy here issued today a blistering denunciation of Communist China's international behavior.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have before me an editorial from your paper of March 29 entitled "More Crop Support Billions." I notice you condemn the agricultural program of crop supports and are now criticizing a bill that would scrap the flexible price program and replace them by the old rigid high support provisions.

Paramount's VistaVision process of filming and projecting motion pictures for big-screen presentation is an improvement on the company's system, first introduced with the showing last October of "White Christmas" at the Radio City Music Hall.

"Inherit the Wind," the new play by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee based on the events "leading up to and including" the John Scopes evolution case in Dayton, Tenn., opens tonight at 8 o'clock in the National Theatre.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) --The Daughters of the American Revolution today shouted approval of a resolution demanding that United Nations "interference" in United States affairs "cease immediately and completely."

WASHINGTON, April 20-- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 13:
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 1 to 14 points lower than on Tuesday. The volume of business was moderate.
The first real step toward convincing hard-headed bankers that the proposed $93,000,000 Throgs Neck bridge would be financially sound will be completed today.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The right of the Board of Education of Yonkers, N. Y., to deny the use of a public school building for a forum on peace was argued in the Supreme Court today.

Travelers in the Negev, Israel's southern desert, have noticed for some time curious decorative markings on rocks along their routes. Until recently the engravings --pictures and inscriptions-- were generally believed to be the work of modern Bedouins, and so some of them were.
The Reynolds Metals Company may split its stock, declare a stock dividend or increase dividends by July or sooner, if financing negotiations now under way are succesful.
A bit of baseball history was made at Ebbets Field last night The Dodgers won their ninth straight game by beating the Phillies, 3-2, before 9,942 Flatbush fans.
BOSTON, April 20--A Justice of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court said no today to a proposal to file the names of 200 Massachusetts subversives in a pigeonhole.
WASHINGTON, April 20-- President Eisenhower's foreign aid message today reflected plans for expanding the United States technical cooperation program.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
Consolidated Textile Company, Inc., of New York now owns a majority of the stock of the Bates Manufacturing Company, Lewiston, Me.
Eric Sevareid, television commentator, warned yesterday that specialized education would turn out highly trained Americans "more and more ignorant of our history and principles of civil rights."
HONG KONG, April 20--The Hong Kong Government reported today that it was satisfied that the plane that crashed April 11 with Chinese Communist delegates aboard had not been tampered with here.

American women, on the average, buy more than four dresses a year. Some never buy a suit and many do not replace their coats each year. Square on their pretty backs rests a gigantic industry, ranking in size below only steel and food.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) --Orlando Zulueta, a left-handed sharpshooter, outboxed the lightweight champion, Jimmy Carter, in a nationally televised en-round bout tonight, earning split decision and a shot at Carter's title.

The centennial of the Young Women's Christian Association was celebrated yesterday in the flower gardens at Rockefeller Center. The background for the noontime ceremonies was a triangle planting of blue hydrangeas and white daisies, simulating the insignia of the organization.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Bandung conference of Asian and African nations should help us to see ourselves as others see us, a facility we shall have to sharpen in our struggle with communism for the loyalty and cooperation of uncommitted millions in whose choice lies the future world balance of numbers and power.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 20 What had been planned as a small memorial service by friends of Dr. Albert Einstein this university town outgrew is original bounds today.

PITTSBURGH, April 20--How tonight's Giant-Pirate game would have resulted will never be known. But one would have had difficulty convincing a crowd of some 6,000 local diehard fans this would not have been the victory-starved Bucs' big night.
As the weather grows warmer most menu-planners tend to think of fruit desserts -- they have that freshness so appetizing in spring.
With the approach of summer, when windows in homes and apartments will be open, the police here will make extra efforts to suppress any unnecessary noises.

CHICAGO, April 20--Wheat futures showed a generally firm tone here today. But while the news from the Southwest was bullish, dust storms being prevalent over large areas, it was difficult to enlist important buying support on the upturns.

THOSE beloved rogues, nogoodniks and innocent, home-loving chorines of Damon Runyon's romanticized Broadway are back in town. They arrived last night at the City Center in a grand revival of "Guys and Dolls" and the Fifty-fifth Street citadel of culture should be a happier place for it.
LONDON, April 20--Herbert Morrison today proclaimed the broad economic principles of nationalization and planned control on which the Labor party will fight the general election.

CHICAGO, April 20 (UP)-- Bobby Thomson today led the Milwaukee Braves to a 9-5 victory, their third straight over the Chicago Cubs. Thomson drove in five runs with a grandslam homer and a single with the bases filled.

Store space in the Green Acres Shopping Center under construction on Sunrise Highway in Valley Stream, L. I., has been leased by the J. J. Newberry Company, a chain of variety and junior department stores. The announcement was made jointly by J. E. Nelson, president of the Newberry company, and Irwin S. Chanin, head of the Chanin Organization, sponsor of the project.

Lower first-quarter earnings for Chance Vought and Douglas Aircraft unsettled aircraft issues on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Steels, communications and a wide assortment of specialties, however, pushed ahead and the averages made new highs.
WASHINGTON, April 20-- The United States Government is looking to Gen. J. Lawton Collins for a cue on what should be done to break the impasse in South Vietnam.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, in its report yesterday covering the quarter ended Feb. 28, showed a net profit of $7,110,794 on sales of $214,824,106. This compared with $8,899,596 realized on sales of $240,867,145 a year before.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 20-- Vanity's Son and Homestretch Sandy teamed tonight for the top daily double pay-off of $324 for $2 this season at Roosevelt Raceway.
LONDON, April 20 (AP)--The Russians today planned a giant program of rural sports meetings in an effort to comb their vast countryside for potential record-breakers.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 20-- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to authorize $3,530,000,000 for military and economic foreign aid in the fiscal year that ends June 30, 1956.
LONDON, April 20--The stock markets greeted the budget will a modest rise in prices at the opening today but the advance was not fully maintained and prices closed irregular.
Russia has invited Columbia University to send two representatives to the 200th anniversary celebration of Moscow University, May 7-15.

A new issue of $24,000,000 of common stock of the Pacific Lighting Corporation, a Southern California public utility holding company, will be placed on the market today by a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc. The offering consists of 600,000 shares, priced at $40 a share.

CINCINNATI, April 20 (AP)-- The St. Louis Cardinals' Luis Arroyo set down the Cincinnati Redlegs, 3-0, with five hits tonight in his first start as a major league pitcher. But he needed the help of right-handed Herb Moford when he became shaky in the eighth inning.

HOUSTON, April 20 (AP)--Tom Brown and Armando Vieira were forced to three sets today before entering the quarterfinals in the twenty-first annual River Oaks tennis tournament. All favorites won their fourthround matches.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) --Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, said today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's report on his income tax status did not call for a Senate apology because Mr. McCarthy "has not been purged of contempt."
Mayor Wagner was 45 years old yesterday.

Junior-size women who do not want to look long and lean this summer should visit Best's Young Cosmopolitan Shop. Hayette fashions have just arrived on the premises, and there is not a sheath dress in sight. The full skirt has flounced away with the honors.
The youth market holds the key to long-range planning of advertising and marketing, a group of advertising executives was told yesterday by officials of Scholastic Magazines.

Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia, winner of the recent tournament in Mar del Plata, took the undisputed lead yesterday in the Argentine Chess Club's jubilee tournament in Buenos Aires. He did so by defeating Carlos E. Guimard, Argentina, in the third round, according to Argentine news sources.

Many good seats are still available for next Wednesday's preview performance of "The Honeys," which will benefit The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind. Mrs. Donald S. Stralem, chairman of the benefit committee, announced yesterday that tickets may be obtained at The Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.
LONDON, Thursday, April 21--Londoners had newspapers again today for the first time in twenty-six days.

Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, has purchased the taxpayer building at 893 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. The property, near Church Avenue, is occupied by Nedick's. It has an assessed valuation of $110,000 and was sold for cash above a first mortgage of $65,000. E. M. Hollister was the broker and E. Louis Gothelf was attorney for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, April 20--The textile industry made today the first major breach in the Administration's stand against "protectionist" amendments to the Reciprocal Trade Bill, H. R. 1. The breach resulted from an amendment of fered by Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia.
Sales of the Acme Steel Company this year will approximate $100,000.000, Carl J. Sharp, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday. In 1954 the company had sales of about $72,500,000.
EAST LANSING, Mich., April 20--The middle-aged woman was portrayed here this week as a person with great but often unrealized potentialities.

That big deal the Orioles worked with the Yankees last November looked just dandy from the Baltimore point of view yesterday. Hal Smith and Willle Miranda, who had figured in the eighteen-player transaction, played key roles in a 6-3 triumph over the Bombers at the Stadium that gave the Orioles their first victory of the American League season.

VIENNA, April 20--The Neue Zeitung, Chancellor Julius Raab's newspaper, revealed today the kind of guarantee of Austrian neutrality his Government envisaged in a state treaty. A Government spokesman said that while an article in the paper could not be regarded as official, it could be considered correct.
If you ask Major Kristen Kristensen what lies ahead for Yonkers he will give you a lecture about the city's hard times back in 1932.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 20--Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies announced tonight that the Cabinet had agreed that Australia must be ready in the event of war to contribute substantial defense forces to Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) --Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today on foreign aid: TO THE CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES: I recommend that the Congress authorize, for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1956, the program for mutual security outlined in this message.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 20--Westchester County will mobilize civil defense forces to prevent an evacuation of New York City in the event of an enemy attack, regardless of Federal recommendations to the contrary.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A strike tomorrow morning of 750 scow captains in this port may be averted. A long meeting yesterday of the employers' group was said to have resulted in a new formula that will be presented this morning at a joint meeting with representatives of Local 335, United Marine Division. A. F. L.

Louisville, Ky., borrowed $7,500,000 in the public market yesterday on serial bonds to finance outlays for street improvement and incinerator purposes. The bonds will come due on Jan. 1 from 1956 to 1995.
BALTIMORE, April 20-- Twenty-two Aerobee-Hi research rockets have been purchased for firing at Fort Churchill, Canada, during the international geophyisical year 1957-1958.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Thursday, April 21--News of the imminent visit of Admiral Radford and Mr. Robertson to Formosa caused some apprehension in Chinese Nationalist circles today over the reason behind the sudden trip.
WASHINGTON, April 20-- President Eisenhower rushed his chief military adviser and the State Department's senior Far Eastern specialist to Formosa today for talks with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.
Twenty-four attorneys and their clients were ordered yesterday to return $100,000 to the trustees in the reorganization of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation.

ALBANY, April 20--Governor Harriman gave the state's parents today the power to take away their children's junior drivers' licenses. The Governor approved without comment a bill requiring the State Motor Vehicle Commissioner to revoke a junior license if one of its holder's parents withdraw his or her consent.
The curtain shall not rise again on burlesque in New York, License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey ruled yesterday.

Many dinner parties were given at the annual Russian Easter Ball last night in the ballroom of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Tolstoy Foundation. Mrs. Albert C. Wedemeyer was chairman of the committee for the fete.
WASHINGTON, April 20-- The Government endorsed today the proposed establishment ii New York of a permanent international merchandising mart.
The Government's second- largest industrial monopoly will start breaking up today -- the synthetic rubber monopoly, exceeded in magnitude only by the atomic energy program.

LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., April 20--Seventy-five automobiles driven by nonstrikers were damaged this morning in picket -line violence at a strikebound defense plant here. One elderly foreman died of a heart attack after pushing his way through a brawling crowd outside the huge Sperry Gyroscope plant.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 20--Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China, dined tonight with several anti-Communist statesmen. They included Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines, Prince Wan Waithayakon of Thailand, Crown Prince Faisal, Premier of Saudi Arabia, and Dr. Djalal Abdoh of Iran.

Employers now engaged in negotiations with unions demanding the so-called "guaranteed annual wage" are setting an example for collective bargaining that deserves special commendation. Not only are the United Automobile Workers and the United Electrical Workers dealing with General Motors, but also Ford and American Motors are involved, and coming up are the Glass Workers demands on Libbey-Owens-Ford and Pittsburgh Glass.

Commodity futures closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, coffee, wool, hides, zinc and copper eased; sugar, rubber, burlap, cottonseed oil and lead were mixed, and potatoes, silk and soybean oil rose.
Slum-clearance action by the Board of Estimate yesterday paved the way for Fordham University to carry out its plans for a university center north of Columbus Circle.
CHICAGO, April 21 -- Sewell Avery, never noted for his fondness for Government intervention, today threw the Clayton Anti-Trust Act at his self-nominated successor, Louis E. Wolfson.
Action will be taken soon on the establishment of a European customs union or a free-exchange zone, it was predicted here yesterday by Jean Van Houtte, Senator and former Prime Minister of Belgium.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The Daughters of the American Revolution unanimously approved today a resolution urging "the immediate abandonment" of President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace plan.
BALTIMORE, April 21 -- Recent automobiles are no safer than those built between 1940 and 1949, it was declared here today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Among the recommendations made to the Democratic National Committee by the advisory committee on the 1956 convention rules was an important one affecting the official ballots in the states. Its origin was the displacement of the Democratic national ticket in 1948 from positions under the traditional party emblems on the November ballots in Alabama and Louisiana.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs pledged its support to President Eisenhower today in his fight for the reciprocal trade program.

More and more employers are threatening to move out of New York, Dr. Isador Lubin said yesterday. On the other hand, more and more employers who have moved away are wishing they had not, the State Industrial Commissioner declared.

FROM 1899, when he was 30 years old, until his death in 1946 Booth Tarkington was one of the most prolific, popular and professionally competent writers in America. The literary gentleman from Indiana wrote forty-one volumes of fiction, short stories and novels, ten magazine serials and many other stories that were never published in book form, more than a dozen plays, radio scripts, several motion pictures and a scattering of magazine articles.

PARIS, Friday, April 22 -- Premier Edgar Faure of France and representatives of Tunisia signed a protocol early today outlining the terms on which France will give her North African protectorate internal autonomy.

Paper work is not confined to the business office, most homemakers will agree after the annual bout with income taxes. Mrs. Doris Anderson, New Jersey Extension Service specialist in home management, suggests that spring housecleaning also applies to the well-stuffed desk drawer.
President Eisenhower will fly to New York Monday to address a luncheon at the annual meeting of The Associated Press in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
A German anti-poliomyelitis vaccine has been on the market since February with the approval of state authorities in West Germany, it became known here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Following is the text of the address by Dr. Robert M. Hutchins today before the American Society of Newspaper Editors:
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $31,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
UTRECHT, the Netherlands, April 21 (AP) -- Richard Miles of New York, nine-time United States table tennis titleholder, bowed tonight in the second round of the world singles championship.
THERE are not many lutes, or lutanists, around in this Atom Era, and you'd probably wander the world without running into a lute maker. The instrument lost ground after the Elizabethan Period.

An investor has bought 1237 Broadway, a sixteen-story and penthouse showroom and manufacturing building at Thirtieth Street, from the Girbran Holding Corporation in a deal negotiated by Byrne. Bowman Forshay, brokers.
The reactivation of Circle in the Square, shut down by the Fire Department in March of last year because of inadequate safety precautions, looms as a distinct possibility.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 21 -- Egypt's efforts to increase her cotton sales to Communist China may lead to consular or diplomatic recognition of Peiping, according to Maj. Salah Salem, Egyptian Minister of National Guidance and Sudan Affairs.

LONDON, April 21 -- Top level Labor party leaders called on Harold Macmillan, Foreign Secretary, today to urge the British Government to conclude a defense pact with Israel. They proposed an accord similar to those in force between Britain and several Arab states.

A cook's tour of country kitchens of representative houses in Greenwich, Conn., will be held under the auspices of the Hortulus Club of Greenwich on the afternoons of May 17 and 18. Proceeds will aid the Greenwich Hospital in constructing and furnishing a diet kitchen on the new fourth floor of the hospital.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins returned from Saigon today for consultations on the future of the tottering Government of South Vietnam. He said the situation there was "serious" but declined to term it critical.
The problem of assuring equitable distribution of the anti-poliomyelitis vaccine "has become too big for voluntary or local effort alone," City Health Commissioner Leona...

Elmer Rice, the playwright, urged students yesterday to "feel free to speak, courageously and honestly," because "this is the only way we can change the current climate of opinion in this country." He spoke at a City College rally opening Academic Freedom Week, a series of debates, discussions and forums on academic freedom.

THE fourth Artur Schnabel Memorial Concert was presented last night in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. From nearly every aspect the program was one to bring nostalgia to admirers of the late German pianist.

I hasten to point out to you several flaws I immediately detected while reading the experimental report card illustrated in The Times of April 16. Alongside "Work Habits" we are informed that Arleen Maiorani is "ready for works," and that she "works with sustained."
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- Pete Runnels' ninth-inning single broke up a pitchers' duel today and gave the Washington Senators a 1-0 triumph over the Boston Red Sox.
The stake of hundreds of American communities in this country's flourishing export trade with Venezuela was given dollar-and-cents emphasis yesterday.
POINT ARGUELLO, Calif., April 21 (UP) -- The Swedish motorship Parramatta collided before dawn today with the fifty-foot yawl Suomi off Point Arguello. Five or six persons were lost.
A thousand persons paid tribute last night to the Rev. Dr. David de Sola Pool, rabbi of Congregation Shearith Israel, the oldest in America, on the occasion of his seventieth birthday.
Investments by Americans in mutual funds in the first quarter sent the assets of such funds to record levels.

MOSCOW, April 21 -- As an alternative to New York the Soviet Union has proposed Geneva or London as the site for negotiations with Japan on "normalizing relations between countries." The Government of Premier Ichiro Hatoyama originally had proposed New York, but the Soviet Union recently demurred and suggested that discussions take place in either Moscow or Tokyo.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Following is the text of a statement given today to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by former President Herbert Hoover:
The Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad sold a new issue of mortgage bonds yesterday as part of a refunding operation aimed at placing $22,840,000 of the carrier's debt on a lower interest cost basis.

THORSHAVN, Faeroe Islands, Denmark, April 21 (AP) -- Three thousand islanders revolted today when officials tried to remove the doctor of Bordo Island. A crowd on the wharf beat the police chief, shoved the officials back aboard their ship and cut the lines.

Raymond Chandler, originator of the fictional detective Philip Marlowe, received an "Edgar" last night from the Mystery Writers of America. The award, a ceramic bust of Edgar Allen Poe, was recognition of Mr. Chandler's "The Long Goodbye" as the "best mystery novel" published in this country last year.
Reports of the passing of the American family appear to be greatly exaggerated.
The close economic, political and cultural associations between the United States and Brazil were underscored last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
LONDON, April 21 -- British scientific authorities have urged their colleagues in India as "a matter of urgency" to support the export of monkeys for polio vaccine manufacture.

The National Dairy Products Corporation had the best first quarter results in its history, according to the preliminary figures disclosed yesterday before a record attendance of stockholders at the thirty-first annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel here.
Six months of daylight saving time will start here on Sunday with the annual two-timing operation that robs the clock of sixty minutes but gives the sun a bigger audience.

The Daughters of the American Revolution are about as reliable an organization as we have. They are good and patriotic ladies, we are certain, each and every one descended from a person who took a respectable part in the Revolutionary War, and they never get together without displaying an amount and degree of antediluvian prejudice that, even after many seasons, astounds the thoughtful observer.

The name of the All American Homemaker of Tomorrow was announced last night at a dinner in Philadelphia. The dinner, held at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel, was attended by all the excitement and publicity that usually goes with the conferring of titles on young women in this country.
PANAMA, April 21 -- A former news editor of the London Communist paper, The Daily Worker, said today communism would succeed only to the extent that Christianity failed.

BANDUNG, Friday, April 22 (AP) -- Delegates reported that Premier Chou of Red China, in the committee meeting today, replied to Sir John Kotelawala that he (Mr. Chou) had not come to the conference to discuss ideology because that was not the meeting's purpose.

Events tonight: Caribbean Calypso Concert, Carnegie Hall; Friendly Sons of St. Patrick Glee Club, Town Hall; Helen Bullis, cellist, Carnegie Recital Hall, and American Symphony of New York, Hunter College Auditorium, all at 8:30.

Harold E. Stassen, special assistant to the President for disarmament warned yesterday against the danger of thinking that the United States could promote peace by scrapping its own most powerful bombs.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senator William E. Jenner and Edward Corsi staged a shouting match at a Senate hearing today.

LANDAU, Germany, April 21 (AP) -- Six German S.S. (Elite Guard) troopers were shot to death by United States forces after they had been captured in the closing days of World War II, German state authorities said today.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- At his conference, Mr. Wolfson said: "When this thing is over we expect to take legal action against Avery. He's a director of the Pure Oil Company, which sells oil in competition with Ward's."

SEATTLE, April 21 (AP) -- The Methodist Council of Bishops today installed Bishop Clare Purcell of Birmingham, Ala., as president, and elected Bishop W. Earl Ledden of Syracuse, N. Y., as president-designate.
JERUSALEM, April 21 -- Israel rejects a proposal for joint patrols composed of Egyptian, Israeli and United Nations vehicles along the Gaza strip.

ALBANY, April 21 (AP) -- Governor Harriman today announced he had vetoed a bill that would have compelled the New York City Transit Authority to allow any employe "the right to select a representative of his own choosing" on grievances.

The city established yesterday eight Jonas E. Salk Scholarships of $3,500 each to be awarded annually to two outstanding seniors in each of its four colleges. The grants will be for postgraduate study in medical science.
LONDON, April 21 -- Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, and Harold Macmillan, British Foreign Secretary, discussed today the Western powers' schedule on a four-power meeting.
The National Jewish Welfare Board named yesterday three winners of the board's 1955 Frank L. Weil Awards.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Herbert Hoover urged today that the United States stay in the United Nations even though that organization "has not fulfilled all our hopes."
The City of New York has received $1,299,025 in a four-day sale of tax-delinquent realty on Staten Island. At the closing session yesterday buyers paid $417,325 for 199 parcels containing 431 lots.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The United States reopened today the question of what the Soviet Union had done with sixteen leaders of the Polish underground whom it arrested in World War II.

ARBOIS, France, April 14 -- According to leaders of the trade, France faces a "wine crisis." To meet it in the Jura region an energetic young man of this town has introduced what the French call -- not necessarily with approval -- American methods.
Thanks to a rally near the close, securities on the New York Stock Exchange managed to show a small gain in The New York Times' average yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- A $20,000,000 credit to be used for the purchase of American equipment for Italian metal working, chemical, automotive and other industrial concerns was extended today by the Export-Import Bank of Washington to the Instituto Mobiliare Italiano.
One million, one hundred thousand customers of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York in this area face a possible increase of 10 cents a month in their minimum rates for gas.

Seventeen leading New York banks have lifted to a new high their loans to brokers and dealers on non-Government securities. In the week ended on Wednesday these loans rose $65,000,000 to $1,820,000,000, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Minnie Moocher and Sometime Thing engaged in a thrilling race at Jamaica yesterday, with the former carrying the silks of C. V. Whitney to victory. She returned $5.30 for $2.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., accused the Association of American Ship Owners yesterday of "blowing through the wrong end of the horn," in suggesting that the union be responsible for the dispositions of its members.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 21 -- Governor Harriman opened today a drive to re-elect Herbert H. Lehman to a second full term as United States Senator next year.

BAYONNE, N. J., April 21 -- A rapid transit system connecting northern New Jersey communities with Manhattan was proposed here today by Alexander H. Elder, member of the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Atomic Energy Commission overrode today the advice of the General Accounting Office. By a majority vote, the commission approved the hiring of Ebasco Services, Inc., to supervise construction of the Dixon-Yates private power plant.

Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by Federated Department Stores, Inc., in its annual report covering the fiscal year ended Jan. 29. The large retail chain, which includes Abraham Straus and Bloomingdale's of this city, showed a net income of $19,091,636, an increase of 40 per cent over the $13,888,484 earned in the preceding fiscal year.
PARIS, April 21 -- Jean Sainteny, French delegate to North Vietnam, is in Paris awaiting a decision on his plans for coexistence with the Communist regime in northern Indochina.

AS the single new work of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Ballet Theatre last night presented David Lichine's "The Sphinx," to music of Henri Sauguet and with setting and costumes by Christian Berard.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, April 21 -- Swedish and Swiss members of the neutral commission overseeing the Korean armistice reported today there were "serious reasons" to believe that the Communist version of an air battle between United States and Red jets two months ago was "in contradiction with the truth."
PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- The New York Herald Tribune won today permanent possession of the third F. Wayland Ayer Cup for excellence in typography, make - up and printing.
ALBANY, April 21 (AP) -- Governor Harriman vetoed today a bill that would have required New York City schools to admit kindergarten and first-grade pupils twice a year instead of annually.
Abraham Straus, Brooklyn's oldest department store, celebrated its ninetieth anniversary yesterday by making gifts of $25,000 each to Pratt Institute and Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.

LONDON, April 21 -- The stock market was unsettled today by renewed talk of a rise in money rates. British Government bonds lost up to 13/16 point ($2.27 1/2) on f100 ($280) units, and many industrial shares lost about a shilling (14 cents).

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Strength in the cash wheat markets at Minneapolis and Kansas City and bullish crop advices from the Southwest induced buying of wheat futures today. Yesterday's advances were extended in some deliveries.

NEWARK, April 21 -- The echo of last year's proxy fight for control of the New York Central Railroad was heard in today's hearing on the proposed abandonment of passenger service on the road's West Shore division.
AN exhibition opening today at the Cooper Union Museum truly glitters. What is not gold are precious stones.
The Panama liner Panama has been reinstated as a passenger vessel after one month's service as a straight cargo carrier.
Cotton futures rose 10 to 26 points (50 cents to $1.30 a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The May position showed the most strength.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins told the American Society of Newspaper Editors today that newspaper monopolies were a menace to freedom of the press as guaranteed by the First Amendment to the Constitution.
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Appropriation of $25,000,000 by Congress to support the United Nations Technical Assistance Program from July 1, 1955 to Dec. 31, 1956, was urged yesterday by Christian Action. This is a group of Protestants organized nationally on a volunteer basis.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 21 -- Avra M. Warren, United States Ambassador, left today for Washington. He will confer with Administration officials and members of Congress on Turkey's request for additional economic aid.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson declared today that it was taking the Government "just too long" to launch a shipbuilding program.

In your editorial of April 18 you state, in speaking of issues at the Bandung conference, "There * * * is the possibility that some of the delegations would be so busy flogging a dead horse that they could not see a live tiger." The implication of your statement, in context, is that, compared to the aggressive, ominous threat of communism, the issue of colonialism is both minor and virtually, if not literally, dead.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Senator Lehman said tonight that he had not decided whether to seek re-election. He said he probably would not make up his mind until late 1956.
LONDON, April 21 -- Sir Anthony Eden was unanimously elected leader of the Conservative party today.

Mary Pickford, whose performances on the silent screen won her the sobriquet "America's Sweetheart," has turned her hand to the literary arts. She has written an account of her life and gives it the title "Sunshine and Shadow."
Joseph P. Hennessey, acting state director of civil defense, said yesterday that "Westchester County will not stop any authorized evacuation from New York City."

Tribute to the founders of The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, and the institution's fifty years of service was paid yesterday at a ceremony at The Lighthouse's headquarters, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

As unlikely a garden spot as one might expect to find in Manhattan has been rescued from possible extinction by neighbors who have been enjoying its beauties from their windows or through its fence. It is on Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, Friday, April 22 -- Soviet colonialism came under strong attack when the political committee of the Asian-African conference resumed its meetings here this morning.

ROME, April 21 -- "Porgy and Bess" came to Rome tonight and opened a three-week run. The George Gershwin-DuBose Heyward-Ira Gershwin operetta created a furor. It had just completed a triumphant tour of Italy.
The rumor of a liaison between Harry Bridges' West Coast longshoremen and the East Coast International Longshoremen's Association was put to rest yesterday by the latter's leadership.

The nation's paper industry is well on the way to another record production year. Indicated output for 1955 will be 27,500,000 to 28,000,000 tons, according to a forecast yester day by E. W. Tinker, executive vice president of the American Paper and Pulp Association.

Today's new film is "Bedevilled," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama in CinemaScope and color starring Anne Baxter and Steve Forrest, at the Palace. Henry Berman produced and Mitchell Leisen directed, from a story and screen play by Jo Eisinger.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- Edward O. Lamb, swore today that he never knowingly contributed money to the Communist party or Communist causes "at any time."
Noel Coward expects to star in some of his own plays next fall over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
Net assets of the four mutual fund groups in United Funds, Inc., reached a new high of $212,715,050 on March 31. This was an increase of $82,366,043 over a year ago and $5,327,310 ever last Dec. 31.
In relation to the death of Professor Einstein, the following incident may interest some of your readers.
A GLANCE at the crystal ball, supplemented by reports from several Catskill streams, indicates that the fly fisherman should have his first interesting week-end of the season.

The Political Committee of the Asian-African conference at Bandung has approved a declaration, backed by a strange combination of Arab and Communist states, supporting "the rights of the Arab peoples in Palestine" and calling both for the implementation of the United Nations resolutions on Palestine and for a peaceful solution of the Palestine question.
MOSCOW, April 21 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party secretary, has reaffirmed that the Soviet European bloc intended to create a new military organization to oppose "German militarism."

BONN, Germany, April 21 -- The British Government has refused to follow the lead of the United States Government to hasten West Germany's sovereignty. A statement circu lated today by the British Information Services in Bonn said: "The British Government intends to deposit all four documents of ratification [of the Paris agreements] simultaneously.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21 -- In his testimony today in Washington, former President Hoover did not specify the six principal achievements with which he credited the United Nations. The following are generally considered, however, to be the major accomplishments of the organization in settling political disputes:
Shad, which to many epicures is the finest flavored of the herring family, is nearing the peak of its all too short season. Increased supplies have decreased prices.
The six-story building at 2187 Holland Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by J. T. Corporation to Yetty Silberberg for cash over mortgages of $199,576.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -- Clark Gable will go to work his summer for Russ-Field Productions as star of the Western, Last Man on Wagon Mound."
Many prominent persons are patrons for the Four House Party to be given this afternoon at the St. Regis Roof.

SUMMER TAN won the world's richest horse race at Garden State on the last Saturday of last October. The next day he was returned to Belmont Park. The following morning he was galloped. That afternoon a hurry call went out for the veterinarians. Summer Tan was a mighty sick colt. Parasitic worms had entered his bloodstream and they came perilously close to killing him.

The first serious inroads on the Administration's reciprocal trade- extension bill (H. R. 1) have now been made by the Senate Finance Committee, and there may be more to come before the measure is reported to the floor. What will happen when the Senate as a whole starts to debate this bill is anybody's guess.

The Louisiana State Building Authority announced yesterday plans for the sale of $9,900,000 of bonds dated June 1, 1955 and maturing serially on June 1 from 1960 to 1984. The Authority was set up in 1952 to construct, improve, remodel, furnish and equip educational, charitable, correctional and penal institutions.
BERLIN, April 21 -- There were two indications tonight that the Communists might be seeking to lessen tension in Berlin.

The Association for the Help of Retarded Children, Inc., 323 Fourth Avenue, has received an allocation of almost $250,000 from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for the development of rehabilitation techniques for mentally retarded adults.
The National Association for Mental Health has issued "safety signs" to help you prove (to yourself, at least) that you are still sane.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare today held two important conferences preliminary to tomorrow's parley on the Salk polio vaccine supply.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The House of Representatives voted today for a $1,317,000,000 naval building program. The vote was 372 to 3.

The Aluminum Company of America in the first quarter this year more than doubled the earnings for the period a year ago with a net income of $17,074,167. In the initial three months of 1954 the net was $8,372,105.

It was the Yankees' turn yesterday to feel jubilant over their big off-season deal with the Orioles. Bob Turley, the principal New York acquisition in the eighteen-player transaction with Baltimore last November, pitched the Bombers to a 14-2 victory over his former team-mates at the Stadium.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (UP) -- The Soviet Union agreed today to return to the United States sixty-two more small naval craft it had received under the $11,000,000,000 World War II Lend-Lease program.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., April 21 -- The tenth anniversary of the beginning of fluoridation of water here was celebrated today.
Republican leaders in New York are almost unanimous in appraising Edward Corsi's immigration policy dispute with the State Department as a party setback.

HOUSTON, April 21 (AP) -- Bernard Bartzen, the national clay courts champion, upset an American Davis Cup player, Hamilton Richardson, in straight sets today. The winner advanced to the semi-finals of the twenty-first annual River Oaks tennis tournament.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly yesterday. Coffee, rubber, wool and zinc rose; cocoa, hides and burlap declined, and tin, lead, silk, copper, potatoes and cottonseed oil ended mixed.

DECATUR, Ala., April 21 -- A public school improvement program that has provided modern, functional and uncrowded classrooms for all Decatur pupils will be celebrated in special ceremonies here tomorrow.

ITHACA, N. Y., April 21 -- Some couples quarrel to pep life up a bit, some because they have the quarreling habit and enjoy it. The fights that really spell trouble are those that by their bitterness reveal that husband and wife have forgotten how to speak each other's language.
Henry Morales, 7 years old, likes to play with money. At school yesterday he had quite a time with $3,940.
The Kips Bay Boys Club celebrated last night the fortieth anniversary of its founding with a dinner dance in the grand ballroom of the Plaza.

LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., April 21 -- Officials of the strike-bound Sperry Gyroscope Company say they plan to open for operations tomorrow in spite of the violence that forced a shutdown of their three plants this afternoon.
Michael J. Quill warned Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner yesterday that a collapse of wage negotiations with the Transit Authority might lead to a "complete breakdown in transit operations."
MONTREAL, April 21 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens won three positions on the National Hockey League's 1954-55 all-star team today. The champion Detroit Red Wings placed only one man.

A GOOD children's show in television is hard to come by. Lest the nation's tots grow blase about the importance of box tops, sponsors and networks are inclined to stick to their own electronic Pablum -- Western movies, space operas, puppets and inane clowns.

The idea of establishing in Manhattan an international merchandising mart, or shopping center, where foreign goods would be displayed to buyers for American stores has been discussed for about a year by officials of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. Now it has received the blessing of the Commerce Department in Washington, and further meetings are proposed to advance plans.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Walter P. Reuther accused the Eisenhower Administration today of promoting "economic stagnation" by opposing what he called a reasonable minimum wage.

BOSTON, April 21 -- With production soaring, General Motors Corporation established new peaks in sales, net income and average weekly wage payments in the first quarter of 1955, Harlow H. Curtice, president, reported today.
Six new slum-clearance projects costing altogether $210,000,000 received the go-ahead signal from the Board of Estimate yesterday.
DETROIT, April 21 (UP) -- George Kell hit a grand-slam home run today to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 9-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

BUENOS AIRES, April 21 -- Bishop Froilan Ferreira Reinafe of La Rioja has excommunicated the editor of an Argentine daily newspaper for his "campaign of libel and insults" against the Roman Catholic Church.
Persons seeking a career in advertising were urged last night by Robert Watson, president of Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., to first develop selling ability.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, retired, today received the Army's Certificate of Appreciation for "outstanding patriotic civilian service."
RABAT, French Morocco, April 17 -- Moroccan Jews have been migrating to Israel rapidly in recent months.

The first local conference in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's nation-wide program to tighten safeguards against bank robberies will be held May 4 at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street.

As one of the many organizations represented at hearings before License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey in opposition to an application for a license to operate a burlesque show in a Brooklyn theatre we are gratified that Mr. McCaffrey has denied the license.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 21 (UP) -- A Federal jury convicted Junius I Scales of Carrboro, N. C., tonight of belonging to the Communist party, knowing that it advocated violent overthrow of the Government. Scales is party leader in the Carolinas.
BOCA RATON, Fla., April 21 -- Except for "normal fluctuations," general business conditions are good "and from all indications will continue to be good," an advertising leader said here today.
VOLOS, Greece, April 21 -- Mayor George Kartalis said today that of 10,000 houses in Volos not one was left undamaged by earthquakes the last three days. Nine of ten houses were no longer usable.

PITTSBURGH, April 21 -- Giant hopes of recouping their early season losses at the expense of the lowly Pirates resulted in a complete washout today. Rain, which had terminated last night's encounter after three innings, also caused a postponement of the series' finale.

There are any number of things which have been invented for no apparent purpose beyond encouraging women to bedevil men. Some of these are big, some are small, and since the whole list has a feminine kind of perversity, the smaller the things, the more trying.
Contract negotiations covering this port's 750 scow captains were still deadlocked at 2:30 A. M. today, but hope was expressed that the strike called for 7 A. M. could be averted.
Herman Pilnik of Argentina tied Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia yesterday for first place in the jubilee chess tournament at Buenos Aires.
The undefeated Dodgers put a new entry in the record books at Ebbets Field yesterday and only 3,874 fans paid to see them do it.
The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy, designed as a permanent Shakespeare theatre in this country, will begin its first season at Stratford, Conn., on Tuesday evening, July 12.
President Eisenhower stated the case for our continued assistance to those who can make use of it in the fewest possible words in his message to Congress when he said:

VIRGINIA, BEACH, Va., April 21 (AP) -- John Serafin of Fox Hills, Pa., and Ted Kroll of Utica, N. Y., carded five-under-par 64's today to tie for the first-round ead in the $17,500 Virginia Beach open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Efforts were made here today to spike speculation that President Eisenhower was trying to persuade Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to yield Matsu and Quemoy.

PARIS, April 22--Antoine Pinay, French Foreign Minister, announced today that France would deposit her instruments of ratification of the Paris accords May 5. He made this statement on his return from London talks with Sir Anthony Eden and Harold Macmillan, the new British Foreign Secretary.
An agreement reached at dawn yesterday headed off a strike of 750 scow captains only an hour before the deadline for the walkout.
Clarence Henry, 27-year-old former heavyweight boxer, pleaded guilty on Feb. 23 to an indictment charging him with having offered a $15,000 bribe to another fighter, it was learned yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 22--Officers of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company testified today that the projected natural gas pipeline across the beltline of Westchester County would possess safety features in excess of all national codes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : It is regrettable that a humanitarian contribution of the magnitude of the polio vaccine, which should stand as a tribute to the ingenuity and industry of American medicine, is being used instead to make political capital for the ambitious and to besmirch the good name of the practitioners of medicine.

The last week was another busy one for anyone with anything to say about atomic energy. Practically all of the many annual meetings of electric utilities brought out regional predictions as to the imminence of atom-powered generating stations.

Frank Boucher resigned yesterday as manager of the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League. Murray Patrick, who had been serving as coach of the sextet, was named to the manager's post by Brig. Gen. John Reed Kilpatrick.

The President's budget for the fiscal year 1956 contains substantial sums for the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics. The appropriation asked includes $63,500,000 for the operating expenses of the N. A. C. A. and $13,300,000 for construction and equipment.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : It is sad and exasperating that our Government has once again created a propaganda victory for Russia in its refusal to waive the fingerprinting requirements for the visiting Soviet editors. In spite of previously admitted "oversights" in the enforcement of this requirement the State Department apparently decided to use this occasion to show its toughness.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 22-- Hal Bales paid the highest straight price at Roosevelt Raceway this season after taking the fourth race tonight. His return was $78.90 for $2.

WASHINGTON, April 22--The Federal Reserve Board acted anew tonight to restrain speculation in the stock market. It raised margin requirements from 60 to 70 per cent effective when the exchanges reopen Monday morning.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 21--At the invitation of the United States, delegates to the forthcoming atoms-for-peace parley in Geneva are to have a chance to touch off a nuclear chain reaction.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- An airmail subsidy famine took shape today.

RANGOON, Burma, April 16 --The Burmese army is engaged in major operations against two groups of anti - Government forces. It hopes to break the backbone of the rebel movements before the monsoon season.
More money will be spent by American business this year for new plants and equipment than in any previous year, according to the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Dixon-Yates utility group asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to approve plans for borrowing up to $120,000,000. The money would be borrowed from two New York insurance companies and twentyfour banks.
ALBANY, April 22--Governor Harriman named Edward Corsi today to a reactivated State Committee on Refugees.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) --The Senate Republican Policy Committee today supplied all G. O. P. Senators with a document criticizing Americans for Democratic Action.
A woman, archaeologist whose eyes have "become saturated with antiquities" has found windowshopping along Fifth Avenue to be "a good cure."

MILWAUKEE, April 22 (AP)-- Brooks Lawrence, a St. Louis right-hander, fired a five-hitter at Milwaukee tonight as the Cardinals triumphed, 2--1, to tie the Braves for second place in the National League.
CARROLLTON, Ga., April 22 (AP)--Betsy Rawls gained the lead in the $5,000 Carrollton women's open golf tournament today with a record round of 67-- five under par.

THE school of symbolic realism in contemporary American painting boasts no more finished artist than Jared French, a retrospective showing of whose paintings and drawings is now being held at the Hewitt Gallery, 29 East Sixty-fifth Street.

HOUSTON, April 22 (AP)-- Tony Trabert continued the hottest winning pace in tournament tennis and Dick Savitt added more polish to his once-a-year comeback today in the twentyfirst annual River Oaks invitation event.

EN ROUTE TO EUROPE, April 22--So far the Bandung conference seems to have helped our cause in Africa and Asia more than we had expected. It has not proved the anticipated boon to Communist propaganda. And the issue of colonialism which friends of the Soviet Union had hoped to exploit has now been thrown back in their faces.
MOSCOW, April 9--In recent months, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Moscow has begun to hold news conferences.

Jamaica's top springtime horse race, the $100,000 added Wood Memorial, is to be run today. It should be a dilly. If the entrants run the way they have done in the past, it should be a two-horse dilly.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, Saturday, April 23--The Asian-African Conference has bogged down today in search of a definition of colonialism acceptable to Communist China, stanchly anti-Communist Turkey and all the shades of opinion in between.
LONDON, April 22--The British Medical Association has placed its seal of approval on the use of hypnotism in certain cases in medical practice.

CHICAGO, April 22--Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, assailed today the "myth which alleges that the Democratic party is against business." He made this prediction: "We are certain that in 1956 more business men will evidence their belief that Democratic policies benefit them more than do those of the Republican party."

It will be no use tomorrow morning to urge Time to turn backward in her flight, as requested by the late Elizabeth Akers Allen in a once well-known song. Time is going to turn forward, not backward, at the stroke of 2 A. M. In other words, so the experts say, at 2 tomorrow morning it will be 3 tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Federal Government for the first time has effective machinery for obtaining compliance with the nondiscrimination provision in Government contracts.
ST. ETIENNE, France, April 19--The St. Etienne basin, one of the oldest of French industrial regions, is about to undergo a transformation.
CLEVELAND, April 22 (AP)-- Cleveland's Indians scored five runs on three hits, two walks and an error in the third inning tonight and beat the Detroit Tigers, 8--5.
The chapel of Christ Church, Methodist, was the scene yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Beverly Brady and Clyde Danforth Knapp. The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman performed the ceremony.
Residential properties in scattered sections of Manhattan passed to investors in deal reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 22--Louis E. Wolfson conceded today he had lost the battle for control of Montgomery Ward Co. to its chairman, 82-year-old Sewell Avery.

Myron Zobel, world traveler, author, lecturer and producer, was bitten some time ago by the trailer bug. He didn't want just an ordinary trailer; nothing but "the biggest, most sumptuous and deluxe caravan on wheels" would do."

Attorneys for the Sperry Gyroscope Company and a striking union agreed yesterday to accept a mediation offer from State Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey. As a first step, Justice Levey signed a formal consent injunction barring violence and limiting picketing at the company's Lake Success plant.

The Western Powers have promptly notified the Soviet Government that they welcome the possibility of concluding the long-delayed Austrian treaty and will be pleased to participate at the earliest possible moment in a Big Four Foreign Ministers conference, for that purpose.

CHICAGO, April 22 (UP)-- Lloyd Merriman hit a seventhinning double with the bases loaded today to give the Chicago Cubs a 6-3 victory over the Redlegs and eliminate a protest of the game by the Chicago manager, Stan Hack.

This has not been the best of all possible years for the ranchers of the southern portion of the old Dust Bowl region. The Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles, eastern New Mexico, eastern Colorado and southwestern Kansas have had less rain than usual and there has been trouble accordingly.

PANAMA, April 22--Under the guidance of Roman Catholic missionaries, cooperative and credit union movements are making major gains in the Caribbean area.
To the delight of young pupils, toys as well as textbooks are becoming standard equipment in science classes in many elementary schools.
WASHINGTON, April 22--The Western Big Three invited the Soviet Union today to begin negotiations toward an Austrian settlement in Vienna May 2.
PARIS, April 21--The study of the integration of air defense of West Europe has produced a divergence of views between Britain and France.

The marketing of substantial new issues of corporate debt securities this week has brought about a visible shrinkage in the backlog of new issues of bonds and preferred stocks for which definite offering dates have been set.

CHICAGO, April 22--BorgWarner Corporation stockholders were told at their annual meeting today that the company had established a definite program to acquire other companies that fit into its business pattern.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (UP)--Del Ennis hit his first home run of the season with two men on bases in the ninth inning tonight to lift the Philadelphia Phillies to a 5-4 victory over the Pirates. Pittsburgh suffered its seventh defeat in seven games.
Billy Brown is a quiet, unobtrusive man of 54. He sits in a modest office in Madison Square Garden surrounded by memorabilia of his days as one of the leading featherweight boxers of the nation.
DETROIT, April 22--State and Federal mediators were seeking today to resolve a dispute that might interfere with the production of the antipoliomyelitis vaccine.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 -- Officers and crew men of the Swedish motorship Parramatta refused to testify today at a Coast Guard investigation of yesterday's collision of the freighter and a yacht off Point Arguello.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 22--The Syrian Government has told the United Nations that partition of demilitarized zones along the Syrian-Israeli frontier "could be considered" under certain circumstances.

WASHINGTON, April 22-- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 110.3 per cent of the 1947-49 average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. A drop of more than 2 per cent in average prices for farm products was the principal reason for the decline, as the index for all commodities other than farm products and foods advanced fractionally.

BOCA RATON, Fla., April 22 --This country's business men must sell an extra $40,000,000,000 worth of goods and services in 1955-56 to keep the national economy moving upward, Arno H. Johnson, vice president and director of research of J. Walter Thompson Company, asserted today.
THOSE who are unswayed by improved angling on fresh and salt water and are inclined toward a noisier form of outdoor activity, will be interested in the new "Official Gun Book," just off the presses.
Several economic and psychological factors strengthen the viewpoint that major depressions will not recur, Leon H. Keyserling said last night.
Niagara Falls cruise ships, known to millions of travelers and honeymooners burned in a drydock at Niagara Falls, Ont., today.

A meeting in Tokyo next month of business leaders from forty countries will direct important new efforts toward solution of Far Eastern economic problems, the head of the United States delegation declared yesterday.

Treated sewage discharged into Raritan Bay from a proposed new treatment plant in New Jersey would be a "serious menace" to Staten Island's south shore beaches, according to Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen.

One of the most important elections of this year in the Western Hemisphere is due at the beginning of October and it is already casting a long shadow ahead. Brazil must choose her President and Vice President for the coming five years and the choice will mean much to all Americans, North and South.

A Roman Catholic chapel on wheels rolled into the city yesterday, completing a 700-mile trip from Edenton, S. C. The Most Rev. Vincent S. Waters, Bishop of Raleigh, N. C., who designed and accompanied the vehicle, said it was his answer to assertions that religion was old-fashioned and not in keeping with modern developments.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- George Meany called upon the government today to "stop beating about the bush on the Quemony and Matsu issue."
THORSHAVN, Faeroe Islands, April 22 (AP)--Defiant Bordo Islanders braced tonight for a fight against a Danish police expeditionary force.

The increase in margin requirements did not surprise Wall Street executives. In recent weeks, the rise in stock prices and securities loans has continued unabated in the face of developments that normally might be expected to put a damper on bullish sentiment.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Administration accepted tonight a recommendation that it create a national advisory committee on state-by-state allocations of Salk polio vaccine.
NOT in many a long day has there been so good a performance of Antony Tudor's "Jardin aux Lilas" as that presented last night by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House.
Two children from Georgia became stockholders yesterday and the New York Stock Exchange staged a celebration of the event.

The body of a murdered man was found by the State Police early yesterday beside State Route 210, south of Monroe, in Orange County. There was at least one bullet wound in the head of the victim, whose body was still warm when found.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points lower to 3 points higher yesterday. There was a moderate volume of business.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The White House refused today to let Maxwell M. Rabb tell the Senate his role in bringing Edward Corsi to Washington.
Perambulator pushers may soon be sporting baby buggies styled like junior-sized Jaguars.
LONDON, April 22--Stocks declined sharply today as fears grew of another rise in the bank rate.

WASHINGTON, April 22--Official Washington has recovered from its apprehensions over the Asian-African conference at Bandung. The meeting is being assessed as a useful exercise in international relations, rather than as a disaster for the West, which many senior officials feared it would be.
Columbia University has accepted an invitation to send two representatives to the 200th anniversary celebration of Moscow University, May 7-15.
It took the appearance of several detectives and fingerprint experts to convince a prominent attorney yesterday that his home had been robbed, while he was in it.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 22--Representative Adam Clayton Powell said today that the United States would lose its friends in Asia if it continued to stand aloof on questions of world colonialism.
