WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) --House Democrats cited the Formosa crisis today in support of their charges that President Eisenhower made a "serious mistake" in ordering a reduction in military manpower.
BALTIMORE, April 22 (UP)-- The Washington Senators used five pitchers tonight to subdue the Baltimore Orioles, 3--2. Four of the hurlers were in action in a hectic seventh inning.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., April 22--Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson, Cherry Valley, carded a 40. 41--81 to win low gross in the Women's Cross County Golf Association one-day tournament at Wheatley Hills today. Mrs. R. A. Ernst, Plandome, was second with 39. 44--83.
A statue of Jose Bonifacio de Andrada e Silva, father of Brazilian independence, was unveiled in Bryant Park yesterday. Orators hailed the event as symbolic of Brazilian-United States amity.

Alpha Portland Cement Stockholders of the Alpha Portland Cement Company at the annual meeting yesterday in Easton, Pa., approved an increase in the authorized common shares and a three-for-one split of the issued stock.

LONDON, April 22 -- British Government officials were reported today to be discussing a temporary guarantee of a line of demarcation between Formosa and the Chinese mainland. The guarantee would be given if the Quemoy and Matsu Islands were evacuated by the Chinese Nationalists.
Fund-raising dinners are netting New York's major political parties at least $1,100,000 this year, according to a conservative estimate made yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 --"One Way Out" is the title of the first picture Frank Sinatra will make through his own independent company, Oxford Productions.
AMMAN, Jordan, April 22-- Lieut, Gen. John Bagot Glubb, Chief of Staff of the Arab Legion, suggested today two prerequisites for any peace talks between Jordan and Israel.

The Yankees, behind Whitey Ford's second straight shutout pitching job, downed the Boston Red Sox, 3--0, yesterday at the Stadium. Although the Bombers moved into a triple tie for second place, it was a costly victory.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- The Consumer Price Index for the United States is setting records for stability.
ATLANTA, April 22 (UP)-- Striking rail and communications workers faced identical showdown dates with the Southern Governors Conference tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) --The Daughters of the American Revolution ended their sixty-fourth Continental Congress today disappointed that President Eisenhower had not appeared.
In the depression year of 1894, a young man from Saginaw, Mich., received a law degree at the University of Michigan. He never practiced.
WASHINGTON, April 22--On behalf of the Navy, three physicists obtained this week a patent covering a practical use for cosmic rays, the mysterious radiation from outer space.

Many or the finest school systems in the country are to be found in the suburban New York area. These systems did not just happen to achieve eminence. MANHASSET, L. I., April 22 -- Fifth-grade pupils of Munsey Park School today planted fifty sturdy rose bushes that had been flown in from Sofia, Bulgaria. The bushes create a memory garden to honor their late teacher, Mrs. Angelina Kisselincheff, who died last year when they were her fourth-grade pupils.
The national board of the Young Women's Christian Association recommended yesterday that all its local groups check their inter-racial practices against their inter-racial policies.
ALBANY, April 22--Governor Harriman signed today a bill designed to strengthen the state's hand against stock frauds.

The six-story building containing sixty apartments at 1041 Sherman Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Leo Bercow and Walter Berger, operators, to Daisy and Lillian Fine, clients of Glaser Glaser, attorneys, who negotiated the sale.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) --A Senate Investigation of delays in a big defense ship building program ended today. There were assurances that a major bottleneck had been passed. Congress itself was criticized for part of the delay.
CHICAGO, April 21--Weekend profit taking by longs put pressure on the wheat market in the early trade today, but declines were moderate, and in the late trade May showed relative strength.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 22 (AP)--Atlantic Coast Line Railroad and attorneys for various bondholders started two new moves in Federal District Court yesterday in the protracted legal battle for control of the Florida East Coast Railway.

The ten-game Dodger winning streak was relegated to the realm of happy Flatbush memories last night. The Giants, twice previously victims of the Brooks at the Polo Grounds, snapped the string, 5--4, in a fogshrouded thriller witnessed by 27,297 spectators at Ebbets Field.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, April 22 (AP)--Harry Hirschkowitz of New York reached the fifth round of the world table tennis championships today. A former United States champion, John Somael of New York, bowed to Ichiro Ogimura of Japan, the defending world titleholder.
WASHINGTON, April 22-- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt suggested today that this was not the time to attempt revision of the United Nations Charter.

FAVERSHAM, England, April 22--The B. P. Haulier, the first British tanker to be fitted with the unorthodox Voith Schneider propeller, was launched here today at the yards of James Pollock Sons Co.
PARIS, April 22--The head of Tunisia's dominant political party said tonight the first task of self-governing Tunisia would be election of a constituent assembly.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- President Eisenhower received a briefing today from Gen. J. Lawton Collins on the deepening political crisis in South Vietnam.
BUFFALO, April 22 (UP)--A New York City Water Department official asserted here today that he "would like the people to know what risks they are exposed to" in using fluoridetreated water.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) --Taxpayer and public affairs groups told Congress today that Federal aid to education was unnecessary and an encroachment on local responsibility.

"Phoenix '55," a new revue, will have its premiere tonight at 8 o'clock at the Phoenix Theatre, Second Avenue and Twelfth Street.

FEZ, Morocco, April 22--The French Government is about to buy out the Compagnie Marocaine de Radio-Television of Casablanca. In doing so it will bring to an end the first French experiment in commercial television.

Potato prices fluctuated sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange However the May positions, which accounted for almost all the volume, closed the 1/4 -cent-a-pound daily limit higher. Final quotations were unchanged to up 25 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,764 car lots.

St. Francis Prep and Boys High shared the honors yesterday as the two-day Queens-Iona Relays began at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. A quartet from each of the Brooklyn schools captured a major test.

FRITZ HENLE'S photographs of people and places in the West Indies have opened a new gallery at Modernage Custom Darkrooms, Inc., Room 847, 480 Lexington Avenue. The show runs to May 31, 9 A. M. to 6 P. M. weekdays.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is progressively replacing the home office buildings it has occupied for many years at Madison Square with modern structures. Over the years the company's expanding plant has taken up the two blocks bounded by Madison and Fourth Avenues, Twenty-third and Twenty-fifth Streets.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) --Prof. Owen Lattimore said today he had completed plans for an extensive European lecture tour, contingent upon the State Department's granting him permission to leave the country.

TOKYO. WITHOUT doubt, the most beautiful, possibly even the most talented, export shipped out in a long time by the gentlemen of Japan is a 32-year-old motion-picture actress named Machiko Kyo, who has been uncompromisingly referred to by one critic as "the Theda Bara of Medieval Japan," and who, only six years ago, in the finest Broadway tradition, was dancing in a Tokyo burlesque house.

LONDON, April 23 (Reuters) --Results of soccer and Rugby games in Britain today: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division Arsenal 2. Manchester United 3. Burnley 0. Sunderland 1. Cardiff City 1. Portsmouth 1 (draw).

Reflecting favorable first-quarter earnings reports and business forecasts, the stock market advanced last week to new high levels since October, 1929. It works out this way: Even without changing the clocks, there has been an increasing period of daylight.
TOKYO, April 23--Japan has decided to ask the Soviet Union to agree to hold peace talks in London in June.

"PEOPLE sit around the saucepan while boiling, and eat taking what they want out of the saucepan and putting it on small dishes. The good point of this is that we can eat it hot, watch it cooking, and feel happy sitting around a saucepan and eat, looking at the food boiling."
Two salesmen did such an outstanding job of "selling" themselves while drumming up orders for tractors and sausages that last week they became the presidents of two leading companies.

Library THIRTY-FIVE years ago--it was 1920 on the nose--the American Library in Paris was founded. Plain American folks who dwelt in that most fragrant of capitals, through their need, desire and inspiration, started it off by managing an endowment from the American Library Association and a gift of books from the American Expeditionary Forces Library.

THE five million tourists who visit the nation's capital each year have long needed a good, lively travel book about Washington to reduce its monumental splendor to more human terms. In "Washington Holiday," Eleanor Early has made a valiant but not wholly successful effort to meet this need.
LITTLE FALLS, N. Y., April 23 (AP)--Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, predicted tonight that a Democrat would be elected President next year.

DIELDRIN-- Dieldrin protects wool against moths and outlasts other insecticides, such as DDT, after repeated washings and dry cleanings. This is the conclusion reached by experimenters M. Lipson and R. J. Hope of the Wool Textile Research Laboratory in Geelong, Australia, and reported in Nature.

To the Drama Editor: May I offer a few opinions on the subject of art and government which your critic discussed so lucidly recently? It it a field in which I have grased these many years and although I have come upon some pretty rough stubble, I still optimistically believe that art and government can be made to mix in this country, given the proper mixer.

BALTIMORE, April 23 (AP)-- Right-hander Harry Byrd blanked the Washington Senators on three scattered singles today as the Baltimore Orioles won, 3-0, for their second victory in ten American League starts.
Goodwill Industries, Inc., which provides employment and training for handicapped men and women, will benefit from two tours of New York homes, on Tuesday and May 3.

TOKYO. THE traditional Japanese influence remains undeniably strong in the Western - style painting's of modern Japanese artists. The two streams of modern Japanese painting are criss crossing each other.

WILLIE MAYS, a superbly muscled and astonishingly well-coordinated athlete, is without doubt one of the most engaging young men hired in recent years to play baseball in the major leagues. He is given neither to blaguing umpires nor to clubhouse lawyering, but simply to playing outstanding baseball and to lightening the frightful burdens of his fellow New York Giants through his innocent diversions and playful wiles.

VIENNA, April 23--A Government spokesman indicated today Austria would ask to be relieved of the military restrictions now in the original draft of a state treaty. This means that she would be permitted to have an army of such strength as she saw fit.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 23 -- Chou En-lai seemed today to have the support of many of the delegates at the Asian-African conference in his bid for negotiations with the United States.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, April 23--This seemed to be the day for assurances by Chou En-lai, Communist China's premier, and his Vietminh Communist colleague to all their neighbors and sometime antagonists at the Asian-African conference here.
MOSCOW, April 23--Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin implied early today that any meeting between himself and President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Eden depended not on him but on them.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., April 23--Scientific warfare against disease by strategy deliberately plotted in research laboratories was envisioned today by a Nobel prize-winning chemist.

TAIPEI, Formosa, April 23-- Since the Chinese Nationalists' retreat to this island in 1949-50 the war with the Communists has been like a shadow-play small events magnified larger than life on the United States screen.

To the Music Editor: S. K. Pearson's letter of April 3 lamenting the decline in local performance of Wagnerian opera was prematurely answered on the previous day's opera broadcast on which Rudolf Bing cited the forces working against an extensive Wagner repertory at the Metropolitan.
Coats of 100 per cent cashmere to retail at less than $100 are a feature of advance showings of fall lines, according to the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

Walter T. Shirley, land developer, announced plans yesterday for erecting factory-built homes in his development at Shirley, L. I., near Patchogue. A franchise agreement has been made with National Corporation of Lafayette, Ind.

CITIZENS of the country's four largest cities, New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and Philadelphia, will all have have outdoor symphony concerts again this summer. Details of the events scheduled for the four major series give an impression of similar ingredients mixed in somewhat different proportions.
MADRID. ALEXANDER THE GREAT, himself a globe-trotter and intellectual, would be pleased to know that his film life is in cosmopolitan, scholarly hands.
DR. FRANCES HORWICH, the amiable lady who amuses and enlightens toddlers and waddlers who watch "Ding Dong School," has a new job.

MINIATURE slide projectors in several new models were recently placed on the market to meet the needs of a growing host of color enthusiasts. Most of them are supplied with automatic slide-changing apparatus.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23--The Pennsylvania crew won the Childs Cup in its opening race of the season today. Leading almost throughout the Henley distance of a mile and five sixteenths, Joe Burk's varsity eight led home Princeton and Columbia on the Schuylkill.

ROME--As soon as it gets warm, Italy embarks again on her two yearly crusades -- one against flies and the other against noise. According to an antiquated joke the anti-fly battle was won, in Naples at least, by "them"--the flies, that is.

IT doesn't take long for birds, even in spring, to find a bird bath in any garden. And it will be the busiest place on the property on a midsummer day. Then there will be a continual flying about of birds awaiting their chance to drink and bathe.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., April 23--The successors to Washington's Continentals fought a new battle today in this historic Raritan River Valley. The First Army clashed with an imaginary aggressor here in its second annual tactical map maneuver.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 23 --Next Tuesday's atomic blast here probably will be the biggest one witnessed by public representatives in the five years of Nevada tests.

IT is nearly sixty years since Henry George died of a stroke on the eve of a New York City election in which, as an independent Democrat, he was seeking the office of Mayor. His doctors had warned that campaigning would kill him, but he felt that "so dying will do more for the cause" than anything he could accomplish in a few more years of life.
LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., April 23--The strike-bound Sperry Gyroscope Company announced today it would reopen on Monday for non-striking employes.

BOCA RATON, Fla., April 23 --To do no more than build a fortress of steel around this country would actually help the Communist cause, Robert B. Anderson, Deputy Secretary of Defense, declared here today.

LET us not malign savage tribes. Within their patterns they cultivate wisdom; they are in a state of growth. It is civilized beings who revert to savagery that are indefensible. Primitive art has its dignity and aspiration, but the cult resulting from the modern imitation of it is already at a dead end.

ZOYSIA grasses have already proved their great merit for southern lawns. In areas south of the transition zone, which runs roughly from Delaware and Maryland west to St. Louis, Mo., zoysias are almost miracle grasses.

WASHINGTON, April 23-- Two mammoth contestants, the railroads and the trucking interests, which have been spoiling for a showdown for the last ten years, appeared ready to enter the legislative ring this week on the heels of a report by President Eisenhower's Cabinet Committee on Transportation.
Carrying swords against gold epaulettes of colorful uniforms, the Old Guard of the City of New York paraded yesterday afternoon at City Hall. It marked the organization's 129th anniversary.

IN March the Federal Reserve index on industrial production reached its highest point since August, 1953. On the basis of current figures for automobile and steel production, it seems likely that the March figure will be exceeded in April.

A tract of forty-four acres on the west side of Route 17 in Ridgewood, N. J., has been purchased by John M. Gabriel for development with seventy-five dwellings. The land, purchased through Walstrum, Gordon Forman, brokers, includes thirtyeight acres of the Hall estate formerly owned by Arlington C. Hall, financier.

TO THE EDITOR: THE review of Edward Weyer's book, "Jungle Quest," by Victor Wolfgang von Hagen contains a dangerous implication concerning the mentality of primitive peoples which should be corrected, along with several of his statements regarding the mental level of the Camayura Indians of Brazil.

"PARTY OF ONE" is, among all incredible things, Clifton Fadiman's first book. Editor, essayist, reviewer, lecturer, reader, quizmaster, radio conversationalist and assorted trade jack, he never before has appeared between hard covers, all by himself.
The first Techbuilt house on Long Island is being opened today in Mill Neck. It is designed with flexible layout which permits the building to "grow" with the family.

AN intensive course of instruction for purchasers of new, high-powered cars before they take to the road is urged as a safety measure by the traffic committee of the Twenty-third Street Association, 175 Fifth Avenue.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., April 23--The Oceanographic Institution's research vessel Caryn has returned to Woods Hole after a three-month cruise in the West Indies.

St. John's University's baseball team remained undefeated in Metropolitan Conference competition with a 7-2 victory over City College at Dexter Park Woodhaven, Queens, yesterday. The Redmen are in first places in the loop with four triumphs.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23-- The Delaware River Port Authority is looking into the possibility of acquiring the TaconyPalmyra Bridge, tearing it down and building a new one within a mile of the present site.

President Eisenhower will address the fifty-fifth annual luncheon of The Associated Press at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tomorrow afternoon. His speech will be the major event of the annual Press Week meetings, at which 1,300 editors, publishers and executives of United State and Canadian newspapers will attend.

Dr. Tom Spies, head of the Department of nutrition in Northwestern University and the nutrition clinic of Hillman Hospital, Birmingham, Ala., long a leader in practically applying the discoveries in nutrition that have been made in the laboratory, has been invited to edit an entire issue of Postgraduate Medicine.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 --Harvard crews scored a sweep on the Charles today. As dusk was settling over the river, the Crimson varsity came through with an impressive triumph against Syracuse, Boston University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 23--Politics, tolls and thruways are threatening to defeat Westchester's plans for modernizing its outmoded parkways.
Industry's recruiting of engineers at Columbia University has broken four records so far this year.
Fred Maytag 2d aims to bring $100,000,000 into Iowa this year by easing the chores of the American housewife.
The indictment recently of the promoters of a food freezer club here brings into focus an industry that has had a stormy career.
Premier T. C. Douglas of the Province of Saskatchewan yesterday urged the Western nations to export "social democracy rather than free enterprise" to the backward peoples of Asia.

TO THE EDITOR: Chester Bowles' illuminating and provocative "Memo: On Our Policy in Asia" (April 10) is, in my opinion, a realistic and concise summation of the pitfalls besetting the Administration in its attempt to work out a foreign policy in Asia.
CHICAGO, April 23 (UP)-- Warren Hacker and Jim Davis shut out the Cincinnati Redlega on five hits today. Their pitching enabled the Chicago Cubs to gain a 1-0 victory.

The first batch of mail sent from a Canadian cruiser on a three-month Pacific training cruise included eleven house keys. Naval headquarters reported that eleven seamen forgot to leave the keys with their wives when they left port.

TO THE EDITOR: Harry Schwartz in "Troyanovsky Fils" (April 3), about Oleg Troyanovsky, the former Soviet ambassador's son who is now a top Kremlin translator, answered a question that has often occurred to many of us who attended high school with him: how has he fared through the various purges that have changed the face of Soviet government over the past six teen years?

CLEVELAND, April 23 (UP)-- Billy Hoeft shut out the Cleveland Indians on three hits today to pitch his first victory of the season for the Detroit Tigers, 3-0. Although it was cold, 6,737 saw the game, which also was Detroit's first victory over Cleveland in four starts.
The Moscow newspaper Izvestia has received a barbed reply to an appeal to New York dressmakers to join Soviet workers in a world peace petition.

PUCCINI'S La Rondine, which has just made its LP debut in a Columbia Entre recording (two disks), adds further weight to the argument that, in operatic literature, there is no such thing as a neglected masterpiece.

A MODIFIED form of automation is creeping into the nation's traffic law enforcement agencies, the latest convert to electronics being New York City, which has just announced that within a few weeks its police will begin pursuing motorists by radar.

DETROIT, April 23--In Michigan's industrial belt and other auto assembly areas of the nation passenger cars, have been rolling off production lines in record numbers. Auto sales are setting records, payrolls are up and weekly earnings of auto workers are at highest levels.

WASHINGTON -- Now that I have been properly put in my place by a bipartisan phalanx led by Senator Ralph E. Flanders (Republican of Vermont) and Gov. Averell Harriman (Democrat of New York) I return to the wars in behalf of the superiority of Western scenery over that of the Eastern states.
Pending Federal legislation was discussed yesterday by Governor Harriman with Senator Herbert H. Lehman and thirteen of the state's seventeen Democratic Representatives in Congress.
Managers of four public housing projects have succeeded in reducing maintenance costs by obtaining tenant cooperation in keeping the grounds clean.

The writer of the following letter is the United States Ambassador to Finland. TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The accolade given under the heading "Acorns or Dragon's Teeth?" by your newspaper in a March 26 editorial to the largely unpublicized but highly commendable endeavor of a volunteer organization known as "Operation Town Affiliations, Inc."

READERS of Leslie Fiedler's writings in the little magazines during the past half decade or so may well have wondered whether this brilliant young writer would make his book-length debut in fiction, poetry or the essay, for his lively talent encompasses all these genres.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 23 (AP)--Mrs. M. G. Walsh's Rhythminhim, running last until he completed the seventh hurdle, stormed in front at the last obstacle today and ran away from the field in the stretch to win the two-mile Mary Mellon Steeplechase.
A major military realignment in Europe will be the inevitable result of an Austrian treaty.
WEST POINT, N. Y., April 23 --The University of Alabama defeated Wilkes College of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., in the finals today of the ninth annual West Point Invitational Debate Tournament.
WASHINGTON, April 23-- Business it not what it used to be back in 1954, fortunately for everyone.

IT has been Handel's fate as a composer to have a few of his works played too much and the rest not enough. One that has been played perhaps too often is The Water Music. But the LP manufacturers, have found a way to give it a new lease on life.

WHEN there is nothing much, doing that is news at the United Nations Buildings on the Manhattan side of the East River, there may still be quite a lot going on. The meetings of the Assembly, or the occasional dramatic sessions of the Security Council, make the front pages and lead the radio bulletins.

NEWELL JENKINS is an American musician who has made a career for himself by cultivating some one else's garden. Through his interest in a relatively neglected area of the repertory, he fired the enthusiasm of a group of Italian instrumentalists.
